title: Factory Orders Up 1.8% in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)New orders received by factories increased 1.8 percent last month to $128.3 billion, mainly because of gains in building materials and electrical machinery, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NATO WARNS SOVIET ITS MOVES IN AFRICA ENDANGER DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON. May 31The leaders of the Atlantic alliance responded today to President Carter's concern about Soviet and Cuban military activity in Africa by cautioning Moscow that such actions endangered dtente and cannot but jeopardize the further improvement of EastWest relations.

title: 5 Soldiers killed in Car Crash
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C., May 31 (UPI)Five soldiers were killed and two other persons were injured in a threecar accident early today on the military installation, officials said. A military spokesman declined to release the names of the dead soldiers pending notification of relatives.

title: Tully, Tax Chief, Says He May Run For State Comptroller Nomination
description: James H. Tully Jr., the New York State Tax Commissioner, said yesterday that he would run for the Democratic nomination for State Comptroller, but that he would be pleased to step aside if Mario M. Cuomo would make the race.

title: WiMam Purtell 81; Served in the Senate From 1952 to 1959
description: William A. Purtell, a Republican businessman who served as a United States Senator from Connecticut from 1952 to 1959. died yesterday at his home in West Hartford. Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: High Court Bars Newspaper Plea Against Search
description: WASHINGTON, MaY 31The Supreme Court ruled today that newspapers do not have any special right to warning of a courtapproved search by law enforcement officers or an opportunity to contest such a search in the courts before it occurs.

title: The Hurricane Buildsin Cost
description: WHERE the budgets of their movies are concerned, producers tend to round figures off to the nearest million. The Hurricane, says Dino De Laurentiis, its producer, was originally budgeted at $15 million, is currently budgeted at $17 million, and will cost S20 million.

title: River Cleanup That Attracted Bid Crowd in '70 Falters in '78
description: HACKENSACK, May 3  Ecological eian which ran so high in Bergen County eight years ago that upward of 2,000 people turned out over four successive Saturdays to help Girl Scouts clear away 60 truckloads of trash and debris from a fourmile stretch of the Hackensack River. has apparently dissipated.

title: House Committee Recommends Funds for Clinch River Reactor
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)Thc House Appropriations Committee recommended today that work on the Clinch River breeder reactor project in Tennessee be financed in the 1979 fiscal year despite President Carter's opposition.

title: PRICES IN APRIL ROSE BY 0,970, LED BY BEEF; BIGGEST GAIN IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 31Consumer prices rose by ninetenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest monthly increase in more than a year, largely reflecting a record 6.6 percent jump in the price of beef, the Government reported today. The figures mean that inflation is again running at a doubledigit annual rate.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration, citing inflation and the trade deficit, warns industrial allies the United States cannot afford to help stimulate world economic growth. Stimulus is the objective of the economic summit scheduled for July. [131.]

title: Merger Is Completed
description: Automation Industries Inc. has become a subsidiary of the General Cable Corporation, the two companies said gesterday, Terms of the deal called for tutinnation shareholders to receive $20 a share, or about $101 million, for the 5,068,302 shares outstanding.

title: United Press International
description: SHAKEN BUT UNHURT was a witness's description of Britain's Prince Charles after a man threw a lemonade bottle at his car on a trip through industrial area around Newcastle uponTyne, England, The man was arrested.

title: School Aides in Essex Are Cleared In Educational Malpractice Suit
description: NEWARK. May 31Five school officials and two physicians were cleared today of negligence in an unusual educational malpractice suit brought by the parents of a former student, Thomas A. McNeil. The parents contended that their son had been awarded a high school diploma despite a secondgrade reading aptitude.

title: Anker Toughens Pupil Promotions
description: In a policy change that could affect thousands of public school students, the New York City School Chancellor, Irving Anker, says he intends to require that any student with poor reading and mathematics scores be kept back any number of times in his elementary, intermediate er junior high school class.

title: Endive Made Simple
description: THE French endives that appear in the produce markets in fall, resembling small blanched heads of cos lettuce, are so expensive that they are usually reserved for special occasions  to make an elegant salad or to serve braised in butter.

title: Disks: Mozart's Mitridate
description: OF MOZART'S 19 completed stage works, only five or six can be said to hold places in the international repertory. The reason usually adduced for this neglect is that the genre known as opera seria, with its stylized formality and emphasis on vocal pyrotechnics, went out or fashion in Mozart's later years, taking into near oblivion most of his operatic output. And so, we rarely hear of, let alone hear, Lucio Si11a, Ascanio in Alba or Mitridate, while such masterpieces of the opera seria tradition as La Clemenza di Tito and Idomeneo are ignored by our major opera houses in favor of the feeble efforts of Giordano and Massenet.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 31 (AP)About 2,500 students rioted at Teheran University early today, smashing windows and wrecking furniture, the authorities reported.

title: Former NBC Sports Executive Joins CBS
description: Carl Lindemann Jr., who for 15 years had been an influential vice president of sports at NBCTV until little more tan a year ago, will join CBS Sports today as a vice president in charge of programs.

title: Shops Must Now Post Warning on Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reuters)Starting tomorrow, all stores in the nation that sell foods containing saccharin must post notices stating that the artificial sweetener may be a health hazard.

title: Deaths
description: UDELL  Sophie. The Officers Trustees and Staff of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York rem in mourning the loss of one of the truly great figures in Jewish philanthropy. For over three decades she helped to shape, with compassion and understanding, the pioneermg programs of the Jewish Child Care Association, as an Agency Vice President and as Chairman and member of numerous Board committees. She was particularly devoted to the Agencies roster Home Prowand and served over ten years as Charmian et the FosterHome Corn mittee. In 1975, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York awarded her the Naomi & Howard LehmanMemorial Award for significant contribution to the welfare Of children. Before becoming a Trustee of the Jewish Child Care Association. Mrs. Udell had been a Board Member of the Foster Home bureau. Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, one of four organizatrans which merged to form the present Association Her contributions to the care & treatment of neglected and troubled children are beyond measure. We who had the privilege of serving with her in this great work were ourselves enriched by our asso ciation with hits beautiful and dere. cated woman. We extend to her bereaved husband, Jerome, her children & prandchildren. our profound sympathies.

title: BID BY LORIS ES 3 NEW YORK HOTELS
description: PHILADELPHIA. May 31The Loews Corporation won a highstakes bidding contest against a group of foreign investors in a Federal court. here today to buy three major Manhattan hotel; from the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: Notes on People
description: AFIRST cousin of Queen Elizabeth II received her consent yesterday, at a formal meeting of the Privy Council, to marry divorcee. In receiving permission to marry Baroness MarieChristine von Raebnitz, Prince Michael of Kent. 35 years old and Nth in line to succeed the Queen, renounced his rights to the throne. Permission to marry the baroness, a 33yearold interior designer who was born in Germany, was obligatory under the Royal Marriages Act of 1772, and it completed church and state ceremony of almost Ruritanian complexity. We are terribly happy, said the Prince, a brother of the Duke of Kent. It has been a long wait. The marriage will take place in July in Vienna, where the brides family, prominent in the European aristocracy, has an estate. The 33yearold baroness was married for four years to an English merchant banker.

title: TALKING BUSINESS GasPricing Bill Appraised
description: Last week, after morn than six months of exacting negotiations, Senate and House energy conferees finally agreed to legislation on pricing natural gas. Perhaps inevitably, the compromise bill (which still requires approval by the full House and Senate) has drawn intense fire from industry leaders and consumer spokesmen alike.

title: Two Officials of Port Authority Indicted in ExpenseAccount Case
description: John Tillman, the former director of public affairs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey who admitted last year that he had systematically padded his expense account, was indicted yesterday on criminal charges of defrauding the authority of more than $1,500.

title: N.B.A. Rivals Resting After Overtime Sizzler
description: SEATTLE, May 31In proving their wisdom and experience, both coaches gave their players today off after last night's overtime game in which the Washington Bullets, making up a 15point deficit, defeated the Seattle SuperSonics, 120116, and tied the National Basketball Association championship series at two games each.

title: In the City, a Night on the Nile
description: TUTANKHAMEN did his bit for charity last night. The Egyptian boy king's treasures, currently touring the country and expected at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in December, inspired a Night on the Nile party to benefit the American Cancer Society.

title: Skateboard Ban in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN (Reuters)A bill banning the use of skateboards in public places in Denmark 1335 been approved overwhelmingly qt s final readipg In Paella'slam It forb:cis tivrn virtually everywhere except on closed tracks.

title: About New York
description: Barefooted and facing away from the urban pueblos of Coop City, the 10speedbike couple carry their bicycles onto the beach and feel yesterday's warmth in the morning sand.

title: NORMAN S. PAUL DIES; HELD MANY U.S. POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Norman Stark Paul, Under Secretary of the Air Force in the Johnson Administration. dird here yesterday of cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: The Guggenheim Estate: Opulence Past
description: SANDS POINT, L.I. T sits on a cliff overlooking Long Island Sound, a Normanstyle brick manor with turrets, steep slate roofs, dormers, casement windows and a cobblestone entrance courtyard that leads the visitor into another world.

title: HAROLD R. WESTON
description: Harold R. Weston, who retired in 1974 as assistant vice president in charge of tour planning and marketing for Thomas Cook & Son Inc., the travel agency, 311 Fifth Avenue, died Monday in New York Hospital after a lingering illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 311 East 50th Street.

title: Defense Urges Separate Hearing On Validity of Tests for Curare
description: HACKENSACK May 31The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, challenging the prosecution's contention that curare killed the alleged victims, filed a motion today requesting a separate hearing on the scientific validity of any discovery of the powerful musclerelaxing drug in the exhumed bodies.

title: Superior Oil Cancels Deal With Hecla
description: The Superior Oil Company said yesterday that it had withdrawn a $53 million offer to buy some 5 million new but unissued shares of the Hecla Mining Company over a fiveyear period.

title: Greece and Turkey Agree Cyprus Accord Is Urgent
description: WASHINGTON. May 31The Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey agreed today, in separate conferences with President Carter, on the urgent need to resolve the Cyprus problem and rebuild the southern flank of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Pop: Hagood Hardy
description: THE last time Hagood Hardy, Canadian vibraharpist who has played with George Shearing and Herbie Mann, was in New Yorkeight years agohe was leading a group in which he was supported by two women vocalists and bass and drums.

title: Legislators Seeking Ways Around Limit Set on Local Taxes
description: ALBANY, May 31With the deadline for its report to Governor Carey a day away, a special legislative  executive panel met today in a search for ways to solve the problem created by a decision barring localities from taxing above constitutional limits.

title: The New Poor
description: WASHINGTONIf you are making more money now than you ever made before, but inflation and the tax bracket creep have reduced the pur. chasing power of your takehome pay, then you are a member of The New Poor.

title: Stolen Collier Air Trophy Is Found in Park
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)The Collier Trophy, America's oldest aviation award, was found undamaged by a maintenance man in a suburban Maryland park today, 26 hours after it was reported tolen from a Washington hotel.

title: Golda Wit. Dubious on Sadat Visit
description: TEL AVIV, May 31Former Prime Minister Golda Meir said tonight she was under the impression President Sadat had made his visit to Jerusalem last November after he had been told he would be offered all of Sinai on a silver platter.

title: A Correction
description: In a let ter from Andreas Lowenfeld published May 28 one line was inadvertently omitted, distorting the following sentence: But where express provision is made in a treaty for termination on a specified period of notice (one year in the case of the 1959 Defense Treaty), so that termination is the exercise of a right, it would be a major and I believe unsound  reversal of constitutional practice to require formal consent by the Senate to a notice of termination of a treaty.

title: ROBERT C. POLLOCK
description: Dr. Robert C. Pollock, a former associate professor of philosophy at Fordham University Graduate School who compiled the anthology The Mind of Pius XII. died luesdav in Doctors Hospital after a lingering illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 630 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken, N.J.

title: House Votes to Warn South Korea Of Aid Cut Unless Envoy Testifies
description: WASHINGTON, May 31Increasingly concerned about the progress of its investigation into South Korean influencebuying, the House of Representatives warned the Seoul Government today that it might cut off economic aid if former Ambassador Kim Dong Jo was not made available to testify.

title: Willianisburg Area Finally Wins Battle For a Fire Company
description: The People's Firehouse Committee in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn claimed a victory yesterday as Mayor Koch announced the reestablishment of an engine company that had fallen to the fiscalcrisis ax more than two and 1 half years ago.

title: $1.26 Billion Spent To Stabilize Dollar
description: The United States spent the equivalent of $1.26 billion to quell what it. considered to he disorderly conditions in international currency markets in the FebruaryApril quarter, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The total was down, but not by much, from a record SI.5 billion spent to support the flagging dollar in the previous threemonth period.

title: Dock Ellis and the Hotel Bar
description: Up to now, organized labor in baseball has debated the conventional issuesfree agents, option clauses, minimum salary, even meal money on road trips. But now something really important has surfaced, a gut issue that threatens the drinking habits of managers and players. Ever since Abner Doubleday had a beer alone in his general's tent after decreeing that the bases shall be 90 feet apart, many baseball managers have maintained a tradition that, when their teams are traveling, the hotel bar is the manager's bar. With this rule the manager always knows where the players will not be and the players always know where the manager will be  a social structure that surely has avoided some fights for the tab, if not some fights. But that tradition is now being challenged by Dock Ellis and other members of the Texas Rangers who, when touring other American League cities, prefer to drink where they live.

title: U.N. Extends Golan Force Mandate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31 (AP) The Security Council today approved a sixmonth extension of the 1,245member United Nations peacekeeping force separating troops of Syria and Israel on the Golan Heights.

title: U.S., Canada Reach Pollution Pact
description: CHICAGO, May 31Strengthening efforts to clean up the Great Lakes, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today a new agreement with Canada that would tighten pollution control guidelines and bring the entire Great. Lakes Basin under surveillance.

title: Vorster Hails West for Changes on Africa
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, May 31 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster today welcomed what he called changing Western attitudes toward Communist involvement in Africa, but he said the changes did not go far enough. He asked why the West continued to withhold weapons from South Africa, which he called the most stable state in Africa.

title: Tiny Tick Is Suspected as Carrier of Lyme Arthritis
description: An unusually tiny species of tick, common in coastal regions from Cape Cod to Florida, has been implicated as the carrier of Lyme arthritis, a disease first found in and around Lyme, Conn. in 1975.

The figures mean that inflation is again running at a doubledigit annual rate.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Reports on U.S. Economy Depress Dollar Anew
description: The dollar skidded yesterday against most major currencies in foreign exchange trading in Asia, Europe and North America after gloomy news about the United States trade deficit and rate of inflation, The Associated Press reported.

title: Film: Mizoguchi's 'A Geisha':A Rediscovery
description: TO the extent that any Japanese film directors can be well known in this country, Akira Kurosawa and Yasujiro Ozu have made it. Yet Kenji Mizoguchi, who died in 1958 and who may well be one of the greatest film makers of all time, remains relatively obscure, even to those audiences for whom such obscurity is usually a certification of honor.Kurosawa had the luck to make a couple of films that found comparatively large American audiences ("Rashomon," "Seven Samurai") while Ozu, though not as well known as Kurosawa, became something of a small fashion early in the decade with the release of many of his later films.To date, fewer than 10 Mizoguchi works have received commercial engagements in New York, and though each has been critically acclaimed, especially "Ugetsu," "Sansho The Bailiff" and "Utamaro and His Five Women," there's never been a continuing Mizoguchi audience. Every time we receive a new-old Mizoguchi, he must be rediscovered.Mizoguchi's "A Geisha," which is having its New York theatrical premiere today at the Film Forum, was made in 1953. Unlike most of the other Mizoguchis we've seen here, it is set in its own time, 1953, in Kyoto, though it shares with the director's period films the quality of being incredibly beautiful without being particularly, foolishly pretty.The story is about the friendship of two women, Miyoharu (Michiyo Korgure), an older geisha bound by a tradition that no longer holds, and Eiko (Ayako Wakao), a 16-year-old girl whom Miyoharu agrees to sponsor and train as a geisha after the death of Eiko's mother, a former geisha who'd been Miyoharu's friend???. Though Mizoguchi's film makes only two quick trips outside Kyoto's tea houses and geisha houses, the film is as much about the social revolution taking place in 1953 occupied Japan as it is about the emotional relationship between the two women.From the beginning, it's apparent that the young Eiko is not going to be a conventional, subservient geisha. After a class in which the teacher has told her pupils that the geisha is a work of art, like Noh drama and the tea ceremony, Eiko wonders whether the new Japanese constitution doesn't guarantee a geisha the right to say no to a patron. The other young women giggle, but Eiko is serious.It's evidence of the system of balances that always operate in a Mizoguchi film that as Eiko is wondering about the geisha's constitutional rights, the geisha's role is being corrupted. In postwar Japan, the geisha, who had once been a highly skilled entertainer, was being called upon with increasing frequency to perform the duties of the not necessarily skilled prostitute.It's a trend that the older Miyoharu resists, more or less passively, while Eiko does battle. When her would-be patron takes the two women on a trip to Tokyo, Eiko refuses to perform the duties she does in the teahouse. "I serve at parties," she says. "I'm a lady."This doesn't put off the man. He makes a lunge at her??? wrestles h???r to the floor, plants a big kiss on her mouth, to which Eiko responds by biting his lip so badly the fellow has to be hospitalized. Because of the scandal, the two women are blackballed by all of Kyoto's teahouses. Miyoharu is confused, worried, though she doesn't blame the younger woman. Says Eiko, in effect, "If that's what being a geisha means, then I don't want it."The charm of "A Geisha" is the compassionate but completely unsentimental way it regards the two women's friendship, as well as the manner in which this friendship changes and deepens as their responsibilities, each to the other are acknowledged. Miyoharu is much the more interesting of the two, but it is the younger Eiko who is more often right.Though the landscape of the film is restricted to a small, rather exotic quarter in Kyoto, "A Geisha" is far from esoteri???. The scope is narrow and the focus is deep.The two actresses who dominate the film are splendid, as are several other performers, especially Chieko Naniwa, who plays the not unkind but money-minded doyenne of Kyoto's geishas, and Eitaro Shindo, who plays Eiko's father."A Geisha" is actually a remake, being based on a film Mr. Mizoguchi made in 1936 that, to my knowledge, has never been released here, yet the 1953 version is far from being dated. One can say that the best, most intelligent film about women to be seen here in the last 12 months was a film made 25 years ago."A Geisha" will be screened at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 and next Thursday through Sunday at the same time.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: CLEVELAND MAYOR'S FOES DEALT SETBACK BY COURT
description: CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP)An appeals court today blocked the clerk of Cleveland's City Council from certifying petitions that would force Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich into a recall election.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Tviay 31.We are just spectators at this World Cup, but the next time, in 1982 in Spain, we hope to sec a United States team on the field, said Gene Edwards, president of the United States Soccer Federation.

They warned Moscow that such actions endangered detente and jeopardized further improvement of EastWest relations. But the final cor;munique of the twoday NATO meeting in Washington was modified to say that the leaders also stressed that such situations should not he viewed only in an EastWest context. title: A Ghost From the Past Banished From My Door
description: WHEN I knew him years ago in Greenwich Village, it was hard to tell whether he was witty or insane. He was one of the first in our crowd to collect pornography for philosophical reasons. He had a fanatical determination experience things that prevented him from feeling them. After a year of smoking marijuana almost daily, he announced that he had at last succeeded in getting high. Because he preferred to go out alone at night, he used to slip sleeping pills into his wife's afterdinner coffee.

title: Going out Guide
description: NEW STITCHES Pins and Needles is back. The famed musical of the 1930s, which the garment industry produced on Broadway for four years and later on tour, begins revival previews tonight at 8 prior to the Wednesday opening at Roundabout/Stage One, 333 West 23d Street. Tickets are $8.95 on weekdays and $9.95 on weekends, with reservations at 9247160.

title: Mexico Needs Soybeans
description: MEXICO CITY, May 31 (UPI)Mexico will have to import a million tons of soy beans during the 197879 harvest to cover its needs for cooking oil, according to estimates by the Confederation of Industrial Chambers, This would represent an outlay of $225 million, 40 percent more than spent during the previous season, the conference said.

title: Japan's TV Exports Off
description: TOKYO, May 31 (Reuters)Japanese color television exports to the United States fell by more than 60 percent last month as a result of Japan's agreement with the United States to curb exports of the product voluntarily for three years. Japanese manufacturers, who agreed to limit exports to the United States to 1.75 million sets year for three years from last July, exported 101,718 sets to the United States in April, a decline of 60.3 percent from April 1977, the Electronic Industries Association said. Over all, color television exports last month totaled 264,418 sets, down 38 percent from April 1977, the association said.

title: A Rockefeller Retreat Is for Salefor $1 Million
description: SEAL HARBOR, Me., May 27Nelson Rockefeller doesn't want it anymore, so you may as well buy it.

title: Parley on Zaire: Dealing With New Realities of AfricanWestern Ties
description: PARIS, May 31The hastily arranged Western meeting here next Monday to consider Zaire's fragile condition reflects two important conclusions on which the United States and France have agreed after much hesitation. One is that the major Western countries cannot ignore military and political instability in Africa, and that the Soviet Union can only benefit from deteriorating situations there, whether or not it actively helps to provoke trouble in sensitive areas.

title: S. E. C. Scrapping Accounting Rule
description: WASHINGTON. May 31The SecuriTiOS and Exclwnge Commission has backed away from a proposal that would have forced publicly held companies to divulge all the reasons for changing independent accountants.

description: LONDON, Thursday, June 1The Labor Government won a major electoral victory yesterday by defeating a spirited challenge from the Scottish Nationalist Party in the constituency where the Nationalist revival bezan 11 years ago.

title: Abraham Shuchman, 58, Professor
description: Abraham Shuchman, professor of marketing at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, died yesterday at Lydia Hall Hospital in Freeport, L.I. Mr. Shuchman, who lived at 28 Oxford Pine:, Rockville Centre, L.I., was 58 years old.

title: To Extradite Terrorists
description: The arrest by Yugoslav police of four suspected West German terrorists conies as welcome news for all societies whose openness and toleration make them targets for political violence. Now the Yugoslays should complete their good work by turning over the suspects to German authorities. Since 1975, Yugoslavia and West Germany have had a treaty providing for the prompt extradition of criminal offenders. The treaty does not cover political offenses; and politically motivated violence occupies an undefined middle ground. So the German authorities are asking the Yugoslays to regard their four prisoners us ordinary criminals; if the Germans can demonstrate that the four are wanted for acts of violence and not for unpopular views, the Yugoslays are likely to comply. The record of collaboration between the two count ties is good. he West Germans have either extradited or punished members of antiCommunist Croatian nationalist groups that have frequently attacked Yugoslav representatives abroad.

title: Of China's Leaders, Hua Ranks Higher but Teng Is Real Chief Executive
description: HONG KONG, May 30The stories may be apocryphal, but they suggest how some Chinese evidently feel about their leaders these days.

title: U.S. Says Many Reports by Agents Link Cubans to Zaire Invasion
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The White House sad today that its evidence linking Cuban forces to the recent invasion of Zaire by Katangan rebels was based on a consistent stream of agent reports from the area.

title: Easing the Pain of Hospital Costs
description: The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee will try again next week to approve a compromise bill to control runaway hospital costs. The bill is endorsed by the Carter Administration as a promising way to reduce the gluttony and obesity of American hospitals. But it is opposed by the hospitals as an unfair imposition of controls that will actually aggravate the problem, insuring the survival of the fattest. The issue is complicated, the lobbying intense. But the compromise is a reasonable, if flawed, way to hold down a major inflationary factor in the economy.

title: Allbritton Resigns as Publisher of Washington Star
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Joe L. Allbritton, the Texas millionaire who bought The Washington Star four years ago, saved it from bankruptcy and sold it to Time Inc. last February for $20 million, announced his immediate resignation today as the newspaper's publisher.

title: TV: Tourism in Africa and Caribbean
description: WORLD, the smashing in. ternational dOcumentary series from WGBHTV in Boston, takes a prow ocative look tonight at the tourist trade in several thirdworld countries of Africa and the Caribbean. Who Pays for Paradise? which can be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, is an unsettling combination of legitimate insights and creap shots, of justifiable anger and almost Puritanical primness.

title: Design Notebook
description: NINETYSIXTH STREET on the East Side has long served as a hinge in Manhattan's urban structure. South of it is Yorkville, traditionally a rich blend of Germans, Irish and various middle European nationalities. North of it is Harlem and Spanishspeaking El Barrio.

title: Irwin Shimron, 58, Israeli Lawyer; Led Inquiry Into Organized Crime
description: JERUSALEM, May 31 (AP)Irwin Shimron, a prominent Israeli lawyer who led an investigation into organized crime that shocked the nation, died today, apparently of a heart attack, the Israel radio reported. He was 5S years old. Mr. Shimron collapsed while visiting friends in Tel Aviv, the radio said.

title: Thomas Hayes Procter, at 93; Professor Emeritus at Wellesley
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 31 (AP)Thomas Hayes Procter, professor emeritus of philosphy at Wellesley College, died yesterday at NewtonWellesley Hospital after a brief illness. He was 93 years old.

title: For Carlos Moseley, a Coda
description: Carlos Moseley, president of the New York Philharmonic since 1970, is retiring today after an association of 23 years with the orchestra. Mr. Moseley, who is 63 years old, will continue with the Philharmonic Society on a volunteer basis as a vice chairman of its hoard of directors. His successor has not been announced.

title: Booksellers Talk Is Foreign
description: GLORGE G. GILMAN writes westerns that are published by New English Library Ltd. of London. He has already written 28 starring a cowboy named Edge. But Mr. Gilman, a typewriterbound British writer, has never been west of the Pecos or even east of the Pecos or, in fact, in the United States.

The robber also made off with a hat and suit belonging to the priest, the Rev. Martin Kelly, the police said.

title: Screen: 'Laserblast':Mother's Fault
description: A YOUNG MAN staggers out into the desert, wearing greenish-white makeup with black circles around his eyes and sporting a dangerous-looking gadget on his right arm. With the gadget, he begins blowing up cactuses. Just then, a spaceship arrives, and out step wo animated clay creaures, with long necks and pretty dark eyes, of the approximate vintage of Godzilla or Rodan. They nod and clap each oher on the back with their three-fingered tentacles. "Gleep," one remarks, approvingly.At first, this turns out to be a dream the young man is having later on in "Laserblast." It turns out to be actually happening. Never mind the fine points: All that matters is that we understand why the fellow is so given over to violent fantasies, and we do. It's his mother's fault. His mother, a swelte blonde who looks younger than he does, appears to be either a jet-setter or a stewardess, and she is neglecting her boy. Just as the film begins, she leaves town, announcing she's headed for Acapulco. "Mama, you've already been to Acapulco. How many times are you going to go?" the boy whines. "Till they stop asking me, sweetheart, "Mom replies, with a pretty little frown.Soon enough, the kid has gone to seed, and developed a big green sore on his chest, too. He blows up a dozen cars andrather amusinglyone "Star Wars" poster, using what the poster for "Laserblast" refers to as "The Force." This is a simple bit of equipment that could easily have become "The Toy" if the film seemed destined for hitdom. But it doesn't.Kim Milford, as the fellow whose fangs get longer every time he goes on a shooting spree, is a dull actor, but the cast also includes Gianni Russo, doing a very curious Clint Eastwood imitation, and Eddie Deezen, as the town creep. Mr. Deezen was very funny in the late, ???amented "I Wanna Hold Your Hand," as all 15 or 20 persons who saw that film at the Rivoli can attest."Laserblast" is playing at the Embassy 46th Street, where one man in the audience began yelling "Sex! Sex! Sex!" and "Meatball!" during the 11 A.M. show. The ushers conferred worriedly about this for a while. Much to the movie's credit, it eventually quieted him down."Laserblast" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains very brief nudity, one mild-mannered sex scene and a lot of explosions.

title: St. Louis Bank in London

LOUIS, May 31 (UPI)The Federal Reserve System has given the First National Bank in St. Louis permission to open a fullservice branchbanking operation in London, the bank announced today. Richard F. Ford, president and chief operating officer of First National, said that the bank would renovate its current London office into a branch, which should be operational before the end of the year. title: The Race Against Senator Case
description: Clifford Case may well be headed for a fifth term in the United States Senate, but one ambitious and able Democrat or another will offer a serious challenge in the fall. That seems to be the story of the New Jersey elections ahead. Mr. Case, a 74yearold liberal Republican, is challenged in next Tuesday's primary by a 34yearold conservative, Jeffrey Bell, a former aide in Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign. Mr. Bell has Deen promoting a tough, freemarket approach to all he nation's ills. He appears vigorous and intelligent, Jut he is probably too new on the scene to dislodge a 24year veteran who has been a reasonable and independnt voice on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee And in other matters.

title: Doing Something Useful for Africa
description: The United States should do something to counter the growing Soviet and Cuban penetration of Africa. That message reaches President Carter from all sides these days. Yet few who express their concern offer any specific suggestions. The President's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski has called for an international response, and Mr. Carter has only begun to define what that might be. As the clamor rises, others will be less cautious and some will inevitably call for either covert or overt military gestures.

title: Stage: Hey, Rube Tells of Ritual Killing
description: IN 1966, a 38yearold Indianapolis mother of seven was convicted of firstdegree murder in the torture slaying of Sylvia Likens, a 16yearold boarder in her home. Found guilty of lesser charges were the woman's accomplicesher own teenaged son and daughter and two neighborhood youths. The facts of the case are so horrendous as to seem unreal. In any attempt to understand the crime, perhaps a documentary is the most viable approach. Earlier this year, something of that nature was undertaken by Kate Millett in a mixedmedia art show.

title: Books of The Times
description: INFURIATED by America's war on Vietnam, Susan Sontag once wrote that the white race is the cancer of human history. She now regrets the metaphor. She is now as suspicious of disease metaphors as she used to be of hermeneutics (Against interpretation). And she regards cancer metaphors as especially pernicious, implicitly genocidal, cheap shots: Tt e people who have the real disease are  hardly helped by hearing their disease's name constantly being dropped as the epitome of evil. Only in the most limited sense is any historical event or problem like en illness. And the cancer metaphor is particularly crass. It is invariably an encouragement to simplify what is complex and an invitation to selfrighteousness, if not to fanaticism.

McClellan. Mr. Pryor received 35 percent of the votes in yesterday's extremely close primary election. title: Letters
description: I was greatly moved when I read Jill Robinson's column [Hers, May 18]. Her frank expos of the generally unrecognized prejudices that are felt against those of us who experience physical, emotional or mental afflictions brought rye, and I am sure a great many others, great relief. I wonder how many of us who read her article actually understood what she was saying and whether only those of us who have been subjected to the tyranny of the fit can understand.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: When an apartment's dining room has either disappeared entirely or been turned into an extra bedroom, what becomes of the diningroom table? Well, if folds up to be only nine inches wide when not in use, you could put it in the foyer, behind a couch or even a closet. But if it's in a highly lacquered red or black beige, chances are no one would want to hide it in closet. There is such a table, and it comes as either 60inch circle or a 60inch square in a choice of 11 colors (gray, burgundy and white among them) with polyurethane coating for sleekness, durability and easy care. When opened, the table can seat up to eight diners  if some of them don't mind straddling a leg. When just one side is folded down, the table can be used for intimate dinners or as a console. The round table is $2,250; the square, $2,150. Through decorators at Cy Mann Designs, 979 Third Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets.

title: Justice Stevens Dissent
description: Just as the witnesses who participate in an investigation or a trial far outnumber the defendants, the persons who possess evidence that may help to identify rn offender, or explain an aspect of a criminal transaction, far outnumber those who have custody of weapons or plunder.

title: Yasutaro Niizeki, Former President Of Japan's Mitsui Bussan, Dies at 81
description: TOKYO, May 31 (AP)Yasutaro Niizeki, former president of Japan's secondlargest trading company, Mitsui Bussan, died yesterday of pneumonia. He was 81 years old.

title: Q&A

description: FULLERTON, Calif.  Freeways, Brian Martin was saying one afternoon recently as he strode off the Amtrak train from Los Angeles, are just a bummer. I decided my mental health couldn't take it.

title: A.M.C. to Halt Building Standard Transit Buses
description: DETROIT, May 31 (AP) The American Motors Corporation will stop building standard urban transit buses in late June, A.M.C. said today in a surprise announcement.

title: Brazil Choice In World Cup
description: LONDON, May 31 (Reuters)Brazil was installed today as the 9.4 favorite to win soccer's World Cup beginning tomorrow in Argentina.

title: Zaire Court Dooms General for Fleeing Shaba Battlefield
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 31 (AP)A Zairian military court has sentenced the commander of Zairian troops in Nolwezi to death on charges of cowardice and having fled from the battlefield during the rebel invasion of the mining center earlier this month, the Government press agency said today. tie agency, known as Azap, said the court in Lubumbashi, the capital of Shaha Province, 150 miles southeast of Kolwezi, convicted the commander, who was identified only as Brig. Gen. Tshikeva, on Saturday. It did not announce a date for the execution.

title: U.S. Shuns 0.E.C.D. Growth Plan
description: PARIS, May 31The Carter Administration is warning its major trade partners that the United States cannot join in plans for coordinated stimulation of world economic growth.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW type of fiberglass screen mesh makes it possible to use window screens not only to keep out insects but also to screen out much of the sun's summer heat.

title: Big Board Reports on Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the Big Board.

title: Beaths
description: GOLDMAN Abraham The Officers and Employees of William B. Goldman Brothers, Inc. records with deep sorrow the passing of its beloved Officer and good friend.

title: Congress Is Accused of Laxity on C.I.A.'s Covert Activity
description: Some members of Congress and Washington officials are openly expressing concern about what they say are weaknesses in the Congressional control and monitoring of the Central lntalligence Agency's covert activities overseas.

title: Gleason Ill, Sly Fox Ends Tour in Chicago
description: A 40week, ninecity tour of the stage comedy Sly Fox, now at the Blackstone Theater in Chicago, has been terminated six months early because of the hospitalization of its star, Jackie Gleason, a spokesman for the production said here yesterday.

title: PRINTERS SAY PAPERS RENEGE ON CONTRACT
description: The president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, said yesterday that The New York Times and The Daily News had told him they had refused to give increases to printers under an existing contract because of their inability to pay.

title: DeCamp Bus Lines Contract Ends But Drivers Will Keep on Working
description: CLIFTON, May 31Drivers and mechanics at the DeCamp Bus Company, which carries 20,000 daily riders between VSsex County and New York City, will work at least temporarily without a contract, a union leader said today. The contract expired at midnight tonight.

title: TV Network Lifts World Cup Goal
description: This afternoon, West Germany, the defending champion, and Poland will kick off in Argentina the first elimination match of the 11th World Cup soccer championship, Before the champion is crowned on June 25, if things go as expected, more than a billion people around the world will have watched at least some of the games on television.

title: Emerald Bay Captures Jumper Title at Devon
description: DEVON, Pa., May 31Hereford Fasm's Emerald Bay won his third championship in three starts this year when he captured the intermediate jumper title today at the Devon Horse Show.

title: Gromyko and Vance Confer on Arms Amid Signs U.S. Is Slowing Pace Toward Accord
description: Amid signs that the Carter Administration was slowing the pace of negotiations on a new treaty limiting strategic arms, Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance conferred for five hours yesterday in New York without resolving the few remaining issues.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hamner
description: LET us consider dining rooms. You need not have one. Nor even want one. Gracious eating, the splendid ceremony of breaking bread communally, depends on the spirit, not on the room. We would be the last to suggest that a place set aside specifically for eating should enjoy any kind of priority in this spacestarved world  it could even be viewed as profligate.

title: 2 GENERALS BATTLE IN BANGLADESH VOTE
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 31This critically poor country is in the midst of a tumultuous election campaign that is testing the strict martiallaw rule of the last two and a half. years years.

title: Barbara Eddy Married To William McLanahan
description: In the chantry of Grace Episcopal Church yesterday, Barbara Edith Eddy, a staff assistant with the Rockefeller Family & Associates, was married to William Alexander McLanahan, an independent commodities broker. The Rev. Dr. Fitzsimmons Allison performed the ceremony.

title: Waiting for Godot Staged in Brooklyn
description: THE most necessary figure in Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot is Godot. True, he never appears; possibly he does not exist, but it is his failure to appear that is the most esential thing that happens in the play. It is the tragedy as well as the comedy of this great work that calls itself a tragicomedy.

title: Chrysler Offer's Yield Seen at 11.7%
description: The Chrysler Corporation's new 5150 million offering of preferred stock and warrants is expected to give investors an effective yield of about 11.70 percent, according to Wall Street's current estimates. The offering, which was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission on May 19, is expected to be offered formally in midJune.

title: New Data Show Birth Rate Down, Undercutting Talk of Baby Boom
description: WASHINGTON, May 31Widespread speculation that a new baby boom is in prospect has been undercut by the latest birth figures compiled by the Federal Government.

title: Trial of Penthouse for Obscenity Allowed by New Hampshire Court
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 31 (UPI)The New Hampshire Supreme Court has ruled that Penthouse magazine, its national distributor and Luv's Pharmacy can be tried in New Hampshire on obscenity charges and has sent the case back to a lower court for trial.

description: BUFFALO, May 31 (AP)Two susponded Buffalo police officers and another man were sentenced to maximum fouryear prison terms today in the beating death of Richard Long, 18 years old, of The sjspendcd policemen. Mop t G????Thlaglia, 31, and Gary M. Atli, 36 and third man, lack R. Giammaresi, a 30yearold tobacco salesman, were convicted of criminally negligent homicide in the case.

Beasley, former executive vice president for finance of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, was sentenced to four years in jail and fined $14,000 yesterday on charges of misusing a material portion of $493,000 obtained from an illegal, secret political slush fund established by the company.

Both accounts are designed as taxsheltered retirement accnamts fur individuals not covered by pension plans, in the case of IRA accounts, and for selfemployed persons or freelancers, in the case of Keogh plans.

The victim was identified as Todd Davis, of Sitka, Alaska. The National Park Service said 11 persons had been involved in avalanches on the mountain in 24 hours and warned against any further climbing until avalanche activity subsided.

That bygone and once benignly comfortable old landmark was long past its heyday by the time it changed hands, but under this new management it is possible that this address may again become a favorite stop for eaters.

description: WENOS AIRES. June 1 (AP)Pele rdlired soccer star, expressed disappointment with the scoreless tie between West. Germany and Poland in the openitT, came of the World Cup today.

description: The Federal Government is again in favor and tradition is once more being honored in this commencement season, further reflecting that the pendulum that swung so far to the left on the nation's campuses in the last decade is making a sweep back to the right.

title: Stocks Tied to Gambling Are Losers, While Change in Dow Is Minimal
description: Casinorelated stocks, which enjoyed a spectacular whirl on Wall Street last week, toppled yesterday as the market's weakest group. Some traders cashed in their profits, while others who had bought at higher prices remained with paper losses.

title: Art: Drawings Of a Vision of Hell
description: RIOGRAPHIES, as couched for exhibition catalogues, often fail into categories, much as movie scripts do. As a general rule, figurative artists tend to have more romantic backgrounds than abstractionists, particularly those specializing in the kind of grotesquerie found on the various 42d Streets of the world. Though not, of course, fictionalized, this type of life is usually purged of the prosaic, the better to match the mysterious oeuvre emerging from it. Such an artist may not actually have been found it the bulrushes but he or she rarely has ordinary beginnings.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: While bond prices rose slightly yesterday and the credit markets took on a somewhat more optimistic outlook for the near term, the volume of taxexempt financing scheduled over the next several weeks expanded as N York State and Florida announced big issues.

title: Belgium Sending Fresh Troops to Shaba
description: BRUSSELS, June 1 (Reuters)Belgium will send replacements for its 600 paratroops in. Shaba Province, Defense Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants said today. Belgium had originally indicated that would quickly withdraw all 1,700 paratroops sent to Zaire last month to evacuate whites from the coppermining center of Koiwezi.

title: Music: Piano Recital by Amiram Rigai
description: JUDGING from his piano recital Wednesday night at the 92d St. Y.M.Y.W.H.A., Amiram Rigai has the intensity and technique to sir up great excitement in bravura passsages, as well as the conscientiousness good sense to make a favorable impression in other types of music. His one, however, was often hard, and his interpretations seemed fairly heartless.

description: EUGENE, Ore, June 1They were noking at Henry Ron and shaking their heads today. They don't know what to make of h:rn. Can any winner he strong enough to sweep the steeplechase, 10,000 meters and 5,000 meters in a single National Collegiate track and field meet?

title: PRISON WORK IS SENTENCE FOR PALLOTINE FATHER
description: BALTIMORE, June 1 (AP)The Very Rev. Guido J. Carcich, who pleaded guilty to one count of misappropriating funds donated to the Pallottine Fathers, was ordered today to work in the hospital unit of the Maryland Penitentiary.

title: Publishing: An Old Leaf for Cheever
description: THE good word for the many admirers of John Cheever is that an omnibus volume of his short stories61, in factwill he coming out next fall from Alfred A. Knopf. It will contain work from earlier collections not now available, as well ac sevcral imporant stories not previously collected.

title: Film: 'Capricorn One'
description: DAWN. Various shots of a huge missile on the launching pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla. Cut to spectators watching from several miles away. Cut to the Houston Mission Control Centeryou've seen it dozens of times on television and in the movies. Real or fake, it always looks the samepeople intensely busy as they monitor complex computers, television screens flash incomprehensible data, and scientists drink coffee from paper cups. On the soundtrack we hear the voice of a radio announcer give the solemn details of what was eaten at breakfast by the three astronauts who begin their journey to Mars this day.The sequence lasts perhaps 10 minutes, and it's very promising. It's funny. It's accurate in all those banalities we know and love. Then, however, "Capricorn One," an expensive stylistically bankrupt suspense melodrama, gets down to its real narrative.This is the story of a United States Mars landing, faked by apparently several hundred thousand employees of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, because the mission's life-support system is faulty, but to scratch the mission would mean the end of the nation's space program. Or so says Hal Holbrook, who plays the mission's director, as he tries to convince usas well as the mission's three astronauts, who've been removed from their space capsule at the last minutethat the plot we're about to ??? is not a piece of ???cheesecloth.Plots of movies like "Capricorn One," which was written and directed by Peter Hyams, don't have to be flameproof, and they don't even have to carry water, only a tiny bit of conviction and??? more important, wit. In addition to its overture. "Capricorn One" has two decent sequencesa runaway??? interlude, which has been done much more funnily by people like Buster Keaton and W. C. Fields, and a final ???chase involving two wicked helicopters and a nice, old-fashioned biplane, the sort of machine that is to aircraft what Labrador retrievers are to dogs. Lovab'e and always reliable.The stuff that comes in between is humorless comic-strip stuff about a conspiracy so widespread that you finally realize that the only people in the country who don't know about it are the three astronauts, a minor space employee, one unreliable television reporter, an eccentric crop-duster, owner of the lovable biplane, and the members of their immediate families.Such complicity reduces the problems for the screenwriter so that, as Mr. Hyams does, he can have the good guys arbitrarily confounded by the bad for as long as it is convenient. No explanations are needed.At movies like this I tend to regress. I'm once again 16 years old when I was quick to point out to adults all those contradictions they'd learned to ignore. For example, how are the three astronauts spirited away from Cape Canaveral in a jet while at least a million people in the immediate vicinity are watching? Why is a medallion, used by one of the astronauts to slip the hinge in their desert prison, later found by the nosy reporter some yards away on the Mars television "set," which has been used to fake the television coverage of the Mars landing? Why . . . but does anyone care?I don't, which is unusual because I am??? by nature, ready to disbelieve everything from religious prophesies to time schedules printed in movie ads.The cast for this nonsense includes Elliott Gould, as the reporter, the fellow who stumbles on what someone must call "the story of the century:" Karen Black, as his sometime girlfriend: James Brolin, Sam Waterston and O. J. Simpson, as the astronauts, whose lives are endangered in inverse relation to the billing they receive: Brenda Vaccaro??? ??? Mr. Brolin's wife: Telly Savalas, as the crop-duster, and David Huddleston, as a United States Senator. If I didn't know they were actors I might suspect they'd originated on a drawing board.It should be noted, I think, that "Capricorn One" is another "presentation" by Britain's tireless show-business entrepreneur Lew Grade, who has recently given us such other exercises in conspiracy as "The Domino Principle," "The Cassandra Crossing" and "Voyage of the Damned," all entertainments of a strikingly similar, mingy order."Capricorn One." which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested".) has some mildly vulgar language, but it offends only common sense. Its a G-rated movie in disguise.

description: MILWAUKEE, June 1A Federal district judge ruled today that the Milwaukee School Board intentionally discriminated against black pupils in the 1960's and the 1970's.

description: The dollar fell sharply in fairly heavy trading against the Japanese yen in Tokyo yesterday but changed little against other currencies in quiet activity in Europe and New York, according to The Associated Press.

title: Mishap Mars Publicity Stunt
description: Diane Terdik, a stuntwoman, preparing to hang by her teeth 100 feet above midtown Manhattan yesterday in a promotion for an upcoming revue. As she was being lowered, Miss Terdik lost her grip, below, and plunged about 30 feet to the ground. She was taken to a hospital with fractures of both ankles.

title: Pop: Dolly Dawn Sings Again
description: DOLLY Dawn, the singer, is going against her name these days as she holds crepuscular salons at Reno Sweeney from 5:30 to 7 P.M., Tuesdays through Saturdays. Her name is not really Dolly Dawn, of course: she is Theresa Maria Stabile of Newark. But she was known as Dolly Dawn when she sang with George Hall's Band at the Taft Hotel for six years in the late 1930's and, when she recorded on her own, the billing was Dolly Dawn and her Dawn Patrol.

Hudson Company, Detroit's largest store group, has been appointed president and chief executive of the May Company, the largest store group in Los Angeles. Before joining Hudson, Mr. Roberts was president of the Franklin Simon apparel store chain in New York.

title: The Wrong Message to Nicaragua
description: The Carter Administration's decision to resume nonmilitary assistance to Nicaragua is regrettable. Gen. Anastasio Somoza, the authoritarian president that country, has recently turned even more repressive in the face of a serious domestic challenge to his rule. The resumption of aid cannot but appear, both to him and to the opposition, as a United States endorsement of his heavyhanded methods.

The Islanders have been ordered by the league to reorganize their operations before the N.H.L. annual meetings begin on June 12.

title: Zarley Leads Golf on 6Under 66
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 1 (AP)Kermit Zarley, without a victory since 1972 and a top10 finisher only once this year, knocked in three consecutive birdie putts during one stretch and got a fourth on the final hole today to take the firstround lead in the $300,000 Kemper open golf tournamont.

title: Jewish High School Vandalized
description: MIAMI BEACH. June 1 (Reuters)The interior walls of a Jewish high school were painted with swastikas and Nazi slogans here yesterday in the third case of antiJewish vandalism in Dade County in recent weeks. The authorities said that among the slogans painted on the walls of Mesivta Hith School were the words: Kill the Jews.

title: Associated Press
description: PAROLED: Joe Wright 2d in Raleigh, N.C., yesterday. One of The Wilmington 10, he was convicted in 1972 along with nine others of conspiracy to firebomb a whiteowned grocery store and to shoot at firemen and policemen.

title: CIVILMI SEES AN END TO KOREA BRIBE CASES
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)Deputy Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said today that he expected no further indictments of past or present members of Congress in the Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: CITY'S LABOR TALKS COLLAPSE IN DISPUTE ON DEFERRED '75 PAY
description: Negotiations between New York City and its municipal labor coalition broke off yesterday after 25 hours of nonstop bargaining in which Mayor Koch abandoned his insistence on givebacks by the unions.

title: Issue in Delayed New York Raise Is Meeting Conditions by June 30
description: The issue that torpedoed New York City's agreement with its municipal labor unions yesterday has been hanging over the city's head since the summer of 1975, when the unions voluntarily agreed to defer part of a wage increase on condition that the workers get the money back when certain conditions were met.

description: BOSTON DONIZETTI'S Don Pasquale, one of the treasures of the comicopera repetory, has been taken up by the Opera Company of Boston, headed by Sarah Caldwell, and it will hardly surprise those familiar with Miss Caldwell's inimitable ways with opera to learn that she has really done a job on this one. A good job, you understand.

description: The High School of Music and Art, which embarked a few months ago on a campaign against a forced relocation to a renovated midManhattan school building, apparently has achieved more than it set out to get  a brand new buildina at Lincoln Center.

description: WASHINGTON, June 1  President Carter called repeal of the embargo on military aid to Turkey his highest foreign policy priority today and gave selected members of the House of Representatives a memorandum detailing an allout drive over the next three weeks to bring the repeal about.

title: Review on Rep. Flood Expected

Yates, said that, as a board member of Lenox Hill Hospital Mr. ?.losbacher possesses invaluable knowledge of the current financial plight of the city's voluntary hospitals.

title: Ballet: Subs Step In
description: PLAGUED by Injuries, American Ballet Theater managed to turn in a decent if unexhilarating evening of ballet on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. A lastminute substitution brought in the season's first performance of a pas de deux excerpted from Kenneth MacMillan's Concerto. Cynthia Gregory used her long limbs and heroic line to advantage in the dreaming extensions and stretches of the ballet's adagio section. She was partnered by a gallant Gayle Young.

The arrival on May 22 of the ship carrying, the wheat was carried on nationwide television and the Americans were guests at a special celebration.

title: County Colleges Merging Studies With Those of Vocational Schools
description: Declining interest among high school graduates in a liberalarts college education and the traditional desire of many bluecollar tradesmen for a college degree have produced a growing trend in New Jersey toward joint curriculums by county colleges and county vocational and technical schools.

title: Jersey's Senate Votes to Restore Death Penalty
description: TRENTON. June 1The State Senate voted tonight to restore the death penalty in New Jersey for firstdegree murders. The vote was 26 to 13. The bill now goes to the Assembty, where passage is almost certain if leaders allow it to come to a vote.

title: Koch Statement on Labor Impasse
description: I regret that we have been unable to reach a negotiation settlement with the muncipal labor unions. In the interest of arriving at such a settlement to enable us to state before the Senate Banking Committee that the city had met its commitments, I tentatively agreed to a wage package greater than I would otherwise hove accepted. Because the unions adamentiv refused to consider any givebacks unless the city added to that wage package additional dollars to pay for those givebacks, withdrew the demand for givebacks. For me that was an enormous concession.

title: Hazard From Toxic Lead Checked After Blast at Refinery in Texas

title: East Germany Is Linked to Increase in Heroin Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The head of a Congressional task force on drug abuse said today that East Germany was a silent partner to increased heroin trafficking aimed at United States servicemen in West Berlin and West Germany.

description: LOS ANGELES, June 1Nearly four months after he was first asked to take the job and refused it, Daniel Melnick today became president and chief operating officer of Columbia Pictures.

title: Business and the Law
description: A year ago, they were respectable men, middle managers, professionals, owners of small businesses, earning $30.000, $40,000 or more a year. Now they are men without names. They feel a deep shame, and as they sat in a prison chapel at Rikers Island, they looked mostly at the floor. These whitecollar criminals spoke only on the condition that they would not be identified.

title: Bratlig

Jerry was born in Bronxville N.Y. April 1 1950. He was a graduate of the Berkshire School, Sheffield, Mass & Hobart College, Geneva N.Y. He was a resident of Boulder for years and a construction contractor there. A memorial service was held Tuesday May 30 at the First Pres. byterian Church of Boulder. Besides his parents he leaves a brother William F: Cordner, Jr. of Simsbury, Connecticut.

title: At the Movies
description: SINCE its earliest days, the movie industry has been buying theatrical properties and putting them on the screen. More recently, it has begun financing stage productions in exchange for their film rights, as with The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas. Now there's another development. Paramount is not only putting up 25 percent of the $1.5 million budget for a stage musical about the record business called Platinum, but it is also making the costumes, providing rehearsal space on one of its sound stages and setting up a publicity and promotion juggernaut. In fact, studio carpenters may even build the scenery on the Coast, if it's decided that this can be done cheaper, notwithstanding the substantial transportation bill to send the sets back East.

title: Betsy Thomas Wed To Edward Mair
description: The marriage of Betsy Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stiles Thomas of Allendale, N.J., to Edward MacDonald Mair, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Mair of Northampton, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Maxwell Tow, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Bell Finds Some Support on a Walk in Suburbs
description: SOUTH ORANGE, June 1Jeffrey Bell, the 34yearold challenger of Senator Clifford P. Case in the primary on Tuesday, spent hours walking through suburban areas today and met some people who agreed with his view that it was time for the 74yearold incumbent to retire.

title: DR. AVERILL A. LIEBOW
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., June 1 (UPI)Dr. Averill A. Liebow, internationally renowned for his research on the pathology of the lung, died in his sleep yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Broadway.
description: CLAUDETTE COLBERT and Rex Harrison will star in The Kingfisher, a comedy by William Douglas Home, in which Miss Colbert will play a new widow and Mr. Harrison famous novelist who tries to rekindle their old love. The Kingfisher, which will be directed by Lindsay Anderson, who directed it in London when Ralph Richardson and Celia Johnson were in it, will go into rehearsal in September. Then it will play Philadelphia, Baltimore and Boston, and open on Broadway on Dec. 5. The producer Elliott Martin, says this is no drawingroom comedy, but is, instead, a comedy of hope and joy. Drawingroom comedies, he sayso are brittle.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Eglevsky Ballet Company, Long Island's professional troupe, is closing the season with a happy endingthe story of Cinderella. The fulllength ballet, staged with fairy tale sets and costumes and Prokofiev's score, will be performed tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 1 and 5 P.M. at Hofstra University's John Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead. Marina Eglevsky, daughter of the company's late founder and a principal dancer with the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, will appear as guest artist in the title role. Tickets arc $4.50 to $8.50. From New York, take the Meadowbrook Parkway to the Hempstead Turnpike and head west; get off at Exit M5 and continue a short distance to the campus. Information: (516) 7988296.
