title: Excerpts From Campus Speeches
description: I learned American history, I majored in it, but when I had gotten my degree in American history I didn't really know that American history was more shaped by the confrontation between blacks and whites in this country than by any other factor. American history is the product of the interaction or these two people, and the cruelty of the one toward the other and the everforgiving nature of the other toward the one.

title: Broadway Rose Was a Lady
description: We thought of the Bag Ladies. Back on the streets after a hard winter, as mysteriousas ever, wearing the same five or six sets of clothes they had on last fall: Curious, we thought, too, how fashionable they now look with all those loose layers of things hiding whatever is underneath. Just as though they'd been designed by the people who this year make'it tough to find out which way a woman's arms and legs and torso go. Including the tatters and the faded print of the organdy or cotton or flannel or whatever. But what fashion designers don't build is something elsethe faces. Those faces come off Chartres or old limestone houses in the side streets on the West Side or the East Side uptown.

title: Continental and Western Study Airline Merger
description: C??? Airlines and ???? announced yesterday that they have heen conducting exploratory talks nn a possible merger.

title: House Unit Votes AbortionAid Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)The House Appropriations Committee voted today to allow Federal financing of abortions only to save the woman's life, setting up another legislative battle of the sort that raged for six months last year, By voice vote, the committee added the provision to legislation financing the departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare for the fiscal year 1979.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Jose Limen Dance Company will be seen at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, on Sunday at 6. Tickets are $10, $8, $6 and $4. For further information, call the box office at 6786900.

title: CITY'S LABOR TALKS COLLAPSE IN DISPUTE ON DEFERRED 75 PAY
description: Negotiations between New York City and its municipal labor coalition broke. off yesterday after 25 hours of nonstop bargaining in which Mayor Koch abandoned his insistence on givebacks by the unions.

title: The Now York Times/Torosa Zabala
description: ART GALLERY INAUGURATED: President Carter views sculpture by David Smith at East Building of National Gallery of Art in Washington. Others are, from left: J. Carter Brown, gallery director; Paul Mellon, gallery president; Rachel Mellon; Joan Mondale, partly visible; and I. M. Pei, the architect. Details are on page A12.

title: Apollo: Eddie Kendricks
description: GIVE and take between performer and audience has always been characteristic of black popular music, whether it is African village music, blues, gospel, or soul. The Apollo Theater, long the New York location where one predictably encountered this give and take, is back in business after several dark years and, although it has been cleaned up and modernized, the spirit is still there. Eddie Kendricks, who is performing at the theater through this weekend, was so involved with his audience at the late show on Wednesday night that he actually began singing a Temptations oldie unrehearsed, and the band fell in behind him, with the bassist calling out the chord changes to the other musicians.

title: Lawrence Richmond, at 68; Headed SheetMusic Concern
description: Lawrence Richmond, former head of Music Dealers Service Inc., a major distributor of popular sheet music, died Friday at his home in Provincetown, Mass. lie was 68 years old.

title: Ford Hires an Aide to Coordinate Campaign Activities
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford has hired a political aide to coordinate his campaign activities this year, in a move that will make it easier for Mr. Ford to make another try for the Presidency if he decides to.

title: Islamic Parley Opens in Nigor
description: NIAMEY, Niger, June 7 (Agence France Presse)  A threeday seminar on human; rights, dignity and liberty, organized by the Secretariat of the Islamic Conference, opened in this subSaharan African nation today. Attending the seminar were representatives of Malaysia, Turkey, Pakistan, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt Saudi Arabia, Senegal and Mauritania, as well as the host country.

title: COMMODITIES
description: CHICAGO. June 1 (AP)Cattle futures phammeted the daily allowable Emit today as speculator; reacted to the threat of increased beef imports and fears of consumer antagonism to high prices.

title: Auctions
description: For decades, art collectors viewed old master paintings as art works that spelled class, but not necessarily cash. Those who found it necessary to sell in a hurry frequently discovered to their dismay that the old masters market was to say the leas, use ???

title: Sun Queried On Becton Purchase
description: KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., June 1(AP) Several stockholders of the Sun Company closely questioned company officials at the annual meeting today about the concern's controversial purchase of a major interest in Becton, Dickinson & Company.

title: Big Power Plants Held Troublesome
description: Large power plants, nuclear as well as coalfired, are much more troublesome to operate than smaller ones. In fact, according to a new study, the difference may be so great that it offsets the presumed economies of scale that originally prompted utilities to invest in big power generators.

title: 4 of French Sextuplets Survive
description: TOURS, France, May 31 (UPI)A woman who had undergone hormone treatments gave birth to sextuplets at a clinic in Tours on Monday. Three boys and a girl survived and are doing well in incubators, clinic officials said today. The identity of the mother was not revealed.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: April Gauge Of Economy ose 0.5%
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)The Commerce Department said today that its barometer of economic trends rose 0.5 percent in April, supporting Administration forecasts that unemployment and production would snap back from a winter slump.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: LIEBERMANRose. Wife of the late David, devoted mother of Eleanor Krasner, Muriel Taylor and Marilyn Janoff. Dear motherInlaw. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Sister of Peter Jacobsen. Services Sunday 11AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset L.I.

title: Around the Nation
description: PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP)Wildcal. picketing resulting from contract disputes with two small coal companies shut down mines in a broad section of western Pennsylvania's bituminous region today, idling nearly 6,700 miners.

title: What's In a name?
description: ATLANTAAt a convivial luncheon here the other day, Hal Gulliver, the editor of The Atlanta Constitution, was drawing out his guests on a variety of hot topics  Rhodesia, the Cubans in Africa, the state of the American! press, the outlook for Jimmy Carter's reelection.

title: Carter Names 15 to Serve As White House Fellows
description: WASHINGTON. June 1 (AP)President Carter today announced the 15 White House Fellows chosen from a field of 2.026 to spend a year as aides to senior Pederal officials.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee
description: LIGHT TURNOUT FOR LAW AND ORDER: Marianne Hofmann, surrounded by reporters and film crews, speaking at a rally she sponsored last night at the Felt Forum. Only 500 people showed up at the 5,000seat arena, rented by Mrs. Hofmann for $6,000, but she said the gathering represented the start of a crusade.

title: Ruling Lets Spouses Sue One Another in Some Cases
description: TRLNTON. June 1The New Jersey Supreme Court overturned a 101yearold legal doctrine today in ruling that husbands end wives could sue each other for iniuries caused by negligence.

title: Republicans Hold High Hope For Success in South Dakota
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 1The Republican Party, striving earnestly this year to fashion the beginnings of a national comeback, can scarcely conceal its glee as it looks ahead to the November election in South Dakota.

title: Don Zimmer, Meet Robert E. Lee
description: The Boston Red Sox turned their scrubbed and shining faces West yesterday, and by the time they return to Fenway Park more than a third of their season will be gone. Setting out on their first visit of the year to the Pacific Coast, they led the American League East by 3 games. They had won to games more than the Cubs, who led the National League East; seven more than Oakland, tops in the American League West, and four more than the Giants, leaders in the National League West. With 34 victories and 16 defeats. they had winning percentage of. 6S0. Projected over 162 games, this gait would carry them to 110 victories for the season, level of success that no team has attained since schedules were increased from 154 games. Since mankind came down out of trees, no team has matched the record of the 1954 Cleveland Indians, who won 1 1 1 times. In the circumstances, one might assume that the Sox flew merrily, looking forward to engagements in Anaheim, Oakland and Seattle. Maybe they did. On the other hand, deep down in the pit of the stomach there may have been a trace of apprehension, for the West and Northwest, for all their scenic splendors, cannot compare with the homey charm of Fenway.

title: Fads Come and Go, but Today's Brides Cling to Tradition
description: Idiosyncratic vows, bizarre locales, occasional pastels and modern premarital living arrangments notwithstanding, those who want to be. reassured by constants in a changing world need only look at the bride, the woman in white, the centerpiece of even a 70's wedding, whose essential character has not altered much since her mother wore satin, orange blossoms and a train a quarter century ago.

title: AMERICAN EMBASSY FINDS SOVIET BUGS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1United States officials discovered a week ago that electronic intelligence devices had been concealed in the American Embassy in Moscow, Administration aides said today.

title: AMERICAN EMBASSY FINDS SOVIET BUGS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1United States officials discovered a week ago that electronic intelligence devices had been concealed in the American Embassy in Moscow, Administration aides said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported the interest rate that Citibank will pay on the new sixmonth certificates keyed to Treasury bill rates. Compounded daily for six months, the rate will come to 7.53 percent.

title: Officer Thwarts a Times Sq. Bank Holdup
description: A man in a green janitor's uniform lured a police officer to a Chemical Bank branch on Times Square with a story about a heart attack yesterday, grabbed the officer's service revolver, pressed it into his back and told the tellers to fill a brown hat with money.

title: The Now York Times/Fred R. Conrad
description: When Bruce Ditmas leaves his Solo loft for work tonight, he'll lock the door as usual and then clash his cymbals up Greene Street, which is not so usual. Peter Zummo will step out of his West 22d Street loft blowing his trombone. Uptown, Steve Johns will play tuba through the lobby of his apartment house and out onto West 90th Strtet.

title: Accountants Ask Public Comment
description: As expecied, the Financial Accounting Standards Board announced yesterday that it was soliciting public comments on all pronouncements it has issued in the last two years.

title: Films From Political Hot Spots Arrive
description: WHEN areas of the world are caught in political tensions, turmoil or war, we frequently turn to the work of their artists for reflections of how those tensions are affecting people in the nations involved. This weekend two ambitious and separate festivals open in New York devoted to the work of filth makers from two such pockets of strain and flux. Cinema Quebecois, a monthlong look at contemporary film making in Quebec is under way at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street; on Sunday; a weeklong Middle East film festival begins at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 114 Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

title: Panel Offers Steps to Offset Curb on Property Taxes
description: ALBANY, June 1A special state panel called tonight for new local taxes, spen.ding cuts, state loans and manipulations of official property values in some communities to solve the financial crisis created by a recent Court of Appeals decision barring localities from taxing above constitutional limits.

title: Vitas, Ashe, Orantes Gain
description: FARIS. June 1 (AP)Guillermo Vitas, down 14 in the final set, fought back to defeat Billy Martin, 62. 26. 36, 62. 64, today in the second round of the French open tennis championships.

title: Deaths
description: RITTE RBettv, devoted mother of Barry, Edward and Robin, dear sister of Jack. Sharp, darling grandmother. Services Sunday, June 4, 1 PM, at The Riverside, Bronx, 179 St. and Grand Concourse.

title: Talented TeenAgers Take to the Stage
description: In almost any other part of the country, a concert or dance recital by local teenagers would bring out a wellmeaning audience of parents and friends. But New York, as they say. is not the rest of the country. By the time artistically inclined youngsters go on stage here, their talents are tuned well beyond the amateur level, and their performances are as likely to draw regular concertgoers, curious about upandcoming entertainers, as the expected group of wellwishers.

title: California Poll Predicts Voters Will Approve TaxCut Proposal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1An initlative ballot measure that would make deep cuts in property taxes at the expense of local government revenues is almost certain to be passed in next Tuesday's primary, the California Poll reported today.

title: The Conflict in Zaire: Local Uprising or a Global Issue?
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 31The Katangan attack on Kolwezi has brought into sharp focus the problems of Western nations casting about for effective responses to the limited but disruptive forays carried out with what some Western diplomats, Zairian ofticials and missionary sources say is the support of the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: California and Penn Crews Gain Varsity Eights Final
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 1A strong crew from California, the Golden Bears of Berkeley, and a revived Pennsylvania eight from the banks of the Schuylkill won the varsity heats at the Inter. collegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta today and qualified for Saturday's final.

title: TROOP PACT REACHED FOR SOUTH LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1The Presidents of Lebanon and Syria agreed today on measures to restore Lebanese authority in the south, which was occupied by Israel in March and is to be evacuated by the Israelis by June 13.

title: Letter: On Dividend Taxes
description: To the Editor: In your lead editorial on May 19, you oppose the bill introduced by William Steiger to reduce capital gains taxes on the grounds that investment might not be stimulated significantly, no one knows how favorably stock prices would be affected, and the rich would be made richer. You suggest several alternatives for stimulating capital formation, which you correctly recognize as an important goal of public policy. However, there does not seem to be any basis for your claim that reduction in the double tax on corporate dividends would be an attractive and efficient way of increasing capital formation.

title: House Approves Credit for Tuition By a 237158 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The House passed a bill today that would allow parents of students in private elementarysecondary schools and in both public and private colleges to deduct a portion of tuition payments from the amount of taxes they owe.

title: John H. Doeg, 69, Won 1930 Title As U.S. Singles Tennis Champion
description: John Hope Doeg, winner of the United States singles champicnship in 1930 and a member of the National Tennis Hall of Fame, died of emphysema at Memorial Hospital in Redding, Calif., on April 27. He was 69 years old.

title: SAUDIS SAID TO OFFER THEIR U.S.MADE ARMS FOR ZAIRE'S DEFENSE
description: PARIS, June1 Arabia soudia is prepare,l In onIbhnte weapons supplied to it by the united States if an African defense force can he organized to relieve French and Belgian troops in Zaire's Shaba Province. knowledgeable officials here said today.

title: Searches and Newspapers
description: The decision by the United States Supreme Court sanctioning police searches of news organizations files is being viewed by press lawyers as a major setback to the protection afforded by the First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of the press. In a 5to3 decision handed down Wednesday. the Court ruled that lawenforcement officers may obtain search warrants if they have a reasonable belief that a person or an organization possesses material that could be relevant in the investigation of a crime.

title: Barney's Seeks Uptown Image
description: A year ago, The Pab, the restaurant in Barney's men's store on New York's 17th Street, served unly cavvecl roast beef. This year, it. has been renamed The Cafe and offers salads, soup, Perrier, wine and sandwiches, including roast beef.

title: Sudan's Ruler Is Bringing Back Many Exiled Political Enemies
description: KHARTOUM, the SudanIn an experiment that is catching the eye of other African nations, President Gaafar alNimeiry is trying a new way to deal with implacable political enemiesreconciliation.

title: Flounder Being Taken In Great Egg Waters
description: AREA AFlounder are being taken in Great Egg Harbor bay using minnows as bait, according to Captain Andy's Marian in Margate, N.J. There are also reporst of blitefish in large numbers in the Atlantic. Weakfish, running between 9 and 13 pounds, are being caught with bucktails or twister tails. The blues have been caught by trolling with hoochies, a lure in the shape of squid. At the Lighthouse Marini in Barnegat, blues up to 10 pounds have been taken by trolling and chumming in Barnegat Light Inlet. the party boats are bottom fishing for sea bass and ling, and some fluke in the small to medium range have been caught around the inlet of Long Beach Island. Min's Landing at Point Pleasant Beach reports bottom fishing for sea bass, porgies and ling with sea clams as bait while the head (open) boats are reporting catches of blues, chumming off Klondike Ridge and Manasquan Ridge.

title: Mopac to Buy Rail Cars
description: ???? CITY, June 1 (UPI)  Mexico will export 1,269 railway cars to the United States this year, the stateowned National Railway Car Construction Company announced today, The ears will go In the Nlissouri Pacific llailrood and the North American Car Corporation.

title: Nazli Fuad, 83, Mother of Farouk; 25 Years a Beverly Hills Resident
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP)A private funeral service will be conducted for Nazii Fuad, mother of the late King Farouk of Egypt, who died in her Beverly Hills home at the age of 83.

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTONIn the first three years its existence, through last March 31, Government assistance program paid out more than S400 million to 338,400 American workers who lost their jobs because imports hurt their industries. Similar disbursements are continuing at the rate of S20 million a month, in addition to expenditures by various agencies for retraining and relocation of displaced workers and for technological and other aid to affected companies.

title: BYRNE DROPS PLAN FOR RAIL EXTENSION
description: TRENTON, June 1Governor Byrne today dropped his proposal for an ext sion of the PATH rail system to Plainfield and instead endorsed a $600 million plan to improve other rail and bus service in New Jersey.

description: DETROITIttne I flIPI1The four maJOR auto manufacturers today reported doimestic car production in May clmmbed to its secondhighest level ever for the month, surpassing output by more than 6 pemtnt.

description: WASHINGTON. June 1 (AP)President Carter opened the nation's newest art gallery today with a sense of exhilaration and joy which I am sure will be shared by the millions who come after me.

title: Excerpts From Campus Speeches
description: I learned American history, I majored in it, but when I had gotten my degree in American history I didn't really know that American history was more shaped by the confrontation between blacks and whites in this country than by any other factor. American history is the product of the interaction of these two. people, and the cruelty of the one toward the other and the everforgiving nature of the other toward the one.

description: ALBANY, June 1Governor Carey said today that he had signed a bill delaying until Nov. 1 the effective date of the socalled plain language law making legalese illegal. The original bill was to have taken effect today.

title: Carter Says U.S. Is Still Seeking Early Accord on Arms With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  President Carter summoned the White House press corps to the Oval Office this morning to reassert his commitment to a strategic arms limitation treaty and said that United States policy remained to proceed aggressively with SALT discussions, to conclude a treaty as early as possible and without delay because of political considerations, and to make sure that that treaty, when concluded, is in the best interests of our country.

title: Saudis Capping OilWell Gas
description: RAS TANURA, Saudi ArabiaOne by one, the huge orange fireballs that burn day and night over Saudi oilfields are disappearing as this country begins to capture large amounts of the $16 million of natural gas each day that has long been flared off as waste.

description: Alisa Ruth Del Tufo and David Saville Hedden, graduates of Colgate University, were married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Hamilton, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Berry performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Colman Brown, chaplain of Colgate.

Once the leader of a pinneering countryrock band with the rather wonderful name of Freda and the Firedogs, Miss Ball has been out on her own for the last several years, and seems about ready to make a national move.

title: Unemployment in New York City Continued to Decline During May
description: The rate of unemployment in New York City is continuing to improve at a modest pace, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, which announced yester1 day that the rate dropped in May to 8.2 percent, with 250,000 people out of work, from 8.4 percent in April.

title: Violence in Nicaragua Stirs Women to Activism
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Until the National Guard made the mistake of using tear gas against a small group of women demonstrating in front of the United Nations building here three months ago, Nicaragua's new women's movement had barely been noticed. The country's attention was taken up by the efforts of others to oust the longruling Somoza family.

title: Bowman to Coach Canadiens Again
description: In Montreal yesterday, Scotty Bowman put an end to speculation that he would coach another National Hockey League club next season when he signed a contract to guide the Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens for another two years. No terms of the contract were made public.

It is pulling a cautious Tulsa along with it.

Comes now reorganizing team from the Carter Administration with proposed changes: some seem sensible but others are highly dubious.

title: Notes on People
description: The man who bucked the airlines and introduced lowprice, nofrills flights between London and New York, Freddie Laker, was elevated to knighthood yesterday by Queen Elizabeth II as part of her traditional birthday honors. Transportation was generally a big winner in the honors list: Terence Beckett, chairman and managing director of the Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary, was knighted, as was Peter Parker, who as chairman of the stateowned British Rail brought highspeed trains and better service to network long notorious for tardy, untidy and antiquated operations. The honors were announced on a day that marked the 25th anniversary of the Queen's coronation on June 2, 1953. and London reverberated with the ringing of church bells, the blaring of trumpets and the crackling of fireworks.

title: Miami Garment Makers Face Labor Shortage
description: MIAMIGarment manufacturing in Miami's fashion district may be as outdated as last year's hemline. The city that drew on its Cuban exile community to become the nation's thirdlargest garment makerafter New York and Los Angelesis experiencing a dwindling supply of lowwage labor.

title: Letter: On Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of May 23 on welfare reform once again demonstrates the general lack of public awareness of the critical role county governments play in the welfare system. Your constant reference to the need of cities and states and mayors and governors for fiscal relief ignores county governments. County government provides the administrative structure for welfare programming in 18 states and services 49 percent of the entire national welfare caseload.

What set off this pleasant foofaraw of sentiment was an Irish policeman, Pat (Babe) McDonald, born in County Clare, on the cops for 41 years, twice an Olympic champion in the shotput and the 56pound weight throw. A hero to the whole zountry and, in the Bronx neighborhood in which he lived, much more than a hero to a generation of children, who, because they knew him close up, thought he was greater than Babe Ruth.

title: Thunder on the Right Has Turned Into an Insistent Rumble
description: WASHINGTON  Americans for Democratic Action recently put out a booklet entitled A Citizen's Guide to the Right Wing, which sought to explain the relentless growth. of the new right and compared the current danger to the McCarthyism that engulfed the nation in the 1950's. Yet by its own analysis, the organization that for decades nas stood ior liberalism in American politics concluded that the new right is pretty much the old right with a new set of leaders who, like the liberals, have learned to be pragmatic and to use new techniques to achieve their ends.

title: Literary Life on the Cape..
description: N Alfred Kazin's latest volume of memoirs, New York Jew, the eminent critic reveals that like other literary New Yorkers he has spent many a summer on the outer reaches of Cape Cod. The book is laced with reminiscences about men of letters who have frequented that seasonal haven, notable among them Edmund Wilson and Edwin O'Connor. There were a couple of OuterCape tidbits, though, that, conceivably for want of space, Mr. Kazin passed over. One he no doubt omitted out of modesty: an account of the time that Alfred K., occupying an old Cape Cod house with a steep staircase, heard the phone ring downstairs while taking a shower, rushed to answer it, tumbled down the steps, dislocated his shoulder and, when help arrived, was less worried about the considerable pain he was suffering than getting his nakedness veiled.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Labor Secretary Ray Marshall met President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers and Council on Wage and Price Stability headon over the issue of enforcing a rule to reduce lung disease among cotton workers. In a memorandum to the President, the Secretary warned of major policital upheaval among labor groups if there was any delay in carrying out the standards. The two advisory groups had recommended postponing enforcement of limits on cotton dust on the ground that the rule would be inflationary.

title: PEOPLE

The move comes only two years after he accepted the post. Norton Simon's chairman, David J. Mahoney, made the announcement last week, adding that although cosmetics operations outside the United States were thriving, a disappointing U.S. performance will result in lower earnings for Max Factor this year.

title: At Home: I Tinker, Therefore I Am
description: SOMETHING there is about a hardware store that stirs in him a deep, atavistic urge. Everything a man can wield in his hands is here. A temple to human Ingenuity, the hardware store is consecrated to care, renewal and perpetuation. Just as living is a continual process of dying for each one of us, so it is with houses. Every home is suicidal, surrendering it. self to time, weather and human error. The hardware store is the emergency clinic of rural domesticity, and he is the surgeon.

title: Satyajit Ray Treats History As a MultiLevel Chess Game
description: Satyajit Ray's The Chess Players, which opened recently favorable reviews, represents a major departure for this Indian director best known in this country fur his Apu trilogy. Mr. Ray's last film in commercial release in New York was Distant Thunder in 1973: The Middleman, made during the emergency declared by Indiri Gandhi, was shown sporadically in secondrun theaters three years ago. Now Mr. Ray has tackled a subject that could have provided fertile ground long ago for an Indian director : the British takeover and colonization of India. An exploration of why and how the takeover happened and an assessment of its consequences for Indian culture, Mr. Ray's film is the first major one on We subject to he made in India.

title: Erik Bruhn Returns to the Dance
description: When, in 1972, at the age of 43, Erik Bruhn announced his retirement, it was assumed that this most classical of classical danseurs would quietly retreat to his native Copenhagen and rest on his laurels. Since he was 18, Mr. Bruhn had been consid- ered one of the world's purest exponents of the classical stylean artist who, for an entire generation, set the standard for male ballet dancing at its most exalted. In matters of technique, stylistic finesse and interpretation, he brought his artistry to bear upon roles that ranged from the Bournonville and Petipa classics to such contemporary and intensely dramatic ballets as Roland Petit's Carmen, Birgit Cullberg's Miss Julie and George Balanchine's La Sonnambula.

This veatr, however. there is a perception among Democrats and some Republicans that the Senator may be vulnerable.

title: Il Furioso,
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 3 Chances are you never heard of, let alone heard, Donizetti's II Furioso all'Isola di San Domingo, the opera that is currently enlivening the second annual Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in this picturebook city. The Madman of San Domingo Island, to translate the title freely, was first performed in 1833 in Rome. It was Donizetti's 43d operatic roject out of a total of about 80, most which he finished. The score, once counted among the most popular in the composer's huge output, somehow fell into neglect and is almost unknown to modern opera enthusiasts. Only one United States performance is listed in Julius Mattfeld's A Handbook of American Operatic Premiers  in New Orleans in 1842.

title: The World In Summary
description: For a change last week, terrorists were being held for ransom. Officials disclosed that Yugoslavia had detained four suspects badly wanted by West Germany, but the Tito Government had a price for handing over two men and two women believed involved in at least three murders, including the kidnapslaying of the West German industrialist, HannsMartin Schleyer. At the start of extradition hearings, Yugoslavia said that it expected West Germany to hand over two Croatians now in a German prison and to crack down on antiYugoslav dissidents operating in West Germany. Heretofore, Yugoslavia had been sharply criticized for letting suspected terrorists come and go as they please; in perhaps the most notorious case of Yugoslav nonchalance, a little less than two years ago, a widely sought Venezuelan terrorist known as Carlos Was allowed to slip away unscathed.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a glimmer of hope for saving hemlock trees in this region from the ravages of hemlock scale. The handsome evergreens are native to the northeastern forests and are used extensively as landscape ornamentals. But their vigor and lives are being threatened by an insect that feeds on the sap of the needles. Experts estimate that heavily infested trees could be killed in 10 years if the scales are not controlled.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE COOKING of India has not yet claimed its share of supporters in the United States. but this may be about to change  and for good reasons. For one thing, the food is interesting. The dishes are usually compounded of many ingredients heightened by a multitude of spices. Thus, tastes and textures change as you proceed, with additional overtones appearing. Then, too, the ingredients, save for some special spices, are not really foreign to us it is just that they are put together in different ways. Finally, it should be noted that the ingredients arc relatively inexpensive; even the meats need not be superior cuts, because they do not play a lone and stellar role.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Striped Bass Are Scarce on East Coast
description: Early signs do not bode well for stripedbass anglers along the East Coast this year. Movements of migratory fish are slowed or changed by various factors, including water temperature and the availability of food, and this year there are indications that this may be a poor season for the striper. Until recently, it was a long, cold spring. The ocean temperature, from New Jersey north to Cape Cod, is not much above 50 degrees at present and it is generally assumed that stripers like the water to be a bit warmer before they move along the coast.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: WHEN it is necessary to replace a broken pane of glass in a window or door, one of the most time-consuming and frustrating parts of the job is getting the old putty or glazing cornpound out of the frame after the broken glass has been removed. The compound is usually so hard and brittle that trying to dig it out is difficult, especially on wood frame, where you have to work carefully to avoid splintering or digging into the wood.

title: MICHIGAN JUDGE ENJOINS USE OF DIMILIN ON MOTHS
description: LANSING. Mich., June 3 (UPI)A judge has enjoined a state program to control gypsy moths with Dimilin, a chemical suspected of causing cancer in humans, and has ordered officials to ship all supplies of the chemical out of Michigan.

title: At Home: I Tinker, Therefore I Am
description: SOMETHING there is about hardware store that stirs in him a deep, atavistic urge. Everything a man can wield in his hands is here. A temple to human ingenuity, the hardware store is consecrated to care, renewal and perpetuation. Just as living is a continual process of dying for each one of us, so it is with houses. Every home is suicidal, surrendering itself to time, weather and human error. The hardware store is the emergency clinic of rural domesticity, and he is the surgeon.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT was inevitable that the evolutionary process of getting us off the ground a little faster and taking us a little farther would result in an airplane like the Concorde. The uproar it has created is understandable and not without precedence. Jets are big and heavy, and grind up the air noisily like some flying prehistoric monster getting ready for a snack. Subconsciously, some people feel that these metal mammoths are about to descend on top of them. The Concorde looks particularly suspicious, as if it belongs in a dream  and not good one.

title: THE REAL MEANING OF THE ENERGY CRUNCHH
description: It need not happen. But, unless we bestir ourselves, it most likely will. By 1985 or 1986 or 1987, if present trends continue, we'll be staring at an energy crisis far worse than the one we went through in the early 70's. And then our present boredom with the energy problem, and with the Carter Administration's efforts to cope with it, will seem like complacent sleep.

title: Outdoor Skills
description: The Mainebased International Backpackers Association will hold three oneweek Schools of Outdoor Skills in the Mattawamkeag Wilderness Park in central Maine this summer. The park has Adirondack Shel- ters, trails, a swimming area and canoeing facilities. The fee of $50 a person includes food, shelters, hot showers, swimming and leadership. Among subjects to be covered are trip planning, camping skills, trail cooking and safety. One item of advice for prospective students: Don't buy new, expensive hiking boots. An old pair of work shoes (hightop) is excellent and should be thoroughly broken in.

title: Messersmith Loses A 51 Decision
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 3Andy Messersmith's second start as a Yankee didn't turn out quite so well as his first. Monday night in Cleveland he pitched five scoreless innings and allowed only one hit in a game Rawly Eastwick eventually won, 10. Today, he was getting by all right until two were out in the fifth. That is when Gary Thoasson tagged him for a tworun homer. When Mitcheil Page and Dave Revering also hit homers starting the sixth, the Yankees were on their way to a 51 loss to the Oakland A's.

title: Headliners
description: What if they gave an,anticrime rally and nobody came? It nearly happened to Marianne Hofmann, who paid $6,000 to rent the 5.000seat Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden for a mass law and order meeting last Thursday night, at which an estimated 500 people showed up. Samuel DeMilia, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association president. was there. though, and called for the death penalty and stiffer sentences for carrying guns. Others spoke up in favor of equipping more citizens with guns, but only the honest ones. Mrs. Hofmann said, perhaps even vowed, she would continue her crusade on crime in New York City.

title: 1977 Flood Victim Identified
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., June 3 (AP)The body of 8yearold Cynthia L. Gibson, the 77th known victim of the July 1977 Johnstown flood, was identified Tuesday, on the eve of the 89th anniversary of the 1889 flood that nearly ended the city's existence. Two men looking for salvakeable debris found her body. Her mother, sister and brother died last July when a small dam burst above their Tanndam burst above their Tanneryville home. The floodwaters swept the girl's body two miles down the Conemaugh River.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Pork Paradox and the Cities
description: When it comes to helping cities, Washington is afflicted by what might be called the Pork Paradox: to focus a meaningful amount of money on some parts of the country requires Congressional support from others. But to get that wider support requires spread- ing out the money so broadly that the original, focused purpose is jeopardized. The Model Cities program of the 1960's was a model case in point. It began as a demonstration of the effect of very large amounts of money and talent on poverty and decay in three big, sick cities. But before long, it was directed to 36 cities, then 63 and ultimately 150. A lot of money for a few places was turned into a little money for a lot of places.

title: What's Doing in ATLANTIC CITY
description: CASINO GAMBLING  Atlantic City, a oncebustling New Jersey resort, long in decline, has sprung to life again with the opening of the first casino in the United States outside Nevada. It's a phenomenon to be witnessed at first hand but expect to shoulder through crowds for a long time to come to make your way to the blackjack, baccarat, big six, craps and roulette tables in the Resorts International Hotel on the Boardwalk at North Carolina Avenue. The 900 nickel, quarter and dollar slot machines may be easier to get to than the tables in the big black and silver gambling room off the plush red Rendezvous Lounge in the lobby, but the odds, set to give the house a 17 percent return, won't be as good as in some of the games.

title: Call To Arms? Africa Hears Different Drummers
description: PREDORIA South Africa  For John Voster. it was the hest thing to come down the pike in a very long time. His old nemesis. Jimmy Carter. suddenly was beating the drums about the Soviet threat in Africa, the very thing Mr. Vorster has been warning about while the United States has been concentratine its African efforts on undoing white minority rule. While Mr. Carter was chivvying Western leaders in Washington last week into a statement of concern, Mr. Vorster was doing his sternest I told you so routine at a gathering to mark South Africa's Republic Day. They said we saw ghosts behind every bush, he said to appreciat ive laughs from supporters. It took Angola, the Horn of Africa and Shaba to wake them up.

title: Without American Express
description: RAVEL, travel  never so much of it, as people try to catch the peak of the autumn in New England, then tuck a vacation into the dead of winter, or hope to experience a double spring by flying south in March. Yet travel books remain the weak sisters of literature, feeble both in the bookstores and in most critics esteem. Unquestionably, they do lack thickness of a sort that only the characters of a good novel or play provide. We know cur author survived in the end, so there is little suspense, and in the meantime he describes his encounters with everybody just in passing, before moving on. Far from spinning out his family history for us, a tale of the loves of his life, he is probably turning deliberately away from family and love.

title: Inflation Puts the Squeeze on Supermarkets, Too
description: Last December, the American Stores Company, an 800unit supermarket chain, raised its planning budgets for its outlets by 6 percent. title: Washington Is Getting Wired for Its First Real Reexamination of the Communications Act

But in the four decades since Congress passed a comprehensive law governing the then new technologies of the radio and telephone, the act itself has grown to fill well over 150 cumbersome volumes of regulations and court intepretations. This week, nine staff members of the House Communications Subcommittee plan to launch a streamlined bill that they hope will become the Communications Act of 1980.

As a driver in the McKinley Park's shuttle bus system, I am forced to venture out of my, trailer cubicle at 4:30 A.M. By 6, I will be on my way to chauffeur the first earlyrising tourists and campers into the park. As the transportation lifeline of Alaska's Mount McKinley National Park, the free shuttle buses are usually crowded, particularly in the early morning, when visitors are eager to get as far into the park as possible,

title: FILM VIEW
description: The 1978 film festival season is now officially open. Cannes, which has just ended, begins the season that includes festivals in Tashkent, Cracow, Cork, Zagreb, Karlovy Vary, Trieste, Taormina, Locarno, San Sebastian, Thessalonika, Cairo, New York, Sorrento, Barcelona, Teheran, New Delhi, London and Jerusalem. That's to name only a fewthere are more, almost as many festivals as there are films. Well, not quite, but it seems that way. Based on the reports from the Cannes festival, it also seems as if the same films, or at least the same kinds of films, keep reappearing, festival after festival, year after year. Dj vu is a system of cinema esthetics.

description: Susan Dale Harrington and Timothy James Butts were married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Andrew.

description: Christine van Eyck, an administrative assistant in the health finance group of Kidder, Peabody & Company, was married yesterday afternoon to Clark Parker Lattin 3d, a vice president in the corporate banking division of the Chemical Bank. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony in the St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Alternative Flight Styles
description: Everyone is doing it. Bankers and backpackers, secretaries and socialites, schoolchildren and grandmothers are flying from New York to London in great numbers, displaying an egalitarian enthusiasm that has astonished even airline officials. Since Laker Airways inaugurated its Skytrain service last falland the other international carriers responded with slightly more expensive budget and standby faresan estimated 150,000 travelers have made the cutrate trip.

title: An Ethnic Flavor Spices Up London
description: In the most recent issue of The Good Food Guide, perhaps England's best guide to restaurant food, Christopher Driver, the editor, takes issue with those who find British restaurant menus boring. He suggests that if visitors get about, wander, and avoid standard tourist literature and standard restaurant stops, they will soon learn that this country can offer them good food as well as ancient stones.

title: Miss Barbato Bride on L.I.
description: In the Congregational Church in Manhasset, LT., yesterday afternoon, Elizabeth Leslie Barbato, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Barbato of Plandome, L.L became the bride of Mark Garland Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Harrington of San Antonio. Tex.

title: Laurie Weinger, Accountant, Wed to Richard Philip Roth
description: Laurie Anne Weimer and Richard Philip Roth were married yesterday at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N. Y., by Rabbi Nleivin N. Sirner. He was assisted by Rabbi Sanford Jayashow.

title: Preschool Pupils Cheat on Tests To Avoid Tuition
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 3 (AP)Some parents are encouraging their preschcol children to cheat on kindergarten screen:rig tests, according to school officials and at least one mother.

title: U.S. Stresses That Role in Zaire Is Restricted to Ferrying Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 3The Carter Administration emphasized today that the American role in Zaire would be limited to airlifEng troops to and from that country, and said it expected that a Paris conference that starts .tomorrow would concentrate on Zaire rather than on the larger question of an allAfrican security force.

title: Deborah Aline Gunther Bride of Edward Stabile
description: Deborah Aline Gunther, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caulby Gunther of Mattituck, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Joseph Stabile, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Stabile of Syracuse. The ceremony was performed in the Calvary Episcopal Church in Homer, N.Y. by the Rev. Jean Jacaues D'Aoust.

title: Boccherini May Be a Composer For the 70's
description: Laigi Boccherini isn't a name that is instantly familiar to most musiclovers. He's been heard of, to be sure, but dimlyjust a little bit betterknown than. Man fredini, LocateIli, Geminiani and those other worthies industriously resurrected during the Baroque revivial of the 1950's and early 1960's.

News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 4, 1978

title: Oregon Gets InnerCity Grant
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today the award of a $600,000 grant to Portland, Ore., to help low- and moaerateincome families remain in innercity neighborhoods being renovated. The money will make it easier for such families to purchase and maintain homes in areas that are becoming affordable only by higher bracket people.

title: Lakeside Buyers Find Paradise Postponed
description: COXSACKIE, N.Y.  All the goings on in this Sleepy Hollow would probably be enough to make Ichabod Crane's head spin. The lawyers have left, there is another owner, men and machines are at work on a sewer, people are actually talking about building and there are plans to expand.

title: Author's Query
description: I am gathering information on German espionage activity during World War II in Mexico, Argentina, Brazil and Chile. I would be interested in corresponding with anyone, particularly FBI, SIS, or diplomatic personnel, who has participated in or has knowledge of this activity.

title: Jackie Gleason, 62, Undergoes 1 6Hour Open Heart Operation
description: CHICAGO, June 3 (UPI)Jackie Ginson underwent a sixandahalfhour openheart operation today in which doctors bypassed three coronary arteries in an effort to control Mr. Gleason's heartbeat.

title: For Some Re. ailers, 6 Days Are Enough
description: THE allegations advanced in support of Sunday shopping [And on the Seventh Day They Shopped, Opinion Page, May 21] are so full of distortion and inaccuracy that we feel compelled to answer them. Those of us who favor a common day of rest believe that there are no real gains for merchandisers in being open on Sunday. We object to being forced by competitive pressures to operate seven days a week, with all that denial of common day off means for our employees. To deal specifically with some of the allegations:

title: Rules Were Relaxed for Casino, Commissioner Says
description: TRENTON  On May 25. as the New Jersey Casino Control Commission was clearing away obstacles so that Resorts International Inc. could open its Atlantic City gambling casino the next day, one of the five commissioners, Albert W. Merck, filed a mild demurrer. We are not doing this according to the rules, and it is over my protest, he said.

title: MissWhiteWins Mini Marathon
description: When Martha White, a 5foot, 90pound high school senior from State College, Pa., put on her closing sprint to win the Mini Marathon in Central Park yesterday, the final quartermile to the finish line at the Tavern on the Green was packed with spectators. cheering and applauding her determined finish.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Thinly disguising her prose as opinion [HighIntensity Power Line From Canada Could Be a Jolt to Westchester, May 28], Irene Dickinson has:provided readers with a largely fictionalaccount of the efforts of the New York State Power Authority to provide a measure of relief to hardpressed electricpower consumers in Westchester and New York City.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Grooving With Academe

title: Transients to Be Fingerprinted
description: MORGAN CITY, La., June 3 (AP)The Morgan City Council has adopted an ordinance requiring employers to furnish the police with photographs and fingerprints of all itinerant workers, a move.prompted by the slaying of three teenagers. Dale

title: World News Briefs
description: JERUSALEM. June 3 (AP)The death toll rose to six today from an explosion On a city bus, apparently timed by Palestinian guerrillas for the 11th anniversary of Israel's capture of East Jerusalem.

title: Congressman Is Suing the U.S. Over Marston Case Documents
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania, has said that he is suing the Justice Department to force it to disclose documents relating to the dismissal of David W. Marston as a United States Attorney in Pennsylvania.

title: 2D TRIAL SET FOR DOCTOR ACCUSED OF KILLING BABY
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., June 3 (AP)A Superior Court judge has ruled that Dr. William Waddill can be tried a second time on charges that he murdered a baby that survived an abortion. Judge H. War- 1 ren Knight set a trial date of Nov. 271 and scheduled a pretrial hearing for Aug. 4.

title: Standing By in London
description: The situation for standby travelers from London is up in the air. In midApril, the British Airports Authority attempted to ban standby ticket sales at Heathrow Airport through the heavily traveled summer months.

title: A Way to Beat the Tiny Foe
description: The caterpillars should disappear on the Island by themselves in two to five weeks, when they begin changing into butterflylike moths. However, if you do want to wait while nature runs its course, there is something you can do. Find egg clusters  each containing several hundred eggs  that have been deposited branches in a compact mass.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: MOST of New Jersey is green and warm again, but the legacy of last winter remains. In our case, it is a couple of broken trees that don't look all that well, even though they've sprouted leaves; some dead shrubbery that will have to be replaced and a lawn that looks as if it had been grazed on by a mammoth ravenous cow.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The article written by teacher Randi Kreiss [ Outstanding, but Excessed, Speaking Personally, May 21] proclaims to all her basic immaturity. Wallowing in selfpity, she refutes all her later arguments in her very first paragraph: I do speak for many distraught teachers who expected to enjoy their work for as long as they wished.

title: Colombia Votes Today, Ending a 20Year Alliance
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 3Colombia, one of South America's two democracies, votes for a new president tomorrow in e!ecticns that will mark the end of an alliance through which the Liberal and Conservative rarties have shared power for 20 years.

title: Common Market Considers Lisbon's Membership This Week
description: LISBON This week, after a commission formally submits its favorable report to Common Market prime ministers, Portugal will move another step closer to eventual full membership in the European Economic Community. Membership has a high priority for Portuguese Prime Minister Mario Soares, a convinced European, and his motivation is largely political. He believes that a Portugal firmly anchored in a democratic Western Europe will be immunized against a slide back to authoritarian rule.

title: Catherine Rice Wed To John Gorrell Jr.
description: Catherine Rice. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Rice of Summit, N.J.. became the bride of John Warren Gorrell Jr.. son of N1r. Gorrell of Paris. Ky., and Geraldine Gorrell of Lexington, Ky., at noon yesterday.

title: White House Fellow Has Overcome Handicaps of Poverty and Polio
description: In naming Dr. Fernando TorresGil as one of 15 White House Fellows on Thursday, President Carter selected a man who has firsthand knowledge of the problems of the poor and also is an expert on the problems of the aged.

title: PleaBargaining vs. Pupils
description: IN the judicial system, plea-bargaining is the admission of guilt to a lesser crime in exchange for a lesser sentence. In education, pleabargaining by students is the admission of wrongdoing, or lack of doing, in exchange for a lesser, or more simple, assignment and a passing grade.

title: Hybrids of the Native American Azaleas Are Gaining Popularity
description: The average gardener seems to think if a plant is spectacular, it originated in a foreign land. The tendency is to look to sources outside of America for exotic splendor.

title: . . . at MacDowell and Yaddo
description: ERTAIN myths need punctual exploding  among them, the notion that art means lunacy or recreation. The superb working conditions provided since 1907 by the Macnowell Colony near Peterborough, N.H., and, since 1920, by Yaddo at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., sometimes incite the fantasies of outsiderswho assume that artists will wax scandalous slothful if they breathe the same air more than briefly. This totally contradicts my experience at both retreats, although listening to marvelous tales of passion, envy, confrontation and revenge from the 1930's and 90's suggests that scandal isn't as portable as it used to be. And if artists are less flammable today, it may be because most of them have a second profession: When poets and painters and composers teach, novelists function as editors, they're apt to bridle their own temperaments in order to earn a living.

title: ABOUT WE STCHESTER
description: LARCHMONT

title: Val De Loire Open Jumper Winner
description: DEVON, Pa., June 3  Val De Loire, an import from France via Spain who arrived in the United States only a year ago, won the open jumper championship tonight at the closing session of the Devon Horse Show.

description: Sandra Joyce Frawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Parke Frawley of Lynnfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Perry Lowell Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Perry Miller of New Haven.

title: Music Festival Gives Amateur Players an Opportunity to Perform With Professionals
description: After nearly 19 years as an amateur cellist, Susan Stein, an unemployed librarian, sat down and played with pros from the American Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon.

title: Coupons Urged As Way to End Parking Meters
description: New York City should replace its 64,000 parking meters with a system of coupons that could be sold like lottery tickets and hung from the windows of parked cars, State Senator Roy M. Goodman asserts.

title: YaleHarvard Race
description: NEW LONDON rLAGS billowing, yacht horns blaring, observation trains rumbling along the banks of the Thames River and rowing shells from Yale and Harvard racing on a June afternoon  those are the images that once made the annual YaleHarvard regatta one of the most glamorous sporting events in the country.

title: Susan Surette Wed To Robert Honstein
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien Conn., yesterday Susan Jeaninne Surette and Robert Le Roy Honstein, graduates of the University of Vermont, class of 77, were married by the Rev. William D. Donovan.

description: EUGENE, Ore., June 3Henry Rollo settled for one National Collegiate title today, but Clancy Edwards scored a sprint double and led the University of Southern California to the team title in the 57th annual N.C.A.A. outdoor track and field chamnionshins.

description: SYRACUSE, June 3Syracuse's varsity crew won the national championship for the first time in 58 years at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta today.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE air is soothing tonic, not yet toxic. The trees are green and majestic. The sky is clear glass behind a polished copper sun. The earth is as neat and clean as a blueprint.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN it is necessary to replace a broken pane of glass in a window or door, one of the most time-consuming and frustrating parts of the job is getting the old putty or glazing compound out of the frame after the broken glass has been removed. The compound is usually so hard and brittle that trying to dig it out is difficult, especially on a wood frame, where you have to work carefully to avoid splintering or digging into the wood.

title: U.S. Preparing Effort to Limit Loss in Quakes
description: To minimize damage and loss of life when, as is believed inevitable, a major earthquake strikes the United States, plans have been prepared for creation of new Federal agencies, widespread reinforcement of structures and extensive research on earthquake prediction, control and hazard reduction.

title: A New Week, a New City Crunch
description: Mayor Koch is due in Washington on Tuesday to plead New York City's case for continued Federal help. The way things are going, he may he in for sonic lastminute packing and a mad dash to the airport.

title: For More C.I.A. Books
description: LOS ANGELES  So far, we have had three defectors from the Central Intelligence Agency, and by my calculations we need 300 more. To root out the undergrowth in our democracy will require that at least that many former C.I.A. officers come forward to write about their secret activities since 1947.

title: Brazil Ties Sweden, 11; Austria Wins in Soccer
description: BUENOS AIRES. June 3Brazil got off to a shaky start in pursuit of its fourth world soccer title today with a 11 tie against Sweden. Austria won its World Cup opener against Spain,

title: Up-in-Air Ending for Aviation Class.
description: A round of applause sounded clearly through the noise of the jet engines as 70 young members of a newly established high school course called the Aviation Careers Exposure program took off from La Guardia Airport last. Thursday for a visit to the Air and Space Museum in Washington. D.C.

description: Book Snags

title: Hollywood's Favorite Ethnic Group
description: Everybody loves Italians! Were emotional, romantic, sentimental and sing wonderfully. Italian men are all studs, and Italian women are all passionate. If we're sometimes a little slowwitted or vulgar, we have ways of taking care of snobs and getting revenge, and we don't bother with those not of our kind. We're a sweet and peppery people who stay to ourselves. And if you don't believe all that, I'll break your arm.

title: Corner Speeds at Indy Are Termed. Dangerous
description: Last Sunday's Indianapolis :100 made severJ points worth noting: a new team can win the hig one on its first try: the cars are going too fast again: Tom Sneva may he developing a reputation similar to Lloyd Ruby's as the hardluck secondplace finisher: Janet Guthrie is a capable chauffeur who can do well with good equipment; Dann. (On-the-Gas) Ongais may be the fastest of the fast. and A .1. Foyt is human after all. He can have problems like others drivers that even he can't chase away by the power of his will.

title: Mixed Signals; U.S. Remains Of Two Minds (At Least) On Africa
description: WASH INGTON  At a regular State Department news conference the other day, the spokesman, Hodding Carter 3d, was asked to produce evidence to back up the Administration's almost daily assertion  denied just as often by Cuba that Cuba was involved in the recent invasion of Zaire. He was told that times have changed and no longer could such statements be accepted at face value.

description: DENVER, June 3 (AP)Federal funds will remain available to the Denver Indian Center if the operator agrees to repay a $58,000 overpayment.

title: The Debate Over College Costs and the Middle Class Family
description: Several weeks ago the College Entrance Examination Board brought the cheery news that next year it will cost about $3,000 to spend a year at a public university, $5,000 at a typical private college, and $8,000 at the most prestigious private institutions.

description: ALBERTSON  Paradox, acrylics, drawings by Iris Kelmenson; through June; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, call CH 87363.

title: Kinks, a Rock Band, at Palladium With Two BrandNew Members
description: The Kinks were at their most glorious at the Palladium Friday evening, offering a performance as charged with revitalized energy as it was rich with memories. The set was far from seam- less, but technical perfection was very much beside the point; what mattered was the ferocity with which the group attacked the various challenges at hand.

title: If You Can Read American Codes, You Are Too (Undecipherable) Smart; Cryptography is Too Good For Anyone's Comfort
description: Once, paper and ink held unchallenged sway as the raw stuff from which societies concocted valuable symbols: money, contracts, state secrets, plans for new weapons and the like. To safeguard these valu- ables. human beings devised systems of secret writing soon after the dawn of recorded history. Increasingly, however, the operating symbols of power and wealth consist of intangible flocks of electrons that travel through computers at almost the speed of light  and that cannot be locked up.

title: Fresh Air Camp Helps Disabled To Gain in Health and Confidence
description: Tamela Perry outside her home on 141st Street in Jamaica, Queens

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is a definite theme to the new Rossini Ristorante in Freeport. The menus are printed with the music of Gioacchino Rossini, some of the dishes bear names such as Figaro and Barbiere di Siviglia, and dinner is accompanied by the lusty strains of the William Tell Overture (try that for relaxing background music, kimosabe).

title: The New York Times/Stephen Szuriez
description: WILION WILTON High School lost lacrosse match the other day. Stop the presses; that's news. Last year, Wilton lost once in 17 games. They lost twice in both 1976 and 1975 and only once in 1974 and 1973. At the last count, the victories added up to 80 and the defeats just nine in the last 51/2 years.

title: Yonkers Studying Attacks on Family Over 3Year Period
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 3  The Yonkers police today were investigating a series of mysterious attacks on a local family over a threeyear period that has resulted in the killing of one member and the critical wounding of another.

description: LONDON

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: At her New York debut concert Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, Carrol McLaughlin seemed bent on proving to all doubters that the harp can indeed sustain an audience's interest during the course of a solo recital. With her interesting program and skillfully exuberant performances she almost even convinced this listener.

title: Nadjari Retained To Defend Builder In L.I. Embezzling
description: RIVERHEAD, LI., June 2Ronald Parr, a Long Island developer accused of embezzling $3.0 million from investors in a condominium project, has retained Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special state anticorruption prosecutor, to defend him in the monthold trial proceedings, which have been adjourned until June 12.

title: A Butterfly
description: WHAT a practical mansion, says Lieutenant Pinkerton about his newly rented Japanese house at the very start of Puccini's Madame Butterfly. A similar thought occurred to Beth Greene one aay, wnen the violinist and frequent promoter of musical affairs in Westchester drove past the Japanese pagoda in Mount Kisco's Leonard Park.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY friend Frank, from out near Northport, and I were chatting the other day about exercise. It is not staple of my conversation, certainly not while I'm eating. In my circles, I am known as the Sultan of Sloth, and I no longer do elbowbending, much less pushups or deepknee bends; not even to tie shoelaces, because I wear only non. lacing shoes.

title: Celebrating Wildflowers
description: WFSTPORT T0 most people, Joe l'ye weed is nothing more than a small yellow plant that wreaks havoc with a lawn. But to the charitable eyes of a wildflower gardener, Joe Pye weed is more properly Eupatorium purpurum, an edible and medicinal herb that occupies a legitimate place in wildplant ecology.

title: The Marble Island Of Paros, Quiet Heart Of the Cyclades
description: On the Greek island of Paros you can pick up a glowing, seapolished white pebble of Parian marble, perfect as a gem. Before you stow it away in your beach bag, hold it up to the sun. Suddenly a whole Aegean day's worth of light condenses into this translucent moment between your fingertips.

title: Beauty
description: My wife was a nail biter. Then she had her nails done in some new way. Now her nails look like Cher's and I do the dishes all the time because she hates lo get her hands wet, says the husband of a woman who has just fallen prey to the new phenomenon of nail fever.

description: The first hotweather or sillyseason news of the year comes from Moscow. It was announced there the other day that Armand Hammer of Texas, Russia's favorite capitalist, had offered to build the first 18hole championship golf course in the soviet union, ana that the offer had been accepted personally by President Leonid Brezhnev. No doubt they will call it the Hammer & Sickle Country Club.

description: Brcadway theaters took in more money in the 197778 season than ever before and had a total audience that had been matched only once before in theater history.

title: Twins 9, Tigers 2
description: DETROIT, June 3 (AP)Larry Wolfe, a rookie third baseman, hit two home runs and drove in five runs, and Dave Goltz hurled a fivehitter as the Minnesota Twins beat the Detroit Tigers. 92, today.

title: Hints for Alpine Hikers
description: Bad Ragaz lies in the valley of the Rhine, 60 miles southeast of Zurich. It is a quiet, almost dull, town but at the end of a day's walking you are not likely to require much more than a stein of beer or a carafe of light red wine in one of the dozen or more cafes. There are 11 hotels and three hotels garnis that offer bed and breakfast only. Prices range from about $25 for the most modest double with private bath to about four times that for more luxurious accommodations. There are also a number of homeowners who take in two or three guests during the season, at considerably cheaper rates; inquire at the local tourist office.

title: Paul Taylor Company Dances His Polaris
description: Some of Paul Taylor's most peculiar dances also contain some of his most interesting choreography. Two works offered Friday night by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at the City Center were not only very peculiar, they were two of the most interesting works he has choreographed during the last few years.

title: Summer Reading List
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1977. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from the Book Review.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3The Navy varsity heavyweight, crew, in the midst of its graduation ceremonies, added to its celebrations by defeating FLPrvard this morning over three miles on its unusually placid Severn River home course.

My round trip ticket cost $256the price is new $299, as compared with $698 tourist or $432 advance booking APEXand was worth every penny. I have no complaints about flying standby, but I did pick up some useful information along the way, and I do have a few caveats.

description: FRANCONIA, N.H., June 3 (UPI)Apparently there is not much of a market for a bankrupt college campus, even if it comes with 220 acres of land in New Hampshire's White Mountains.

The compound is usually so hard and brittle that. trying to dig it out is difficult, especially on wood frame, where you have to work carefully to avoid splintering or digging into the wood.

title: DISSENT AMONG REDS IN FRANCE IS GAINING

They will also look like a doub:e star tonight, he said, and can best be seen after the sky is very dark.

He would make it easier to hold back elementary and intermediate school students whose scores on standardized tests fall below grade level. For Mr. Anker, these new rules mark a significant evolution in philosophy. But the proposals are illtimed in two respects.

He stands just under 6 feet 7 inches tall and weighs just about 270 pounds, so any refer ence to the term Bullet is in uniform only. He doesn't even shoot bullets; outside of six feet, anything he throws up resembles a grenade.

Presented at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University in Hempstead, LI., as the final offering of the current subscription series, Cinderella closed this season stylishly enough to suggest that the company is confidently looking forward to next season. Yet for a time dancegoers wondered whether the company would have a next season.

He also has a sinker pitch that frustrates and infuriates batters, a great love of baseball and a greater Eve of life.

The older children were on a bus bound for the Staten Island Zoo, the younger ones were playing in the nursery of Trinity Church on East Mat Street, and now their parents were waiting downstairs in the chapel for start of a Single Parents Forum, the first of its kind held on the East Coast.

title: How Many Recessions Will It Take?
description: The inflation news from Washington last week was grim. A sharp rise in retail food prices has driven inflation above 10 percent. Though some analysts expect food prices to quiet down later this summer, others think food may batter the price indexes for months. Either way, it will be difficult to avoid higher industrial prices and bigger wage demands. These would dash any hope of an effective voluntary effort to reduce the inflation rate and would surely lead to recession.

title: Teaching the Drug Law to Doctors
description: New York State's new drug substitution law has gotten off to a disappointing start. The law requires physicians to indicate, on new prescription forms, whether a highpriced brandname drug must be supplied or whether the pharmacist should substitute a cheaper, therapeutically equivalent alternative. 1 ne aim is to save consumers money. But a survey of 49,000 prescriptions written during the first month of the law's operation found that in a third of the cases, doctors were not even using the proper forms. In the rest, doctors refused to allow substitution three out of four times. This record stands in startling contrast to what has been happening in some other states. In Michigan and Wisconsin, for example, doctors prohibit substitution in'only about 4 percent of the cases.

title: Jockeys
description: There was a 10minute delay at the start. of yesterday's program at Belmont Park because of an unscheduled meeting by the jockeys in their headquarters beneath the racing plant's grandstand. The riders were protesting new rules that limit access to the jockeys room.

title: Gleason's Condition Satisfactory
description: CHICAGO, June 4 (AP)Jackie Gleason was reported in satisfactory condition today in the intensive care unit of a Chicago hospital where he was recuperating from openheart surgery. Two sur- geons and two assistants yesterday removed a vein from the 62-year-old comedian's leg and used it to bypass narrowing blood vessels in his heart. Mr. Gleason will be hospitalized for as long as two weeks and will not be performing for at least a month, his doctors said.

title: Iranians Protest in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (Reuters)Thousands of Iranian students marched in Washington today to mark the anniversary of an uprising against the Shah of Iran on June 5, 1963. More than 150 armed policemen with riot gear formed a barrier three deep in front of the White House while about 3,000 Iranians demonstrated across the street in Lafayette Park. The demonstrators wore hoods or paper masks to conceal their identity from the Iranian security service, known as Savak.

The country is in deep deficit in interna- tionat trade and payments, while inflation, the underlying cause of dollar weakness, has worsened.

description: RALLYING FOR FUNDS FOR HANDICAPPED: Hundreds educators, representing 77 educational organizations, gathered outside the State House with handicapped students and parents to urge Governor Byrne to reconsider a cut of $27 million from state aid to handicapped students. Byrne administration officials contend that the special education allocation was too high in relation the total budget. The $75 million this year will be increased, they say, to $101 million for the 19791980 school year, for a 65 percent increase in five years.

title: TaxCutting, California Style
description: Probably not since the Boston Tea Party has there been such unhappiness over taxes on this continent as in California today. Instead of dumping cargo, however, Californians apparently intend to pass Proposition 13 and to toss the state's financial system into chaos. If the polls are correct, they will vote today reduce their local property taxes by more than 50 percent, limit growth of future property taxes to 2 percent a year, sharply reduce the government's capacity levy substitute taxes, and leave the politicians to figure out how to meet expenses with $7 million less to spend.
