description: Joseph W. Barr, who served briefly as Secretary of the Treasury in 1968 and 1969, and who was the last chairman of the Franklin National Bank before it was taken over by the EuropeanAmerican Bank, was named to the Conrail board of directors yesterday by the United States Railway Association. He replaces G. William Miller, who resigned from the board of the federally planned railroad when he was named chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Norris Goff, Abner of lum and Abner,
description: Norris Goff, who played Abner, the bumbling shopkeeper on the Lum and Abner radio comedy programs, died Wednesday at Palm Desert, Calif., after a stroke. He was 72 years old.

title: 1On the Waterfront in New York: Its Crime Ridden Histoiy Is Linked to the ShapeUp.
description: The work can be grueling and uncertain, the pay has been low, and over the years those who unload the great cargo ships have tended to be rough and quicktempered men who have given the nation's waterfronts a turbulent and crimeridden history.

title: A Temptation in India
description: Little more than a year after the restoration of Indian democracy, there is discernible fear that the country's troubles might again make it vulnerable to authoritarian politics. The immediate threat is posed by the political recovery of Mrs. Indira Gandhi, but the larger issue is the capacity of democratic politics to withstand bickering at the top and communal problems below.

title: Rep. Richmond Honored at Party While Pickets Assail Him Outside
description: While pickets stationed themselves outside the entrances of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the Mayor and three former Mayors of New York City, the majority leader of the House of Representatives and 500 other people paid tribute yesterday to Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: Bell Says He'd Give A Pardon to Nixon
description: By The Asselated Press

title: Solzhenitsyn, in Harvard Speech, Terms West Weak and Cowardly
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8In a commencement address at Harvard today, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn left traditional sentiment to others and delivered his own bitter view of a West grown slack, pusillanimous and evil through devotion to'0020;man's appetites instead of God's design.

title: Woodward BidsFor Seat Held By Goodman
description: William Woodward, a wealthy Democrat who had served in the Carey administration for the last three years, yesterday entered the race for his party's nomination for the State Senate seat on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The seat has been held for the last decade by- a wealthy Republican, Roy M. Goodman.

title: PoliceFiremen Pension at 50 After 20 Years Is Voted
description: TRENTON, June 8The State Senate approved today a bill that will allow members of the police and firemen's pension system to retire at half pay after 20 years of service once they have reached age 50.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: House RollCall on Loan Guarantee
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-ollowing is the 247-to-155 rollcall vote in the House of Representatives approving longterm Federal loan guarantees for New York Cal,. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

title: Britain Raises Lending Rate
description: LONDON, June 8In an effort to revive confidence in the management of British finances, the Government announced today a tough package of measures to help it avoid increasing the money supply.

title: President and Senghor Exchange Their Books
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)Two Presidents who are also authors got together today in the Oval Office and exchanged copies of their books.

title: Columbium Price Up
description: Kawecki Berylco Industries said that prices of Columbium, its alloys and compounds would be increased with all shipments on and after June 12. The percentage of the increase will range from 4 percent to 8 percent, depending on the type and quantity of the product.

title: A New Revolution
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8  At first glance it could have been a crowd celebrating a George Wallace primary victory  many elderly people, some with h fierce eyes and grimlyset jaws, fervently cheering a leader who spoke with messianic energy; while even in their moment of triumph, a clear edge of bitterness and anger seemed to unite leader and followers in a common passion,

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO LIFT IMPORTS OF BEEF TO CUT COST
description: WASHINGTON, June 8As a modest gesture toward checking soaring beef prices csident Carter announced today fhat he would allow an increase in the woont of imported beef allowed to enter the country this year.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: Incoming

title: More Americans Are Taking the Waters
description: Americans will probably consume more than 15 million gallons of bottled mineral water this year, and an increasing share of it will bear such exotic labels as Evian, Perrier, Vichy St. Yorre, Badoit, Apollinaris, Fiuggi, Spa and Solares.

title: Apathy Slows Democrats
description: Democratic Party efforts to encourage broad participation in a midterm nationalissues conference later, this year have run into widespread apathy in New York.

title: Cauthen a Clear Leader
description: Steve Cauthen rode 433 winners at New York tracks in 1977, more than double the 211 for the runnerup, Angel Cordero.

title: Welfare Agency Moves to Share In Brooke Mother-in-Law's Estate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8The Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare went to court today to be listed as creditor in the estate of Senator Edward W. Brooke's late mother-in-law, according to data filed in the Middlesex county Court here.

title: Case Lays Loss to Antigovernment Mood
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Senator Clifford P. Case said today that his defeat Tuesday in New Jersey's Republican primary was the result of the dissatisfaction of people with government.

title: Teng Says China Is Cutting Aid to Vietnam
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, June 9)Deputy Prime Minister Tang Hsiaoping of China, in what appears to be China's strongest statement so far on its conflict with Vietnam says that Peking is reducing its assistance to Hanoi.

title: Auctions
description: SALES of elaborate Victorian furnishingsthere are two scheduled in Manhattan next weekare rapidly transforming the auction houses of this city into assembly halls that are attracting gatherings almost as international as meetings of the United Nations.

title: City Sees an Intolerable Situation If Congress Votes Against Loan Aid
description: If Congress does not approve longterm loan guarantees for New York City, the city says it will slash its fouryear borrowing plan from $4.5 billion to $2.5 billion, an amount that would not be enough for it to rebuild its physical .plant, close its budget deficit or reduce its seasonal harrowing needs.

title: Senegal Leader Reads The Unofficial Line His Poetry
description: There are not many heads of state who, coming to New York on their nation's business, will stop at the Poetry Center of the YMYWHA to read their verse. But Leopold S. Seng- hor, President of the Republic of Senegal since its founding in 1960, did so this week during his state visit, joining an illustrious group, T. S. Eliot, Dylan Thomas and Robert Lowell among them, whose voices have been heard there.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 9, 1978

title: Broadway
description: TIMES change; so do plots in the theater. Jack Lemmon comes in and does a comedy about a man dying of leukemia, and Cold Storage, which was loosely about the terminally ill, also had laughs in it. Now there will be a musical. Flowers for Algernon, about mental retardation. The music for this is by Charles Strouse, who most recently has done well for himself with music about orphans and a dog, and the book is by David Rogers. The director will be Peter Coe. and the producer is Isobel Robins Konecky. Obviously, this will not be one of your everyday musicals, and the way it gets produced will not be everyday, either. Flowers for Algernon will go into rehearsal Nov. 14 in Edmonton, Alberta, and open there in the Citadel Theater on Dec. 12. Then, if all goes well, it will be on Broadway by February.

title: ES.FINDS NEGLIGENCE BY THREE COMPANIES IN SCAFFOLD DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The Government charged three companies today with willful or serious violations of safety regulations in the collapse of scaffolding at a power plant cooling tower that was under construction.

title: Exxon Sued by U.S., Asking $183 Million In Embargo Profits
description: WSHINCTON. June S (AP)The Department of Energy filed suit today reeking repaymmt of 8183.3 million from the Exxcn Corporation in alleged overcharges or c:ude oil after the 1973 Arab oil embargo.

title: Holtzman Protests Disabled
description: Ken Holtzman, who has endured a bizarre existence with the Yankees the last year and a half, charged yesterday that the Yankees had placed him on the disabled list when he wasn't disabled.

title: Nets Get Phil Jackson as Part Of a Settlement With Knicks
description: Phil Jackson was obtained yesterday by the New Jersey Nets in surprise move that was part of the Nets $3.2million settlement of their indemnification debt to the Knicks. Jackson, who would have become free agent today, had played 11 seasons with the Knicks.

title: California Ratings Curb
description: In a reaction to the taxpayer revolt in California, Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday suspended its ratings on many bonds issued by localities within the state and said it would not rate any new bonds that may be impaired by Tuesday's vote sharply reducing local property taxes.

title: Black Leaders Are Critical of Some of Koch's Policies
description: In late July 1967, Jerome Cavanaugh, then the Mayor of Detroit, looked out of a window of Police Headquarters toward a city that had been torn by three days of rioting and talked softly and thoughtfully about what it took to build a community and hold it together.

title: ISRAELIS ASK BRAZILIANS TO EXTRADITE EXSS AIDE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 8Israel has asked Brazil to turn over Gustav Franz Wagner, identified here as the deputy commander of the Nazi death camps at Treblinka and Sobibor in occupied wartime Poland.

title: Stage: Brecht's Joan
description: WHAT Bertolt Brecht obviously had in mind in writing Saint Joan of the Stockyards was a broad satire, not of workers and capitalists, but of sentimental attitudes to themthe notions, for example, that the lot of the industrial worker can be bettered through good will alone, that a capitalist with a soft heart is a different breed of capitalist and that the promise of.a good life in the hereafter will assuage the miseries of life right here and now. And in utilizing a modern Joan of Arc for his heroine, he was also spoofing Friedrich Schiller's Romantic portrait of the French girl in his plan The Maid of Orleans.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 8, 1978

title: Publishing: Funny Thing Happened on may to Printer
description: IT WAS a lark, a divertissement, said Madeline Gilford. We were trapped in the some hotel in California. The men were out working, so we decided to turn out a book.

title: SCHOOL BOARD CITED FOR FAILING TO TEACH
description: The New York City Beard of Education was held in contempt of court yesterday for failure to give a student a suitable education and letting him remain ate, although he will be 21 years old next Thursday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The country is 98 years away from, its tercentennial, but the little town of New Paltz in Ulster County is there already. Huguenots settled in this area of the Hudson Valley in 1678an event that is being celebrated with music and pageantry this weekend. Today at I P.M., the Nieuw Nederlande Consort, a group specializing in Dutch colonial music, will give a free performance at the French Church. And at 3 P.M. today and tomorrow, a pageant called Our Huguenot Colony will be presented on the soccer field at the New Paltz campus of the State University of New York;, admission is $2. From 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. both days, there are guided tours through seven town treasuresthe stone houses built between 1692 and 1712. For information about other events and special exhibitions, call (914) 2551660. From New York City, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 18; turn left on Main Street, continue to Huguenot Street, and turn right.

title: Nigh School Girl From Jersey Wins Year's Scholarship in Times Contest
description: Paulette Glassman, a 17-year-old senior at Roxbury High School in Succasunna, N.J., has won a year's scholarship as first prize in The New York Times's Life in America Today contest, it was announced by John B. Degnan, manager of the paper's college and school department.

title: Garrett Clouts No. 22
description: TOKYO, June 8 (AP)Adrian Garrett. a former major leaguer, hit his 22d homer of the season as the Hiroshima Toyo Carp edged the Yokohama Tailo Whales 65, today.

title: Shakeup Makes Hauser Wanamaker's Head
description: When Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. of Los Angeles acquired the John Wanamaker chain in Philadelphia five weeks ago, it steadfastly denied there were any plans for a management shakeup. Yesterday management was shaken up.

title: Fed Clash Seen With Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 8A confrontation is looming between the Federal Reserve System and Congress over plans by the central bank to pay interest to member commercial banks on the money that they now have to freeze in reserve accounts, which do not bear interest.

title: The Larger Danger in Rhodesia
description: Joshua Nkomo's recent boast of Cuban support for his Rhodesian guerrillas sounded arresting but was not surprising. The fact that he has been receiving aid from some 75 Cubans now in Zambia  and from the many others in Angola  was no secret. But in advertising his Cuban connection and shrilly denouncing the West, Mr. Nkomo is now signaling that he has lost hope for negotiation and is preparing to heat up the guerrilla war with the only allies at hand.

title: Macy's Asking Cash Customers For. Names Sets Off Controversy
description: Macy's customers who pay cash are lag asked to give their names and adrpcses as part of a new procedure that the store says is aimed at deterring crime, but that the New York State Atforney General's office says raises questions about invasion of privacy.

title: Campbell Ousted in British Golf
description: TROON, Scotland, June 8 (AP)Frank W. Campbell Sr., an insurance broker from Huntsville, Ala.. was eliminated from the British Amateur golf championship today. He was the last of the 79 United States players who started the tournament.

title: Accused Nazi Seeks New Trial
description: CHICAGO, June 8 (UPI)Frank Walus will seek a new trial in an attempt to overturn a judge's ruling that he be stripped of his citizenship because he hid his World War II Nazi activities from United States immigration authorities. Mr. Walus's attorney, Robert A. Koren- Kiewicz, said yesterday that ne wouia als.o ask Federal District Court Judge J. Hoffman for a delay in Mr. Walus's surrender of his citizenship certificate to the Justice Department, sateduled for Friday.

title: Blessing of Fleet In Northport Harbor
description: Maneuvers by the Antique Airplane Club of Greater New York and the Huntington Militia will help mark the Fourth Blessing of the Fleet of sail and power boats tomorrow at II A.M. Sponsored by the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, the blessing will take place in Northport Harbor, Huntington, L.I. Information: (5) 6) 2817989.

title: Multifoods Proposal
description: William G. Phillips, chairman of the International Multifoods Corporation told security analysts here that the company would present a proposal to its directors to construct a $3 million grain storage elevator at Duluth, Minn. He said the new elevator would replace the grain storage and handling capacity destroyed by a fire in January.

title: Mary Grisanti Wed To Paul T. Schnell
description: Mary Lee Anne Grisante, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Philip Grisanti of Mamaroneck. was married yesterday to Paul Thomas Schnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schnell of New York.

title: National Zinc Drops Increase
description: Just four days after major zinc producers raised their prices by 2 cents a pound in an attempt to stem losses, the National Zinc Company said yesterday that it was rescinding its increase because the market could not sustain it.

title: Expos
description: MONTREAL, June 8 (API)Steve Rogers pitched a onehitter. and Andre Dawson hit a threerun homer off Don Sutton as the Montreal Expos heat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4I, tonight.

title: Central Bank Expects South American Offer
description: A tender offer by an unidentified South American businessman for up to 60 percent of the shares of Central State Bank is expected within 60 days, the bank announced yesterday.

title: Barons Hope For Home In Garden
description: The Cleveland Barons have asked for permission to play half their home games in Madison Square Garden next season to prepare the New York market for a shift the hope to make to the Meadowlands arena that is expected to be built by 1980.

title: Big Rise In Supply Of Money
description: The Federal Reserve, surprising the credit markets for the second Thursday afternoon in a row, disclosed that the nation's basic money supply  M1  showed a huge $4.2 billion increase in the week ended May 31. The broader money supply  M2  jumped $5.7 billion, also considered a large rise.

title: A Club With a Different Jazz Band Every Night
description: Until recently, New York's quotient of traditional jazzDixieland and Swingera styleswas centered on a single block on West 54th Street between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas where two clubs that specialize in that music, Jimmy Ryan's and Eddie Condon's, are virtual nextdoor neighbors. But now, traditional jazz has found a toehold in an Upper East Side restaurant, the Red Blazer Too, where it can be heard in a variety of forms seven nights a week.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 9, 1978

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Tristate Regional Planning Commission appropriated money yesterday for several interstatehighway construction projects, including a major highway link in New Jersey.

title: Bluefish Fill LocalVVaters; 30Pound Bass at Montauk
description: AREA AThere are gobs of blues out there, according to a spokesman for Captain Andys Marina at Margate, N. J., who said that two private boats yesterday took in almost 50 bluefish two miles offshore. The blues, weighing between 6 and 8 pounds, were attracted by tube lures and bucktails on the surface. Ushg twister tails, Fred Gadd and Doc Huntley caught 35 blues and weakfish in the mouth of Delaware Bay. Flounder in Great Egg Harbor are averaging two pounds, with minnow and squid the most popular baits. At Barnegat Ridge, blues from 4 to 10 pounds have been taken in good numbers by chummers. Sea bass and ling have been caught by bottom fishermen at the Wrecks.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Lower Abroad; Gold Declines Slightly
description: The dollar drifted lower on foreign money markets and was mixed at home yesterday in what some dealers described as uncertain trading, according to The Associated Press.

title: Cabaret: Miss Nelson
description: IN the 10 years since Novella Nelson made her nightclub debut as a singer at the Village Vanguard, she has zigzagged between work in the theater as a director and actress and a nightclub career. Her approach to singing has shown a somewhat similar tendency to keep shifting ground.

title: Report on Ocean Thermal Energy Calls Early Exploitation Unlikely
description: Thermal energy in the Florida current as it flows past Miami is said to he more than enough to provide all the electric power needed by the United States, but Congress's Office of Technology. Assessmen has concluded that harnessing such energy is a long way off.

title: Court Fines Spinks
description: ST. LOUIS, June 8 (UPI)The World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, Leon Spinks, was fined $10 plus $12 court costs for driving the wrong direction on a oneway street.

title: Doctor Says Herrin Was Psychotic
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 8A psychiatrist testified today that Richard J. Herrin, on trial here in the slaying of his girlfriend, was a poorly put together person who was suffering from a very severe mental disease last July when he allegedly bludgeoned her to death with a hammer.

title: Around the Nation
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 8 (AP)Many more patients are injured by negligent doctors than ever file medical malpractice claims, despite complaints by physicians that such claims are excessive, says a study released today.

title: Upstate District Is Told to Repay Property Taxes to Steel Company
description: ALBANY, June 8The Court of Appeals, the state's highest, today ordered the Lackawanna School District to repay about $1.37 million in property taxesa fifth of its budgetto Bethlehem Steel, in line with a recent decision prohibiting localities from collecting property taxes above constitutional limits.

title: City Council Legitimizes Previous Shift in Budget To Pay Teacher Salaries
description: Over objections that the money has been taken out of New York City'S classrooms and put into teachers pocketbooks, the City Council yesterday approved the transfer of $13.8 million in the Board of Education's 1978 budget to Day teachers salaries.

title: An Unusual Woman Joins Forces With an Unorthodox School
description: She looks the role of headmistress far more now than she will when she assumes it: the silky bowneck blouse will doubtless give way to a flannel shirt, the sensible pumps to hiking boots. But then, threepiece lady executive suits do seem of somewhat remote relevance on a farm.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar posted marginal gains yesterday in Tokyo and in large Ellyn pean money markets, but fell slightly in New York against major foreign currencies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Miss Lopez Cards 65136 To Share L.P.G.A. Lead
description: MASON, Ohio, June 9 (AP)Nancy Lopez played her last 10 holes in eight under par today for a 65 to move into the lead with Amy Alcott and Jo Ann Washam after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

title: New York State Budget Shows Surplus of $46 Million
description: ALBANY, June 9A surplus of at least $46 million, and possibly more than SS0 million, has appeared in the New York State budget since it was adopted by the Legislature two months ago, according to a report released today.

title: Your Money
description: Richard Phalon

title: N.C.A.A. Charges Untrue, Tarkanian Tells Hearing
description: WASHINGTON. June 9Jerry Tarkanian, head basketball coach at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, denied today that he was guilty of having violated National Collegiate Athlet-

title: Close Scrutiny Expected For Union Bancorp Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9  The chairman of Union Bancorp Inc. of California said today that he expected close scrutiny by regulatory agencies of a proposal by Standard Chartered Bank Ltd. of London to acquire the American bank for $372 million.

title: Air Bumping Award Made
description: MANILA, June 9 (AP)  A Filipino judge has ordered Korean Air Lines to pay 411,230 in damages to a Filipino passenger bumped from a K.A.L. flight in favor of an American.

title: Molson in Acquisition
description: Molson Companies Ltd. said in Toronto yesterday that it had acquired about 94 percent of the Diversey Corporation under a $30-a-share offer that it further extended to June 20. Before the offer Molson held 11 percent of Diversey's 2 million shares.

title: Case of the Vanishing Headmistress
description: It sounds like the title of a Gothic horror story, but according to various educators, the vanishing headmistress was a phrase that began turning up in academic articles with increasing frequency during the 1960's as more and more men replaced women as heads of private schools.

title: New York's 0.C.B.: It Helps City Settle Its Labor Disputes
description: New York City's Office of Col:ective Bargaininginto whose lap the the thorny issue of deferred raises has fallen is an impartial agency set up by local law, as authorized by the state's Taylor Law, to help management (the city) and labor (unions representing city employees) settle their differences.

title: LEESBURG PRISONERS STAGE BRIEF PROTEST
description: TRENTON, June 9Inmates at the state prison that produces all of New Jersey's license plates and much of the bread consumed at state prisons and mentalhealth institutions staged a fivehour work stoppage today to protest orders that they reduce their use of personally owned electrical appliances in their cello.

title: ISRAELI COMMANDOS RAZE GUERRILLA BASE ON LEBANON'S COAST
description: JERUSALEM. June 9Israeli naval commandos and paratroops raided southern Lebanon from the sea before dawn today and devastated a Palestinian coastal base north of the zone held by United Nations neacekeeninc troops.

title: Dent's Hit Is Decisive as Yankees Beat Angels, 31
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9With Ed Figueroa. whose malior league career started here, pitching for the New York Yankees against Frank Tanana, who has emerged as the most respected left- hander in the American League, me Yankees and California Angels opened a threegame weekend series before a large crowd in Anaheim Stadium tonight.

title: 4 ACCUSED OF BRIBING A PROBATION OFFICIAL
description: Four men suspected of being organizedcrime figures were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday on charges of bribing a Federal probation official.

title: `The Winter's Tale
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 9Thou mettest with things dying, I with things newborn, the old shepherd tells his son, and it is the heart of Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale.

title: Jaworski Calls for Action To Learn if 4 Violated Rules on Accepting Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)Leon Jaworski, speciai counsci to the House ethics committee, has recommended proceedings to determine whether the former Democratic whip. Representative John J. California, and three other Democratic Congressmen violated House rules in connection with contributions from Tongsun Park, the Korean rice dealer, Congressional sources said today.

title: Moscow Piano Competition: Strong Nerves Are the Key
description: MOSCOW, June 9Today was a day when young pianists needed sirong nerves, but not everybody had them.

title: ExPennsylvania House Speaker Drops His Effort to Avoid Prison
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 9The former Pennsylvania House Speaker, Herbert Fineman, who had sought to avoid imprisonment for two convictions of ob1 struction of justice by establishing a , foundation to find jobs for nonviolent! criminals, today asked for a leave of ab sence from the foundation's board ot directors and said he would go to prison.

title: Hungary's Leader Voices Confidence on Detente
description: BUDAPESTJanos Kadar, First Secre4ary of the Hungarian Communist Party and undisputed leader of this somewhat maverick Communist nation for more than 20 years says that despite the obvious rise in SovietAmerican tensions in recent weeks, he is confident of a ran-soever to be found in the presence today of Russian troops in Hungary.

title: George Clinton's 'Funkadelic' Band
description: George Clinton's Tunkadelic Band

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Several paragraphs of comments by Mayor Koch about his policies toward and relations with poor and minority groups in New York were inadvertently omitted from the Urban Affairs column published in The New York Times yesterday. A corrective article appears on Page 17.

title: Catwalk Jumpoff Victor In Kent Horse Show
description: KENT, Conn., June 9  Anthony D'Ambrosio Jr. rode Catwalk lo victory in the preliminary juniper derby today with a swift, faultless effort in a jumpoff at the closing session of the Kent Horse Show.

title: The Winner Takes a Dive-in Pool
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. June 9Shortly after winning the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship Larry Holmes jumped in the swimming pool at Caesars Palace, then took a bath in his hotel suite before returning to the Sports Pavilion interview area nearly two hours alter his split-decision triumph over Ken Norton.

title: U.S. HELPING TO OPEN SOUTH BRONX PLANT
description: YONKERS, June 9A window company that is owned by blacks and that plans to expand into the South Bronx has received approval for a $965,290 Federal loan to help it make the move. The amount is the largest loan granted so far under President Carter's $55.6 million pledge to help New York City rehabilitate depressed areas of the Bronx.

title: Dyson Proposes Limit on Number Of Public Employees in the State
description: ALBANY, June 9New York State's Commerce Commissioner, John S. Dyson. has called for a constitutional amendment to limit the total number of public employees to 3 percent of the population a proposal that would force the dismissal of tens of thousands of state, county and municipal workers.

title: Disillusion Decried at City College Commencement
description: The chancellor of the State University of New York told a commencement audience at City College yesterday that the nation's public colleges, despite the opportunity they have provided for millions of young people, were being criticized as a drain and a waste for the taxpayer.

title: Repeat Passengers (One Has Flown 63 Times) Encourage Concorde's Operators Despite Current Losses
description: Pierre Gousseland, a miningcomp:my executive from Greenwich, Conn., held an hour-and-a-half business meeting in his Paris office on Tuesday morning. Then he caught an II A.M. Concorde supersonic airliner for New York and thanks to the fivehour time difference he arrived at his Greenwich office at 9:30 A.M. after a flight 0f les than tour hours, ready for a normal day's work.

title: Ulster Official Says Charge of Brutality Hasn't Been Proved
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 9Ulster's police chief, Sir Kenneth Newman, denied today that a report by Amnesty International, the Nobel Prize-winning human rights organization, had proved allegations of police brutality against terrorist suspects.

title: About New York
description: When; Mothers. Learn Mothering

title: The Fitness of a Good Leather Chair
description: We saw a picture in the paper not long ago and left us, as Eliza Doolittle's father says, Wore out. showed a husband and wife in the Bronx Botanical Gardens. She was wearing a headband and running. He was pushing their child in a stroller and running. We are not against jogging, marathons, pushups, isometric exercises, organic foods not for a moment. But, the last few years, we have seen such an alarming outbreak of athletics that it has left us  motionless.

title: Ford Orders Recall Of 1.5 Million Pintos For Safety Changes
description: DETROIT, June 9After months of vigorously defending the safety of the fuel systems in its Pinto automobile, the Ford Motor Company today announced the recall of 1.5 million of the subcompacts for modifications of the fuel system aimed at increasing resistance to leakage and diminishing the risk of fire in the event of rearend crashes.

title: South Korean Farmers Productive but Vanishing Breed
description: SHINDO, South Korea  A helicopter heat its way northward toward the United States Second Infantry Divi-

title: Pryor Aide's Action in Rate Case Dominating Arkansas Senate Race
description: LITTLE ROCK. Ark., June 9Goy. David H. Pryor's campaign for the United States Senate was damaged this week by the disclosure that his campaign manager had asked the State Public Service Commission to delay action in a rate case involving a gas company owned by one of the state's most powerful political figiirec

title: Relief Recipients Warned
description: JERSEY CITY, June 9 (AP)Welfare recipients will he cut from the rolls unless they accept work assignments cleaning streets and tittered lots, city officials said. The pilot program, whicn is to start in August, will require all ablebodied recipients, estimated at 1.200, to accept job counseling explaining how to dress for seeking a job and what to say to a potential employer.

title: $3.3 MILLION IS AWARDED WIDOW OF BEATING VICTIM
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan awarded $3.3 million to a Syosset, L.1., widow and her four children yesterday in a civil suit against the Long Island Rad Road and three of its police officers,

title: Tanker Hits Sailboat
description: CAPE MAY, N.J., June 9 (UPI)--A 30foot sailboat with four men aboard was struck by an S00foot oil tanker in the fog yesterday, but the men survived the crash. A Coast Guard crew and men from another tanker pulled the four men from the water at the mouth of the Delaware Bay. Their sailboat sank.

title: Carter Offers 26 Water Projects And Threatens to Veto Wider Plan
description: WASHINGTON. June 9  President Carter today asked Congress for Money to begin 26 new water projects, most of them small and few of them in the waterhungry West.

title: Text of Letter to Mormon Officers
description: As we have witnessed the expansion of the work of the Lord over the earth, we have been grateful that people of many nations have responded to the menage of the restored Gospel, and have joined the Church in ever-increasing numbers. This, in turn has inspired us with a desire to extend to every worthy member of the Church all of the privileges and blessings which the Gospel affords.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal Immigration Service Judge from Nutley was stabbed to death as he walked on the Charlotte Amalie waterfront on St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands, according to the Public Safety Commissioner Charles Gronveldt.

title: New Peruvian Loan Deal Seeks to Avoid Default
description: Lima, June 9  Peru's central bank has put together a financial package that it hopes will insure that no default takes place on its international debt payments.

title: Swiss Bank Accord Set In Scandal

title: Daytime Curfew

description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)Jacques de Larosiere, a top French Government official, was formally named today the new managing director of the 134nation International Monetary Fund, effective June 16.

title: F.D.I.C. Fights Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided to try to appeal a Federal court ruling that, if permitted to stand, not only could cost the agency more than $40 million from its insurance fund but also could alter in important ways the manner in which the Government reassigns assets of banks that have failed.

title: The Return of Prepaid Medicine

Small wonder then that Washington's seesaw romance with prepaid health mainte- nance organizations  H.M.O.'s  is on again. The Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare is reorganizing its disjointed regulatory apparatus, and a bill sponsored by Senators. Schweiker and Kennedy awaits action. The faltering prepaid healthcare movement may be ready for revival.

title: For a Total Ban on Chemical Weapons

Unlike bullets and conventional bombs, chemicals  espe- daily the supertoxic nerve gases developed since World War II  hold out the terrifying prospect mass annihilation. It is good news, therefore, that the United States and the Soviet Union are within sight an agreement to ban chemical weapons altogether.

title: Geoff Muldaur Sings the Blues
description: Geoff Muldaur, who is performing at the Other End with his friend, Amos Garrett, through this weekend, was probably the finest white blues singer, and certainly the finest nonSouthern white blues singer, of the 19tars. During the early 70's he made several albums with his then wife, Maria Muldaur, and the sweet, supple strength of his voice, the assurance of his phrasing, and his various textural colorings overpowered her thinner, less assured singing rather decisively. By the mid1970's, Miss Muldaur was a major singing star and Mr. Muldaur's claim to fame was being her ex-hushand. But now Miss Muldaur's fame has receded somewhat, leaving Mr. Muldaur doing pretty much what he always did.

I sat in my seat, fidgeting nervously, waiting for what seemed like an eternity for my name to he called. Finally. I was an. The President handed me a package containing a new suit of clothes, $300 in cash, and a bus ticket back to Tulsa. I just want you to know, I said to him, that I'm out for good. He smiled yty. You'll he back, he said. Maybe not here, but you'll wind up back behind the ivy walls. Kid, your kind is all the same. It's in your blood.

title: Proposition 13 Is But the Tip Of the Iceberg
description: Call it, for want of a better label, The Cantankerous Factor. It crystallized with Vietnam and Watergate and has been a political force ever since. Its principal symptom is an acute skepticism, at times unchanneled, and voter assertiveness that says no no to incumbents, no to familiar faces, no to government doing business as usual. Last week, in the busiest week so far of this election year, with primaries in eight states, the no's were louder than ever, and they have a potential for altering government at every level.

title: Ideas &
description: The Carter Administration, like all rightthinking people, is against inflation and also against occupational diseases. Last week the Administration's chief watchdogs on these two issues, Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall and Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, contended over the cost of protection against brown lung disease, caused by inhaling dust in cotton mills. On successive days Mr. Carter apparently gave the victory to each. Finally, however, Mr. Schultze appeared at the White House to announce that Mr. Marshall seemed to he getting his way: The Labor Department will issue its rules for control of worker exposure to cotton dust  but with modifications. Until the actual standards appear, it will not be clear who is the victor, or whether a reasonable compromise has been engineered. The Administration, meanwhile, is keeping mum.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The assistant curator of modern coins at the American Numismatic Society, Dr. Richard Doty, has written pair of small books that have a wide scope: Coins of the World and Paper Money of the WOId. In format, illustrations and text, they have to be about the best value in numismatic literature that we have seen for some time. Both are softcolier volumes, published by Bantam Books, Inc., at $1.95 and $2.25, respectively. Each one has 159 pages, including:index, with hundreds of very sharp pictures in color. They are Ridge Press balks, printed in Italy by Mondadori Editore of Verona. The coin book will be of particular interest to readers of this column.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Who's worried about the economy? Consumers, according to the Conference Board. The nonprofit business research organization said that in May its index of consumer confidence  based on a survey of 5,000 households  fell to 28.5, down from 96.9 in April, the fourth consecutive decline. The cause for all that pessimism: inflation.... Some of the concern about the prospects for prices may have been reflected in May's newcar sales. Domestic auto makers posted a hefty 11.1 percent increase over yearearlier levels, while sales of imports dropped 14 percent. Analysts suspect that consumers are buying now to avoid paying a higher price later. ... Those same fears also clouded the latest word on consumer elebt, which expanded by the second largest amount on record, according to the Federal Reserve Board. April's $3.72 billion increase in borrowing was exceptionally strong in a time of rising Interest rates. ... Good news for the government's inflation fighters: the Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, scaled back a previously announced price increase and postponed the implementation of two other increases planned for aluminum used in autos.

description: NEW DELHI  Just before Morarji R. Desai left India to visit the United States last week, it was decided that the Cabinet would not meet during his absence so that none of the rivals for power within the Government would have the privilege and prestige of presiding in his place. The decision, which was made after a series of urgent, highlevel conferences, reflected the kind of difficulties Prime Minister Desai has left behind as he travels around the United States, from the United Nations to the White House, from a farm in Nebraska to Bloomingdale's boutiques.

title: Rock Sings an International Tune
description: Despite continuing worldwide economic difficulties, political upheavals and rigid cultural barriers, the international popmusic industry is booming. The rise in record sales abroad is so spectacular that it even surpasses the remarkable growth of the American pop market. In many countries the big hits are the very same songs which can be heard blaring out of radios and record shops on the streets of New York.

The wire fox terrier was awarded his 49th top prize in a field of 1,751 dogs today, being singled out in the Greenwich Kennel Club's 46th dog show for the second straight year.

title: `Gator Farm Yields Hides but No Steak
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Ha., June 10 (UPI)  At. Ed Froehlich's alligator farm, business has gone on as usual since he received his Federal harvesting permitexcept for the fact that he cannot sell the meat he produces. Mr. Froelich said he had to cut through a mile of red tape to get the permit, which allows h:m to market. the skins from his farm. He was the first in Florida to he licensed. There are three others now, including his father-in-law.

title: A Gershwin Musical Meant More Than Good Tunes
description: There seems to be quite a diversity of talent in the Gershwin family, what with brother George at the piano and brother Ira at the dictionary, a reviewer wrote in 1924, after the triumphant opening of Lady, Be Good!, the Gershwins first collaborative hit show. Indeed, Lady, Be Good! and several succeeding Gershwin musical comedies of the 20's, Tiptoes, Oh, Kay! and Funny Face, displayed many facets of the Gershwins individual and symbiotic creativity and set high standards for musical and lyrical literacy in the musical theater.

title: Mortgage Money Comes on Strong
description: Home mortgage rates have hit 10 percent in California and are edging up close to that mark in many other states, reflecting the rising costs of all types of borrowing. But America's thrift institutions, which finance more than 60 percent of all mortgages, are giving no indication that they are ready to turn off the money tap. And consumers appear undaunted by housing loans accompanied by doubledigit interest charges.

title: A Lifeboat for New York
description: The question now for New York City and a surprisingly sympathetic Congress is whether the Federal Government wishes to bail us out  and to keep on bailing year after yearor to give us one good shove, sink or swim. Those are the choices posed by the financial salvage director, Felix Rohatyn, the only certified pessimist among professional faithhealers. Without his dread visions of municipal bankruptcy, New York would be governed today by a Federal judge and a politburo of bankers. Without his gloomy respect for the coldheartedness of the bond markets, New York's political leaders would be lunging for the tideover seasonal loans that even the Senate Banking Committee would grant in a jiffy. But Mr. Rohatyn has organized the drowning crew to wave aside the buckets and to beg for a lifeboat instead: Not another round of cash loans, but a Federal guarantee for up to $2 billion in bonds sold on the open market. The White House has agreed. Now the House has agreed. Senator Proxmire, the Banking Committee chairman, and a few of his colleagues remain to be convinced.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: One of the remarkable things about Jack Lemmon is that, as an actor, he seems to think with his entire body. Merely cocking his head and looking reflective as he spins an idea into the air isn't enough for him. The idea must be the air, weaving its patterns through his restless, nimble, shapely fingers, fingers that play over the face of a telephone dial as though he hadn't quite finished doodling at the piano, fingers that speculatively toy with a brandy glass as though he just might consider challenging it to a duel, fingers that probe the corners of his eyes in a busy but vain effort to improve the landscape.

title: South Africa Hanged 151 in 2 Years
description: JOHANNESBURG. June 10 (AP)Justice Minister James T. Kruger disclosed that 151 men have been hanged in South Africa in the last two years. The Rand Daily Mail reported today.

title: A Sipie Traveler's Lament
description: Blasting! Turn off twoway radio. That ominous dangercolored sign along a highway never fails to shift my adrenaline into high gear. With heart outracing the car, I approach the next sign, which explains the warning signals in detail. At least 15 lines of detail, in small print. The first line says, A. Oneminute series of long blasts. That's as far as I've ever got.

title: New Help for Travelers: Diarrhea Prevention
description: Until recently there has been little that travelers could do to prevent the common ailmentdiarrheathat afflicts just about every American who ventures almost anywhere in Africa, Asia or Latin America. About the only course of action has been to avoid drinking the water or eating fresh vegetables and fruit. Now, however, medical scientists have demonstrated a method of prevention that seems to work. It is simply to take one 100-milligram capsule of the antibiotic doxymycin each day.

title: What's Doing in the THOUSAND ISLANDS
description: THE SCENE - The St. Lawrence River is the drainway of the upper midcontinent, where the Great Lakes spill their waters toward the sea. The river begins its course at the eastern end of Lake Ontario and rolls majestically northeast to its mouth in the north Atlantic between the Gaspe Peninsula and Labrador. For its first hundred miles or so the St. Lawrence is shared by the United States and Canada; the boundary runs down the approximate middle of the river. Below Cornwall, Ontario, it is a Canadian river.

title: A HowTo Disk For Every Problem
description: Our national appetite for selfhelp, self-improvement and selfinstruction is apparently insatiable. Consider the number of howto records presently listed in the Schwann catalogue. There are albums to tell you how to stop smoking, lose weight, read and write, improve your sex life, train your dog. You can practice seduction through witchcraft, cast your own horoscope, live with love, learn stenography in two hours, practice elementary karate and the Morse code, and hypnotize yourself. There is even a record for your plants, released by Pickwick International, put together by a Long Island dentist whose hobby is botany. It's called Music to Grow Plants By, and my own plants swear by it.

title: Listening for Peace During a Mideast Crisis
description: A few days after a recent attack by terrorists of the Palestinian Liberation Organization in Tel Aviv a gregarious IrishAmerican grandmother stood in the village of Metulla at the Good Fence between Israel and Lebanon. She was part of an interfaith tour group on its way to Galilee. As the strong, stocky Israeli guide conversed in English with a Lebanese soldier, Lebanese women, returning from work in an Israeli factory, crossed back over the border to a line of waiting cars. Suddenly the grandmother went to the Lebanese soldier.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Everybody has his own definition of a summer movie. To some it's the sort of movie that you might expect to see in a drive-insoft-core sex n violence or maybe softcore sex n comedy. To others, a summer movie is one that doesn't make you think, as if the mind has to stay in the city while you go to the shore. If it's true that more people tens go to movies in the summer than at any other time of year, then most movies are summer movies, since most people see them then. A summer movie is a movie that's experienced in summerthat's allwhether it's Mizoguchi's A Geisha or Michael Rae's Laserbiast.

title: Formoso Is Shaping Up As Sleeper on Cosmos
description: Santiago Formeso who grew up in Kearny, N. J., near Giants Stadium, leads the Cosmos in several categories. He is the sharpest. dresser, the fastest Cosmo, skinniest andin practiceone of the laziest. Formoso also leads the team in fines. That is because he often oversleeps.

title: David Cowley Makes Cello Debut
description: David Cowley's New York recital debut last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Reoital Hall was appreciably more interesting than most such affairs. First, of all, Mr. Cowley was very good. Sec- and his instrument is the cello which is less common than the piano, the violin or voice. Third, he chose a program of entirely unaccompanied pieces. And fourth they were for the most part unusual and interesting works.

title: Susan F. Nolte and Andrew Loti Wist, Teachers, Are Married in Oyster Bay
description: Susan Farrar Nolte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Nolte Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married there yesterday to Andrew Lott Wist, son of Mrs. John F. Wist of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Mr. Wist.

description: GA RGANVirainia Taylor on June 9, ISIS of 636 West End Avenue, NYC. Wile of the late Howard M. Interment private. Memorial service to be arranged.

description: ITHACA, N.Y., June 10The North overwhelmed the South today, 19.6, in the 37th annual allstar lacrosse game, played at Cornell University.

title: THE MARKETS
description: For the last quartercentury, June has ranked as the poorest month for stockmarket performance, but prices ignored precedent last week and continued to push ahead. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.69 points to finish at 859.23 after climbing nearly 16 points in the previous week.

title: Primaries: 2 Parties Seen as Real Losers
description: THE real losers in Tuesday's primary elections for United States Senator were the New Jersey Democratic and Republican Parties.

description: GREENWICH

title: ON THE ISLE
description: When it comes to house tours, the folks at Brookhaven National Laboratory may have devised the ultimate: a visit that includes a chance to play ticktacktoe with a computer; see raw sewage, filtered through a meadowmarsh pond environment, turned into drink- able water, and watch toy mice caper about in a sealed glove box that keeps them safe from human contamination. Besides these regular features at the lab's Exhibit Center, visitors to the 800acre site today will be bused to the underground building that houses the tandem Van de Graaff accelerators, the largest facility of its kind in the world. Next weekend, Isabelle, the world's most powerful proton intercepting storage accelerator, on which construction is scheduled to start next year, will star (in mockup form) in the regular tour. Running through Oct. 1, the free two-and-a-half-hour guided tours get under way at 10 A.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, with the last bus leaving at 3 P.M. For each weekend's specialty of the house, call 3452345. The laboratory is on William Floyd Parkway in Upton.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today-Conference of Long Island Sports Car Clubs championship autocross, at Gateway National Recreation Area, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn. Registration: 9 A.M.; first car off 11.

title: Yugoslays Allow Mihajlov to Leave; He Vows to Return After U.S. Trip
description: One of Yugoslavia's leading dissidents, Mihajlo Mihajlov, is visiting the United States after unexpectedly receiving permission from the Tito Government to travel to the West. Mr. Mihajlov was freed last November from the latest of prison sentences that started in the 1960's.

title: English Couple Pedal From Sea to Shining Sea
description: FAIRFIELD

title: Reverend Martin's
description: IN KT FATHER'S HOUSE

title: INVESTING
description: Few commodity futures markets In recent years have proven so frustrating and costly to the small trader as silver. Today, however, a new army of intrepid small traders is once again being lured into the silver market in the belief that the metal's time has finally come.

title: Harness Race Writers Will Honor Krumpe
description: John H. (Jack) Krumpe, the executive director of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, will receive a special citation, the United States Harness Writers Association announced yesterday.

title: Notes: The America Returns to New York
description: Once the queen of the American merchant marine, the 38-year-old, 2,258passenger ocean liner America is making New York her home again after an absence of 14 years. The former flagship of the United States Lines, which saw World War II duty as a troop car- rier and has sailed on all the world's oceans, has returned to the Port of New York from where, at the end of this month, she will begin a series of cruises to Nova Scotia, the Bahamas and Nowhere.

title: Light on Car Arouses Suspicion
description: soot traffic signal on lop of II. The officers said that Mr. McCarthy crashed into the standard and drove another four blocks, oblivious In the fact that the sig-

title: Ideas &
description: Few people were immediately affected by last week's announcement by the Mormon Church that its president, Spencer W. Kimball, had received a direct revelation from God stating that henceforth black men may hold the Mormon priesthood. The Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints numbers only a handful of blacks among its four million members. But the revelation was nevertheless significant, both theologically and historically.

title: Master of the Small World of Bonsai
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR YUJI YOSHIMUR A is considered a man of great stature in the miniature, verdant world - of bonsai gardening. In the years since 1950, when he left Japan to bring the art of bonsai to the United States, he has delivered thousands of lectures, been consulted by governments, and until recently had one of the finest collections, with more than 1,000 trees, of bonsai outside of Japan.

title: The Locusts Are Restless
description: Fin years they creep about innocuously on scrubby desert vegetation, munching torpidly in the African or Arabian sun. Rather like grasshoppers during these times, they live almost solitary lives of little consequence to human beings.

title: Tudv Gibson Married
description: Judy Gibson, daughter of Gloria Berry Gibson of Trenton, and William Swiggard, son of Jeannine Leech Swiggard of Alexandria, Va, were married yesterday at Les Mouches in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. S. Howard Woodson, pastor of the Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton. The bride, an actress and singer, is a standby in Ain't Mishehavin. Mr. Swiggard, a singer and guitarist, has appeared in Broadway and Off Broadway productions,

title: Senate Panel Given Rohatyn Argument For LongTerm Aid
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday that failure to approve longterm loan guarantees for New York City would cost Congress more money in the future.

title: NONFICTION IN Danz
description: SONS AND LOVERS

title: Cultural Opportunities for the Handicapped
description: THE CIVIL rights movement for the handicapped differs from the movement for minorities or for women in one important respect, according to Larry Molloy, director of the National Art and Handicapped Information service, who will be keynote speaker at a conference on cultural opportunities for the handicapped Tuesday at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: CANADIANS have been known to say that living next door to the giant American economy is like sleeping beside an elephant. Every twitch can cause major repercussions for the smaller neighbor.

title: Florida Battling Phosphate Industry Over Mining
description: iALLAHASSEE, Fla.The State of Florida, disturbed by phosphate mining on disputed land and the prospect of strip mines in a national forest, is fighting with the industry over the use of thousands of acres in the worlds richest phosphate reserves.

title: Firm Nepal Rule Is Being Relaxed A Bit by the King
description: KATMANDU, NepalKing Birendra, Nepal's 32yearold Monarch, has recently relaxedjust a bitthe stern control with which he rules this remote and mountainous land.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES 1978
description: They Select Their Best

title: Inquiry Begun in Police Killing of Man Who Called 911
description: A grand jury will consider the findings of an investigation into the death of a nearly blind Washington Heights man whom the police apparently mistook for a burglar when they shot and killed him early. Friday in his apartment.

title: Italian Communists Face Testin Referendum
description: ROME, June 10The Italian Communist Party, which suffered an embarrassing setback in local elections four weeks ago, is facing a difficult test tomorrow in a nationwide referendum.

title: Truckers Asked to Test Fuel Claim
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)The Transportation Department asked independent truckers today to test their claims that they get better fuel mileage when speeding than when following the 55mileperhour speed limit. The department wants 33 tractortrailer operators to volunteer to test their claims on highspeed track at the Transportation Research Center in East Liberty, Ohio.

title: In Case of Avalanche, the Dogs Are Ready
description: The Swiss Alps have an average of 80,000 avalanches and snowslides annually, most of them in spring when the weather warms and different layers of snow at different temperatures become unstable. The vast majority of these slides occur high up in desolate regions, beyond the top of ski lifts, but every year some hapless skiers who have ventured up there are swept down and buried by sliding snow. Some are injured and some die.

title: Treaty Dispute With Canada on Fishing Rights Remains Amicable, but Both Sides Fear Economic Harm
description: SEATTLE, June 10Crewmen aboard the United States Coast Guard cutter Modoc exchanged waves and salutes with their counterparts aboard Canadian patrol boats the other day in the coastal waters at the boundary between the two nations. Their responses reflect the amicable air that is still prevalent after each country ousted the other's fishermen from its territorial waters.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: University Press Centenary

title: Don't Tread On Me
description: WASH  Nearly three months of primary elections, capped by last Tuesday's California vote to slash property taxes and take a chance on losing important services, have shown that the voters attitude in 1978 is not the hopeful one of 1976. Then, President Carter won by promising a government as honest and truthful and decent and fair and competent and idealistic and as full of love as are the American people. In 1978, many voters are hostile to government and the people who are governing them.

title: Richard McConnell Jr. Weds Margaret Wood
description: Margaret Miller Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Joseph Wood Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday to Richard Esterbrook McConnell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McConnell, also of Charlottesville. The Rev. George W. Wyer performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's granduncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs, Whitney Stone.

title: Wendy Cushman Married to David Richmond
description: Wendy Lee Cushman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Cushman of Wallingford, Conn., was married there yesterday to David A. Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Richmond of East Greenwich, R.I. The Rev. Seymour St. John, an Episcopal minister and retired headmaster of Choate Rosemary Hall, performed the ceremony in the school's chapel.

title: The Cold War Again?; FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Soviet Premier Leonid i. Brezhnev recently charged that certain circles in the West are trying to mar the process of dtente and to return if not to the cold war, then at least to a. chilly war.

title: The Three Days of Altai n Madness in Dallas, ennsylvania
description: Dallas, Pennsylvania, 10 miles north of .WilkesBarre via State Routes 309 and 118, is normally a quiet residential community. There are shady streets lined by gnarled trees, small housing developments that blend with the rural atmosphere, little shopping centers and a complacent feeling. Normal gathering places for the residents are the golf courses, tennis courts and swim clubs, but the weekend after the Fourth of July, the whole complexion of the town changes and auction mania takes over. This July 7, 8 and 9 will Mark the 32d running of the July classic, the Back Mountain Memorial Library Auction.

title: F. T. Thurston, Pamela Hackes Wed in Capital
description: Pamela Townsend Hackes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Sidney Hackes of Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Timothy Thurston, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Llewellyn Thurston of Baton Rouge, La.

title: Group Offers the Special Aid Required by the Partly Sighted
description: For 6.3 million Americans classified as partly sighted, whose world is often one of broad outlines but no sharp details, understanding what is wrong and dealing with it can be a harrowing process.

title: Andrea Rhodin, Writer, Is Bride Of Paul Tebbets
description: In the First Parish Meeting House (Unitarian) in Cohasset, Mass., yesterday, Andrea Wolfe Rhodin, a writer with the International Monetary Fund in Washington, was married to Paul Eugene Tebbets, a program officer at the Rand Corporation, also in Washington. The minister, the Rev. Edward T. Atkinson, performed the ceremony.

title: NanciHeller. David McAlpin Wed in Jersey
description: Nanci Beth Heller and David Mark McAlpin were married yesterday at noon by the bridegroom's father, the Rev. David H. McAlpin Jr., a Presbyterian minister, who is director of the Center for Action Research in Princeton. N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: STAMPS
description: In case there are any collectors who missed it, the United States Postal Services has taken swift contingency action to implement an increase in postal rates but it has given collectors plenty of time  the deadline is July 15  to acquire first-day-of-issue cancellations of the new nondenomination A stamps and stamped envelopes that have been thrown into the breach.

title: GARDENING A Welcome Touch of Blue
description: BLUE is a welcome color in the summer garden. The recent unscheduled hot spell in this area was a good reminder of how restful blue can be. It is especially appealing when set against a background of green foliage or joined with white flowers.

title: THE SHORT HAPPY LIFE OF A CHILD OF THE LAND
description: By 10 A.M. on Friday, July 15, 1977, Robyn Wesley, a midwife specializing in home births, and Kim Myers, a freelance carpenter, had reported to the Superior Court for the County of Santa Clara, State of California, the Honorable John R. Kennedy presiding.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Richard Himmel is certain that we are on the verge of a major revival of Rene Lalique lighting, a movement that he predicts may soon outstrip the current craze for Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps. And Mr. Himmel, a Chicago decorator and entrepreneur, is backing his conviction with an exhibition of the Art Deco glass designer's chandeliers, the largest such show held west of Paris since they were new.

title: Eastern Suffolk School of Music, Started With a Budget of $500, Is Successfully Completing Its First Year
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.They said it couldn't be done, but a group of musicians here did it anyway. Last September, they started a music school with a S500 budget, a rented piano, a borrowed room and a staff of four teachers who were to willing to wait for their money. had to rent more space in the Congregatienal Church across the street. People just kept coming.

title: Mormon School Gains Agreement on Housing
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)The Government has reached an agreement with Brigham Young University that permits the Mormon school in Provo, Utah, to continue to regoire single students residing on dampus to live in housing segregated oy sex.

title: Paris's La Defense Cluster: Coup of DrawingBoard Style
description: Paris It is 10 minutes rorn the heart of Paris to La Defense and a few thot:sand light ears from the French tradition of restrained, homogeneous architectural elegance to a world of tomorrow that no architect ever envisioned, This Manhattanized section of Paris, which reared its first towers on the periphery of the city in the 1960's, continues to grow extravagantly in the 70's.

description: New York, June 3, 1978

title: Comissiona, Musical Firebrand
description: After several years of annual visits to Carnegie Hall with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and regular guest conducting stints with the American Sym phony Orchestra, Rumanianborn conductor Sergiu Comissiona is about to become a prominent figure on the New York music scene. Beginning this week, he takes on a threeyear appointment at the helm of the ASO. His duties begin this Tuesday at Carnegie Hall with a fiveday Schubert Fest.

title: Leaders in Albany Are Developing A FiscalRelief Plan for Yonkers
description: ALBANY, June 8The leadershp of the Democraticdominated Assembly and representatives of Governor Carey are moving to develop a fiscalrelief proposal for the City of Yonkers within the next two weeks, as the Republicancontrolled Senate advances its own plan.

title: Jagger, Springsteen And the New Angst
description: At least in retrospect, it seems as if some artists's record releases 10 years ago carried with them an enormous cultural weight. A disk by the Beatles or the Rolling Stones or Bob Dylan was awaited with all the expectation of a tablet from on high. People defined themselves in relation to the music they heard, and invested that music with a personal, political and visionary importance that seems hard to believe in our more mellow, realistic 1970's.

title: Holtzman Traded
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10  Ken Holtzman, a center of controversy for most of the two years he pitched for the New York Yankees, was traded today to the Chicago Cubs for a minor league player to be named later,

title: ART Life Is Earnest, Art Is Fun
description: PURCHASE HERE was a time when artists didn't dare have fun with their art. Making art was serious business and didn't allow for amusement. Even satires and caricatures had their solemn sides. Red Grooms, however, is one artist who has made fun his hallmark and demonstrated that fun and art can be very compatible and amusing companions.

title: The Other Side of Stardom
description: Nobody likes having to go to summer school. And nobody likes it less than an Old Dominion University sophomore, Nancy Lieberman. Not only must the allAmerica basketball player spend the summer inside studying instead of being outside shooting, but also she

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PINE BARRENS, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $2.95.) Some 650 million acres wilderness in the heart of the most densely populated state  New Jersey  support a small population that scrapes a livelihood selling scrubby products of the land. John McPhee, who achieved bestsellerdom with Coming Into the Country, caught the essence of the place superbly in this 1968 book.

title: Mostly Mozart, Starting July 17, Will Celebrate Schubert, Too
description: While Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival, opening in Avery Fisher Hall on July 17, will give most prominence to Mozart's music as usual, the works of Schubert will play a large role, in commemoration of the sesquicentennial of the composer's death.

title: Mexicans Will Appear at Ox Ridge
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show, for more than four decades one of the premier equestrian events in the country, will get under way for six days starting Tuesday. As a part of the show, the Mexican Equestrian Team will conduct screening trials for the PanAmerican Games.

title: Realty News
description: Crocker United Factors Inc., a subsidiary of the Crocker National Bank, is moving from 1407 Broadway to 1114 Avenue of the Americas.

title: How Long Can Japan Rule The World of Audio?
description: Walk into any big audio shop, prospecting for stereo, and you are dazzled by gleaming rows of equipment in countless makes and models. Yet, in all this plethora of sweetsounding hardware there are surprisingly few American entries. Of the approximately $2 billion componentgrade sound equipment sold in the United States last year alone, only an estimated 10 to 20 percent was of American manufacture. Especially among such basic items as stereo receivers and cassette decks, nearly all available models are Japanese, though they sometimes flaunt English nametags like Kenwood or Pioneer.

title: Economists
description: AN unassuming branch of the Island's softdrink industry, adorned in what economists call softsell, crayon packaging, is now the exclusive topic of Wall Street conversation. Most New York moneymen long ago dismissed the Island's lemonade stands as fragmented and economically trivial. But now even conservatives consider them part of a huge underground network  probably controlled by a syndicate of entrepreneurs.

title: What Is Gifted?
description: JUST how special must a child be before he or she earns the label gifted? The publicschool system in Montclair has placed a rather liberal definition on the word; it considers all of its students gifted.

title: Bruce, With a Facelift, Is Up to His Old Tricks

title: GARDENING Strawberries From Your. Backyard
description: JUNE is strawberry month. You will find boxes piled high with these red, juicy fruits in all the markets or, better still, at roadside stands in the agricultural sections of the Island. Since little space is required to grow these tender morsels, you may wish to try your hand at growing them in your own garden another year.

title: Lower Tax Assessments Have Helped Keep Land in Crops
description: TRENTON  For years, it's seemed to be only a matter of time until all the farm land in New Jersey was paved over. That time has not come, and, in fact, agriculture is making a recovery of sorts, although some authorities worry about whether or not it's just a temporary surge. Prompting further concern is the fact that a state program intended to ward off urbanization of farm land expires next month.

title: House Chiefs Reach Welfare Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)Two key House members who have been at odds over President Carter's welfare proposal have reconciled enough of their differences that they plan to cosponsor a new, scaleddown version.

title: VIRGINIA DEMOCRATS PICK SENATE NOMINEE
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 10Andrew P. Miller, a former Virginia Attorney General, won the Democratic nomination here tonight for the United States Senate seat being vacated next year by William L. Scott, a conservative Republican.

title: Nancy L. Haaren to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Haaren Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Haaren, to Douglas Sydney Bassett. son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Bassett 3d, also of Scarsdale.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers and Aides Hold a Meeting in Detroit to Organize a National Union
description: DETROIT, June 10Lawyers and office workers from federally financed legal aid programs around the country met here last evening to form a national union.

title: Anthony Sarno, Realty Aide, Marries Nancy Lee Carter
description: The marriage of Nancy Lee Carter to Anthony Sarno took place yesterday in the Bedford Presbyterian Church in Bedford Village, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas A. Hughart nerformed the ceremony.

title: Edwards Wins 2d Dash For Rare Double Sweep
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10Clancy Edwards lowered the boom today and raced to the top of American sprinting by sweeping the 100 and 200meter dashes at a national championship for the second consecutive week.

title: Adrien Wing Planning Marriage on July 8
description: Mrs. John E. Wing Jr. of Cringe, N.J., has announced the engagernent of her daughter, Adrien Katherine Wing, to Dale Washburn. son of Gale Washburn of Detroit and Barbara Hightower of Los Angeles. The wedding is planned for July 8 in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Around the Nation
description: HOUSTON. June 10 (AP)The final maneuver to extend the life of the Skylab space station was delayed today while experts studied a problem that sent the craft out of control for 90 minutes yesterday. The Natirnal Aeronautics and Spare Administration tentetively rescheduled the maneuver for early tomorrow.

title: Housing Aid For the Elderly Under Study
description: Pressures are building in Washington and in various state capitals to ease the plight of elderly homeowners living on fixed incomes and squeezed by inflation.

title: Jonathan Reynolds Weds Charlotte Kirk
description: Grace Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Charlotte Link Kirk of New York. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haddon Spurgeon Kirk Jr. of Elkin, N.C., to Jonathan Randolph Reynolds, also of New York. He is a son of Donald Worthington Reynolds of Las Vegas. Nev., and the late Edith Remick Reynolds. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl.

title: PAPERBACK TALK

A cluster of offices along a few blocks of Manhattan's Fourth Avenue, plus several outposts in Boston and Philadelphia  that was the extent of Publishers Row.

title: Wedding Sept. 16 Set By Marguerite Flues
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilmore Flues of Washington had announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Jamieson Flues, to Carter Strong. son of Helene Wevns Strong of Poughkeepsie, N.V., and Shirley Carter Strong of Freeport, the Bahamas.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN SEOUL ENDS A TRYING TOUR
description: SEOUL, South KoreaAmbassador Richard L. Sneider's tenure here, which ends this month, has been one of the most turbulent ambassadorial eras in AmericanSouth Korean relations.

description: In Summary

title: Tara Ghoshal Becomes Bride
description: Tara Ghoshal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. U. K. Ghoshal of New Delhi, India, was married yesterday in Spring Valley, Pa., to Henry Scott Wallace, who graduated this spring from the Villanova University Law School. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Wallace of Spring Valley and Washington and a grandson of the late Henry A. Wallace, Vice President in President Franklin D. Roosevelt's third term and unsuccessful Progressive Party candidate for the Presidency in 1948.

title: Iraq Cool to Soviet After Report of Communist Plot
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10Iraq has foiled a plot by proSoviet Communists to overthrow the Government of President Ahmed Hassan alBakr and a drive is under way to purge the army of Communist and Marxist elements, according to wellinformed Arab diplomats here.

title: Growing Old Without Dignity
description: AMAN works all his life, beginning at the bottom rung and acquiring the skills and tenacity that enable him to survive, progress and assume greater responsibility and stature. When he retires, rather than graduating to a position of value and respect, he is seen by society at large to be a person of lesser consequence, over the hill and obsolete. The same general situation is true for a woman.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: James Feron

title: United Press International
description: A MATTER OF OPINION: Roy Hartsfield, manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, had some words for Terry Cooney, firstbase umpire, when Dave McKay was called out in the third inning in Milwaukee. The Brewers downed the Blue Jays by 50.

title: Midseason Pointers to Keep the Crops Growing
description: The harvest is now well under way and there are a few special tricks to follow to keep things productive. Pull up every other baby beet and carrot so that the remaining roots have at least three to four inches to mature. Save the beet toos to use as boiled greens. Spinach must be used up before it bolts to seed in the heat. An exception is Winter Bloomsdale which does almost as well in summer as in the cool weather. Swiss chard can be harvested most of the summer. Cut or break off the outside foliage once a week and new growth comes quickly at the center. The bulbs of kohlrabi, which grow above ground, should be picked when no more than two inches across for best flavor. And save the foliage to cook as cabbage.
