description: THE MELLON FAMILY

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FURTH. West Germany. June 10 (AP) Grazvna Rahsztyn of Poland broke the world record for the women's 100meter hurdles by 11hundreths of a second today. posting a time of 12.4S seconds at an international women's track meet,

title: Mehta as a Musician A Look at the Records
description: Anyone who passes Avery Fisher Hall this summer can scarcely avoid noticing that the city's principal orchestra is about to experience a change. The posters are everywhere, and a banner headline proclaims the joyful news: The New York Philharmonic Welcomes Its New Music Director Zubin Mehta. And sure enough, there is an imposing photograph of the maestro himself, baton in hand, his arms spread wide as if ready to enfold all New York in a musical bear hug.

title: Free Jazz at Citicorp Center
description: Two months of free twohour jazz programs, four nights a week, will begin tomorrow evening at 6 in the Atrium of the Market at Citicorp Center, 54th Street at Lexington Avenue. These programs are part of a varied series of free musical programs that began in February and include classical music programs on Sundays at ,3 P.M. and children's programs on Saturdays at noon.

title: DESAI ASKS ELIMINATION OF ALL NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 (AP) Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India has called for an immediate ban on the use of nuclear technology for military purposes, and the elimination of all atomic weapons within 10 years.

title: Lake Itasca, Where the Mississippi River Starts to Roll
description: The first time my wife, Tony, and I saw the Mississippi River, way down yonder in New Orleans, we were stunned by its size, power and sheer volume. A majestically moving inland sea, it bore without strain the mingled weight of countless lakes, rivers and streams.

title: Unsung Heroines
description: WOMEN OF CRISIS

title: Pick of the Contemporary Crop
description: ANTHOLOGIES of contemporary writing pose special problems for a reviewer, because whatever he says can only be partly adequate to his responses  there are 87 contributions in these two collections  and, worse, he will be insidiously tempted toward grand and pompous speculation. Re- garding with austere eye the 18 0. Henry Award stories and the 69 selections of assorted prose and poetry in The Pushcart Prize, III, I feel queasily obliged to use these two books as symptomatic evidence of the current state of our literary activity. I feel that wisdom is being called for, and I would like to declaim with the serene assurance of a glacialist or a volcanologist: Ach so, the precise Celsius reading of our literary waters is such-and-so. These are the dominant currents, the movements, the directions. Pre-

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

title: Ved MehtaUnique Documentarian
description: Ved Mehta has been a staff writer with The New Yorker for 17 years. This Thursday at 9 P.M., Channel 13 will televise his first film, an hourlong documentary, entitled Chachaji: My Poor Relation. While it is not uncommon for writers to turn from their typewriters to the world of purely visual images, this documentary may well be a first in the history of filmmaking inasmuch as Mr. Mehta is totally blind and has been so since the age of 4, when he almost succumbed to a bout of meningitis.

title: AirDemocracy in Tazz Action
description: Ensembles that create their music together and stay together, without changes in personnel, over long periods of time, are a rarity in jazz. Aside from a few longlived units that were led and almost wholly dominated by successful musicians, such as John Coltrane's quartet of the early 60's and Keith Jarrett's quartet of the mid70's, there have been a mere handful, with the Modern Jazz Quartet and the Art Ensemble of Chicago perhaps the most prominent among them. For the most part, jazz is created by leaders and sidemen, for reasons that are partly economic and partly, one suspects, due to the individualism and selfassertion that seem so endemic to jazz as a music and a way of life.

title: Barnard Hughes Born to Play Da?

Mr. Hughes, who wears them as the star of Da, is not by nature a superstitious man, but by this time he tends to eye those shoes with the respectful affection of someone who knows he has stepped into a good thing.

title: TV VIEW
description: Once upon a time last fall, the Carter Administration unveiled a new Public Broadcasting Financing Act. Among other things, it proposed extending the overall funding period to five years from three and reducing the authority of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting over specific programs and scheduling. Officials of the Public Broadcasting Service, meeting in February, took a series of positions on the provisions. The bill was altered slightly and reintroduced by the White House on Feb. 25. Generally pleased PBS executives prepared to testify in midApril before the House and Senate Communications subcommittees. Then, catching the hierarchy of public television totally unprepared, the legislative roof fell in. On April 11, Lionel Van Deerlin (Democrat, Calif), chairman of the House Subcommittee, and Ernest Hollings (Democrat, S.C.), the Senate counterpart, introduced their own financing proposals, which called for threeyear funding and more stringent regulations aiming for fuller financial disclosures, increased use of independent producers, and more hiring of women and minorities. The debates and bickering began in earnest.

title: 'Bonjour Amour,' a French Film About First Love, at the Cinema 2:The Cast
description: If you can't wait to see another French film about first love, then rush over to the Cinema 2 where "Bonjour Amour" opens today. It might not be there long.The film is about Marc (Pascal Meynler), a boy of unspecified teen age and the sweet, presumably older 17-year-old shopgirl, Martine (Guilhaine Dubos), with whom he shares first love's joys, sorrows, discoveries and other cliches, until they are separated by his boorish, lower middle-class parents.There's nothing stunningly wrong with the movie except a lack of apparent talent, which is as fatal to a movie about first love as it would be in the counterfeiting of $20 bills. Roger Andrieux, the director, obviously means the film, called "L'Amour en Herbe" (Budding Love) in France, to be tender and sensitive. It is, instead, trivial and humorless. Watching it is like waiting for a subway with nothing to read.The performances are adequate, though Mr. Meynier appears to be not only very young but slightly stunted. Everybody in the movie seems to be bigger than he is.

The companies the Penley Corporation in West Paris, the Diamond International Corporation in Peru, the Forster Manufacturing Company in Wilton and the National Clothespin Company in Montpelier, Vt.  contend that China, Rumania, Poland and Czechoslovakia are using pricc-cutting tactics.

title: 22 Rhodesian Blacks Dead in Clash
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 11 (Reuters)Twentytwo blacks, most of them civilians, were killed yesterday in a battle between security forces and black nationalist guerrillas only eight miles from Salisbury's northern limits, Rhodesian military headquarters announced tonight.

title: Mr. Carter's Compromise on Water
description: President Carter provoked a major battle with Congress last year when he  courageously? naively?  issued a hit list of 18 water projects that he wanted deleted from the budget as economically or environmentally damaging. In the end, the President was forced to compromise with the porkbarrel politicians; he agreed to continue nine of the projects but he also pledged to develop more rational criteria for the future. Last week he unveiled his new water policy. It won cautious praise from two contending forces environmentalists who oppose many projects as costly and destructive, and Western governors who see them as the key to their prosperity. The environmentalists are pleased that new criteria will make future boondoggles more difficult. The governors are relieved that the policy will have scant effect on $20 billion worth of projects already under construction, such as those on last year's hit list. Mr. Carter's policy seems designed to be as tough as possible without provoking another damaging political brawl.

title: Topics
description: Camp life? Not quite. This writer's age was more likely in the seventies, and the camp experience was provided by a nonprofit community agency, called Vara t ions and Senior Centers Associations, Inc. (VASCA). Founded in 1959, this organization has enriched the lives of hundreds of thousands of elderly lowincome New Yorkers. Last year, at an average weekly cost to the camper of only about $40, its 17 affiliated camps provided summer vacations for 7,654 older persons who would otherwise have spent the hot summer in the city. In addition, VASCA offers a wide variety of services in its 250 Senior Centers.

title: Concert: The Housing Symphony
description: GLAMOUR is not a word one would associate with a musical organization that rejoices in the name of the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra. But then, the orchestra has a more important mission than to challenge the world's greatest symphonic outfits. Its primary good work is to bring orchestra music to areas of the city that would not ordinarily experience such a cultural treat.

title: Renault SitIn Ends
description: PARIS, June 11, (Reuters)  About 150 strikers ended a nineday sitin at a Renault car factory at nearby Cleon yesterday after more than 1,000 riot police surrounded the plant at dawn and ordered them outside. The strikers, de- manding better pay, longer boilaays and early retirement, were to meet later in the day to consider new strategy, a spokesman for the Communistled union C.G.T. said. At the stateowned car concern's factory at Flins, from which striking workers were also evicted this week, 150 men reoccupied the press room on Friday.

title: HARSH ECONOMIC PLAN FOR FRANCE IS PUSHED

title: Sporting Gear
description: Just when you think there could be nothing different in baseball gloves, along conies Franklin Sports Industries with a new concept: Corolac, a synthetic designed to feel and look like leather. Corolac, now being used as a liner for seven models of baseball and softball gloves, not only costs less and weighs less than leather but alSo lasts longer. So, after a season or two of hard play, the inside of your favorite mitt won't dry up, crack or rot away because of perspiration. Though this year's glove models are only part Corolac (and part cowhide), next year's may be all Corolac, which, according to the manufacturer, will make them much more pliable and easier to break in. From $12 to $30 at Tony DePhillips Sports Center, 2915 Francis Lewis Boulevard, Baysicle, Queens: Morris E. Levine Company, 348 Knickerbocker Avenue, Brooklyn, and Rockaway Sales, Route 46, Rockaway, N.J.

title: U.S. Urged To Lower Oil Imports
description: BASEL, Switzerland June 11  The Western world's plans for aiding economic growth and cutting unemployment which dominate the agenda for next month's Bonn economic summit meeting  will fail unless the United States takes drastic action to reduce its oil imports and other countries intensify their energysaving efforts, the Bank for International Settlements warned in its latest annual report.

description: WASHINGTON, June II (AP)  A ,strong earthquake occured this morning in the northern Pacific off the coast of Ganada, scientists in the United State and Canada reported. The United States Geological Survey said the earthquake, with a preliminary magnitude estimated at f, on the 10.point Richter scale, wss entered about 200 miles off the coast of Vancouver Island, British Columl., so damage was reported.

But now the way seems to be drifted over with the shifting sands of Middle Eastern politics.

description: A revolutionary astronomical instrument combining six telescopes into one nearing completion atop Mount Hopkins, an 8,550foot summit near Tucson, Ariz.

title: The Watergate Window
description: It has now been six years since the burglars were discovered in Democratic Party headquarters, six years in which Congress has taken some serious reform steps concerning law enforcement abuse and ethical behavior by officials, including an admirably strong code of ethics for its own members. But some contrary signs are also becoming evident some members are talking as if reform has become the midiskirt, yesterday's fashion; given the wave of taxpayer revolts, today's fashion seems to be not morality but frugality. I'm afraid, a prominent Capitol Hill veteran said the other day, that the window Watergate opened for reform is now closing.

title: Bishop Harold L. Wright, 46, Dies; Episcopal Suffragan in New York
description: Bishop Harold Louis Wright, who in 1974 became the first black Bishop in the Episcopal Diocese of New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Queens Hospital Center. He was 46 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: ST. LAWRENCE, Barbados. June 11 The semifinal stage of the Central American and Caribbean zonal championship will be contested here tomorrow by teams from Guadeloupe, Venezuela, Jamaica and Panama, which finished in that order in the qualifying stage last night.

title: GOING OUT Guid
description: POUNCE For only 50 cents, you can pick up one of the best buys relating a to cultural New York. This is a statistical indexbrochure, out since February, covering the activities of 115 museums, zoos and botanical gardens in the metropolitan area; and it folds to fit into nto the palm of your hand and pocket. The booklet is titled A Guide to New York City Museums. Some newsstands carry it but it's available in all sales shops of museums listed (only a few newcomers are omitted). The paperback guide is also available at its source, the nonprofit Cultural Assistance Center for the city's Commission for Cultural Affairs.

description: CITY CYCLISTS RALLY FOR BIKE LANES: Hundreds of cyclists from around the city pedaling down Fifth Avenue near Washington Square yesterday on their way to rally in front of City Hall. Politically minded bicycle users organized the demonstration in an effort to raise the bikeconsciousness of New York City officials.

title: SOVIET INTENSIFIES ITS ATTACKS ON U.S. OVER CARTER SPEECH
description: MOSCOW, June 11The Soviet Union stepped up its attacks on the Carter Administration today, calling the President's speech last Wednesday on Soviet-American relations a series of categorical demands, and charging that American propaganda was working up antiSoviet hysteria.

title: Pop: The Dells, From DooWop to Funk
description: THE DELLS, who were at the Apollo Theater over the weekend, are celebrating their 25th anniversary In show business this year, with just one personnel changea replacement back in 1959. This means that the group nas weatnered changes from doowop harmony singing to rock-and-roll to soul to funk, a remarkable accomplishment in a field that often sees a rapid turnover of artists and especially of group personnels, it suggests that the Dells have something special, but it also indicates that black group singing has been one of the more stable aspects of American pop music during the last quarter of a century, evolving conservatively while the styles that flourished around it came and went,

title: Taft Gets Channel 20
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said that it had reached a definitive agreement to purchase the stock of Channel 20 Inc., a unit of the Superior Tube Company, for $13.5 million. The final transaction is subject to approval from the Federal Communications Commission. Channel 20 operates WDCATV in Washington, D.C.

title: 21 Killed as Quake Rocks Japan; Northern Coast City Severely Hit
description: TOKYO, June 12 (Reuters)Japan's densely populated main island of Honshu was rocked today by the strongest earthquake to hit the country in 14 years, and at least 21 people died and 350 were injured as buildings and power lines crumbled. At least two others were reported missing.

title: A Convenient Luxury: Limousines Are Becoming Commonplace

Mary Anne Krupsak withdrew as a candidate for reelection today, charging that Governor Carey was inaccessible and unwilling to fulfill his obligations of office. Her move, made as Mr. Carey was formally announcing his candidacy for reelection, threw the state Democratic Party into turmoil.

title: Plucking The Naked Goose
description: The injustice of the property tax is that it is a tax on potential wealth rather than real wealth. Let's say you are a well setup young man with a bull neck and ample thigh girth and you have gone into the hairdressing business, that you have a small shop in a suburban shopping mall and are happily getting by on $25,000 a year and are having a good time cutting and spraying hair.

description: HOUSTON, June 12A former assistant chief of the Houstop police was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of perjury, obstruction of justice and extortion.

title: News Summary

title: The Obsession of Solzhenitsyn
description: If anyone has earned the right to call the West to moral reckoning, it is Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. The high courage and conviction which sustained him in the Soviet Gulag have captured the admiration of all free mole. So his criticisms of America, excerpted on this page, compel attention and cut deep. Yes, our laws are used by the rich and powerful to gain more wealth and power; our press is often irresponsible; television is swamp of nonsense; pornography does flourish; and, yes, the nation is in thrall to material things. But given all that, Mr. Solzhenitsyn's world view seems to us far more dangerous than the easygoing spirit which he finds so exasperating.

title: Police Manpower Tripled In the Times Square Area
description: The New York City police have begun] a newand unannounceddrive to clean up the Times Square area by tripling the number of uniformed foot patrolmen in the neighborhood on most nights. The move has increased the size of the force to over 100 officers.

In the doubles final, Betty New- field of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Marilyn Katz of North Hills, L.I., beat Louise Cilia of Whitestone, Queens, and Kathy Dalton of Port Washington, L.I., 63, 60.

description: The Polaroid Corporation said that exploratory talks to find a basis for settling its patentinfringement suits against the Eastman Kodak Company had not led to an agreement. Polaroid said it therefore intended to continue to prosecute vigorously the actions against Kodak.

Marcos opened the first session of the Philippines new interim assembly today, calling it a signal change in the evolution of our political life, but said that for the time being he would not lift the martial law under which he has ruled since September 1972.

description: MADRID, June 12  Lastminute lobbying by Spanish banking interests appears to he delaying the Government's issuance of a major decree that would permit foreign banks to open branches and subsidiaries in Spain for the first time since the civil war.

description: A major show of ancient Greek art from Greek museums, covering more than 3,000 years, will take place next year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: President Envies Pages For Knowledge of Hill
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI). President Carter told a group of young Capitol Hill pages today that if he had known, when he first came to Washington, as much as they did about how to deal with Congress he might have been more successful in the last year.

title: Castro Says Carter Was Deceived
description: HAVANA, Tuesday, June 13President Fidel Castro charged early today that President Carter had been manipulated and deceived by elements in his own Administration concerning last month's invasion of Zaire's Shaba Province by Katangan troops. He blamed Zbigniew Brzezinski, the President's adviser en nationalrarity.

title: Downs Named 20/20
description: One week after its debut, and after a wave of negative reviews around the country, ABC News has put the scalpel to its primetime magazine series, 20/20, dismissing the two hosts and eliminating many of the departmental features.

title: TRUDEAll INTRODUCES CONSTITUTION PLAN
description: OTTAWA, lune 12Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trucl,au today introduced in Parliament his longawaited proposal for a new Canadian constitution inc9rporating a bill of rights and guarantees to linguistic minorities, among other changes.

title: COMMERCE OFFICIALS LIFT SECRECY ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The Commerce Department has lifted the controversial secrecy order that its Patent and Trademark Office had imposed on publicly funded research on computer security conducted at the University of WisconsinMilwaukee, Government officials confirmed today.

title: Aberdeen Told to Vote On Changing Address
description: ABERDEEN TOWNSHIP, June 12 (AP)If the residents here want to get mail addressed to Aberdeen Township, instead of Matawan Township, they are going to have to vote on Postal Service change, a White House spokesman said today.

title: TV: Skyline
description: WNILE the television halfhour might seem limited to carrying little more than situation comedies soap operas and game programs, the form can still emit occasional glimmerings of additional energy. On public television, for instance, Channel 13 has come up with Skyline, a series focusing on the cultural riches of New York. So far, separate essays have covered JeanPierre Rampal, the flutist, on a tour in the city: the Monet exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and, with Edward Villella as hot, classes at the School of American Ballet, which will be repeated tonight at midnight.

title: Study Finds Loss of Members By Major Protestant Churches
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)The major Protestant denominations lost. members in 1976, but increases were reported by evangelical, Pentecostal and Roman Catholic churches, the National Council of Churches said today.

title: Syrians Guilty In Bribery Case
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 12 (Reuters)  Eight employees of the staterun Syrian National Oil Company were found guilty yesterday of accepting $4.7 million in bribes from unidentified foreign companies and sentenced to jail terms ranging from eight months to 15 years.

title: White House Aides Say Carter Has No Plans to Meet With Sadat
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters)President Carter has no plans for a meeting with President Anwar elSadat, White House officials said today.

title: United Press International
description: A SPORTING GOVERNOR: It was a busy weekend on the playing fields for Governor Byrne. First, he played a little pickup with Mayors Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City. Yesterday the Governor officiated at a footrace around the Capitol between Assemblyman Peter Shapiro, above left, and Senator Brian T. Kennedy, with proceeds from heavy betting going to the Deborah Heart and Lung Center. Mr. Shapiro easily beat his rival.

title: Bache Buys Stock At $10.25 a Share
description: The Bache Group said that it had purchased 489,300 shares of its common stock in a private transaction at $10.25 a share. The Bache Group is a holding company for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, one of the nation's largest brokerage firms.

title: Cheyenne Indians Block Construction Of 2 Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 12In one of their biggest victories in years, the Northern Cheyenne Indians have, at least for the moment, succeeded in blocking the construction of two enormous coalfired electric power plants 15 miles from their reservation in Montana.

title: The Driver's Rule Book
description: David Klein, who began the DayE1 Livery with one car on the opening night of Follies, in 1971, now runs a fleet of 30 limousines as well as what he believes to be the city's only school for limousine chauffeurs. Some of the tips he gives to prospective DayE1 drivers are:

title: Jaws 2
description: WHEN Universial's newest mechanical shark  Jaws 2'-swims into 500 theaters on Friday, it will be dragging behind it more Tshires, bubblegum cards, beach towels, coloring books and loaves of sliced white bread than any other new movie in the history of a fantastically promotionminded industry.

title: Dekker Finds Books In Arcane Fields Are Money Crops
description: If you haven't picked up your copy of Chemistry of Acetylenes yet, you'd better hurry. The price recently jumped from $92.25 to $125 and, inflation being what it is, it will probably jump again.

title: BROCK SEEKS NO LIMIT ON CAMPAIGN COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, called today for the abolition of the spending limit in Presidential election campaigns and advocated the use of private contributions in addition to Federal funds in such campaigns.

title: Elderly Vacationers Stricken in New Jersey
description: Dozens of elderly vacationers on a package tour of South Jersey shore resorts were stricken with apparent food poisoning last night after eating lunch at the Smithville Inn colonial village near Atlantic City, authorities reported.

title: Film: 'The Popovich Brothers':A Loving Look
description: THE POPOVICH Brothers of South Chicago," a 60-minute documentary about the small but fiercely close-knit Serbian community in this country, heads the week's new film program opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art.The film is the work of Jill Godmilow, who co-produced and co-directed "Antonia: A Portrait of the Woman" with Judy Collins, and was commissioned by the Balkan Arts Center. It's a loving examination of Serbian customs, family ties and especially Serbian music, as represented by the Popovich Brothers, who played and sang for their countrymen around America for more than 50 years.Also on the Whitney bill is Dennis Pies's short, beautiful, animated film, "Sonoma," an expressionist recollection of what seem to be landscapes, sea-scapes and times of day executed in pencil and vivid watercolors.

title: Steel Price Action: Last Big Strauss Gain?
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  On the platform in the White House briefing room, Robert S. Strauss was exultant. A major breakthrough, he called the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's decision to raise prices by roughly 3 percent and not more.

title: Mass Production of Insulin Hinted
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)The artificial creation of rat insulin may point the way to mass production of human insulin and an unlimited supply of the hormone that keeps many diabetics alive, researchers say.

title: Prices of Cattle Futures Decline by 1.5c a Pound
description: Prices of live cattle futures closed down as much as 1.5 cents a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Because cattle futures were up about a halfcent a pound shortly after the opening, the day's decline was roughly 2 cents, or $800 per contract of 40.000 pounds.

title: Austin T. Cushman, Retired Chairman Of Sears, Roebuck
description: Austin T. Cushman. retired chairman and chief executive officer of Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retail organization, died yesterday in a hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in San Marino, Calif.

title: Derailed Tanker Safely Moved
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., June 11 (UPI)Workers righted a derailed tank car car ruing liquid butane today and rolled it to safety, averting the possibility of an explosion. The authorities then reopened the 16-square-block area from which more than 100 people were evacuated after the derailment last night of four cars on a Union Pacific freight. No one was injured in the accident, which a rail road spokesman blamed on a worn switch

title: Yanks in Auction for Rod Carew
description: The auction for Rod Carew has begun. By midnight Thursday, the major league trading deadline, baseball's best hitter expects to have been dealt by the Minnesota Twins to one of five contendersthe New York Yankees, the California Angels, the Texas Rangers, the Kansas City Royals or the Boston Red Sox. Those are the only clubs that Rod Carew would accept being traded to, as listed last week in a letter to Calvin Griffith, the Twins owner, after their contract negotiations collapsed with the 32-year-old first baseman spurning a $2million offer over five ycars. Over the weekend Calvin Griffith alerted those five teams that Rod Carew was available. And the Yankees are interested. Al Rosen, the Yankees president, acknowledeed yesterday that I'm going

title: Italians Vote Heavily to Retain Law That Widened Powers of the Police

title: CALIFANO SAYS H.E.W. CAN ABSORB $1 BILLION CUT
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, who last week implored Congress not to take a meat ax to his budget in a drive against waste, said the department can absorb a $1 billion cut without reducing any services.

description: Representative Bruce Caputo of Yonkers declared officially yesterday for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor and said his role would be expanded beyond the nonjob that the incumbent says she is abandoning.

title: Questions Remain After Decision On Milwaukee School Integration
description: MILWAUKEE, June 9After 13 years of litigation, a Federal court here has ruled that, at least since 1950, decisions by Milwaukee public school officials were undertaken with an intent to segregate students and teachers by race.

title: 21 Killed as Quake Rocks Japan; Northern Coast City Severely Hit
description: TOKYO, June 12 (Reuters)Japan's densely populated main island of Honshu was rocked today by the strongest earthquake to hit the country in 14 years, and at least 21 people died and 350 were injured as buildings and power lines crumbled. At least two others were reported missing.

title: Mentor and Students Test Limits of Matter
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  On a steep, wooded hillside looking toward San Francisco Bay, a score or so of men and women, most of them young and casually dressed, are looking for the ultimate limit of matter.

description: Uniroyal, one of tw.., nation's largest producers of footwear, announced yesterday that after 86 years it was getting out of the footwear business in the United States.

description: The First Boston Corporation yesterday became the third major dealer to cut fees on its commercial paper business, following the lead of Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, which lowered their prices earlier this spring.

Kennedy Memorial Stadium. The ccurt's action means the Redskins and the city government hero soon may have to stand trial on antitrust charges.

title: PlayActing and the Police
description: While the leaders of the largest New York City municipal unions spoke generously of further sacrifice before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, the heads of the police union were threatening strike, legal picketing and rulebook action to win a higher pay raise than all other city workers. Even if they do not finally risk all illegal walkout, they promise a series of noisy demonstrations distracting police officers from their duties and widespread refusals to report for work whenever a patrol car or other condition of work is technically in violation of regulations. The most generous interpretation of these threats is that Samuel DeMilia, the head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, feels compelled to stage a bitter drama in the streets this summernot because he expects to get more that way but to survive as head of the union against more militant challengers.

title: GUILDNEWS TALKS RESUME; A STRIKE DEADLINE IS SET

title: Zairian Embassy Bombed in Bonn
description: BONN, June 12 (Reuters)A fire bomb exploded at the Embassy of Zaire here early today, causing slight damage. Leaflets scattered in front of the embassy were signed by a group calling itself the People's Army of the Oppressed in Zaire, Foreign Brigade. A 'similar fire bomb was placed two months ago, apparently by the same group, the police said.

Murrow, puts the question of television and the First Amendment in an imminently serious way: Network and station executives who seek the same protection afforded print journalism, he says, are asking for freedom of the press  and, at the same time, monopoly to operate the unly press in town.

description: WASHINGTON, June 12The General Accounting Office, in a report made public today, joined tie rasing criticism of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which it said had failed to act promptly and effectively to protect consumers from hazardous products.

description: Witnesses for New York City testified yesterday that provisions of a 1975 wagedeferral agreement affecting municipal employees limited the city's liability for repayment to a period ending this June 30.

In fact she is almost transfixed as she focuses on the witness addressing the chairman. The chairman's left ear seems cocked to catch her next whispered remark, even though his face expresses impatience as the long hearing on S2 billion in longterm loan guarantees for New York City drones on.

title: LAS VEGAS OPERATOR PLANS CASINO IN YEAR
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 13 The. operators of Caesars Palace, one of the most successful gambling casinos in Las Vegas, announced today that they had leased choice property in the heart of Atlantic City and planned to open a casinohotel on it within a year.

title: U.S.S.R. Rock Concert
description: Bill Graham, the San Francisco rock promoter, will produce a free largescale concert in Leningrad on July 4 featuring the Beach Boys, Santana and Tnan Baez. The concert which is ex- pected to attract 200,000 persons, will mark the first time that major American rock and folkrock performers have appeared in the Soviet Union. The event will be formally announced at a news conference in San Francisco today.

title: Young Satisfied by His Role in Carter's African Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 13The way Andrew Young tells it, the Carter Administration has not veered from its African policy, talk about infighting in Washington concerning Africa policy has been grossly exaggerated, and the United States is gaining and the Soviet Union is losing influence in Africa.

title: City U. Freshmen Good in Reading but Bad in Math
description: More than threequarters of the freshmen who are to enter the City University of New York's fouryear senior colleges next fall are reading at the 12thgrade level or betterconsiderably above the average for high school seniorsbut are seriously deficient in mathematics, according to the universitywide basic-comnetencv examinations.

description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 13Gov. David Pryor defeated Representative Jim Guy Tucker tonight in a bitterly contested runoff election for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

title: Ending the Oil Entitlements
description: Yesterday  a year, a month and 24 days since President Carter proposed his National Energy Plan Congressional conferees completed their agreement to decontrol natural gas prices. If the two houses concur, the nation will have taken an important step toward the rational use of energy. But Congress cannot stop there. A true energy policy still must deal with the nation's slavish dependence on foreign oil. That is why the centerpiece of the Carter program was a tax on oil and why the case for that tax remains compelling.

Notte hopes he can get the publicity that eluded him as the uncontesteJ candidate for the Republican nomination After a highly publicized campaign, Mr. Shapiro, it 26-year-old State As.;embly man from Irvington, narrowly won last Tuesday in a field of four contenders His victory was so close that Sheriff John F. Cryan. vino ran second, has won a court order for a recount on Friday. Little change is expected, however, in the 2,500vote margin.

In a sense, where the character and flavor of most fish is concerned, this is unfortunate, because fish cooked with their bones intact are generally more distinctive. It is no fantasy: the nearer the bone the sweeter the meat.

title: Film: 'A Different Story':Caught in Switches
description: THE lovers in "A Different Story," which opens today at the Baronet Theater, don't meet cute, they meet adorable Stella (Meg Foster), a real-estate sales representative who seems to deal exclusively in mansions, first encounters Albert (Perry King) because he is the chauffeur and Boy Friday of one of her homosexual male clients. Later, after Albert's lover has found a new driver, Stella is showing another palazzo and finds Albert camping in it. She invites him to stay on the sofa of her comfortable apartment.He stays for good, and soon the comfortable mess is no more. Because Albert is a homosexual, you see, he likes to cook, vacuum, fluff pillows and hang up Stella's clothes.The Gay Activists' Alliance has circulated a letter expressing alarm about "A Different Story," and, indeed, the group has a point.Albert, thinking himself very clever, tells Stella at dinner one night "Yes I have, several and not particularly," in answer to three questions he anticipates her asking. ("Have I ever been with a woman, how many, and did I like it?") But Stella turns out to be a lesbian, so she isn't nearly as shocked by this as Albert expects her to be. Albert and Stella don't appear to remain homosexual for long: they marry, have a baby, buy a Mercedes, move into a big house with too much wallpaper, and squabble just as other couples do.The movie's use of their homosexuality is indeed exploitative, insensitive, and offensive in a variety of ways. Even worse, it is unconvincing. For all of Mr. King's mincing, preening and complaining about how Miss Foster's tardiness has made him scorch their dinner, Albert's homosexuality is nothing but a gimmick, something for the screenplay to coax him out of. Mr. King makes Albert so unattractive that it's hard to care about his taking the cure.Mr. King is much worse than the movie, which is no mean accomplishment Miss Foster is much better, with an aggressive vitality that lets her upstage Mr. King at every turn. But her talents are continually undercut by the direction of Paul Aaron, who makes the kind of debut that ought to be a swan song. Mr. Aaron's ineptitude knows no bounds, especially when it comes to blasting an insufferable score, ending scenes at uninteresting moments, and making the film's chronology completely obscure. After a while, the only way to mark time is by counting Albert's divine little dinners.The film's notion of reversing sex roles is not without comic potential. But there's something quite ugly about its manner of accepting sexual stereotypes in the first place, just for the sake of shuffling them around.

title: CHARLES A. SEVERS

title: Rock: Cheap Trick Quartet
description: CHEAP TRICK, a hardrock quartet from Chicago that fills stadiums in the Midwest and in Japan but has not yet become a household word around here, cut short its second set at the Bottom Line on Monday night. Robin Zander, the lead sinner complained that he was losing his voice. One was scarcely surprised. The group was pumping out enough decibels to fill Shea Stadium, and one stumbled out of the Bottom Line with whole frequency bands of one's hearing rendered inoperable. Even though he was singing through a beefedup public address system, Mr. Zander had to bellow just to be heard.

Mercado and El Cronista Comercial said Mr. Delgado, who is 44 years old, married and has two children, vanished in his car after visiting his doctor. Sources close to the family said his disappearance was not disclosed earlier because of private efforts to find him.

title: Personal Health
description: THIS year more than 90,000 American women will be diagnosed as having breast cancer. For the vast majority, their second chance at life will cost them the loss of a part of their bodies that has become endowed with far more emotional and cosmetic significance than its main biological function would imply. In bosomoriented American society, the breast is often regarded as a visible symbol of a woman's femininity, sexuality and desirability. Little wonder, then, that for many women who must lose a breast to cancer the scar is more than skin deep.

title: Include Head Start Out

It is a poor idea for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that it would move the Head Start program out of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Lobbying for City Aid Stepped Up As Proxmire Unit Ends Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, June I3The Carter Administration today stepped up its lobbying on behalf of the New York City loanguarantee legislation as a new compromise embodying loan guarantees was being proposed by a Senator who had opposed aid for the city.

title: Disturbed Youngsters Are Still in There Pitching
description: Lylenett Bolding never had a chance to warm up, but his first three pitches were fast, high and inside the netexactly where he wanted them.

title: Toyota, Toyo Exports Up
description: TOKYO, June 13 (UPI)  The Toyota Motor Company announced today that car exports in May were up 7.9 percent from the level of the year before. Meanwhile, Toyo Kogyo, maker of Mazda cars, announced that its exports were up 10.1 percent for the same period.

title: Byrne Says DeathPenalty Veto Can Be Opposed
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 (AP)The New Jersey Legislature will get a chance to override a veto of capital punishment, Governor Byrne promised today.

description: ToTHELIvINGSEctioN:

title: Around the Nation
description: SRINGFIELD, Ill., June 13 (AP)Phyllis Schlafly, prominent opponent of the proposed equal rights amendment, says she could accept a modified amendment that guaranteed women the special rights she says they now have.

title: L.I. FinancialDisclosure Bill Voted
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 13After seven months of debate and repeated delays, the Suffolk County Legislature today approved legislation requiring elected county officials and top employees to file statements of their income, assets and liabilities.

title: ISRAELIS WITHDRAW LAST INVASION UNITS IN SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: MEIS ALJABAL, Lebanon, June 13Israeli military forces completed their withdrawal from southern Lebanon today, handing over a border strip about six miles deep to Lebanese Christian militia units rather than to the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Greenwich Rejects Plan for Subsidized Bus System
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 13Appre hension over government influence in this affluent town won out last night over concern for growing traffic congestion as the Representative Town Meeting rejected a proposed bus system subsidized with state and Federal funds.

title: Chess:
description: PASADENA, June 11After five rounds of the United States Championship, Grandmaster Anatoly Lein, a Russian emigre now living in Cleveland, held the lead with a 31

title: Yacht Has Rough Trip To the Start
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 13It was a less than a perfect morning on Rhode Island Sound today for Hector Domato and his crew of seven aboard the yacht Fantasma II, which had come all the way from Buenos Aires for the NewportBermuda ocean race.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Bottle Portraits

title: Panel Agrees on Gas Pricing.
description: WASHINGTON. June 13 (AP) HouseSenate energy conferees completed work on the naturalgas pricing section of President Carter's energy program today, clearing the way for final action on the legislation in both houses.

title: Drawing the Line at Studio 54
description: Cindy Stella from Martinsville, Incl., heard about Studio 54 on the Tonight show. Michael Di Fazio of New Rochelle read about it in a gossip column. And Claude Carre, a reporter for a French television station, saw pictures of it in a magazine.

title: MORTIMER WOLF, LAWYER AND A FORMER U.S. AIDE
description: Mortimer B. Wolf a trial and appellate lawyer here, died Monday in the Pritikin Longevity Center, Santa Monica, Calif., where he had been undergoing treatment. He was 66 years old and lived here at 203 East 72d Street.

title: The Seafaring Chef: Ship's Mainstay During a Big Race
description: STATING Friday afternoon, Stuart Ingersoll of Essex, Conn., will feed 10 men three times day for the next five days In an aim with a 20-by-24-inch floor space and 24-by-36-inch counter space. Moreover, none of these surfaces can be relied on to remain either level or steady at any given time. In actuality, the kitchen described is the galley of the 43foot sloop Emily, which will be competing with about 160 other craft from Newport, R.I., to Bermuda in the annual Bermuda Race.

title: SOVIET POLICE SEIZE A U.S. BUSINESSMAN
description: MOSCOW, June 13An American businessman representing International Harvester was pulled out of his automobile last night by Moscow policemen and taken into custody on a charge of smuggling, the American Embassy disclosed today.

title: TV: Norman Conquests
description: ALAN AYCKBOUFtN is often called the Neil Simon of England. He's not. His peculiar domestic comedies, including How the Other Half Loves and Absurd Person Singular, are much more complex and infinitely sadder than the typical collection of Simon gags, Mr. Ayckbourn comes closer to resembling Ingmar Bergman in search of a television situation comedy. Scenes from his marriages are most penetrating when most daffy.

title: JapanE.E.0 Talks
description: TOKYO, June 12 (UPI)  Japan and the European Economic Community will hold highlevel consultations in Tokyo June 22 and 23 to exchange views on various economic issues, the Government announced today.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMRoy E. Our sincerest condolences are extended to Daniel Abraham, dedicated member of our Global Board of Trustees and The Abraham Family on the passing of Roy E. Abraham.

title: American Distilling Buying Brown Stock
description: The American Distilling Company said its board had approved an agreement between the company and Mr. and Mrs. Russell R. Brown for the purchase of 110,000 of their 160,000 shares of the company's common stock at $11.75 a share. The company intends to use the shares principally to satisfy outstanding stock options.

title: Deaths
description: FERNBACHToni. Beloved aunt who was like another mother to us. We loved you and will miss vou.

title: New York City Gets EarlyTax Bonanza: It Totals 151 Million
description: New York City took in about $150.9, million in early tax payments yesterday. enough cash to allow the city to pay its bills for the rest of the fiscal year, which ends June 30.

title: Wine Talk
description: BERNARD GRIVELET, a wine producer whose name will be familiar to burgundy lovers, was in New York recently to promote his wines. What he had to say about French wine laws was, in some ways, more interesting than what he had to say about his wines.

title: Dance: Miss Alonso Stars in Giselle
description: THE National Ballet of Cuba made its New York debut last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a fantastic production of Giselle, starring its founder-director-prima ballerina, Alicia Alonso, in the title role.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY. JUNE 14, 1978

title: John Jay Takes Title on NoHitter
description: Luis Figueroa, an 18-year-old senior righthander, pitched a nohitter yesterday as John Jay of Brooklyn captured the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship by beating John Bowne of Queens, 20, at Yankee Stadium. It was John Jay's first P.S.A.L. playoff appearance.

title: Miss Platzer Leads in Golf
description: MUTTONTOWN, L.I., June 13Nancy Platzer shot a 77 today, tnre strokes over par, but still led the opening round of the 2Sth annual Women's CrossCounty Golf Association 54hole medal championship over the 5,780vard Muttontown Club course.

title: Rhodesian Authorities Censor Part: Of Speech by a Former Premier.
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 13 (AP)Military censors ordered reporters today to delete parts of a speech by former Pr.ime Minister Garfield Todd in which he criticized the killing of 22 blacks by security forces.

title: Technology
description: WASHINGTON

title: Castro Tells Congressmen of Bid To Prevent the Invasion of Zaire
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Fidel Castro told two visiting Congressmen during a ninehour meeting that ended this morning that Cuba had been aware of rumors of a planned attack by Katangan rebels agaiost Zaire from Angola and had persuaded President Agostinho Neto of Angola to issue instructions last February to try to prevent the raid.

title: Guild Strikes at The Daily News But Pacer Is Printed and Delivered
description: About 1,340 news and commercial employees struck The Daily Newsthe largestcirculation daily in the countryyesterday, but management produced a 64page issue without them and about half of The News's deliverytruck drivers crossed the picket line to distribute the papers.

title: Notes on People
description: BRITAIN pulled out most of the ceremonial stops yesterday to welcome President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, the first Communist leader to pay a state visit to that nation. Queen Elizabeth II met the Rumanian President and his wife, Elena, at the Victoria railway station. They rode through the streets of London, decked with flags for the occasion, in a horsedrawn open carriage escorted by 120 horsemen of the Queen's household cavalry. In addition, some 2,000 troops lined the route to Buckingham Palace, where President Ceausescu will be the first Communist head of state to be the Queen's honored guest. His visit had been preceded by protests in the press and from Rumanian exiles. President Ceausescu's fourday visit will include talks with British Government leaders on EastWest relations and economic cooperation.

title: 50 Lawmakers Urge Carter To End Trade With Uganda
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)Fifty members of Congress urged President Carter today to terminate trade with Uganda in order to remove American support of President Idi Amin.

title: N.B.A. Sifts Violence
description: The National Basketball Association discussed violence on the court and third official at its annual meeting. Page B11.

title: TM New York Times
description: COMMISSIONER FOR A DAY: Peggy Stein, 16, being sworn in as Police Commissioner for a day at Police Headquarters. Miss Stein won first prize in Police Athletic League essay, contest; she suggested a buddy sys-

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett
description: A MEETING OF PEERS: Hundreds of elderly citizens of the New Jersey Coordinating Council of Organized Older Citizens meeting at the Garden State Arts Center. They listened to speeches by leaders, sang songs and discussed mutual problems at the fourth-anniversary assemblage.

title: Hornsby's .400 Years
description: Rogers Hornsby, while playing for the St. Louis Cardinals, batted over 400 three times. He hit .401 in 1922, 424 in 1924 and .403 in 1925.

title: Southern Baptists Alter Focus of Antigambling Battle
description: ATLANTA, June 13While the drive to expand legalized gambling has gained ground in many parts of the nation. Southern Baptists are renewing efforts to defeat such practices, having won a recent battle in Texas.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS STRUCK BY THE GUILD
description: About 1,340 news and commercial employees struck The Daily News, the largestcirculation daily in the country, at 2 P.M. yesterday, but the paper's management produced a 64page issue without them.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Reflecting the steep rise in interest rates this spring, yields on tripleA taxexempt state bonds yesterday climbed to their highest levels in .more than a year and a half as Illinois borrowed $150 million in the capital market.

title: Real Estate
description: THE world has heard of the 39 steps. But what are the 82 steps? They are the stations along the route to a longterm loan from the New York City Community Preservation Corporation for an older tenanted apartment house. And to change the metaphor to one of a nautical persua. sion, a variety of hazardous reefs line the course.

title: Seagram Net Up In Quarter
description: The Seagram Company Ltd. reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter ended April 30 were up, although those for the nine months declined.

title: White's 2 Homers Key Yank Victory
description: Roy White, the switchhitting outfielder who has more seniority than any of his fellow Yankee employees, demonstrated last night that there is good reason for him to keep punching the New York team's time clock.

title: Panel Votes $19.4 Billion BudRet For Agriculture Department in 75
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The, House Appropriations Committee proved today a $19.4 billion Agriculture Department budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, rejecting a plea for changes by Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ABOUT TIME The popular Music for a City Evening concerts are back. The fifth season of the 90minute outdoor series resumes today at 4:30 P.M. at Rockefeller Center's Channel Gardens between 49th and 50th Streets. Bobby Shcrt leads the warmweather parade of stars, singing and playing Cole Porter, Non Coward and Rodgers and Hammerstein at the keyboard, backed by a bassist and a drummer.

title: U.S. Bars Antitrust Exemption That Hospitals Sought to Help Curb Costs
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Justice Department announced today that it wauld not grant an antitrust exemption to the nation's hospitals for their voluntary effort to hold down costs.

title: Berkowitz in Prison; More Tests Are Due
description: David R. Berkowitz was taken to the State Correctional Facility at Ossining, N.Y., yesterday to start serving 25 years to life for the Son of Sam murders.

title: A.C.L.U., at a Parley on Free Speech, Defends Its Aid to Nazis at Skokie
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday held a daytong convocation on free speech in an effort to rally its declining membership, refill its coffers and offset the nationwide criticism of its defense of the rights of a Nazi group to demonstrate in Illinois.

title: Issues in Strike at The Daily News
description: ParticipantsThe Newspaper Guild of. New York, which went on strike at 2 P.M. yesterday, claims 1,340 news slid commercial members at The Daily News. The newspaper; which employs 5.100 workers overall, has the country's largest daily circulation of 1.9 million, and a Sunday circulation of 2.7 million.

title: Carter News Parley On at 3 P.M. Today
description: All three television networksCBS, NBC and ABCand their local stations Channels 2, 4 and 7have scheduled live telecasts at 3 P.M. today of President Carter's news conference in Washington. The conference will also be broadcast live by WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA and WNYCAM.

title: Carey and Running Mate Cuomo Forget Barbs and Trade Plaudits
description: ALBANY, June 13  Governor Carey and his new running mate, Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo, appeared together today as the top of their party's ticket and, patching up their differences from last year's New York City mayoral race, praised each other.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Finkelstein Is Promoted To Chairman of Macy's

title: Equity Leader Chides N.L.R.B. for Stupidity
description: Donald Grody, executive secretary of Actors Equity, yesterday denounced the National Labor Relations Board for having filed a complaint against the actors union. He said the board had shown arrogance and stupidity, and a thirst for publicity, and might cause disruption in the American and British theater.

title: Visitors From Another Viewpoint
description: ONE of the reasons why fanatics are so unpopular outside their own circles is because they are so crystal clear about the point life. This makes people who aren't so clear uneasy. Furthermore, the fanatic tends to jab his noint where it's not invited, like into your stomach, and this makes people who consider the point of life private matter, mad. But I have always admired the fanatics for a certain singlemindedness I am not capable of, a humility that gives them the courage speak when not spoken to.

title: Parole Unit Puts Off Release of Galante Pending a Hearing
description: Carmine Galante, a reputed leader of organized crime in New York, was told by the United States Parole Commission yesterday that he would not be released from prison today as previously scheduled.

title: Caesars Palace Operators Plan Atlantic City Casino Hotel in 79
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 13The operators of Caesars Palace, one of the most successful gambling casinos in Las Vegas, announced today that they had leased choice property in the heart of Atlantic City and planned to open a casinohotel on it within a year.

title: Cruise Missile To Be Effective But Expensive
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The cruiF..e missile program, with its military advantages and implications for the nuclear arms race, is emerging as the most extensive and expensive weaponssystem development in Defense Department history.

title: Two Anchorage Publishers Await Arbitrator's Rulin in Trust Suit
description: ANCHORAGE, June 13For Katherine Fanning, publisher of The Anchorage Daily News, the issue is, We want some input to management.

title: Cosmos Top Kicks With Rally, 42
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 13The Cosmos showed 46,370 fans at Metropolitan Stadium tonight the kind of poise that separates the most successful team in the North American Soccer League from the second most successful.

title: Concert: Schubert
description: THIS year mrarks the 150th anniversary of Schubert's death, and Carnegie Hall IS noting the occasion by presenting five evenings of his music. Each program will extend over tour hours, with the American Symphony Orchestra's performances of a complete cycle of his symphonies as the central event. This minimarathon format, as an orchestra press releease calls it, has some justification in Schubert's case. Schumann was referring to the Great Symphony in C when he spoke of those heavenly lengths, but the phrase can apply to much of Schubert's music.

title: In America, Fashion as a Grace Note
description: THE excitement over the fall fashion openings on both sides of the Atlantic has receded into history. Back in the design rooms, attention is being paid to the seasons ahead.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of precious metals futures shot forward yesterday as traders saw more negative than positive economic news. For one, the. Japanese yen set new high against the dollar, while the stock market showed signs of running out of steam, and several major banks indicated they would lift the prime rate from the current level of 8.5 percent.

title: National Steel to Lift Prices by 3%
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest steel company, fell into line yesterday and said it was raising its prices on steel by 3 percent, a level that has been endorsed by the leaders of the Carter Administation's effort to slow inflation.

title: Missouri Firemen Given Ultimatum On Their Second Strike This Spring
description: HAZELWOOD, Mo., June 13 (UPI)A judge has given striking firemen until Thursday to reach a contract agreement with city officials or face further court action.

title: JAMES ELLIS, AN EXCHIEF OF KUDNER ADVERTISING
description: James H. S. Ellis, retired president of the Kudner Advertising Agency, died Sunday in Hot Springs, Va., near his summer residence. He was 85 years old and lived in Reno.

title: Cause Is Being Sought In Illness of 42 Riders
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., June 13 (AP)A Pennsylvania woman remained hospitalized in satisfactory condition here today, 24 hours after she and 42 other elderly tourists were stricken with severe stomach cramps, nausea and diarrhea.

title: Zaire Agrees to Control by I.M.F. In Return for Economic Assistance
description: BRUSSELS, June 13Zaire agreed in principle today to wideranging international control over its economy as part of a $1 billion plan for shoring up the shaky Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: Court of Appeals Upholds Power Of Regents Over State University
description: A four-year-old conflict between the two most powerful educational bodies in the state was resolved yesterday by the New York Court of Appeals, which upheld the right of the Board of Regents to close two doctoral programs at the State University Center at Albany.

title: ExSoviet Worker Is Rebuffed
description: The way Victor Herman tells it, he is the last of 300 Americans who went to the Soviet Union in 1931 under a contract with the Ford Motor Company to help build an auto factory in Gorky. He became an athlete, winning championships in track and marksmanship. Later he became a stunt pilot and instructor and set an early world record for parachute lumping.

description: BUENOS AIRES, June 14  Peru,a surprise team in the first round of the World Cup soccer championship, was routed, 30, tonight by Brazil, heretofore a disappointing team.

title: Books of The Times
description: AFTER reading this odd memoir, I wentback to look at Of Human Bondage for the first time in 25 years. Of all Meugham's novels, it was the one I remembered best. It is, of course, a perfect book for 15yearolds: the sensitive youth, the hopeless, infatuation, the unworthy obieot that infatuates. CONVERSATIONS WITH WILLIE. Recollections of W. Somerset Maugham. By Robin Maugham. Illustrated. 188 pages. Simon & Schuster. $10.

title: Use of Private Planes For Politics Explained
description: ALBANY, June 14  The flights that Governor Carey and Lieut. Mary Anne Krupsak took throughout the state last Monday announcing their political plans were on private airplanes, paid for by independent political committees, aides to both officials said today.

title: Spying Is Back ith New Vigor
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Suddenly this spring it was all back in the headlines: secret agents, double agents, mail drops, code books and invisible writine There has been more public attention to international espionage in the last six months than at any time in a decade.

title: A Cold Shoulder Awaiting Carter in the Canal Zone
description: BALBOA, Canal Zone, June 14  Less than a mile from where, Panamanian workers are hanging up posters and fitigs to welcome President Carter on Friday, the Americans in the Canal Zone seem indifferent, if not hostile, to the 23hour visit, terming it variously as an affront and pure public relations.

title: AReligious Zionist Urges Compromise On Occupied Lands
description: Prof. Uriel Simon, a religious Zionist, bas been visiting this country to argue against those who say that the Bible commands Israel to hold every inch of the territory it occupies in the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip. The Bible also requires ethical standards and peace demands territorial compromise, he suggests.

description: THE RACE IS OFFICIAL: In Albany, Governor Carey and his choice as Lieutenant Governor, llario M. Cuomo, acknowledged State Democratic Party meeting's greeting, while in Manhattan, Republican nominee, Perry B. Duryea, appeared with his running mate, Rep. Bruce! Caputo. Pages B12 and B13.

title: Supreme Court, Reversing Itself, Narrows Ban on Double Jeopardy
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal defendant who at his trial wins dismissal of charges against him on grounds unrelated to factual guilt or innocence can be tried by the Government a second time.

title: L.I. Girl, 9, Found Murdered in Brook Had Been Molested
description: WESTPORT, June 14  A 9yearold girl whose body was found face down in a shallow brook last night had been sexually molested, according to a preliminary analysis, Police Chief William Stefan stefan.

title: Editor To Be Envoy to Netherlands
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  President Carter will nominate Geri Joseph, a contributing editor with The Minneapolis Tribune, to be ambassador to the Netherlands, the White House announced today. She is a member, of th' President's Commission on Mental Health.

title: William Robert Fraad, Chairman Of Top Allied Maintenance Panel
description: William Robert Fraad, chairman of the executive committee of the Allied Maintenance Corporation here for the last ten years, died in Port Chester (N.Y.) Hospital on Monday after a short illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Dorchester Road, Harrison, N.Y.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: States can bar oil companies from operating gasoline stations, the Supreme Court ruled in upholding a Maryland law calling for the divestiture of some 200 stations in that state. If other states pass similar laws, the result could be to stem the steady increase in share of the retail gasoline market held by oil refiners at the expense of independent local dealers. [Page D1].

title: New YorK, Art Lender
description: The purpose certainly was not to get any message across, especially not to Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, but the latest report of the Cultural Assistance Center discloses that, in the year ended last June 30, New York City's cultural institutions lent their expertise, talent and even their materials to a dozen places in Wisconsin, from Appleton to Sheboygan.

title: Three Students Reported Killed in Panama City Clash
description: PANAMA CITY, June 14  Three students were reportedly killed tonight during a gun battle between supporters and opponents of the Government that began during a.demonstration on the university campus against President Carter's visit here Friday.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Minority. Members To Get Better Jobs, Casino Promises
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 14  A Resorts International executive said today that steps had been taken to give members of minority groups better jobs in the hotel's casino.

title: Soviet Is Said to Have Warned U. S. Of Retaliation in Arrest of Russians
description: WASHINGTON, June L4  Authoritative sources said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko warned Secretary of State Cyprus R. Vance two weeks ago that the Soviet Union would soon retaliate against Americans in Moscow unless the United States released two Soviet employees of the United Nations being held on espionage charges.

title: WEST TO GIVE ZAIRE 3MONTH AID PACKAGE
description: BRUSSELS, June 14  A twoday conference of nations considering assistance to Zaire ended here today with an agreement in principle to extend enough emergency aid to meet the immediate needs of its crisistorn economy over the next three months.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS CALL FOR ARMS LIMIT
description: ATLANTA, June 14  The Southern Baptists, joining a broad range of religious groups, today added a voice to the growing statements of concernabout arms control.

title: Home Improvement
description: REGARDLE of how many hand or power tools a home carpenter may have, no tool* box or workshop is complete without a few highquality wood chisels. They are used for many cut.

title: A Palestinian Solution
description: The idea of a Palestinian state raises such emotions that it is usually debated, or dismissed, in terms of passion and slogan, without any reasoned discussion of what such a state would be. That gap is filled by a notable art!. cle in the new issue of the quarterly Foreign Affairs. It is by Walid Khalidi, a Palestinian who is professor of political studies at the American University, Beirut.

title: Mopping Up After a Disaster
description: AT 8:30 on a Monday morning in March, a building superintendent in the East 40's slipped a monkey wrench around an old steam radiator valve and tugged. Instead of stopping a tiny leak, he created a $50,000 disaster. The valve snapped off, sending a geyser of steam and hot water into Carol Brener's sixroom apartment.

title: PrimeTime Special News Report Is Back on NBC
description: The primetime special news report, something missing for at least a year and a half from NBC, will return to the network tomorrow, and the impetus for.the reversion to the custom appears to have come from NBC's new president, Fred Silverman.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aetna Business Credit Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Aetna Life and Casualty Company, engaged in old line factoring, general commercial financing, and intermediateterm lending, has elected Richard B. Polivy vice president and general counsel.

title: Woman Surrenders In Big Welfare Case
description: COMPTON, Cahf June 14 (UPI A 32year old woman who owns a $170,000 home and two cars, including a Cadillac, surrendered to the authorities today to face 23 counts of welfare fraud in which she allegedly collected nearly $290,000 for 30 children she did not have.

title: Pilots Parachute in West Germany
description: BONN, June 14 (Reuters)  Three military pilots, an American and two Britons, ejected from their planes and parachuted safely but with minor injuries in separate crashes in West Germany today, military spokesmen reported.

title: Virchem Purchase
description: Plans for the purchase of a substantial minority interest in Virchem S. A., a wholly owned Belgian subsidiary of Virginia Chemicals, were announced in Brussels by UCB S.A., a diversified chemical and drug producer. A spokesman for Virginia Chemicals said that the value of the purchase could not be immediately determined. Virchem plans to build a plant at Ghent, Belgium, for production of higher amines that would serve European markets now served from the United States. Construction is scheduled to start early next year. It will be financed primarily with overseas borrowings by Virchem.

title: Stage: Getting Act Together New Room at the Guggenheim
description: I' M Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Rdad is a musical entertainment about a 39yearold woman finding herselt.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Copper futures prices timbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in record trading volume after several major producers cut their cash price at least 2 cents a pound.

title: RULING POSTPONED ORTION FUNDS
description: NEWARK, June 14  A State Superior Court judge today postponed a ruling on lawsuit challenging the New Jersey law restricting Medicaid funds for abortion after assurances by physicians that the plaintiff, a Newark woman in ther 12th week of pregnancy, would not require medical attention before next.week.

description: Ed Towles

title: Soviet Official Calls for Trade
description: Leading a mission meeting with American business leaders on trade development, Leonid A. Kostandov, the Soviet Minister of the Chemical Industry, said yesterday that current tensions between Washington and Moscow were temporary.

title: Connors, Gottfried and Tanner Victors in GrassCourt Tennis Tourney
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, June 14 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors, Brian Gottfried and Roscoe Tanner advanced today in a $125,000 grasscourt tennis tournament, a tuneup for Wimbledon. Four other Americans, however, failed to survive  Tom Gullikson, Rick Fisher, Erik vaq Dillen and Terry Moor.

title: Associated Press
description: BULLISH BEAR: Jack Nicklaus, the pretournament favorite, teeing off during practice round for the U.S. Open, which begins today.

title: South's Confidence in Carter Slips But He Is Still Popular, Polls Show
description: ATLANTA, June 14  President Carter, suffering a lack of support in the rest of the country, swings briefly into his friendly home state Fricfay, but he had best be prepared for some more bad news in his own backyard: The home folks also think he is making a bad job of his Presidency.

title: A Functional, Flexible Beach House
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. SHE calls it Infinity after the phenomenon of the candles and the waves. It is the stilluncompleted house that Luba Marks started to build five years ago to serve as a refuge from the cramped spaces and frenetic activity of her Manhattan apartment and office. The phenomenon occurs at dusk any day that she happens to be ir. residence at her beach retreat in Southampton, L.I. The candles twinkle on the low white tables as a breeze from the ocean wafts through the sliding glass ceiling4ofloor doors. As the twilight deepens, the flames grow more distinct as they repeat endlessly in the mirrored walls. The boom of the surf fills the room, voices are lowered and reflections of the sea itself join the flickering lights in the mirrors.

title: Justice Dept., After Inquiry, Finds Charges Against Senior Aide False
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The Justice Department closed out an internal inquiry of a senior department official this week after concluding that charges of professional misconduct against him were false.

title: Books: The Politics of Fighting Cancer
description: IF AMERICANS could put men on the moon, then scientists with enough money and planning could cure cancer. That moon

title: Falk Says No to Press Junket
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14Angered over the advertising campaign for his new film, The Cheap Detective, Peter Falk has backed out of a New York press junket this week, leaving Columbia holding a $35,000 bag. Nearly 75 reporters and columnists will arrive in New York tomorrow to meet Peter Falk,. but Peter Falk will be in Boston.

title: Waldheim Criticizes Israel for Giving Lebanese Areas to Militia Forces
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim criticized Israel today for having turned over control of the Lebanese border strip evacuated yesterday to Lebanese Christian militia units rather than to the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: Mortgages Tighten In New York State
description: Thrift institutions and banks throughout New York State are turning away applicants for home mortgages or demanding higher down payments or other restrictive terms, according to realtors, bankers and state officials.

description: After nearly three months of searching hundreds of acres of rugged, Westchester County woodlands, a New York City detectftn:i yesterday found the skeleton of a 23yearold East Side woman who disappeared almost a year ago.

Mr. Carter, speaking at a news conference, called on the Cuban President and Angola to pledge to prevent any future Katangan invasion into southern Zaire's Sheba Province. [Page A1, Column I.1

title: Terrorist Bombs Badly. Damage Rome Power Plant
description: ROME, June 14  Terrorists detonated a chain of time bombs in a power plant on the outskirts of Rome early today, touching off a large fire that caused an estimated $600,000 worth of damage and left part of the city without power for several hours.

title: GARDENING
description: AROSE garden is a very special place. It's a flower that likes to be visited. In the morning, yesterday's bud has opened; in the afternoon, when the sun has warmed the petals, the fragrance is mellow. For, more than any other flower, the rose responds to care.

title: Dr. Vratislav Busek, 81, Authority On Czech Affairs and Canon Law.
description: Dr. Vratislav Busek, a writer on 1Czechoslovak affairs, an authority on canon law and a writer for Radio Free Europe for many years, died Tuesday after a heart attack in his home, 8510 34th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 81 veers old.

title: Goldberg at City Ballet
description: JEROME ROBB1NS took on quite an esthetic problem when he chose Bach's Goldberg Variations as a score for his ballet of the same name, choreographed in 1 971 for the New York City Ballet.

title: Around the Nation
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 14  The Illinois House of Representatives today voted to allow another vote on the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: An attempt by the domestic copper industry, to increase prices suffered a setback yesterday as three major producers announced that they were rolling back the price to 65 cents a pound from 67 cents on electrolytic copper.

title: WESTCHESTER PUTS CETA IN NEW HANDS
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 14  The Acting Westchester County Executive, J. Robert Dolan, said today that the county's Comprehensive and Employment Training Program, the target of a threepronged investigation, was being placed in new hands.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SIP TWO Along with new songs and sketches, the word more is being added to the title, A Little Wine With Lunch, as last season's musicalcabaret hit previews its second, summer tdition, starting tomorrow night. The place is the No Smoking Playhouse (but you can in the lobby) at 354 West 45th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues (next to the narking lots).

title: A.C.L.U. Leader Sees Need for Improvement Despite Rights Gains
description: Roger Baldwin was in his study, talking of law and justice, of terrorism, of Nazis, of civil rights and women's rights and the First Amendment. All of a sudden, he gave a speech impassioned, reasoned, loud.

title: Yarikees Edge Mariners, 119, Qh 4. in 10th
description: The New York Yankees, with two dramatic sequences in which they tied the score with a tworun homer in the eighth and won it with a threerun clout in the, 10th, beef:the Seattle Mariners; 119, at Yankee Stadium last night.
