title: Art: 19thCentury English Paintings
description: ONE of the problems about English art in the 19thcentury is that there is so much of it.Sometimes it seems as if there wasn't a man, woman or child in the whole country who wasn't scratching,away with a pen or pencil and dabbing away with the brush. Bishop and parricide, beggar and belted earl, poets like Gerard Manley.Hopkins and novelists like W.M.Thackerayall found their place in a period of art history that is only now being studied in the round.

title: Pop: Stones, Hottest Ticket in Passaic
description: PASSAIC N.J. AS rumored, the Rolling Stones played a concert at the 3,265seat Capitol Theater here Wednesday night, the third stop in a sixweek American tour that will include a number of other such theaters, as well as a few huge outdoor stadium dates.

title: Deaths
description: WEINSTEINEdward, MD.The Alumnae Association of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine is profoundly shocked and saddened by the untimely death of Dr.Edward C.Weinstein.A graduate of the Class of 1962, Dr.Weinstein has distinguished himself as an Associate Professor of Medicine at the College and served the Alumnae Association with dedication as cochairman of the Collecticut region and as a member of the Board of Govenors.

title: Caramoor Opens 32d Year
description: The grandeur of the museummansion and magnificently landscaped grounds at Caramoor, the former estate of the late Walter and Lucie Bigelow Rosen at Katonah, in Westchester County, is such that additional lures to attract visitors are scarcely needed. But this summer, as in the last 32 years, Caramoor will again present a music festival of uncommon quality with a varied array of weekend events for adults and children.Caramoor 78 is to begin tomorrow and will run through Aug.20.

title: Give the District the Vote
description: The District of Columbia's drive for equal suffrage, launched nearly two centuries ago, may actually be in sight of victory.Only recently granted the right elect their own mayor, District residents remain unrepresented on Capitol Hill, except for one nonvoting delegate in the House.In March, the House approved constitutional amendment assuring full voting representation in Congress.The measure enjoyed bipartisan backing.Now it's up to the Senate, where lingering opposition threatens passage.We hope the Senate will recognize that Washingtonians deserve the full privileges of citizenship.

title: Soviet Police And Detente
description: MOSCOW, June 15 The case of an American businessman arrested by the Moscow police Monday night has stirred deep.anxiety among Americans living in the Sqviet capital, and has raised important questions about the Kremlin's priorities and objectives in relations with the United States. A number of American officials and businessmen are convinced that the smuggling charges lodged against F.Jay Crawford, a 37yearold employee of the International Harvester Company, are complete fabrications made by Soviet authorities for political reasons not yet clear.Mr.Crawford is said to have flatly denied the allegat:ons, details of which have not been made public.

title: Ballet: Quicksilver Showcase
description: TCHAIKOVSKY Piano Concerto No.2 came into being in 1941 as Ballet Imperial, a work its creator, George Balanchine, intended as a classical showpiece of Russian ballet for a South American tour by the New York City Ballet (then Ballet Caravan).Thirtytwo year's later the ballet was given a new look.A backdrop and costumes evocative of imperial Russia have been replaced by simple flowing chiffon dresses and tunics and the familiar open empty stage, and the dance has been stripped of its original classical time.

title: Margaret B.Meyer Wed to Kjeld Hvatum
description: Margaret Butler Meyer and Kjeld Hvatum were married yesterday in St. Josephs Roman Catholic Church in St. Louis by the Rev.Frank Cleary.

title: Confidence Is Mark Of Guidry Success
description: Ron Guidry decides it is futile to talk in the clubhousetoo many interruptionsso he takes the key to the exercise room where he can have some privacy.Guidry shrugs; he has grown accustomed to this phase.

title: Market Place
description: THE Corning Glass Works, a company that has not performed well in economic downturns, may do better in such periods in future.That, at least, is one way of viewing the strength in the shares of this oldline, bluechip holding.

title: Auctions
description: ABONANZA of Americans in paintings, duck decoys, comicstrip art, toys, furnishings and Art Nouveau will be sold in New York in what promises to be.one of the liveliest weeks of late June sales ever mounted in the city.

title: U.S.Pilot Safe as F15 Crashes
description: EDINBURGH, June 15 (Reuters)  A United States Air Force F  15 fighter crashed into the North Sea on a routine mission today, and the pilot parachuted to safety.An Air Force spokesman said Capt.Henry B.Johnson, 32 years old, of Bethesda, Md., was in good condition after having been picked up by a ship.

title: Edelman Emerges as a G.O.P.Challenger For Seat Held by Representative Ottinger
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 15  Michael Edelman, a 30yearold assistant district attorney in Westchester County, entered the race in the 24th Congressional District today against the Democratic incumbent, Representative Richard L.Ottinger of Pleasantville, who is seeking his sixth term.

title: Heart Law Pension Provision Extended for Police and Firemen
description: ALBANY, June 15Legislative leaders have agreed to a oneyear extension of the controversial heart law, which lets policemen and firemen retire at threequarters pay if they develop a heart ailment during their employment.The move was another rebuff to the Koch administration, which had lobbied against extending the law.

title: Ruling on Tellico Dam Puts Other Projects in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Supreme Court's decision barring the Tennessee Valley Authority from closing the gates on the Tellico Dam, which could doom the snail darter, a rare species of fish, casts a cloud over 11 other major projects.

title: Notes on People
description: Just after being sworn in as a judge on Louisiana's Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, Jim Garrison, New Orleans's former District Attorney, said he couldn't resist getting in one more comment about his belief that Presi dent Kennedy was assassinated as part of a conspiracy.Judge Garrison conceded that he would have to be less controversial now, adding, This will be my final comment for some years on the matter, but I think before long, history is going to prove that I was right about some of my statements that were called controversial. In 1967, Judge Garrison prosecuted the late Clay Shaw, a businessman, on charges of conspiring with Lee Harvey Oswald and others to kill Mr.Kennedy. A jury deliberated less than an hour, after heari::g 40 days of testimony, beore acquitting Mr.Shaw.

title: DEMOCRATS IN ESSEX ELECT NEW LEADER
description: NEWARK, June 15A veteran political leader in Bloomfield was elected chairman of the Essex County Democratic Party organization early today.

title: News Summary
description: King Hussein of Jordan married Elizabeth Halaby, a 26yearold American, in a brief Moslem ceremony and later proclaimed her Queen.A statement by the royal palace indicated that the bride, nominally a Protestant, had become a Moslem.The marriage was the fourth for the 42yearold Jordanian monarch and followed a brief courtship.[Page Al, Columns 12.]

title: Amy Carter to Change Schools in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) President and Mrs.Carter have decided to transfer their 11yearold daughter.Amy, this fall from her predominantly black school near the White House to another public school in a fashionable section of Washington, officials announced today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel company, followed.other major steel makers and announced yesterday that it would increase its prices on steel by 3 percent, effective July 30.

title: PRESIDENT OF ITALY RESIGNS IN SCANDAL
description: ROME, June 15President Giovanni Leone of Italy announced his resignation tonight in a statement a few hours after the Communist Party had urged him to step down in the face of charges of corruption.

title: At the Movies
description: EVEN in an industry as given to extravagance as films, it isn't often that a performer's salary is questioned by the stockholders, but that's what happened recently at the annual meeting of MCA Inc., the parent corporation of Universal Pictures.At issue was the $242,349 paid to Lorraine Gary for her starring role in Jaws 2, which opens today at scores of theaters in the metropolitan area.

title: Plenty of Pizza and Coffee, but No Tension
description: ALBANY, June 15  If 357 delegates, 62 county chairmen, 30 state committeemen and 3,000 other participants could agree on just one thine today, it would be that they were attending the dullest Democratic convention in decades.

title: Israeli Accord on West Bank Seen
description: TEL AVIV, June 15An Israeli Cabinet source active in behindthescenes peace negotiations forecast tonight that Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government would reach consensus on Sunday on a controversy over the future of the Most Bank and the Gaza Strip and that a Cabinet crisis would be averted.

title: Rate Fears Send Dow Down 10.31
description: Takeover stocks were the market's chief winners yesterday, while some casinooriented issues that had shown recent strength headed lower.The general market, weakening noticeably in afternoon trading, reflected fears of rising interest rates that some analysts said might produce a credit crunch. The Dow Jones industrials plunged 10.31 points to 849.25.

title: House Votes to Restore 8 Major Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, June I5  The House of Representatives, ignoring the threat of a veto, voted today to restore eight major water projects that President Carter killed last year.

title: Carey Asks the State Legislature For $5001 Million in New Spending
description: ALBANY, June 15Governor Carey today asked the Legislature to authorize more than $500 million in new spending, provoking a partisan furor between his officials, who insisted the state would spend less than $100 million of it this Year, and Senate Republicans, who charged Mr.Carey intended to spend an outrageously high $236 million and that they would reject it.

title: The Pop Life
description: RY COODER is not a rock superstar.It's not that I'm not topping the charts, he said the other day.I'm not even on the charts. Yet, Mr.Cooder, who will appear in concert Monday night in Carnegie Flail, is nonetheless as respected and interesting a rock performer as we have today.

title: Wallace T.(Ed) Kirkeby, at 87; Was Manager of Fats Waller
description: Wallace T.(Ed) Kirkeby, who managed the late Thomas (Fats) Waller at the height of his musical career nearly 40 years ago, died Monday.in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I.He was 87 years old and lived at 55 Ashwood Place, Port Washington, L.I.

title: A Critic Previews The Wares at the Fair
description: Once again 52d Street will be transformed Sunday into a colossal bazaar, at which curbtocurb crowds numbering hundreds of thousands of shoppers are expected to browse and sometimes buy the antiques, collectibles and crafts set out by 1,000 dealers.

title: Just a Kid in China
description: LOS ANGELES  If elected in 1980, Ronald Reagan, at age 70, would bethe oldest President ever inaugurated. Put this proposition to him and you get a rueful grin together with proof positive that he's been pondering the matter  a practiced recital of how many United States senators are past 65, and a quip that in China he'd be considered just a kid.

title: Manila Protests on New York Clash
description: Two New York City policemen, who moved in to break up what they described as a brawl in front of the.Philippine Center on Fifth Avenue early Sunday, touched off a chain reaction that led yesterday to a strongly worded diplomatic protest by the Philippine Government and the preparation of an official apology by the United States.

title: Losing Daughter, Gaining Queen
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 15  He seems like any otner doting father of thebride  happy, sentimental, nervou and more than a little bewildered. But Najeeb E.Halaby, a Texasborn lawyer and businessman, concedes that there has to he a difference when his daughter Elizabeth chooses no less a husband than the reigning King of Jordan, Hussein Ben Talal.

title: Jazz at the Modern
description: As part of a free weekly series of concerts in the Summergarden of the Museum of Modern Art, S West 54th Street, Perry Robinson, the jazz clarinetist, and Lawrence Cooke, the jazk vibraphonist, will perform tonight and tomorrow night at 8 P.M.The Summer garden, which will feature free programs through Sept.3, opens at 6 P.M. and closes at 10 P.M.on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.Information: 9566100.

title: News Summary
description: King Hussein of Jordan married Elizabeth Halaby, a 26yearold American, in a brief Moslem ceremony and later proclaimed her Queen.A statement by the royal palace indicated that the bride, nominally a Protestant, had become a Moslem.The marriage was the fourth for the 42yearold Jordanian monarch and followed a brief courtship.[Page Al, Columns 12.]

title: Gullett Victor as Yanks Beat Mariners
description: The Yankees, who have been hoping to come up with a healthy lefthanded pitcher who can compare with their unbeaten Ron Guidry.had good reason to feel that they had regained one in the person of Don Gullett.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Design deficiencies caused the Jan. 18 collapse of the snowladen Hartford Civic Center roof, the final engineer's report said.

title: HIGH COURT BARS DAM, REPRIEVING RARE FISH
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that Congress's commitment to protecting endangered species of wildlife is so strong that completion of a $120 million Federal water project must be halted to save the last survivors of an obscure kind of tiny fish. Given a DavidandGoliath choice, the high court majority came down on the side of the snail darter; a threeinch variety of perch with a single remote habitat, thus rejecting the mighty Tennessee Valley Authority and the 30mile reservoir it has been planning behind its virtually complete Tellico Dam.

title: Strauss Says U.S.Will Lean Hard On Postal Workers' Wage Demands
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Robert S. Strauss and Barry P.Bosworth, the Government's top pricewage troubleshooters, disclosed today that the Administration would lean hard on the 600,000 postal workers to sign a new contract that would slow wage gains.

title: Confidence Vote in Commons  Britain's Day of High Political Drama
description: LONDON, June 15 As it turned out, the Government did not fall, and the long day ended in anticlimax.But yesterday was still a treat for British political connoisseurs, one of those rare occasions when a struggle for parliamentary power takes place in full view, with the outcome in serious doubt.

title: Company Access to Labor Case Testimony Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Supreme Court ruled today that a company under investigation by the National Labor Relations Board could not use the Freedom of Information Act to get early access to the statements of witnesses scheduled to testify on the matter.

title: Money Supply Steady For Week Ended June 7
description: The nation's basic money supply, to the disappointment of the bond market, showed no change in the week ended June 7, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Inventors of the World Show Off Their Dreams
description: Vincent Siano, who is an artist for Grumman Aviation, was explaining Tarot Tells the game he and his friend Nicholas Piazza, a fuel oil company president, have devised.

title: PRESIDENT OF ITALY RESIGNS IN SCANDAL
description: ROME, June 15President Giovanni Leone of Italy announced his resignation tonight in a statement a few hours after the Communist Party had urged him to step down in the face of charges of corruption.

title: Screen: A Slick Version of 'Grease':Fantasy of the 50's
description: "GREASE," the film version of the still-running Broadway musical show, is not really the 1950's teen-age movie musical it thinks it is, but a contemporary fantasy about a 1950's teen-age musicala larger, funnier, wittier and more imaginative-than-Hollywood movie with a life that is all its own. It uses the Eisenhower era  the characters, costumes, gestures and particularly, the musicto create a time and place that have less to do with any real 50's than with a kind of show business that is both timeless and old-fashioned, both sentimental and wise. The movie, which opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters, is also terrific fun.Because I seem to be one of the few persons who has never seen the Broadway show, I'm not sure how the movie differs from the original, yet it's apparent that the film's score, which is one of the best things about the production, has been liberally supplemented by new material and new-old material, including "Love Is a Many Splendored Thing," which has never before sounded so marvelously, soaringly inane.Somewhat in the manner of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," which recalls the science-fiction films of the 50's in a manner more elegant and more benign, than anything that was ever made then, "Grease" is a multimillion-dollar evocation of the B-picture quickies that Sam Katzman used to turn out in the 50's ("Don't Knock the Rock," 1957) and that American International carried to the sea in the 1960's ("Beach Party," 1963).The gang at old Rydell High, which is the universe of "Grease," is unlike any high school class you've ever seen except in the movies. For one thing, they're all rather long in the tooth to be playing kids who'd hang around malt shops. For another, they are loaded with the kind of talent and exuberance you don't often find very far from a musical stage. They not only portray characters but effectively make comments on them.Olivia Newton-John, the recording star in her American film debut, is simultaneously very funny and utterly charming as the film's ingnue, a demure, virginal Sandra Dee-type. She possesses true screen presence as well as a sweet, sure singing voice, while the Sandra Dee I remember had a voice that seemed to have been manufactured in Universal's speech-and-special-effects department.John Travolta, as Miss Newton-John's costar, a not-so-malevolent gang-leader, is better than he was in "Saturday Night Fever." I'm still not sure if he's a great actor, but he's a fine performer with the kind of energy and humor that are brought to life by the musical numbers.Stockard Channing, as the high school's tramp who has a dirty mouth and a heart of gold, would (if it were possible) stop the show twice, once with a pasty put-on of poor Olivia ("Look at Me, I'm Sandra Dee") and another when she attempts, in song, to explain why it's more honorable to be loose than uptight ("There Are Worse Things I Could Do").The film's producers, Robert Stigwood and Allen Carr, and director, Rundel Kleiser (whose first theatrical feature this is), have also supplemented the cast of comparative youngsters with a whole crowd of actors we associate with the 50's, and who seem here to have survived with barely a visible dent.Eve Arden, a fixture of the 50's as Our Miss Brooks, plays Rydell High's unflappable principal; Sid Caesar is the football coach; Edd Byrnes comes on briefly as the lecherous host of a teen-age TV show that decides to spotlight Rydell in a network program; Jean Blondell is the harassed waitress at the corner soda fountain, and, maybe funniest of all, is Frankie Avalon, who appears in a dream sequence to counsel an unhappy student ("Beauty School Dropout").Bronte Woodward has adapted the Broadway book by Jim Jacobs and Warren Casey, who also wrote the show's original score, in such a way that the plot serves the purpose of the music without needlessly interfering with it.It's to the director's credit that the musical numbers slip in and out of reality mostly with hugely comic effect. The highlights of the stage show include the upbeat rock number, "We Go Together," and the rueful "Summer Nights," both sung by Mr. Travolta and Miss Newton-John, but the hit of the film is probably a breathless new number, "You're the One That, I Want," written by John Farrar and beautifully choreographed by Patricia Birch.Because there haven't been that many movie musicals recently, it doesn't mean much to say that "Grease" is the best we've had in years. I'm also afraid that people who (like me) have no special fondness for the 50's might be put off by the film's time and place. Let me emphasize, then, that "Grease" stands outside the traditions it mimics. Its sensibility is not tied to the past but to a free-wheeling, well informed, high-spirited present."Grease," which has been ruled PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") has some language that would never have been heard even on Broadway in the 50's, and though it deals with teen-age lust quite frankly, it's heart is always pure.

title: Sandhogs Share the Digging And Dig the Sharing
description: Half a loaf is better than none.

title: About Real Estate City and State Map New Rules For LoftBuilding Conversions
description: South of 59th Street, Manhattan has more than 4,000 industrial buildings with a total of almost 200 million square feet of space, the equivalent of about 200,000 conventional twobedroom apartments, or 50,000 large lofts.

title: Canada Forms Inflation Office
description: OTTAWA.June 15  The Canadian Government announced today Ihe formation of a new agency to lead the fight against persistent inflation here.

title: Pool! 52d St.Becomes 2 Magical Miles of Fun
description: On most Sundays, 52d Street is what all other midManhattan latitudes are, a.mostly quiet weekend street on watch you can park your car because nearly everything is closed.This Sunday, however 52d Street will undereo what has been an annual transformation: It will become probably the longest (two miles) street fair anywhere.

title: Matty Matlock, 71, Jazz Clarinetist
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP)The jazzman Julian (Matty) Matlock, whose clear clarinet tones carried above the big band sounds of Bob Crosby, Jack Teagarden, Billy May and Bobby Hackett, died yesterday at the age of 71.

title: Hussein Marries American And Proclaims Her Queen
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 15King Hussein of Jordan today married Elizabeth Halaby, a 26yearold American, in a brief Moslem ceremony and later proclaimed her the new Queen of fris desert kingdom.

description: Grace Glueck

title: Iphigene Sulzberger Is Honored By New York City School Board
description: Sixty years ago when cooperative education was first started in New York, Iphigene Sulzberger was one of the prime movers in setting up the program to which high school students alternate classroom work with paying jobs in stores and other businesses.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: ROSENBLUMFrank, beloved husl band of Ann.Devoted father of Doris.Adored grandfather of Susan end Honey.Beloved brother of Friedel Auni, Sylvia Sandier and Helen Weg. His suffering mercifully ended when he peacefully passed away Thursday, June 15, 1978.Services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, Sunday 12:45PM.

title: Peanut Politicians Criticized by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Iune 15  Reactionary peanut politicians were accused today by the official Soviet press agency, Tass, of provocative propaganda against the Soviet Union, but the word peanut was later removed from the article.

description: (9)News (7)All My Chihli; Evening; SATURDAY; TOP WEEKEND FILMS; SUNDAY; Rosey Grier (left) tries to enlist Jack Klugman's aid a repeat of Quincy, 10 P.M.on Channel 4.

title: Savings Banks Deposits Rise
description: New York State savings banks had a net deposit gain of $41 million in May, in sharp contrast to the net deposit outflow of $356 million in April, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported.In May 1977, the banks reported a net gain of $329 million.

title: Returns Show Carter Paid $48,000 in Taxes in 77
description: WASHINGTON June 15  President 1Carter paid slightly more than $48,000 in Federal income tax lest year, according to tax returns he made public today.

title: Hussein Marries American And Proclaims Her Queen
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 15King Hussein of Jordan today married Elizabeth Halaby, a 26yearold American, in a brief Moslem ceremony and later proclaimed her the new Queen of his desert kingdom.

description: Ad Hoc Committee of the 10th Special Session on Disarmament10:30 A.M.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: DORIC (Name).Lett Bermuda June 15; duet A.M. At W.55th Street.

title: 2 Block Parties Set for East and West Side
description: Food, entertainment and prizes will be offered tomorrow at two block parties in Manhattan.

title: Panama Cracking Down on the Critics of Carter's Visit
description: PANAMA, June 15The Panamanian Government clamped down today on opposition groups that have been protesting! against President Carter's visit here tomorrow to exchange the documents ratifying the new Panama Canal treaties.1

title: Former Florida Judge Disbarred Over Actions for Political Friends
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 15 (AP)Former Florida Supreme Court Justice David McCain was disbarred today on charges that he had tried to put pressure on lowercourt judges to rule in favor of political friends.

title: Bridge
description: The world's mostsuccessful charity tournament, if one measures success in terms of charitable profit per bridge player, has been played in the metropolitan area during the last 10 days. It was a twopronged effort in aid of various Jewish charities.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Detroit Celebrates an Old Hotel's Rebirth
description: DETROIT, June 13  There was much fanfare on the downtown streets of this big industrial city the other day. High school students, maintaining a long tradition here, took to the streets in their cars.organizine imoromotu horn blowing motorcades through the central business district, signaling the advent of diploma season.Business executives and politicians, meanwhile,. spent the best of a day toasting the official reopening of this city's grand old hotel'  the Cadillac on Washington Boulevard.

title: Wide Application Seen for Ruling Opening Cities to Civil Right Suits
description: When the Supreme Court decided last week that local government bodies were not immune from suits seeking money damages under one of the oldest civil rights laws in the country, civil rights and civil liberties lawyers were jubilant.

title: Brooke Deposition Held False
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 A Middlesex County judge, ruling that Senator Edward W.Brooke had substantially misrepresented his financial condition in _deposition in his divorce case, turned the matter over to the District Attorney today for possible perjury action.

title: 77 TV Profits: ABC Is Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 15 (AP)  The ABC television network had a tremendous lead over NBCTV and CBSTV in profits last year, according to Television Digest, a weekly publication.

title: Restored L.I.Village To Hold Horiculture Show
description: Plants and produce that were native to Long Island during the 19th century will be on display this weekend at the Old Bethpage, L.I.village restoration.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON.June 15  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18.3 billion tonmiles, 5.5 percent above the corresponding week a year ago.Carloadings in the same period totaled 501,132 cars, 0.2 percent above the figure for last year.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: New Yorkrelated bonds rose in price after news that the Senate Banking Committee had approved loan guarantees for New York City.New York State bonds advanced enough to lower their yields 10 basis points; several Municipal Assistance Corporation issues climbed one or two points and some Port Authority bonds gained more than a point.

title: Southeastern States Taking Over As Chief Conduits for Marijuana
description: ATLANTA, June 15 It comes by and by sea: Last Saturday, a shrimp boat docked at Darien on the Georgia coast at the odd hour of 3 A.M., and Federal agents swarmed aboard to find 15 tons of Colombian marijuana in the hold.

title: Steiner, 17, Excels.in L.I.Golf
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 15The Long Island Golf Association's 53d amateur championship attracted a field of 104 competitors today at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.

title: A Second Toxicologist Testifies on Curare Findings
description: HACKENSACK, June 15The chief toxicologist of Suffolk County, L.I., testified at the murder trial of Dr.Mario E. Jascalevich today that he found evidence of curare in three of the doctors alleged victims.

title: Democrats Pick Goldin, Abrams for Comptroller and Attorney General
description: Albany, June 15Harrison J.Goldin, New York City's Comptroller, and Robert Abrams; Borough President of the Bronx, were designated today as the Democratic candidates for State Comptroller and State Attorney General, but a politically unknoWn upstate woman judge won enough votes to challenge Mr.Abrams in the Sept.12 primary.

title: Insuring a Fair Deal for Homeowners
description: Homeowners in fashionably restored parts of Park Slope are discovering that they share something besides Brooklyn addresses with their poorer Crown Heights neighbors, namely, Brooklyn ZIP codes.Insurance companies use them to redline  deny insurance to  enure communities.The homeowners are thus forced into a highrisk pool that provides less coverage at greater cost.They are not the only victims.Insurance redlining, with invidious racial overtones, spreading in other cities and pressure is building on Washington to intervene.But that would not be necessary if the states, which regulate the insurance industry, took the initiative.

title: Rethinking Our African Policy
description: In his Annapolis speech June 7, President Carter promised that America would assist African efforts to contain the intrusion of Sovietsupported Cuban troops, as we have done recently in Zaire.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The town of Huntington, L.I., doesn't try to compare itself with Montmartre, but that will be the general idea.The village green will be turned over to 200 artists this weekend for the 11th annual outoor art exhibition, Hours: 11 A.M.until dusk today, tomorrow and Sunday.There will be paintings, graphics and assorted crafts.Everything will be for sale at prices ranging from $10 to $5,000.A special feature this year will be the many crafts demonstrationspottery, pewter, wood carving, stained glass and more.From New York, take the Long Island Exprssway to exit 51; follow Deer Park Road to Park Avenue, and the signs will guide you to Huntington.Information: (516) 2718423.

title: TENTATIVE PACT REACHED IN POWER PLANT STRIKE
description: SEABROOK., N.H..June 15 (AP)  A tentative agreement has been announced

title: Islanders, Rangers in Draft
description: The Rangers picked a defensernan and the Islanders chose a center in the first round of the National Hockey League draft yesterday in Montreal. Details on page B7.

title: Business and the Law
description: THERE are occasions when lawyers say what they really think.These moments of candor usually occur only in the privacy of lawyers offices, but more and more, lawyers are revealing trade secrets in classroom settings where they are teaching other practicing lawyers.

title: Books: Behind the Brass
description: ETHEL MERMAN forewarns the reader of her autobiography that I'm not exactly the kind of dame that people always thought I was. Fifty years of playing a professional brassy dame has, she feels, left her followers with the idea that this was a reflection of Ethel Agnes Zimmermann, her offstage persona.

title: The Comptroller in Albany Rules A Powerful and Mystical Realm
description: ALBANY, June 15  Perhaps it is a desire to be a loudgrowling fiscal watchdog and a whirlwind investment banker  or simply to while away the hours vicariously spending billions of dollars. Whatever it is has so far enticed a number of men into the fray to succeed State Comptroller Arthur Levitt in one of the state's most powerful and least understood jobs.

title: Advertising
description: A wellknown Philadelphia lawyer identified as an investor in Everest Industries denied it yesterday.

title: Dance Festival Moves to Durham With Gala
description: The American Dance Festival, in New London, Conn., for the last 30 years, will begin its first season at Duke University in Durham, N.C., with a gala benefit tomorrow and Sunday.With North Carolina's Governor, James B. Hunt, and Terry Sanford, president of Duke University, as cohosts, the gain will feature historical films of Charles Weidman and Jose Limon and performances by Annabelle Gamson of dances by Isadore Duncan and Mary Wigman, modern dance pioneers.Also on the program will be performances of three works premiered at the modern dance festival: The Moor's Pavane, choreographed by Jose Limon and performed by the Limon company, Paul Taylor's Aureole, performed by the Taylor company, and Pilobolus Dance Theater in Ciona. Mr.Taylor and former Limon dancers Lucas Hoving, Betty Jones and Pauline Koner will be on hand to discuss the works.

title: The New York Times/Jack Manning
description: A WALK IN THE GARDEN: Visitors to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden yesterday sampled the beauty and bouquet of the Rose Garden.Pleasant weather should continue today with sunny skies and a high around 80.

title: World News Briefs
description: KUWAIT, June 15 (Reuters)Ali Yasin, regarded as a moderate in the Palestinian movement, was shot to death here today.The guerrilla organization Al Fatah, of which he was a member, accused extremist elements in Iraq of having instigated the murder.

title: Events and Openings
description: JAWS 2, directed by Jeannot Srwarc; starring Roy Scheider, Lorraine Gary and Murray Hamilton; at the Cinerama, RKO 86th Street Twin 1 and 2, Murray Hill, D.W.Griffth and other theaters.

title: Trenton Suspends 2 Officers in Leak Of Report on Lordi
description: TRENTON, June 15Two state police lieutenants were suspended without pay today, accused of disclosing a confidential background investigation report on Joseph P.Lordi, the chairman of the Casino Control Commission, which regulates casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Air Traffic Increases
description: The Air Transport Association said yesterday that domestic and international air traffic last month increased by 18.8 percent over May 1977.Domes tic revenue passenger miles for the month increased 17.5 percent over last year, while international service revenue miles showed a May increase of 24.5 percent over last year.Travel on scheduled airlines in the first five months of the year was 15 percent greater than in the same period last year, the association said.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES 123 TO BACK GUARANTEES FOR NEW YORK BONDS; ASSISTANCE LIMITED TO $1.5 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Senate Banking Committee voted today to authorize S1.5 billion of longterm loan guarantees for New York City, but set strict preconditions before the Federal assistance could be given and created tight controls to monitor it.

title: Deaths
description: JOSEPHBerenice H.On June 13. Wife of the late Leon W.Joseph.Beloved mother of Stephen & Susan C. Krone.Loving grandmother of Janis & John Joseph & William Krone III. Friends may cell at Frank E.Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday & Thursday 79pm, with service on Friday loam.Interment BethEl Cemetery

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beker Industries Corporation, Greenwich, Conn., announced that A.P.. Gates, president of the chemical fertilizer company, has resigned.

title: Drivers Out, Halting The News; Times Moves to End Guild Pact
description: The Daily News, unable to find drivers to take its papers past the picket line of the striking Newspaper Guild of New York, decided last night to abandon efforts to publish its Friday editions.And The New York Times, as a sign of support for The News, announced that it would institute new work rules, in effect terminating its contract with the guild.

title: Plenty of Pizza and Coffee, but No Tension
description: ALBANY, June 15If 357 delegates, 62 county chairmen, 30 state committeemen and 3,000 other participants could agree on just one thing today, it would be that they were attending the dullest Democratic convention in decades.

title: George Spaventa, at 60; Sculptor and an Instructor In Maine and New York
description: George Spaventa, a sculptor and a teacher of sculpture at the New York Studio School, was found dead yesterday in his apartment in the Westbeth residence for artists at 463 West Street, in Greenwich Village.He was 60 years old..

title: Odds Lowered On Netherlands
description: LONDON, June 15 (AP)Britain's bookmakers said today that the Netherlands, by virtue of its 51 victory over Austria in the opening of secondround World Cup play yesterday, had joined the contenders for the soccer title. According to the revised odds, Argentina, the host nation, is still favored at 21, followed by Italy, 31; Brazil, 41; Netherlands 51; West Germany, 61; Poland, 1001; Peru, 2001, and Austria.5001.

title: The Wrong Question
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  This city is now engaged in a most peculiar foreign policy debate  not about whether the nation's strategic arms policy, its African policy and its Middle Eastern and Chinese policies are right or wrong, but about whether President Carter or Fidel Castro is telling the truth on the invasion of Zaire and about whether Secretary of State Vance or Zbigniew Brzezinski is up or down as the principal foreign policy adviser to President Carter.

title: May Output Shows Moderate 0.6% Gain
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  The nation's industries increased their output.by a moderate sixtenths of 1 percert.in May, the Government said today, confirming expectations of slower economic growth this summer.

title: NUMBER ON WELFARE ROLLS FALLS BUT COST INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The number of people on the rolls of the Government's biggest welfare program fell in 1977 for the second straight year, but the cost, of providing the benefits increased, the Government announced today.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOISE, Idaho, June 16Federal District Judge Ray McNichols ruled today the Federal Bureau of Mines and a polyurethane foam manufacturer were not liable for the Sunshine Mine disaster that killed 91 miners at Kellogg, Idaho, in May 1972.

title: Ford Throws $1 Million Birthday Party
description: Ctit the cake already, someone said. I want to see the parade.

title: A New American, and He's 101
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 16 At first the crowds, the photographers and the television lights seemed too much for Salvatore Napoli. But he applauded each speaker vigorously and, when came time to recite the Pledge of Allegiance, he whipped the brown straw hat off his head, placed his hand over his heart and stood at attention with the othersmany of whom watched him.

title: The New York Times/Edwaia Mausner
description: INTERESTED OBSERVER: Kim Martin, 8, watching commencement exercises yesterday at Bronx Community College. Her Mother, Evonne, was among 800 students graduating. Dr. Roscoe C. Brown Jr., who has been acting president of the college since September 1977, was officially installed yesterday as its third president.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar staged a modest come, back in Toyko yesterday, advanced on other foreign money markets in generally quiet trading but lost ground in New York, according to The Associated Press.

title: The City Ballet Combines Its Flags on a Program
description: The New York City Ballet's three flag ballets Union Jack, Stars and Stripes, Tricolorehave always been presented separately. But on Thursday night at the State Theater, the company put, them together for the first time and called the homemade special occasion Entente Cordiale.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times reported incorrectly yesterday that Senator Ricnard G. Lugar of Indiana was chief strategist for the Administration's proposal to revise the Federal Labor Law. He is a leading opponent of the effort to change the law.

title: Duryea Observes a Campaign Rite
description: Perry B. Duryea was baptized in a New York City political rite yesterday when he made a noontime handshaking tour of the Seventh Avenue garment district to open his gubernatorial drive,as the official can! didate of the Republican state organization.

title: Where Sunlight Pours, Like Lemonade, Into the Bedr9om. Where the Bell Says, One More Day Is Done. One More Day.
description: WHITE LAKE, Wis. I went home. to summer today because June is a month when all roads  all days  go there.

title: Soviet Jet Overshoots Runway
description: BOMBAY, India. June 16 (AP)A Soviet jetliner overshot the runway at Bombay airport today and became bogged down in mud, the United News of India reported. Word from the scene said the flyushin 62 was undamaged and none of its 53 passengers was injured. The Aeroflot plane 3.vas on a scheduled flight from Moscow to Hanoi, Vietnam, via India.

title: Court Refuses to Block Auction of Ringer Hors
description: MINEOLA, L.L., June 16The Nassau County District Attorney was restrained today from interfering with the sale of a horse, which he contends is the Uruguayan champion, Cinzano, at an auction to be held at Belmont Park on July 10.

title: Yank Rally Falls Short, Angels Win
description: Jim Fregosi, the new manager of the Angels, brought a California team to Yankee Stadium last night that seemed to have a new look. It showed power at the plate, hustle on the bases and finesse in the field.

title: Doctor Says No Sure Sign of Curare Exists in 2 Bodies
description: HACKENSACK, June 16A prosecution toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that there was not sufficient scientific certainty to say that the drug curare was present in two of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: Abel, Dean of Journalism At Columbia U., Resigns To Teach at Stanford
description: Elie Abel has resigned as dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism to join the faculty of Stanford University at Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Tale oft Champions: Cheersand Regrets
description: The two heavyweight boxing champions of the world, Leon Spinks and Larry Holmes, had a chance to pay respect to their fans this week. One did and one did not.

title: Prime Rise Cuts 7.28 From Dow
description: Computer, airline and semiconductor issues headed lower yesterday as the stock market continued to plow through a pricecorrection process for sectors that showed strength earlier this spring.

title: Giant Clouts In 9th Beat Mets. 7 to 4
description: SAN FRANCISCO; June 16The San Francisco Giants had a sixgame winning streak going, launched in New York. laet weekend, and the New York Mets had lost three of their four games on this trip as the teams met in Candlestick Park tonight in the opener of a fourgame series.

title: 2,500 School Buses Recalled
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 16 (UPI) The International Harvester Company today announced the recall of 2.500 school buses to correct an emission system that could cause fires. The recall affects only buses manufactured from 1973 to 1977 for use in California under the state's emission standards.

title: New York's Sanguine Politics
description: A few moments into the first round, it looks to be a peculiar political battle in New York State this year.

title: Prosecutor in Brooke Case Plans Investigation Into Possible Perjury
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16The District Attorney here said today that he would begin an immediate investigation into whether United States Senator Edward W. Brooke committed perjury or violated other laws in connection with his pending divorce.

title: Texas Quake Shakes Area
description: SNYDER, Tex., June 16 (AP)An earthquake registering between 4.75 and 5.0 on the Richter Scale shook dwellings and awakened residents in a large triangular area of West Texas early today, but apparently caused no injuries or damage. The San Angelo police said'they had received about 30 telephone calls from worried residents who reported that the floors and walls of their homes had shaken and furniture and moved, The National Earthquake Information Service in Golden, Colour placed the epicenter 20 miles north of Snyder at 6:47 A.M. Snyder is about 120 miles northwest of San Angelo.

title: Miss Lopez Trails Golf by 1
description: ROCHESTER, June 16(AP)Silvia Bertolaccini scored an eagle en route to a twounderpar 71 and took a onestroke lead over Nancy Lopez today after the first round of a $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Detectives Take Sleuthing Lessons and Help Out in Real Murder Case
description: It was an unusual classroom assignmentto help find a murdererbut then, this was an unusual group of students.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AN airline stewardess has perfected a way for passengers to cart their suitcases around. Deborah M. Ratchford of Arlington, Va., was granted a patent this week for a hook that fits through the luggage handles and a wheel carrier that supports the bags.

title: Wimbledon Debentures a Secure Ticket
description: LONDON, June 16  Having trouble lining up tickets for Wimbledon this year? Maybe you should try the Stock Exchange.

title: 8 Plans for Wilderness Studied
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Forest Service is considering eight alternative plans for setting aside as wilderness part, of 66 million acres of roadless land in the national forests.

title: Bridge
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 16The twoyear cold war between the World Bridge Federation and the Italian Bridge Federation appeared to be ended last night on the eve of the world championship tournaments here when the president of the world organization withdrew a suspension threat that had been hanging over the Italians since last October.

title: Chicago and Midwest In Joint Options Accord
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Midwest Stock Exchange announced yesterday arr agreement in principle to combine their options operations on the floor of the C.B.O.E.

title: On the Right Track
description: The Federal Office for Civil Rights and New York City's Board of Education have reached a sensible agreement on two disputed issues: the public schools will be able to continue to group youngsters by ability, even if this leads temporarily to racially imbalanced classes; and the city's three selective high schools Bronx Science. Stuyvesant and Brooklyn Tech  will not have to lower their standards in the interest of achieving racial balance.

title: 68 Bumped Without Frills From a $149 Flight to Europe
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)Unlucky travelers lounged again on the terminal floor at Logan International. Airport today, hoping to board the second Pan Am nofrills flight from Boston to Amsterdam.

title: News Summary
description: The new Panama Canal treaties were formally concluded at ceremonies in Panama attended by President Carter and Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's leader. The ceremony was alSo attended by a delegation of 12 United States senators and a contingent from the House. title: Fideldor Drops Dividend And Predicts Yearly Loss
description: Fidelcor Inc., a major bank holding company in the Philadelphia area, said yesterday, that its directors had voted to omit the company's regular guarterly dividend, that it would probably report a loss for the year and that it had set aside $11 million to meet possible bad loans.

title: Personal Income Surges, But Housing Starts Ease
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The combined personal income of all. Americans increased sharply in May for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today.

description: PARIS, June 16 Egypt won pledges of sufficient financial support today to prevent it from defaulting on its huge fOreign debt.

title: The Li'l Abner of the Open
description: DENVER, June 16He wins bets In bars by biting chunk out of the cover of a golf ball. And he once flipped an alligator over by the tail. His name is Andy Bean and he's one of golf's most appealing players. He's big and strong and emotional. Whether it's a tee shot or his annoyance at a bad shot, he lets it all hang out. The other touring pros call him Li'l Abner for his strength. At the United States Open here, he was asked not to hit his driver at the Cherry Hills Country Club practice range in order to preserve the spectators and vehicles out on University Ave nue more than 800 yards away. He arrived as the winner of the previous two events on the PGA Tour, the Memphis Classic and the Kemper open in Charlotte, N.C., and he had an opportunity to be the Open's secondround leader today until he plopped wedge shot into the creek fronting the 17th green for double bogey and missed the 18th green with a 3iron for bogey. With a 72, 72 for 144, he was only four strokes behind Andy North, the 36hole leader, but Andy Bean might be the leader in selfconfidence.

title: Guild and Daily News in Accord On Contract to End 4Day Strike
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York and The Daily News reached a tentative agreement on a new threeyear labor contract last night, signaling an end to strike that had halted publication of the nation's largest circulation daily and averting a threatened citywide newspaper shutdown.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Japanese Seek U.S. Company
description: Corporations in West Germany, Britain and other European countries have been active buyers of American industrial companies in the last year. Japanese companies, however, have been notably absent. Now that may be changing.

title: The (World) Cup Runneth Over for Britons
description: LONDON, June 16  Britain has caught a bad case of World Cup fever. The symptoms are plain for all to see: empty restaurants on the nights when the big soccer games are televised from Argentina; flowers bought to assaugedisgusted wives, and a tendency on the part of the average male, middleaged Briton to babble uncontrollably about tackles, crosses, saves and penalties. The fact is that the World Cup finals, monthlong ritual that takes place every four years, has cast a spell over this country, even though the English national team failed to qualify and the Scottish team was eliminated after two performances of comic ineptitude and a brave but futile comeback in a third match.

title: A Virus That May Cause Hepatitis Linked to Donor Blood Is Isolated
description: Scientists have captured and taken electron microscope photographs of a virus that may prove to be the cause cf most of the hepatitis transmitted by blood transfusion, according to a report published yesterday.

title: Irene Kral With Difficule Songs
description: One of the pleasures of hearing Irene Kral, who will be singing at Michael's Pub for the next two weeks, is the opportunity it affords to observe complete professional at work.

description: ATLANTA, June 16President Carter appealed to an audience of Southern Baptist laymen today to become more involved in public life, assuring them that in his own office he had not encountered any conflict between God's will and my political duty.

title: New Actions on Alleged Nazi War Criminals Expected
description: The controversy surrounding the Federal Government's continuing investigation of 147 alleged Nazi war criminals living in this country will receive new focus this month with several developments in Congress.

title: Ballet Blaska Presents a New L'Histoire du Soldat
description: Ballet Blaska is now commemorating its 10th year, a not inconsiderable age in dance, but the French modern dance company looked like a group with youthful high spirits when it presented the second program of its New York season Thursday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

description: To the Editor: In your editorial of June 13, (Play. Acting and the Police) you comment: Mayor Koch wisely insisted that the legislation limit all arbitration awards to amounts the city can afford.

description: ANCHORAGE, Jurie 12Polls and other political indicators give former Gov. Walter J. Rickel a substantial lead over Gov. Jay S. Hammond in their contest for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: HEAD OF T.V.A. AGREES ON REDESIGNING DAM TO COMPLY WITH LAW
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority formally agreed today that a controversial water project on the Little Tennessee River should be redesigned following a United States Supreme Court decision that the project should be blocked to protect an endangered species of fish.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: ALLIGERJoseph K. of Great Neck died on Thursday, June 15, 1978 at the age of 82 in Bay Harbor Islands, Fla, where he lived In retirement. Survived by his wife Gladys, two sons Martin & Howard, six grandchildren and two great grandchild. ren. A pioneer in mortgage banking for over 55 years. He founded the Sterling Investing Corp. He was active In Jewish and Secular (Milan. throphy. Services June 18, 10AM at Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. Interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. description: JUST WHAT'S NEEDED FOR THE TURNPIKE: Visitors to the Bergen Mall in Paramus examining a World War II tracked vehicle known as a Weasel. Vintage trucks and jeeps were on display in Military Vehicle Exhibition.

description: The United States Department of the Interior has designated 57 national historic landmarks, including such New York City business structures as Macy's Herald Square store, the Tiffany & Company building, the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company building.

title: And What Is the Bad News?
description: First the good news: I was not hurt. It happened on the Seventh Avenue subway. During the long trip 1n the Bronx Zoo, I kept busy with a Sunday crossword puzzle. My pocketbook was on my lap, serving as a desk. At the 110th Street station, two young men came into the car. I glanced up, and my eyes met the pale ones of the youth nearest me. His blank face looked drained of life. He seemed an automaton, and totally amoral. I shuddered. If ever I got into trouble, it would be through someone like him. But the advice given on a television program returned to me: Never look vulnerable. returned to the problem of 34 across.

title: M. STUART ROESLER
description: M. Stuart Roesler, who retired in 1960 as a director and senior vice president of the Empire Trust Company, now the Bank of New Yorx, died Thursday in his home en Mooreland Road in Greenwich, Conn., following a long illness. His age was 65.

title: Soweto Hospital Is a Showcase of South African Medicine
description: SOWETO, South Africa, June 16The first man to come in from the night, blood trailing on the linoleum floor, had a thumbsized stab wound on the back of his head. A minute later, a young woman staggered through the door on the arm of her mother, with five deep gashes on her face, head and shoulders that she said were inflicted by her boyfriend.

title: Books of The Times.
description: He.writes from an area beyond psychology, where feelings acquire the adamancy of randomly encountered, geologically analyzed pebbles. I read this quotation from John Updike's review of Peter Handke's last novel on the dust wrapper of The LeftHanded Woman, and I wondered whether this statement was intended as a compliment. If it is, it shows you what the avantgarde novel has armed at.

title: Dylan's European Tour Draws16,000 in London
description: LONDON, June 16At first, the 16,000odd fans who elbowed into Earl's Court last night did not seem to understand. Bob Dylan had not stepped onto a European stage since 1969, and he neither looked nor sounded the same.

title: Notes on People
description: Two Austr:ans are sticking to their contention that they conquered Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, without oxygen tanks, even though Tenzing Norkay and six other Sherpa guides have expressed serious doubt that such a feat was possible. Mr. Norkay. who with Sir Edmund Hillary, was the first to scale the 29,028foot Himalaya mountain in 1953, and his fellow Sherpas, all of whom have made the ascent, said that it takes from 12 to 14 hours for a climber using oxygen to get to the summit from the 26,200foot South CoI and back. Climbers not aided by oxygen would have taken even longer, the Sherpas said, which is why they doubt that Peter Habeler and Reinhold Messner 3d made the trip May 8 in eight hours. Mr. Norkay and his guides said pictures taken by the Austrians at the summit do not provide strong evidence that they didn't use oxygen. However, the Austrian expedition's leader, Wolfgang Nairz, dismissed the Sherpas's assertions and said more proof was forthcoming that the two team members made the trip without oxygen tanks.

description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony in C, Mozart; Clarinet Concerto in F minor, Weber; Overture to Oedipus at Colonnus, Sacchini; Legend in G, Dvorak; Symphony in A minor, Vierne; Overture to Zampa, Herold; Concerto for Two Guitars, CastelnuovoTedesco; Sicilienne from Midas et Men. sande, Faure; Ballet and Final Tableau from The Wasps, Vaughan Williams.

title: 7 Air National Guardsmen Killed in Crash Honored in LI. Ceremony
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., June 16 The bodies of 'seven Air National Guardsmen killed in Tuesday's helicopter crash in the Adirondack Mountains were returned to their home base here today for ceremonies in which Governor Carey made posthumous presentations of the state's Conspicuous Service Medal.

title: City Fiscal Plan Called Imperiled By U.S. Aid Cut
description: New York City and state officials warned yesterday that unless they could persuade Congress to restore $500 million in bond guarantees cut by the Senate Banking Committee the city's fouryear financing plan would be jeopardized.

title: Airline Talks Uncertain
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 16 (AP)  A Federal mediator has fa:led to get representatives of Northwest Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association to resume negotiations. The mediator, Robert Harris, returned to Washington after conferring with both sides yesterday.

title: Begin Is Said to Gain Backing in Rift
description: TEL AVIV, June 16An Israeli Cabinet minister said today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin appeared to have succeeded in rounding up majority support in his Government for a compromise statement on Israel's longterm intentions toward the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: CORE Plans Mideast Job Venture
description: Acting as an agent for a planned $40 million corpbrate project, the Congress on Racial Equality has begun compiling a list of skilled workers in hopes of sending 10,000 to 12,000 workers from Harlem and the South Bronx to jobs in the Middle East.

title: Camden Dedicates System Ending Sludge Dumping
description: Camden dedicated a $2.2 million sludge composting system yesterday that makes it the first major city on the East Coast to end the dumping of sewage sludge in the ocean.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The automobile insurance industry reacted sharply yesterday to Governor Byrne's charges that the companies had mounted a highpressure campaign of threats and misstatements of facts to defeat his proposal to revise coverage in the state.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Dock Craft With an Orbiting Space Station
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, June 17 (UPI) The Soyuz 29 astronauts successfully docked their spacecraft to tha Salyut 6 orbiting laboratory early today, the Tass press agency said.

title: Mayor Kucinich Loses Court Recall Ruling
description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich today lost a round in his attempt to stave off removal from Office, but he said that he had been given time to appeal and would make use of ft.

title: The Rationalization of NATO
description: The 15 NATO nations have more people and wealth than the Warsaw Pact countries and they spend about as much for defense. Yet they have always been outnumbered in conventional combat forces. For three decades the West has relied on superiority in nuclear and conventional weaponry. But the balance has been shifting. The East has improved its nuclear weapons, added five Soviet divisions in Czechoslovakia since 1968, modernized its conventional arms and stepped up its readiness, reducing NATO's warning time.

title: Apples Lose, 2924
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)  Martina Navratilova won her seventh straight singles match tonight to lead the Boston Lobsters to a 2924 World Team Tennis victory over the New York Apples. Miss Navratilova beat JoAnne Russell, 62, and then teamed with Terry Holladay for a 63 doubles triumph over Russell and Billie Jean King.

title: The Second Trial of Hermine Ryan
description: Five years after her extradition, Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, the only person ever sent from this country to Germany to stand trial as a war criminal, is appearing before a court along with 13 other defendants in Dusseldorf, West Germany.the trial that Mrs. Ryan, as an SS prison guard, had whipped five women and a child to death at the camp.

title: The New York Times/Lou Mama??
description: AT THE AGE OF 101, Salvatore Napoli was one of 117 persOns to become new U.S. citizens. Page 9.

title: Judy Carne in Serious Condition After Pennsylvania Auto Accident
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 16 (AP)Judy Came, the actress, was in Doylestown Hospital today in serious condition with a fractured neck after an auto accident near Doylestown, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Prime Rate Set at 8%, Up 1/4 Point
description: Citibank, anticipating higher rates In the money market, yesterday raised its prime rate on corporate loans to 8 percent, the highest level for this key rate since February 1975.

title: APlant Builder Turns to Dismantling Old Ones
description: MARCOULE, France  For the last 20 years. Andrd Cregut has built most of the important nuclear power plants in France, including the controversial Phoenix breeder reactor that rises amid the vineyards and medieval villages here on the bank of the Rhone River But Mr. Cregut, a robust 50yearold engineer, has now decided to spend the rest of his active years figuring out how to dismantle the nuclear plants he has erected. This is not case of a consciencestricken scientist converted to environmentalism. Quite the contrary. Mr. Cregut is as convinced as ever that nuclear power plants will continue to grow as an essential source of energy for the foreseeable future.

title: CARTER AND TORRIJOS CONCLUDE TREATIES ON CANAL'S TRANSFER
description: PANAMA, June 16President Cartel joined Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera here today in ceremonies that formally concluded the new Panama Canal treaties, declaring that a new era of interAmerican understanding and cooperation was at hand.

title: Philip johnsonWins His Dispute On Florida Architect's License
description: ORLANDO, Fla., June 16Philip Johnson, the architect, today was permitted to practice architecture in Florida. He was given a license by the State Board of Architecture, the same body that last month denied him the permit and threatened to take him to court over the issue.

title: Seaver Defeats Cardinals With His First NoHitter
description: CINCINNATI, June 16 (AP)Cincinnati's Tom Seaver, who, has had five onehitters in his 11.:year career, pitched his first nohitter tonighta 44 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinalsjust a year and a day after being acquired by the Reds from the New York Mets.

title: F.C.C. Rebuffs Challenge, Renews WPIXTV License
description: By a vote of 43, with a lengthy and stinging dissent by the minority, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday awarded a renewal of license to WPIXTV in New York and dismissed the nineyearold challenge by an independent company known as Forum Communications, which sought the right to onerate on Channel 11.

title: Associated Press
description: REPAIRS CONTINUE on bridge at Brielle that carries Conrail commuter trains from Bay Head to N'ewark and New York. The bridge, which spans the Manasquan River, has been out of service for a while.

title: U.S. Is Catching Up With Swiss Fitness Idea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 16A popular Swiss fitness program with a business aspect is catching on across the United States, impelled in part by French company Perrier, the bottler of mineral waterand America's J.C. Penney, the big retail chain..

title: Italian Parties Avoid Strife on Successor to Leone
description: ROME, June 16Italy's leading political parties, the Christian Democrats and Communists, went out of their way today to reassure the nation that they would continue their de facto alliance and that the resignation yesterday of President Giovanni Leone would not lead to a political upheaval.

title: About New York
description: ALBANY, June 16The subject was women. Where are the broads? asked Meade Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic chairman, noticing a number of female delegates absent on the final morning of the party's nominating convention.

title: 110,000 Applications, 55,000 Jobs for Youths
description: Over the years, New York City's summer youthemployment program has been criticized because of poor management and oversight on the part of the city. This year, a number of changes have been instituted, and now the criticism seems to be that the city is exercising too much control at the expense of community groups.

title: Nelson Poynter, 74, Dies; Publisher of 2 Papers in St. Petersburg, Fla.
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 16 Nelson Poynter, chairman of the board of The St. Petersburg Times and Evening Independent, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 74 years old.

title: Associated Press
description: COLORADO BLAZE FOUGHT: Firefighters dig trench continuing battle against flames raging on the Killpecker Ridge near the ColoradoWyoming border. The fire began in an area where the U.S. Forest Service earlier conducted a controlled burn of scrap timber. The blaze was fanned by westerly winds of up to 35 miles an hour.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 16 (Reuters)England's lineup of young batting stars, led by Ian Botham, took command of the second cricket test against Pakistan at Lord's today.

title: Japan Doubled Surplus In U.S. Trade in May
description: TOKYO, June 16 Japanese exports to the United States surged to $2:14 billion last month, or 36 percent above the level of May 1977, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Blumenthal On Dollar Support
description: LONDON, June 16 (AP)  W. Michael Blumenthal. United States Treasury Secretary, declared today that Washington was ready to support the troubled dollar on foreign money markets,if necessary in large amounts.

title: Associated Press
description: TRAGEDY AVERTED: Police officers grabbing and pulling an unidentified man to safety as he hung by his fingertips from the roof of the Coliseum after threatening to jump. He was taken to a hospital for observation.
