description: DENVER, June 16Gary Player, who has been in each United States Open golf tournament for the last two decades and who won it in 1965, described the treacherous 18th hole at Cherry Hills Country Club as the best finishing hole I've ever seen at a U.S. Open,

title: Guild and Daily News in Accord On Contract to End 4Day Strike
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York and The Daily News reached a tentative agreement on a new threeyear labor contract last night, signaling an end to a strike that had shut down the nation's largestcirculation daily and averting a threatened citywide newspaper shutdown.

title: Logue, Who Led U. D.C., Is Asked to Head Bronx Plan
description: Edward J. Logue, who headed the New York State Urban Development Corporation when it was the most powerful agency of its kind and then quit under fire when it collapsed financially, is being sought by the Koch administration to be chief of operations of the South Bronx reconstruction program.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Porkbelly futures prices declined on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday, giving rise to consumer hopes for lower bacon prices.

title: Lebanese Militiamen Block U.N.'s Force From Southern Zone
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 16 (Reuters)Lebanese Christian rightwing militia forces continue, to prevent United Nations peacekeeping troops from moving into areas of southern Lebanon evacuated by, Israeli occupation troops this week. But leaders of the irregular military forces were said to he at odds over the issue.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The General Motors Corporation accused the Government yesterday of conducting unreasonable and discriminatory tests to try to prove that the company's 1977 Chevette did not meet safety rules that prevent the gasoline tank from exploding in a crash.

title: Blacks in Soweto Mark 1976 Riots
description: SOWETO, South Africa, June 16Thousands of blacks marked the second anniversary today of the outbreak of rioting here with freedom songs, poetry readings and speeches declaring that nothing fundamental had changed in the plight of the country's black majority despite pledges of reform made by the Government following the upheaval.

title: News Summary
description: The new Panama Canal treaties were formally concluded at ceremonies in Panama attended by President Carter and Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's leader. The ceremony was also attended by a delegation of 12 United States senators and a contingent from the House. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: SOVIET SAYS THAT CARTER MAY START NEW COLD WAR
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, June 17 (UPI)The Soviet Union warned President Carter today that his tough line on SovietAmerican relations threatened to usher in a new cold war and wreck efforts to control the arms race.

title: Jury Award To Berkey Is Reduced
description: A jury's award of $37.6 million from the Eastman Kodak Company to Berkey Photo Inc. was reduced to $27.1 million yesterday by the judge in the long and complex antitrust case.

title: Brooklyn Businessman Strangled In a Struggle With Police Officers
description: A 30yearold businessman and community leader in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn was choked to death Wednesday evening by policemen trying to arrest him during a street confrontation, according to Milton A. Wald a deputy medical examiner.

title: 162 Yachts Start Race to Bermuda
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 16So eager were Stanley Livingston and his crew aboard the yacht Hokulele to get going for Bermuda, 635 miles away, that they jumped the gun on the starting line today, and then failed to heed the recall signals. For failing to make a proper start Livingston, a former commodore of the Cruising Club of America, the sponsor of this ocean race, and his crew of nine aboard the 46foot sloop, will learn when they reach Bermuda on Tuesday or Wednesday that they have been penalized two hours by the club race committee.

title: Scientists Find Virus They Feel May Cause Transfusion Hepatitis
description: Scientists have captured and taken electron microscope photographs of virus that may prove to be the cause of most of the hepatitis transmitted by blood transfusion, according to a report published yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda June 15; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Senators to Consider Curb on Government Searches
description: A Senate subcommittee will hold hearings Thursday on a proposal to limit the Government's power to conduct searches of newsrooms and of the homes and businesses of private citizens.

title: Balancing, the Ticket Is Still the Rule in Albany's Politics
description: ALBANY, June 16One of the hallowed traditions of politics in New York Statethe fashioning of balanced tickets to suit different ethnic, geographic and religious constituencieswas once again a dominating factor at the Republican and Democratic state conventions this week.

title: NEW PROCEDURE AIDS SOME HEART PATIENTS
description: A new medical procedure that opens clogged coronary arteries by inflating tiny, catheterinduced balloon inside of them has been developed by Lenox Hill Hospital for some patients as a relatively safe and less costly alternative to highly expensive and often risky coronary bypass surgery.

title: The New York TImes/Gary Settle
description: RINGING IN THE SUNSHINE: Visitors to the boardwalk in Atlantic City had similar callings yesterday although in different attire. The forecast for today is partly sunny skies and temperatures in the 80's.

title: Eventa Today
description: Music

title: Obscure Rule Blamed In Gasoline Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  Amercans could pay $500 million to $600 million more a year for gasoline, according to a study by the Library of Congress, as a result of an obscure change in a pending energy regulation that an oil lObbyist says he has won from the Federal Government.

title: Todd Wright, in Lake Worth, Fla., Former Financial Editor of News
description: Todd Wright, former financial editor of The New York Daily News, died in Lake Worth, Fla. on June 8. He was 79 years old.

title: HAROLD P. BURDICK, ACTOR AND RADIOSERIAL WRITER
description: Harold P. (Hal) Burdick, an actor and writer, died last Monday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Text of Carter's Speech at Rally
description: This day marks the beginning of a new partrership between Panama and the United States. The new treaties embody our mutual commitment to work together to assure that the Panama Canal shall always remain open, secure and accessible to the vessels of all nations.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: With the passage in California of Proposition 13, an initiative that will slash propertytax collections by 60 percent on July I. interest in tax cuts has intensified across the country.

title: Hsinhua/Associated Press
description: FROM ONE LEADER TO ANOTHER: In Peking, Seiji Ozawa, conductor the Boston Symphony Orchestra, demonstrates violin technique to Ulanfu, a deputy chairman of the National People's Congress of China. They met at a concert by the Peking Philharmonic, conducted by Mr. Ozawa.

title: ExBatmanFoilsPurse Snatchers
description: I guess I'm still a cop at heart, said Assemblyman David Greenberg, a 34yearold Brooklyn Democrat who used to be Batman on the Police Department's famous Batman and Robin team.

title: Britain Inflation Rate Falls
description: LONDON, Iune 16 (AP)  Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.7 percent: last month, clown from 7.9 percent In April and at its lowest level in five and a half years, the Labor Governmentannounced today. Officials 'said that the fall in May was the 11th straight month the inflation rate had dipped since reaching 17.7 percent last June. Figures published by the Department. of Employment showed that the retail price index rose only 0.6 percent in May, one of the smallest overall rises in months.

title: Your Money
description: FREQUENT job transfers for upwardly mobile executives are so:deeply woven into corporate life, that the big joke among employee relocation specialists is I.B.M. stands for I've been moved.Lately, however, the laughter has been wearing thin. Inflation, runaway housing costs and tricky tax considerations have all made transfereven when it means promotion  much more of a negotiable item than it used to be.

title: Red China Marks Its First Visit by a European King
description: HONG KONG, June 16King Juan.1 Carlos of Spain arrived in Peking today; for the first visit to China by a European monarch since the Communists came to power in 1949.

title: From RahRah Cheerleader, to 'Soap's' creator
description: She was a cheerleader in high school. and a straightA student, and she had. what was; all in all, a pretty normal Wetitchester County upbringing. Her father Was an accountant; her mother was a housewife, and the members of her family were not weird at all, Susan Harris says now.

title: Carey Proposes Outlays to Aid Prison and Health Facilities
description: ALBANY, June 16Governor Carey asking the Legislature for more than $130 million to add 3,000 new prison spacesat least some of them on Rikers Islandbetween now and 1982, along with major requests to finance improvements in mentalheath care, mass transportation, State University facilities and dozens of other programs.

title: P.B.A. Cancels Demonstration as Contract Talks Make Steady Progress
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that it was calling off demonstrations it had planned for next week because New York City had made a key concession and progress was being made in contract negotiations.

title: Sentencing Set for Michigan Man In Hammer Slaying of Woman
description: DETROIT, June 16 (AP)  A June 26 sentencing date was set today for an unemployed, selfstyled playwright who pleaded guilty to the hammer killing of a young woman who had told friends that sloe was going to audition for a play called Hammer.

title: HEAD OF T.V.A. AGREES ON REDESIGNING DAM TO COMPLY WITH LAW
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority formally agreed today that, a controversial water project on the Little Tennessee River should be redesigned following United States Supreme Court decision that the project should be blocked to protect an endangered species of fish.

title: U.S.STILLINQUANDARY OVER NEUTRON POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Ten weeks after President Carter's decision to defer production of neutron weapons, the Administration is still undecided about how to carry out the instructions to leave open the possibility of building'the controversial warheads at a later date.

title: Seven on British Tanker Die
description: HONOLULU, Tune 16 (UPI)Seven crewmen aboard the British tanker Anco Duke died while cleaning a tank or hold, the Coast Guard reported yesterday. A spokesman said that the victims had died from fumes or from a lack of oxygen.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Carter Intends to Appoint Resor To New Policy Post in Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  President Carter intends to appoint Stanley B. Resor, who was Secretary of the Army at the peak of the Vietnam War, to .4 newly created Pentagon post of Under Secretary for Policy.

title: Troggs Pound Out 1960's Rock
description: The Rolling Stones aren't the only veteran British bluesrock band in town. The Troggs, who date back to the early 1960's of British rhythmandblues revivalism, and who had a No. 1 American hit in 1966 with Wild Thing, have always hovered charmingly between seriousness and parody. And things haven't really changed with the band, which opened at Max's Kansas City Thursday and will be there through tomorrow.

title: Doctor States No Certain Trace Of Curare Exists in Two Bodies
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Tune 16  A prosecution toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalerich that there was not sufficient scientific certainty to say that the drug curare was present in two of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: Torrijos Turns the Carter Rally to His Own Purposes
description: PANAMA, June 16Tightly packed buses drove here overnight and a convoy of trains crossed the 50 miles from Atlantic to Pacific Oceans to bring crowds to receive President Carter at a mass gathering today in the Fifth of May Plaza shortly after he put the final seal on the new Panama Canal treaties.

title: PORNOGRAPHY ZONES PROPOSEDINSTATE
description: TRENTON, June 16 (AP)New Jersey municipalities could set up combat zones to permit live sex shows and the sale and exhibition of obscene materials under legislation approved today by the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

title: Diane Von Furstenberg: Making Some Changes
description: Diane Von Furstenberg has changed her image.

title: Jane Richards Wed To John R. Lane
description: Jane. L. Richards,. assistant director cf the Hirschl fi Adler Galleries, was married yesterday to Jchn R. Lane, executive assistant to the director of the Brcoklyn Museum. The ceremony was performed at the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. William Hudnut.

title: Ford Co. Asks Inquiry on News Leak
description: WASHINTON, June 16 The Ford Motor Company has asked Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney General, to begin an inquiry to determine whether anyone in the Justice Department had leaked a letter from Ford that was obtained by The New York Times.

title: Soviet Hints It Backs U.S. Trade Despite Arrest
description: MOSCOW. June 16The'soviet Union signaled its desire today to continue business as usual with International Harvester even though the company's Moscow service representative is locked in a cell in Lefortovo Prison.

title: Record Price for a Puzo Paperback
description: After 15 hours of bidding that ended in the early hours yesterday, Mario Puzo's novel; Fools. Die, to be published next Oct. 9 by G. P. Putnam's Sons. has been sold for a record figure of S2.55 million for paperback reprint rights to New American Library. Pert of the package includes reprint rights to Mr. Puzo's bestknown novel, The. Godfather, which had been previously licensed to Fawcett Books.

title: Summer Search For Smooth Skin
description: This year's beach scene promises to be the barest  short of a nudist colonythis country has ever seen. Bikinis have shrunk to a few triangles held together with cords, and even the more modest maillot has legs cut up to the hipbone. Which means that the skin exposed should be slick and hair free:

title: Cash And Run
description: At 7:33 P.M. Car 73 answered threeohnine at the Cyprus Hot Dog n Fried Hoininy Counter n CarryOut.

title: Suspect Called Unsure Whether He Killed Girl Scouts
description: PRYOR, Ckla., June 16A convicted robber stunned a pretrial hearing here today by testifying that Gene Leroy Hart, charged with the murders of three young Girl Scouts, told him in a recent jailhouse Jimmy Don Bunch, summoned as the first witness for the defense, said under crossexamination by state prosecutors that he asked Mr. Hart several weeks ago while both were in the State Penitentiary at McAlester whether he was guilty of the charges.

title: Felicia Montealegre C. Bernstein, Actress, Composer's Wife, Dead
description: Felicia Monteslegre Cohn Bernstein, the cctress and wife of Leonard Bernstein, died yesterday of cancer at their home in East Hampton, L.I. She was 56 years cid.

title: Spain Lifts Foreign Bank Curb
description: MADRID, June 16  A longawaited decree that would permit foreign banks to open in Spain  the last major country in Western Europe to restrict their entry  was approved tonight at a Cabinet meeting presided over by Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez.

title: Bones in Venezuela Hint at Culture 13,000 Years Ago
description: The prchistric Clovis hunters of North America, long considered the oldett example of a biggamehunting culture in the New World, may now have a rival for that distinction: the El Jobo Hunters of what is now Venezuela.

title: APlant Builder Turns to Dismantling Old Ones
description: MARCOULE, FranceFor the last 20 years. Andre Cregut has built most of the important nuclear power plants in France, including the controversial Phoenix breeder reactor that rises amid the vineyards and medieval villages here on the bank of the Rhone River.

title: Thomas Poulter, 81, Polar Explorer
description: Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, a scientist, inventor and polar explorer who was second in command of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, from 1933 to 1935, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Stanford Research International in Menlo Park, Calif.. where he was a research consultant. He was 81 years old and lived in Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: Reds Tom Seaver after nohitter
description: Associated Press

title: Court Orders New Jersey to Pay For Abortion for Medicaid Client
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 16Despite a New Jersey law that permits the use of Medicaid funds for an abortion only if a woman's life is in danger, a Superior Court judge ordered the state today to pay for an abortion for a 24yearold Newark welfare recipient who fears that her child would be born deformed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The JarvisGann initiative adopted in California provides an opportunity for political leaders to face reality. A great many Americans feel alienated from their government and their political leaders. Many of the leaders know this and move in a variety of ways to restore public confidence in themselves. Mostly they fail because they do not understand public sentiment. Properly interpreted, JarvisGann may jolt them to reality.

title: Carbide To Sell B.P. Some Units In Europe
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell two European subsidiaries and other facilities to the British Petroleum Company for about $400 mil. lion.

title: Cuban Ballet Performs an Unfamiliar Coppelia
description: By introducing an unfamiliar version of Coppelia to New York Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the National Ballet of Cuba reminded audiences that, just as playwrights repeatedly extract fresh meanings from wellknown Greek myths, choreographers like to rework certain ballet scenarios.

title: CARTER AND TORRIJOS CONCLUDE TREATIES ON CANAL's TRANSFER
description: PANAMA, June 16President Carter joined Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera here today in ceremonies that formally concluded the new Panama Canal treaties, declaring that a new era of interAmerican understanding and cooperation was at hand.

title: A Penalty for Matewan's Teachers
description: TRENTON, June 16 (AP)The 470 teachers who struck the Matawan school system for 15 days last year will spend a 10hOtir day removing rubbish from the New Jersey Shore as a penalty, a spokesman forGovernor Byrne said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Jersey municipalities could set up combat zones to permit live sex shows and the sale and exhibition of obscene materials, under legislation approved by the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE GIMBELS GROOVE Tomorrow the big store at Broadway and 33d Street begins a free entertainment series saluting the forthcoming Newport Jazz Festival, with daily sessions of live music, dancing, and performances by jazz specialists, many of them. scheduled to appear in the festival.

title: Tom Robinson, Rock, Politics
description: Tom Robinson, who began a twonight run at the Bottom Line on Thursday, has attracted a good deal of attention. His opening show was broadcast on WNEWFM with a fervent introduction by that station's Vin Scelsa, and in general Mr. Robinson has drawn the sort of press and progressiveFM radio attention heretofore reserved for such other British new wavers as Graham Parker and Elvis Costello.

title: Museum Seeks Funds For Theater Collection
description: The Museum of the City of New York plans two fundraising events for the benefit of its Theater Collection, which is said to be the country's most extenSive archives on the Broadway theater.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 16 (AP)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain agreed today that prospects were improving for talks among all parties in the Rhodesian conflict, A participant at a? conference here of the two aides commented: The consensus at the meeting was that the time is not yet ripe for the U.S. and British Governments to push too hard for the convening of allparty talks bringing Prime Minister Ian Smith's Government together with the leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrillas. But there was a shared view that the time for such a develop; ment is ripening.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times reported incorrectly yesterday that Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana was a chief strategist for the Administration's proposal to revise the Federal Labor Law. He is a leading opponent of the effort to change the law.

title: City Fiscal Plan Called Imperiled By U.S. Aid Cut
description: New York City and state officials warned yesterday that unless they could persuade Congress to restore $500 million in bond guarantees cut by the Senate Banking Committee the city's fouryear financing plan would be jeopardized.

title: Detectives Take Sleuthing Lessons and Help Out in Real Murder Case
description: It was an unusual classroom assignment  to help find a murdererL  but theft, this was an unusual group of students.

title: Manhattan Opera's Tledermaus
description: Like so many of New York's smaller operatic organizations, the Manhattan Opera Singers was established three years ago to give muchneeded experience to young performers. A laudable goal, but one wonders if it was best served by the group's overly ambitious choice of Die Fledermaus on Thursday night in_Alice Tully Hall.

title: Miss Farrell And Martins In G Major
description: There was a goodly amount of music In G Major on Friday night at the New York State Theater. There was a lot of piano music, too, that kept Gordon Boelzner busy as piano soloist. Not only did the New York City Ballet offer a repetition of George Balanchine's Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2, a magnificent tribute (in G Major) to the grandeur of academic classicism, but the program also included this season's first performance of Jerome Robbins's In. G Major, to the Ravel piano concerto.

title: Carey Proposes an AutoExhaust Inspection Plan
description: ALBANY, June 15Attempting to win approval of an automobileinspection program, Governor Carey has proposed an exhaustemissions inspection program for the New York City metropolitan area that is considerably weaker than one required under a Federal Court order.

title: Merger Moves
description: The play in acquisitions last week shifted to attractive companies outside the United States. The Occidental Petroleum Company pitted itself against the Canadian Government's PetroCanada in bidding that reached over $500 million for Husky Oil Ltd., a company with vast reserves of heavy oil in Saskatchewan and Alberta. And Tenneco Inc. reached an accord with Albright & Wilson Ltd., a British chemicals producer whose profits have been on the rebound, to buy all the shares of Albright & Wilson it did not already own  after TennecO raised its offer of $180 million to $215 million.

title: Key Matches Set Today In Soccer's World Cup
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 17The dramatic moments of the 11th world soccer football championship begin tomorrow, when Argentina faces Brazil and West Germany, the defending champion, takes on the Netherlands in the second games of the second round of play.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation Continued

title: Television This Week
description: 3 P.M. (7) U.S. OPEN. Live coverage of the final round of play in the golf tournament being held at the Cherry Hills Country Club in Denver.

title: DINING OUT Discomfort Razes Expectations La Ruche
description: IN OUR brief career as a restaurant critic, we have not been so disappointed as we were on our two visits to La Ruche in Cold Spring. Expectation, of course, plays an important role in disappointment, and perhaps we had been led to expect too much.

title: Three Approaches to Jazzmen's Piano Pinnacle
description: Three jazz pianists, all with roots in the bebop period but none suffering from overexposure in New York's clubs or concert halls, took provocative but quite different approaches to their music in concert at Cami Hall on Friday evening called Piano Pinnacle.

title: India: New Tourist Developments Help the Twain to Meet
description: Oh, East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet Till Earth and Shy stand presently at God's great Judgment Seat.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Gruszeckl of Kings Point, N. Y., are proud to announce the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia, to Gary David Kronfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loster Kronfeld, of Brooklyn, N. Y.

title: Spokane Gets Hockey Team
description: PHOENIX, June 17 (AP)  The Pacific Hockey League announced today that a franchise in Spokane, Wash., had been added to the conference and that a 60game season aould open in that city on Noc. 4, League officials also said they would give further consideration tomorrow to an application by Tucson, Ariz., to join the conference. Phoenix, San Diego, San Francisco and Long Beach. Calif., were the previous members of the P.H.L.

title: Woman Charged in Assault of Agent
description: A woman sought as a, witness in a Federal grand jury inveStigation of a teamsters union local has been arraigned for allegedly assaulting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who tried to sere her with a subpoena to testify.

title: GARDENING Child's Play in the Summertime
description: SCHOOL will be out in this area this week and restless children are eager to turn in their books and have some summer fun. Some of their friends in private schools have already been set free.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT IS difficult to conceive of Luigi Bartolini, or Vittorio De Sica for that matter, being able to deal adequately with that sophisticated new phenomenon, The Suburban Bicycle Thief.

title: Authority On Mental Lapses
description: MANCHESTER, England Please don't call me an absentminded professor, begged James Reason, an experimental psychologist here who, for the past two years, has been studying what he terms slips of action  in other words, absentmindedness.

title: United Press International
description: TOWERING FLAMES: Firefighters are dwarfed by flames from refinery blaze at El Segundo, Calif. Some flames leaped 400 feet into the air. No Injuries were reported and fire was controlled within iwo hours.

title: 5 Children's Bodies Recovered
description: SAN LUIS PASS, Tex., June 17 (UPI)The bodies of five children dragged out to sea by a powerful undertow on Thursday have been recovered. The children had been on an outing with their families and had asked to go swimming after the campers in which they were traveling got stuck in the sand at Surfside Beach. Te strong current at the beach was well known to area residents, officials said, but many warning signs had been taken for firewood or souvenirs.

title: POLITICS Ticket Formation Proves Difficult
description: THE Westchester politicians, putting their county tickets together for the November election, have been involved in an unusually slow process. It looks now as if that process will not be completed until tomorrow night and possibly not even then.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Everywhere I went last week I felt for the performers. Or most of them. There they were, noble souls to the final curtain, doing not only their own work but practically everybody else's, too.

title: Pearson Wins Pole Spot
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 17 (AP)David Pearson shaved twothousandths of a second off the hourold track record of Benny Parsons today and won the pole position for the 400mile Grand National stockcar race tomorrow. Pearson drove lap over the twomile Michigan International Speedway oval in 44.162 seconds, an average speed of 163.936 miles an hour.

title: Nassau A.A.: We've Come a Long Way'
description: THIRTY years ago they met in the basements of private homes, they met in church basements in ;Queens, and Brooklyn and Manhattan, and in Nassau County there was only a scattering of organized groups of Alchoholics Anonymous. It was, then, almost a furtive fellowship. A veteran of A.A. said in an interview last week that the total of A.A. groups in Nassau in 1948 was 15 to 20.

title: Sniper's Bullet Wounds Woman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (AP) A young woman was wounded by a sniper's bullet last night as she watched a fireworks display at Candlestick Park after a San Francisco Giants baseball game. Lynn Atkins, 19 years old, was resting today after surgery for a 38caliber slug in her abdomen. Her condition was described as serious. The police said they had no clues or suspects in the shooting.

title: Some Rock Groups Are Thinking Small
description: The Rolling Stones's concerts in the New York area this monththe band was in Passaic, N.J. last Wednesday and will be in Manhattan this weekcall atten tion io a trend that is gaining increasing currency among rock stars.Performers are starting to appear in halls far smaller than their popularity might entitle them to.

title: Farm Belt Democrats Unhappy With Beef Import Rise
description: CHICAGO, June 17  The political waves from President Carter's decision to grant a slight increase in beef imports are washing across the Farm Belt faster than the economic ripple the Administration expected from its rather modest move to slow inflation.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: PEOPLE with very good memories may recall that Harper & Row used to publish books designated as a Harper Find. Harper Finds were supposed to be books of quality by unknown authors that had strong sales potential.The selection was made by the Harper & Row salesmen; editorial types had absolutely no say, and, as in a Quaker meeting, the vote had to be unanimous. Harper Finds over the years have included The Wapshot Chronicle by John Cheever, A Tree Grows in Brooklynby Betty Smith and Reveille in Washington by Margaret Leech. The last one was Cricket Smith by Monte Linkletter (remember him?), published in 1959.

title: Holly H. Campagna Married to James W. Riley 3d
description: Holly Harcourt Campagna and James Wilson Riley 3d were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane Griswold in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Samuel C. Walker of Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, performed the ceremony.

title: ONEMAN RADIO CARS TERMED SUCCESSFUL
description: The New York City Police Department's experiment with oneofficer radio cars is working out well, according to police officials, but there are no plans at present to expand their use.

title: Officials Call South Shore Beaches And Water in Excellent Condition
description: Despite the ferocious storms. of last winter and some recent sightings of sludge and muck, Federal, state and local Officials report that tlie beaches on the South Shore are in excellent condition and that the water quality has never been better.

title: NEW JERSEY REAL ESTATE
description: WHEN most people think of a house, they conjure up images of, perhaps, Colonial, a Cape Cod, Tudor, a Victorian or a contemporary style. taut a handful of New Jerseyans have a different kind of vision. They live in geodesic dome homes, and they have found a mixed bag of pleasures and pains to go with this life style.

title: Fashion
description: There's something about slipping into a man's terrycloth bathrobe. Or silk pajamas. Or Shetland sweater. Men's clothes have always had an appeal to women. Today, it's a growing trend, and women are invading the men's departments of stores everywhere to equip themselves with the latest fashions. for women  bow ties, boaters, vests, pajamas and oversized nightshirts.

title: DINING OUT
description: Since last summer, the 1770 House has been owned by Mimi and Sid Perle. Mrs. Perle was one of the original partners in Les Chefettes, a Great Neck caterer and cooking school. A stint in a Sag Halibor restaurant a few summer seasons ago convinced her that owning and running a country inn was a dream that required realization. The Perles left Great Neck for East Hampton, along with carloads of antiques and artifacts that they had collected over the years.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The competitive pressures of business in recent years have brought about a decided increase in the number of executives who get fired.

title: PRACTICAL ADVICE
description: Use double rods to increase hanging space.

title: A Project to Combat Beach Erosion
description: THE Army Corps of Engineers plans to combat beach erosion and provide hurricane protection in several areas between the Fire Island National Seashore and Montauk Point.

title: John D. Pennekamii, Former Editor And Florida Environmental Leader
description: MIAMI, June 17 (UPI)John D. Pennekamp, former associate editor of The Miami Herald and a leader in Florida's environmental movement, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: The New Dtente Musicians in Exil
description: W HAT do you do? said Joel Spiegelman, professor of music at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville. The musicians are very good. Each one has been trained to be a virtuoso. We promised them piece of America, a piece of apple pie. What do you do with them?

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: We share Representative Joan Kemler's concern [May 21] over the inequity of the present welfare system and the continuing wellbeing of the system.

title: POLITICS
description: STATE Senator Bernard Smith's surprise retirement will cost Suffolk County one of its heavyweights in the State Legislature and is particularly significant now because it follows the loss of another influential state legislator from Suffolk, Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader, who is gambling his political future on the gubernatorial race.

title: Zambia's Copper Wealth Has Become a Lead Balloon
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ten years ago Zambia, mineralrich country of seven million people, had the highest per capita income in Africa. Even now, Lusaka, its capital, has a clean and polished look, the public buildings overlooking pleasant thoroughfares. But it is all a Potemkin village, obscuring deepseated troubles.

title: Millions for Bikeways Are Unused
description: THE flurry of enthusiasm that erupted a few years ago over a future profusion of bicyclepath networks in New Jersey seems to have abated with few tangible results. For all the excitement and dreams, and the millions of dollars made available for bikeways, less than a million was spent between 1974 and 1977.

title: Daddies
description: On Father's Day, Judy called. Are those doctors taking good care of you, Daddy? They damn well bet ter. I'll be very angry if they don't. Oh, Daddy! A breathy delight in her voice. Daddy will make them make all right. I love you so much, Daddy.

title: Buck Fever
description: ALBANY  Nelson A. Rockefeller underwrote his own gubernatorial campaigns for years and, in 1979, he helped his losing faithful lieutenant, Malcolm Wilson.

title: Deaths
description: WEINSTEINHelen, beloved wife of Hymen, devoted mother of Margot Baron arid Stephen Weinstein, cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Richard Baron, Lawrence and Janet Weinstein. Services Sunday, 11:30AM, The Riverside, 7651 and Amsterdam Ave. Family will receive at the residence.

title: MINOR PARTIES BACK MAJORPARTY SLATES
description: The New York State Liberal and Conservative Parties held their nominating conventions yesterday and, as had been generally expected, their memberships endorsed the statewide tickets of the Democratic and Republican Parties, respectively.

title: Guide to Free Jazz Concerts
description: Passaic Public Library, 195 Gregory Avenue (2017790474), New Orleans Nighthawks, today; Moorestown Public Library, 111 West Second Street (6092340333), Nighthawks, July 9; Elizabeth Public Library, 11 South Broad Street (2013546060), Howard McGhee, July 9; Phillipsburg Public Library, 200 Frost Avenue (2014543712), Jazz a Cordes, July 16; Plainfield Public Library, Park Avenue and Eighth Street (2017571111), Nighthawks, July 16, and the Bayonne Public Library, 697 Avenue C (2013390690), Howard'McGhee, July 16.

title: Pat Costello Captures Women's Bowling Event
description: DOWNEY, Calif., June 17 (AP)Pat Costello finished a Women's Professional Bowling Association tournament in top form today, rolling five consecutive strikes and a ninecount to win the $50,000 Los Angeles event.

title: Homosexuals Find It Easier To Buy Homes in Suburbs
description: He was a young man, welldressed though somewhat subdued. He was looking for an interesting house, he told the real estate agent, preferably something secluded with lots of trees on the property.

title: Charles L. Brock, Publisher, Marries Mary Jane Hipp
description: Mary Jane Hipp, a member of the NeW York Junior Lergue, was married yeSterday to Charles Lawrence Brock of New York, publisher of the international division of Scholastic, educational publications.

title: Flynn Takes Yonkers Race for Humans
description: YONKERS, June 17Trotters and pacers travel about twice as fast as racing human beings. A standardbred track is not designed to bring out the fastest speed of top human milers.

title: Making Our Way in the World
description: KISSINGER loss is a psychological disorder afflicting many commentatqrs here and abroad, and not a few foreign heads of government as well. Its most obvious symptoms are frequent expressions of distress at the present course of American foreign policy, a visible bewilderment at the conflicting signals that come from the Carter Administration's uneasy combination of evangelical zealots and gray bureaucrats, and strident complaints that there is no sign of grand design (architecture the term often used) underlying this country's actions in international arenas. If only Henry Kissinger were still running things, goes a popular refrain, we would be doing very much better.

title: Where Islam is the dominant religion
description: INDIA  Although India is officially secular and nonsectarian, the distrust of gig centuries between its Hindu majorityidolaters in the eyes of Islam and its huge Moslem minority of more than 60 million largely farmers and concentrated in the north, remains. It is frequently exacerbated by traditional petty provocations as well as the memory of the Moslem Mogul empire which once conquered and ruled the subcontinent. Despite disclaimers, domestic policies are often seen by Moslems as being aimed at the repression of their community or even, as in the case of the forced sterilization program under Indira Gandhi's Government, at its destruction.

title: The Nurse in a New Role
description: ANEW patient at Planned Parenthood of East Suffolk had been told that she would he examined by a nursepractitioner rather than by a physician. Nonetheless she seemed surprised and relieved  when an assistant at the Patchogue clinic. introduced her to Thelma Georgeson. Mrs. Georgeson is a warm, gentle woman in her early 50's who is among those pioneering expanded roles for nurses in her area.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSETT  Still Life  the Unusual, oils on canvas by Frank Bologna; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Thursdays through Saturdays, Mondays; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Sundays; through July 1; Gallery East, Main St. Reception today 3 to 6 P.M.

title: Miss Lopez Trails by 3 In Pursuit of 5th Title
description: ROCHESTER, June 17 (AP)  Jane BlaAock shot a fiveunderpar 68 today and took a twoshot lead after two rounds of a $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association event. Nancy Lopez, seeking a fifth consecutive L.P.G.A. victory, shot a 73 and, was in third place, three shots behind the leader.

title: Planners vs. Business: Easing the Acrimony
description: NEW ROCHELLE THIS city is among several Westchester communities that recently have seen the clashes between planners and merchants that often occur when implementation of the planners dreams interferes with business and costs the merchants money. But at least in New Rochelle the acrimony has been considerably minimized by a broadbased and detailed information program.

title: LIBEL SUIT AGAINST PAPER WON BY STATE SENATOR
description: ALBANY  State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn, RepublicanConservative of CornwallonHudson, has been awarded $38,000 by a jury in State Supreme Court in Orange County, in a libel suit he brought against a Middletown, N.Y., newspaper five years ago.

title: Ideas & Trends The Court Backs Multiple Voices In All Communities My Billy Fishes Keep Their Pool SeCond Thoughts In the Cancer War Connecticut With Bagels? Feds Back Down On Code Research In God We Trust and Bankers Tom Fqrrell and Virginia Adams Dr. Arthur Upton
description: Some thought the porridge was too hot and some thought it was too cold, but the Supreme Court thought it was just right. Last week the Court upheld Federal Communications Commission regulations governing ownership of newspapers and broadcasting stations by the same companies. The decision settled cases filed both by owners who claimed the regulations were too restrictive and by the Justice Department and a nonprofit organization who claimed they were too generous.

title: Don Allen, Lawyer, Weds Toni Golden
description: Toni K. Golden, daughter of Mrs. Irving M. Schoolman of Chevy Chase, Md., and New York, and the late Mr. Schoolman was married yesterday evening to Don Affeldt Allen, son of Mrs..Wildemar W. Affeldt of Oak Park, Ill., and..the late Dr.Affeldt. The bridegroom legally transposed his middle name and surname.

title: Crime And Punishment
description: O UR society is plagued by two crimes that require immediate attention. The first is burglary and related offenses, and the second is the illegal possession of a weapon.

title: Helen Elliot Bearn Fiancee
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Gordon Bearn of New York and North Stonington, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Elliot Bearn, to Russell Parsons Pennoyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morgan Pennoyer of New York and Katonah, N. Y. The wedding is planned for Sept. 16 at the Brick Presbyterian Church, where the future bride is on the board of deacons.

title: Almost All People Were Created Equal
description: IF the history of the oppression of blacks in the United States displayed merely murder, beating, robbery, rape and other extralegal violence, would be bad enough. But it has been worse  a history of atrocities sanctioned by the majesty of the law.

title: An Optimistic Scenario From the I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON  A world torn apart by trade and banking incongruities while the Middle East piles up petrodollars  that was Paul E. Erdman's depressing scenario in his popular novel, The Crash of 79.

title: STAMPS
description: The first 1978 commemorative of the United States to bear, starkly in black, the designation of a new higher firstclass postage rate that is undisguised by such de vices as the letter A, is a multicolored 15cent vertical rendering honor to photography.

title: What's Doing in DETROIT
description: RENAISSANCE CITY  There's probably no major city in the nation more misunderstood than Detroit. The civil disturbances of the late 1960's and the deterioration that followed shackled, the Motor City, capital of the world's auto industry, with the reputation of being a highcrime area, but fortunately that image is fading fast. The main reason for this is that Detroit, the largest city in Michigan and sixth largest in the nation, is enjoying a renaissance, a rebirth highlighted, appropriately enough, by the construction of the $340 million Renaissance Center downtown. This development, incorporating housing, office buildings and hotels, is rising on the banks of the Detroit River, the tributary that links Detroit with the Great Lakes, the world's busiest inland waterway.

title: Kuo Mojo Cremated in Peking
description: PEKING, June I7 (Reuters)Kuo Mojo. one of modern China's leading literary figures, was cremated here today after lying in state at the Peking hospital where he died on Monday at the age of 86. Mr. Kuo was president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and a deputy chairman of Parliament.

title: H. T. White 3d Plans to Wed Miss Phillips
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C. Spencer Phillips of Lake Fairlee, Vt., and Rotonda West, Fla., of the engagement of Mr. Phillips's daughter, Elizabeth Wallace Phillips, to Harold Tredway White 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. White Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and West Falmouth, Mass.

title: United Press International
description: HIGH STEPPING: Butch Hobson of the Red Sox narrowly avoided falling into the Mariners dugout as he chased foul ball in third inning yesterday in Boston. Red Sox won, 54.

title: Music and Mester Thrive in Aspen
description: To conductor Jorge Mester and many of his musical colleagues, Aspen is magic word this time of year. It carries connotations of pastoral Colorado, serenity, fresh air and beautiful, mountainous country, all appealing thoughts after a full season of jetting around the globe to guest engagements. More important, though, is that Aspen, as the home of one of the country's biggest and bestknown summer music festivals and study institutes, offers virtually unlimited opportunities for chamber music and orchestral performances. To the harried concert artist, it is the perfect place for a working vacation.

title: BILL BRADLEY for U.S Sector
description: He had been a Princeton basketball allAmerican in the mid60's, a goldmedal Olympian, a New Yorker profile subject at the age of 21, a Rhodes scholar and, for a decade, an enigma wrapped in a New York Knick uniform. And now he was representing himself as a politician. But 12 days ago the voters of New Jersey were finally convinced that the real Bill Bradley had at last stood up. As a candidate for the United States Senate in the June 6 Democratic primary, he was a walkaway. Bradley carried 20 of 21 counties, and raked in more than 60 percent of the vote.

title: Pylons as a Way to Cut Clutter
description: Around the city's 318,000 lampposts there is an everwidening clutter traffic signals, trash receptacles, mail boxes, fire hydrants, public telephones, parking meters, police and fire call boxes, regulatory and directional sign posts, flag poles.

title: Councilman De Marco Weds Dorothy Vecchione
description: Dorothy Joan Vecchione of Little Silver, N.J., widow of Joseph M. Vecchione, was married last evening to Councilman Michael De Marco of the Bronx. Civil Court Judge Anthony Mercorolla performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz.

title: HIGH SOCIETY
description: No one forced Karl Marx to go to Monte Carlo. No British tax counselor put him onto it, no Italian security adviser suggested it to him as a place where he could work on his tan and ride out the Red Brigade storm, no travel agent from Cleveland offered him sevenday allinclusive junket directly to the dice tables with action guys like Artie Smolen, his brother Murray from the jewelry business and their ecumenicalyear buddy Frankie Donofrio. Karl Marx  yes, the beard and class struggle guy  simply arrived, it seems, in Monaco late in the last century on a slightly mysterious visit that made clear he thought something interesting was going on.

title: ANTIQUES
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD SOME 30 dealers in antique clocks, watches and parts, and just plain collectors who wanted to show off what they had, spread out their wares in a motel assembly room here recently.

title: Sleeping Beauty as a Housewife
description: BACK in 1966, the then 24year old Peter Handke made a triple debut, more or less simultaneously: he published his first novel, produced his first play, and launched his career as a 1960'sstyle rebel. Critical notices were mixed, but his vituperative and muchpublicized assault on Group 47, the newly enfranchised German literary establishment, brought the young Austrian instant and gratifying notoriety.

title: Zaire Said to Seek More Aid to Meet New Peril to Shaba
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 17 (Reuters)Zaire has appealed privately for fresh Western military aid following reports that up to 1,000 antiGovernment rebels are massing on the Angolan border facing. Shaba Province, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Lessons Learned With Rhododendrons
description: EARLIER in the season, caution was urged against being too hasty in pruning back winterdamaged rhododendrons and other broadleaf evergreens. By now they have begun to recover, if indeed they are alive, and it is much easier to distinguish between living and dead tissue. Luckily, it would appear that most plants seem to be recovering much better than earlier appearances would have indicated.

title: 28 Are Charged With Selling Fake Lottery Tickets
description: Twentyeight New York City shopkeepers have been arrested on charges of selling bogus lottery tickets offering better odds than the authentic state version.

title: Leslie Conrad Wed To Dana Dreibelbis
description: Leslie Conrad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Conrad of New York, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Dana Ernst Dreibelbis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jason F. Dreibelbis of Oxford, Pa. The Rev. Allen Gartner performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of the Messiah.

title: Naval Officer Weds Marian Livingston
description: Marian Bayley Livingston, daughter of Mr.. and Mrs. Ralph Livingston of Concord, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Comdr. Eric Vanderpoel 2d, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Arent Vanderpoel, also of Concord.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I don't jog. If this makes people who do jog feel smug about their muscle tone, so be it. One old geezer, a friend who chuffs and wheezes through Manhattan each dawn, assures me that refusal to pound arches on concrete signifies a yearning for the grave.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In concluding his June 11 OpEd article [The Cold War Again?], Norman Podhoretz seeks to support his argument (in essence, for resistance to the U.S.S.R.) by citing a piece of current advice from Peking. He says: As the Chinese tell us, the most dangerous source of a new world war today is the Soviet Union. And as they also warn  it is appeasement of Moscow, not resistance, that will bring us closer to war.

title: Utilities And Shutoffs
description: ONMAY 1, the state's Board of Public Utilities adopted significant new administrative rules that both strengthen the protections afforded to the consumer and delineate the responsibilities of the individual public utility. These new rules concern residential shutoffs and customer deposits.

title: THEATER The Hartman Is Not As Plush as Its Seats
description: IT IS time to drum up enthusiasm for the Hartman Theater Company, which may have had a helping hand when it was being born but is in no plushier spot today than any other regional theater. And no theater in Connetticut has suffered more from rumors of wealth that it doesn't have thin the Hartman.

title: A FlandsOn Experience With Art
description: MOST art displayed in museums and galleries is meant to be seen and not touched. But visitors to unusual exhibition that begins next Sunday at The Gallery in HastingsonHudson will be encouraged not only to touch, but also to stroke, strum, sit in and try on the works of 17 artists and sculptors.

title: PUBLIC UNITS COMPETE FOR CALIFORNIA FUNDS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17Eleven days after Californians voted to slash property taxes 60 percent, state and local government has become a battleground of competing interests vying for money, jobs and bureaucratic survival.

title: LaudaWins Grand Prix In Sweden
description: ANDERSTORP, Sweden, June 17(AP) Niki Lauda of Austria, driving his controversial Brabham BT 46 sucker, captured his first Formula One victory of the season today in the Swedish Grand Prix.

title: Howard Snyder Weds Francesca L. Engler
description: Francesca Louise Engler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Engler of Kings Point, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last night to Howard Mark Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Snyder of Willow Grove. Pa.

title: The World
description: For reasons of politics as well as health, Prime Minister Menachem Begin chose to rest for four days last week in preparation for a Cabinet meeting today that may prove crucial.. After two futile efforts,the Cabinet will try again to decide on a response: to United States questions about the future of the West Bank of the Jordan River. The Cabinet has been divided for weeks because the answers could: determine the course of American relations with Israel, now at a low point, and of the deadlocked peace ne. gotiations initiated by President Anwar elSadat in November. They wil1 also be a measure of Mr. Begin's internal political strength. '

title: Questions/Answers
description: Is there a way to inhibit violets speading throughout the lawn? Mrs. E.I.S., Waban, Mass.

title: Deriving Inspiration From the Cascades
description: From a hillside above Puget Sound, 40 miles away, the Cascade Mountains are not very imposing. They resemble a craggy spine sprawled across Washington State's broad forests. It is not until you are actually in the mountains that you begin to feel how big they areand how small you are.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TO travel quickly between the Island and Albany, Perry B. Duryea usually pilots his own plane, using the airport in Montauk as his home base. Therefore, it seemed like a good idea the other day to stop by at the airport on the eve of Mr. Duryea's selection as the Republican candidate for Governor to chat about the airport's most noted customer.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The problem presented in A Tale of Two Downtowns [May 21] is certainly a concern of many people. I compliment the Chambers of Commerce and each village for the efforts to restore these areas.

title: Val de Loire Displays Top Form for Ox Ridge
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 17AL this juncture in the horse show season, the pieces in the open jumper division are beginning to fall into place. The horses that pose a threat have asserted themselves and the ones that are destined to become alsorans already have been frustrated in most of their action.

title: Against.the Odds, New York Gets Its Guarantees
description: An ideological logjam over Federal loan guarantees for New York City was blown away by a neatly placed charge of Hoosier common sense last week, perhaps opening a path to a coherent attack on the city's financial shambles.

title: United Methodists Vote to Allow Homosexual Minister to Keep Job
description: For the first time since he publicly acknowledged being a homosexual last year, the Rev. Paul Abels has been assured of retaining his Methodist congregation for the next year.

title: BRIDGES IN NEW YORK ARE CALLED UNSOUND
description: A strong possibility of structural failure exists on many of New York City's bridges, according to a draft of an audit report being prepared by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Ice Cream Joins Cookies on Town's Proscribed List
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, June 17 Last year, this seashorecommunity drew wide attention because it was enforcing its antilittering law by fining people for eating cookies in public, while letting off icecream eatersbecause ice cream an American institution.

title: A Warrant for New York
description: It is clear now that Congress will agree to let the taxpayers of the United States cosign at least $1.5 billion worth of New York City's bonds over the next few years. In all likelihood, this will cost them very little. But it is an extraordinary guarantee that needs to be Understood, and honored with further commitments in many quarters.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on cloture motion on Labor Reform bill, requiring a threefifths vote of those present for passage,. rejected, 58 to 39, June 15.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IF you are a family with a couple of children, living in the vicinity of Smithtown, how would you like a puppy? Not just any puppy, either. How would you like a Labrador retriever or a golden retriever? Along with the puppy comes free veterinary service, free equipment for the dog and a chance to deduct the dog food as charitable expense.

title: GOLDEN AUDIT STUDIES AID TO HANDICAPPED
description: A New York City Comptroller's audit has disclosed that it is far cheaper for the city to send handicapped children to private schools than to educate them in Its public schools.

title: Transit Quiz: How Big, Old or Many Is a Kid?
description: Did your daughter ever suffer a trauma on a bus?

title: Affenpmscher Leads Way For Breed in No. America
description: Ch. Lel Cocagi Kamehameha, named for kings in his native Hawaii, is now the king of the affenpinschers. Last Sunday the little monkey dog became the first representative of his breed to win a best in show in North America. The 7pound toy accomplished this feat by beating almost LON dogs at the Tonawanda Valley Kennel Club Show in Batavia, N.Y. Robert Wills of Newbury, Ohio, judged the final.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THIS is the season for weddings on the Island  and it is also the season for bar mitzvahs and that paean to young Jewish womanhood, the bat mitzvah party.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: MONTAUK, by Max Frisch. (Harvest / HBJ, $2.95.) The Swiss novelist and playwright, a considerable figure in contemporary German literature, used this memoir of a weekend spent on Long Island with a young New York woman as an occasion to reflect onhis early career as an architect, his gradual literary success, his relationships with many women. Thin, tricky but appealing and often moving, wrote our reviewer, Michael Wood.

title: 106Piece Machine
description: THE symphony orchestra seems always to have been with us. In reality, it is a fairly recent invention, not much over a hundred years old. There were orchestras before the 1850's, of course, and in this lively, informationpacked book about the history of the symphony orchestra, Henry Raynor goes back to medieval times looking for the roots. But not until the middle of the last century, with the development of valved instruments that could play in every key, and with the prodding of such composers as Berlioz and Wagner, did the symphony orchestra assume the form it still substantially has today.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IF YOU think they have problems in places like Zaire, you haven't been paying attention to the ominous rumblings in Westchester. Stirrings of discontent are in the air. The natives are restless. There are discurbing mutterings about the injustice of the political divisions. Towns are accused of exploiting villages, incorporated areas milking the unincorporated, cities plundering townships. The havenots are looking hungrily at the haves. Meetings are being held with increasing frequency, their attendance growing, anger mounting.

title: A Tradition of Taxpayer Revolts..
description: CALIFORNIA may feel it's trendsetter in property tax revolts, but East.Haddam is not impressed. We cut ours first. We preceded them, said Clara Scheideker, whose own version of Proposilion 13 was approved by East Haddam voters May 31, reducing local spending by more than $123,000 in a town where the total budget is less than $3 million. Mrs. Scheideker's action cut in half proposed tax increase of just under 3.5 mills.

title: Two U.S. Senators and a Professor  All Urban Specialists  Discuss Ills of. the Cities and Some Remedies
description: The Week in Review invited Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin; Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and George Sternlieb, director of the Rutgers Center for Urban Policy Research, to discuss wider urban issues raised by New York City's request for Federal loan guarantees. Immediately following the vote last week approving such loans by the Senate Banking CommitteeMr. Proxmire was opposed and Mr. Lugar forged the successful compromise  they convened in Chairman Proxmire's office. Joining them to ask questions were Robert Reinhold, a reporter specializing in urban affairs in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, and Daniel Lewis, an editor of The Week in Review. Excerpts from the discussion follow.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Anything Goes. Tonight only, 8:30 P.M. $5.50. The Ritz. Wednesday to next Sunday, 8:30 P.M. (through July 2). $5.50 to $7; discounts available for students and the elderly. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6.

title: What the County Can Try Besides Proposition 13
description: JUNE 6 was the Day of the Locust for politicians and government bureaucrats in California as voters swarmed to the polls and passed, by a 21 ratio, Proposition 13; I was not surprised by the way the voting went. I had just returned to Westchester after spending a week in southern California and had seen signs everywhere of a rebellion in the making.

title: Louis Zukofsky: All the Words
description: EYES, YES, he wrote, is pronounced I's; language blinks, his eye was unblinking:

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Gore is a compulsive worker, Mr. Epstein said. He gets up very early, writes on legal pads until late in the morning, does his mail, and then gets When I called Gore Vidal's editor at Random House, Jason Epstein, he said that at the moment the author was having dinner at a restaurant in Amalfi but would probably return soon to his villa in Ravello. That seemed right. If you have written Kalki, a novel about apocalypse and the brave new world to come, living along the Amalfi coast in Italy seemed the only way to go. back to work again. He goes through a number of drafts till he gets it right. I don't think he can type  at least I've never seen a typewriter in his house. But he turns over his draft to a typist, insists on giving me a clean copy, and revises his manuscript several times over.

title: IRAQ, IRAN AND SAUDIS DISCUSSING ALLIANCE
description: PARIS, June 14  Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia are discussing a Persian Gulf security arrangement that could create a major shift in the strategic balance of the oilproducing area, according to informblion reaching high French officials and intelligence officers of other countries.

title: Chinese Aide Bids Third World Unite With.West Against Soviet
description: TEHERAN; Iran, June 17 (AP)Foreign Minister, Huang Hua of China, in an interview published today, urgedthird world countries to unite with Western Europe to thwart what he called Soviet plans for global dominance.

title: Births
description: Susan and Neil Chodorow of Prince Edward Island, Canada, are happy to announce the birth of their son, Nicholas Isaiah, at 10 pounds and 6 ounces, on May 28, 1978.

title: Molly Bedell Wed To John Robinson, Broker in Chicago
description: Molly Barnes Bedell and John David Robinson were married yesterday afternoon in the Palisades Presbyterian Church in Sneden's Landing, N. Y. by the Rev. Fay Ellison.

title: DINING OUT Down on the Farm in Flanders Silver Spring Farm (Fair)
description: ON A recent Saturday night, our party of four arrived promptly at 8:45, which was the earliest time that the restaurant (Silver Spring Farm in Flanders, in Morris County) could take us. At 9:45, we were still without appetizer, wine, bread or even water. At 10:45, we were still waiting for the entrees. At 12:15, we were still waiting for dessert and coffee.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Stock prices suffered a sharp break late last week under the pressure of rising interest rates and fears of a possible credit crunch that ultimately might force some borrowers out of the marketplace.

title: L.I. Pediatric Wing Called a Waste
description: The $35 million pediatric wing just approved by the state for the Long Island JewishFIillside Medical Center will have a turbulent impact on pediatric service on the Island, predicts Thomas Cranshaw, head of the federally financed health planning agency for Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Carey Is Sent a Bill To Allow Lawyers Before Grand Jury
description: A controversial change in New York State law that would permit lawyers inside the grand jury room has been quietly passed by the Legislature and sent to Governor Carey for his signature.

title: The Regibn
description: Not long before the Democrats picked New York City for their 1976 national convention, city officials persuaded the legislature to pass a law designed to drive streetwalkers off the streets. For a while at least, the pedestrian aspects of Sin City would vanish from midtown. Basically, the law made it a crime for prostitutes on the prowl to loiter, and actively solicit, in public places. Twentysix hours after the law took effect, there was an arrest and, not much later, a conviction and an appeal.

title: Linda Powers Wed To John Middleton
description: Linda Leigh Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Muller Powers Jr. of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday to John 5taubus Middleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Middleton of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. DaVid B. Waftermulder.

title: Anne Rutherford Fiancee Of Lawrence E. Morelli
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Woodson Rutherford of New Canaan, Conn., and Annisquam, Mass.., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Afton Rutherford, to Lawrence Edgar Morelli, son of Dr. Lorenzo MorelliPando of Jackson, Mich., and the late Louise MorelliPando.

title: Charles Rappold 2d Weds Melinda Seeley
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patricks Cathedral yesterday morning, Melinda C. Seeley and Charles E. Rappold 2d associates with the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, were married by the Rev. James Stanton.

title: U.S. Knows of No Buildup
description: WASHINGTON, June 17A State Department official said the United Stateshad not received any indications of a new buildup of Kantangan rebel forces in the AngolaZaire frontier region. The official said he thought it doubtful that such a buildup had developed.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN you want to install number of fence posts so that their tops will be level, or if you are building a brick wall, sundeck or other project with posts or other structuralis not so easy to do with a portable handheld drill. One trick that works in almost every case is to wrap a short piece of plastic tape or masking tape around the bit so that its bottom edge indicates the exact depth you want the bit to penetrate. As you drill each hole, just keep feeding until the bottom edge members that are many feet apart yet must be exactly at the same overall height, the easiest way to do the job is to use a simple and inexpensive little tool called a line level.

title: Rendezvous in Montauk
description: In Montauk, Max Frisch, the distinguished European dramatist and novelist, tells of a weekend spent on the Island's East End with a young woman, and he considers, at the age of 64, his dimishing future.

title: NEW CHINESE ROAD OPENS REMOTE AREA TO THE WEST
description: ABBOTABAD, Pakistan, June 17 (Reuters) The Karakoram Highway, a masterpiece of modern road engineering, opens tomorrow, and the 500mile allweather road stretching from the border of Sinkiang Province to a few miles ncrrth of Islamabad will draw China a little closer to the West.

title: Inshore Anglers Focus on Fluke
description: FISHING

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: By a vote of 7 to 1, the Supreme Court last week upheld a Maryland law prohibiting oil companies from operating their own service stations  a decision that could have national impact. Delaware and the District of Columbia have passed almost identical measures, California has a related law and bills are pending in a number of other states. If a movement toward functional divorcement catches on, as now seems likely, the gasoline business is in for a bit of a shakeup.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF

title: Beauty
description: Some men say that a beard makes them feel more virile, others, when pressed, admit that it may have something to do with insecurity. There is always some reason for growing a beard, says one woman who has been married to three different men with beards. Sometimes they want to show something, sometimes they want to hide something.

title: Bill on Slaughtering Of Animals Advances
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)The House Agriculture Committee has approved a bill covering all Governmentinspected plants that requires animals to be knocked unconscious before they are killed.

title: Punishment by Death An Appeal to Principle
description: THERE is a single argument in favor of reinstatement of capital punishment and, admittedly,, it is a powerful one. It is public opinion. Regionally and nationally, polls indicate that a substantial majority of the American people somewhere between 65 and 75 percent  support the death penalty.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: PARIS Now that the new East Building of the National Gallery in Washington has opened with appropriately restrained fanfare and to general critical acclaim, comparisons beg to he made with Paris's Centre Georges Pompidou, or Beaubourg. The new French national center of art and culture has not ceased to be a lively focus of controversy after 18 months of operation.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly comes back to the Capitol tomorrow to complete the last step in writing this year's additions to the state's General Statutes, but Governor Grasso didn't leave the lawmakers all that much to do.

title: Pretoria to Yonkers
description: Sydney Maree of Pretoria, South Africa, and Villanova, Pa., had a dinner date last night with Bert Lancaster, who runs the Martin Luther King games in Philadelphia; Alex Woodley, coach of the Pioneers Club there; Andrew Hatcher, now with Don King Productions; Kevin Brennan, South Africa ViceConsul in New York and Mr. Brennan's father. Dinner was at Yonkers Raceway where not an eyebrow was raised.Some might have been in Johannesburg, for the Brennans are white and the others are not.

title: Soviet Starts Criminal Action Against Jailed American
description: MOSCOW, June 17 (Reuters)The Soviet Union has initiated criminal proceedings against Francis J. Crawford, charging the American with having repeatedly sold large amounts of foreign currency to Soviet citizens at speculative prices, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: IRANIAN AUTHOR CHARGES REPRESSION IS CONTINUING
description: President Carter's support for human rights has raised hopes of intellectuals and writers in trouble with the regime in Iran, according to Dr. GholamHosseim Sa'edi, a prominent author and playwright who is in the United States on a brief visit. He said, however, that intimidation and persecution continue despite some surface changes.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Lynn Chang and Richard Kogan both have won important international music competitions as soloists and as a violinandpiano duo they have performed for four years in major East Coast cities. Their appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. however, was their New York debut as a partnership, and it turned out to be an impressive event.

title: SPORTS The Pilots Who Stay on the Ground
description: WIND never mattered to the entrepreneurs who once raised merion bluegrass on the broad acreage opposite Syosset High School. But to the modelglider pilots who have been earnestly honing their skills on that field in recent days, the wind is more precious than the best price the sod ever commanded. Potential victory is in the air.

title: Design
description: Clothes may make the man, but clothes closets may undo him. Here are three different systems of storage  that keep clothes organized and easy to find and that also reflect the ways of life of the men who own them.

title: Births
description: Sharon (nee Rudolph) and George are delighted to announce the arrival of quadruplets born on June 6, 1978. Liza and Chad are very excited about their new sisters, Alexis Halley: Brooke Ivy, and brothers Ross Can and Jarret Brice. The quadruplets were named in memory of their maternal grandfather Abraham Rudolph, great grandmother, Helen Frey, and beloved friend, Edwin Eiseman. The ecstatic grandparents are Bobbe Rudolph of Cliffside Park, N. J., and Ruth and Al Prussin of Hollywood, Fla. We would like to thank the entire staff of New York Hospital and, most of all, our three excellent doctors, Dr. Michael Strongin, Dr. David James and Dr. Frederick Silverman, who were responsible for the quadruple.

title: Sara Gottlieb, Rush Student, Married to Dr. Paul Monroe

title: Newly Found Papers in Birmingham, Ala., Cast Light on Civil Rights Drive in 1960's
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 17 (AP)A routine search of stored city records has uncovered thousands of documents from the civil rights days of the 1960's, including transcripts of conversations of leaders in the integration movement.

description: At 8 A.M. on June 16, 1904, in Dublin, stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from a stairhead, bearing a bowl of lather.
