description: BESSBROOK, Northern Ireland, June 17 (Reuters)Irish guerrillas shot and, killed a policeman today and abducted another in a carefully planned ambush of an unmarked patrol car.

title: Study Says Oil Embargo Could Wreck South Africa
description: LONDON, June 16  A study commissioned by the United Nations says that an international oil embargo would make the South African economy collapse within two years.

title: More Auto Insurers Weigh Leaving State
description: TRENTON THE automobileinsurance crisis facing the state's more than 3.5 million drivers continues to escalate. Industry officials are warning of dire consequences If proposals by the Byrne administration are approved. the insurance companies say that because of successively high claims made against them, combined with inadequate premium rates to meet the costs of paying such claims (medical bills and damages to vehicles and property), they are losing millions of dollars each year and must reevaluate whether they can continue to do business in New Jersey.

title: Mary Williford Bride Of Dr. P. S. Hedstrom
description: The Reformed Church of itronavIlle, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Ruth Williford, daughter of. Mrs. Oscar Hutcherson Williford of Bronzy'lle and the late Mr. Williford, to Dr. Peter Stuart Hedstrom, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ephraim Hedstrom of Tewksbury, Mass.

title: LettersT0 THE EDIT0
description: I don't know Joan and Paul Garland, but they are much on my mind since the publication of A Fatal Romance at Yale (by Jesse Kornbluth, May 7). These parents have every right to feel bitter about the crusade to save Richard Herrin (left, in photograph), and the fact that he went free 35 days after their daughter Bonnie's murder without a psychiatric examination, and that he had enrolled in college under an assumed name. They cared about Bonnie's chance for an education; this was their oldest child, and she showed much promise. They were almost forced into letting Richard Herrin in for that last and fateful visit, because they had been out of touch with and alienated from their daughter and wanted a fresh start in their relationship.

title: Miss Plimpton Has Nuptials
description: Victoria Plimpton, who graduated magna cum laude last month from Wellesley College, was married yesterday to William Nash Babcock, who graduated June 8 from Harvard University.

title: Wrong Welfare Rejections Are Cut
description: A program for retraining New York City welfare staff mernliers has cut down the number of wrong rejections of applicants from 30 percent to. 11 percent in a month, according to Dr. Blanche Bernstein, the New York City Human Resources Administrator.

title: Stacy Anne Brown Bride Of David Barr Vermylen
description: Stacy Anne Brown and David Barr Vermylen of Cos Cob, Conn., product managers with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, were married yesterday in Saddle River, N.J. Msgr. David Price performed the ceremony in the St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: In Search of Solitude on the Mediterranean's Secret Beaches
description: Some people like me ask little more of life than to come upon a small empty crescent of white sand facing a body of translucent water. Failing that, a long stretch of deserted beach will do very well. The relative modesty of this desire suggests a simple mind, devoid of both originality and energy. While others search for love, wealth or intellectual fulfillment, we have long since abandoned such lofty goals, which is not to say that our limited objective is easily obtainable.

title: Yachting Calendar
description: 14Larchmont Yacht Club Independence Day regattas.

title: 16 Libraries to Give Free Jazz Concerts
description: FREEHOLD AJAZZ fan's dream of having concerts in. his local library has turned into a series of free programs that will be presented this summer and fall in 16 New Jersey libraries. For five years, John H. Livingstone, director of the Monmouth County Library, has been, staging free monthly jazz programs at the librarys Eastern Branch in Shrewsbury. He has now managed to spread the concept throughout the state by means of grant from the State Council on the Arts to the New Jersey Library Association.

title: Young Widowed: Helping Them Cope
description: DIANE FLUTIE'S husband died in November when he was struck by a car, and for the 48yearold woman, going to a meeting of the Young Widowed of Westchester was the first time I had sat down with a group of people since the accident. There were a lot of tears, there still are, but I felt I wanted to be with people I could relate to.

title: Turkish Trouble
description: T THE function of the novel seems to be changing, wrote Doris Lessing in The Golden Notebook. It has become an outpost of journalism; we read novels for information about areas life we don't know Nigeria, South Africa, the American army, a coal mining village, coteries in Chelsea, etc. Most novels, if they are successful at all, are original in the sense that they report the existence an area of society, a type of person, not yet admitted the general consciousness.

title: Deaths
description: ELLSBERGLucy Buck, of Southwest Harbor, Maine, died on June 15. Beloved wife of Admiral Edward  Ellsberg, she is also survived by a grandson, Edward Ellsberg Pollard, of Wayne, PA; a granddaughter, Ann Pollard Hellakka, of Brooklyn; and a great grandson, Nicholas Cooke Ellsberg Pollard. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Mary Ell sberg Pollard Memorial Scholarship Fund, Hollins College, Roanoke, VA 24020, would be appreciated.

title: When the Coach Told Billy Baney to Sit on the Ball, Billy Sat on
description: Now that the National Basketball Association playoffs are over, I can think about other things. I love basketball and the playoffs. They remind me of my days as a basketball coach.

title: Headliners
description: One way or another, somewhere or another, David It Berkowitz and his demons seem sure to spend the rest of their mutual life in confinement. Last week the criminal justice system performed the necessary gesture: Mr. Berkowitz was sentenced, by judges from Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, for six murders and several assaults and attempted murders in those boroughs. Some of the 25yeartolife murder sentences are to run concurrently, others consecutively, but by state law Mr. Berkowitz will be, theoretically, eligible for parole after 25 years. He was transferred to Dannemora, where he underwent psychiatric examinations to see if he should serve in prison or in a facility for the criminally insane. Few criminals have been so thoroughly psychiatrically examined as Mr. Berkowitz already, and to verify that he knew what he was doing at the sentencing, one judge asked if his guilty plea had been your own, without the compulsion of the demons? They had some influence, Mr. Berkowitz admitted, but maintained the ultimate decision had been his.

title: Regulation: Do Its Costs Outweigh Its Benefits?
description: WASHINGTON  Suddenly, everyone is against regulation. Regulation is being blamed for high airfares, bad train service, energy shortages and any number of economic and noneconomic ills. The present occupants of the White House, who trace their political heritage to the New Deal, are sounding more and more like the laissezfaire Republicans they replaced. Conservative economists are saying I told you so and liberal economists are claiming they've been telling us all along.

title: Food
description: WASHINGTON  The painful rise in meat prices slowed last week as more animals came out of the feed lots and into the market. But that bulge in the supply will soon disappear, and the Agriculture Department brought no cheer to consumers when it predicted beef would cost them an average of 20 percent more this year than last.

title: Floral Park Nine Takes Title

Floral Park defeated Southampton, 64. for the Class A title, while Commack South edged South Side of Rockville Centre, 76, for the Class AA crown.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS TO ADD BORDER UNITS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17  Lebanese Christian factions have decided to send reinforcements to southern Lebanon to strengthen their forces near the border with Israel, according to Christian sources here.

description: Theodore R. Mann, a lawyer from Philadelphia, has been elected chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations. He will assume the office on July 1, succeeding Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, who has headed the conference sInce February 1976.

description: MAMARONECK O NCEthese would have all gone to be cut for wiper cloths for industrial use, Kal Fagan said, sweeping an arm past 1,000 pairs of used jeans awaiting new owners. Outside his crammed, oneroom shop, The Attic, sign proclaims brokenin jeans. The sign might have said brokendownnearly all appear to have suffered a hard existence at the hands, and seats, of previous owners.

title: Deteriorating I80 Typifies Ailments of Interstate System
description: BARTONSVILLE, Pa.  The whole Interstate 80 isn't worth the powder and lead you'd need to blow it apart, declared a trucker who calls himself Pocket Rocket as he waited to cash check at the Union 76 Truck Stop here.

title: INVESTING
description: Sometime this week, the Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third biggest auto manufacturer and a company that lost $120 million in the first quarter, is scheduled to sell $150 million of preferred stock and warrants to purchase common shares in the largest sale of speculative securities this year. The uncertainty of Chrysler's financial future  and the caution with which some analysts view the offering  is underscored by the unusually high, 11 percentplus yield on these units.

title: Castro Says Carter Lied on Cuban Role
description: Fidel Castro, the Cuban Communist leader, has accused President Carter of lying about Cuban involvement in the recent invasion of Zaire while, he added, the Central Intelligence Agency was setting the stage for American intervention in Angola.

title: The Policemen Want the City To Prove It Can't Pay More The New York Times/Gary Settle Richard Hartman (left) and Sam DeMilia, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
description: Like Pauline tied to the tracks, New York City has successfully weathered the peril of many labor crises. And last week it seemed likely to avoid the most traumatic of urban walkouts, a police strike.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: May was not a pledsaht month so far as the health and safety of American workers were concerned. Both a recent ruling by the Supreme Court of the United States and a decision by President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers leave working people wondering just where they can find help in their attempt to reduce the 13,000 workplace deaths and 300,000 new cases of occupation disease they face each year.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Here is a littleknown fact that many collectors may not be aware of: Our government once put out a $10 bank note to promote an exposition. It was the Buffalo Bill of 1901 with pictures of Lewis and Clark on it, and was undoubtedly issued to stimulate interest in the Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition held in Portland, Oregon in 1905. (Gene Hessler in The Comprehensive Catalog of U.S. Paper Money.)

title: HOW CARTER CAN STOP INFLATION
description: Inflation begins as a social good, not as an evil. Take what happened during the French Revolution. It started out as a simple, Spartan reaction to the extravagant, lascivious, pleasureloving habits of the aristocrats. But, because it frightened businessmen and drove capital out of the country, commerce and trade stagnated. To cure the stagnation, the Revolutionary Government printed paper money, the socalled assignats, issued against the security of the vast public lands confiscated from the church and the emigrant noblemen. At first the assignats got the country humming again and revived employment. But the initial success created demands for more. As more and more assignats rolled off the printing presses, prices soared and a new disease infected the French character. Speculation and gambling became epidemic; some gamblers rushed to the stock market, others to the roulette wheel. Workers loafed ; productivity lagged. Businessmen, looking for the big kill, stopped going after small gains by investing in plant and equipment or making stepbystep technical improvements. Corruption spread to government ; the public grew cynical about politicians who enriched themselves while mouthing the rhetoric of popular reform.

title: The Politics of Education
description: STUDENTS in my course read Diane Ravitch's The Great School Wars, a superb political history of the conflicts over New York City's schools from the Catholic immigrant wars of the 1840's to the tragic communitycontrol battles of the late 1960's.

title: Unemployment: The Structural Variety Is The Toughest
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter took office year and a half ago, his avowed domestic priority No. 1 was bringing down the unemployment rate, then topping 7 percent. With occasional spirited prodding from organized labor and minority groups, Mr. Carter adopted policies that helped subtantially. Unemployment declined by more than a percentage point; employment grew by four million.

title: Saudis and Iranians Block OPEC Oil Price Increase
description: GENEVA, June 17  Saudi Arabia and Iran were reported tonight to be blocking at effort by other major oil producers to raise world prices at the annual summer meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here.

title: FILM VIEW
description: One of the most obvious pleasures in watching movies is responding to a film's sense of place, which is more than just the way a place looks, though that too is important. I remember some years ago when, for the first time, I arrived Cairo by air. As we circled the city we could see the Citadel and the old quarter on the east bank of the Nile, while, on the other side of the river, just beyond the line where the city suddenly stops and the desert begins, we could see the Sphinx and the pyramids at Giza. I had the feeling that I'd been through all this before, but it wasn't djvu. It was Cinerama. To be more exact, This Is Cinerama. The first Cinerama feature had included a spectacular flight over Cairo that gave the audience not only breathtaking view but an awareness of where each major landmark stood in relation to the others. The film, in fact, was more efficient than the airplane I was in, since it was necessary, in the plane, to dart from one side of the cabin the other while the Cinerama. view, shot from the pilot's cabin, set everything before us in one vast panorama.

title: Richard Pilsbury Jr. Weds Mary Anderson
description: The Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Wells Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Anderson of Clinton, to Richard C. Pilsbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pilsbury of Laurens, S.C.

title: J. R. O'Donnell Weds Brian D. Mackinnon
description: The marriage of Brian Denvir MacKinnon, daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward MacKinnon of Houston and the late Mr. MacKinnon, to James Robert O'Donnell took place yesterday in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, where the bride did graduate work at the Instituto Allende. The bridegroom is a son of Rear Adm. Edward O'Donnell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. O'Donnell of Monterey, Calif. The Rev. Olegario Gaitan Zavala performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Parroquia Arcangel.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN you want to install a number of fence posts so that their tops will be level, or if you are building a brick wall, sundeck or other project with posts or other structural members that are many feet apart yet must be exactly at the same overall height, the easiest way to do the job is to use a simple and inexpensive little tool called a line level.

title: Richard J. Sirota Will Wed Lynda Carol Chyhai in Fall
description: Col. Alex Chyhai U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Chyhai of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynda Carol Chyhai, to Richard J. Sirota, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Sirota of New York. A late September wedding is planned.

title: THEATER Fourth Act at the Hartman Theater
description: STAMFORD THE very first column I wrote for this section a year and a half ago concerned two new regional theaters, one of which was the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford. One of the people I interviewed shrugged off the success of the Hartman with, Listen, what do you expect? They were given $2 million to start off with. The implications beneath the statement are: (1) With a great deal of money any theater can succeed, which is too ridiculous to waste time discussing; (2) I'm jealous of all that money, which I would like to have, and I hate them for having it; (3) So why should anyone ever help the Hartman?

title: Successful Heretic
description: WRILE no crowd has ever unhitched the horses of Gian Carlo Menotti's carriage draw him through the streets in triumph after a premiere, he is, perhaps, the only living composer who earns a good income from, of all things, his operas. In recent years Mr. Menotti has devoted himself to another sort of brainchild, the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, an annual summer presentation of music and theater. He has also been a spokesman for younger composers, a patron of rising artists and an antagonist of many trends in modern music, despised by the establishment for the double sin denying 20thcentury orthodoxy and, worse, doing very well out of his heresy. Now 63 years old, he has been everywhere and known everyone. This biography by John Gruen, a frequent commentator on the arts for newspapers and magazines, is apparently the first in English.

title: Judith Ayres, John Burke 3d Are Married
description: Judith Elzabeth Ayres, a legislative affairs specialist with the National Park Service in Washington, was married yesterday to John Woolfolk Burke Sd. a lawyer with the Sollcotor's Office of the Department of the Interior, also in Washington.

title: Bethlehem Steel's Grand Inquisitor
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.  Some 18 months ago, Donald H. Trautlein was. thinking about taking early retirement from his senior partnership at Price Waterhouse & Company. After 25 years there, the 51yearold accountant was contemplating teaching, or perhaps writing a book about the quiet, seldom reported infighting that goes on between clients and accountants.

title: Out From Under the Shadow
description: The chief uses of a second in a match are to help his principal work up a strong opening repertoire in the months before the contest, making whatever emergency changes may be required during breaks between the games, and to analyze nonstop an adjourned game in the 24 hours before play is resumed.

title: If You Go
description: to North Cascades National Park from Seattle's SeaTac Airport the trip covers about 100 miles on Interstate 5 and State Route 20 to the western portals of the park. To Chelan, the gateway to the park's east side, is 200 miles. Take 15, U.S. 2 and U.S. 97. Charter planes are available from Seattle.

title: 25 Years After East German Revolt, Strains Linger
description: EAST BERLIN, June 15  Twentyfive years ago this week, on a cool morning, construction workers at a downtown building site put down their tools and went on strike to protest production norms. The workers march to the city center set off the first uprising in Sovietoccupied Eastern Europe since 1945.

title: Cuban Dancers Represent Two Societies
description: Mention the National Ballet of Cuba, now appearing at the Metropolitan Opera House in its first New York season, and the name of its founder and director quite properly springs to mind. Alicia Alonso has lone held a special place in the hearts of New York balletomanes. But the company is more, of course, than Miss Alonso and more than the usual collection of dancestruck youngsters now grown into a profession. The 70 Cuban dancers, products_ of a balletconscious society, represent both preand postrevolutionary artistic roots in Cuba in a way that mirrors the changes brought on by the revolution in 1959.

title: South Korean Defects to North
description: TOKYO, June 17 (UPI)  A South Korean Army intelligence officer defected to North Korea because he was greatly discontented with President Park Chung Hee's puppet clique, a North Korean broadcast reported today. The Korean Central News Agency identified the officer as Maj. Li Jungwang, 35 years old.

title: Seaver Hopes to Duplicate Vander Meer Feat of 1938
description: CINCINNATI, June 17 A(P) month ago, suffering the worst slump of his career, Tom Seaver scoffed at suggestions that he had grown old or was hiding an injury.

title: U.S. Aides Push New Plan for Random Deploying of Mobile Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Senior defense and foreignpolicy officials, eager to curb the increasing vulnerability of American landbased rockets, are pressing the White House to insure that proposed strategicarms accord with Moscow will not rule out a new plan for deploying mobile missiles in the 1980's.

title: SPORTS The Communications Gap
description: EAST RUTHERFORD THE communications gap in sports is getting wider, not smaller. For example, take Roy Boe, the beleaguered boss of the New Jersey Nets of the National Basketball Association.

title: Reopening of People's Firehouse Is Celebrated
description: The people of Brooklyn's Northside section yesterday celebrated the reopening of Engine Company 212's firehouse, which had been shut down during the city's fiscal crisis, partly reopened and is now, after months of clamor, fully reopened.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Nurses, in Survey, Contend Understaffed Hospitals Endanger Patients
description: Patients face intolerable dangers in American and Canadian hospitals that are short of nurses, according to many licensed practical nurses and registered nurses who took part in a study of working conditions and job satisfaction.

The Mets return to Shea Stadium to play the Montreal Expos at 8 P.M. on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday and the Pittsburgh Pirates at 8 P.M. on Friday and P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE first warm winds of spring reached the tall oaks on High Mountain in Franklin Lakes in the early days of April. It was a special time for those who were living the first seasons of their own lives.

title: lust For Once, National Selfishness May Save a Natural Resource
description: WASHINGTON  A belief that the sea is an almost inexhaustible well of food for mankind may not be true. But several factors, which ironically include selfish nationalism, may mean that it is not far from true in practical terms.

title: Helping the Chronically Ill Adjust
description: WHITE PLAINS IN NOVEMBER Ethel Mee, who was born in England 85 years ago and had never before been a hospital patient, suffered a stroke that affected her speech and weakened her left side. She spent seven days at Northern Westchester Hospital, then a month at the hospital's Skilled Nursing Care Facility. Mrs. Mee would gladly have gone straight home but her doctor insisted that the Burke Rehabilitation Center was the proper next stage.

Williamson Jr., of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., to Stephen Rossi Shambaugh, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Shambaugh of Old Mission, Mich., took place yesterday at the home of the bride in Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Will Herzfeld, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: For 39 Pupils of an Orthodox Jewish School in Riverdale, It Was. a Capital Adventure
description: WASHINGTONDiana Lisa shrugged her shoulders and said, I can define Washington in three words: pillars, steps and marble.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Most of the nation's major commercial banks, led by Citibank, increased their prime rate last week to 8 percent from 8, the highest level since January 1975. A major reason for the increasing cost of money has been action by the Federal Reserve to control overly rapid expansion of credit as a means of checking inflation. The prime rate is the rate banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.  M1, the basic measure of the nation's money supply, was unchanged last week at $349.7 billion, and money markets, which had expected a decline in the aggregate, braced for more credittightening moves by the Fed.

title: California and the World
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  If you want to see a clear example of the influenc6 of domestic politics on United States foreigR policy, consider the effect of California's Proposition 13 on this year's Federal foreign aid budget, which goes to the floor of the House in a few days.

title: Deborah Sampson, Teacher, Married to Mark D. Reutter

title: Ann Gaumond Lainer Married to David Wilson Jr.
description: Ann Gaumond Leiner and David Anthony Wilson Jr. were married yesterday in the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N. J., by the Rev. Bruce G. Ineles. He was assisted by the Rev. Richard G. Jordan, vicar of St. John's Episcopal Church in North Guilford, Conn., and uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Jeannette Hunt Married
description: Jeannette Fisher Hunt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving R. Fisher 3d of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to J. P. Robert Nolette, son of Mrs. J. P. Robert Nolette of Beverly, Mass., and tne late Mr. Nolette. The ceremony jvas performed at the Fisher home by the Rev. R. Sherman Beattie of the Mound Hill Community Church in Lizenwich, Conn. The bride and bridegroom were both previously married and divorced.

title: FISHING
description: THE best inshore bets for the Island angler this week are fluke and blackfish, while offshore the action alternates between blue shark and bluefish, with the elusive swordfish the province of the purist.

title: Balloons and a Kite Fail to Halt Flights at Tokyo's New Airport
description: NARITA, Japan, June 17 (Reuters)Three tethered balloons and a kite were hoisted near Tokyo's new international airport tonight but they did not affect plane landings and takeoffs, the police aid.

title: Agriculture Aide Picked
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) Gene Triggs, an executive of the Mississippi Chemical Corporation, has been selected for the Agriculture Department's second highest. position, Administration sources said today. Mr. Triggs, 49 years old, of Yazoo City, Miss., would fill the deputy secretary's job, left vacant when John White left the Agriculture Department to become chairman of the Democratic National Committee in January.

title: Losers, taxes a new jail and culture
description: Citizen protests have managed to bog it down, and William Fauver, the new Commissioner of Cor rections, said last week that the site in northern Mercer County, now tentatively agreed upon, might be scrapped.

title: Crime From the Victims View
description: EVEN today, two years later, the Winterfeldt family of Hempstead still suffers from the traumatic effect of the incident. Now 33 years old and prematurely gray, Douglas Winterfeldt was born with cerebral palsy. His wife, Paulette, 30, who has long, flowing black hair and sparkling blue eyes, was also afflicted with the diasease. Both have spent their entire lives confined to wheelchairs.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY A Grandmother Makes the Grade
description: PICTURE this: Graduation night at the Nassau Coliseum, more than 3,000 graduates, and this grandmother, the oldest fulltime woman student attending Nassau Community College. After the delirious joy of the processional, granting of diplomas, and speeches, the recessional begins. The faculty, in all their traditional majesty, lead the way.

title: Dance: 2 Premieres by Cubans
description: Tha National Ballet of Cuba continues alonrin its deliriously received way at the Metropolitan Opera House. Friday night brought in two premieres, Alberto Mendez's Tarde en la Siesta ("Late in the Afternoon") and his Ad Libitum, a novelty number for the company's prima ballerina, Alicia Alonso, and the Spanish dancer, Antonio Gades, who is appearing as guest artist.

title: Pension Fund ConsultantsThe Tail That Wags the Dog
description: The $200 billion invested in corporate, union and other pension funds is the largest and fastestgrowing single pool of private capital in the world and the chance to invest those billions, and reap the commissions therefrom, In 20 minutes some guy with a pencil goes scratch and twoandahalf years of going after an account is down the drain. I tell you, it's the last time I go after an account when a consultant is involved.  a West Coast investment manager.

title: Keds Outpaced
description: Sneakers meant summer, and they belonged to kids  tree climbers, fence runners. But with the rise of tennis and jogging, sneakers have been taken over by grownups, and competition among footwear makers has become intense.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN you want to install number of fence posts so that their tops will be level, or if you are building a brick wall, sundeck or other project with posts or other structural members that are many feet apart yet must be exactly at the same overall height, the easiest way to do the job is to use a simple and inexpensive little tool called a line level.

title: Mets riumph, 5 to 4, Ending Giant Streak
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17A 40 lead proved insufficient for the New York Mets last night, but a 5.0 advantage proved just enough today as they triumphed by 54 and ended the San Francisco Giants sevengame winning streak.

title: Miller Back In Control After Slump
description: DENVER, June 17  For more than a year now, golf aficionados have been asking, What has happened to Johnny Miller? What happened today was that he shot a threeunderpar 68 to move into contention in the United States Open at Cherry Hills, only four strokes off the lead.

title: Spiritual Healing Gaining Ground With Catholics and Episcopalians
description: The practice of spiritual healing, traditionally associated with Pentecostal groups, is rapidly gaining favor in thousands of Roman Catholic and Episcopal chuches, institutions that have long been uncomfortable with the ancient Christian practice.

title: Reporter's Notebook: On the Fluctuations of N.B.A. Owners Meetings
description: CORONADO, Calif., June 16Franklin Mieuli, the owner of the Golden State Warriors, walked through the 91yearold lobby at the Hotel del Coronado, the site of the National Basketball Association meetings, in his usual faded dungarees. A colorful Tahitian shirt was adorned by love beads dangling from his neck. Most of the other owners were also casually dressed. Some had just come off the tennis courts. But David Stern, the league's new general counsel, carrying a huge briefcase and a copy of Roberts Rules of Order, was dressed in a beige threepiece suit.

title: Inside Congress
description: MEMBERS of New Jersey's Congressional delegation will soon become visible to their constituents again in this election year, and when they ask for voter support to return them to their desks in the Capitol, a good question to ask might be: Why?

title: INTERVIEW
description: EDISON WHEN Dr. Rose Channing came into her office the morning after she was appointed president of Middlesex County College, the switchboard operator was so overjoyed that she told the new president that the campus was walking three feet off the ground.

title: Barry, Free Agent, Signed by Rockets
description: HOUSTON, June 17Rick Barry, free agent who is one of the most accurate shooters in professional basketball, signed a twoyear contract with the Houston Rockets today. No other terms of the contract were available.

title: Indians at San Quentin Complete Sauna Lodge
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., June 17 (AP) American Indian inmates have finished building San Quentin Prison's first sacred sweat lodge, a saunalike but where Indians can meet for an ageold ritual of purification.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MANHASSET THE Miracle Mile offers something for everyone  status labels, standard brands, super style and service for the namedropper or discount shopper. In the Munsey Park center, for instance, trio of fashion shops bridges the wardrobe pattern from birth to career, marriage and maternity.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE balanced ticket is alive and well in Connecticut, if one can judge by the speculation among Democrats over possible choices for a candidate for lieutenant governor.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: There is something to be said for preWorld War prudery about the unclothed human bodyat least I thought so after viewing the exhibition photographs of male nudes at the Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street, through July 28. If artists of the 19th and early zutn centuries used unclothed human figures in a picture, the figures had to stand for something other than themselves: for Truth, for Aspiration, for Labor, for Innocence, for any number of ideals and abstractions. Otherwise the pictures were merely pornographic or merelyscientific or joke.

title: A Specialist for the
description: WHITE PLAINS SHERRI, a bright, energetic 5yearold, stormed out of her house one evening after an argument with her mother. She picked up her brother's baseball bat and slammed it against a light pole. In an instant, the neighborhood was in darkness. The lights had all gone out.

title: Charlotte Lyeth, Michael Dively, Lawyer, Marry
description: At the RiverdWle Presbyterian Church inthe B.ron. yesterday, Charlotte Dobson Lyeth was married to Michael Augustus, Dively. The ceremony was peyformed, by the Rev. David D. Cockc(oft. assisted by the Rev. Dr. Alvin Ciirtis Brewer of the First Congregational ChurCh in Traverse City; Mich. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Jervis Campbell Webb of Riverdale, Detroit and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late John William Clarke of Evanston, Ill., was adopted by her stepfather, the late 1. M. Richardson Lyeth Jr. of New York. The bridegroom is a son of George S. DiVely of Cleveland and Bbca Raton, Fla., and the late Harriet Seeds Dively.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Former Inmate Returns to Prison To Join Her Class in Graduation
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 14When Barbara Jenkins, a 30yearold woman who was serving a oneyeartolife sentence at the state prison for women here was paroled last March, she told other inmates that she would never return to the prison.

title: Used Cars: The Poor Get Poorer
description: The poor, who provide a disproportionate number of customers for the $33 billionayear used car market (as large as the new car market), pay significantly more for used autos than do other people.

title: Practical Advice Has Not Worked Will Persuasion Work Better? The Epidemic of TeenAge Pregnancy A nurse Instructs unwed motherstobe about Occupation and contraception.
description: WASHINGTON About one million teenage girls, one in 10 between the ages of 15 and 19, get pregnant every year. About 600,000 actually bear children, and childbirth often triggers consequences that cloud the rest of the mothers lives. Teenage mothers are much more likely than their peers to drop out of school, earn low wages, have large families, and wind up on welfare.

title: France's New Film Idol Is a Cuddly Bear: Victor Lanoux
description: PARIS Talking to Victor Lanoux, the engaging danceinstructor hero of Cousin, Cousine, you get the feeling he has been somewhere you have not. That's probably because he has. Experience hangs about him like cologne. With A Woman at Her Window and Servant and Mistress just having opened in New York, We Will All Meet in Paradise just closed and Replay scheduled to open next month, Victor Lanoux is dominating the movie houses.

title: ART
description: TRENTON THE State Council on the Arts has been a powerful and generous asset over the years, inspiring and enabling scores of New Jersey artists, as well as a number of cultural institutions, to come into their own.

title: CORRECTION
description: Assemblyman Peter Shapiro of South Orange, who won the Democratic nomination for the new job of Essex County Executive  sort of county mayorin the June 6 primary, will resign from the Assembly if he wins the county post in November.

title: Behind Scenes Of Carew Story
description: It occurred to Rod Carew sometime last year that, while $190,000 a year \vas a pretty good salary for most ballplayers, he was being grossly underpaid.

title: For the Elderly, a Reign of Fear
description: MANY elderly men and women in New Haven, Hartford, Bridgeport and Stamford and throughout the state live in fear of crime. These elderly are the same people who heard Franklin D. Roosevelt state that the world was founded upon four essential human freedoms  freedom of speech, the worship of God, freedom from want, and last but not least, freedom from fear.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PHILADELPHIA  On the same day last week that one of the nation's most prominent economicforecasting services here issued a fairly optimistic report on the American economy, a leading businessresearch organization convened a twoday meeting to discuss another crucial economic problem  how to find more jobs for vast numbers of minorities and other hardtoemploy individuals.

title: SAKHAROV WARNS FREEDOM HINGES ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and political diesklent, has warned Western foes of nuclear power that such power plants could be a key to the continued economic freedom of the West.

title: Nancy Epstein, Dan Malchi Planning to Marry on July 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Epstein of Bayonne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Sue Epstein, to Dan Malchi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Malchi of Natanya, Israel. The wedding is planned for July 20.

title: Saranac Inn Destroyed by Fire
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 18 (AP) Fire destroyed the remains yesterday of the centuryold Saranac Inn, where President Grover Cleveland spent his honeymoon. Five stories of the woodframe structure were standing when the fire broke out, Four firemen were injured fighting the fire, according to fire officials. The state police said some 300 firefighters from a 50mile radius were at the scene of the blaze, The old structure was being torn down, but five floors remained. The fire burned the building to the ground and destroyed one nearby cottage, officials said.

title: Cafe Shooting Leaves Five Dead
description: WARWICK, R.I., June 17 (AP)Five persons were killed in a shooting spree tonight in a Chinese restaurant here, the pace said.

title: MARATHON WOMAN
description: There is an entry in Diana Nyad's current itinerary that reads: Depart Cuba July 14  arrive Florida Keys July 16. It does not mention that she plans to swim the distance  103 miles through open water.

title: Unbridled Artist Proving Popular At Soviet Show
description: MOSCOW, June 17One of the happiest men in Moscow at the moment is Glazunov, who is a controversial Soviet artist but is neither a dissident nor a conformist. After 20 years of struggle with the artistic establishment, he has finally been alloWed a fullscale showing in the city's main exhibition hall, the Manezh, situated beside the Kremlin.

title: Rumblings Over a New Pediatric Wing
description: THE $35 million pediatric wing just approved by the state for the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center will have a turbulent impact on pediatric service on the Island, predicts Thomas Cranshaw, head of the federally funded healthplanning agency for Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: DINING OUT Fine Greek Fare for Hearty Appetites
description: NEW HAVEN BASEL'S is anything but a closely guarded secret in New Haven, but it is time word got around to the rest of the state. This Greek restaurant, run by Lou and Ed Basel, has been a local favorite for years, and with good reason. Not only does it boast a big and somewhat unusual Greek menu, but also the prices are extraordinarily low for the quantity of the food served. If you go on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday evening you can enjoy live bouzouki music and dancing.

title: Dr. Karl E. Felsen Weds Carol Laden
description: Carol Terko Laden, an editor and writer with the New York State Assembly, and Dr. Karl E. Felsen, director of Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut's correspondence unit, were married last evening in St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church in Albany by the Rev. Joseph Cebula.

title: Kappas Gets Ohio U. Job
description: ATHENS, Ohio, June 17 (AP)  Bob Kappas, an assistant football coach at Ohio University, was appointed today as acting head coach for the coming season. Kappas, 49 years old, came to the school in 1958. He was offensive line coach.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Priding itself on being the Island's foremost melting pot, Glen Cove salutes its varied ethnic strains in a Festival of the Arts of All Nations today. From 1 to 7 P.M., School Street, smack in the heart of the city, will be turned into a veritable international bazaar and stage, as residents of Italian, Greek, Norwegian, Korean, Irish, Spanish, American Indian, Indian, Jewish, Polish, Czech and Rumanian origins demonstrate and sell their native arts, crafts and culinary delights and perform their backhome songs and dances. In the evening at 8, the festibities, organized by the newly founded Glen Cove Council for the Arts, will move to Middle School, Forest Avenue, for a concert by the Gregg Smith Singers. A Great Neckbased choral group and concert orchestra, the Singers will feature George Gershwin's rarely performed satirical Let em Eat Cake, along with more familiar offerings by Victor Herbert. There's no admission charge to the daytime events, but the concert will cost $3, and $2 for students and the elderly. For reservations, call 6761625.

title: CONGRESS RESPONDS TO FRUGALITY SIGNAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 17When Joseph A. Culfano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, went to Capitol Hill the other day to ask for $60 million to combat the national epidemic of teenage pregnancies, he figured that he would get a sympathetic ear. Instead, he got a lecture on the implications of Proposition 13', the California indtiative that cut property taxes.

title: Guild Vote Ends Strike at News; Reduced Sunday Paper Is Issued
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild of New York voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a threeyear contract agreement with The Daily News, ending a violencemarred, fiveday strike that had shut down the nation's largestcirculation daily newspaper. The contract included some of the givebacks that had been sought by management.

title: U.S, AID TO COLLEGES AHEAD OF INFLATION
description: Federal support for higher education rose faster than the inflation in the 197576 academic year and is expected to sh an even larger increase this year and next, according to an annual survey by the National Science Foundation.

title: 1978 Summer Theater Straw Hat Directory
description: June 28, Just the Immediate Family (new play by Grace Kimmins)

title: Around the Nation
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 17Officials of the Synanon Foundation Inc., a Callforniabased drug and alcohol rehabilitation organization, have entered into a contract to purchase a 167acre farm adjoining the Mright D. Eisenhower farm and histciric site here for $190,000.

title: The Nation
description: Living with Proposition 13 has proved more difficult than voting for it. Californians still were not sure last week if their ballotbox decision to reduce property taxes by $7 billion and limit future increases would mean (a) acute and widespread dislocations, (b) manageable inconveniences or, as conservative economists predict, (c) an opportunity for economic boom.

title: Deaths
description: JONESArthur J. (Ret. Acting Batt. Chief, NYFD), on June 16, 1978, beloved husband of Helen M., (nee Leaver), dear father of Arthur, Margaret Hermansen, Audrey Higgins, and The late Jean Hodgens, brother of Margaret O'Connell. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Funeral Monday, 9:45 AM, from the McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 8225 Third Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of the Resurrection 10:15 AM, St. Anselm's Church.

title: Alice Cooney Wed in Darien
description: Alice Knotts Bossert Cooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Cooney of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to George Lovett Kingsland Frelinghuysen, son of Mr. and Mrs.suelo H. SeherrThoss, wife of the best man. Henry O. H. Frelinghuysen of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Silent Toads: Suitors on the Sly
description: It was the eloquence of Cyrano de Bergerac, in Edmond Rostand's famous play, that won the heart of the beautiful Roxanne. But not for himself. She assumed that the expressions of passion had come from a suitor who actually had remained silent.

title: Ilona Schnapp Is Married
description: Ilona Jill Schnapp and Joel Ian Ontell were married yesterday in the Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle. N.Y.. by Rabbis Samuel Schafler, Samuel Cohen and Melvin N. Sirner. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Schnapp of New Rochelle. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Ontell of Livingston, N. J.

title: Clara Freedman, Pianist, in Recital
description: Judging from her Carnegie Recital Hall program Friday night, Clara Freedman is a young pianist well worth hearing even if her performances did not always quite come together in ways she perhaps intended. Miss Freedman, a native of New York and a JuilHard graduate, is clearly a musician with ideas, and whatever passing flaws her thoughtful, cultivated playing might have had, they were certainly not errors of omission.

title: Residents of Region in Virginia Called Prone to Asbestos Disease
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 17 (AP)The Tidewater region of Virginia has been designated one of 15 areas in the nation where asbestosrelated diseases are most likely to occur, according to the Federal Government.

title: Arts and Leisure
description: WINGSConstance Cummings stars in a Play by Arthur Kopit which received its Premiere this spring at the Yale Repertory Theater. Directed by John Madden. Public, 425 Lafayette St. (6776350) Previews Tues. Opens Wed.

title: Violence For a Cause
description: EVEN those who abet and profit from terrorism find it necessary to condemn it before rationalizing their own complicity. The rationalizations are familiar  how terrorism, rightly seen, is the original sin of imperialists, multinationals or Israelis  but a weak analogy is still not an explanation. It How Democratic Societies Respond to Revolutionary Violence.

title: Top New York State Democratic Candidates, Including Carey, Face Possible Challenges in Primaries
description: While the Republican state ticket began campaigning and fundraising for the general election in November, three of the four designated Democratic statewide candidates, including Governor Carey himself, today still faced possible primary campaigns through the summer.

title: Florida Prison Officials to Stop Free Cigarettes for Jail Inmates
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 17 (AP)Florida prison inmates who now get free cigarettes might find it is a good time to break the habit. They are going to have to start paying far their cigarettes after June 30.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHEL  Paintings by Elaine Feiner, collage by Enid Munroe, through July 5, Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave. Tuesday through Sunday II to 5.

title: 6 Killed and 14 Injured as Boat Capsizes in Tornado in Kansas
description: POMONA, Kan., Sunday, June 18 (AP) Six persons were killed last night and 14 injured when a dinner theater showboat capsized in a tornado on Pomona Lake, about 40 miles south of Topeka. Three persons were missing early this morning.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: I T WAS Friday, Alfred B. DelBello's last day of work before a twoweek European vacation, and he was in an elevator heading for his ninthfloor office. Where would he and his wife,Dolores be visiting, a passenger asked?

title: Momentum Is Seen Shifting to Labor Bill Opponents
description: WASHINGTON, June 17After a fifth attempt to end the filibuster against a bill to revise the national labor law fell short last Thursday, several senators opposed to the legislation took the floor to ask pointedly when diehard proponents would end their efforts and allow the Senate to proceed with other business.

title: Palette of Steel And Brush of Fire
description: NORTH HAVEN ROBERT GIZA struggled with a twoinch pipe, bending it to fit in with a dozen others that began in a rectangular cluster and ended with each pointing in its own crooked path. Close by on the floor lay a large red disk in a stainlesssteel frame, to which the nines would later be attached.

title: Ashley Rowe Bride Of Jeffrey R. Gould,
description: St. George's Episcopal Church in Fredericksburg, Va., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ashley Kennedy Rowe, daughter of Charles S. Rowe of Fredericksburg. and the late Margaret D. Rowe of Richmond to Jeffrey Richard Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Gould of Murfreesboro, Term, Theceremony was per formed by the Rev. Charles Sy Jr.

title: Realty News
description: The law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine is expanding in the RCA Building and the architectural firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum Inc., is moving to the AMAX Building at 1270 Avenue of the Americas, both in Rockefeller Center.

title: Brand Vies to Be No. 1 As Cosmos Goalkeeper
description: Jack Brand, the goalkeeper the Cosmos acquired in the offseason to be their starter but who ended up playing second fiddle to Erol Yasin, will get his third start today when the Cosmos meet the Washington Diplomats at Giants Stadium.

title: Anne Guerci Married To Dr. George Tyson Jr.
description: Anne Elizabeth Guerci, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Harold B, Guerci of Rumson, NJ., was married yesterday to Dr. George Stackley Tyson Jr., a resident in at the Duke University Hospital in Durham, N.C. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Tyson of Florence, S.C.

title: Pan Am Offers Lowest Price Yet
description: After losing its bid to keep its BostonLondon flight in the latest route assignments under the air pact between the United States and Britain, Pan American World Airways took the lead in the escalating discount air fare competition last week by setting the lowest scheduled transAtlantic air fare in the industry's history.

title: ART VIEW
description: Has art now become too expensive to be enjoyable? Does money affect the way we look at an art object? Does money influence the way we study it? What is the relation of money to esthetics, anyway? There is no question but that money plays a roll in the way we think about artbut what is that roll? And is it necessarily deleterious, as most of us tend to think?

title: Lucy Christensen Married To Craig Davis, Engineer
description: Lucy Ann Christensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Walter Christensen Jr. of Cincinnati, was married yesterday evening to Craig MacKalip Davis, son of Mrs. Roy Bryan of Greenville, Del., and the late Mr. Davis.

title: Joanne D. Balfour Married To James Morgan, Lawyer
description: Joanne Dorothy Balfour, daughter of Mrs. Gene Sullivan and the late Henry Balfour, was married yesterday to James Van Doom Morgan, son of Mrs. WilmaKasarda Hodges of Cambridge.

title: Public's Interest in Proposition 13 Moves DelBello to Seek Budget Suggestions
description: WHITE PLAINS ASTHEY sought to translate what California's overwhelming vote for Proposition 13, the voter initiative to roll back property taxes, might mean for Westchester, county officials were focusing their attention on a plan by which County Executive Alfred B. neliiello hopes to harness the public's interest in tax reductions by involving them in preparations for the next county budget.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN you want to install number of fence posts so that their tops will be level, or if you are building a brick wall, sundeck or other project with posts or other structural members that are many feet apart yet must be exactly at the same overall height, the easiest way to do the job is to use a simple and inexpensive little tool called a line level.

title: Maitland Ewing Wed To Richard Lammert, Executive Assistant
description: Maitland Marshall Ewing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tucker Ewing of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Thompson Lammert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lammert 4th of St. Louis.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMERICA'S GREAT ILLUSTRATORS, by Susan E. Meyer. (Abrams, $35.) The work of 10 American illustrators in the popular media from 1880 to 1930, informatively analyzed, beautifully reproduced.

title: Book Review
description: Book Review

title: Guidry Strikes Out 18
description: Ron Guidry of the Yankees struck out 18 batters, one short of the majorleague record, in beating the Angels, 40. Details, Section 5.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter warned Panama to respect the civil liberties of., the 40,000 Americans in the Canal Zone. He said in an address to Americans there, who gave him a generally cool welcome, that he had personally taken steps to assure that their rights would be undisturbed. [Page 1, Column 6].

title: A Guide to Long Island's Beaches
description: The following table shows Long Island beaches that are open to the public. In cases where access is limited for instance, when beach use on weekends is restricted to residents of the town in which the park is locatedthis is indicated on the chart. Hours of operation given indicate times when lifeguards are on duty.

title: Jones's Appendix Removed
description: BOSTON, June 17 (AP)  Rupert Jones, outfielder for the Seattle Mariners, underwent an appendectomy at Beaconess Hospital today. He was hospitalized yesterday after complaining of abdominal pains. This is the 17th major injury or illness to hit us this year, the Seattle manager, Darrell Johnson, said. We're just going to hang in there. In 64 games this season, Jones has a.256 batting average, with three home runs and 23 runs batted in.

title: A Day in the Life of The Radio Mystery Theater
description: The scene is Studio G on the sixth floor of the old CBS Radio Annex on East 52d Street. It is 9 A.M., and five actors are seated around a table covered with scripts. eyeglass cases, coffee containers, pencils, newspapers folded to the crossword puzzle and scattered paper clipssome bent open by anxious fingers.

title: The New Look in Fathering
description: Among the letters of annoyance inspired by our Mother's Day editorial, Some Mothers We Can Do Without, was this challenge from a reader in New Jersey: We will be waiting patiently for Father's Day, not really hoping that The Times will show equal malice toward fathers.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge, Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Niiddlesex Road, Darien. Conn. Junior AmateurOwner Hunter Classic. 9 A.M.; Grand Prix tor jumpers, 2 P.M.

title: Britain Says Saudis Detain a Pilot On a Charge of Making Alcohol
description: LONDON, June 17 (Reuters)A British airline pilot is being held by Saudi Arabian authorities on charges involving the illegal making of alcohol, only days after two other Britons were flogged for liquorrelated offenses, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Facing Reality
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Here is the reality of Proposition 13, as it is being faced by Mayor George Moscone of this city:

title: UNIDENTIFIED SOURCE HELD VALID BY COURT
description: An appeals court has ruled in Manhattan that the Government can use information from an unidentified informer in the sentencing of two reputed members of organized crime.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Out West. Ask a typical New York book publisher what he thinks about the Coast and he's apt to start babbling like a merchant of Venice who's heard a Marco Polo describe a faraway, incredible land. Even if he's had occasion to visit the place himself, his talk is likely to be a compound of confusions. He'll apply the phrase loosely and interchangeably to the American West between Seattle and San Diego, to the whole state of California, to Southern California, to Los Angeles and Hollywood. He'll speak of it as a world where everyone has moved from someplace else, spends half of his waking hours driving from home to office to golf course on crowded freeways, attends the stateliest occasions dressed for the beach.

title: Citibank Fees
description: Fighting banks, some would say, is akin to fighting City Hall. But last week a New York State court, in a suit brought by three Nassau County residents, ruled that Citibank illegally charged and must refund a fee of 50 cents a month to Master Charge customers who paid their bills on time and thus avoided interest charges. The fee, started in April 1976 for billpaying services, was dropped last January.

title: THE ROSENBERGSOBELL CASE REVISITED'The execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1953 for espionage is reexamined in Alvin Goldstein's updated documentary, tomorrow at 9 P.M. on WNET/13.
description: SCOTT JOPLIN: KING OF RAGTIME'Billy Dee Williams stars in a madeforTV biography of the turnofthecentury composer, Tuesday evening at 9 on NBC.

title: Happy Comeback for the Beaches
description: DESPITE the ferocious storms of last winter and some recent sightings of sludge and muck, Federal, state and local officials report that the beaches on the South Shore are in excellent condition and that the water quality has never been better.

title: Julie Diehl Fiancee Of Gary Holloway
description: Julie Ann Diehl and Gary Flint Holloway plan to be married Sept. 9 in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Westfield, N.J.

title: Ancient Tools Found on Hainan
description: HONG KONG, June 17 (Reuters) Relics more than 4,000 years old have been unearthed cn Hainan Island, according to the cfficial Chinese press agency, Hsinhua. The report today said that the site on the island, which is in Chinese territory, contained stone spades and axes, pottery jars and pottery spinning wheels.

title: JOAN LITTLE PLACED UNDER TIGHT SECURITY
description: RALEIGH, N. C., June 17North Carolina officials have taken extraordinary precautions to insure the safety of Joan Little, who was, until her return from New York on June 9, this state's most famous fugitive.

title: Stuart Nathan of F.B.I. Weds Susan Gail Sugar
description: Susan Gail Sugar, a student at the University of Maryland School of Law, was married yesterday to Stuart Milton Nathan of New Haven. who received his law degree from Maryland. Rabbi Donald Berlin, assisted by Cantor Melvin Luterman, performed the ceremony at the Woodholme Country Club in Pikesville, Md.

title: BRIDGE
description: Nobody knows exactly how old the game of bridge is, but it has certainly passed the century mark. The earliest firm date is 1878 when a certain Colonel Studdy, an Englishman, learned to play in the trenches at Plevna while aiding the Turks agaiflst Russia. The actual origin must have been several years earlier, probably in Turkey  or Egypt.

title: Lucia Anderson Wed To James Simpson Jr.
description: Lucia Chase Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Robson Anderson Jr. of La Grange, Ill., was married there yesterday in St. Helena's Episcopal Church to James Johnson Simpson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Craig Barry Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: Keeping Scientists Humane
description: Congress created a national commission four years ago to protect people who serve as subjects of experimental research. There had been reports over the years of patients denied treatment so that researchers could observe the effects of their diseases, drugs being tested on unwitting subjects, mental patients undergoing brain surgery who might have been treated by conventional therapies. Most often the victims were are and uneducated. Su the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research  composed of scientists, doctors, lawyers, theologians and others  was given the job of designing a more humane research policy.

title: Music Festivals:
description: REMEMBER when a music festival was a welcome summer interlude and a great escape to some charming outoftheway spot for a relaxed weekend?

title: While the Giants Go Head to Head, Dixie Holds On
description: NEW ORLEANS  A few weeks ago a young lawyer here moved to a new job in San Francisco. In her luggage, to ease the transition, were two New Orleans mementos: a small bottle of hot pepper sauce and a sixpack of Dixie beer.

title: BROOKE TAX RETURNS SAID TO LIST MARRIED CHILDREN
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, claimed several thousand dollars in income tax exemptions by listing his two daughters as dependents when they were married and liviing away from home, according to The Washington Post.

title: PEOPLE
description: Up from The Cellar: Edward S. Finkelstein, the man who turned Macy's bargain basement into The Cellar, a chic arrangment of shops and gourmet foods, and who is credited with turning Macy's New York Inc. around as well, was promoted last week to chairman and chief executive officer of the division. He had been its president.

title: The World Of Birnba One Version Of Luxury
description: Philip Birnbaum was driving through Queens not long ago when he spotted what he thought was a rather decently designed apartment building. He asked his companion to stop the ear so he could have a look at the building, and wondered who the architect was.

title: The Soviet Terror Continued
description: W E have known about the Russian purges, Edmund Wilson wrote in 1971, but we have not really been able to imagine them. The writer who, more than any of his contemporaries, decisively changed this situation, giving the world an epic account of the suffering and destruction Russia has endured under its Communist leaders and giving it in the most concrete, most moving, most Hilton Kramer, art critic of The New York Times, is the author of The Age of the Avant Garde. classical human termsis Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. others have written brilliantly and courageously about their own experience of the Soviet terror and of the ordeals of those close to them. But it is Solzhenitsyn, above all, who has made it possible to imagine the criminal horrors of the Soviet regime both in the magnitude of their history and in their terrible particularity. He is virtually alone among the major writers of the 20th century in having found a form, in The Gulag Archipelago, capable of encompassing the awful moral history of our time.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Climb Into Salyut 6 And Revive Systems
description: MOSCOW, June 17 (UPI)Two Soviet astronauts climbed from their space capsule into the Salyut 6. orbiting station early today after a flawless docking and began flicking the switches that brought their floating home in space back to life.

title: Cheerleader for the Connecticut Yankees
description: BRIDGEPORT CAN somebody help this man? After four years as the owner, coach, general manager and parttime player of the Connecticut Yankees, Robert Kratzer is finding out he can't do it all by himself.

title: Hunt Suspended For Obscene Gesture
description: Steve Hunt of the Cosmos, who made an obscene gesture toward the fans in a game last Sunday, has been suspended for 10 days for conduct unbecoming a player in the North American Soccer League.

title: The Nation
description: ATLANTAFor the first time in a generation or more/ the dominant figures who set the tone of politics throughout much of the South are gone, a point underscored by primary elections and runoffs held in the last two weeks. Time has taken its toll through deaths, retirements and political accommodation. The names that will be absent this fall from ballots for the United States Senate alone read like a short rollcall of the Old South  SparkmanEastland AllenMcClellaneven Wallace, Alabama's Governor having looked hard and decided not to run.

title: At the Barricades in Westport
description: WESTPORT WHILE educators around the country learn how to manage declining student populations, school officials here face a difficult task: convincing taxpayers that a shrinking student enrollment needs better facilities, in the form of a $12.4million renovation of Staples High School.

title: Sports Today
description: USAC Milwaukee 150, for Indianapolistype cars, at Wisconsin State Fair Park. Periodic updates of the Swedish Grand Prix will also be shown. (TelevisionChannel 2, 4 P.M.)

title: Laurie C. Pile, Teacher, Bride Of D. A. Barrett
description: Laurie Chadbourne Pile, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Pile Jr. of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to David Anson Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Anson Barrett of Marion, Mass.

title: Greenwich Wins Police Tax Case
description: AFTER four years of investigations conducted by the Hartford district office of the Internal Revenue Service, the national office in Washington has ruled that Greenwich does not have to pay an assessment of $49,471.30 in taxes, plus interest and penalties, allegedly accrued because of money earned by its police officers when they worked at security jobs on their own time.

title: Suzanne R. Griffin Is Wed To William Benton Hale
description: Suzanne Rivers Griffin and William Benton Hale, graduates of Northwestern University, were married yesterday in the Congregational Church of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony.

title: The Artist as an Old Photographer
description: FROM the start, Paul Theroux's eighth novel takes us by surprise. In the first place, it's less exotic than most of his books, which tend to be set in faroff countries and to be peopled by characters who are foreign at least in outlook, if not in fact. lacks the snap and crackle of, say, The Family Arsenal, his bestknown novel, and draws its energy instead from internal events: the unfolding and shaking out of old memories, the slow evolution of character over years and years.

title: GuidryFans 18 Angels for Yank Mark And Wins No 11 Without Loss, 40
description: Ron Guidry, adding even more drama to what is perhaps the most exciting development of this baseball seasonhis performanceshattered a 59yearold club record last night by striking out 18 batte.rs as the Yankees trimmed the California Angels, 40.

title: Nancy Epstein, Dan Malchi Planning to Marry on July 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Epstein of Bayonne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Sue Epstein, to Dan Malchi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Malchi of Natanya, Israel. The wedding is planned for July 20.

title: Linda Powers Wed To John Middleton
description: Linda Leigh Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Muller Powers Jr. of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday to John 5taubus Middleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Middleton of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. DaVid B. Waftermulder.

title: German Intelligence
description: AT first this book may represent yet another spy thriller, a rehash of ofttold tales, another Bodyguard of Lies or A Man Called Intrepid. Make no mistake, however: It is really an academic monograph of the most demanding nature, its origins in a doctoral dissertation, its appeal primarily to those specialists who can digest the raw chunks of data that David Kahn presents about the intelligence system  its organization, its personnel  of Hitler's Germany.

title: Western Section of Pennsylvania on Political Ascendancy
description: PITTSBURGH, June 14One morning this week, a man on a tight schedule strode briskly through the airport here on his way to catch a jet to the slate capital. People in the corridors called out. Hi, Dick and Good luck

title: Poor Service to Minorities Charged
description: The Clergy and Laity Concern, an interdenominational group, has charged that the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company gave poor service to residents of the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn and Manhattan's Harlem community.

title: U.S. Volleyball Team Wins
description: HONG KONG, June 17 (UPI)An American women's volleyball team rallied tonight and beat China's Shensi team, 615, 1517, 155, 1512, 1510, in a match played in Peking.

title: Caramoor: A Visit to a Work of Art
description: CARAMOOR is a house that art built  that is, the arts were its reason for being. The Mediterraneanstyle villa of Walter and Lucie Rosen was meant to house his collection of European and Chinese art, dating from the Middle Ages through the 18th century.

title: PRISONER IS TRYING TO RETRACT HIS PLEA
description: Henry Barker, who apparently became a model citizen after brealdng out of a Rikers Island jail, began a new attempt yesterday to escape a long sentence for murder. But this time he is trying to get out of. prison legally.

title: Frankfurt Police Battle Leftists Seeking to Block a NeoNazi Rally
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 17 (Reuters)Policemen using water cannons clashed today with thousands of leftwing demonstrators seeking to disrupt a neoNazi rally to mark the East German uprising 25 years ago.

title: Lucia. Brooks Batchelder Is Bride of. Frederic Pamp
description: Lucia Brooks Ilatchelder and. Frederic nichard Pamp were married yesterday in the Dundee Presbyterian Church in Omaha by the Rev. Dr. Gerald Hazel???

title: Mozart Takes Center Stage at Caramoor
description: I THINK a festival should be festive, says Michael Sweeley. It should also be appealing, ought to have a considerable amount of musical weight, and should make sense as a totality, with some kind of underlining focus. Mr. Sweeley is the executive director of the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, which began its 33d season with a gala benefit concert last night, and as I look over the programs for the next 10 weekends I have the distinct feeling that Mr. Sweeley has followed well his own recipe for success.

title: Molly Ferrer Wed to A. W. Regan
description: Maiy Seton Ferrer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married in Southampton yesterday to Andrew William Regan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Regan of New York and East Hampton, L. I. The Rev. William J. Remey performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary.

title: Garden
description: Postpone major lawn renovation to September since hot dry, weather is ahead Sow cabbage family vegetables; seedlings will be set out for early fall harvest Protect strawberry and raspberry crop from birds with netting.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: GIVING up a seat in Congress for no purpose could make a person feel foolish, so Representative Joseph A. LeFante, Democrat Bayonne; could be excused if he is getting that old feeling.

title: 2 Nuclear Reactors to Be Built In Japan If Subsidy Is Approved
description: TOKYO, June 16 (Reuters)Japan's Electric Power Development Company said today that it was planning to build two Canadian heavywater nuclear reactors, subject to approval by the Government.

title: AllWheatley Hills Final Shapes Up in L.I. Amateur
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 17The 53d Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship will be an allWheatley Hills final.

title: Of Atoms and Allies
description: LONDONFor reasons not difficult to understand, the United States has always been against other countries having nuclear weapons. Putting such awesome power into irresponsible hands, or increasing the danger of accidents, could hardly be expectedto win American support. Even American liberals who favor a more plural world, with a less hegemonic role for the United States, almost invariably balk at proliferation.

title: HOVERN ASKS STAND AGAINST TAXCUT TIDE
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Senator George McGovern, bowing out as president of Americans for Democratic Action, today urged liberals and President Carter not to panic over California's Proposition 13.

title: Masterpieces That Might Have Been
description: There is often a mystique surrounding the final works of great composers. Take, for example, Verdi's Falstaff, Wagner's Parsifal, Mozart's Requiem, or all the masterpieces Schubert wrote in the last years of his short life. As death drew nearer, the creative energies of such geniuses seemed to develop an even more profound and concentrated expressive power.

title: Galbraith Urges Price Controls
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, said today that the Administration must return to mandatory wage and price controls to slow inflation, hold down unemployment and protect the weakest, most helpless people in the society.

title: Sink the Nuclear Carrier
description: When next you hear talk from Capitol Hill about he tax revolt and the need to hold down spending, remember the carrier  the supercarrier. President Carter was quick enough last week to respond to the anguish of California by preaching spending restraint to Congress. He might have been more direct by pointing straight at the $3.5 billion that the House has insisted on adding to the defense budget for a nuclearpowered behemoth carrier plus a nuclear cruiser for its defense. The Senate ought to scrap them both.

title: Times Square Hotels Surviving With a PiedTerre Motif
description: If buildings could be schizophrenic, this one might qualify.

title: Mound Woes Accompany Yanks to Boston
description: Whoever would have though would come to this:

description: Street Festival: Ethnic foods, dancing, art, music, exhibits; 10 A.M. fo 6 P.M.; 197 East Broadway, between Pike and Rutgers Street, Lower East Side.Fourth Annual 52d Street Festival: Music, arts, dancing, crafts, ethnic foods, entertainment, exhibits; 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; 52d Street from the East River to Ninth Avenue.

title: Youth Held in Burglary Accused of Slaying 9YearOld Girl in Westport
description: WESPORT, Conn. June 17An 18yearold youth was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 9yearold girl whose body was found in a brook near her home here on Tuesday evening. Police Chief William Stefan said that the youth, Edward Falby, had been arrested earlier yesterday in connection with a burglary and that the police had then sought a warrant to search his residence. Evidence gathered in the search, Chief Stefan said, led to the murder charge against Mr. Falby.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States

title: To Gatwick Now the Travelers They Wende
description: Chaucer's Canterbury pilgrims, whose story was set near where we now found ourselves, were carefully created by a genius of English poetry to form a colorful contrast of physical, professional and social types. But the wrinkled crowd in Gatwick Airport had been thrown together by nothing more profound than the need to get from one place to another on the same inclement day. With the announcement that the flight was postponed until the next morning and that we would have to shift for ourselves overnight, people abandoned the usual rules of anonymous airport behavior. Some wept, some cursed, some coolly demanded straight answers to tough questions.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Anyone who ever doubted that needlework ranks as the one craft that flourished in virtually all centuries and cultures will no longer question it after viewing Embroidery Through the Ages. The show, which will be at the CooperHewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, through Sept. 3, is certainly the most comprehensive and glorious exhibition on the subject to be presented in New York in recent memory.

title: Owolabi Sets U.S. Mark With 533I/2 Triple Jump
description: NAPERVILLE, Ill., June 17Sanya Owolabi of Sleepy Hollow High, Tarrytown, N.Y., set a nationai scholastic record of 53 feet 3 inches today in the triple jump at the international prep track and field invitation meet. The previous mark was 5261/4 by Dave Tucker set in 1970.

title: CONNECTICUT REAL ESTATE
description: IT'S not easy to find a summer tenant this year. High prices plus cold and rainy spring have slowed the summer rental market to point where it has been termed disastrous in Westport, slow in Fairfield and not outstanding in Madison.

title: Death
description: ALLIGER.Joseph K. of GreatNeck died on Thursday, June 15, 1978 at the age of 82 in Bay Harbor Islands, Fla, where he lived in retirement. Survived by his wife Gladys, two sons Martin & Howard, six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A pioneer in mortgage banking for over 55 years. He founded the Sterling Investing Corp. He was active in Jewish and Secular PhiIanthrophy. Services June 18, 10AM at Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. Interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. Family suggests planting JNF trees in lieu of flowers.

title: Yanks Sold Out Today
description: The Yankees have announced that no tickets are left for today's game with the California Angels. The last ticket was sold Friday.

title: A Dashing Daddy's Vacation Strategy
description: My son Billy was 2. His mother was out of town for a week. It was the first time he had been away from her for such an extended period. It was 15 de, grees here in New York and still snowing. My mother and father were basking in 80degree Florida sunshine. C'mon down, they said. Why not, I replied.

title: Army Officer Weds Sheila Morrison
description: Sheila Morrison, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ian A. Morrison of Millbrook, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Bruce Davis Jackson, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Porter Jackson of Houston. The Rev. John C. Heaven, assisted by the Rev. Thomas W. Sumners, performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: Letters: Traveling In Italy
description: An advertisement bearing the headline, Come See the Real ItalyWhere Even Hospitality Is an Art, compels me to write this letter. My own travel experiences in Italy were horrendous, and since my return, I have found that rather than being unique, they appear to be, unfortunately; quite typical.

title: If You Go
description: to India, plan carefully, far in advance. A good starting point, if this is your first trip, is a Government of India Tourist Office, of which there are three in the United States. The addresses: 30 Rockefeller Plaza, North Mezzanine, New York 10020 (2125869901); 201 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago 60601 (3122366899), and 3550 Wilshire Boulevard, Suite 209, Los Angeles 90010 (2133808855).

title: The Moslem World Rekindles Its Militancy
description: CAIRO  in Saudi Arabia last week, two Britons were flogged for making beer in violation of Moslem law prohibiting alcoholic, In Iran, conservative Moslems of the Shiite sect recently spearheaded riots that rattled the. country's foundations. In Egypt last March, five militant zealots were hanged for murdering a former Cabinet minister in protest against modernization.
