description: Ol Diz was more than just an ol hillbilly.

title: SEMINARY PRESERVES JUDAISM IN RED BLOC
description: BUDAPEST  Six years ago Adolf Shayevich left his native Birobidzhan in the Soviet Union to study at the Jewish Theological Seminary here. This fall, reversing the usual oneway path of Soviet Jews, he will return, as Moscow's first newly ordained rabbi in a generation, perhaps more.

title: Special Effects
description: PITTED cratered calderaed blazing hot moon terrain, croaks the entranced scientist hero of Altered States, after he gets into the id. His colleague replies: Are you okay, Eddie?

description: President Carter's appearance Friday before a gathering of his fellow Southern Baptists in Atlanta came two years after his Presidential candidacy helped give the church heiphtened prominence, fresh vigor and new problems.

title: Carter's Visit Was Designed as an Antidote for Torrijos's Difficulties
description: PANAMA CITY  Having barely surmounted the final obstacle to new Canal. treaties, Panama's strongman, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, is already paying the price for having relaxed domestic political controls during the long debate.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 17 (AP)  Mate Parlov of Yugoslavia scored a 15round split decision over John Conteh of Britain and retained his World Boxing Council lightheavyweight boxing championship tonight.

title: Spring Check Up for Outboard Motor
description: Keeping an outboard motor running throughout the boating season requires little more than giving it some attention before launching, If the motor was not, properly laid up last winter, spring maintenance is even more important. The motor itself can be regarded as consisting of several systems, and if each system is put in order the outboard will give back a troublefree summer.

title: Excessive Force in Brooklyn Man's Death Is Denied
description: A police official and the deputy chief medical examiner who examined the body of a Brooklyn businessman and community leader who died in a struggle with 16 officers said yesterday that they did not believe excessive force had been used by the police.

title: GARDENING
description: SCHOOL will be out in this area this week and restless children are eager to turn in their books and have some summer fun. Some of their friends in private schools have already been set free.

title: Gunman Is Shot Dead in Attempt To Rob a GypsyCab Driver
description: A man attempting to rob a gypsycab driver at gunpoint was shot dead with the gun Friday night during a struggle in which the robber and an accomplice were overpowered by the driver, the police said.

description: Let's say you want to buy several items of photographic equipment such as an Omega D2V enlarger, a Majestic tripod, an 8foot stainless steel darkroom sink, and a Beal Commercial 200 16x20inch dry mounting press. Checking with various New York dealers of new photographic equipment for representative prices the enlarger will be tagged at around $450, the tripod may cost over $200, and the sink will set you back anywhere from $700 to $1,000.

In the last few months the Lega, an organization of more than 11,000 production and service cooperatives. has:

title: Helen Wendell Johnson, a Law Student, Is Married to Craig Robert Williamson
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Riverdale, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, Helen Wendell Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Johnson of IrvingtononHudson, N.Y., became the bride of Craig Robert Williamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Williamson 2d of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Robert R. Rodie Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Yacht Takes A Last Fling To Bermuda
description: It took only an hour and a quarter to start the ocean race to Bermuda last Friday as the six divisions left Newport, R.I., on signals 15 minutes apart. But to finish the race takes at least two days because the 162 yachts become scattered over the sea while they make the 635mile passage southeast to the 365 little islands of Bermuda.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE ordinary capacity of women is inadequate for the communion and fellowship which the nurse of the sacred bond of friendship, Montaigne wrote four centuries ago, nor does their soul feel firm enough to endure the strain of so tight and durable a knot.

title: Jane Dickenson Is Bride
description: The marriage of Jane Monroe Dickenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dickenson Jr. of Garden City, L.I., to John Frank Lawlis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawlis Jr. of Lansdale, Pa., DOOR place yesterday in Christ's First Presbyterian Church in Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Wallace Winegard performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Nils Blatz, a brotherinlaw of the bride, who is rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Worker Burned in Jersey Blast
description: DEEPWATER, N.J., June 17 (AP)One worker was seriously burned in an explosion at the Du Pont Chambers Works plant here last night, the police said. The worker, Hugh Rafferty, 27, was taken to Salem Memorial Hospital, but watd later transferred to the CrozierChester Medical Center in Chester, Pa. A column in which phenyl glycidyl ether was being distilled exploded and caused a fire which was extinguished by Du Pont workers said Robert Shinn, assistant works manager at the plant.

title: On Location in StarryEyed Yonkers
description: YONKERS THE MOMENT residents and city officials learned that madefortelevision romance was being filmed in the area, there was talk that it might bring to Yonkers a bit of the glamour  and perhaps the gold  that Saturday Night Fever brought to the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Late Birdie Helps North Keep Open Lead
description: DENVER, June 17Andy North sank a 50foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to maintain his lead after three rounds of the 78th United States Open. He led by one stroke over Gary Player, who birdied that difficult finishing hole moments before North arrived on the ereen.

title: Oerter Takes Met. A.A. U. Discus
description: Al Oerter, not in the least discouraged by his ninthplace finish in the discus throw at 194 feet 6 inches in last week's Amateur Athletic Union national championships, improved almost three feet on that performance yesterday.

title: Golfdom's Jaws in the Rockies
description: DENVER, June 17  The rest of the year, golf theatrics resemble heavy drama or situation comedy or soap opera. But the United States Open projects the chills of a horror show. This is the only tournament where the world's best golfers suddenly are confronted with the same problems that a duffer has. They must keep their tee shot in the fairway or they won't reach the green. They must be close tothe pin or they will need three putts. The slightest mistake produces a bogey. Or a double bogey. Or worse. The other major events are not as frightening.

title: Dressing to Visit Granma
description: Timothy Dunleavy is a designer with a very special vision of little girls clothes. He's not interested in playground outfits or the frilly party dresses that are worn once and left to hang in the closet. instead, he designs clothes to be worn to the museum on weekends, to a restaurant in the evening or to Grandma's house on holidays. They're urban and sophisticated.

title: PRESIDENT CAUTIONS PANAMA TO RESPECT RIGHTS OF AMERICANS
description: FORT CLAYTON, Canal Zone, June 17  President Carter today warned Panania to respect the civil liberties of the 40,000 Americans here who have operated and defended the Panama Canal for decades, and said that he had personally taken steps to assure that those rights would be preserved.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  The High Chairs and The Zoo Story, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through July 1). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Byung Sun Sob, A Lyric Tenor
description: Byung Sun Soh, who came to this country from South Korea in 1969, studied at the, luilliard School and perfomed with several small opera companies in New York, made his recital debut on Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Soh, a lyric tenor, included two operatic pieces on his program, but it was otherwise devoted to songs in German, French, English and Italian.

title: Assembly to Debate Death Penalty
description: TRENTON THE Assembly is scheduled to begin debate this week on two emotional issues: restoration of the death penalty and revision of the state's Penal Code.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: MONTAUK POINT THE pouredconcrete studio stands on a bluff with a commanding view of the Atlantic. But the windows of the spartan structure are small, leaded and closed to keep out the sound and the sight of the turbulent below. long and often controversial career that has seen him emerge as one of the outstanding individualists in 20thcentury American painting, at the age of 74 Balcomb Greene does not like to be distracted from his work.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: DID a slick New Jersey Congressman invade North Carolina to put on a dog and pony show in the name of laborlaw reform, and did he conduct hearings so biased and onesided that they bordered on the absurd?

title: A Slice of Houston History Goes On the Block at the Rice Hotel
description: HOUSTON, June 17Like an aging dowager pawning. the last of her jewels, downtown Houston's historic Rice Hotel opened its elegant but tarnished brass rimmed doors for a public sale yesterday.

title: Skin Doctor Warns That Sun is Harmful
description: With growing numbers of sailors, fishermen, golfers and tennis players heading outdoors every summer and traveling to warm climates in the winter, the incidence of skin cancer has increased significantly and will get worse before getting better, according to one skin expert.

title: No Coast Race For Affirmed
description: Affirmed's owner said yesterday there was no way in the world the triple crown winner would run in the Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park on July 2.

title: Tax Cuts Are Popular But So Are Programs
description: WASHINGTON  It has been 20 years since John Kenneth Galbraith described in The Affluent Society how the United States was a land of private wealth and public poverty. Since then, the nation has poured many billions into the pupae sector in national defense, education, public works, highways, antipoverty programs, public safety and many other areas  until onethird of personal income now goes into local, state and Federal treasuries.

title: ART
description: GREAT NECK OUR interest in contemporary Latin American art has noticeably increased over the last two decades, but our knowledge and appreciation of it still remain painfully inadequate. We are not sufficiently familiar with the names of the artists; we know little about prevalent styles, developments or trends. Since our attention has been almost exclusively focused on art produced here and in Europe, we have in effect ignored the vital creative activity of a major part of the world.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Soviet Warns That Policy of U.S. Is Fraught With Dangers to Peace
description: MOSCOW, June 17  The Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda, in commentary evidently approved at the Politburo level, said today that the present course of the United States is fraught with serious dangers, dangers for the United States, for all countries interested in peace, for the entire course of development of international relations.

title: Food
description: 12 crepes (see recipe)

title: Last Day to Register for Fresh Air Fund Camp Is a Big Day for Little Ones
description: All that was missing were the camp bound buses. Mothers and children crowded the cheerful waiting rooms of the Grand Concourse Family Health Care Services building on Grand Concourse and 182st Street in the Bronx, waiting with varying degrees of patience on the last day of registration to sign up ror the Fresh Air Fund Camp Julius Richmond chapter summervacation program.

title: Elizabeth Heath Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Stanton Heath was married yesterday in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Farmington, Conn., to Robert Thomas Walsh Jr. The Rev. John P. Courtney of Los Angeles performed the ceremony.

title: Rono Establishes African Record
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, June 17 (AP)Henry Rono of Kenya, who has set three world records in the last two months, won the 3,000meter steeplechase at a track meet today in the fastest time recorded in Africa.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HARTFORD THE Public Utilities Control Authority will be flexing its powerful legal muscles to adopt regulations that limit nuclearplant growth, the new chairman of the authority, Miriam B. Butterworth, predicted recently.

title: Tiller Victor on Grass, Eclipsing Track Mark
description: When a horse gets good, a few more pounds on his back aren't likely to slow him down. Especially if the race happens to be a long one, and the horse with the 117pound weight assignment was bred to run all day.

title: INTERVIEW Father Doesn't Always Know Best
description: WHITE PLAINS AS A CHILD growing up in Washington, Cheryl J. Bradley was no stranger to legal matters, but they were supposed to be no concern of hers. Her father, Harry Levy, a patent lawyer, encouraged a son, Robert, to become a lawyer, she said, but he saw no place for women in the field of law.

title: India Is Waiting and Praying For the Crucial Monsoon Rains
description: NEW DELHI, June 16With the temperature here now regularly reaching an afternoon high of 110 degrees, almost all of India is engaged in the annual exercise of waiting for the monsoon.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Joan S. Krinsly
description: Joan Susan Krinsly, a probation officer in the United States District Court in Washington, will be married on July 8 to Barry P. Rosenthal, an associate in the Washington law firm of Brownstein Zeidman Schomer & Chase.

title: Mormon Decision on Blacks Promises Impact on Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 15  In Utah, they are calling it Black Friday, and they  Mormons and nonMormons, blacks and whites  are jubilant about it. Moderately jubilant, since Mormons are traditionally temperate and blacks say they hive cause for reservations.

title: Notes: More Than A View From the Bus
description: Treks for those who want to explore terra firma and observe its creatures, group tours for women, excursions geared to accessibility for handicapped people.

title: 132 Vietnamese Reath Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, June 17 (AP)A motorized fishing junk with 132 Vietnamese's refugees aboard arrived at Hong Kong harbor today, the police reported. Immigration Department officials said no decision had been made on whether to allow the refugees to remain in this British crown colony.

title: Eleanor T. Martin, Leigh W. Hoagland Engaged to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Eleanor Townsend Martin to Leigh William Hoagland, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Williams Hoagland of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lee Gwynne Martin of New York and Wainscott, L.I. The wedding is planned for September.

description: Gore Vidal

title: Linda Joy Married To Elliot Baines Jr.
description: Linda Fessenden Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Fessenden Joy of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Elliot Arthur Baines Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baines of Woodbridge, Conn. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Bloomfield, N.J., by the Venerable Henry Biggin.

title: Realtors Don't Contest U.S. Charge
description: SYRACUSE, June 17  The Greater Syracuse Beard of Realtors and 14 other defendants pleaded nolo contendere in Federal District Courthere this week to a charge of pricefixing in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: I've Grown Up With the Manhattan Theater Club
description: A in't Misbehavin,  the awardwinning musical celebration of Fats Waller at the Longacre Theater, began as an intimate revue in the cabaret of the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: A Cutting Edge in the Kitchen
description: GREENWICH AM a big help to my wife around the house. Don't ask her. Take my word for it.

title: Deborah Reade Bride Of James Christensen
description: Deborah Hughes Reade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Reade of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to James Dale Christensen of Park City, Utah, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arlon Dale Christensen of Medford. Ore.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: VOLENDAM (HollandAmerica). Left Bermuda June 16; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St..

title: WESTCHESTER REAL ESTATE The Summer Rental
description: WESTCHESTER homeowners could make a nice bit of income by renting their houses in the summer. Potential renters from New York City are still calling realestate brokers in the hope of finding some county resident who wants a combination of income and housesitting and who can offer a house, preferably with a pool, within an hour's commuting distance of Manhattan.

title: GARDENING
description: WISTERIAS are among the world's most beautiful flowering vines, but their culture can be vexatious. Although the vigorous twining vines can grow to great length if given proper soil, some fail to bloom for extremely long periods and some naturally bloom much earlier in life than others.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The recent death of Tamara Karsavina in England at the age of 93 does not bring an era to a close much as it recalls the continuity of the tradition which fostered the growth of this wild flower, as she was dubbed in her early days at the Marvinsky Ballet by the Russian critir, V_?? lov.

title: 3 Drown in Canoeing Accident
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 17 (UPI) Three persons drowned today in a canoeing accident on Bryant Pond in the town of Putnam Valley, the police said. One of the victims was identified as Grace Chang, 16 years old, of New York City.

title: RISE IN GRADUATE STUDENTS IN SCIENCE REPORTED OVER
description: WASHINGTON June 17 After a period of rising enrollments, the growth in the number of graduate students enrolled in science programs appears to have halt ed in 1977, according to a National Science Foundation report.

title: Man Is Stabbed in Central Park And Two Are Arrested in Attack
description: With the help of a bystander, two men were arrested last night minutes after they allegedly stabbed a stroller they were trying to rob in Central Park near West 80th Street and the bridle path. me victim was identified as Peter Semen, 47 years old, of 200 West 90th Street. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital, where he was in critical condition with stomach wounds.

title: FOOD
description: PICKING your own is picking up on the Island. The number of farms that have opened their strawberry fields to people eager to supply their own labor has doubled this year, with the greatest concentration of them in the Riverhead area and stretching out along the North Fork.

title: Connors Continues to Show Top Form
description: BIRMINGHAM. England, June 17 (AP)Jimmy Connors of the United States and Raul Ramirez of Mexico registered semifinal victories today in the $125,000 Grand Prix grass tennis tournament.

title: Keep It Simple On a City Terrace
description: R obert Thorson follows all the rules to tend his lawn. It is limed, fed, watered and cut regularly. And when bare spots appear, he reseeds in fall. Most garden ers would not have the patience to cut the lawn as carefully as he does but when your lawn is 20 floors up and only four by six feet wide, what else would you use but hand clippers?

title: Janina Ann Longtine Wed to Steven Walske
description: In St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Palmer, Mass. yesterday morning, Janina Ann Longtine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Longtine of Palmer, became the bride of Steven Carl Walske, son of Dr. and Mrg. M. Carl Walske of Potomac, Md.

title: Police Fire to Halt Soweto Stoning
description: SOWETO, South Africa, June 17 (UPI)  Policemen opened fire and used tear gas today to disperse hundreds of black youths who stoned a police car rnd a bus after a memorial observance on the second anniversary of the Soweto riots.

title: The Art and Science of Finding a Job
description: FINDING work on the Island is proving to be a pressing problem, not only for the printer or laundress, but also for many others with backgrounds in a myriad of fields  especially the recent college graduate.

title: Antiques: The Season Ahead
description: WHERE is an outdoor antique show called a flea market, and where does flea market still mean an alfresco antiques festival, not just collection of tagsale leftovers and rummagesale dropouts? Probably only in Connecticut, where these popular shows originated a generation ago.

title: U.S. to Coordinate Its Efforts to Fight World Hunger
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  President Carter is planning to establish a commission on world hunger to coordinate the efforts of United States agencies with international organizations to combat starvation; Administration and Congressional sources said today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NEWPORT, N. H.  Thunderheads were piling up over the green, forested hills to the west, but trout were rising for tiny, gray aquatic insects and every once in a while one of them would hit our offerings.

title: MUSIC
description: WE probably attract more than half a mil-lion people. over the course of the summer, Jeri Skinner said, and that's the nominal. Remember, this is only our fifth season.

title: The Region
description: Picket lines and violence roiled around the midtown offices of The Daily News last week while editorial and commercial employees, members of The Newspaper Guild of New York, were on strike. Yesterday, five days after their walkout began, the guild membership ratified a new threeyear contract.

title: Joan Mondale, Reader
description: IN the spring of 1972, a children's art book was published, written by the wife of the senior Senator from Minnesota. Entitled Politics in Art, represented a confluence of the two streams flowing through Joan Mondale's life. It also hinted at the indefatigable advocacy of the arts that she.brought to the political arena following the CarterMondale accession to leadership.

title: Reunion CoMplex in DallasCenterpiece for the City
description: Architects who are not Jahn Portman splashy Hyatt Regency hotels for some years now, mostly to dreary results. The atriums that looked as though they were going to bring life to hotels when Mr. Portman started doing them in the mid60's have become timesome clichs, and even Mr. Portman, himself his ties with the Hyatt Corporation severed, has eone on to other things.

title: World News Briefs
description: QUM, Iran, June 17 (AP)  Soldiers with bayonets stood by at key points in this holy city today, but a virtual general strike by thousands of conservative Moslems remained peaceful and seemed to break a cycle of antiGovernment violence.

title: JAMES C. JACOBSON
description: James C. Jacobson, former president of the Voland Corporation and a civic leader in New Rochelle, N.Y., died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Jacobson, who lived at 108 Echo Avenue, was 77 year old.

title: Mathilda Cox Married To Marc Stephen Wein
description: Mathilda Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Cox of Sally Park, England, was married at the Metropolitan Club yesterday to Marc Stephen Wein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney F. Wein of Passaic, N. J. State Supreme Court Justice Frank Vaccaro performed the ceremony.

title: Admen Woo the Working Woman
description: Do you talk to a working woman any differently than a housewife? asks Sanford Buchsbaum, senior vice president of advertising for Revlon. It's a question that is roiling the marketing marketplace.

title: Colsrado Fire Is Contained
description: RED FEATHER LAKES, Colo., June 17 (AP) fire that burned 1,200 acres of pine and spruce in the Rocky Mountains about 90 miles from Denver was reported contained Saturday.

title: If Actors Had Their Choice of Roles..
description: Many theater people, summer is not only a time for stocksee the Straw Hat listings elsewhere in this sectionbut for stocktaking. The critics have had their say, the awards have been awardea, aria an actor's fancy can turn to thoughts of more perfect parts and brighter tomorrows. Accordingly, The Times asked a number of actors and actresses what roles they would most like to play, given a choice of characters from existing plays, history, literature or even current affairs. Here, in alphabetical order, are their replies.

title: Garbage Dump Is Called A Hazard to Rare Birds Bred at Maryland Center
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  Federal biologists fear that a new garbage dump in suburban Maryland will bring disease to whooping cranes and other endangered animals being bred at the wildlife station in Patuxent.

title: TV VIEW
description: Tired of trying to explain the significance, or insignificance, of television, I fall back on retained images or, if you will, afterimages or, heaven help us, feedbacks. There, in living color, is Edith Bunker putting trembling hand to mouth and chirping, Oh, no, Archie! Walter Cronkite keeps assuring us that that's the way it was. Carol Burnett and Mary Tyler Moore are now repeating themselves unto infinity. But these, like Milton Berle and Edward R. Murrow and Lucille Ball, are the established stuff of television. What of the occasional pieces or new series desperately trying to work up a bump in the night? Consider the past few weeks.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: If it were true, as the Soviet scientist Lysenko contended a generation ago, that environment could change human's genetic makeup, wouldn't most babies today be born with ruptured eardrums? The world has been getting increasingly noisy for a long time and yet no appreciable deterioration of aural membrane has been reported in the infant population. Once born, however, the child of our time is in trouble. Chances are good that he or she will have to endure the most excruciating aural pains that a hostile environment can concoct. The only seat on the bus will be near a humanoid carrying a bellowing transistor radio or cassette player. Or it may be necessary to stand regularly on a subway platform where two express trains roar through while two locals simultaneously screech to a stop. And can any noise be more painful than a passing subway train?

title: Outdoors: Bass, the No. 1 Game Fish
description: EVERY game fish has its devotees, but the various black basses are by far the most popular quarry across the nation. Explosive, aggressive fighters that often take to the air when hooked, these fish can tolerate a wide range of water temperature, and they will, at the proper time, hit everything from a garden worm to a flyrod popping bug.

title: Mormon Couple Wins on Adoption
description: SANTA FE, N.M., June 18 (AP)A white Mormon couple, after fighting the state's Human Services Department in court, has won the right to adopt a boy of mixed racial background.

title: North Wins U.S. Open by Shot on 74 for 285
description: Denver, June 18  Andrew Stewart North, a 28yearold native of Wisconsin, blasted out of a sand bunker at the final hole of the 78th United States Open golf championship today and then sank the following fourfoot putt to win by a stroke in one of the most exciting stretch finishes in the tournament's history.

title: Prosecutor Is Told Teachers Upgraded Their Transcripts
description: A district attorney is investigating charges that several dozen Bronx teachers falsified graduateschool transcripts to obtain promotions and salary increases between 1969 and 1975.

title: Riding the Laffer Curve
description: It was a great intellectual triumph when Adam Smith concocted,a theory 200 years ago that seemed to justify the selfishness imbedded in capitalism. The Glasgow scholar demonstrated that such selfishness, moderated by competition, could eventually maximize a nation's wealth.

title: 6 Teams Still Vie For Cup
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 18Brazil tied Argentina and the Netherlands tied West Germany in World Cup play today, leaving six teams still in contention for the soccer championship.

title: State Attorney General Candidate
description: ALBANY, June 16To the annals of New York State politics, Democrats have now added the story of the chocolate birthday cake. The cake was being baked in Buffalo last Wednesday evening by Dolores Denman a fudge on the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, while in Albany party leaders Were cooking up a confection of their owna lastminute deal to net a place for an upstater on the Democratic ticket led by Governor Carey in November.

title: Nelson Captures Bowling Tourney
description: RENO, Nev., June 18 (AP)  Warren Nelson captured the $100,000 Professional Bowlers Association national championship today for his first P.B.A. title victory in two years on the pro tour.

title: TV: RosenbergSobell Revisited Offers New Thinking on Spy Case
description: IN 1974. public television broadcast the documentary called The Unquiet Death of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Alvin H. Goldstein spent a year and a half assembling material strongly supporting the argument that the Rosenbergs, executed as spies on June 19, 1948, were victims of what some have called the most notorious frameup in the history of our country.

title: Organ Recital: Arthur Phillips
description: ARTHUR A. PHILLIPS, who offered an organ recital at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, is a native New Yorker and a graduate of the Juilliard School. He has been organistchoirmaster of many churches in the New York area. currently serving at the Church of St. Marks in Brooklyn.

title: Cup Soccer Unites Argentine People
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 18On days like today when World Cup soccer matches are held, Juan Carlos Desideri, a hardware store employee, his wife and two daughters gather around television set in their Parque Chacabuco apartment to watch Argentina play. They stand for the national anthem and sit to watch the game.

title: A Shooting Star, Many Gazers
description: DENVER, June 18Bob Clampett, the young golfer who had one brief shining moment at the beginning of the United States Open, sat back after his last round today and waxed philosophical. Clampett is a 17yearold amateur, a freshman at Brigham Young University who at one point had a shot at winning one of the premier golf tournaments in the world. After the first round, he was one stroke behind Hale Irwin, the leader.

description: Abraham, Roy

title: Issue and Debate
description: Early last October, under pressure from critics who questioned his commitment to the nation's troubled cities, President Carter paid a brief but dramatic visit to the devastated South Bronx.

title: Man Killed by a Lightning Bolt In a Golf Contest in Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP)A 28yearold mart trying to win a prize for his father in a golf tournament was struck by lightning and killed at the Currie Golf Course in Wauwatosa, a suburb of Milwaukee.

description: Morning

title: Hauser's Tangled Affairs
description: Until he was indicted by a Phoenix grand jury last week, Joseph Hauser, Florida insurance promoter, had quite a deal going  or so the Government charged.

title: Debra Miller Married to Joel Davidow
description: Debra Lynn Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Miller of Stamford, Conn., was married at noon yesterday to Joel Davidow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Davidow of Trenton. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony in Temple Sinai in Stamford.

title: Edith Elizabeth Dowling Wed to Benjamin Sendor
description: Edith Elizabeth Dowling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grafton Geddes Dowling of Beaufort, S.C., and Benjamin Burton Sendor, son of Mr, and Mrs. Mortimer Samuel Sendor of Queens Village, Queens, were married yesterday in the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

description: DANCIN', DANCIN Choreographically speaking, the Big Apple Is quivering as perhaps never before, from the ballet concentration at Lincoln Center to the various companies playing elsewhere in the metropolitan area, and the Bob Fosse evening of dance thriving on Broadway. And now, in the heart of Manhattan, City University's Graduate Center is offering a monthlong series of films, videotapes and discussions by dance experts.

title: Deaths
description: CRAVERLloyd Freeman, M.D.,at his retirement home, Gilgo Beach, L.I., N.Y.,where he resided per manently since 1962,on June 18, 1978. Dr. Craver was Chief of Medical Services, Memorial Hospital, N.Y.C. from 1920 to 1959, and held the title of Emeritus Consulting Physician. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Dr. William L.,M.D.,John F., and the late Anne Sammons. Also survived by 12 grandchildren. Reposing Tuesday 710 P.M. at the Fredrick J. Chapey Funeral Home, Montauk Highway, West Islip, L.I. Prayers Wednesday, 11 A.M. interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Plnelawn, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Dr. Lloyd Freeman Craver, M.D.Memorial Fund, Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Ave, N.Y.C. preterred.

title: TRIAL OVER C.I.A. BOOK RAISES RIGHTS ISSUES
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 18The Government's civil suit against Frank W. Snepp 3d, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who wrote a detailed account of the fall of Saigon, is scheduled to open here Tuesday with attorneys for both sides arguing that far more than a contract dispute is at issue.

title: U.S. Family Conference Delayed Amid Disputes and Resignations
description: The White House Conference on Famlliesonce seemingly the simplest of President Carter's campaign promises to keep, but recently mired in controversy, rumor and suspicionhas been postponed from December 1979 to 1981.

title: Silverman Is Likely to Surprise NBC Affiliates
description: Owners and managers of the 216 television stations affiliated with the National Broadcasting Company are in New York this week for their annual conference with the network and for their first glimpse in person of Fred Silverman, the new president of NBC.

description: WASHINGTON, June 18Israel's longawaited response to the United States On the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Palestinian issues seemed today to have fallen short of what Administration officials in the past have said would provide a breakthrough in the stalled Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Giants Conquer Mets Twice
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18Two more losses, 30 to Vida Blue and 43 in 10 innings, sent the New York Mets on their way home today at the low point of their season, while the San Francisco Giants reached the high point of theirs.

description: MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978

description: ATLANTIC CITYRobert Ready is a 56yearold Cornell University graduate who got bored selling food to airlines and hotels.

title: The Fear
description: When they died, 25 years ago today, we all felt a tearing and a shudder, of great explosions threatened, of darkness, mystery and, confusion. When Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed, many of us at once saw, and had seen all through the trial, the history of the Truman Doctrine ramifying without scale through our lives. This was long before we knew of the testimony,. so lone in following.

title: Deaths
description: SILLSHelen, daughter of the late Lester and Millie Blaushild of Clevelano, Ohio. Beloved wife, mother and sister, succumbed at the age of 53, on Wednesday, June 14, at the family residence In Riverdale, N.Y. Survivors include her husband, Philip and children Jody, Penny, Jonathan and Lester, sister Rose (Mrs. A.D.) Pelonis of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and brother David Blaushild of Pepper Pike, Ohio. Private funeral services were held on Thursday, June 15. Interment in Mayfield Mausoleum, Cleveland, Ohio. Mrs. Sills was Vice President of Sills & Co. for 28 years, a founder of Fashion Institute of Technology, NYC, the LesterBlaushild Vocational School in Safed, Israel, and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, and a volunteer at Guttman Institute Free Breast Cancer Dedication Center and Planned Parenthood Assoc. Contributions may be sent to Immunological Cancer Research, Presbyterian Hospital, New York, in her memory.

title: Dance Festival Opens in Durham
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 18Basking in the glow of a highly unusual show of support by the past and present Governors of North Carolina, the American Dance Festival opened a sixweek season in a new home here last night on the Duke University campus.

title: Sweet Madness On the Coast
description: Los ANGELES SQUATTING in California for a spring headcleaning, the true baseball believer is quickly convinced he has died and gone to heaven. Walter O'Malley knew this 20 years ago, when he was granted 300 acres of downtown Los Angeles to shanghai the Dodgers out of Brooklyn in the dead of night. Whatever else O'Malley was, stupid he wasn't.

title: Jazz: Suzannah McKorkle Sings
description: SUZANNAH McKORKLE is a puzzling singer. An American who has spent most of the last 12 years in Europe and England, she has performed in New York occasionally during the last three years. Over the weckend, she was at Barbara's, Thompson and West Third Streets, where she was accompanied by her English pianist, Keith Ingham, who was not with her on her earlier visits. Even with Mr. Ingham. she remains puzzle.

title: AntiTax Movement Poses Danger to Foreign Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Carter Administration may be heading this week for a legislative rebuff with international repercussions as the House, apparently swayed by California's taxcutting Proposition 13, debates a foreign aid bill that has already been slashed by a billion dollars.

title: U.S. and Latins: Unsolved Issues
description: PANAMA, June 18If the United States doesn't reach agreement with Panama on a new canal treaty, it will never hear the end of the subject from Latin America, a South American diplomat warned a year ago. But if it does. it will never hear the issue mentioned again.

title: 52d St. Fair: Food, Fun and Neighbor's Elbow
description: You should have seen them peeling off down Ninth Avenue, the western end of the 52d Street Fair yesterday.

title: Upper Nile Wins Nassau Handicap
description: Upper Nile won the $53,250 Nassau County Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, setting a stakes record time of 1:46 25 in the 1mile event. Upper Nile returned $12.40 for $2 to win.

title: Extra Police Added In Areas of Protests Over Death of Miller
description: Additional police officers will be assigned today to at least two Brooklyn locations where public gatherings are expected in reaction to the death of Arthur !Miller, a businessman and community leader, following a struggle with 16 police officers late Wednesday.

title: China Said to Send Instructors to Train Zaire Navy
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 18 (Reuters)China has sent several military instructors to help train Zaire's navy, according to the official Zairian newspaper and diplomatic sources.

description: Jean Potvin is hoping that, somehow, he will wind up playing hockey back in New York.

title: Horace C. Flanigan, ExChairman Of Manufacturers Trust, Is Dead
description: Horace C. Flanigan, a former chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died Thursday in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

description: TONIGHT

title: Money Panel Expected To Raise Interest Rates
description: When the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee holds its monthly meeting in Washington tomorrow to set monetary policy for the month ahead, the consensus in Wall Street is that the group will have no real choice but to push interest rates higher.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)The United States is not doing enough to counter increased Soviet activity in Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa, the Shah of Iran said in a magazine interview released today.

title: Francis Sets Mark With 6th L.I. Title
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 18Gene Francis, a 40yearold stockbroker from Huntington, won the 53d Long Island Gold Association's Amateur Championship today for a record sixth time, beating his Wheatley Hills clubmate, Dick Hanington, one up, in the 36hole final.

title: Seats on New Exchange
description: The new Amex Commodities Exchange announced last week that it would open its books to three classes of membership for a 10day period starting June 30. ACE, the first new commodity exchange in New York in several decades, is an offshoot of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Alsan Triumphs At Ox Ridge Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 18Alsan, virtually unknown on the Eastern circuit and the only competitor to get round the course without a fault, won the grand prix today at the closing session of the 49th edition of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

description: For week ended June 17 1978

title: D.D.B. Officer Waxes Lyrical
description: Doris Willens loves to write. She's always, well practically always, done it. She's written for newspapers  a column even and she's written such fun things as annual reports and speeches as vice presidentpublic relations of Doyle Dane Bernbach. She also writes a musical salute to the agency every fifthyear anniversary.

title: PERU ELECTING ASSEMBLY TO DRAFT A CONSTITUTION
description: LIMA, une 18Peruvians voted for the first time in 11 years today to choose 100 delegates to an assembly that will draw up a new constitution in what the military Government has said is the first step in a return to civilian rule.

title: Horace C. Flanigan, ExChairman Of Manufacturers Trust, Is Dead
description: Horace C. Flanigan of Palm Beach, Fla., a former chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died Thursday while visiting at the home of a friend in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

title: Kazuko Hirabayashi Presents Her Dances at Riverside Church
description: THE Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater is that rare thing, small modern dance repertory company with rigorously trained dancers and real intelligence and taste. Miss Hirabayashi, a former member of the Marrha Graham Dance Company, now teaches at the Juilliard School, where she herself first studied dance after having received law degree in Japan. Her company presented its ninth season last week at the Theater of the Riverside Church, and its program on Saturday night was a typically thoughtful one.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: Outgoing

title: Books: Duke Ellington
description: HE WAS a phenomenal person to me, Mercer Ellington writes, and I found it very difficult to believe that anybody was capable of doing the things that he could do. He. of course is Mercers legendary father, the late Edward Kennedy (Duke) Ellington, and the sentiment expressed is perhaps exactly what one would expect. from an admiring son. But surprisingly, in this forthright memoir, there is no syncophancy or chauvinism; Mercer Ellington has given us one of the most complex and candid portraits of Duke currently available.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: JAMES C. JACOBSON
description: James C. Jacobson, former president of the Voland Corporation and a civic leader in New Rochelle, N.Y., died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Jacobson, who lived at 108 Echo Avenue, was 77 year old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Gene Scott, the 40yearold former Davis Cup player, made one of his last hurrahs in tournament tennis yesterday and found age and Erie Fromm too formidable.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The OPEC meeting in Geneva remains deadlocked over whether to raise oil prices to offset the declining value of the dollar, but there are signs of compromise in the wind. Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia arrived in Geneva last night. [Page D1.]

description: Music

title: Scientists Identify More Members Of the Third Kingdom of Life
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The group of scientists that, last year, pinpointed a third kingdom of life, a class of organisms simpler than bacteria, has now identified two more of the group's esoteric members.

title: Reporter's Notebook: The Politics of Persuasion Behind Senate Panel Approval of New York Aid
description: In the aftermath of last week's 11thhour turnaround by the Senate Banking Committee, which overwhelmingly supported longterm aid for New York City, many people claimed credit for the switch. Those who argued the

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THERE'S much ado about productivity. This important barometer of economic health plummeted in the first quarter and is likely to show only a small increase  if any at all  in the second. The drop has worried Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, who, finding it hard to explain this phenomenon in traditional ways, has sent his staff looking for explanations.

title: De Gustibus: A Pasta Dish With Oriental Accent
description: One of the oddest, tastiest and most intriguing recipes for pasta we've found in a long time arrived recently from an acquaintance, Joe Famularo, who is an executive with McGrawHill publishers. He is the author of The Festive Famularo Kitchen (Atheneum, 1977).

title: Music: Caramoor Opens 33d Season
description: KATONAH, N.Y., June 17The musical events for the opening of the 33d annual Caramoor Festival today were of a light nature that tried valiantly to dispel the dark skies and constant threat of rain. At least the sun shone in spirit if not in fact during the morning hours as an auuience consisting primarily of children gathered for two premiere performances of The Daughter of the Double Duke of Dingle, onehour opera written especially for the festival by James Billings and Dennis Arlan.

title: Deaths
description: FLATHEREdward G., Jr., died on Saturday, June 17,1978, of Leesburg, VA. He Is survived by his wife, Anne M.; a daughter, Lindy F. Lawrence; a sister, Vivian Donahoe, Simsbury, CT; and three grandchildren. Friends may call at the MuseReedBange Funeral Home, 101 Edwards Ferry Rd., Leesburg, VA, Monday, June 19, 79 pm. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, June 20, at. 2pm. Interment will be In Connecticut. Memorial contributions may be made to the Heart Fund or the American Cancer Society.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player is at the net in a tennis match. His opponent's shot hits his body and bounces back over the net. Is this a legal return?

title: ANITA DANIEL
description: Anita Daniel, an author of travel books who also was a contributor of articles to The New York Times magazine, died Saturday at her home after a long illness. Mrs. Daniel, who lived at 120 East 62d Street, was 85 years old.

title: Triple Play
description: WASHINGTON...Two followups and a fresh subject:

title: Growth Of Savings Slows
description: The nation's mutual savings banks experienced a $100 million net deposit inflow last month, considerably less than the May 1977 figure of $577 million, according to preliminary figures released over the weekend by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

title: U.S. Controls Urged For Funeral Industry
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission is proposing regulations aimed atbroad reform of the funeral industry.

title: U.S. Ships Fear Soviet Rate Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Ratecutting by Soviet ships is being viewed increasingly by Government officials and American shipping executives as a threat to the United States maritime industry.

title: Ballet: Jewels by Balanchine; Cubans Perform Coppelia
description: RECENTLY, there has been renewed interest in the eveninglong ballet. Yet most attempts to create new multiact works have been timid, choreographers remaining content with formulas inherited from centuryold narrative ballets.

title: By Day, a Village Postmaster
description: By night, Jim Smith is known in New York's Greenwich Village as the owner of the Village Corner, a small tavern on West Bleecker Street. By day, the 46yearold proprietor is also known as a parttime postmaster.

title: Robin Bell Is Wed To Oliver Morris
description: Robin Bell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bell of Ardsley, N.Y., and Childmark, Mass was married yesterday afternoon to Oliver Smith Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Morris of New York.

title: CUTS IN ES. SPENDING UNEDATCONFERENCE OF NATION'S MAYORS
description: ATLANTA, June 18  Mayor after mayor took the microphone today at a session of the United States Conference of Mayors here to demand, in a departure from tradition, that the Federal Government soend less rather than more.

title: Commodities
description: COTTON, normally one of the duller futures markets, has suddenly come alive and is providing traders with the price action and battle of wits that they seem to crave.

title: HERRIN FOUND GUILTY IN SCARSDALE KILLING
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 18Richard J. Herrin was convicted today of manslaughter in the hammerbludgeoning last year of his former girlfriend, Bonnie Joan Garland.

title: High Gold Bids Expected
description: WASHINGTON June, 18 (UPI)  Demand for gold being auctioned Tuesday by the United States Treasury will be the strongest since the auction series began three years ago, Federal officials said. A spokesman for the General Services Administration said bids in Tuesday's auction of 300,000 ounces will be in line with world prices. The G.S.A. sold 300,000 ounces in May for an average price of $180.38. World gold prices have firmed since then to a range of $183 to $184.50. If bidding in the Tuesday auction runs in the $184 range, the auction would yield a record return of more than $55 million for the United States.

title: A New Twist: Gymnastics For Adults
description: BEAT and over. Here comes the swan. Chin, cast, double up. Sit on the bar. Lean back. Farther. Higher on your fannyI'll catch you. Extend, double up, swing down, double up, and dismount.

title: City College Quality Still Debated After 8 Years of Open Admissions
description: Once a week last semester, Myriam Sarachik, a professor of physics at City College, began her working day by teaching remedial algebra to a class of freshmen. Then she walked over to her laboratory in the Science Building and spent the rest of the day working with graduate students in an experiment on superconductors.

title: North Wins U.S. Open by Shot on 74 for 285
description: Denver, June 18Andrew Stewart North, a 28yearold native of Wisconsin, blasted out of a sand bunker at the final hole of the 78th United States Open golf championship today and then sank the following fourfoot putt to win by a stroke in one of the most exciting stretch finishes in the tournament's history.

title: Artist Rewarded by Students Praiseand $150,000
description: It's virtually invulnerable to the effects of galeforce winds, sonic booms and earthquakes; but the fourton sculpture just placed in front of Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx barely made it through the strike by Coop City residents that held up millions of dollars in construction funds.

title: Bjorklund, Slack Again Run 1 and 2
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18 Just as they had been 24 hours earlier in a 10kilometer race in Minneapolis, Garry Bjorklund and Mike Slack were at the front of the field today in the second running of the Westchester Half Marathon, a 13.1mile race,on the roads from White Plains to Iona Collaze here.

title: Cosmos Win, 61; Chinaglia Scores 3
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 1.8The Cosmos exploded for five goals in the second half this afternoon to trounce the Washington Diplomats, 61, at Giants Stadium.

title: Thom Bishop, Singer, Does New Folk
description: THOM Bishop, who was at the Other End over the weekend and will be at Kenney's Castaways June 27 to 29 is a most appealing singer and composer in what might be called the new folk idiom. What that means is that like Loudon Wainwright 3d, George Gerdes, Steve Forbert. Jack Hardy and others, his music seems to fit into the folk category in that it consists of songs accompanied by the singer's own acoustic guitar or otherwise minimal. backing (Mr. Bishop had an excellent pianist with him for the second half of his late Saturday set). But were the same music played with an electric band, it would be magically transformed into folk rock or even plain old rockandroll.

title: ANITA DANIEL
description: Anita Daniel, an author of travel books who also was a ,contributor of articles to The New York Times magazine, died Saturday at her home after a long illness. Mrs. Daniel, who lived at 120 East 62d Street, was 85 years old.

description: Once a week last semester, Myriam Sarachik, a professor of physics at City College, began her working day by teaching remedial algebra to a class of freshmen. Then she walked over to her laboratory in the Science Building and spent the rest of the day working with graduate students in an experiment on superconductors.

title: Chess:
description: PASADENA, Calif.  After seven rounds of the United States Championship Tournament, Grandmasters Lubomir Kavalek of Washington and Anatoly Lein of Cleveland shared the lead with a 42 score.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978

title: Dwindling Orchards MarkMontvale Change
description: MONTVAILE, N.J., June 16The rural apple and peach orchards that Ed DePiero's father started assembling over 50 years ago have shrunk from 150 acres to about 60. And the riding paths and the woodlands that surrounded the orchards and bustled with deer and pheasant are all but gone now.

title: How Koreans Built Saudi Success
description: These guys are something else. They go in there like a tornado. They bring their own workers from engineers on down, their own clerks, cooks, food, doctors, clothing, movies. They build their own housing. They do the job faster than anyone else, working 14hours shifts, sevenday weeks.

title: U.S.Canadian Fishing Talks Resume Today
description: SEATTLE, June 18United States officials are to resume talks with their Canadian counterparts tomorrow on the sensitive and vital issue of reciprocal fishing rights in coastal waters, and fishers of the migrant salmon on both sides of the border here in the West are saying that they should be left out of the discussions.

title: San Andreas Fault Found Shifting at Rapid Rate
description: GREENBELT, Md., June 18 (AP)The San Andreas Fault, which produced the San Francisco earthquake of 1906, is shifting at a faster pace than expected, according to scientists at Goddard Space Flight Center.

title: Teacher Transcripts Under Inquiry
description: A District Attorney is investigating charges that several dozen Bronx teachers falsified graduateschool transcripts to obtain promotions and salary increases between 1969 and 1975.

title: Trade Talks Intensify As Bonn Summit Nears
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The rough outlines of a new agreement to liberalize world trade by reducing both tariff and nontariff barriers are beginning to emerge after nearly four years of haggling by nonCommunist industrialized countries.

title: Market Place
description: THOSE M.A.C. bonds move with the headlines. It makes little sense, but that's the way it is. Thus spoke a dealer in the bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which were issued after June 1975 to help New York City provide uninterrupted essential services and create investor confidence in the securities of the city at a time when bankruptcy was just around the corner.

description: An infant boy died Saturday of dog bites after being attacked at his home in Mount Sinai. L.I.

description: Jim Palmer, a 20game winner in six of the last seven seasons for the Baltimore Orioles, and Rick Waits, who has never won 20, have been pitching well this year. Yesterday, they both won.

description: For those who might wish to do some homework on bass fishing, the following texts are recommended:

title: Lauren Ivy Meshel Is Bride Of David Yadgaroff ,Executive
description: Lauren Ivy Meshel, daughter of Mrs. Morris L. Meshel of New York and the late Mr. Meshel. was married yesterday to David Alan Yadgaroff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Yadgaroff. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Meshel in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Worsened Conditions on L.I.R.R. Found in Tighter Federal Scrutiny
description: Safety and equipment conditions on the Leng Island Rail Road, the biggest passenger railway in the nation, have deteriorated to a point where they may be the worst in more than five years, according to Federal inspectors.

title: Whisper Who Dares
description: Here is an ingenious plan to assure secrecy in government: declare all information in official files to be, legally, government property. Then using the information without permission would be a crime, like stealing an Army truck.

title: South Africa May Tone Down Its Foreign Lobbying
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 17  When Prime Minister John Vorster announced two days ago that he was scrapping the country's controversial Department of Information, he may have been sounding the death knell for the agency's costly and occasionally bizarre campaign of backdoor diplomacy, the management of which has been compared by newspaper critics here to the activities of the Keystone Cops.

title: 14 Bodies Found in Kansas Lake After Tornado Upsets Showboat
description: OTTAWA, Ran., June 18Body after body was pulled from Lake Pomona today after a tornado, too small to be tracked by radar, flipped a twotier, paddlewheel steamboat yesterday, dumping the 59 passengers and crew members into the lake.

title: Shadows In Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI JUST two years after the ball club here annihilated the New York Yankees in a World Series and showed the swagger of young Olympians, mortality has embraced the Reds. Johnny Bench lies in a hospital bed reading The Last Convertible while doctors debate how to repair his strained back. Pete Rose, the almost eternal imp, has not been hitting. Rose is 37; there is talk of sitting him down to rest. George Foster, last season's most valuable player, stumbles in left field. Joe Morgan's swing sometimes seems indolent.

title: Judith Lynne Goldstein Is Bride of Stephen Lewis
description: Judith Lynne Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Goldstein of Tenafly, N.J., and Stephen Hatchfield Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Von Sever Lewis of Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Apple Ridge Country Club in Mahwah, N.J. by Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg.

title: Head of Newspaper Union Group Endorses Settlement at The News
description: The president of the 10union Allied Printing Trades Council said yesterday that he would have no qualms in recommending to other unions as a basis for the contract agreement reached by The Daily News and the New York Newspaper Guild. The agreement, voted by the guild Saturday, ended a fiveday strike.

title: Woman Sues in Pinto Accident
description: NEW CASTLE, Pa., June 18 (UPI)A woman severely burned when the gas tank on a 1972 Ford Pinto exploded after an accident, has brought a negligence suit against the Ford Motor Company and a western Pennsylvania Ford dealer for negligepce. The suit, by 20yearold Debra Ann Oherding of New Castle, said she suffered second and thirddegree burns over nearly her entire body.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Budget Rent a Car Corporation, Chicago, a subsidiary of Transamerica Corporation, has elected Clifton E. Haley executive vice president, operations.

title: Lillian Roberts, Gotbaum Aide, Keeps Management on Toes.
description: Quiet steel, that's what she's likeLillian Roberts tough and tenacious and solid but smooth and charming, said a New York City commissioier, struggling to simplify the complexities of a labor leader who regularly confronts him and the other 17 commissioners on behalf of municipal employees.

title: Candidate for New York Attorney General
description: ALBANY, June 18To the annals of New York politics, Democrats have now added the story of a lastminute deal to put an upstate judge and former teacher on the November Democratic ticket led by Governor Carey.

title: Record 5th for Miss Lopez
description: ROCHESTER, June 18 (AP)Nancy Lopez surged past Jane Blalock in a stirring duel today and won a record fifth consecutive Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

description: WHITE PLAINS, June 18Richard J. Herrin was convicted today of manslaughter in the hammerbludgeoning last year of his former girlfriend, Bonnie Joan Garland.
