description: ANCHORAGEThe land, awesome in its size and in the beauty nature has worked on its face, dominates Alaska.

title: HENRY A. WILMERDING
description: Henry A. Wilmerding, a private investor and business executive, died yesterday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. Mr. Wilmerding, who lived Mill Neck, L.I., was 72 years old.

title: Big Week for U.S. Issues
description: With many bond dealers and moneymarket economists predicting that the Federal Reserve will shortly tighten credit further, interest rates are expected to rise over the nearterm.

title: Our West, Water and Carter
description: DENVERThe West is beset by proposals to change the basic institutions governing the use of its natural resources. Changes are proposed for water law, water projects, grazing fees, mining law and wilderness designation. However, the mechanisms of the existing institutions are not well. understood by those proposing changes, nor are the probable effects of such changes recognized.

title: Automated Trading Debated
description: CINCINNATI  In a small room on the mezzanine level of the Dixie Terminal Building, three people sit quietly in front of video display terminals watching the screen. Every few minutes the silence is broken when someone answers or places a telephone call or makes a comment to a coworker.

title: Jazz: Julius Hemphill and Friends, And a Few Ideas for Improvisers
description: JULIUS HEMPHILL, who led a quintet at the Public Theater Friday night, is finally living up to the promise of his impressive debut album, Dogon A.D. That recording, produced privately by Mr. Hemphill in 1972, found him playing bluesy, ingenious alto saxophone solos over a droning cello and looselimbed drum backbeat. The idea was limited, perhaps, but it was brilliantly executed, and Mr. Hemphill's succeeding albums never quite matched his first one. His live performances were uneven, too. A duo concert by Mr. Hemphill and his cellist, Abdul Wadud, was one of the most satisfying jazz evenings of the last few years, but: other performances, with larger groups, were cluttered and lacked definition.

title: With 38 Rooms of Controversy, A Sheik Asks the Neighbors In
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 17 Joe Tilem, the Mayor of Beverly Hills, bounded down the spiral staircase from the bedroom suite and looked amazed. Nine hundred mil, he said. That's what they said the family is worth, 900 mil  $900 million. They're very open about it.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Early last October, under pressure from critics who questioned his commitment to the nation's troubled cities, President Carter paid a brief but dramatic visit to the devastated South Bronx.

title: Sherril Gutberlet Wed
description: The Church Center for the United Nations was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sherril D. Gutberlet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl A. Gutberlet of Boca Raton, Fla., and Amagansett, L.I., to Richard G. Gruner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul G. Gruner of New York and Southampton, L.I. Msgr. Harold J. Byrne and Rabbi Albert Strumer officiated.

title: LeFlore Play Creates Confusion on Baselines
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 18 (AP) A confusing and unusual fourth innning highlighted Minnesota's 84 victory over Detroit today.

title: High School Senior to Tell of Vitam Bonam
description: IRVINGTON, June 18Lidia Mostovy Nvill deliver the valedictorian's speech at her high school commencement tomorrow in two of the three languages she speaks fluentlythat of Cicero and Caesar and that of her classmates.

title: The Ins, and Outs of Tumbling and Turning
description: Here are some basic movements that, as the adult gymnast progresses, are incorporated into morecomplicated routines.

title: Audrey Fishman Wed to Andrew Franklin
description: Audrey Marcia Fishman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Fishman of Vergennes and Panton, Vt., was married yesterday to Andrew DeJongh Franklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. DeJongh Franklin of Atlanta and Washington. The ceremony was performed at the summer home of the bride's mother in Panton by Rabbi Max Wall of Burlington, Vt.

title: 100 Attend Conference in Teaneck On the Problems of Black Women
description: TEANECK, June 17The blaick woman her needs and problemswas the focus of a allday seminar today as more than 100 black women from Bergen County attended the first United Black Women's Conference, held on the catinpus of Fair1ei2h Dickinson University.

title: National Debate Over Appeal of Bhutto Death Sentence Grips Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 12In an ornate, whitestone courthouse set in a pleasant rose garden here, the Supreme Court of Pakistan is considering what could be one of the most important cases in the country's historythe appeal by former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of his murder conviction and death sentence.

title: Gently Through the Stream
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18The ocean race to Bermuda is not a leisurely cruise down from Newport but rather a serious competition full of challenges. The two most difficult are the Gulf Stream and the approach to Bermuda, and the race is won or lost in these two areas.

title: Who Should Pay for Civil Wrongs?
description: Cities and towns received an unexpected jolt last week when the Supreme Court ruled that they were subject to lawsuits for violations of civil rights. The decision, which reversed a 1961 case, stripped away the blanket immunity long enjoyed by local governments in such cases. Previously, the only recourse for victims of misconduct by police officers or discrimination by city officials was to sue them individually. The Court's decision makes sense as a general principle of public policy. But it raises troublesome questions about municipal liability and who should bear the cost  questions that Congress must now confront.

title: Carter Opens Home To Jazz as an Art
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The full spectrum of jazz from ragtime to blues through swing and bebop to the avant garde, was compressed into a twohour program on the South Lawn of the White House early this evening when President and Mrs. Carter played host to a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Newport Jazz Festival. The festival begins a 10day run on Friday.

title: A Motorcycle Buff Named Davidson
description: Back in 1903, three fellows named Davidson and a fourth named Harley decided it would be a good idea to put a motor on a bicycle. That was the beginning of HarleyDavidson, the bestknown name in American motorcycles  possibly because it is the only name in American motorcycles.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HOW much is beauty worth? If a museum or a collector will pay a million dollars for a painting of a landscape, what should we be willing to pay for all the landscapes we have left in the United States? What will it be like for future generations if they have to grow up in a world bereft of landscapes? Will it be like having an unhappy childhood? Would such sensory deprivation thin or cool the blood?

title: Where to Learn
description: Private gymnasiums teaching adult gymnastics include:

title: After 2 Decades, C. Northcote Parkinson Finds His Law Is Still Inexorable
description: ST. MARTIN'S, GuernseyParkinson's Law will soon be 21 years old, and its author is working on a new edition bringing some of the statistics up to date. But otherwise he feels his thesis of useless proliferation of bureaucracy hasn't aged a bit. If anything he says, time has validated its vigor.

title: Disagreement Delaying Division Of Federal Judgeships for South
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Legislation to create 152 new Federal judgeships, sought for years by Warren E. Burger, the Chief Justice of the United States, and by others, is stuck in a conference committee, the victim of a controversy that is as much political as judicial.

title: Vietnam's Leadership, Despite Economic and Border Woes, Shows Unusual Cohesion
description: HONG KONG, June 18Although Vietnam is still facing a series of troubling and evidently intractable problems three years after the end of the war, Hanoi's Communist leadership has remained remarkably cohesive, diplomats in the Vietnamese capital and elsewhere in Southeast Asia believe.

title: Castro Praises Carter as Honest, But Again Attacks U.S. for Lies
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  President Fidel Castro of Cuba says he would like to see President Carter reelected because he is the only President in the last 20 years to have made some positive gestures toward us.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Auchincloss a Bride
description: Dr. Elizabeth Lowell Auchincloss was married in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday to Dr. Richard William Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Weiss of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Delray Beach Fla. Judge Robert D. Gruen of the Teaneck (N.J.) Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Auchincloss of Ridgewood and Manchester, Mass.

title: Text of Cabinet Statement on Occupied Areas
description: JERUSALEM, June 18 (AP)Following is the text of a statement by the Israeli Cabinet replying to American questions about the future of the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The Begin Government refers to the West Bank area by the biblical names Judea and Samaria.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMRoy. Young Israel of the West Side mourns the passing of Mr. Roy Abraham, beloved brother of our distinguised founding members, Dan & Jerry Abraham. May the Comforter of Zion console the entire family

title: Japan to Spur Imports
description: TOKYO, June 18 (Reuters)  Japan is planning emergency imports worth up to $4 billion to help reduce its huge trade surplus. The plan includes the stockpiling of crude oil and enriched uranium. Japan's current account surplus at the end of the 1977 fiscal year stood at a record $14.13 billion.

title: Rhode Island Cook Is Arraigned In 4 Shooting Deaths at Restaurant
description: WARWICK, R.I., June 18 (UPI)A restaurant cook accused of gunning down his boss and three coworkers last night was arraigned today on murder charges and ordered held without bail.

title: Tannenbaum on Top At New Jersey Bell
description: When he was working at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., Morris Tannenbaum developed a new type of transistor and led a group that discovered practical materials for superconducting magnets. Now he is the new president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, and his inventions are not likely to be much help in the job.

title: Andrea Lang Is Married
description: Andrea Ilona Lang, daughter of George Lang, the restaurateur and international food and design consultant, and Doe Lang, was married yesterday to Michael John Gurka, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gurka or Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Arthur Kortfieuei performed the nondenominational ceremony on the 59th floor of the Citicorp Center. The bride, an actress and illustrator, and the bridegroom, a professional clarinetist, are managers of Small Pleasures, a pastry shop and boutique at the Citicorp Center.

title: The Handicapped Are Emerging As a Vocal Political Action Group
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Leslie Milk doesn't like posters depicting children in leg braces and brave smiles seeking donations for Easter Seals or the March of Dimes.

title: Playoff to Newton
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 18 (AP)Jack Newton of Australia sank a 15foot putt on the first hole of a sudden death playoff today to defeat Mike Sullivan and capture the $20,000 first prize in the $100,000 Buick open golf chapionship.

title: U.S. Family Conference Delayed Amid Disputes and Resignations
description: The White House Conference on Fami: liesonce seemingly the simplest of President Carter's campaign promises to keep, but ,recently mired in controversy, rumor and suspicionhas been postponed from December 1979 to 1981.

title: Jobless Get AutoRepair Training Through Program in South Bronx
description: In a longempty factory in the South Bronx, a blue 1973 Volkswagen Beetle, a red 1975 Rabbit and a whole array of tools and auto parts on new workbenches will be waiting this morning for Misael Vasquez, Melvin Sutton, Ian Hill, Sigfredo Calderon and 16 other jobless young men, most of them black or Hispanic.

title: Reggae: Bob Marley In Jamaican Program
description: MADISON SQUARE GARDEN remains a potent symbol for many popmusic performers. a certification that one has attained superstardom. That's not invariably true. though: Acts that appeal to specific ethnic communities have played there without ever lapping over into the mainstream of American success.

title: Where to Join
description: For additional information on buying clubs, write or call the following organizations: Bartertown, 476 Broadway, 11th floor, New York, N.Y. 10013, 9644190; Free For All, 1623 Granville Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif., 90025, (213) 8269665; Mutual Credit Buying Systems International, 6420 Wilshire Boulevard, 7th floor, Los Angeles, Calif., 90048, (213) 2786192.

title: OPEC Still Deadlocked On Oil Price
description: GENEVA, June 18  Ministers froth the world's major oilexporting countries remained deadlocked here for the second consecutive day over plans for new pricing system that could raise the cost of oil if the United States dollar continues to decline in value against other currencies.

title: SOVIET PRESSES WARNING ABOUT AMERICAN POLICY
description: MOSCOW, June 18 (Reuters)The Kremlin showed today that it wants maximum attention for its warning this weekend that United States policies pose a threat to world peace.

title: Meeting Set to Aid Minorities as TV Writers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18Representatives of the Writers' Guild of America will meet tomorrow with the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers in the second step of an attempt to help members of minorities become television writers.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 18The world pair championship began here today,with 192 pairs competing for a title that will take six .days to determine.

title: Teacher Weds Miss Curley
description: The marriage of Margaret Cowan Curley to Peter Thompson Wiles, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Gordon Wiles of East Lyme, Conn., took place yesterday in Bedford Village, N.Y. The bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister and professor emeritus of religion at Connecticut College, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. P. Curley, parents of the bride. The Rev. Daniel K. Miner of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church assisted.

title: Nancy Friedman Married
description: At Temple B'nai Sholom of Rockville Centre, LI., yesterday, Nancy Ilene Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mr. Henry Friedman of Hicksville, LI., was married to Lawrence Mark Schleifer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schleifer of Rego Park, Queens. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: Artist Rewarded by Students' Praiseand $150,000
description: It's virtually invulnerable to the effects of galeforce winds, sonic booms and earthquakes, but the fourton sculpture just placed in front of Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx barely made it through the strike by Coop City residents that held up, millions of dollars in construction funds.

title: Free Agents Find A Wealth of Woes
description: EVERY day I play, says Oscar Gamble, a San Diego outfielder who surrendered his free agency last winter for a contract worth $2.85. million, I hear about how much money I got. It's like my last name. My name is 2.85 instead of Gamble.

title: Ruth Sandler Married To Mark J. Raiffa on L.I.
description: Ruth Handler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Sandler of East Meadow, L.I., and Mark Jay Raiffa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Raiffa of Belmont, Mass., were married yesterday by Rabbi Bennett Hermann at Temple EmanuEl in East Meadow.

title: Beth Weinstein Is Married To Kenneth Hapke, Lawyer
description: At the Free Synagogue of Flushing, Queens, yesterday, Beth Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Weinstein of Flushing, became the bride of Kenneth A. Hapke, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Hapke of Braintree, Mass. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony.

title: Deaths
description: BERKMANAlbert, beloved husband of Anne, devoted father of Cynthia and Joyce, loving brother of Marty, Murray and Jessie, cherished grandfather of Joanne, Scott, Jeffrey and Robin. Services were held Sunday, at the Jetfer Funeral Homes, Hillside Ave at 188th St, Hollis, L.I.

title: They Know Andy North Now
description: DENVER IN his early years on the golf tour, Andy North often was confused with Jerry Heard because of their facial resemblance. In recent years he. was confused with Andy Bean because of their first name. But now that his name will be engraved on. the United States Open trophy, Andy North no longer has an identity problem. Not that it bothered him that much. I don't think I'm an ego maniac, he was saying with a smile, but it's nice to have people call you by your right name. Andy North, tali and slim and 28 years old, was sitting in a brown leatherandwood chair up on the platform in the Cherry Hill press tent. With one white golf shoe up on a small table where the silver Open trophy gleamed, he was relaxing after having won the Open by sinking a 4foot bogey putt on the final green to avert an 18hole playoff with Dave Stockton and Jesse Carslyle Snead tomorrow. Better than anyone else, Dave Stockton summed up what the 4foot putt meant to Andy North.

title: Mears Coasts To Auto Victory
description: MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP)Rick Mears's car ran out of fuel today but coasted to victory in a 150 mile race at State Fair Park.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMRoy. Young Israel of the West Side mourns the passing of Mr. Roy Abraham, beloved brother of our distinguised founding members, Dan & Jerry Abraham. May the Comforter of Zion console the entire family

title: PoliceSchool Effort To Pick Up Truants Sought in Passaic
description: PASSAIC, June 18In a move to curb increasing juvenile delinquency, the Board of Education here is proposing that school attendance officers cruise with police officers in unmarked cars to pick up truants.

title: Scientists Identify More Members Of the Third Kingdom of Life
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The group of scientists that, last year, pinpointed third kingdom of life, a class of organisms simpler than bacteria, has now identified two more of the group's esoteric members.

title: Barter Clubs Become Big Business as Americans Cash In on Their Skills
description: In Merritt Island, Fla., a dentist performs oral surgery in exchange for a swimming pool. In Tempe, Ariz., a lawyer trades legal work for several nights in a Diego hotel. And in Venice, Calif., a computer expert takes flying lessons without ever taking a dollar froth his pocket. The doctor, lawyer arid computer expert are all engaging in doe of man's oldest forms of trade, barter.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Any Shape, in Foam

title: Vaccine: Low Profits and High Liability
description: Even though vaccines are among the most important and effective weapons Of public health, American pharmaceutical firms for more than a decade have been dropping out of the business.

title: Lillian Roberts a Quiet Force In the Largest Municipal Union
description: Quiet steel, that's what she's likeLillian Roberts is tough and tenacious and solid but smooth and charming, said a New York City commissioner, struggling to simplify the complexities of a labor leader who regularly confronts him and the other 17 commissioners on behalf of municipal employees.

title: Head of Newspaper Union Group Endorses Settlement at The News
description: The president of the 10union Allied Printing Trades Council said yesterday that he would have no qualms in nomMending as a basis for settlement the contract agreement between The Daily News and the Newspaper. Guild of New York, which on Saturday ended a fiveday strike.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC JUNE FAVORITES; Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: Nkomo, Spurning BritishU.S. Plan, Sees Rhodesia Victory in 10 Months
description: WASHINGTON. June 18  Joshua Nkomo, one of the leaders of. the Patriotic Front that is waging a guerrilla war ilagainst the Rhodesian Government, predicted victory in 6 to 10 months today and said that the BritishAmerican plan for a Rhodesian solution was getting out of date.

title: Westinghouse Settles Lawsuit
description: PITTSBURGH, June 18  The Union Electric Company of St. Louis has reached an outofcourt settlement with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in a lawsuit involving two steamturbine generators, it was announced today.

title: Jayne Mellenthin Wed To Robert Rogers 2d
description: Jayne Elizabeth Mellenthin and Robert Hastings Rogers 2d were married yesterday by the Rev. Vincent Mangrelli, a Roman Catholic priest, in the Vassar College Chapel.

title: CUTS IN U.S. SPENDING URGED AT CONFERENCE OF NATION'S MAYORS
description: ATLANTA, June 18  Mayor after mayor took the microphone today at session of the United States Conference of Mayors here to demand, in a departure from tradition, that the Federal Government spend less rather than more.

title: Beginning of a New Era
description: Baseball's freeagent system stems from an arbitrator's ruling in the Andy MessersmithDave McNally case.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Supreme Court agreed today to take another ook at the question of whether racial discrimination in hiring can be proved by statistics alone, without any demonstration that the employer intended to discriminate.

title: Payoff Issue Raised After Killing by Police
description: A Crown Heights construction contractor whose partner was killed in a tussle with policemen last week said yesterday that the businessman and civic leader had told him of being approached by policemen seeking payoffs.

title: Moon Church Competition Worries Montauk Fishermen
description: MONTAUK, L.I.The latest addition to the growing fishing fleet of the Rev. Sun Myung Moonthe steelhulled, 78foot Sea Richsailed into port here the other day and when it tied up at the end of a pier rumors spread from one end of Montauk Lake to the other,

title: Silverman Keeps Chancellor on News
description: Fred Silverman, whose success as programmer for ABC and CBS won him the position as operating head of the National Broadcasting Company, said in a brief interview yesterday that he had had to resolve two urgent matters during his first week in the job: the new program schedule and the status of John Chancellor on The NBC Nightly News.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: State Dedicates First Rail Station For Commuters in Meadowlands
description: SECAUCUS, June 19The first commuter rail station in the Hackensack Meadowlands was dedicated today, with Louis J. Gambaccini, the state's new Transportation Commissioner, and other speakers hailing the venture as a model of cooperation between government and private enterprise for the improvement of mass transit.

title: Helping Mentally Ill Mothers and Their Children Cope
description: CHICAGO, June 19  Marilyn relaxed in the doctor's office, chatting with her friends about summer camp, her diets and an examination she was going to take Monday for a license to sell real estate. Whenever I start dieting that's when the trouble begins, she said, smiling. It's probably the pressures of the kids, studying and hunger all at once, she said.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 19 (Reuters)A Protestant policeman kidnapped in a weekend ambush has been killed, according to a statement purporting to come from Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Oil prices will remain at their present level this year, OPEC announced, but it is studying ways to protect its revenues against the decline of the dollar  indicating a possible increase next year. Sheikh Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia said he was very satisfied, but militant delegates were angry at the decision. [Page A1.]

title: Investigators Say McClellan Admitted an Unreported Tongsun Park Gift
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)Senate investigators said today that Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, admitted before his death last fall that he had received an unreported campaign donation rrom Tongsun Park, the South Korean rice merchant.

title: Soviet Warns Japan Aiainst China Pact Aimed at Moscow
description: TOKYO, June 19The Soviet Union issued a stern warning to Japan today that this nation would be drawn into the current SovietChinese conflict if should conclude a peace; treaty with China aimed against the Soviet Government.

title: Ohio Court Grants Recall Delay
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 19 (AP)The Ohio Supreme Court today granted an indefinite delay to certification of petitions that seek to recall Cleveland Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich.

title: Coast Author Of the Tax Cut Scouts Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Howard Jarvis caught up with himself today, roaming the halls of Congress where his political reality has already been scaring lawmakers for two weeks.

title: BYRNE MAKES PLEA FOR HIS PROGRAMS
description: TRENTON, June 19Governor Byrne made a rare personal plea today to the Assembly's Democratic majority in an effort to rescue his sagging legislative program.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 20, 1978

title: Ali, Brezhnev Break Clean  And Come Out Loving
description: MOSCOW, June 19Both dtente and Muhammad Ali may haVe taken a beating lately, but for 35 minutes today the exheavyweight champion talked peace in the Kremlin with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leaderand the round clearly went to improved SovietAmerican relations.

title: Deaths
description: FLOODAnna G., On June 19, 1978 formerly of Forest Hills, N.Y. and Rockaway Park. Beloved wife of Arthur P. Flood. Mother of Dorothy Simon and Robert Flood. Sister of Sister Marie Tobin CSJ. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave., corner Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Mercy Church, Thursday, June 72 at 9:20 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery

title: Four Die in Tennessee Fire
description: GALLATIN, Tenn., June 19 (AP)Four persons were killed and a fifth was critically burned in a house fire early today, the authorities said. We know whose house it is but we haven't positively identified the victims yet but we believe it's several members of the family, a Gallatin Police Department dispatcher said.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO ANYONE over the age of 45, the story of the boxer Joe Louis is as familiar as the sound of radio static at night. Born in 1913, the seventh child of an Alabama sharecropping family Louis grew up to become in 1937 the second black athlete to win the heavyweight championship since the socalled Queensberry Rules put gloves on boxers a little over a century ago, and the first since the controversial Jack Johnson had lost the title to Jess Willard 17 years earlier. Louis's plodding but devastating ringmanship, his fights with the Teutonic Max Schmelling and the dancing Billy Conn, his troubles with fast women and relentless tax agents, and his latterday apotheosis as a symbol of black competence that even a white racist could live withall this is so familiar that indeed one wonders how his autobiography, Joe Louis: My Life, recorded by him with the assistance of the former sportscaster Art Rust Jr. and Mr. Rust's wife, Edna, could further enlighten us about his life and times.

title: Japan Acts to Revive Depressed Shipyards
description: NAGASAKI, Japan  The huge Japanese shipbuilding industry, once the world's leader btit now run aground on the rocks of recession, is turning to a variety of new  and unusual  ways to keep afloat. The immediate outlook, however, is for more rough seas.

title: Duryea Sounds 3 Themes Upstate: Taxes, Crime, Lack of Leadership
description: HENRIETTA, N.Y., June 19Like a lead singer and his backup group, Perry B. Duryea and his three Republican running mates began touring upstate television studios and hotel meeting rooms today.

title: Yanks Lose, 104, as Red Sox Erupt for 6 Runs in 8th Inning
description: BOSTON, June 19Just as everyone expected, the longawaited first meeting between the rYankees and the Boston Red Sox produced thunder and lightning tonight. The first combination of thunder and lightning led to a deluge of rain after the game was only 5 minutes and half an inning old. The second produced six Boston runs in the eighth inning and a 10.4 victory.

title: Deaths
description: GREENHOUSEAnne Pick on June 18, 1978. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Greenhouse. Adored mother of Jane & motherInlaw of John Rlsden. Loving grandmother of John, Ellen, Maryann, & John, Jr. Devoted sisterInlaw of Lillian Pick. Sister of the late Fred E. Pick. The family will be at home, 211 E. 70 St., Tuesday, June 21st 24pm & 79pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, Tenn. would be appreciated. Interment private.

title: Stars and Stripes, G.I. Paper, in Financial Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The Stars and Stripes, the American servicemen's daily newspaper abroad, is in financial trouble and may have to carry commercial advertising to avoid possible extinction.

title: Princeton Football Coach Finds Slot At New Jersey Bank
description: Robert F. Casciola recently joined the First National State Bank of New Jersey as assistant vice president for government banking. If everything goes well, though, he might end up assistant vice presidentfootball. As the most recent former head football coach at Princeton, he would be the man for the job.

title: TOXICOLOGIST GIVES CURARE TESTIMONY
description: HACKENSACK, June 19A toxicologist testifying for the defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E; Jascalevich said that the prosecution's tests for the presence of curare in the bodies of the alleged victims were too uncertain to be accepted as valid.

title: Mets Obtain Perez, Infielder
description: The Mets signed Marty Perez, veteran infielder, as a free agent yesterday and sent him to their Tidewater club in the International League. He was released earlier in the season by the Oakland A's.

title: Events Today
description: SCENES OF LIFE AND DEATH and FOREVER AND A DAY. With Estela Medina, in Spanish for 10 performances in repertory. Presented by Gilberto Zaldivar, producer of the Spanish Repertory Theater. At the Gramercy Arts Theater, 133 East 27th Street at 8.

title: Real Places
description: NEWARK HER friends relax and just call the slender, grayhaired woman Walter sometimes instead of Sister Mary Walter. Where is Walter? they'll ask when she is not in her principal's office at St. Columba's. But the children of St. Columba's School, misleadingly uniform in their blue shirts and plaid parochial school jumpers, give her the greatest respect in looping little singsong as soon as she puts her head in a classroom doorway.

title: Four Die in Tennessee Fire
description: GALLATIN, Tenn., June 19 (AP)Four persons'were killed and a fifth was critically burned in a house fire early today, the authorities said. We know whose house it is but we haven't positively identified the victims yet but we believe it's several members of the family, a Gallatin Police Department dispatcher said.

title: Steel Output Down by 0.7%
description: Steel production for the week ended June 17 declined seventenths of 1 percent to 2,781,000 tons from 2.8 million tons the week before, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Administration Discloses Plans For Uses of Space Technology
description: WASHINGTON. June 19Officials of the Carter Administration made public today partial results of a Presidential review of both civilian and military space policy that indicate basic divisions on the civilian program of the future.

title: Los Angeles Group Presents Plan to I.O.C.
description: MONTREAL, June 19 (AP)A plan under which an organizing committee for the 1984 Summer Olympics would assume responsibility for deficits incurred rather than the taxpayers of Los Angeles was presented to the International Olympic Committee today.

title: Peru's Moderate Leftists Are the Apparent Victors In First Voting in Decade
description: LIMA, Peru, June 19 (AP)Led by 83yearold Victor Raid) Haya de la Torre, APRA, the moderate leftist party, appeared today to have won the largest bloc of constitutionaI assembly seats in Peru's first nationwide elections in 11 years of military rule.

title: 4 Teams in Battle for World Cup Final
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 19 (AP)It's been tough going in the World Cup soccer tournament as the bruised teams face their sixth game in 17 days, and it looks as if the team with the most stamina will win the title.

title: MAYORS OF BIG CITIES SEEK U.S ATTENTION
description: ATLANTA, June 19A group of bigcity mayors, worried that they are losing national influence, are trying to resurrect a device that they used some years ago to call attention to the special problems of the nation's older cities.

title: Soviet Soldier Is Seized After East Berlin Shooting; Diplomat Among 4 Injured
description: EAST BERLIN, June 19A Soviet soldier driving a delivery van was chased through East Berlin today by East German policemen and captured after. an exchange of fire in which a West German diplomat and three other persons were wounded.

title: Mariners 7, White Sox 4
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI)Bob Robertson's threerun homer highlighted fiverun third inning tonight that carried the Seattle Mariners to a 74 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Tree Surgeon Is Guilty In Killing of Student
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., (AP) Ricky Knapp, 27, an Oneonta tree surgeon has been found guilty of seconddegree murder by an Otsego County jury here.

title: NEWSPAPER GUILD NAMES PAGE ONE AWARD WINNERS
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York has announced the winners of its Page One Awards. Their work appeared in newspapers and magazines ouring 1977.

title: A Big Change in Year for Red Sox
description: BOSTON, June 19Mike Torrez, a strong righthanded pitcher who won two World Series games for the Yankees last year, then defected to the Boston Red Sox as a free agent, was talking the other day about his new mates.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: SMITHMary T. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. On June 18, 1978. Wife of Raymond A. Smith. Sister of James SkellyFriends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, Tuesday 24 and 79 p.m. where the St. Veronica's Guild will meet on Tuesday at 3 p.m. Mass of Christian burial will be held at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, Wednesday 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers contributions to Immaculate Heart of Mary Church In her memory would be appreciated.

title: Carter Proposes a Reorganization Giving Civil Defense New Emphasis
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Carter, in a shift in strategic policy, proposed today a reorganization plan that would place new emphasis on civil defense in what Administration officials said was a response to a major effort by the Soviet Union to protect its civilian population from the hazards of nuclear war.

title: Miss Myers Wins Berth On U.S. Wheelchair Team
description: FISHERVILLE, Va., June 19 (UPI)Sharon Myers of Troutville won a berth on a United States team of disabled athletes that will compete in London and Brazil after she broke national records in the shotput and javelin events at the National Wheelchair Games.

title: SUCCESSOR TO MARSTON IS CONFIRMED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The Senate today confirmed President Carter's candidate for United States Attorney in Philadelphia, succeeding David W. Marston, who was dismissed.

title: ATLANTIC CITY FEARS RISE IN KLAN ACTIVITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 19A recent increase in racial incidents attributed to the Ku Klux Klan is making city officials and some residents nervous.

title: Lyon Leads Qualifiers
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., June 19Bart Lyon of Bamm Hollow, a 23yearold insurance salesman, carded a oneunderpar 69 and captured medalist honors among the 36 qualifiers in the New Jersey Slate open southern sectionals today at Raritan Valley Country Club. The 36 who made the cat qualified for the state open July 1214 at Canoe Brook, Summit.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: when the armed forces broke up into rival Moslem and Christian factions. The navy was held by the Christians.

title: U.S. SUES TEAMSTER FUND TO GAIN NEW DOCUMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The Labor Department went to Federal court today in an attempt to force trustees of the teamsters largest health and welfare fund to turn over information in connection with a department investigation of alleged mismanagement of the fund.

title: Economic Scene
description: Agreat divide in the postWorld War II economic history of the United States was reached in the middle of the 1960's. Before then, the nation had enjoyed relatively rapid economic growth, low unemployment and reasonably steady prices, despite cyclical swings. But starting in the mid1960's, stagflation  that baffling mixture of economic stagnation and inflation  set in, and has not yet been dispelled.

title: Rep. Clifford R. Allen, at 66; Crusader on Issues in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, June 19Clifford R. Allen, Representative of Tennessee's Fifth Congressional District and a colorful figure in Tennessee politics for 30 years, died yesterday of complications following a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: 24 SCHOOL WORKERS MAY FACE DISCHARGE
description: Fingerprint checks of public school custodifins in New York City have turned up 24 with criminalconviction records for offenses that disqualify them from work in the schools, a Board of Education spokesman said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on barter clubs on the Style page in The New York Times yesterday, the telephone number for Bartertown, a New York City group, was incorrectly listed. The correct number is (212) 9645190.

title: Israel's Choice
description: WASHINGTONThe Israeli Cabinet's decision on Sunday is primarily designed to avoid committing Israel to withdraw from the West Bank and to accept the right of the inhabitants of those territories to selfdetermination, thus blocking United States peace efforts in the Middle East.This decision, on the future of the West Bank and Gaza, comes as an additional proof of Israel's obstruction of the the emergence, at long last, of a viable and just peace in the area. Especially, when the sovereign right of Israel to exist as a state under Resolution 242 is accepted by the Arab states.

title: Israelis Said to Take Arms Vessel Lebanese Seized
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 19Lebanon's military command said today that two Lebanese coastal patrol vessels seized an arms ship off the southern part of the country yesterday but that Israeli gunboats had soon appeared, had opened fire and had taken the ship away from them.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar slumped to a new low against the yen yesterday, apparently on continued expectations that Japan's chronic trade surplus would continue to grow, The Associated Press reported.

title: Chief Justice Hughes Reaffirms Right of Women to Early Abortion
description: TRENTON, June 19Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the New Jersey Supreme Court reaffirmed today that women in the state have a constitutional right to undergo abortions during the first 2 weeks of pregnancy, but said the constitubionality of a state law Prohibiting tax money from being used to pay for such abortions must await further court tests.

title: A's 2, Rangers 1
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 19 (UPI)Jeff Newman hit his fourth homer of the season to breck a 11 tie in the eighth inning tonight and help the Oakland A's end an 11game losing streak with a 21 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Hughes to Add To Employees
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19  Responding to a turnaround in the aerospace industry, the Hughes Aircraft Company has announced plans to hire 3,500 new employees by the end of the year and an additional 7,500 new employees over the next five years.

title: U.S. Is Pressed to Comply With Wildlife Protection Treaty
description: The United States, long accustomed to prodding other countries to look after dwindling species of wildlife, is now being pushed by some of those countries to take stock of its own wild animals and plants.

title: Yamani Emphasizes Need for Strong Dollar
description: GENEVAL, June 19  Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Oil Minister, explained tonight his stand in favor of the oil price freeze by saying, We do not want to do anything that might help the deterioration of the dollar's value.

description: TUESDAY, JUNE 20, 1978

title: No Sightings Of Yachts in Bermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 19Where were they? That was the question asked frequently here today with regard to the 162 yachts that were sailing in the NewportBermuda ocean race.

title: Casino Stocks Rake In More Gains As Dow Nudges 1.65 Higher to 838.62
description: The casino stocks and a handful of glamour issues moved higher yesterday as Wall Street witnessed its slowest trading session this month. The turnover of 25.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange was the lowest since 21.03 million shares changed hands May 30.

title: Deaths
description: BROWNW. Gordon, on June 18, 1978, of Ridgewood, N.J. Husband of Isabella Brown and father of Phillip, Peter and James. Also survived by six grandchildren. Service and Interment private.

title: Convention Center Bill Is Opposed by Upstate Republicans in Senate
description: A bill calling for the state and the city to share equally in the financing of the proposed $257 million New York City convention center has run into opposition from Republicans in the State Senate.

title: 3State Cancer Study Getting Final Revision
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 19  A study of possible environmental causes of cancer in the New YorkNew JerseyPhiladelphia area has been prepared and is now undergoing final review and revision, Dr. Michael Greenberg, professor of urban studies and geography at Rutgers University, said today. He is in charge of the project.

title: Asa V . Call, at 85; Pacific Mutual Life's Honorary Chairman
description: Asa V. Call, honorary chairman of the Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., after a short illness following surgery. He was 85 years old.

title: No Progress in Hospital Labor Talks
description: The League of Voluntary Hospitals and Monies and District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health. Care Employees resumed talks but reported no progress yesterday on contracts, expiring at the end of this month, coveting 37,000 employees at 55 private, nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City metropolitan area.

title: Libyan Leader Vows to Back Revolts in Arab States
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, June 18Col. Muamnar elQaddafi said today that the Arab unity to which he has dedicated himself will come through popular revolutions in each country, and indicated that he would do what he could to promote them.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The bodies of two men and a women who had been bound hand and foot were found in an unoccupied house in the South Jamaica section or Queens. The victims, who were not immediately identified, might have been killed in a dispute over drugs, the police said.

title: Business People
description: What do you do when a movie is good but not that good and you want to put it over big? According to Norman Levy,, you call in a marketing man. He happens to be one and yesterday he was named president of Columbia Pictures Distribution, a new title.

title: S.E.C. Chairman Backs Internal Accounting Rule
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency would require corporations to file public reports on the adequacy of their internal accounting controls at some point in the near future.

title: George H. M. Lawrence, at 67; Known Internationally as Botanist
description: Dr. George H. M. Lawrence, an internationally known botanist, died June 11 in Kent County Memorial Hospital in Warwick, R.I., at the age of 67. He lived in Easr Greenwich. R.I.

title: Yonkers Mayor to Run for Seat
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 19 (UPI)Westchester County Republicans tonight chose Angelo Martinelli, the Mayor of Yonkers, as their candidate for the House seat of Representative Bruce F. Caputo, who is giving up the seat to run for Lieutenant Governor.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 19Two members of Sweden's team burst to the head of the standings at the end of this afternoon's play in the World Bridge Federation's Open Pair championship here. PerOlov Sundelin and Anders Morath scored 66 percent in the session, which carried them from 11th position to first.

title: Dr. Walter C. Alvarez, 93, Dies; Had Been Mayo Clinic Specialist
description: Dr. Walter Clement Alvarez, a retired medical specialist at the Mayo Clinic and a popular writer on health subjects, died Sunday in his native San Francisco at the age of 93.

title: How Open Admissions Plan Has Changed City College
description: The faculty is having to change its identity  from professional persons as sociated with an academic discipline to undergraduate teachers, said Anne Rees, dean of student affairs at city College. It's not easy to redefine your professional life.

title: TALKING BUSINESS The Arab Monetary Fund and Its Aims
description: Since 1974, when the price of oil quadrupled, the.Arab world has discussed and debated how much control the Arabs will actually enjoy over recycling, or investing, their own money. Arab politicians, newspapers and magazines periodically lament the paucity of Arab financial expertise and financial instruments. They say that by default, the surplus of Arab funds has been in the hands of foreigners.

title: Students Are the Building Blocks As Cuba Constructs New Society
description: ISLE OF PINES, Cuba, June 18In the afternoons, when lines of thunderstorms sweep in from the sea and drop curtains of cool rain on this green island, hundrecis of young Africans march into the fields to cultivate the land.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Credit Corporation, Charlotte, N.C., a diversified financial company, has named Bruce C. McMillen senior vice president and principal financial officer.

title: SixMonth Bill Rates at 3Year High
description: Rates on sixmonth Treasury bills hit their highest levels in three and a half years yesterday as the credit markets sagged while they waited for today's meeting of the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.

title: Atlantic City Concerned About Rise In Racial Incidents Linked to Klan
description: ATLANTIC CITY. June 19A recent increase in racial incidents attributed to the Ku Klux Klan is making city officials and some residents nervous.

title: An English Potter With an Oriental Touch
description: If the work of David Leach, an English potter, on exhibition at the Florence Duhl Gallery through Saturday, strikes you as Oriental rather than English in style, there's a reason for it. Mr. Leach, a very proper Englishman, was born in Tokyo, where his father, the potter Bernard Leach, happened to be working and absorbing Japanese techniques.

title: Beatrice Won't Delay Tropicana Deal
description: The Beatrice Foods Company has declined to comply with a request by the Federal Trade Commission that it delay its impending acquisition of Tropicana Products Inc.

title: Rock: Climax Blues Band Plays at Belmont Track
description: MANY racetracks in recent years have taken to luring younger fans by staging rock and pop concerts in conjunction with a day at the races. And although there have been such ventures before in the New York area, no track has pursued such a policy with the ambition and scope of Belmont Park this year. Over the course of the season a number of wellknown popmusic acts have played or will play the facility, and have been attracting healthy crowds that presumably spill into the attendance and betting, as well.

title: SIR DINGLE FOOT, AT 73; SERVED IN BRITISH CABINET
description: HONG KONG, June 19 (AP)Sir Dingle Foot, a member of one of Britain's leading political families, died after collapsing in his hotel room here last night, the police reported today. He was 73 years old.

title: TOXICOLOGIST GIVES CURARE TESTIMONY
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 19  A toxicologist testifying for the defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich said that the prosecution's test for the presence of curare in the bodies of the alleged victims were too uncertain to be accepted as valid.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN a dozen takeover rumors are making the rounds at once, it is not surprising that some have as much substance as a hungry broker's empty order pad.

title: Ali, Brezhnev Break Clean And Come Out Loving
description: MOSCOW, June 19Both dtente and Muhammad Ali may haVe taken a beating lately, but for 35 minutes today the exheavyweight champion talked peace in the Kremlin with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leaderand the round clearly went to improved SovietAmerican relations.

title: The Storm Over the Negev: Bedouins of Israel Are Victims of Progress
description: ABU TULUL, BEDOUIN ENCAMPMENT, IsraelAfter miles of travel over an illdefined series of ruts and little gullies that the locals call a road, a traveler's eyes, suffused with the stark unending desert landscape, catches sight of a modest garden and an even more modest orchard with apples, figs and almonds.

title: The Ripple Effects of Horrigan's Promotion
description: The loss of a leader can be sad  but not always. Take the case of Edward J. Horrigan who yesterday was named chairman and chief executive officer of R. J. Reynolds International, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries. Mr. Horrigan's new job touched off a whole chain of promotions at Buckingham Industries, the Culty Sark importing division of Northwest Industries.

title: Youngstown Seeks a Grasp On Its Fading Steel Industry
description: YOUNGSTOWN, OhioFor decades, it was said that one could not hear a conversation in Youngstown for the clamor of the steel mills. No matter how often the mills closed in business downturns, there was always confidence that they would soon be back in operation.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, June 21 QUEEN ELIZABETH II (Cunard). Lett Cherbourg June 16; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOONTIME NOTES With free, earlyevening entertainment now continuing into its fifth month in the Market atrium of the Citicorp Center on the midtown East Side, office workers and residents of the West Side now have a free series of lunchtime diversions, too.

title: Cotton Dust Rule Issued; Both Sides Are Unhappy
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  After three weeks of intense debate at the highest levels of the Carter Administration, Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall announced today a health rule aimed at reducing the incidence of lung disease among 600,000 cotton workers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on barter clubs on the Style page in The New York Times yesterday, the telephone number for Bartertown, a New York City group, was incorrectly listed. The correct number is (212) 9645190.

title: 30Year Acoholism Study Is Begun
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 19 (UPI)Rutgers University said today it would undertake a 30year study to trace the origins of problems that lead to problem drinking or alcoholism

title: OPEC WILL MAINTAIN PRESENT OIL PRICE FOR THE REST OF '78
description: GENEVA, June 19The world price of oil will remain frozen at its present level for the rest of this year, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today.

title: Moon Church Competition Worries Montauk Fishermen
description: MONTAUK, L.I.The latest addition to the growing fishing fleet of the Rev. Sun Myung Moonthe steelhulled, 78foot Sea Richsailed into port here the other day and when It tied up at the end of a pier rumors spread from one end of Montauk Lake to the other.

title: Bonnie Garland's Parents Urge A Maximum Term for Her Killer
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 19The parents of Bonnie Joan Garland said today that they hoped the public would join them in urging imposition of the 25year maximum sentence on Miss Garland's killer, Richard J. Herrin, who was convicted yesterday of the reduced charge of manslaughter.

title: State Street Mall: Chicago's Retail Hope
description: CHICAGO, June 19  State Street, that great street of song and local history, is undergoing a revolution of sorts, giving rise to merger fever and hopes for a better future for the city's motor retailers.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A further decline in the dollar combined yesterday with widespread expectations that today's Treasury auction of gold would produce strong bidding to raise prices of precious metals futures.

title: Bonnie Garland's Parents Urge A Maximum Term for Her Killer
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 19The parents of Bonnie Joan Garland said today that they hoped the public would join them in urging imposition of the 25year maximum sentence on Miss Garland's killer, Richard J. Herrin, who was convicted yesterday of the reduced charge of manslaughter.

title: Import Beer Sales Gain
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The National Association of Beer Importers reported that sales of imported beer. had nearly tripled since 1970 and were still growing. Though only a tiny share of the market, last year imports rose 7 percent to 78.9 million gallons. The United States Brewers Association, on the other hand, says domestic beer sales in 1977 amounted to 4.8 billion gallons  up 4.4 percent over 1976.

title: Batya Zamir Choreographs And Dances Out of the Blue
description: OUT OF THE BLUE, which Batya Zamir presented Sunday afternoon at St. Clement's Theater, was a study in pure virtuosity.

title: Christians Arrest Officers
description: NAQURA, Lebanon, June 19 (Reuters) Lebanese Christian militiamen who have taken control of border positions evacuated last week by Israeli troops said at a checkpoint here today that they had arrested local commanders for seeking to allow United Nations peacekeeping troops to move in.

title: Topics
description: In the shadowy Corners of Fire Island you will find them, clutching their little brown bags and eyeing passersby with suspicion. No, they are not winos. Their bags contain not red eye but ice cream from the DariSwirl store. The village fathers of Ocean Beach, who achieved celebrity last year by declaring the eating of cookies in public a violation of the law, have now banned the public eating of ice.crearn as well and summonses are being handed out right and left. It's all part of an antilittering drive. We would call the an unAmerican if that word did not have such disagreeable connotations. So let's just call it unappetizing.

title: Looking Before Leaping
description: In January 1971, the U.S. State Department instructed the American Embassy in Manila to give all possible encouragement to the desire of the Philippine Government to build and operate a nuclear power plant. In January 1976, the ExportImport Bank authorized a $277million loan and further loan guarantees of $367 million for. construction and purchase of the reactor.

title: 24 SCHOOL WORKERS MAY FACE DISCHARGE
description: Fingerprint checks of public school custodians in New York City have turned up 24 with criminalconviction records for offenses that disqualify them from work in the schools, a Board of Education spokesman said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York said it had agreed to make a tender offer for the 1.95 million outstanding shares of the Jeannette Corporation at $20 a share, for a total of about $39 million.

title: Notes on People
description: THE WHITE HOUSE said yesterday that President Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, would spend July 14 and 15 in West Germany as the guests of President Walter Scheel. President Carter also plans to attend a summit meeting in Bonn on July 16 and 17, at which he will confer with leaders of several European countries and Japan on the economy. While in West Germany, the Carters plan to visit Berlin.

title: VANCE URGES EFFORT BY U.S. AND RUSSIANS TO REDUCE TENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Carter Administration would bend our efforts to expand cooperation with the Soviet Union. He urged that both Washington and Moscow put polemics aside and concentrate on the concrete actions we both can take to reduce tensions and to reach agreement on the critical issues now under negotiation.

title: RABBI CHARLES M. BATT
description: Rabbi Charles M. Batt, a Jewish community leader and businessman from West Hartford, Conn., died Saturday in Jerusalem while visiting members of his family. He was 74 years old.

title: Bid to Aid MitchellLama Program By Carey Appears to He Doomed
description: ALBANY, June 19Governor Carey' plan to bail out the financially troubled MitchellLama housing program appears dead for this legislative session, with cach attempt to placate a resistant Demo craticled Assembly, further alienating the Senate's Republican majority.

title: Cohan Stamp Coming July 3
description: A United States Postal Service. stamp honoring George M. Cohan will he issued on the 100th anniversary of his birth. July 3, in the city where he was born; Providence, R.I.

title: BUILDING IN MIDTOWN TO SUPPLY ITS POWER
description: A major private office building in midtown Manhattan is being rebuilt and equipped with diesel generators to make it the first such building in the city to supply its own energy and, its developers say, to reduce electrical costs for tenants by 10 percent or more.

title: Midtown Office Building to Supply Its Own Energy to Reduce Costs
description: A major private office building in midtown Manhattan is being rebuilt and equipped Withdiesel generators to make it, the first rich building in the city to upply its own energy and, its develonF say, to reduce e??e??cal costs for tenants by 10 percent or more.

title: The Urban Cowboy, 1978 Style
description: HOUSTON YOU can't miss him on the freeways. He rides high in his pickup truck, a straw hat or black felt cowboy hat on his head, a pinch of snuff in his cheek and a Lone Star beer (the brand is important) at hand. One booted foot is tapping to the beat of a Willie Ne:son song. The other spurs the pickup in and out of traffic lanes in a style that might be called, with some understatement, individualistic.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) America Stock Exchange thee and (O) overthecounter.

title: OncePowerful Easily Become SoonForgotten
description: Last week's meetings of the Democratic and Republican State Committees demonstrated how the mighty have fallen and how soon politicians are forgotten, even by their fellow politicians.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: ExGulf Official Given Jail Term
description: PITTSBURGH, June 19  Fred W. Standefer, a forMer executive of the Gulf Oil Corporation, was sentenced today to six months in prison for having approved five illegal vacation trips for an Internal Revenue Service superivisor.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978

title: AntiAbortionists' Impact Is Felt In Elections Across the Nation
description: IOWA CITY, June 17State Senator Minnette Doderer, a leading figure in Iowa politics, was narrowly and unexpectedly defeated June 6 in the Democratic primary election for Lieutenant Governor.

title: Envoy in Lisbon Assails Sadat
description: LISBON, June 19 (Reuters)Egypt's Ambassador to Portugal, Lieut. Gen. Saad Eddin alShazli, made a strong attack on President Anwar elSadat today, saying that his regime was no better than the former dictatorships in Portugal and Spain.

title: Reporter's Notebook
description: BONN THE Schmutzfink, a kind of dirty bird who tells people how to behave on West German autobahns, has altered his approach this year and maybe, just maybe, the change says a little bit about language and the style of living in a country where admonition, exhortation and the imperative have been very much at home.

title: DeMilia Puts Off Mailing of Ballots
description: The executive board. of New York City's Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday directed Samuel DeMilia the union's president, to mail cut strike ballots if negotiations yesterday were not productive.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Plan
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it was undertaking a $7 million program to modernize three of its five domestic extrusion plants. The projects are being undertaken at the company's Los Angeles; Dolton, Ill., and Woodbury, N.Y., facilities. The company's five domestic extrusion plants produce window and floor frames, truck trailer bodies, spectator seating and automobile parts.

title: Kentucky Baptists Sue to Bar State From Imposing School Standards
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., June 17When they were children, they were taught that every word in the Bible was the truest word that ever was set down: God created the world and Adam and Eve, paradise was lost on account of temptation, Jesus' birth was a virgin birth and He was crucified to save mankind. From Genesis to Revelations, there was not a sentence that could not be taken literally.

title: Advertising
description: GEORGE LOIS, mecurial and talented president and creative director of Creamer Lois FSR, stalked out of his office yesterday after resigning his position. His name has oven on the door there for about eight months.

title: The Judge vs.the Attorney General
description: The executive and judicial branches of Government appear headed for a collision in a Federal courtroom in New York. Judge Thomas Griesa has ordered Attorney General Griffin Bell to disclose the names and files of F.B.I. informers in a suit brought by the Socialist Workers Party. The. Attorney General says he won't, even if that means forfeiting the case or being found in contempt. The collision would be unfortunate. It might weaken law enforcement and dilute public respect for law. But it can still be avoided.

title: Forego Triumphs by a Neck in '78 Debut
description: For the first time in nine months, New York racing fans heard a familiar but magic battle cry yesterday at Belmont Park: Here comes Forego on the outside.

title: Case Against Red Brigades Goes to Jury in Turin
description: ROME, June 19The case against 15 admitted members of the Red Brigades and 31 other suspects went to the jury today after the key defendants took turns reading a long statement in which they proclaimed themselves to be militant revolutionaries but not terrorists.

title: Text of Vance's Opening Statement to House Committee
description: I welcome this opportunity to meet with you on behalf of the President to address the concerns that members of this committee expressed in their letter to the President.

title: Carter Seeks Civil Defense Plan In Response to Action by Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Carter, in a shift in strategic policy, proposed today a reorganization plan that would place new emphasis on civil defense in what Administration officials said was a response to a major effort by the Soviet Union to protect its civilian population from the hazards of nuclear war.

title: Conklin Retiring From Albany Seat; State Position for Buffalo Senator
description: ALBANY, June 19Twentytwo years after a skeptic told hun to enjoy his first term as a State Senator because you probably won't be back, William T. Conklin of Brooklyn, deputy majority leader of the Senate, announced today that he would not seek reelection.

title: Vietnam Reports Peking Has Ordered It to Close Three Consulates in China
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 19 (AP)China has ordered Vietnam to close its consulates in three Chinese cities, the Hanoi radio announced today. The move came as two Chinese ships stood by to begin a largescale evacuation of Chinese refugees from Vietnam.

title: DAVID ROCKER, AN AGENT FOR SOME OF TOP STARS
description: David Hacker, a talent agent and president of Lansdale Artists Management at 171 West 57th street in Manhattan, died Friday of a stroke at Lenox Hill. Hospital. lie was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FRANZ G. TALLEY, AT 59; LED AEROSPACE COMPANY
description: Franz G. Talley, president and chairman of the board of Talley Industries, based in Mesa, Ariz., died Sunday of a heart attack in the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Los Angeles. He had maintained an office in that city. Mr. Talley was 59 years old.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Chrysler Corporation and its investment bankers, led by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group, have apparently scored a coup in the financial markets.

title: Husky Oil Denies Occidental Collusion
description: Husky Oil Ltd., deeply embroiled in a takeover battle with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and PetroCanada, the Canadian Government oil company, voiced shock and surprise yesterday to charges of collusion with Occidental to drive up the price of Husky stock. It vigorously denied the accusation.

title: TV: Scott Joplin: King of Ragtime
description: ORIGINALLY made as a television movie, Scott Joplin: King of Ragtime was first released theatrically in 1976 by its overly optimistic producer. It failed at the box office and inevitably triggered a great deal of clucking about the anemic state of television movies. Now, tonight at 9 on NBC, Scott Joplin can be seen on television. The fact is it's not even a very good television movie.

title: High Court Restricts Class Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  The Supreme Court restricted somewhat further today the ease of bringing classaction lawsuits by ruling that the plaintiffs in such a suit must ordinarily bear the cost of compiling the names and addresses of members of the affected class, who often number in the tens of thousands.

title: Clay Shaw's Lost Cause
description: The Supreme Court has ruled that the death in 1974 of Clay Shaw, a New Orleans businessman who once faced preposterous charges of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy, also meant the death of his civil lawsuit against former District Attorney Jim Garrison. The sad result is that. Mr.Garrison will not be .brought to judgment for prosecutorial abuses that injured the reputation of an innocent man for a petty purpose: to build a conspiracy theory and discredit the Warren Commission.

title: Pinochet Order Hinted In Letelier's Killing
description: LONDON, June 19 (Reuters)Mariana Townley, the wife of an American charged with conspiracy to murder former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier of Chile, said in a television interview tonight that it was quite possible that President Augusto Pinochet of Chile ordered the slaying.

title: Music: Chorus Makes Debut
description: MUCH of the music that has found its way into the permanent modern repertory may puzzle and discourage at first, but grows more stimulating and accessible with repeated hearings. By comparison, Carl Orff's cantata Carmina Burana, composed in 193536 and still going strong, is easy to assimilate. Based or a collection of earthy poems from the 13th century, it is colorful, exuberant stuff, and purposely simple.

title: That Labor Bill
description: WASHINGTONAlmost without notice, the Senate wrote history last Thursday, when it refused for the fifth time to shut off debate on the socalled Labor Law Reform Act, The Senate has voted on cloture only 127 times in its history and no previous filibuster on a legislative issue has been prolonged beyond four ballots.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: Incoming

title: Play: Acting Bohemians
description: ALTHOUGH he was preeminent as a literary critic and social historian, Edmund Wilson, nevertheless tried his hand at all forms of literary discourse: poetry, short stories, novels and plays. Some of these efforts had a certain fame (I Thought of Daisy), even notoriety Memoirs of Hecate County), but the feeling among many readers was that in these works Wilson was simply keeping in his hand, much as a music critic might take the third piano in Bach's concerto for three pianos or play one of the instruments in the Toy Symphony.

title: Committee to Seek Beaumont Troupe
description: A committee designed to reopen the darkened Vivian Beaumont Theater, possibly by the fall of 1979, with a new institutional repertory company has been appointed by Lincoln Center.

title: Carter Hawley Set To Add Thalhirner
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., which failed in February to, acquire Marshall Field & Company and then in April acquired the John Wanamaker chain in Philadelphia, announced yesterday a $70 million agreement under which it is to acquire Thalhimer Brothers Inc., a departmentstore chain based in Richmond.

title: AntiAbortionists Impact Is Felt In Elections Across the Nation
description: IOWA CITY, June 17State Senator Minnette Doderer, a leading figure in Iowa politics, was narrowly and unexpectedly defeated June 6 in the Democratic primary election for Lieutenant Governor.

title: Steel Merger Awaits Bell Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Executives of LTV Inc. and the Lykes Corporation and the companies' lawyers will call on Griffin B. Bell tomorrow as the Attorney General approaches the Carter Administration's first major antitrust decision.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONTheodore MacGregor, beloved husband of the late Blanche Spier Anderson, Services Wednesday, June 21,12 noon, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street.

title: POLL FINDS CONTRASTS IN VIEWS ON RELIGION
description: The first major national survey comparing the views of churchgoers with those of the unchurched shows considerable agreement on basic religious beliefs but sharp differences in attitudes toward organized religion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)Bjorn Borg, bidding to become the first player in 42 years to win the Wimbledon tennis title three years in succession, was seeded No. 1 today for the men's singles. The twoweek tournament starts next Monday.

title: Levi's Net Off In 2d Quarter
description: Levi Strauss & Company reported yesterday that its net income for the second quarter, ended May 28, amounted to $30.7 million, or $1,39 a share, on sales of $381 Million. These results include a onetime payment of $3.5 million, equal to 8 cents a share after taxes, to the State of California in settlement of a suit alleging price maintenance from 1972 to 1975.

title: Vote on Labor Filibuster Delayed As Senate Recesses for 2 Days
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)A sixth and recordtying vote on whether to cut off a filibuster against a labor law reform bill was postponed today when the Senate went into an unexpected two day recess.

title: All's Well in Newark, 640Page Book Says
description: NEWARK, June 19 (AP)A book just published should reduce the level of nonsense that exists about Newark, according to the book's editor, Dr. Stanley B. Winters.

title: Israeli Parliament Approves Reply To U.S. Questions on Peace Plan
description: JERUSALEM, June 19After nearly six hours of often stormy debate, the Israeli Parliament approved tonight the vaguely worded reply of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet yesterday to American questions about Israel's future plans for the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip.

title: England Tops Pakistan In Test Cricket Match
description: LONDON, June 19 (Reuters)  Ian Botham, Somerset's 22yearold all rounder, bowled England to victory in the second cricket test against Pakistan today with a remarkable spell of seven for 14.

title: Miss Krupsak Holds Discussions On a Possible Race Against Carey
description: After she indicated that she would not be a candidate for any office this year, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak discussed with various political figures a possible challenge of Governor Carey in the Democratic primary and even ordered the printing of designating petitions, according to a ton aide.

title: Washington Journal
description: AT THE END of another day in the United States Senate, George McGovern relaxed in his big corner office on Capitol Hill, a glass of iced vodka chilling his hand, his prominence as a liberal gadfly warming his heart.

title: HeinWerner Merger Talks
description: The HeinWerner Corporation, a maker of hydraulic jacks, said it had received an inquiry from a company expressing an interest in possibly acquiring HeinWerner and had met with representatives of the company last week. It declined to identify the company and added the inquiry was preliminary in nature.

title: Deaths
description: Anderson, T.

title: CAIRO WILL CONTINUE PEACE BIDS WITH U.S.
description: CAIRO June 19Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel of Egypt said today that the intransigence shown by the Israeli Cabinet yesterday would not deter Egypt's attempts to work with the United States to revive the stalled Middle East peace initiative.

title: Israeli Parliament Approves Reply To U.S. Questions on Peace Plan
description: JERUSALEM, June 19After nearly six hours of often stormy debate, the Israeli Parliament approved tonight the vaguely worded reply of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet yesterday to American questions about Israel's future plans for the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip.

title: MARTHA KAPLAN KWITNY
description: Martha Kaplan Kwitny, a deputy attorncy general for the State of New Jersey, died yesterday in Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn at the age of 33. Mrs. Kwitny had suffered from kidney disease in recent years.

title: Injuries: Too Costly For Sports?
description: Four years after a high school football injury left him paralyzed, a Florida youth wins a $5.3 million jury award against the company that made the helmet.

title: Restaurants Are Cited for Violations Of the New York City Health Code
description: New York City's Health Department yesterday cited six restaurants that had violated the Health Code, one that had corrected earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so. The restaurants were listed as follows:

title: Greatest Athlete In the World
description: Bruce Jenner, the noted cereal eater, wears a fine gold chain around his neck and at the throat hang gold figures: 73076. That's to remind him, in case it slips his mind, that it was July 30, 1976, when he completed the 10th and last event of the Olympic decathlon in Montreal and succeeded to the title of Greatest Athlete in the World. The Olympic decathlon champion has been the Greatest Athlete in the World by royal decree ever since Monday, July 15, 1912. Sir, King Gustav V of Sweden said to Jim Thorpe when Jim won the gold medal on that date, you are the greatest athlete in the world. Thanks, King, Jim said. Times and monarchs have changed. Queen Elizabeth H and Prince Philip attended the Montreal Olympics but didn't say a word to Jenner when he won. Instead, Bruce had a locket made for his manager with the numbers: 8618. That was his winning score in the 10 events, the highest score ever made by anybody anywhere. The world record Jenner broke, 8,524, was his own.

title: The Storm Over the Negev: Bedouins of Israel Are Victims of Progress
description: ABU TULUL BEDOUIN ENCAMPMENT, IsraelAfter miles of travel over an illdefined series of ruts and little gullies that the locals call a road, a traveler's eyes, suffused with the stark unending desert landscape, catches sight of a modest garden and an even more modest orchard with apples, figs and almonds.

title: The Cheap Blue Yonder
description: I wanted an airline ticket. First class with frills? asked the clerk. It is our most expensive flight.

title: In South Korea, a New Group Is Emerging: A Middle Class
description: SEOUL South KoreaKang Dal Ohn is a teacher, a husband and a father. He is also a symbol of major change here.

title: A.T.&T. Bars Aid On Pacific Unit's Tax
description: In a highly unusual move, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would not help its 90 percentowned subsidiary the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company pay as much as $1 billion in back taxes that the subsidiary may owe because of an opinion by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Japanese Banks Agree to Loan
description: TOKYO, June 19 (UPI)  A group of 21 Japanese commercial banks has signed an agreement to lend $265 million to Mexico's Nacional Financiera S.A., a member bank said today.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: A new cottage industry, based on peer review, is emerging on the accounting scene. Spawned by Congressional pressure for revision of accountingprofession practices and new requirements that many accounting partnerships submit to periodic reviews by other firms, these specialty peerreview firms derive  or expect to derive  a large part of their revenues from such examinations. One firm moving aggressively into this field is Hurdman & Cranstoun, a mediumsized New York accounting concern.

title: Stage: Borman at Niagara
description: NIAGARAONTIELAKE, Ontario, June 19Ibsen's John Gabriel Borlunan is a play consisting of four acts. It is in climax from the very beginning, when one old sister bursts tin on the otter after a snowy journey across Norway to claim the son they have alternately raised between them. Overhead, the pounding steps of Borkman are heard. He has immured himself for years in his room, ever since his disgrace as an embezzler.

title: Royals 6, Indians 5
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 19 (UPI) Clint Hurdle had two hits, scored twice and knocked in a run tonight to help. the Kansas City Royals gain. a 65 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Ozawa Impressed With Upbeat. China
description: TOKYO, June 19  Seiji Ozawa, musical director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who last week became the first foreigner to conduct concerts in China in many years, has returned to his native Japan with a vivid personal account of his stay in Peking, where hen lived as a child.

title: OPEC WILL MAINTAIN PRESENT OIL PRICE FOR THE REST OF '78
description: GENEVA, June 19The world price of oil will remain frozen at its present level for the rest of this year, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today.

title: The Spring Abortion Rite
description: Congress seems to be perfecting a sad spring rite in which the members magisterially decide which of the nation's poor women shall be allowed Federal abortion funds. The House voted a stringent limit this week that would fund abortions Only for those whose lives are actually endangered by a pregnancy. The Senate is expected to be more lenient, offering help to those whose physicians, certify that the procedure is medically necessary.

title: Illinois Bell Names First Woman Director
