description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21The Fijian infantrymen serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon like to boast that they represent Fiji's entire military establishment except for a few traffic policemen.

title: TREMORS CONTINUE IN NORTHERN GREECE
description: SALONIKA, Greece, June 21 (AP)Sharp new earth tremors shook northern Greece today in the aftermath of a powerful earthquake that devastated this city of 600,000. killing at least 14 persons and injuring 150, according to the police.

title: U.S. AGENCIES LAGGING IN WORK SAFEGUARDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Federal Government is failing to protect the safety and health of its own employees adequately and, as a result, the costs of worker sickness and injury are skyrocketing, according to internal Administration documents.

title: $5 Million Awarded in Tank Blast
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 21 (AP)Survivors of two men killed in a tank explosion have been awarded a total of $5 million in punitive damages The Circuit Court jury handed down the verdict yesterday against the Union Oil Company of California in the deaths of Chester Bagby, 22 years old, and Herman Robertson, 43. The two men were welders working on a storage tank at the Union Oil depot at Birmingport when the tank exploded Nov. 2, 1976. The awards of $2.5 million each will go to Mr. Baghy's mother and Mr. Robertson's widow.

title: U.S. to Ask Cairo To Propose Plan For West Bank
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Carter Administration has decided to seek a formal proposal from Egypt on the future of the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip as a possible way of reviving the stalled Middle East peace talks, officials said today.

title: Gasoline Stocks Drop Sharply
description: The American Petroleum Institute yesterday reported a biggerthanexpected decline in gasoline stocks. They fell to 231.5 million barrels in the week ended June 16 from 236.4 million barrels the week before.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TURNABOUT During its tours abroad, La Mama Experimental Theater Club has made guest appearances in Zagreb on the stage of Theater Etc., one of Yugoslavia's foremost drama companies. Now the Greenwich Village troupe is sponsoring the American debut of a puppet performance for adults by the Zagreb unit tonight through Saturday.

title: Carey's CrimePenalty Proposals Stalled by Partisan Wrangling
description: ALBANY, June 21Governor Carey's proposals to toughen penalties for violent crime were falling victim tonight to bitter partisan maneuvering, and both Republicans and Democrats said the prognosis for the program was grim.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE WON'T FEEL BOUND BY CONGRESS VETOES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  President Carter warned Congress today that his Administration would not consider itself legally bound by legislative vetoes of arms sales, Federal regulations, departmental spending and other executive actions.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 21A bill to exempt newspaper files and reporters notes from search and seizure in New Jersey was introduced in the State Legislature today.

title: Bonds sold By Columbia
description: Columbia University sold $30 million: of taxexempt bonds yesterday to finance a dormitory and a healthsciences center. The highgrade securities were priced to yield as much as 5 percent  the highest rate this year for topquality bonds exempt from Nevi York City, State and Federal income taxes.

title: Public Service Shares Sold
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, sold 3 million shares of common stock yesterday to a group of underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. at a price of $22.07 a share. The investment bankers then offered the stock for sale publicly at a price of $22,75 a share, 12 cents above the closing price in the secondary market. At $22.75, the stock yields 9.32 percent.

title: Herrin Jury Recalls Tortuous Path It Took Trying to Reach a Verdict
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 21Last Saturday night, on the third day of their deliberations, the jurors in the murder trial of Richard J. Herrin seemed deadlocked, with nine favoring a verdict of guilty of a reduced charge of manslaughter and three holding out for guilty of seconddegree murder as charged.

title: U.S.AGENCIES LAGGING IN WORK SAFEGUARDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Federal Government is failing to protect the safety and health of its own employees adequately and, as a result, the costs of worker sickness and injury are skyrocketing, according to internal Administration uocuments.

title: Fish Poisoning Tests Negative
description: BOSTON, June 21 (AP)Tests disclosed no evidence of paralytic shellfish poisoning, or red tide, in a bluefish found near 50 dead gulls and terns on a beach near Chatham last week, the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Quality Engineering said today. The gulls and terns had died after eating eels that had ingested plankton, causing the poisoning, according to environmental officials.

title: Large Group of Farmers Idling 20% of Their Land
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  More than half of the country's grain and cotton farmers, who together till threequarters of the normal crop acreage, indicated today they were idling more than 20 percent of their land this summer, a move that will helping to improve the nation's farm economy.

title: Maryland Bonds sold
description: Maryland, a tripleArated state that some analysts in the taxexempt bond market nevertheless believe has an unpromising future, sold $115 million of bonds yesterday that were priced to yield as much as 5.50 percent, highest for such securities this year.

title: Centronics Signs Pact
description: The Centronics Data Computer Corporation said it had signed a multimilliondollar cooperative agreement with Electronum, the Rumanian state enterprise for foreign trade, to supply that institution with Model 761 teleprinters over the next five years. Delivery of the initial production order of 750 units has already begun, following evaluation and acceptance of several printers, Centronics said.

title: Religious Movement Leader Dies
description: DALLAS, June 21 (AP)  The Rev. Howard Conatser, a leader in the worldwide neoPentacostal movement who openly defied Southern Baptist tradition in the early 1970's by announcing that he had experienced a baptism of fire, died Monday at the age of 52.

title: Carter Tells Latins at O.A.S. Conference That He Will Continue to Stress Human Rights in Foreign Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  President Carter told Latin American foreign ministers today that his Administration would continue to give strong emphasis to human rights in the conduct of foreign relations despite bitter criticism of the policy by some hemisphere governments.

title: Behind the Legislative Snag in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 21The 1978 Legislative session is sputtering toward an end this week in much the way it beganwith Senator Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, playing a pivotal but enigmatic role that is frustrating the hopes of Governor Carey and his Democratic allies in the Legislature.

title: The Me Movement
description: BALTIMOREWe got to relive the 1960's last week, a friend from Los Angeles told me the other day. All the liberals left in L.A. came to the Hollywood Bowl for Survival Sunday. According to my friend, the crowd was treated to a cavalcade of antiVietnam War superstars, including Eugene J. McCarthy, Daniel Ellsberg and Arlo Guthrie.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday introduced 14 unbranded food and nonfood productswhich it said were priced about 30 percent below national brands  in its fivestate Southeastern division and in its Baltimore division.

title: President Stresses Vance's Role As His Foreign Policy Spokesman
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  President Carter stressed to members of Congress last night that he was the chief spokesman on foreign affairs for his Administration and that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was the principal spokesman for him.

title: GasGuzzler Tam Issue Snarls Energy Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 President Carter's longdebated energy legislation ran into another roadblock today when House and Senate conferees failed to agree on provisions for cutting gasoline consumption.

title: JAYCEES RETAIN BAN ON WOMEN MEMBERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 21The United States Jaycees voted overwhelmingly today to continue excluding women from full membership in the organization, which is dominated by rural and smalltown businessmen.

title: Still Not Time To Quit
description: WASHINGTON  Israel's reply to American questions about the Begin plan for selfrule in the West Bank and Gaza, produced this week after long delay, was a damp negative. The Government rejected the one way of making the plan a real basis for negotiation  to see it as an interim step, opening the way for talks on a permanent solution.

title: Knicks, Rangers Raise Ticket Price
description: Madison Square Garden has raised the ticket prices for Knick and Ranger games next season. A letter from the Garden to seasonticket subscribers said  the increase was necessary to recover some of the increased costs and to continue to bring topcaliber sports to the fans.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Annie Get Your Gun on WQXR
description: Cast members of the Jones Beach Theater production of Annie Get Your Gun will perform in a twohour salute to that Irving Berlin musical to be broadcast live this morning over radio station WQXR. The special broadcast will be presented on The Listening Room at 10:A.M., by Robert Sherman, the station's program director.

title: Court Calls Import Duty Optional, Probably Averting a Price Spiral
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court today averted an increase in the prices Americans pay for Japanese electronic products that would almost certainly have affected many other imports and touched off an inflationary spiral.

title: Jaworski Takes a Dive
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Leon Jaworski, Certified Media Hero, came to the moment of truth in the Koreagate investigationand caved in.

title: U.S. Is Said to Offer A 40% Cut in Steel Tariffs
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The United States has offered to cut tariffs on steel by more than 90 percent and is making lamentable progress toward an international agreement that would try to deal with steel's trade problems, according to industry officials and the United Steelworkers of America.

title: 10 Envoys in South Africa Shunning The WhitesOnly Premiere of Golda
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 21 (Reuters)At least 10 Western ambassadors have refused to attend the premiere of the play GoIda, based on the life of Golda Meir, former Israeli Prime Minister, at a theater for whites only.

title: A Leader Chosen, U. of Chicago Sees More Choices Ahead
description: CHICAGOPerhaps the best testimonial to the University of Chicago is that it enrolls as undergraduates so many of tie children of the nation's college professors, making it a kind of college professors' college.

title: Expos and Rogers Register a 21 Triumph Over Mets in Game Curtailed by Rain
description: The Mets who still have some things to learn, were done in by the three R's last night at Shea Stadium: Runs (Montreal got 2 to the Mets' 1), Rogers (Steve, the Expos' pitcher) and a night full of rain, which shortened the game to 6 innings.

title: Standby Gas Ration Plan Due
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)The Energy Department is ready to send to Congress a new standby gasoline rationing plan with major changes from the proposals drafted under the Ford Administration, department sources said today.

title: Reflections on an Unphotogenic Childhood
description: PEOPLE say, I had a wonderful childhood or I had a disastrous childhood, but I know only that I had an unphotogenic childhood. This is my impression after spending the morning looking through an old family album of photographs of myself and my two sisters when we were children. I happened on the album by accident; whatever kind of childhood I had, I would not deliberately have gone back to look for it.

title: Advertising
description: AFTER retaining the mystical services of Lord, Geller, Federico, the Palm Beach Company, makers of men's clothing, made a second major move  it turned from its traditional form of promotion, coop advertising in print, to a national advertising program on television. And, surprisingly enough, there doesn't seem to be too much unhappiness in the market place.

title: Mayors Meeting: Uncertain Fiscal Future
description: ATLANTA, June 21Mayors these days must feel a little like General Custer when he learned that two expected columns of relief troops would not arrive at Little Big Horn.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, June 2l,1978

title: The Fine Art Of Paring Down
description: POSSESSIONS. They have us by the jugular. Books dusted and catalogued, jewelry insured, machines serviced, mortgages paid. The country house. Enhancement? Relaxation? Ha! The lawn mowed. The hedges clipped. New tires for the car. Repairs on the boat.

title: United Technologies
description: The power systems division of the United Technologies Corporation announced it had received more than $120 million in contracts from the Government of Saudi Arabia. Under the contracts, the division will supply all of the drive systems for the EastWest Petroline, a 750mile oil pipeline that will span Saudi Arabia from the Arabian Gulf to the Red Sea.

title: Murder Site Is Ruled No Exception To the Need for a Search Warrant
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the scene of a murder is no exception to the constitutional requirement that the police obtain a search warrant before conducting a nonemergency search.

title: Mark Robson, Film Director, Dies; Did Champion and Earthquake
description: Mark Robson, a film director whose works ranged from Champion and Home of the Brave to Peyton Place and Valley of the Dolls, died of a heart attack Tuesday in a London hospital. Mr. Robson, who was 64 years old, had collapsed 10 days earlier while completing his latest film, Avalanche Express, costarring Lee Marvin and Robert Shaw, on location in northern Italy. The Montrealborn director lived in Los Angeles.

title: Jazz: Wild Bill Davison
description: WILD BILL DAVISON, a charter member of the Eddie. Condon mob that played at Nick's and the original Eddie Condon's Club in the 1930's and 40's, is making his annual visit from his base in Copenhagen to the current Eddie Condon's, 144 West 54th Street. He is flaunting his age (72) and proclaiming in a voice that is as penetrating and positive as the brassy punches of his cornet that he is busier and playing better than when I was 20.

title: Carey Signs Bill to Let Lawyers Assist Clients Before Grand Jury
description: ALBANY, June 21Reversing an earlier position, Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a controversial bill permitting lawyers to appear with witnesses at certain grand jury proceedings.

title: Office Design: At Home With Quality
description: CHICAGO THE new designs exhibited at the 10th annual Neocon show, the largest display of contract, or office, furnishings in the country, proved once again that furniture designed for office or institutional use is often superior in design and craftsmanship to that produced for the home.

title: Indian Leader's Conviction Upheld
description: PIERRE, S.D., June 21 (AP)The South Dakota Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the 1975 riot conviction of Russell Means, the former American Indian Movement leader. Mr. Means was found guilty after a trial without jury of rioting to obstruct justice in connection with a disturbance at the Minnehaha County Courthouse in Sioux Falls on April 30, 1974.

title: PORT AUTHORITY PLAN ADVANCES IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 21Leaders of the New York State Senate and Assembly have reached agreement on a bill to allow the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to develop industrial parks in central cities ane??d to sell bonds to fina the projects, but two other measures designed to spur economic development are in trouble.

title: Red Brigades Kill Police Official in Genoa
description: ROME, June 21Gunmen belonging to the Red Brigades terrrorist organization shot and killed a senior police official in Genoa this morning.

title: Dtente on the Ropes
description: The most important thing to be said about Pray da's lengthy reply to President Carter's latest speech on SovietAmerican relations is that dtente lives; it is too deeply rooted in mutual selfinterest to be swept away by the winds of rhetoric  from either side.

title: Cosmos Defeat Caribous With 2 Late Goals, 31
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 21After a 61 victory over Washington last Sunday that left little doubt, the Cosmos gave 32,476 rainsoaked fans a bit more suspense tonight, breaking a 11 tie in the last six minutes of the game and defeating the Caribous of Colorado. 31.

title: U.S. APPROVES MERGER OF LTV WITH LYKES, CREATING STEEL GIANT
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell consented today to a controversial merger proposal that would forge two steel companiesJared & Laughlin and Youngstown Sheet and Tubeinto the thirdlargest steel propc4 er in the United States.

title: Caracas Rules In OilTax Case
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 21 (Reuters)  A ruling by Venezuela's income tax court has opened the way for claims of about $550 million against foreign oil companies that operated here up until December 1975.

title: DAYTON T. BROWN
description: Dayton T. Brown, chairman of the board of Dayton T. Brown Inc.. an engineering and sheetmetalfabrication concern on Long Island, died Tuesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 21 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace announced today that he would not run for either of the United States Senate seats from Alabama in this year's elections, but said he would remain politically active.

title: Iroquois Brands Sets Refinancing
description: Iroquois Brands Ltd. said that it had completed a $21.8 million refinancing, including the placement of a note with the Prudential Insurance Company of America and borrowings through a group of banks headed by the Irving Trust Company, to refinance the company's total debt including demand borrowings in connection with its recent acquisition of Archon Inc. Iroquois produces beverages, food and vitamins.

title: U.S. Payments Deficit Sets Record for Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  The United States balance of payments, an important indicator of the country's economic position in the world, was in deficit by a record $6.95 billion in the first three months of this year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Money Rates
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 21, 1978

title: Simon Pays Million For di Paolo Painting
description: LONDON, June 21Norton Simon, the 71yearold California multimillionaire, paid, almost $1 million today for a madonna by the 15thcentury Siennese painter Giovanni di Paolo.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The proposed merger of LTV and Lykes was approved by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, clearing the way for the largest consolidation in the history of the American steel industry. The union of Jones & Laughlin Steel, owned by LTV, with Youngstown Sheet and Tube, owned by Lykes, will create the nation's thirdlargest steel producer. Citing the failing company doctrine, the Attorney General said Youngstown Sheet would probably go out of business if not rescued in the takeover. [Page A1.]

title: Port Authority Plan For Industrial Sites Advances in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 21Leaders of the New York State Senate and Assembly have reached agreement on a bill to allow the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to develop industrial parks in central cities and to sell bonds to finance the projects, but two other measures designed to spur economic development are in trouble.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Koch Honors 6 Employees For Never Missing Work
description: In an age when some people say the work ethic has gone the way of chivalry, here was living proof to set the record straight: six city employees who have never missed a day of work in more than 20 years. Yesterday Mayor Koch held a breakfast in ttheir honor.

title: Plan to Raise the Interest Ceiling On Mortgages Loses Out in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 21A proposal to allow interest rates for home mortgages to rise is apparently dead for this legislative session, despite a massive lobbying effort by savings banks, realestate interests and contractors who argued that the state's limit had dried up the homemortgage market.

title: LIFE SENTENCES GIVEN IN PROVENZANO CASE
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., June 21 (UPI)An official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Anthony Provenzano, was sentenced today to life in prison for ordering the death of a union rival 17 years ago.

title: Southern Comfort: A Brumby
description: MARIETTA, G.A. FOR a hundred years. Southerners have prized the Brumby rocker as the ideal chair for sitting on the front porch, feeding babies, growing old and mashing the tails of sleepy cats.

title: In Support Of Marcos
description: PHOENIXEver since Commodore George Dewey defeated the Spanish fleet in Manila Bay, Americans have been telling the Filipinos how they should govern themselves.

title: Books of The Times
description: SO READS the epigraph of Saphia Burnham's new book, The Landed, Gentry, raid though it may nbt be immediately apparent what a warning to tattletales has to do with a dissection of America's propertied class, this epigraph represents What lends the book. its chief interest. an& tension. For, as the author quickly confesses, she is herself a member of the group she is about to anatomize; she belongs, as she puts it, to an Old Family of Decaying Means from Green Springs Valley, Maryland. And her origins, along with her ambivalence about anatrimizing them, are finally what focus the reader's attention.

title: Research Leaders Debate How to Raise Productivity
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Faced with a decline in the growth of American productivity that some regard as alarming and with a threatened loss of world technological leadership, research leaders have debeated here for two days on how to turn the tide.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 22, 1978

title: Yale Drama School Dropping Brustein
description: Yale University has decided not to renew the contract of Robert Brustein, dean of its drama school and director of its nationally acclaimed repertory theater.

title: Events Today
description: MATILDA, directed by Daniel Mann; starring Elliot Gould, Robert Mitchum and Clive Revill, at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Acadia Is First on Time In Bermuda Sail Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21Burt Keenan's Acadia, a dark blue yacht from New Orleans, won the Bermuda ocean race today, or at least half of it. The 51foot sloop had the best corrected time of the 90 yachts racing under the International Offshore Rule, and those 90 were the newest and fastest in the fleet of 162.

title: Design Notebook
description: THESE days, everyone seems concerned about interior design, and there is much talk about, how such and such a chair expresses this about its owner, how a particular color expresses that.

title: JOHN B. THOMSON
description: John B. Thomson, founder and president of Thomson Industries Inc. of Port Washington, L.I., died Tuesday at his home in Plandome, L.I., He was 61 year old.

title: Ellen Lurie, 47, a Rights Activist And School Integration Leader
description: Ellen Lurie, a civilrights activist in the 1950's and 1960's, an author and community organizer, died of cancer Tuesday night in Calvary Hospital. the Bronx. She was 47 years old and had lived for many years at 180 Cabrini Boulevard, in Washington Heights, before moving a year ago to Upper Greenwood Lake, N.J.

title: The Makings of Mulch
description: Just about any organic material can be used for mulch. Black plastic isn't included on the list, even though it is sold as mulch. It will retain moisture and reduce weeds, but those are only two of the benefits of true mulch. Just as important, if not more so. is the fact that mulching improves the soil quality by adding organic matter, and here black plastic scores zero. The most readilyavailable mulches for the home gardener usually include the following:

title: Backgammon:
description: DALLAS The International Backgammon Association sponsored the annual Metropolitan Backgammon Open, held in Dallas June 811. Although most participants were from the New York metropolitan area, first place went to David Groner of Indiana. Dave Milton was runnerup, with Jim Pascoe and Cathy Posner as semifinalists. Roberto Hof fman took the consolation flight, and Avi Samuels won the lastchance competition. The winning doubles team was Fernando Arce and Adrian Scotto.

title: 5 Housing Officials in Lodi Indicted
description: NEWARK, June 21 (UPI)The executive director and four other present and former Lodi Housing Authority executives were lindicted today on charges of extorting more than $137,000 from contractors and suppliers doing work on public projects.

title: Red Sox Rout Yankees, 92, Under Steinbrenner Scrutiny
description: BOSTON, June 21George Steinbrenner, agitated owner of the Yankees, saw his first road game of the season in person tonight, arriving after a couple of days of tarpon fishing in Florida. What he saw, along with a crowd of 32,312, might prompt him to go fishing for some new pitchers, if not a new manager.

title: American Aide Is Sent to Angola
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The United States began a new effort to improve relations with Angola. today by sending a senior member of its delegation to the United Nations, Donald F. McHenry, to confer with the Marxist Government of President Agostinho Neto.

title: For Newcombe, Time Appears To Run Out
description: LONDON, June 21The mustache still is unmistakably bushy, stamped on his shirts and painted on the strings of his metal racquet as a commercial reminder. But the shots coming off John Newcombe's racquet today also were a reminder that time might have run out cn his hopes for a fourth Wimbledon singles title.

title: Expos Beat Mets, 21
description: The Expos beat the Mets, 21, at Shea Stadium last night in a game delayed three times by rain and finally curtailed in the seventh inning. Details, page B9.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Incacates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Relative ofSlepaks Gets Word at Wailing Wall.
description: JERUSALEM, June 21Genrietta Orlovsky unsteadily observed her fourth day of an outdoor hunger strike today near the Wailing Wall in east Jerusalem. A handlettered sign pinned to her makeshift tent pleaded: Save the Slepak familymy sister Mariya, her husband Vladimir and their son Leonidfrom a Soviet prison.

title: Ali the Ambassador Returns Home With Positive Impressions of Russia
description: Looking and sounding more like an ambassador than a prizefighter, Muhammad Ali made the reentry from the Kremlin to the Big Apple yesterday without missing a syllable.

title: Carey Signs Bill to Let Lawyers Assist Clients Before Grand Jury
description: ALBANY, June 21  Reversing an earlier position, Governor. CareY announced today that he had signed a controversial bill permitting lawyers to appear with witnesses at certain grand jury proceedings.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My dining room floor, which was installed in 1950, is covered with black and white 12inch square tiles that are either rubber or asphalt. The tiles are worn and the colors bleed into each other when the floor is washed. It is now in need of a sealer or finish of some hind. Can it be sealed with a clear, high gloss acrylic or urethane, and if not how should it be treated? G.R.S., New York City.

title: Cup Final: Argentina AndDutch
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21Argentina routed Peru tonight, 60, thereby qualifying for Sunday's final of the World Cup soccer championship and touching off one of the biggest and most colorful celebrations the country has ever seen.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve, making a muchanticipated move, implicitly tightened monetary policy yesterday as it engineered a quarterpoint rise in the Federal funds rate  the basic rate of the shortterm money market.

title: Conflict Over Fees Keeps Barges Waiting
description: ABOARD THE BAXTER SOUTHERN, on the Mississippi near St LouisCapt. Claude Sexton is used to waiting.

title: Poll in Quebec Indicates That Independence Party Would Lose in Voting Now
description: MONTREAL, June 21The hopes of federal opponents of Quebec independence have been raised by the results of a poll that the Canadian Broadcasting System released last night.

title: Home Beat
description: WHEN the browneyed Welsh lady appeared on the stairs, she wasn't wearing a Laura Ashley. She was wearing a Chlo. Which, in view of the fact that the lady was Laura Ashley herself, was interesting  although not in the least disappointing.

title: Sons of Former Mafia Leader Ordered to Return to Prison
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (AP)Two sons of a former Mafia leader, Joseph Bonanno, must return to prison for violating probation terms of 1972 conspiracy and extortion sentences, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 22, 1978

title: 9 Police Officers Silent on Death Of Businessman in Crown Heights
description: Nine of 15 police officers who were at the scene last week when Arthur Miller, a 35yearold black businessman, was fatally injured in a struggle with policemen in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, have refused to talk with Police Department investigators, according to Assistant Chief William R. Bracey, the commander of Brooklyn North.

title: Dow's June Gains Erode As Stocks Drop 5th Day
description: Stock prices fell back across a wide front yesterday in response to the dollar's weakness in foreigncurrency dealings and signs that the Federal Reserve was tightening credit another notch.

title: Hearst Corporation Elevates Bennack To Its Presidency
description: Frank A. Bennack Jr. has been named to succeed John R. Miller as president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corporation, one of the nation's largest news companies. The 45yearold executive will assume the post next January.

title: U.S. APPROVES MERGER OF LTV WITH LYKES, CREATING STEEL GIANT
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell consented today to a controversial merger proposal that would forge two steel companiesJones & Laughlin and Youngstown Sheet and Tubeinto the thirdlargest steel producer in the United States.

title: Nazi March in Skokie Still in Doubt
description: SKOKIE, III., June 21The status of a march by Chicago's National Socialist Party of America through the suburban village of Skokie, which has been scheduled to take place this Sunday, remained in doubt today as village officials and organizers of a counterdemonstration awaited word on whether the small neoNazi group would carry out its threat to march.

title: Unfinished Business in Albany
description: Politics are more interesting than government Albany in June of an election year. Accordingly, important legislative action may be overlooked while Governor Carey and the Republicancontrolled Senate spar over the supplemental budget that Mr. Carey has proposed. Mr. Carey wants to take credit for June generosity to go with his January tax cuts while the Republicans hope to take credit for keeping the budget trimmed without looking meanspirited.

title: BreakIn Memos Allegedly Missing
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  A memorandum that could show that President Nixon authorized illegal breakins against leftwing terrorist groups is missing from Government files, according to a former official of the Federal Burealu of Investigaticn who is accuesd of authorizing such breakins.

title: YONKERS TURNS DOWN A LOAN FROM STATE
description: Saying that they wanted a direct state grant, members of the Yonkers City Council voted Tuesday night to reject a $10 million state loan designed to avert layoffs of 300 city employees and a 13 percent tax increase in the city's upcoming budget.

New York producers eyed it with interest, and it may yet come here if the Royal Shakespeare Company cast can ever be spared to bring it over.

title: Court Calls Import Duty Optional, Probably Averting a Price Spiral
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court today averted an increase in the prices Americans pay for Japanese electronic products that would almost certainly have affected many other imports and touched off an inflationary spiral.

description: Palm Hut scored another runaway victory yesterday, winning the 80th running of the $37,275 Fashion Stakes for 2yearold fillies by seven lengths at Belmont Park.

description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Carter Administration has decided to seek a formal proposal from Egypt on the future of the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip as a possible way of reviving the stalled Middle East Peace talks, officials said today.

description: Automated Building Components Inc. of Miami, said it had tentatively agreed to be acquired by Redland Ltd. of Reigate, England, for about $27 million in cash.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE storm over the multinational corporations and their dealings with politicians has not yet blown over. Last week, President Giovanni Leone of Italy resigned after months of allegations his involvement in the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's bribery scandal in Italy. Mr. Leone, insisting that he had always behaved as an honest man, said a defamatory campaign had undermined confidence in him.

title: Notes on People
description: YESTERDAY was the 15th anniversary of the election of Pope Paul VI, and the 80yearold Pontiff told his weekly audience that his life was fleeing and nearly ended. An official celebration of the anniversary will be held June 29. the feast day of St. Peter, but Pope Paul used the occasion of yesterday's audience to call once more for a ban on nuclear weapons. We are menaced by enormous and terrible destruction, he told about 10,000 people in St. Peter's Square. If someone goes crazy and he is the head of a nation which has these arms. what will happen to humanity? The Pope's coronation took place on June 30, 1963.

title: Witness Describes Finding Curare in Exhumed Body
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 21  A toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he had found evidence of the drug curare each time in repeated tests of various tissues from the body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: It Hurts Me, Billy Martin Said
description: BOSTON, June 21With the powers, principalities and archangels of the Yankee hierarchy looking on, Billy Martin managed his brainy head off tonight but he couldn't do the pitching for Jim Beattie, Dick Tidrow or Catfish Hunter Before a Boston batter was retired in the third inning Beattie, a reformed roundball player from Dartmouth, was shelled for five runs. Before the inning ended Butch Hobson smote a tworun homer off Tidrow. Before the game ended, Hunter pitched for the first time since coming off the dis abled list and was rocked for successive home runs by Fred Lynn and George Scott besides giving up a single, double and base on balls. When the First Great Confrontation of 1978 ended. the Yankees were eight games behind the Red Sox.

title: Giants 3, Reds 0
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (UPI)Ed Halicki outdueled Tom Seaver before 37,334 fans and Roger Metzger doubled in two runs tonight as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 30.

title: Harriman Reassures Third World on Arms Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21W. Averell Harriman, calling on his more than 30 years as an American diplomatic negotiator, appealed to impatient third world countries today to have confidence in the pledges of Washington that it will reach agreements with Moscow curbing the nuclear arms race.

title: Summer Arrives
description: At exactly 2:10 P.M. yesterday, the sun reached its northernmost point and summerwhich has been here in an informal way, on and off, for weeksarrived formally. The temperature in Central Park at that moment, according to the National Weather Service, was 72 degrees Fahrenheit. The sun rose at 4:25 A.M. and set at 7:31 P.M., making the day the longest of the year. From now until the sun reaches its southernmost pointthe first day of winterdays will get shorter and nights longer, although both are more than likely to get hotter before they get colder.

title: Soldiers Ambush and Kill 3 Men Trying to Plant Bombs in Belfast
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, June 21Three members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army were shot to death early today by British soldiers disguised as civilians. The I.R.A. members were trying to plant bombs at a postal depot in Belfast. Two passersby were also shot, one fatally.

title: Miller Asks Tighter Rein On Foreign Banks in U.S.
description: Mr. Miller told a Senate banking subcommittee that the legislation it was considering, which has already been passed by the House, should be strengthened.

title: Theater: Wings By the Yale Rep
description: WORDS are the legs of the mind; they bear it about, carry it from point to point, bed it down at night, and keep it off the ground and out of marsh and mists. Arthur Kopit's Wingsis a remarkable attempt to dramatize the agony of a stroke victim. It presents mind whose language has been knocked out from under it; one that struggles blindly, with alternating grace and terror, to regain its footing.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21The Union of Arab Journalists condemned President Anwar elSadat today for his moves to purge the Egyptian press of his critics, and the organization said that it had decided to move its headquarters from Cairo to Baghdad.

description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 3.3 million shares to 39.6 million shares in the monthended June 15. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 29.6 million shares.

title: Barely Beautiful: The Minimal Look
description: JOSEPH D'Urso takes himself very seriously. He is a designer and an intellectual, not, he is quick to point out, a decorator. An associate professor of design at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, Mr. D'Urso is a firm supporter of the current belief that minimal design, through simplification and order, can solve the spatial problems and restrictions of contemporary dwellings. He believes that if our homes are not cluttered, our minds will not be either. Freed from the crutch of what he calls tasteful objects, we will be more able to express ourselves.

description: WASHINGTON, June 21  President Carter warned Congress today that his Administration would not consider itself legally bound by legislative vetoes of arms sales, Federal regulations, departmental spending and other executive actions.

title: Woman, 18, Slain in Jersey May Have Known Killer
description: CRANFORD, N.J., June 21The police speculated today that an 18yearold high school senior who was raped and fatally bludgeoned late Monday night or early yesterday morning may have known her assailant.

description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today that he and other Democratic House leaders would support reducing aid to South Korea because it continues to refuse to allow testimony by a former Ambassador suspected of giving cash payoffs to Congressmen.

Snepp 3d, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, had deliberately and wrongfully violated a secrecy agreement with the agency by publishing a book about the fall of Saigon without first submitting it to the C.I.A. for review.

title: Manhattan Dentist Is Convicted in SexualAbuse Case
description: A Manhattan dentist was convicted in State Supreme Court yesterday of sexually abusing two of his women patients after sedating them.

title: A Market For Your Possessions
description: SEVERAL years ago, my wife and I went around our Cambridge, Mass., apartment putting price tags on nearly everything we owned. For we were about to travel in Europe and would need money, not furniture.

title: Disks: Blues Classics Reissued
description: UNITED and States records were two pioneer blackowned record labels. Founded by Leonard Allen, a tailor and retired policeman, and based in Chicago, United and States recorded blues, jazz, and gospel music in the early and middle 1950's and were responsible for some undisputed classics, especially in the blues field. But, for years now, these recordings have been available only among collectors and on an occasional bootleg album.

title: RealEstate Developer in Bronx Under Criticism by Miss Bellamy
description: A South Bronx realestate developer took advantage of city and Federal regulations to reap windfall profits of up to 1,000 percent, the New York City Council President, Carol Bellamy, charged yesterday while he and his associates owed the city $1 million in back taxes.

title: Carter Urges Job Aid for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON. June 21 (UPI)Presi!dent Carter today proposed allowing most veterans a onetime preferential hiring advantage in seeking civil service jobs within 15 years of their discharge.

title: Hers
description: DISHWASHING is not interesting either to do or to think about, but thinking has dignified other mundane things. At least it will postpone the dishwashing, which stupefies. After eating, I look at the dishes in the sink and on the counters, the cat's dirty bowl and saucer underfoot. swipe at the dabs and smears recognizable from several meals ago, pick up a cup from among the many on chairs and beside beds, and think about suicide. Also about what to write in the suicide note.

title: Film: Boxer With Pouch:'Roo in the Ring
description: "MATILDA," which opens today at Radio City Music Hall, is a comedy about a male kangaroo named Matilda who is the chief contender for the heavyweight boxing championship of the world.The cast is headed by Elliott Gould, as the vaudeville promoter who gives Matilda his start; Clive Revill, as a former British flyweight boxer who owns Matilda and loves him like a son, and Robert Mitchum, as a sports columnist who manipulates the news he covers and, at the end, becomes the managing editor of the New York Post.According to the film's production notes, the role of Matilda is played both by a kangaoo named Whammo and by someone named Gary Morgan in a kangaroo suit that reportedly cost $30,000 but fits as if it had been ordered by seamail from Hong Kong. Matilda looks like the neighborhood practical joker on his way to a costume party, so I assume that it's Mr. Morgan we see on the screen most of the time.Paul Gallico wrote the novel on which Albert S. Ruddy and Timothy Galfas based their screenplay, which was directed by Daniel Mann with a total lack of spontaneity and with the groveling desire to please you might associate with a door-to-door salesman.The movie is chock-a-block with un-comic jokes and facetious inspirations, including Lionel Stander as a short-tempered boxing promoter, and several scenes showing two inept Mafia "soldiers" trying to kidnap Matilda and then to cut off his tail. Harry Guardino, a good actor, plays the Mafia chief with no great charm.Mr. Mitchum sort of lazes his way through the movie, knowing that he's bigger than it is. Mr. Gould seems to want to disassociate himself from the picture by watching the other actors as if astonished by the fools they are making of themselves. He's right, of course, but since he's in the movie, he looks a bit foolish, too. Mr. Revill, another able actor, plays Matilda's owner in a manner that recalls David Wayne's leprechaun period, which may not be something that all of us want to recall at this very minute."Matilda" is a movie that's in even worse shape than the Music Hall. It's future is decidedly iffy.

title: Ballet: Ritmicas, Oedipus by Cubans
description: II would have been easy for the National Ballet of Cuba to confine its season at the Metropolitan Opera House to a few triedandtrue classical favorites. Instead the company has adopted the more adventurous policy of presenting both old favorites and totally unfamiliar new ballets by Cuban choreographers and composers. By showing such works to the world, the Cuban dancers can proudly demonstrate how specifically Cuban their company is.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST home garages hold a lot more than the family automobile  they are used to store an assortment of yard and garden tools, outdoor furniture. power mowers, snowthrowers, bicycles, toys and various other items. In many cases, the bulkiest and most frequently used objects are the most inaccessible  stored in that extra space in front of the automobile, SO that the car must be pulled out of the garage in order to get to a particular piece of equipment. The other option is to squeeze past the car and drag what's needed out along the side; assuming, of course, that the thing will fit through that narrow space.

title: GARDENING
description: AFTER a rather cool, dry spring, vegetables are now well on their way. The peas are flowering, tomatoes are at least the size of marbles on early varieties such as Ultra Girl, radishes and lettuce have already graced the salad bowls.

description: The staff of the Emergency Financial Control Board said yesterday that New York City's budget for next year might still be out of balance, and it recommended that the city be asked to say how it would make up a deficit if there was one.

Amoco received rights to drill six wells in the lake, the first to a depth of about 10,000 feet, at an estimated cost of $5.5 million. Results of the first drilling will determine whether more wells will be drilled in the area.

title: $139 a Week For Family of 5

title: Screen: Simon's 'Cheap' Detective':Everybody Revisited
description: IN 1853, 12 Albanian fishermen conquered China, Mongolia and Tibetone souvenir of that extraordinary moment of history being a set of diamond eggs, each the size and shape of a Grade A, extralarge, brown chicken egg. In pursuit of this prize, more, than a dozen persons converge on San Francisco in 1939 to cross and double-cross one another in "The Cheap Detective," Neil Simon's funny, affectionate recollection of "The Maltese Falcon," with substantial references to "Casablanca" and more than a passing interest in "The Big Sleep."From that description you might suspect either that "The Cheap Detective" takes in more territory than can easily be evoked by one picture or that it's very thin material to sustain an entire feature-length film. Either way you may be right. "The Cheap Detective," which was directed by Robert Moore and produced by Ray Stark (Mr. Simon's collaborators on "Murder by Death"), belongs to a very special subcategory of motion picture comedy whose rules, which have the tensile strength of hot fudge, are what you want to make them.Like Mel Brooks's "High Anxiety," which was a fond overview of the career of Alfred Hitchcock, "The Cheap Detective" is not the parody of ridicule that is most readily appreciated, but a cheerful remembrance of old movies that are as substantial today as they ever were. From time to time, "The Cheap Detective" seizes and wickedly shakes a remembered moment of outrageous foolishness or sentimentality, but, mostly, watching it is like being with a group of friends as they recall their favorite moviegoing experiences. It's not as a movie that it's so much fun, but as a multimillion-dollar, all-star parlor game.Starting with Peter Falk, who gives a fine, feature-length, utterly straight-faced imitation of Humphrey Bogart as a Frisco private-eye named Lou Peckinpaugh, most of the players are superbly funny. They Include Ingrid Bergman in "Casablanca" (described by her husband as "a brave, beautiful, extremely boring woman"); Marsha Mason as the Gladys George character from "The Maltese Falcon," perhaps the only woman in San Francisco who knows how to find an all-night dress shop specializing in widow's weeds; Madeline Kahn as the mysterious Mary Astor character, also from "The Maltese Falcon," and John Houseman (wearing something that is less a suit than a special effect), Dom DeLuise and Paul Williams, as, respectively, characters who would once have been played by Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre and Elisha Cook Jr.Then, too, there are Nicol Williamson, as the Nazi colonel whose mission is to prevent the Free French patriot (Fernando Lamas) from opening a French restaurant in Oakland; Sid Caesar (in a fright-wig) and Ann-Margret (in virtually nothing) as mysterious Rumanians; James Coco as a cafe Impresario, and Stockard Channing as Lou Peckinpaugh's ever-faithful though never-to-be unfulfilled Girl Friday.Phil Silvers is also in the movie but he's on and off the screen so quickly that I don't really remember him. The one place where the recollections go awry is in the casting of Eileen Brennan as the Lauren Bacall figure. Miss Brennan is an able comedienne but next to the original she is small, limited. She never once recalls the amalgam of larger-than-life sexuality, intelligence, self-mockery, and class that was (and is) the unique Bacall screen presence."The Cheap Detective," which opens today at the Coronet, Little Carnegie and other theaters, is more difficult to review than to talk over, as one might last night's dinner party. One wants to ignore the lapses in taste and wit as well as the lack of coherence. No particular comic point is made by setting the film in 1939, which is a year before there ever was a Free French movement, and though the movie tries very hard to reproduce the "studio" look of the 40's, that look is over-whelmed by vivid color photography.More Important, though, are the inspirationslarge and smallthat do work beautifully, such as Lou Peckinpaugh's undershirt, to which is still attached every laundry marker it ever knew. I also admire Mr. Simon's variations on 1940's movie dialogue, whether snappy (reports a detective to his superior, "We got four bodies, three as cold as yesterday's toast and one ready to pop up") or solemn ("Paul is an obstinate man. Even with a bullet in his head, his mind is made up"). And, there is no way seriously to object to a movie that has as one of its principal locations a seedy hotel called the Crusaders, which, on its first floor, houses the St. John the Divine Bar."The Cheap Detective," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language. The film's violence is in the nature of slapstick comedy.

The biggest defeat, however, is for workers who want the freedom to bargain collectively. The Wagner Act promised that right 43 years ago; for many, the promise remains unfulfilled.

title: The Old Scout Who Found Guidry
description: The old scout is nearly 68 years old now. Atley Donald does some hunting and fishing around Downsville, La., but he's retired from the cattle business and from scouting. Had openheart surgery three years ago, he drawled over the telephone. Bobby Brown did it for me. Old ballplayers stick together. Atley Donald once pitched for the New York Yankees and Dr. Bobby Brown once was their third baseman while going through medical school in the offseasons. But every fifth day now Atley Donald's heart skips a beat when Ron Guidry pitenes. Atley Donald found, recommended and signed Ron Guidry for the Yankees when the slender lefthander was firing his fastball for the University of Southwestern Louisiana seven years ago. Atley Donald knows a fastball when he sees one. Back in 1939 his fastball was timed at 94.7 miles per hour, faster than Bob Feller's that night. That same season Atley Donald opened with 12 consecutive victories, as Tom Zachary had in 1929, to share the Yankee record that Ron Guidry equaled last night against the Detroit Tigers with ninthinning help from Rich Gbssage.

Baker, fiscal agent, told a meeting of creditors of the Commonwealth Oil Refiriing Company in San Antonio yesterday that the company's unaudited net earnings for May were $l.7 million, or 10 cents a share, after an extraordinary credit of $378,000, or 2 cents a share. He said the comnanv's revenues in May amounted to $97.5 million. The company has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since March.

title: Notes on People
description: A jury in Glenwood Springs, Colo., found Frank Tucker, the chief prosecutor in the homicide trial of Claudine Longet, the Frenchborn actress, guilty of two counts of felony embezzlement. As a result, Mr. Tucker said, he would resign very soon. Mr. Tucker, cleared of two other charges was found guilty of using public funds for telephone calls to a young woman in California and of doublebilling Rio and Garfield counties for expenses incurred while attending a convention in Colorado Springs in the company of the woman, Debbie McGuern. The prosecutor came to national attention last year in the trial of Miss Longet, who served a 30day sentence on her conviction of criminally negligent homicide in the death by shooting of Vladimir (Spider Savich, a ski instructor.

title: New Face: Max Wright
description: ACONVERSATION with Max Wright is rather like an imagined encounter with Lewis Carroll's White Rabbit. Not that Mr. Wright resembles that harebrained character from Wonderland in any special way, but the slight, bespectacled actor does convey a mildly jumpy sense of being perpetually late for some very important date. Mr. Wright speaks rapidly, perhaps because his mind seems to jump from thought to thought like a hungry flea at a dog show.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Yale carries on another of its many long traditions this weekend. The summer chamber music series in Norfolk, which began 70 years ago, opens a new season tonight at 8:30. The concert, in the Music Shed on the beautiful grounds of the Ellen Bette11 Stoeckel Estate, will include music by Telemann, Beethoven, Jan Neruda and Richard Wernick, winner of the Pulitzer Prize last year. The musicians come from the faculty of Yale's music school. Joining them will be the cellist Sadao Harada of the Tokyo String Quartet, which is in residence at Norfolk and plans to give two concerts of its own in July. Tickets are $3 to $6; call (203) 5425537 for reservations. From New York, take the Taconic State Parkway to U.S. 44; turn right and continue to Norfolk.

title: Large Blues Continue to Run Off Jersey and Block Island
description: AREA A The fishing for blues is still super, according to Captain Andy's Marina in Margate, N.J., where fishermen have been returning arm weary  with catches averaging 10 pounds. Most of the strikes have been in the 25mile stretch from the Avon Shoals to the Atlantic City Ridge in 60 to 65 feet of water. Bluefishing is also reported excellent at Barnegat Ridge, the Mudhole, Tolton Lump and Manasquan Ridge. And there have been catches of smaller blues, in the 2-to-4pound range, in the inlets around Margate and up to two miles off Great Egg Harbor Inlet. Best results have been achieved just before dark, at high water, by fishermen casting into schools or trolling with small lures. Striped bass in the 50pound range are being taken regularly around the Margate, Longport nad Ocean City bridges with live eels or live herring, generally in the early morning hours on the high tide. Flounder fishing has fallen off, but there are still a few of the fish in the warmer waters of the backbays.

title: At The Movies
description: WHO would guess, seeing Stockard Chanruing as the tough, promiscuous girl gang leader in Grease ,or as Peter Falk's frustrated secretary in The Cheap Detective, which opens today at the Coronet, the Little Carnegie and other local theaters, that she was reared not merely on the right side of the tracks, but right over them, on Park Avenue and 85th Street? Or, for that matter,,that she was educated at three citadels of gentilitythe Chapin School on East End Avenue and the Madeira School near McLean, Va., and at that Parnassus of female intellectuality, Radcliffe? Or that if it weren't for a strain of rebellious Irish blood, which is reflected in her bluegray eyes and her tilted nose, she might well be playing golf in Greenwich, Conn., and drawling complacencies instead of associating with mimes and mummers, the sort of people that one simply can't place?

title: Broadway

I guess I'll go to see `Gorey Stories when it opens, he says. But then again, maybe I won't. I'll probably be in such snit, I won't want to see it. Mr. Gorey is an original.

title: City College Lives
description: The good old days of City College for many New Yorkers were when City was known as the Harvard the Proletariat  when its graduates, mainly the sons of poor Jewish immigrant families, went on to earn more doctorates than the graduates of any.other college in the country. But in the 131 years since its found- ing as the Free Academy, the college has served an everchanging city. And in assessing its performance today, The Times's education editor, Edward Fiske, has assembled evidence that City still lives up to its traditional mission of making higher education a path out of poverty for firstgeneration college students.

title: About New York
description: Every week Bernard Brown gees back in time to crash his cares against a flat gray wall. He leaves his good address on the East Side and drives his Cadillac Fleetwood up to a small city park in a humble part of the Bronx where there remains a gift from his boyhooda passion for handball that he describes as narcotic and beatific in his 54th year as it was in his 15th.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 23, 1978

title: Albany Senate, Defying Carey, Recesses Indefinitely
description: ALBANY, Saturday, June 24The Democratic - led Assembly failed this morning to pass a key portion of Governor Carey's crime package and made a raucous exit, hours after the Republicancontrolled Senate defied Mr. Carey by recessing without acting on Democratic proposals on crime, economic development and the budget.

title: United Press International
description: GUN BATTLE IN TIJUANA PRISON: Under cover of a guard, two children are taken from the courtyard of Mexico's Baja California Penitentiary yesterday as people who had been visiting prisoners when gunfight between guards and some armed prisoners broke out He on the ground to be searched by authorities. Eight persons, including the warden, his deputy, three guards and three prisoners were killed in the fiveminute gunfight.

title: WARM SAYS TALKS ON ARMS SHOW GAINS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22The chief disarmament negotiator for the United States insisted here today that significant progress was being made in wideranging arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: Sports Today
description: NASCAR Charlotte 600, at Cliarlott Motor Speedway, Charlotte, N.C. (TelevisionChannel 2. 5 P.M.)

title: Deaths
description: SCHIFFJacob Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of NY, saddly records the passing of the beloved father of Dr Alvin I. Schiff, Executive Vice President of our member agency, Board of Jewish Education. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to all. In the bereaved family.

title: Daughter, 20, Gets Provenzano's Post
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., June 23 (UPI)The 20-year-old daughter of the convicted killer Anthony Provenzano took over her father's duties today as secretarytreasurer of Local 560 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Court Aids Inmates on Legal Fees
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The major vehicle for financing public interest lawsuitsa legal cornerstone of the civil rights movementsurvived an important test today when the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that the state of Arkansas can be required to pay the attorneys fees of a group of prisoners who had successfully sued the state on the ground that the conditions of their imprisonment were unennstitutinnal.

title: Five Killed in Plane Crash
description: LIMERICK, Pa. June 23 (UPI)Five persons died in the crash of a twinengine aircraft shortly after takeoff from the PottstownLimerick Airport, the authorities said today. The victims, all from Pennsylvania, were identified as the pilot, Joseph Anthony Colantonio, 34 years old, of West Chester; William +P. Ryan, 28, of West Chester, and his wife, Lorraine, 23; David Saul Rossen, 30, of Philadelphia, and Anthony Joseph Brazzillo, 29, also of Philadelphia.

title: HMO International Agrees to INA Tie
description: HMO International; which operates 19 health care centers in southern California, said that it had signed a definitive agreement for merger of the company into the health care management group of the INA Corporation, a large diversified finanical institution.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a book review in Weekend yesterday, the full title, publisher and price of Helene Hears Apple of My Eye was inadvertently omitted. The publisher is Doubleday; the price is $8.95.

title: Daughter, 20, Gets Provenzano's Post
description: FECAUCUS, June 23 (UPI)The 20-year-old daughter of convicted killer Anthony Provenzano took over her father's duties today as secretarytreasurer of Local 560 of the international Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: U.S. Keeps OnionPatch Trophy
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23Although beaten on points in the Bermuda race by the British trio, the United States yachting team retained the Onion Patch Trophy today in the biennial international series sailed in conjunction with the 635mile ocean race from Newport, R.I.

title: Problem Growing, U.S. Says
description: A jet airliner carrying 103 people, and a twin-jet corporate plane with two men aboard came within about five feet of colliding at high speed on a La Guardia Airport runway Wednesday night alter two traffic controllers radioed conflicting instructions, Federal investigators said yesterday.

title: Fannie Mae Plans Sale
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday that it would sell $1.2 billion worth of debentures next Wednesday to raise money tofinance:its operations in the mortgage market.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last weep.

title: Briton, in London Meet, Runs 10,000 in 27:30.5
description: LONDON, June 23 (UPI)Brendan Foster, a Briton, captured the 10,000meter run at a meet here tonight in 27 minutes 30.5 seconds. Only Henry Rono of Kenya, who set the world record of 27:22.5 in Vienna 10 days ar!o has run the distance faster.

title: U.S. Women's Five Loses Opener of Chinese Tour
description: TOKYO, June 23 (AP)A United States women's basketball team lost to the Chinese national team, 9867, yesterday in the opening game of goodwill tour in China, Peking's Hsinhua press agency reported.

title: Hearing on Passman Continued
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)Federa District Judge Barrington Parker today continued until Monday a hearing tc determine if former Representative Ottc Passman, Democrat of Louisiana, is capable of standing trial on bribery and in come tax charges.

title: California Leaders Act to Postpone TaxCut Impact
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23In a decision that could postpone the full impact of Proposition 13 for another year, California legislators agreed today to distribute most of the state's $5 billionplus surplus to schools and local government in the fiscal year beeinnine July 1.

title: U.S. Discussing Nuclear Curbs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 23 Proposals for comprehensive multinational control of the nuclear power industry, including the construction and ownership of uranium enrichment plants, nuclear safeguard agreements and inspection of facilities, took a tentative step forward yesterday in talks between senior American and Australian officials.

title: Red Brigades Trial Ends in Italy; 29 Given Sentences, 16 Cleared
description: TURIN, Italy, June 23Twentynine members of the Red Brigades terrorist organization were sentenced to up to 15 years in. prison today after a trial .lasting 15 weeks.

title: L.I. Man Acquitted in Stabbing Of Fellow Cadet During Hazing
description: James Savino, who was accused of fatally stabbing a fellow R.O.T.C. cadet during illegal hazing rites, was found not guilty of murder yesterday by a jury on Long Island.

title: CLAUDE E. MONLUX
description: Claude E. Morlux who retired in 1959 as vice president of the Linde Division of the Union Carbide Corporation, 270 Park Avenue, died last Sunday in Boynton Beach, Fla., where he had been living since 1971. He was 83 years old.

title: Quebec Sets Rules That Would Govern Independence Vote
description: MONTREAL, June 23The Quebec government pushed through the assembly this morning a bitterly contested bill that provides the legal machinery for holding a referendum on independence for the province.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: New York Terminating Contracts With 5 Antipoverty Organizations
description: The contracts of five New York City antipoverty agencies, including the giant BedfordStuyvesant Youth in Action, will not be renewed on July 1, Haskell G. Ward, the Community Development Commissioner, announced last night.

title: Copyright by the Lawrence Eagle Tribune
description: ELUSIVE MANEUVER: Carl D. Bogen, wanted for an alleged assault and an alleged rape, escaped from the grasp of a Lawrence, Mass., police officer who had cor- nered him on the roof of a two story building. Mr. Bogen then jumped from the roof and was pursued until he was wounded by police fire and apprehended yesterday.

description: Joe Torre gave us a little pep talk before the game, Lenny Randle, the third l:aseman, was saying, tracing the strange events of last night in Shea Stadium We've been flat lately. I've played for Billy Martin and Ted Williams, and heard them. But Torre a modernday linute Rockne. He's gocd St. John's-before-the-basketballgame speaker,

title: WIRETAP EXTENSION IS SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, June 23Governor Byrne signed a fiveyear extension of the state's Wiretap law today, saying it would provide an indispensable tool for investigators of organized crime in New Jersey.

title: How Afghans Fit Into Soviet Global Strategy
description: The establishment of a powerful Soviet military and political influence in Afghanistan is regarded by experienced analysts as more valuable strategically to Moscow than any of the Kremlin's gains in Africa.

title: Bhutto's Fate
description: OXFORD, EnglandIn the Supreme Court of Pakistan, the last legal battle is now being fought over the life of the country's former Prime Minister, Zulfikar All Bhutto. It is an unequal battle in which justice has been overshadowed by power. As an old ? or Mr. Bhutto I am personally concerned for his life. But there may well be grave political consequences too. His death could lead to the end of Pakistan and a further defeat for the West.

title: GermanAmericans Grow Uneasy
description: CHICAGO, June 23The increasing interest in Holocaust studies in schools and the notoriety attached to recent neoNazi activities have aroused a growing uneasiness in GermanAmerican communities throughout the country.

title: Yugoslavia's Reds, Ending Congress, Streamline Party
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23In apparent preparation for smoothing the transition into the postTito era, Yugoslavia's Communist Party cut the membership of its executive body today from 48 to 24

title: Hundreds Attend the Funeral for Slain Cranford Girl
description: GARWOOD, June 23Hundreds of mourning teenagers crowded into St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church today for the funeral mass of Michelle DeMarzo, the 18-year-old Cranford High School senior who was murdered Monday night.

title: Wheeling Steel Lifts Prices in 3% Range
description: PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP)  The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation today followed other steelmakers in raising prices of mill products, and Dennis Carney, the chairman, criticized the Government for trying to inFluencesteel steel pricing.

title: U.S. RECALLS ENVOY TO CHILE IN PROTEST ON LETELIER INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The United States recalled its Ambassador to Chile today in a rebuke to that country's military Government, which, it said, had not, cooperated satisfactorily in the investigation of the 1976 assassination in Washington of a former Chilean diplomat and Cabinet minister.

title: MAYOR OF CLEVELAND DROPS RECALL FIGHT
description: CLEVELAND, June 23Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich today abandoned his legal efforts to block a recall election aimed at removing him from office and vowed instead to go to the voters to save his job.

title: Associated Press
description: EARTHQUAKE TOLL RISES IN GREECE: A child sleeping on the ground in a camp set up in a park in Salonika. The discovery of more bodies yesterday put the number of dead from Tuesday's earthquake at 45.

description: Summertime and the viewin is easyif not alt of it, some of it, and CBSTV is adiustine to season.

title: TWO HASIDIM ACCUSED OF BEATING BLACK, 16
description: Two tiasiclic Jews, both British subjects, were arraigned yesterday on charges of attempted murder in the beating of a black Crown Heights youth who remained in critical condition. Both pleaded not guilty and were released on bail.

title: FIGURE IN U.S. INQUIRY RESIGNS KOREAN POST
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 23Kim Dong Jo, the top South Korean Government official whose testimony has long been sought by investigators of the House ethics committee in Washington, has abruptly resigned from his post as national security adviser to President Park Chung Hee. President Park officially accepted the resignation this afternoon.

title: Red Sox. Topple Palmer and Orioles, 52
description: BOSTON, June 23 (AP)Carlton Fisk drilled a threerun homer in the first inning and the Boston Red Sox went on to snap Jim Palmer's sevengame winning streak tonight with a 52 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON A. widely known metallurgist, professor of engineering at Purdue University, in West Lafayette, Ind., has developed a new method of producing lowsulfur fuel gas from highsulfur coal. Rheinhardt Schuh- mann Jr. was granted patent 4,095,960 this week for the apparatus and method.

title: Sarah Lawrence Arts Center Presents Intimate Don Giovanni
description: Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence, the impressive series of cuttural events at the college in Bronxville, N.Y., has included several performances of Mozart's Don Giovanni, which will come to an end tonight. They are he- ing given in the Studio Theater of the Performing Arts Center, a 175seat theater. Aphrt from the exceptional intelligence that informed every aspect of the production, it was seeing a masterpiece in such intimate surroundings that was particularly rewarding to the viewer.

title: Your Money
description: Richard Phalon

title: MOZAMBIQUE ACCUSES RHODESIA OF ATTACKS
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, June 23 (Reuters)Mozambique said tonight that Rhodesian troops had killed 17 refugees from Rhodesia and 2 Belgians in an attack on its western border area last night.

title: High Court Bars New Jersey Law Against Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The Supreme Court ruled today that New Jersey could not prevent neighboring states from dumping their waste inside its borders.

title: Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of todai's Newport Jazz Festival events:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MINIFEST The mammoth 52d Street fair has come and gone, but the residents of the Clinton area believe their gala today, from noon to midnight, should also be rewarding on a smaller scale. Blockassociation festivities will cover West 48th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues, The event features arts and crafts exhibitions, food, drinks and a flea market, plus sports demonstrations, a flamenco show from Spain and two orchestras for street dancing, along with games and prizes.

title: Cecil F. Holland, a Reporter, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Cecil Fletcher Holland, a wellknown Washington reporter, died yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital of an aortic aneurysm. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Welcomes South Korean Bid For Cooperation With the North
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (Return)The 23 (Reuters)The Llnited States welcomed today the call ;bil President Park Chung Hee of South Korea for greater economic cooperation bdtween North and South Korea.

title: Boeing Awaits British Talks
description: American aviation experts said yesterday that the talks that Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain will have with officials of the United States aerospace industry in Washington this weekend would be critical to the future of the Boeing Company's planned 757 commercial aircraft proiect.

title: How the PropertyTax Base Affects 2 L.I. School Systems
description: LEVITTOWN; L.I.  When School Superintendent Robert Neidich guided a visitor around the Wisdom Lane School recently, the guest was warned to step gingerly.

title: Car Sales Set MidJune Record
description: DETROIT, June 23  The four domestic automobile manufacturers today reported record sales for the middle 10 days of June, with deliveries running 11.8 percent ahead of the 1977 pace.

title: U.S. Delays Sales Made To Libyans
description: The Carter Administration is holding up saleS to Libya of about $400 million in trucks, aircraft and spare parts in an effort to discourage that country from harboring international terrorists.

title: Vance Proposes Talks With Israeli and Egyptian
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has proposed a meeting with the Egyptian and Israeli Foreign Ministers in Europe next month to revive the stalled Middle East negotiations, officials said today.

title: Associated Press
description: FLOWERS AND TEARS FOR SLAIN FRIEND: Classmates of Michelle DeMarzo placing flowers on her coffin yesterday before burial at St. Gertrude's Cemetery in Colonia, N.J. The Cranford, N.J., high school senior was murdered Monday night. A former boyfriend was charged In crime.

title: 15 Seized in Drug Raid at Kings Park in South Jamaica
description: To the astonishment of several dozen sun lovers and children, 30 police officers swept into Kings Park in South Jamaica, Queens, yesterday and arrested 15 suspected drug dealers and addicts who, the police said, have made the park an area of concentrated drug trafficking.

title: Problem Growing, U.S. Says
description: A jet airliner carrying 103 people, and a twinjet corporate plane with two men aboard came within about five feet of colliding at high speed on a La Guardia Airport runway Wednesday night alter two traffic controllers radioed conflicting instructions, Federal investigators said yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALBANY, June 23By a vote of 127 to 16, the State Assembly approved a measure tonight intended to spur the thoroughbred racing industry in New York State. The bill, passed by the Senate last night by 4113, now goes to Governor Carey, who is expected to sign it.

title: A Salute to Jazz Women
description: During the next month, New York will see an unaccustomed emphasis placed on women in jazz: a fourevening Salute to Women in Jazz starting Monday at Casa Blanca 2, Broadway at 52d Street; another Salute to Women in Jazz for four days the following week, starting July 3, in the Atrium of the Market at Citicorp Center, 54th Street at Lexington Avenue, from 6 to 8 P.M.; and a fiveweek series called Great Women in Jazz at Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street, beginning next Tuesday with Helen Forrest, who will be there for two weeks, followed by Anita O'Day, Maxine Sullivan and Helen Humes.

title: Arthur D. Little Lifts Dividend to 33 Cents
description: Directors of Arthur D. Little Inc., the research and consulting concern, raised the semiannual dividend to 33 cents a share from 30 cents, payable July 19 to holders of record July 5. The board alSo voted a 3-to-2 stock split, payable Aug. 18 to shareholders of record July 20.

title: Casino Issues Pace Trading
description: Speculative interest in casinorelated stocks reached fever proportions yesterday, while the general market moved lower amid fears of rising interest rates.

title: Japan Showing New SelfConfidence in Talks With China:
description: TOKYO, June 23The Japanese decision to press on with talks on concluding a peace treaty with China in the teeth of Soviet opposition indicates a growing selfconfidence in this country, long regarded as too timid to have a foreign policy of its own.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, June 23 (AP)With just the weekend left to decide on whether she wants a new divorce trial, Remigia Brooke reportedly has a new offer to consider: her former husband's willingness to sell his house in the French West Indies and turn the proceeds over to her.

title: SteppedUp Tax on Oil Swells Alaska's Coffers
description: ANCHORAGE  Alaska, which at times has viewed its oil boom as something of a mixed blessing, is beginning to reap some extraordinary financial benefits.

title: Two Good Samaritans
description: A 29-year-old factory worker from Rahway, N. J., was fatally stabbed early yesterday when, according to the police, he interceded to stop two motorcyclists from harassing three Women in Washington Square.

title: BRAZIL'S CHIEF PROPOSES POLITICAL LIBERALIZATION
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23 (AP)President Ernesto Geisel proposed a series of reforms today that he said would fulfill his promise to give up dictatorial powers and bring Brazil closer to democracy.

title: Harpooned Shark Pulls Fishing Boat 14 Hours Off L.I.
description: MONTAUK, L.I., June 23A huge white shark won a 13hour battle with a fishing boat after being harpooned this morning, dragging the boat all day and then escapingwith three harpoons still in itwhen the line snapped, according to the boat's captain.

title: Unveilings
description: SEROTOFF-An unveiling In memory of Isaac Serotoff will be held at New Monteflore Cemetery, Plnelawn, L.I., on June 25 at 12:30 p.m., at Section 4, Block 17, Row 15.

title: $3 Billion Credit Set For Canada
description: A. group of 90 banks in the United States, Europe and Japan agreed yesterday to lend Canada $3 billion. The transaction was described by Citicorp, which organized the bank syndicate, as the largest private international credit ever extended.

title: Artist Losing Her Window on the World
description: Isabel Bishop stands trained against the eastern light coming through the window of the fourthfloor studio in which she has drawn, etched and painted for 44 years. Through it she can see the old colonnaded Union Square bandstand, a view she will miss.
