description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Motets for the King's Chapel, Henry du Mont; Songs and Ayres, Dowland; Farewell, unkind, farewell, Dowland.

title: IC Nears Agreement With Pet
description: IC Industries, the big Chicago railroad holding company, cleared the way yesterday for what could be a $500 million takeover of both Pet Inc. and Hardee's Food Systems. Pet is a leading foods company and Hardee's is a leading fastfoods chain.

title: UpjohnPortugal Tie
description: The Upjohn Company said yesterday that the Council of Ministers of the Portuguese Government had authorized the investment of up to $50 million in a proposed joint venture involving Upjohn. Upjohn, an ethical drug and chemical manufacturer, said the proposed 5050 venture between itself and Quimigal, a Portuguese Governmentowned chemical concern, would build a polymeric isocyanates plant at Estarreja, Portugal. Polymeric isocyanates, made from petrochemical feed.; stocks, are used in producing urethane, widely used in industrial and consumer products. Upjohn declined to disclose its proposed investment or the expected total cost of the chemical plant.

title: Cutting Federal Waste
description: WASHINGTONThe Department of Health, Education and Welfare's Inspector General, Thomas D. Morris, testified before a House Appropriations subcommittee April 11 that waste, fraud, abuse and mismanagement in the department has cost the taxpayers $6.3 to $7.9 billion.

title: BYRNE IS SEEKING TAX ON DUMPING IN STATE
description: TRENTON, June 23Governor Byrne said today that he would recommend to the State Legislature that a tax be imposed on out-of-state garbage dumped in New Jersey.

title: A Yale Feast, a Nibble
description: The other day I graduated from Yale with a B.A. in English. I am now, officially, a college graduate, a member of the company of educated men and women.

title: Services Set for Reporter
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 23 (AP)A private funeral mass for Felix Belair Jr. of Alexandria will be held tomorrow at St. Mary's Catholic Church. Mr. Belair, a former correspondent for The New York Times, died Wednesday at Winchester Memorial Hospital.

title: Insurers
description: ALBANY, June 23  In an unusual effort to recapture a lost portion of the insurance business for New York State, the Assembly tonight passed and sent to Governor Carey a bill that would create a freetrade zone to exempt large and unusual insurance contracts from state taxes and regulation, and to establish a reinsurance exchange in New York State.

title: Letter: On Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPLOSIONS LEVEL PLANT IN CALIFORNIA, 5 HURT
description: AZUSA, Calif., June 23 (UPI)An hour long series of explosions leveled a chemical plant and rocked a wide area of Southern California tonight. At least five persons were injured but it was not known how seriously.

title: Consumer Notes MortgageRate Ceiling Is Raised To Help Home Buyers Get Cash
description: The State Banking Commissioner, Angelo R. Bianchi, said yesterday that the ceiling on mortgage rates had been raised to 9.5 percent from 9 percent, effectively immediately.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A retired assistant New York City realestate commissioner, Harry Stern, was sentenced yesterday to two months in jail and fined $16,000 for evading income taxes of $23,120 on more than $56,000 he received as interest from 1971 to 1975.

title: Graham Has a Deficit; May Curb Radio and TV
description: MINNEAPOLIS. June 23  The Billy Graham Evangelistic Association and five affiliate organizations recorded a combined deficit of $3.2 million last year, they disclosed today. As a result, associates of the evangelist at his world headquarters here are studying possible cutbacks in the operation.

title: Books of The Times Maverick of the Opera
description: Frank Corsaro has directed more than 70 opera productions, including some 25 for the New York City Opera. He has selected a dozen of thege to discuss in some detail in this book, ranging from such generally acknowledged successes as his La Traviata and PeIleas et Melisande to his infamous Don Giovanni, which Mr. Corsaro deals with in a chapter called The Night tt:e Roof Fell In.

title: Mantle Improved, Off Critical List
description: DALLAS, June 23 (AP)Mickey Mantle said he was feeling pretty good today after having been taken off the critical list suffering from bleeding ulcers

title: An Ire Fed by Fabricated Foods
description: There's nothing synthetic or artificial about Beatrice Trum Hunter. She's a naturalborn reformer. And at 60, calm, quiet eyes and a casual country manner belie the anger and alarm that her books convey.

title: Korf Financing Of $25 Million Set
description: Korf Industries, a steel producer, said that arrangements for a $25 million financing program had been completed. The financing package includes a longterm loan supported by a guarantee of the Economic Development Administration of the United States Department of Commerce and new capital.

title: Nicaragua Leader, in U.S., Plans To Meet With Human Rights Group
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 23 (UPI)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua has promised to meet with representatives of the human rights group Amnesty International tomorrow.

title: The HandWriting on the Hospital Wall
description: New York City already has 5,000 more hospital beds than it needs and the surplus is increasing as the population declines and hospital stays grow shorter. Painfully but inevitably, some hospitals must be closed and others must have their services curtailed. State health officials have now embarked on a plan to do just that, starting in Brooklyn. Despite a faulty start, it is creditable example of how to practice the politics of the 70's, the politics of less.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Friday, June 23, 1978

title: Goody Takeover Set
description: The American Can Company disclosed the completion of the acquisition of Sam Goody Inc., the New Yorkbased operator of home entertainment stores, in a transaction involving approximately 125,000 shares of American Can common stock. Goody, which becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of American Can, will operate as part of Pickwick International Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of American Can. Under the agreement, shareholders of Goody will receive 0.1811 of a share of American Can common stock for each share of common stock of Goody, which operates 28 retail outlets.

title: Convicted Driver Commits Suicide
description: PRINEVILLE, Ore., June 23 (UPI)Albert Stacey, 17. years old, was found guilty of careless driving and fined $27 yesterday morning. Moments later he walked out to his car and fatally shot himself. He was convicted in a nonjury trial before Justice of the Peace Vern Boyer.

title: Associated Press
description: ALBANY, Saturday, June 24The Democratic - led Assembly failed this morning to pass a key portion of Governor Carey's crime package and made raucous exit, hours after the Republicancontrolled Senate defied Mr. Carey by recessing without acting on Democratic proposals on crime, economic development and the budget.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 23Two young Brazilians completed a rara double here this afternoon by winning the World Open Pair Championship two years after [snatching the World Team Olympiad Title away from Italy. The double victory in teams and pairs has not been achieved since 1962.

title: Billy Graham a Best Seller, Too
description: One of the world's bestselling authors shuns fourletter words and never deals in trendy themes. Even after he became a financially successful author, he decided against a career in writing because he thought he lacked intellectual depth. Nevertheless, his books nave sold more than 12 million copies, including several million in hardback, and earned him millions of dollars in royalties.

title: A 1769 Table Draws $396,000 At Sotheby's
description: LONDON, June 23Today was supposed to he the off day in the recordsmashing von Hirsch auction, but it produced one of the highest prices ever paid for a piece of furniture.

title: Concerto Barocco
description: The New York City Ballet's seasons at the Wew York State Theater are so long, its dancers are so familiar to ardent ballet fans and these fans, in turn, are so loyal to the dancers that the company has become a kind of family for many balletgoers. Thus it was not surprising that Thursday night's program was notable both for several debuts and for the announcement of a lost dog.

title: Robin Donovan Bride Of Joseph T. Harper
description: Robin Donovan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Donovan of Ridgewood, N.J., was married in the Joseph Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago yesterday to Joseph Timothy Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Harper of Shorewood, Wis. The Rev. Robert Oldershaw performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 24, 1978

title: 2,000 Acres Burned in California
description: HEMET, Calif., June 23 (UPI)Southern California's first major brush fire of the year has destroyed 2,000 acres of vegetation. The fire, which at one time threatened a rural community, was 90 percent contained late last night. Qne firefighter was treated at. Hemet Hospital for heat exhaustion and returned to the fire. Another suffered second and thirddegree burns. The cause of the blaze is under investigation.

title: Legislature Laying Groundwork For CasinoGambling Referendum
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23The Legislature today laid the groundwork for a referendum in which voters could asked, as soon as November 1979, whether they want casino gambling legalized in the state.

title: Cubans Dance in Alba and Carmen
description: THE HOUSE OF BERNARDA ALBA, based on the WRY by Federico Garcia Lorca. Choreography, Ivan Tenorio; music, Sergio Fernandez Barroso; scenery and costumes, Salvador Fernandez.

title: Occidental Seeks Canadian Approval
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that it was seeking Canadian Government approval before proceeding with a $530 million takeover bid for Husky Oil Ltd.

title: U.S. RECALLS ENVOY TO CHILE IN PROTEST ON LETELIER INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The United States recalled its Ambassador to Chile today in a rebtike to that country's military Government, which, it said, had not cooperated satisfactorily in the investigation of the 1976 assassination in. Washington of a former Chilean diplomat and Cabinet minister.

title: Newport News Ship Is Laying Off 1,000
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 23 (AP)  Newport News Shipbuilding, troubled by productivity problems and a steadily dwindling backlog of work, said today that it was laying off 1,000 of its 25,000 employees.

title: Albany Is Hopeful on July Passage Of New York ConventionSite Bill
description: ALBANY, June 23Negotiators working on a bill to provide financing for the proposed $257 million New York City convention center said today that the legislation stood a good chance of passage in a special session in July, even though the Legislature has not acted on the measure during its regular session.

title: Notes on People
description: Howard Dietz, the songwriter, playwright and former newspaper reporter, motion picture publicity agent and executive, is in Mount Sinai Hospital with a hip injury and is expected to surgery. A spokesman for the hospital said yesterday that details on how the 81-year-old Mr. Dietz was injured were not available, and members of the family could not be reached. Mr. Dietz collaborated with some of the great composers and writers of show business, including Jerome Kern and George S. Kaufman. With his partner, Arthur Schwartz, he wrote dozens of popular songs, among them That's Entertainment! Dancing in the Dark, I Guess I'll Have to Change My Plan, Alone Together and Something to Remember You By. For many years he handled public relations and advertising for Metro-GoldwynMayer Pictures.

title: Fillol Is Man of Hour In Argentine Hearts
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 23If there is one man chiefly responsible for Argentina's reaching the World Cup soccer final for the first time in 48 years, it is Uboldo (Pato) Fillol, the 27-year-old goalkeeper who did not allow a goal in the three secondround victories by the Argentines.

title: USE OF PROPERTY TAX TO FINANCE SCHOOLS VOIDED IN NEW YORK
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 23A State Supreine Court justice ruled here today that the present method of financing public edUcation through the property taN was unconstitutional because it discrimi. nated agaillst children in poor districts and thus violated the State Constitution's equal-protection clause.

title: Dance Turns Durham Into One Big Festival
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 23The yellow handbills, featuring a strutting drum major, announced what was going on to amazed strollers: Durham Welcomes the American Dance Festival With a Parade Down Main Street.

title: L.I. Man Acquitted in Stabbing Of Fellow Cadet During Hazing
description: James Savino, wnd was accused of fatally stabbing a fellow R.O.T.C. cadet during illegal hazing rites, was found not guilty of murder yesterday by a jury on Long Island.

title: TALKING BUSINESS Airline Changes: A Leader's View
description: Richard J. Ferris, the 41-year-old president and chief executive officer of United Airlines, is one of the new breed of airline chiefs who have strong marketing backgrounds  an ascendancy reflecting the strong competition in the industry.

title: Soviet Union and Turkey Sign Nonaggression, Trade and Cultural Pacts
description: MOSCOW, June 23Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey and Soviet officials signed an accord today pledging that they would not use force against any country or allow other nations to use their territory for aggressive and subversive actions against other states,

description: Dave Anderson

title: Low Copper PriceHard Times in Zambia
description: KITWE, Zambia, June 18Along with its sister community of Ndola, 40 miles away, Kitwe is a oneindustry town in a oneindustry country. And Kitwe, like that industrycopper mininghas come on hard times.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 24, 1978

title: Mobil Unit to Buy Land In Reston, Va.
description: The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the Mobil Land Development Corporation, had decided to exercise its option to purchase approximately 3,500 acres of undeveloped land in Reston, Va. The company will buy the land for an undisclosed amount from Gulf Reston Inc., a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Two Good Samaritans
description: A 29-year-old factory worker from Rahway, N. J., was fatally stabbed early yesterday when, according to the police, he interceded to stop two motorcyclists from harassing three women in Washington Square.

title: DEFENSE CHALLENGES CURARE TESTIMONY
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 23Challenging the state's chief toxicologist, the defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought today to show that the drug curare could not have survived for the decade that the bodies of the alleged victims were buried.

title: Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON June 23Congressional investigators believe that the trustees of the $1.4 billion Teamsters Central States Pension Fund dismissed the fund's actuaries earlier this year because the actuaries had told the trustees that large increases in contributions would be needed to keep the fund sound.

title: Beach Wear, Tennis Togs And Some Holder Wizardry
description: Dancer. Choreographer. Painter. Director. Geoffrey Holder has been them all. Now he has his eyes on still another discipline: dress desiener.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Retreats Broadly
description: The dollar resumed its chronic slippage against other major currencies in foreign exchange trading in Japan, Europe and New York yesterday, ending Thursday's oneday rally, according to The Associated Press.

title: Studying Government Role in Family
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  When A. Sidney Johnson's mother took sick recently, he wanted to care for her at home. But since Medicare will pay for a nursing facility and not for homebased care, it would have been more expensive to keep his mother in her own house, surrounded by her own family.

title: Western Oil Offer
description: The Western Oil Shale Corporation said that a group of Oklahoma City in vestors had bought 657,000, or about 46 percent, of its common shares, through atender offer at $2 a share. The com- pany said that the group had bought 618,000 of the shares from the Texas American Oil Corporation and the rest from the public. Western Oil said the investors planned to investigate possibilities for developing its 76,000 acres of oil shale leases in Utah and to expand operations into the conventional oil and gas business.

title: Fed Directive Suggests Tighter Stand on Credit
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, the 12 governors and regional reserve bank presidents who set monetary policy, all but confirmed yesterday that it decided to tighten credit conditions earlier this week.

title: Miss Lopez Lags as Miss Blalock's 67 Leads by Two
description: HERSHEY, Pa., June 23 (AP)Jane Bialock carded a five-under-par 67. today. breaking the women's course record at the Hershey Country Club and taking a twostroke lead after the first round of the $50,000 Lady Keystone open golf tournament.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, June 23 (Reuters)Vietnam assailed China today for what it called procrastination over departure arrangements for ethnic Chinese there, and said that three Vietnamese ports were ready to handle the departing Chinese.

title: Sun a Stellar Attraction For NewYork's Elderly
description: For the elderly people of New York City's boroughs, summer is the time to enjoy their neighborhoods by going outdoors, playing pinochle and majjongg, chatting with friends or simply sitting on a bench, all the while soaking in the soothing summer sun.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a book review in Weekend yesterday, the full title, publisher and price of Helene Hanff's Apple of My Eye was inadvertently omitted. The publisher is Doubleday: the price is $8.95.

title: A. P. Quarter Loss Placed at $9.9 Million
description: DETROTT, June 23  The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company today reported a $9.9 million loss for its first fiscal quarter ended May 27 and voted to omit its quarterly 5-cents-per-share dividend.

title: Jane Thomas Young Wed to David Acton
description: The marriage of Jane Thomas Young of Haverford, Pa., widow of Ronald J. Young, to David Acton of Wayne, Pa., took place yesterday in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder nerformed the ceremony.

title: 2,000 Protesters Drown Out Nazis at Chicago Rally

description: Kerri Beaumont Hubbard, daughter of Mrs. Leonard R. Sargent of Corwin Springs, Mont., and Thomas B. Hubbard of New York, was married yesterday to Walter Henry Hart. The cere- mony was performed in the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N. Y., by the Rev. Theodore P. Fritsch. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart of Perrysburg, Ohio.

Presbyterian Church to Michael Doyle Sikorski of Reno, a Pan Am pilot. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick F. Jenkins, pastor of the church. He was assisted by Msgr. James J. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest.

description: AS the Rockefeller Foundation's director for the arts, Howard Klein supervises the annual distribution of about $3 million. In the 1960's, he spent five years as a music critic for The New York Times. He has a wife and two children, a house in Setauket and a cozy Manhattan apartment.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY factors can contribute to paint peeling on the outside of a house. Using the wrong kind of paint for a particular surface, improper preparation of these surfaces, failure to follow directions as to application or thinning, or even a heavy buildup of too many layers of old paint are among some of the common causes.

description: Two environmental regulations with industry impact emanated from Washington last week, one aimed at protecting the health of cottonmill workers, the other designed to keep toxic wastes out of city sewer systems.

description: TUPELO, Miss., June 24 (UPI)The Justice Department is investigating police activity and Ku Klux Klan conduct in Tupelo, the scene of five months of racial trouble, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

description: ART

title: Poor Countries Helped With Books
description: One of the great nonprofit ventures in international publishing, Franklin Book Programs Inc., is closing up shop at the end of this week for a very good reason. It has completed its mis- sion of translating cultural and educational works and of helping a dozen developing countries get their own publishing houses off the ground.

title: Judith Ryan Married To Charles F. Reusch
description: Judith Seraphim Ryan, a psychologist at Prince George's School in Bowie, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to Charles Frederick Reusch, an attorney with the Department of Energy. The Rev. Thomas C. Nagle performed the ceremony in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Britain Ties Aid to Reforms
description: PARIS, June 24 (Reuters),Britain's Foreign Secretary says that the West should not prop up corrupt African regimes, adding that Zaire is at typical example of a country where major structural reforms are necessary.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 25, 1978

title: California Researchers Report They Have Identified a Bacterium Linked to Crib Deaths
description: A team of researchers in California say they have identified an unusual form of botulinum poisoning as one cause of sudden, otherwise unexplained infant deaths.

title: The Nation
description: It is usually unwise to predict how judge will rule, but in the suit against Frank W. Snepp 3d there is little doubt that the Government is about to win the right to seal the lips of Federal family members, even as they leave home. Unless an appeals court later says otherwise, a ruling expected this week will make it easier to enforce secrecy oaths as a legitimate feature of Government contracts with employees in sensitive jobs.

title: Earthquake Recorded in Hawaii
description: HILO, Hawaii, June 24 (UPI)A sharp earthquake shook the entire island of Hawaii yesterday but caused no damage or injuries. The Hawaiian Volcano Observatory said the quake registered 4.5 on the Richter scale and occurred at 1:48 A.M.

title: MUSICSummer Music:A Delightful Debut

Since the ambiance of the tree- skirted Venetian [neater remains unique and the music all seemed chosen for its gracious lilt, it turned out to be a lovely first night after all.

Re- hearsing recently for Annie Get Your Gun, which will open on Thursday, the Cast had just had its first encounter with the outdoor theater's competing stars  the elements.

title: GARDENING A Time to Show, a Time to Sow Again
description: SO FAR this season, the weather in the area has been ideal for growing vegetables  just enough rain in between some good hot spells to push along the corn, beans and leafy crops. Radishes. scal- lions and peas are just finishing. Tomatoes are a bit slow in getting started, but never mind  they will have the rest of the hot months of July and August to mature.

title: The Scots Low Road
description: EDINBURGHScotland has Just passed through two miserable weeks. The national football (soccer) team, swollen in the popular imagination to an army of invincibles, went down to instant defeat in the World Cup competition in Argentina. And Scotland, shamed far beyond the implications of a mere encounter at sport, turned it upon herself for a bout of selfhatred and selfpersecution.

title: Express 3. Hurricane
description: HOUSTON, Rine 24 (AP)  Alan Brazil headed a perfect pass from Steve Earle 44 seconds into overtime to wore his second goal of the gam= and lift the Detroit Express to a 32 N.S.A.L. victory over the Houston tonight.

title: Huskies
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 24The winds blew fiercely and unfavorably today on the Nottinghamshire International Regatta,. causing a twohour delay in the racing schedule for the first of two days of competition. The 2,000meter Holme Pierrepont rowing course, site of Nottingham's 1975 world championships, has a reputation for bad racing conditions, but today's weather made previous years water look like a mill pond.

title: Police Surveillance in Birmingham Once Extended to a Vice President
description: BIRMINGHAM, June 20The Birmingham police department's program of surveillance of civil rights leaders in the 1960's was later broadened to include politicians, and at one point even touched Vice President Hubert, H. Humphrey, according to a cache of city documents recently discovered here.

description: JUNE 15,1977 SITTING here with nothin to do, so thought I'd drape some lines you about my master plan, effective when The Man unlocks this can. (Smile  hope ya like my poetry.)

title: Status or Comfort?
description: What do. Jerry Lewis, John Wayne, and Reggie Jackson have in common, other than fame and money? They are all constant customers of Gucci, according to the store's publicity staff, and fans of the slipon loafer that, more than any other item, carried the company to fortune.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: FULL DISCLOSURE, by William Safire. (Ballantine, $2.50.) Sven Ericson, 41st President of the United States, is blinded in a helicopter crash during a visit to the Soviet Union, and in Washington the power struggle grows more furious than ever. This veteran of the hardcover bestseller lists, the first novel of a columnist for The New York Times, is remarkable for its sharply etched characters and for the author's familiarity with the ins and outs of the White House.

title: Viva! Viva! Brings Back Leggy Showgirls
description: Back in the golden days women who anced in nightclubs and entranced the Patrons in a frank display of thighs and size were called showgirls. Who would have dreamed that that nightclub art. in New York anyway just about gone the way of the whooping crane, would have found one of its last nesting places atop Rockefeller Center?

title: Familiar Evidence
description: SHORTLY after getting into Lionel Davidson's Murder Games, which is described on the book jacket merely as a novel, there comes a nagging feeling of familiarity that is reinforced as one goes along. What? What? And then it hits home.

title: Martha Dillon and Hilton Stothers Jr., Lawyers, Married in Pocantico Hills
description: In the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Martha Langford Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Dillon of Chappaqua, N.Y., became the bride of Hilton Hadley Stothers Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Stothers of New York and Point O'Woods, L.I.

title: Philadelphia Fire Kills Man
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UPI)One man was killed and a woman was critically burned today in a one:alarm fire in a twostory row house in North Philadelphia. Willie Sanders, 32 years old, was pronounced dead on arrival at Medical College of Pennsylvania Hospital of smoke inhalation. Doris Humphries, 32, was reported in critical condition with burns on her chest and arms. Fire officials said that the blaze broke out shortly after 3 A.M. and was believed to have been caused by a cigarette thrown into a trash can.

title: At Home: Send in the Troubadors
description: WHAT we need out here in the country is a revival of the wayfarer. We need minstrels, peddlers, beggars, pardoners, vagabonds and knights. Scribes, tinkers, troubadours, charlatans, gleemen and jongleurs. As J.J. Jusserand says in his classic English Wayfaring Life in the Middle Ages, such men are the microbes of society, carrying the germ of ,human contact from one isolated soul to another.

title: London's Times Square
description: LONDON  Piccadilly Circus is thought by nostalgic Londoners to be the hub, albeit a rather seedy one these days, of the universe. Like Times Square, it attracts millions of out-of-towners .every year. Unless they're on their way to a play, most Londoners avoid it as determinedly as New Yorkers avoid Times Square.

title: Shrubs That Grow In Scale Can Make A House a Home
description: RA any of the homes constructed after World War II were landscaped with largegrowing evergreens Norway spruce, arborvi taes and pines. Builders were comply- ing with F.H.A. requirements and planted inexpensive fastmaturing trees. Left untended and untamed, these plants now cover the homes engulfing the facades in a dense forest of foliage that cuts out light and air. It's high time to bring these landscape plantings up-to-date and replace the overgrown forests with proper landscape specimens with builtin size control.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: TWENTYTWO years ago, when I was 9, men like Duke Snider, Gil Hodges, Carl Furillo and Don Newcombe were the only truly important people in my life. Of course, they didn't know me. but one day they would. I would become one of the great baseball players of my time, and they would admire me, just as I admired them.

title: Nancy F. Watkins, Engaged to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Watkins of Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Fairbank Watkins, to Robert Gordon Harrigan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank E. Harrigan Jr. of Manchester, Vt.

title: Shows and Events

The jazz picnic starts at noon and continues until 10 P.M. The New Jersey Jazz Society will sell tickets at the door.

title: Printing at SUNY: A Past Recaptured
description: T0 nine out of 10 people, the phrase the printed word suggests words  in books, newspapers, magazines that are interesting primarily for their meaning. How the words get on the pagethe mechanics of ink, paper and the transfer of images generally concerns only a handful of specialists. How these me- :.anics have changed over the years concerns an even smaller group.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLYConverzzzzation at a Dinner Table
description: DINNER parties in lower Westchester, once a joy to the palate and a catalyst in intellectual stimulation, are getting to be a bore. That remark is likely to result in my being blackballed from future invitations and having to rely on out-of-county parties to eat, but it's time to be firm.

description: Susan Jacquelline Stover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hawkins Stover of Cannes, France, formerly of Mamaroneck, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Stephen Laurence Hill, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lyndon Hill of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Last Week's Vote Sharply Divided Israel's Cabinet
description: CAIRO  The noncommittal response of the Israeli Cabinet last week.to'American questions aimed at getting the Egyptian,Israeli peaCe negotiations moving again were a public demonStration of the emerging strains in Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government. The turbulence was chiefly evi- dent around a man who is no stranger, to controversy and who seems at this juncture to be steering for headon collision with Mr. Begin: Ezer Weizman.

title: Dorothy A. Osborne Becomes the Bride Of William J. Cox 3d
description: Dorothy Allison Osborne and William James Cox 3d were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Osborne Jr. in Sandy Hook, Conn. by the Rev. Parkham D. Howe Jr. an Episcopal priest of Laconia, N.H.

title: P. L. O. Said to Reap Gains From Israeli Push Into Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23The shifting fortunes and morale of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which were in decline early this year, appear to have improved in the three months since Israel invaded southern Lebanon with the avowed aim of uprooting the guerrillas.

title: NEV YORK TEACHERS ACCEPT 2YEAR PACT
description: The United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education .reached agreement yesterday on a twoyear contract after two days of round-the-clock negotiations.

title: THE MARKETS Skepticism Takes Its Toll
description: The stock market continued to give ground last week. It was hit by both rising interest rates and rising skepticism  and by new postWorld War II lows for the dollar against the Japanese yen in foreign-exchange dealings. As a result, the popular stock averages sank and so did the broad list of common stocks.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. PROPOSES JAIL CONDITION GUIDELINFs
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)The Justice Department has proposed voluntary guidelines to improve conditions and security in prisons and jails.

title: And Word Power in Washington Is Misfiring
description: WASHINGTON  From the outset, one trademark of the Carter Administration's foreign policy has been a certain laissezfaire laxity about public pronouncements. First there were the unguided sallies of Ambassador Andrew Young. Now there is the more serious matter of President Carter and his chief advisers speaking with different voices on American policy toward the Sovie,t Union  an issue which is exacerbated by infighting, sniping and news-leaking at the second echelons of Government.

title: Realty News.

title: Maddox Auctions Memorabilia in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, June 24With the bang of a miniature ax handle as a gavel, Jack Jones, an auctioneer, put the life and times of Lester Garfield Maddox on the block to the highest bidder today.

description: DALLAS, June 24 (AP)  Mickey Mi, ntle was in stable condition at Brookhaven Medical Center today, where he was being treated for a bleeding ulcer. A hospital spokesman said the former Yankee slugger was doing lint.. Mantle, who was hospitalized Wednesday, said he hoped to be released Monday.

title: CHILE DENIES U.S. CHARGE ON THE LETELIER INQUIRY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 24 (Reuters)The allegation by United States authorities that Chile is not cooperating fully with an investigation into the killing of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean foreign minister, conflicted with reality, a Government spokesman said here today.

description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.If you plan to drive to the Winter Olympics in Lake Placid in February, 1980, be prepared to become a statistic in traffic that may at times resemble New York City at rush hour.

title: Phil Woods And Quartet: Boppish Jazz
description: Phil Woods has long since risen beyond the sleek Charlie Parker lines to which he was very closely tied when he first appeared on the New York jazz scene in the 1950's. But even as time has passed and he has found his own musical voice and his own style, those early lines at times still echo through his performances.

title: `Lost
description: Lost and Found, the film seriescoproduced by WNET and the Museum of Modern Artwhich began last night and will run through August 12, is dedicated to the search for our cinema heritage, the American movies that disappeared over the years through actual film deterioration, accident, or neglect and disinterest. These are films which no longer exist in American film archives nor in the studios which produced them.

title: Joan S. Silverblatt Wed
description: Joan Susan Silverblatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Silverblatt of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Seth Darryl Bykofsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving R. Bykofsky, also of Bayside. Rabbi William Orentiicer performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens. The bride's mother is controller of RAAM Information Services, a New York division of the Rapid American Corporation, and her father is president of Wonder Bar Products, a Bronx importing and giftpacking company. Dr. Bykofsky is a professor of government at Brooklyn College. The bride was graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. Her husband, a Queens College graduate, will attend the Benjarlin N. Cardozo school of Law at Yeshiva University in September.

title: Change IsThe VerdictOf Time
description: FIRST came the General Court of Connecticut 1637. After that came the Particular Court and the Quarter Court. Then there was the Court Assistants. Soon after, courts with more familiar names  the County Courts and the Probate Courts were started. Old courts were discarded, and new courts were created to meet the changing needs of the state, and as Connecticut entered its fourth century, the organization chart of its court system resembled a Rube Goldberg cartoon.

title: Yemen Arab Republic Set Up In 1962
description: Yemen, which has a population of about 6 million, was established as the Yemen Arab Republic in 1962 when a group of army officers overthrew the country's imam, who was both king and spiritual leader.

title: Trapping a Bit of the Past While in Astoria, Oregon
description: The Oregon coastal town of Astoria had a beginning swaddled in both fur and fir. Its founders were a party of Scots traders and French woodsmen dispatched by John Jacob Astor in 1810 to establish the farthest frontier outpost of his peltseeking empire. It is part of the pleasantly persisting anomaly of the community that today's archetypal Astorian is a Finnish-descended fisherman or logger swapping yarns over coffee at the Pig n Pancake and that this oldest American settlement on the Pacific shore still has neighborhoods that look as if they are barely holding even in the contest with the forest.

title: Why Censor NonSecrets?
description: Roarin Oren, they call him in the Federal courthouse in Alexandria, Virginia, and in a case this week, United States District Judge Oren R. Lewis demonstrated why. The suit involves Frank Snepp, a former C.I.A. agent who last year published a book about the fall of Saigon. The Government sued because he did without submitting it, as pledged, for approval before publication. To many, the case involves a complex clash of principles -- the Government's need to keep secrets versus the public's need to learn about the misdeeds or failings of Government But it seemed simple to the 75-year-old Judge Lewis. .

title: For Kremlin Policymakers U.S Rhetoric Is Just Words

Many of them now have direct access to policymakers in their capitals. Yet for all the expertise, the Soviet-American relationship has deteriorated markedly, and at times the behavior of the White House and the Kremlin seems almost designed to infuriate, rather than to reduce tensions.

The. entire system of retirement income in the United States is crazyquilt that includes private pensions, Federal, military state and local retirement plans as well, and it is widely regarded as, at best, inadequate, at worst, tottering into collapse.

title: The New
description: A few years ago, around the middle of this decade, a number of exceptionally talented young jazz musicians converged on New York from Chicago, St. Louis and Los Ankeles. They were very different from one another in terms of style and temperament; yet all of them had some important qualities in common, qualities that distinguished them from earlier jazz avantgardists and made them stand out as a group. They were intensely concerned with structure and with varieties of structure. They were knowledgeable about earlier jazz traditions and about contemporary European concert music. They tended to play in continually shifting combinations, often using unusual groupings of instruments, and to vary their approaches to conform to the demands of each particular playing situation. They were interested in developing personal sounds, as earlier jazzmen had been, but many of them seemed even more interested in creating a succession of new sounds, and in ordering these sounds in unpredictable, fresh, and interesting ways.

The two family dogs, being walked on leashes by the children out in the street. Nothing wrong here, except that. if this family lives on Long Island, Dad is polluting the underground water supply with nitrogen, Mom may be adding dangerous chemical solvents to the ground water, and the dogs are helping contaminate the shellfish in nearby bays.

title: CRIME
description: Auillors are no longer interested in young, efficient, lethal espionage agents. Secret agents these days have to be sedentary and middleaged. It's even better if they're failures, sitting in some miserable office, shuffling reports. Naturally, they turn to drink under those conditions. It happens almost always that they are sent out on what appears to be a simple mission because a superior needs a gambit pawn  and guess who the pawn is going to be. But part of the gamels that the old boy  who, after all, was once a smart, tough operative  has vast experience and  knows a hawk from a handsaw.

title: Design
description: One of the most persistent of Manhattan fantasies is that of living in a duplex. Developers have found that there is a market for spaces that may be relatively tiny but which,through effects of height, create an illusion of grandeur and amenity.

title: Carter's New Media
description: WASHINGTON They are talking a lot about 1980 at the White House. Perhaps they're whistling in the dark, but the consensus is that barring a disaster such as an economic slump, the boss will run for reelection and win. The President said the other day that whatever disadvantages he faces in 1980, they're a damn sight fewer than they were in 1976, says Jody Powell, Mr. Carter's press secretary. In this view, it is hard to underestimate the power of incumbency, and it leads one new White House aide, Anne Wexler, to insist that he's unbeatable.

title: Mixed Images
description: THE best news photographers  the ones who win the prizes  are paid to stand by the gates where love and death change places. They are told to walk into panics. They are sent into the center of catastrophes. They are asked to retrieve anoma-

title: Dr. Mary R. Newburger Is Wed to John Korn
description: The marriage of Dr. Mary Roberta Newburger to John Michael Korn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Korn of Sebastapol, Calif., took place yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Einest Som- merfeld, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Newburger, parents of the bride.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 24 (AP)Nearly 100 ethnic Chinese fled to Thailand this week from Laos, where they said they had suffered the same kind of persecution as has been alleged by Chinese in Vietnam, a newspaper reported today.

title: Sailing Under Sun and Rain In the Bahamian Out Islands
description: We flew to Abaco, a Bahamian Out Island northeast of Nassau, to take out a chartered sailboat for 10 days. We wanted cruising, swimming, snorkeling and sun. We got them allplus a few things we did not expect.

title: The German Connection
description: TOWARD the end of April, 1976, this book begins, a tall, welldressed South African walked into the offices of the London publishers W. H. Allen and Co. and offered to sell them the confessions of the celebrated Great Train Robbers.

title: SKEPTICS ARE SCORED ON PARANORMAL ISSUE
description: One of the scholars who helped start a campaign to investigate reports of paranormal phenomena has split with his former colleagues, contending that the movement became more preoccupied with denouncing such reports than with investigating them fairly.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ANY factors can contribute to paint peeling on the outside of a house. Using the wrong kind of paint for a particular surface, improper preparation of these surfaces, failure to follow directions as to application or thinning, or even a heavy buildup of too many layers of old paint are among some of the common causes.

description: WASHINGTON, June 24.(AP)Edward Hunter, a noted atuthoriky on psychological warfare who popularized the term brainwashing, died today, an aide said. He was 75 years old.

title: FINANCIAL OUTLOOK BETTER FOR RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL
description: The financial outlook for Radio City Music Hall has improved considerably in recent months, according to Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak, who heads a special group trying to save the debt ridden hall I think we've turned the corner on Radio City, Miss Krupsak said Friday during a meeting of the group, the Civic Flail Preservation Project Corporation. Everybody is very optimistic.

title: A Slowdown But Is Recession Really Inevitable?
description: WASHINGTON  Most economists agree that the current, aging business expansion will slow in the second half of the year. But that begs the central question: Will it be a pause, as the Carter Administration contends, or something more ominous?

description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP)Butch Hobson drove in two runs with a homer and a single and Carlton Fisk hit homer today as the Boston Red Sox routed the Baltimore Orioles by 83 behind unbeaten Luis Tiant.

title: Footnote to a Survey
description: What are the seven natural and manmade wonders of the United States? Four years ago the United States Travel Service published a list that it based on a travel industry survey. In an effort to revise the list this year, the service wrote to 300 writers and editors, but only 30 replies were received, and they were so divergent, according to Carolyn Perroni, coordinator of the survey, that no consensus seemed possible. The project was abandoned, but the concept will be included in broader survey this summer, with results expected in the fall.

title: Where Moscow Goes, Can Peking Be Far Behind?; China Is Back in Africa, Modestly
description: HONG KONG  On a tour of Africa some years ago, Chou EnIai remarked that the continent was ripe for revolution. Little did he anticipate that having thrown off colonialism, the fledgling states of Africa would remain ripe for foreign intervention, and that China would find itself in ironic alignment with the United States and the former European colonial powers against the Soviet Union and Cuba.

description: The way was cleared last week for the creation of an instant steel giant when Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, overriding the objections of the Justice Department's antitrust division, approved the merger of the Lykes Corporation into the LTV Corporation.

title: Barbara Kingsbury Married to Designer
description: Barbara Hamel Kingsbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kirk Kingsbury of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to William Talmadge Spencer Jr.,'son of Mrs. Spencer of Sayville, L.I., and Mr. Spencer of Phoenix.

title: Ford Doubts He Will Play for Kansas City
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 24 (UPI) Phil Ford, the allAmerica guard from North Carolina, said yesterday that he doubted that he would play basketball for the Kansas City Kings. I doubt you'll see me in a Kansas City uniform next season, he said. It's important to be a winner. I've been a winner everywhere I've played. Kansas City does not have a winning tradition. Ford was the second player selected in the National Basketball Association draft last month and said he was so upset that Kansas City picked him as its first choice that he has not negotiated with the club.

title: A Correction
description: The price of a summer rental for a house on the water in Westport was incorrectly given in a caption on this page last week. The correct price is $7,500 for five weeks.

title: Company Says 76 Blast in Italy Caused Little Injury
description: ZURICH, June 2QTwo years ago, an explosion in a northern Italian chemical plant release a poisonous cloud that led to the evacuation of residents of the most contaminated area. According to the Swissbased corporation that owns the factory, scientific findings now permit the confident assumption that no serious and permanent damage to health occurred.

title: Traveler's ookshelf: Seriousness counts
description: The summer vacation season is upon us, and we are all set to go off and have a good time. Ha! That's just what we think, or rather what we think we think. Somewhere, tucked away in a dark corner of our psyches, there's a separation anxiety, coiled and ready to spring. And that's only the beginning.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Consumer beat: The Supreme Court suled that the plaintiffs in classaction suits, often used by consumer sroups, must bear the costs of compiling lists of all members of the particular class. The court had ruled four years ago that the plaintiffs must notify individually all members of the class and bear the cost of notification. ... A House panel cleared a bill that would allow consumers to sue producers for pricefixing and other antitrust violations even they had dealt through a middleman.

description: FORT HOOD, Tex., June 24Crisscrossing Texas in a busy day of politicking that had all the trappings of a Presidential campaign, President Carter warned today that his hopes of reducing the Federal budget deficit this year were threatened by several appropriations bills before Congress.

title: Guesting Games: Rules of The House
description: You may as well forget George Vigouroux if you can't get up for lunch by 2 P.M. You will absolutely never, ever, be asked as a house guest to his villa in Tunisia.

title: Trade Talks and an Uncertain Dollar
description: The instability of the dollar, a specter that has haunted foreign and financial ministries for months, continued to dominate international economic relations last week. The value of the American currency declined still further vis-a-vis the Japanese yen, falling to a postwar low.of 209.52 in Tokyo by Friday.

title: GARDENING
description: THE pollution of our underground water supply is of increasing concern. Along with contamination from industrial sources, runoff into roadside sumps and cesspool infiltration, there is an in- dication that we have been applying excessive quantities of fertilizer to lawns and gardens, especially lawns, with the nitrogen not used by the plants eventually reaching the water supply.

title: FISHING Mako Sharks: A Tasty Catch
description: THE fast and powerful mako shark has arrived in New Jersey coastal waters in good numbers and should be the prime target now for the offshore angler.

title: Two Years Al ter Quake Chinese City of Tangshan Is Still Desolate Scene
description: TANGSHAN, China, June 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Nearly two years after the disastrous earthquake that leveled it, the city of Tangshan still looks like shantytown.

title: SPORTS Chasing the Little America's Cup
description: TONY DIMAURO. Does the name ring a bell? Try this one: Little America's Cup. Still not sure? That's the problem with an esoteric sport like catamaran racing. Though DiMauro's a world champion in his own right, having captured that sport's highest honor, hardly anyone recognizes his name, much less his face.

title: PEOPLE
description: Ghalth R. Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian businessman, last week succeeded in acquiring a controlling interest in the First National Bank of Georgia, the bank once headed by former Office of Management and Budget Director Bert Lance, and the fifth largest in the state.-

description: Lieut. Gov, Mary Anne Krupsak will announce her candidacy tomorrow for the Democratic nomination for Governor, high aides to the Lieutenant Governor said yesterday.

title: KnockOffs Aside, Gucci's Blooming
description: FLORENCE, Italy  The American consul general here is faithful to the Gucci loafer with the linked horsebits he slightly raised a pants leg to prove the point. At the bar of the Excel- sior Hotel, an elegant watering hole on the banks of the Arno, the tall young brunette chatting with a man with Great Dane was swinging a large package slashed with Gucci's red and green stripe. And an affluent pair of middleaged Californians, outside Gucci's burnished boutique on the Via Tornabuoni, were stamped from belt to bag with the doubleG initials that do not stand for Guelph and Ghibelline.

title: MABEL LOSSING JONES, 100, FORMER INDIA MISSIONARY
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., June 24 (AP)Mabel Lossing Jones, a missionary for many years and the widow of the Rev. E. Stanley Jones, the Methodist missionary and evangelist, died yesterday at nursing home here. She was 100 years old.

description: THE 20 and out early retirement plan for New Jersey policemen and firemen, which the Assembly killed Thursday night by a margin of one vote, was a victim of Proposition 13.

title: Hundreds Vie for Chance at 550 Apprenticeships
description: Equipped with sleeping bags and tents, food and vitamin pills, transistor radios and chess boards, more than 1,000 prospective plumbers and electricians camped out for the weekend on sidewalks in Flushing, Queens, and in Manhattan, waiting to receive apprenticeship applications that will be distributed early tomorrow morning.

title: The Mavor of Greenport, L.I., Hasthe Long Pull in Mind and Is Training Hardfor the Henley of Regatta
description: GREENPORT, L I.Twice daily for the last six months, Joe Townsend and Dick Curtis have been rowing a 65pound shell across Hallocks Bay in Orient in a demanding rhythm that probably extracts more from the human body than any other activity.

title: Rent Guidelines: Room for Disagreement
description: WHITE PLAINS THE RECENT decision of the county's Rent Guidelines Board to approve rent incre. ses of 14 percent on threeyear leases was based, in part, on data collected from only 10 percent of the landlords in the 11 Westchester communities that come under the state's Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974.

title: Rhode Island Loses to Brazil
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 24 (UP1)  Brazil's Sirio Club defeated the University of Rhode Island, 10995, last night, handing the American team its fourth straight defeat in the William Jones Basketball Cup. The American team quickly fell behind and by the middle of the first half was losing, 209. By half time, the Americans were losing, 5239. Iry Chatman, with 20 points, and Jim Wright, with 24, led Rhode Island in scoring in its last match in the international tournament.

title: Tenure Dispute
description: ONE of the most controversial issues affecting publicschool education in recent years, both in New Jersey and the rest of the country, has been the repeated efforts of school administrators and school boards to apply tougher standards in evaluating tenured teachers.

title: A Mighty Uproar Over a Trucker's Pension
description: WASHINGTON  In 1973, John B. Daniel, a Chicago truck driver, retired after 22 years membership in the pension fund of Teamsters Local 705 with every expectation of receiving a pension of $100 a month. He was ruled ineligible. An involuntary layoff of three and a half months prevented his fulfilling the fund's requirement of 20 consecutive years of work.

title: Few Bus Drivers Are Reported Off Job After Chicago Slaying
description: CHICAGO, June 24 (UPI)Chicago Transit Authority drivers were urged to stay off the job today in memory of a fellow bus driver who was slain in a traffic dispute, but transit officials said that only a handful of drivers did not report to work.

description: ACOMPUTER can perform 20 million calculations a second, but what is the minimum time in which it can add or multiply two numbers? How close are the actual times computers take to add or multiply to the theoretically lowest times required for these operations?

MacMillan of Vero Beach. The Rev. Thomas Collins performed the ceremony. The bride is a nurse at the Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach. Her father is president of Gordon Publications Inc., publishers of trade magazines in Morristown. Mr. MacMillan is vice president and his father president of the MacMillan Oil Company in Vero Beach.

title: The People vs. Green Acres
description: CONCERN about the environment has tipped the balance in many suburban communities from one of moderate growth to a rigorous adherence to preserving any open or vacant land. Woodlands, marshlands, littered lots, large estates  all have been enshrined as legacies for generations yet-to-come.

title: Two Surrender in Holdup Killing
description: A gunman accused of killing a 61-yearo1d clothier who was trying to thwart the robbery of an Upper West Side supermarket Thursday night and a man said to have acted as a lookout in the crime have surrendered to the police, homicide detectives said yesterday.

title: Medicine
description: ATLANTAUntil recently, many Americans had little awareness of byssinosis, the disabling and potentially fatal respiratory disease also known as brown lung. Last week, after years of delay, the Occupational sately and tieaitn Administration issued new rules giving the cotton mills standards by which to cut levels of the cotton dust that causes the disease. Those favoring stiff standards found the complex new rules too lenient; the industry found them too costlyand unnecessary.

title: New Challenge for GrahamThe Met
description: Martha Grahamthe doyenne of American modern dance, its artistic conscience, oracle and legendmakerwill once more break with tradition when her company begins a weeklong season at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow. marking the first time that opulent hall has presented modern dance. The openingnight benefit will be highlighted, by the unusual presence of a Broadway star performing with the dancers. And the work which Liza Mine111 will narrate at that single performance is one of Miss Graham's rare comic dances, a new piece called The Owl and the Pussycat.

Designed with an eye to politics rather than simplicity, each option is designed to help particular districts that might be hurt under a less complex plan.

title: Should F.B.I. Agents Be Punished for Actions That Once Would Have Earned Medals?; The Answers For Webster Are NoWin Solutions
description: WASHINGTON  Last October, a young Federal Bureau of Investigation agent named Jack T. Caldwell was discovered, to the professed horror of some of his superiors, to be living with a woman who was not his wife. He was suspended for three weeks without pay, reprimanded by the director for failing to maintain the high standards expected of employees of the F.B.I. and given a disciplinary transfer from Washineton to New York. There was some comm. bling among younger agents, but the action wasn't considered outrageous or even unusual. Although agents no longer. are transferred to Omaha for such petty infractions as drinking coffee on Government time, even the postHoover bureau is noted for sudden and arbitrary discipline.

title: AHAWAIIAN PREVIEW OF TAX VOTE'S EFFECT
description: HONOLULU, June 24If California's Proposition 13 is the pattern for future taxation by local governments around the nation, then government in Hawaii has been living in the future for more than a century. And the tax burden here is one of the nation's highest.

title: POLL FINDS DEMOCRATS FAVORED AT THIS TIME
description: If Congressional elections were held now, Democrats would outpoll Republicans, 59 to 41 percent, thus retaining their solid majority in the House of Representatives, the Gallup Poll reported this weekend on the basis of two surveys taken last month.

title: Sporting Gear
description: If Submax Calculator sounds complicated, it is, for it was developed by scientists and athleteclinicians as an accurate means of measuring improvement in aerobic fitness. The'device, a sort of slide rule about the size of an index card, estimates your body's capacity to process oxygen apd bring it to the muscles. It takes five minutes at home for the step-by-step test, Which, according to the inventors, indicates one's fitness and calculates the best running speed for a person's weight and fitness level. About $4 at Cornell Mcd Center Book Store, 424 East 70th Street, Manhattan, or from West Mountain Scientific, Box 489, Summit, N.J. 07901.

title: Thomas Goldberger Marries Sue Sand

title: Francine Schore Married
description: The marriage of Francine Schore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Schore of Silver Spring, Md., to Jay. Fischer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Fischer of Great Neck, L.I., took place yesterday at the Dix Hills (L.I.) Jewish Center. Rabbi Israel Nobel performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Paul Carus. The bride, who will keep her maiden name, is market editor for The Daily News Record, a Fairchild Publication. Her husband is with the marketing department of the ColgatePalmolive Company

title: The City, South and Caribbean (I)
description: Twentyfive years ago, down in North Carolina where I was raised, my father took me to a ribboncutting for a new plant. As the Mayor of Durham, he proudly introduced the main speaker, Gov. Luther Hodges, an ebullient extextile executive who once had his. picture in Life magazine in a shower to boost nonshrinking North Carolinamade underwear. The Governor boasted about the new jobs, and how the state was leading the Southeast in new plant locations because our schools are good and our people are great. No one mentioned unions or tax breaks for new industry: So it was no wonder the welldressed Yankee owners smiled when the high school band played Nothing could be finer than to be in Carolina.

title: Battle of 1778 In New Jersey Is Reenacted
description: MANALAPAN, N.J., June 25After 100 minutes of musket fire and cannon blasts in the 81degree midday sun today, the Redcoats retired, leaving American troops to take possession of the same cornfield that their ancestors won 200 years ago in the first Battle of Monmouth.

title: Volume of Paperwork That Public Does for Government Is Declining
description: WASHINGTON. June 25Contrary to a widespread perception, the burden of paperwork and red tape imposed on the public by the Federal Government has been going down, rather than up, a Government report shows.

title: Business People
description: Penny Foley, at 32, is one of the bankers at the Citicorp international group who put together the recordbreaking $3 billion standby credit line for the Canadian Government announced last week. Mrs. Foley never planned to be a banker. I was an economist with the Federal Reserve in Boston, she said. I came here because they offered me $500 more.

title: Why the U.S. Wasn't There
description: The United States failed to qualify for the 16nation final stage of the tournament. The Americans made it only as far as an early elimination round with Mexico and Canada, from which two of the three nations would advance to the next qualifying round.

title: Syracuse Crew Victor in Britain
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 25The American crews entered in the Nottinghamshire International Regatta continued to test the relative speeds of their potential opponents today in preparation for this week's Henley Royal Regatta. In a number of matchups, yeiterday's winners became today's losers, causing one British observer to remark, Seems as though the Yanks are intent on confusing the bookmakers for Henley.

title: 3 Die in Illinois Air Crash
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., June 25 (AP)A light, twinengine plane crashed and burned five miles west of Belleville today, and the three persons aboard were killed. The authorities said the plane was on its way from New Orleans to Cahokia, Ill., when it crashed in a nonresidential area.

description: David E. Rosenbaum

title: Free Concerts to Begin July 18 in Washington Sq.
description: The Washington Square Music Festival, which has been offering free summer musical events to New Yorkers since 1953, will present the first concert of its 1978 season on July 18, at Grace Church, Broadway and 10th Street. Johannes Somary, the conductor, will direct the organist Frank Smith, the soprano Dilys Smith, the Horace Mann Chorus and the Festival orchestra in works by Albinoni, J. S. Bach, Poulene, Mozart and Schubert. Subsequent concerts will take place at Washington Square Park on four consecutive Tuesdays at 8 P.M.

title: 20,000 Gather at Site of Seabrook Nuclear Protest
description: SEABROOK, N.H., June 25Demonstrators against nuclear power, who staged a legally sanctioned rally yesterday on a site where there were mass arrests here last year, threw their makeshift compound open to the public today for speeches and exhibits on the dangers of nuclear nower.

title: Prime and Discount Rate Rises Expected
description: The Federal Reserve is likely to raise its discountrate soon, and commercial banks will probably raise their prime rates shortly, too.

title: El Barrio in Nieuw York
description: THE taxi moved swiftly through the Sunday streets and into a snarl of traffic on the Seventh Avenue side of Madison Square Garden. At 1 P.M. crowds clogged the sidewalk and the Garden entrance. There were flags everywhere, mostly light blue and white. Young people were handing out blue and white sheets reading: Argentina Campeon 78. Voices, mostly young, were raised in a chant: Ar-gen-teen-ah! Ar-gen-teen-ah! The cab driver stared.

title: Amending The Court
description: The Supreme Court decision last month upholding a surprise police search of the Stanford Daily has aroused unusually strong reaction in Congress. Half a dozen Senators and Representatives, from both parties.

title: Cows, Horses and Kids
description: Should I eat the bone, too? asked the nineyears old girl from the Bronx, having already eaten the corn off the cob in the course of her first meal outside the city limits. She was one of thousands of innercity youngsters, aged 5 to 12, who last year spent a smalltown vacation with host families in The Fresh Air Fund's 342 friendly towns in 12 states.

title: A Cool Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  In recent days there have been implications  sometimes attributed to President Carter, sometimes to national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, sometimes to the Committee on the Present Dan- ger or other exalted sources  suggesting that the United States is standing by helplessly while the Soviet Union, with the help of Cuba, is taking over first Africa and then the world.

title: Pritzkers Drop Offer for Hyatt
description: The Hyatt Corporation, which operates a national hotel chain, announced yesterday that the Pritzker family of Chicago, its principal stockholders, had withdrawn their offer to buy the outstanding shares in the company they do not already own.

title: GOING OUT
description: ALL KINDS In a way, the following diversions are a microcosm of what to expect locally in the summer ahead, activities that make the Big Apple different and keep it ripe. Some events are free and none are priced unreasonably. They range from a new series of lunchtime concerts at one of the city's miniparks to midday theater, a solo recital by a cast member of one of Broadway's biggest hits, a convergence of female jazz performers, special poetry session at a library branch and a singalong concert in Greenwich Village featuring two choral classics.

description: MOSCOW, June 25The Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev charged today that the Carter Administration was pursuing a shortsighted and dangerous policy of trying to play the Chinese card'  against the Soviet Union, Its architects, he said, may bitterly regret it.

title: Wanted:Black Mayoral Assistant; Must Meet Special Qualifications
description: The simmering difficulties between the city's black community and the Koch administration have led to renewal of the Mayor's quest for a black assistant to help take the sting out of the charge that City Hall is insensi- tive to minorities. Half a dozen people have been interviewed so far by John LoCicero and Herbert Rickman, two of the Mayor's political advisers but none have been found acceptable.

title: Chess:
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Grandmaster Anatoly Lein of Cleveland pulled ahead of the field after nine rounds of the United States Championship with a 63 score. He was held to a draw in a placid Queen's Pawn Opening by Grandmaster William Lombardy of New York in the eighth round and then swamped weak play by Kenneth Regan, the United States junior cochampion, in the ninth round in an old - fashioned Queen's Gambit Declined.

The company's statement did not mention any specific price it would pay for the shares, 0.9329 of which would be exchanged for each share of Spectronics. title: Whose Veto?
description: Backwards runs the governmental process when Congress insists on what has become known as the legislative veto. It is the nowcommon device of granting discretionary power to the President and his departments with a proviso that Congress retain the authority to block specific actions once decided upon: the sale of jet planes to Saudi Arabia, say, or the reorganization of an executive agency. By President Car- ter's count, Congress has resorted to this device in 48 measures over the past four years and he served notice last week that he intencls to challenge this fundamental departure from the way the Government has been administered throughout American history.

title: As Armed Factions Multiply, Lebanon Lives in Fear of a Bloodbath
description: BEIRUT, June 23Survivors of one of the most vicious civil wars of this century, the Lebanese are waiting for their little country to explode again.

title: Colombia Abductions Create Climate of Insecurity
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaA few weeks ago, six men and two women armed with submachine guns abducted a Columbian businessman by day on a busy Bogota street. Only one person in a crowd of bystanders, a women, joined her screams with those of the victim in a futile cry for help, and the police and newspapers have cited this as a sign of hoW a wave of kidnappings has begun to numb public sensibility and instill fear.
