description: Karen Charlotte Gellermann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert G. Gellermann of Lake Worth, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Anthony Crawford Cahan. Milton Mollen, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Second Judicial Department of the State Supreme Court, performed the garden ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Cahan, father and stepmother of the bridegroom, who is the son also of Mary Sykes Cahan.

title: Carter News Parley On Television Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 25President Carter will hold a news conference at 4 P.M. tomorrow, the White House has announced. It will be televised by the three major national networks, ABC, NBC and CBS.

title: Public Employees Face Problem With Tax Revolt
description: LAS VEGAS, June 25The biggest, fastestgrowing union in the A.F.L.C.I.O. is running headon against the biggest, fastest-growing political issue in the country.

title: Faster Antitrust Cases Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Thirtythree ways to speed up antitrust cases litigated before the Federal Trade Commission, including measures to give administrative law judges ironhearted control over the proceedings, have been recommended by a working group created by Michael Pertschuk, commission chairman.

title: Lietzke Triumphs In Canada
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, June 25 (AP)Bruce Lietzke, benefitting from the collapse of his challengers, needed only a two-over-par 73 today to score a onestroke victory in the Canadian open golf championship.

title: Rigoli Makes It To A's Bull Pen
description: Joe Rigoli, a 21-year-old catcher who was a senior aft Fairleigh Dickinson University earlier this month, is the latest beneficiary of the youth movement of the Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley. Rigoli, signed by the A's last Monday and assigned to the Bend, Ore., fairm club, was called up by the A's on Saturday and made the bullpen coach.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Someone wrote recently asking for enlightenment as to the foodstuff known as miltz.

title: Goldman Band Opens With Typical Potpourri
description: Rained out on Wednesday, the Goldman Barid began its 61st summer season of free openair concerts Thursday night at the Guggenheim Memorial Band Shell in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park. The weather could not have been more ideal, and a goodsized audience was on hand to enjoy the music and the mild evening breezes.

title: Treasury Sale Awaited
description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell $1.75 billion of 15year bonds on Wednesday, and the issue is likely to capture the strong attention of investors, because longterm Government bond yields have climbed back very close to the peaks they reached in late August 1974.

title: EXHANOI AIDE AT U.N. SAID TO DIE IN CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Vietnamese Mission to the United Nations has informed the State Department of the death of Dinh Ba Thi, a United Nations delegate who was expelled in February for his alleged complicity in a Federal esnionage case.

title: Fossils Are Found Of Fish That Lived In Cambrian Era
description: Fossil remains of what may be the world's oldest known vertebrate, a primitive jawless fish that lived about 510 million years ago, nave been discovered by a paleontologist with the United States Geological Survey

title: California Campground Evacuated After a Camper Wounds a Bear
description: GLENDORA, Calif., June 25 (UPI)About 1,000 campers were evacuated early today from the Crystal Lake campground north of Glendora after a camper shot and wounded a large black bear.

title: Study Backs Council on Pay Issue
description: The salaries of New York City Council members are below average when compared with those in similar legislative bodies, a study by the research affiliate of the Citizens Union has found.

title: F15's Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  The Air Force has announced the award of a $980.8 million contract, as was expected, to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for production of 97 FI5 jet fighter planes this fiscal year.

title: Factory Life: An Unsung World Where Time Off Is the Best Time
description: This is the first of a series of articles to appear from time to time about the texture of life in a New York City factory and about the men and women who work there.

title: Rev. A. L. Davis; Founded Rights Unit With Dr. King in'57
description: The Rev. Abraham Lincoln Davis, a founder, with the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the first black member of the New Orleans City Council, died on Saturday. He was 63 years old.

title: U.S. Law Against Bribes Blamed For Millions in Lost Sales in Asia
description: HONG KONGWhen representatives from the Dow Chemical Company and the Union Carbide Corporation went to the Philippines last year to discuss investing in a proposed new petrochemical complex there, they were surprised to find themselves dealing with a close friend and inlaw of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Boating Collision in Maryland Leaves 1 Dead, and 12 Injured
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 25 (UPI)A boating collision on Chesapeake Bay which a woman died and 12 persons were injured was being investigated today by Ithe Maryland marine police.

title: The Berlin Airlift: 30 Years Ago, a Victory for the West
description: Late in the morning of June 26, 1948, a C47 transport lumbered into West Berlin's Tempelhof airfield. The Berlin airlift had begun and the Soviet Union was on the way to its first serious reverse in the cold war.

title: Metromedia to Televise Royal Ballet July 22
description: Metromedia Television, which owns seven television stations, including WNEW-TV-Channel 5 in New York, has arranged to televise live by satelliteon July 22 a performance by Britain's Royal Ballet from the stage of Covent Garden. The telecast, expected to run more than two hours, will be repeated on video tape the following evening.

title: Coleman and Taylor Share Bill
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN, whose group shared a Newport Jazz Festival Program with the Cecil Taylor Unit at Carnegie Hall late Saturday night, has made impressive progress in harnessing the raw power of his electric band Prime Tirne since its appearance at last year's festival. Then, he seemed to have the music thought out on a theoretical level, but there were still some problems in group communication and in the practical, minute-to-minute definition of group roles.

title: Ballet: Cubans Close With Miss Alonso in La Peri
description: THE National Ballet of Cuba closed its first New York season Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with the kind of delirious ovation for Alicia Alonso that, has marked every performance by the company's prima ballerina and director.

title: PAUL JACOBSON
description: Paul Jacobson, a senior vice president of Schiff Terhune Inc., died Friday at his home at 920 Park Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Jacobson, who was 77 years old, had been active in the insurance business for half a century.

title: HighSchool Mark Is Set in ShotPut
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 25Mike Carter of Dallas won the 16pound shotput at the Amateur Athletic Union's national junior track and field championships today and broke one of the oldest scholastic records in the hook. His firstround put of 61 feet  inches clinched the event and added 3 inches to the high school standard established 10 years ago by another Dallas athlete, Sam Walker.

title: Accidents With SteelBelted Radial Tires Stir Fears
description: AKRON, OhioAbout two years ago, Gunter and Cassie Hoagland were riding along Interstate 65 In Alabama when tire blew out, causing Mr. Hoagland to lose control of his automobile. It ran off the road and rollea over, and Mrs. Hoagland was killed.

title: Associated Press
description: Tourney Tally: Mediocre Play, Poor Officiating

title: 196975 Family Income in South Rose as National Rate Stagnated
description: ATLANTA, June 25New statistics from the Bureau of the Census show that family incomes in the South increased significantly from 1969 to 1975 when incomes in the country as a whole remained virtually unchanged.

title: Milner Torments Mets
description: Baseball, Joe Torre observed yesterday in Shea Stadium, is made up of streaks: good, bad and indifferent. Right now, ours is bad.

title: Six Chicago Bombings Reported
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (Reuters) A militant Puerto Rican liberation group has claimed responsibility for the explosion of six incendary bombs in three crowded suburban department stores yesterday. The devices went off shortly after noon, about the time the annual Puerto Rican Day Parade began in downtown Chicago.

title: Advertising
description: GPI Publications in Saratoga, Calif., has had such success publishing two magazines for specific groups of musicians that it is planning two more.

title: Palestine Group Linked to Terrorists of 14 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 25United States intelligence agencies, drawing largely on information from foreign intelligence sources, have linked terrorists from 14 countries with international operations of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine

title: Soviet Cyclist Victor In junior World Event
description: WASHINGTON, June 25With his Soviet teammates successfully blocking a crowded field, Vladimir Nlakarkin won the gold medal today in the grueling, 76mile roadracing event of the iunior world Cycling chamoionshins.

title: New Health Plan Threatens Clinics That Serve Coal Miners
description: McDOWELL, Ky.'It may be that the days of progressive American medicine as pioneered here in the mountains are gone, said Jerry Frost, the slim, Chainsmoking, Appalachianborn administrator of the McDowell Miners Clinic.

title: Outdoors: Clambakes and So Forth
description: BLEND wood smoke, salt air, the aroma of rockweed sizzling on heated stones and the hot juices of softshell clams and lobsters, and you have the essence of one of the most rewarding of seashore banquets, the New England clambake.

title: HOLLENBECK STARTS BID FOR REELECTION
description: DUMONT, June 24Alleging that election of his Democratic opponent would begin an era of machine politics in Bergen County, Representative Harold C. Hollenbeck of the Ninth Congressional District officially opened his campaign for election to a cerand term today.

title: REP. WILLIAM M. KETCHUM; WAS IN 3D TERM IN HOUSE
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 25 (UPI)Representative William M. Ketchum, Republican of California, died last night of an apparent massive coronary. He was 56 years old.

description: To try the Jet Ski and the Wetbike, write to the manufacturers for a list of the dealers closest to you:

title: More Tremors in Greek City
description: SALONIKA, Greece, June 25 (Reuters) Earth tremors continued to shake this northern Greek city today, but Greek and foreign seismologists described them as weak and said the chances of another serious earthquake such as last Tuesday's, which killed 47 people, were remote. Most shops, factories and small industries in Salonika have already reopened.

title: Herstatt Bank Scars Remain
description: BONN  Few people outside a select group of bankers had ever heard the name Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt when the regional West German bank collapsed with little warning four years ago today.

title: Racing: Buckaroo Takes Saranac
description: Buckaroo, a speedy 3-year-old colt owned by Greentree Stable, was nervous wreck a year ago in his first year of competitive racing. But now, according to John Gayer Jr., his trainer, he has settled down and is carving out an impressive record for his age group.

title: Yanks Weigh Shift Of Martin's Aide
description: DETROIT, June 25In a move that was seen by some of the players as a way of inducing Billy Martin to resign as manager, the Yankees set the stage today to demote Art Fowler from his job as pitching coach.

title: Deaths
description: KITZINGERHarry L., on Sunday, June 25, 1978, formerly of NY, NY, son of Helen and the late Stanley A. Kitzinger, brother of Richard and Cynthia and uncle of Stanley and Stephen Kitzinger. Service at Knapp's Colonial Home, 132 South Harrison St. East Orange, NJ, Tuesday morning, June 27 at 11 o'clock. Entombment Maimonides Cemetery, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Kessler Institute, West Orange, NJ.

Marcos

title: More Quit Armenia Than Arrive
description: YEREVAN, U.S.S.R.Soviet Arme nia; which as the only national homeland for the persecuted and widely scattered Armenian people drew hundreds of thousands of immigrants over half a century, is now losing more pea? ple to emigration than it gains by repatriation.

title: Music: Fania All Stars Offer a Pure Latin
description: THE Fania All Stars, that gathering of Latin music talents led by the cofounder of Fania records, Johnny Pacheco, may dabble in disco and other mainstream pop forms on its albums, which are distributed by Columbia records. But playing for a Latin audience, the group sticxs to its roots, and at its best, when it playing as a unit and not as a collection of stars, it plays with heat and precision and exudes a fierce collective joy.

title: Bank. Controls Improved Since 1974, Study Finds
description: The banking crisis of 1974, which saw West Germany's Herstatt failure and the collapse of .the Franklin National flank in the United States, produced important and permanent changes In the management of international banking, a recently completed study of the Franklin case concludes.

title: Beware
description: Seacoast foragers should he aware that, along much of the shore, there are times when socalled red tides may result in shellfishes being toxic to humans, and sometimes fatal. The villain is a microscopic marine organism called a dinoflagellate. The various states keep a close watch on this and issue warnings.

title: Callaghan Meets Plane Producers
description: Britain's Prime Minister, James Callaghan, held meetings in Washington this weekend with American aviation executives to gain perspective on a critical airlinerproduction decision soon to be made by the British.

title: Miss Horvath, 12, Triumphs Again
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 25Kathleen Horvath of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., the 12-year-old prodigy of Eastern tennis, claimed her second consecutive women's tournament title today when she won the Eastern clay court championships for women at the Orienta Beach Club here.

title: From License to Liberty in Broadcasting
description: Despite the dramatic changes in American radio and television during the past four decades, the Federal law that governs their operation remains much as it was when enacted in 1934. Efforts to bring up to date, promised frequently, have succumbed before the complexity and controversy of the, task. But

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 25Donald F. McHenry, a softspoken diplomat with a persuasive negotiating style, was quietly dispatched to Angola this week to confer with officials in the Marxist Government of President

description: SUMIKO MURASHIMA and HOD O'BRIEN, vocal and Pktno recital, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8.

title: Several Agencies Are Combining Efforts to Keep Vigil on Offshore Waters for Pollution
description: The environment of the ocean off New Jer,sey and Long Islandthe scene of fish kills and debris washups for the last two summerswill be carefully monitored by everything from satellites to skin divers this summer.

title: Don and Doryt Moss: Their Life in the Berkshire Hills Is in Full Bloom
description: EAST CHATHAM, N.Y.  The peonies, shading from white to deep red, are in bloom. So are the huge orange poppies, and irises that go from deep purple to a delicate blue or coppery red. Soon the day lilies and roses will add their color to the meandering garden backed by tall shade trees and the forests of the Berkshire Hills.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: FRANCIE HIDDEN

title: EPISCOPAL PRIEST REFUSES TO YIELD PULPIT IN DISPUTE
description: WEST ORANGE, June 25 (AP)A deposed priest who led his congregation in a secession from the Episcopal Diocese of Newark refused today to give up his pulpit to the Archdeacon appointed to replace him.

title: Legislature Called at an Impasse Over the Politics of Crime
description: ALBANY, June 23The 1978 New York State legislative session was perhaps destined to become caught up in acrimonious electionyear politics, but few politicians thought that it would deteriorate in the fashion that it did this week: with bitter partisan namecalling and a complete stalemate on more than a dozen critical issues, including a tough new package of anticrime bills. The crime legislation, at least, had been the one set of measures that virtually everyone had thought would be enacted into law this year in one form or another. But it ?? ?? question that the Legislature will ever adopt the bills that, in fact, have won virtually complete bipartisan approval in all their major details.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE 10th and penultimate chapter of Leonard Silk's uneven Economics in Plain English is called What Economics Can Do for You. Its gist is that Economics can help you reason more clearly about issues. For economics offers a special approach to reasoning aoout problems, an approach that has six main elements: I. Define the problem or issue carefullyand assemble the relevant facts. 2. Identify the goals and objectives you hope to achieve. 3. List the alternative means of attaining your goals. 4. Identify the economic concepts needed to understand the problem you are working on and analyze the alternatives in terms of those concepts. 5. Choose the alternative that appears to solve the problem bestand act on it. 6. Verify whether that alternative worked.

title: Black School Principal in Wayne Says He's Target of Racial Slurs
description: WAYNE, June 25This predominantly white Passaic County community has been shaken by charges that the school district's only black elementaryschool principal has been subjected to racial slurs and that the school district's administration has ignored repeated requests for action to combat them.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt's latest peace proposal was rejected by Israel before it received formal notification of its terms. The Cabinet had heard about the terms through Cairo radio reports. Under the proposal, Jordan would resume control of the West Bank and Egypt of the Gaza Strip while they help work out security guarantees for Israel as well as some autonomy for the Palestinians. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: 1778 Battle of Monmouth Is Reenacted in Manalapan
description: MANALAPAN, June 25After 100 Minutes of musket fire and cannon blasts in the 81degree midday sun today, the Redcoats retired, leaving American troops to take possession of the same cornfield that their ancestors won 200 years ago in the first Battle Of Monmouth.

title: Two Seized in Bank Robbery
description: MADISON, June 25 (UPI)Two Newark men were arrested over the weekend and held in lieu of $150,000 bail each on bank robbery charges. The police said that Theodore Simmons, 36 years old, and Robert Brown, 32, had been charged with armed robbery in thetheft of $6,500 from the Orange Savings Bank. They were caught early Saturday in a wooded area off Route 22. All of the stolen money and two weapons were recovered.

title: Mob's Role Discounted in Gambling
description: Federally financed studies have challenged repeated contentions by investigators that illegal gambling is organized crime's largest source of revenue and a basis for financing heroin trafficking, loansharking and the fencing of stolen property.

description: Federally financed studies have challenged repeated contentions by investigators that illegal gambling is organized crime's largest source of revenue and basis for financing heroin trafficking, loansharking and the fencing of stolen nrnnprtv.

title: VERSAILLES PALACE IS DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: VERSAILLES, France, Monday, June 26 A bomb e::ploded in the historic Palace of Versailles early today, injuring a guard and destroying priceless works of art and period furniture.

title: Attorneys Quit F.T.C. Oil Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Federal Trade Commission is losing the services of the two lawyers who have been directing its massive, fiveyearold antitrust case to break up eight major oil companies.

title: P.B.A. Chief Calls For Gold's Ouster In Brutality Inquiry
description: The president of the Policemen's Benevolent Association called yesterday for the removal of District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn from any investigations of policebrutality cases in the borough.

title: Newport Jazz
description: LESS than three weeks after appearing before a cheering, overflow audience at Avery Fisher Hall, Ella Fitzgerald was back in town Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival. The closeness or the two engagements, caused when her Avery Fisher Hall concert scheduled for midMarch was postponed until June because of her illness, did not seem to diminish her Newport Festival appearance in the slightest. The hall was packed and the audience was on its feet cheering at her first entrance.

title: Letter: On Homeowners
description: To the Editor:

title: Brezhnev Attacks United States For Trying to Play Chinese Card
description: MOSCOW, June 25The Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev charged today that the Carter Administration was pursuing a shortsighted and dangerous policy of trying to play the Chinese card against the Soviet Union. Its architects, he said, may bitterly regret it.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: NATHAN AGAR, ORGANIZER OF SOCCER TEAM, WAS 90
description: Nathan Agar, who in the 1920's was responsible for bringing the Hakoah of Vienna soccer team to this country, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 90 years old and resided at 240 Central Park South.

title: Ford Tracks $1 Million In Indonesia
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Ford Motor Company is seeking to determine whether one of its subcontractors carried out a 1975 attempt by officials of a Ford subsidiary to bribe an Indonesian general in order to obtain a $30 million telecommunications contract, member of the company's board of directors has confirmed.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: The New York Times
description: AM ISRAEL CHAT, which means Israel shall live, was chanted by nearly 1,000 people at rally in Bowling Green Park in Manhattan yesterday. Called to express outrage at the presence of Nazism in America, gathering attracted city and state political leaders, including Governor Carey and the Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea.

title: MidAmerica's Minicontracts
description: CHICAGO, June 25 Waves of sound, the shouts and tumult of the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange, pounded at young Don J. Casser the other day as he stood at the edge of the trading pit. In front of him, just below his line of sight as he looked up at an electronic tape, flashing arms and thrusting hands of dozens of traders tugged at his attention.

title: Jim Rice, the most destructive hitter, P. 4
description: IF Jim Rice were a Broadway play, his advertisement would read something like this: Most destructive hitter in baseballReggie Jackson, New York Yankee slukeer.

title: Gay Quimby Is Wed to Alan J. Auerbach
description: Gay Cameron Qulmny, aaugnter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad L. Quimby of Derry, N.H., was married yesterday at her parents home to Alan Jeffrey Auerbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Auerbach of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Samuel Umen performed the ceremony.

title: Market Place
description: SMALL investors who have bought commercial property to hedge against inflation may discover that these properties are increasingly hard to find. Prices have risen so substantially that yields on, say, a strip of property of a supermarket and smaller local service stores have dropped so low as to make the proposition possibly unattractive.

title: Long Ear Of the Law
description: WASHINGTONNow that the Carter Justice Department has won its argument in the Supreme Court and can rummage through your home and mine without having to show wrongdoing, a new assault on personal privacy is underway: a plot to give Congressional sanction to warrantless wiretapping, and to turn the telephone comaanv into an arm of the law.

title: Union Official Says industry Hinders Cancer Fight
description: A union orricial charged yesterday that the refusal of many. Industrial companies to disclose the results of their research into the causes of health problems among their workers was hindering progress toward elimination of cancer hazards in the American worker's environment

title: Us Magazine Names New Editor
description: Sam Angeloff, a founding editor of People magazine, has been named editor of Us magazine, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Angeloff, who will assume his new duties July 15, will replace Ron Martin, who resigned this month.

title: Lemon
description: WILTON, Conn., Awe 25'Are you looking for Corvairs or lemons? Welter Grischuk asked motorists who lined up at the entrance to Allen's Meadow this afternoon.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Timas last Friday incorrectly included the Consolidated Edison Company in a list of utilities operating boilingwater reactors manufactured by the General Electric Company.

title: Canadian Jet Carrying 107 Falls in Ravine on Takeoff; 2 Killed and Many Injured
description: TORONTO, June 26 (AP)An Air Canada jetliner with 107 people aboard went off the end of the runway during takeoff and plunged 40 feet into a ravine today, killing two and injuring at least 100, aviation officials reported.

title: Impressionists Fetch $6 Million
description: LONDON, June 26Robert von Hirsch's collection of Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings was sold at auction tonight for $6,216,808 as the dispersal of the Swiss leather merchant's treasures neared its completion.

title: A 1950's From fora 1950's Romance
description: HAWORTH, N.J.  Bob Kaplan, a 38-year-old salesman of corrugated paper materials, went to his senior prom the other night. It cost him $3,500, but who counts pennies on prom night? Not Mr. Kaplan, a tall, boyishlooking figure in a white dinner jacket from the 1950's. No, he said with a dreamy smile, I'll have this memory for a long time.

title: Paine Webber Shifts Orders to Coast
description: Paine Webber, Jackson & Curtis said yesterday that it had begun directing the retail order flow in 30 securities traded on the New York Stock Exchange to the Pacific Stock Exchange. Possibly by the end of this week, it added, three or four of these stocks would be transmitted for execution from the Pacific exchange to the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, where an allelectronic national market system market experiment has been authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission

title: It Was a Day for Miniparks Despite the Overcast
description: The overcast sky with its threat of rain yesterday did not keep all New Yorkers from enjoying Manhattan's miniparksthose tiny oases of plantings, trees, waterfalls and bubbling fountains tucked between soaring skyscrapers, and the bushbordered and benchlined plazas prominently placed along the Avenue of the Americas in the Rockefeller Center area.

title: U.S. and Soviet Give Up Custody Of Three Suspects Pending Trial
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Two Soviet citizens, each being held on $2 million bail on espionage charges, were released today in the custody of Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union, and an American businessman being held in a currencyviolation case in Moscow was turned over there to Ambassador Malcolm Toon.

title: I.B.M. to Close Business in Nigeria
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was pulling out of Nigeria because the Government did not grant it an exemption froin a law requiring that nationals

title: LANDMARKS STATUS EXPECTED TO SPREAD
description: The affirmation of New York City's landmark designation of Grand Central Terminal by the United States Supreme Court yesterday is expected, according to many real estate and zoning experts, to lead to a wave of similar designatidns, primarily of commercial properties, by municipalities across the country that have been hesitant because of potential legal challenges.

title: Police Will Arrest Wife Beaters In Reversal of New York Policy
description: Reversing a longstanding practice, the New York City Police Department has agreed in an out-of-court settlement to arrest wife beaters.

title: Makler Is Epee Victor After 4Man Barrage
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., June 26Brooke Makler, of Philadelphia, captured the national individual epee championship of the Amateur Fencers League of America tonight.

title: Bank and Carter Committee Fined $6,200 for Campaign Plane Use
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Federal Election Commission announced today that it had assessed civil penalties of $6,200 against President Carter's Presidential campaign committee and the National Bank of Georgia, then headed by Bert Lance, for illegal use of the bank's airplane in Mr. Carter's election campaign. The committee and the bank have agreed to pay to close the case.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, June 26The Chicago Park District announced today that it would appeal the court ruling last week allowing a Nazi rally on July 9 in Marquette Park, located on the city's southwest side.

title: Saudi Backs Price Rise
description: CALGARY, Alberta, June 26 (AP)Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabian Oil Minister and the most powerful member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said today that a serves of small increases in oil prices was necessary to avoid grave consequences for producers and consumers alike. He did not specify the size of the increases he had in mind, but said any sharp rise might plunge the world into another recession. Saudi Arabia has been one of the moderate members of OPEC in recent years, resisting efforts by other cartel members to raise prices.

title: Liggett Sells Foreign Cigarette Operations
description: The Liggett Group, which has repeatedly denied rumors that it las getting out of the cigarette business because of declining sales, said yesterday that it had sold its foreign cigarette operations to a Swiss affiliate of Philip Morris Inc. for about $108 million.

title: ALEX E. B.J6RKNER
description: Alex E. Bjorkner, the chief of the New Jersey Department of Transportation's bureau of railroad operations, died Sunday at Hunterdon Medical Center. He was 69 years old.

title: ExJudge Says He Was Conduit For South African Ads Abroad
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 26The Club of Ten, which placed advertisements defending South African policies in numerous Western newspapers, was a front for the South African Government, according to a retired British judge and writer who has written a series of articles for The Rand Daily Mail.

title: Voters to Decide on Jai Alai Wagering in November
description: TRENTON, June 26A referendum on legalized betting on jaialai games will be placed before New Jersey voters in November.

title: How to Get There
