title: Forbes Duo Wins
description: The team of Isabel Forbes and Jo Unbert won the New York open women's lawn bowling tournament Sunday in Central Park. The ForbesGilbert team, from the Essex Lawn Bowling Club, defeated Dorothy Henry and Toni Mercer in a playoff.

title: Israel Seeks Air Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Government. of Israel proposed today that Israeli and American airlines operate between the two countries on an unregulated bask, free to set fares and offer services without official approval.

title: Blue Jays Rout Orioles By 2410
description: TORONTO, June 26 (AP)--John Mayberry knocked in seven runs with two homers and the Toronto Blue Jays scored nine runs in the second inning en route to a 2410 victory over the Baltimore Orioles toight.

title: Blind W oman, 62, T ells State Panel Of Abuse by BoardingHome Owner
description: TRENTON, June 26A 62-year-old blind woman testified today that the operator of a boarding home ransacked her bank account and then choked her and thiew her down a flight of stairs when she complained.

title: Harkness, Long Lead Golf on 69's
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26A pair of 69's by Fred Harkness of Apawamis and Nelson Long of Century were the best scores today in a field of 136 seeking to qualify in the twoday Westchester County Golf Association on open tournament at the Knoll

title: Mantle Released From Hospital
description: DALLAS, June 26 (AP)Mickey Mantle was discharged from a hospital today after treatment for a bleeding ulcer.

title: Appellate Court With No Case Backlog Is Honored
description: Such is the state of justice in America that, when a Federal appellate court operates on schedule, some of the country's leading lawyers feel that there is cause for a celebration.

title: Ban onGrand Central Office T ower Is Upheld by Supreme Court 6 to 3
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court ruled today that New York City could prohibit the construction of a 53story office building above Grand Central Terminal because the tower would significantly alter the terminal's status as a historic landmark.

title: TV: Priceless Treasures of Dresden
description: THE Priceless Treasures of Dresden is another in an apparently lengthening series of glossy commercials for traveling art exhibitions. Tins one, which can be seen on WNETTV tonight at 9 o'clock, was written by Lou Solomon and directed by Sid Smith.

title: Women's Group Stages a Protest At H.E.W. Office
description: WASHINGTON, lune 26 (UPI)  A women's rights coalition, charging that sex discrimination thrives in the education system and that Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, is partly to blame, staged a runin protest today.

title: Paris and Bonn Press Money Stabilization
description: PARIS, June 26  The French Government said today it would send a high economic official to Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg to inform the governments of these countries about a new plan for stabilizing European currencies. The plan apparently was agreed upon by France's President, Valery Discard d'Estaing, and West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, during private talks in Hamburg last weekend.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE Business Roundtable, a group of 190 chief executive officers of major United States corporations, has pledged to cooperate with President Carter in trying to slow inflation, but with the caveat that the private sector cannot succeed in com bating inflation unless the Government adopts sound fiscal, monetary and regulatory policies.

title: Court Says 2 Household Cleaners Must Be Marked for Eye Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)Two widely used household cleaners, Janitor in a Drum and Spray n Wash, will have to carry warning labels advising users that they can harm the eyes, the Consumer Product Safety commission said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A Lewis Carroll Find
description: PHILADELPHIA FOUR examples of one of the lost curiosities of Victorian photography  Lewis Carroll's photographs of very young girls in the nudehave come to lieht for the first time. They are being shown at the Rosenbach Foundation Museum here as part of a Lewis Carroll exhibition.

title: Exxon Puts Oil Find At 50 Million Barrels
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., domestic arm of the Exxon Corporation, estimated yesterday that a major new discovery it had made in the Gulf of Mexico contained more than 50 million barrels of oil. This rates among the best oil and gas discoveries made by Exxon in recent years, a spokesman said.

title: Primaries Today in Mississippi and South Carolina
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 26Gov. Cliff Finch, the ardent populist who suddenly finds himself in an uphill battle for the Democratic nomination for the Senate, has apparently decided upon a veiled attack on the man he hopes to succeed, retiring Senator James O. Eastland, a giant in Mississippi politics for several decades.

title: U.S. Attorney in Mississippi
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)The White House announced today that President Carter had named Robert E. Hauberg, 67 years old, of Jackson, Miss., for another term as United States Attorney for the Southern District of Mississippi, a post he has held since 1953.

title: Beaths
description: BINDERClara. Beloved daughter of Jennie and the late Nathan. Dear sister of Sylvia Peri and Lillian Rose and Sidney and the late Emma She piro. Beloved niece and aunt and friend of many. Services Tuesday, 2 PM Parksidc Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Buttoning Up Federal Blue Collars
description: The most visible symbol of President Carter's commitment to fight inflation within Government is his decision to hold Federal pay increases to 5 percent next year. Unless Congress matches the President's initiative with legislation, however, the Government's 400,000 bluecollar employees are likely to take home a 9 percent raise.

title: Jets for AllNippon
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that AllNippon Airways had purchased 10 jetliners valued at $240 million. Delivery of the order for four 747's and six advanced 737200 jets is scheduled for September 1979 through February 1980.

title: Interest Futures Are Widening Field
description: CHICAGO, June 26  As interest rates again surge toward the peaks they attained in 1974, professional money managers are focusing on a new and novel money market devised to shelter companies and investors from the usual battering they suffer in a time of sharply rising money rates.

title: Traviata
description: Verdi's La Traviata will open the fifth season of staged operas in Central Park by the New York Grand Opera. It will be given on July 6 at 8:30 P.M. on the Mall, with Norma French, soprano; Ronald Naldi, tenor, and Theodore Lambrinos, baritone, in the lead ing roles. Vincent La Selva, founder of the company, will conduct.

title: DR. ROBERT W. LAIDLAW, 77, PSYCHIATRIC SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Robert Wordsworth Laidlaw. who in 1949 founded the department of psychiatry at Roosevelt Hospital and was its chief director until 1957, died Sunday at the hospital following a heart attack. He was 77 years old, lived in the Hotel Beekman at 575 Park Avenue and maintained an office at 565 Park Avenue.

title: Lynne Eve Kluger Married To Jeffrey Adam Altshuler
description: Lynne Eve Kluger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kluger of Great Neck, LT., was married last evening to Jeffrey Adam Altthuler, son of Sophie Altshuler of Teaneck, N.J., and the late. Irving Altshuler. Rabbi Stanley Ger stein performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Simple SlipOn Shoes For a WellHeeled Man
description: They don't look much different from any other men's shoes displayed in a locked shatterproof glass showcase during the day, kept in a vault at night and carrying a $1,000 price tag.

title: The City, South and Caribbean (II)
description: Immigration is now a major source of annual American population growth. But old images mislead us: for example, the immigration of Jews to New York City in the 19th century. was a permanent relocation of people yearning for assimilation. There would be no return and each family knew it. But the pattern of migration from Puerto Rico is a circulating one, fluid and filled with ambivalence and doubt. The numbers rise when jobs are available in New York and decrease when jobs are scarce.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter was optimistic on SovietAmerican relations. Speaking at a news conference, he said the basic relationship was stable, that Leonid I. Brezhnev shared his desire for better friendship and that current negotiations were proceeding in good faith. Mr. Carter said he was very disappointed by Israel's occupied territories. [Page Al, Col. 6.1

title: PANAMA DROPS PROPOSAL FOR A BAN ON WHALING
description: LONDON, June 26Panama, allegedly under Japanese pressure, withdrew a proposal to ban all commercial whaling for 10 years shortly before the start of the International Whaling Commission's meeting here today.

title: Real Places
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J. GIL GIBBS is feeling shaky again, which probably augurs well for his survival and triumph.

title: Hearing ArabAmericans Now
description: WASHINGTONFor the last 30 year's, the principal American constituency addressing itself to United States Middle East policy has been the AmericanJewish community. Its role, understandable in the light of Jewish experience, has been played vigorously, occasionally noisily, and with almost total success: Americans have come to see the ArabIsraeli conflict largely from a proIsrael point of view.

title: Pacific Exchange Joins
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange yesterday became the third exchange to tie into the Intermarket Trading System, an electronic communications network that eventually will link six of the nation's stock exchanges. The system began on a pilot basis with the New York and Philadelphia exchanges trading 11 stocks last April.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Treasury bill rates, continuing to mount as a result of the Federal Reserve's decision last week to tighten money policy, soared yesterday to their highest levels since December 1974.

title: MortgageRate Average Drops
description: The average rate on home mortgages accepted yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation declined slightly for the third consecutive week as the quasiGovernmental agency stepped up the percentage of offerings it accepted this week.

title: Southern Yemen at a Glance
description: GeographyThe People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, or Southern Yemen, occupies a strategic position on the heel of the Arabian Peninsula, where the Red Sea opens into the Indian Ocean. Its 112.000 square miles are divided between mountain and desert. Except in the higher parts, which have a light covering of thorn scrub, and in the limited areas of cultivation, the territory is bare of vegetation. Rainfall is scanty overall, but may he markedly different in neighboring areas. The port capital of Aden receives a hare five inches of rain a year, but the highlands a few miles to the north sometimes record annual rainfalls of up to 30 inches.

title: New Film Theft Cases Filed
description: LOS ANGELES June 26Two new embezzlement accusations have come to light in Hollywood in the space of one week, just as the film industry was finally putting the David Begelman case behind it.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter was optimistic on SovietAmerican relations. Speaking at a news conference, he said the basic relationship was stable, that Leonid I. Brezhnev shared his desire for better friendship and that current negotiations were proceeding in good faith. Mr. Carter said he was very disappointed by Israel's position on occupied territories. I Page A 1, Col. 6.1

title: EARL G. NISONGER
description: Earl G. Nisonger. president of the Nosonger Corporation of New Rochelle. N.Y., importer of British auto parts, died Sunday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., at the age of 78. Mr. Nisonger's company represented Smith Industries of London, manufacturer of parts for British cars. He took part in the sponsorship of auto and motorcycle races and was a member of the Sports Car Club of America. He is survived by his wife, Beatriz Medina de Nisonger.

title: $58 Eaton Offer for Cutler
description: The Eaton Corporation and CutlerHammer Inc. annOunced yesterday that Eaton had offered to purchase the 68 percent of CutlerHammer's 6.6 million shares it does not already own at $58 a share, or a total of $261 million.

title: New Pritzker Offer
description: The Hyatt Corporation announced yesterday that its principal stockholders, the Pritzker family of Chicago, had made a new proposal to acquire, for $17.75 a share, the outstanding shares of Hyatt that they do not already own. Over the weekend, Hyatt had announced that the Pritzkers, who own about 2.8 million shares, or 35 percent of the hotel chain, had withdrawn their proposal to buy the stock at $15 a share,

title: Tower Over Grand Central Barred As Court Upholds Landmarks Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court ruled today that New York City could prohibit the construction of a 53story office building above Grand Central Terminal because the tower would significantly alter the terminal's status as a historic landmark.

title: Letters
description: The current craze to make drastic cuts in taxes is an uninformed reaction to our current economic distress. High taxes are not the prime mover in the crippling of our economy. Those who hope to stop inflation and deliver us from recessions by cutting taxes are trying to cut down a tree by lopping off the end of a branch.

title: BorgWins, Escaping An Upset
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26A deep, fast, viciously spinning second serve surprised Victor Amaya and saved Bjorn Borg, from firstround elimination at the Wimbledon tennis championships today.

title: 3 Black Physicians Protest Move Ending Their Surgical Training
description: Three black resident physicians at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn diarged yesterday that they were being dropped from a surgical training program Fecause of their race, and they asked the Federal District Court to order that fhev be reinstated.

title: Eight Women Become Graduates Of the Merchant Marine Academy
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., June 26Eight of the 245 caps that went flying into the air today as the Merchant Marine Academy wound up its graduation ceremonies in traditional fashion returned for the first time in, the academy's history to the hands of women.

title: Equitable Plans Gulf United Merger
description: The Equitable General Corporation, a life insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Gulf United Corporation to be merged into it or its subsidiary, the Gulf Life Insurances Company.

title: Notes on People
description: WEDDING FEVER was spreading in Monaco yesterday, as the marriage of Piincess Caroline to Philippe Junot approached. The Princess can celed a rehearsal for the religious part of the ceremonies, to be held Thursday, because she was too busy with lastminute preparations. Everything will be all right on the day, palace sources said, last night. The bridal couple were guests of honor at a lavish party given by Philippe Niarchos, son of the Greek shipping millionaire, Stayros Niarchos, aboard the Niarchos yacht Atlantis. There were 300 invited guests at the ball on the $80million yacht, whose presence in the harbor at Monte Carlo is commanding. The civil wedding ceremony is set for tomorrow afternoon, to be followed by a garden party for the people of Monaco in the palace.

title: The Killings in Rhodesia
description: Last Friday's massacre in Rhodesia of eight white missionary teachers and four of their own children was a peculiarly vicious and senseless outrage in a horrifying war. Those murdered were defenseless British citi zens whose only purpose in Rhodesia was to serve the people among whom they worked. The guerrillas made Clear that they were precisely the ones singled out to die; the black teachers and the allblack student body of the remote school were left unharmed, but were ordered to leave and to close the school  as if education itself were the target.

title: Manager Is Told He Will Remain for Season
description: As they did every few weeks last season, Billy Martin and George Steinbrenner cleared the air yesterday in a meeting that solidified Martin's job as manager of the Yankees.

title: 2 Juilliard Pianists In Tchaikovsky Contest
description: In addition to the three American contest pianists who advanced to the second round in the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, as announced last week, two Juilliard School students who are registered from their native countries also were chosen. They are Diana Kacso of Brazil and Andre LaPlante of Canada.

title: CARTER, CALLING TIN WITH SOVIET STABLE, SAYS TALKS PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  President Carter, in one of his most positive evaluations of SovietAmerican relations, said today that the underlying relationship was stable, that the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, shared his desire for better friendship and that current negotiations were proceeding in good faith.

title: Television
description: 8: 00(4)Kids Are People Too

title: BERGEN RUNS SHORT OF BUSINESS SPACE
description: PARMVIUSNext month, the first tenants will move into the new Mack Centre II, a 330,000-square-foot building in this Bergen County community at Exit 165 of the Garden State Parkway, and they can apparently consider themselves fortunate to have the opportunity.

title: Detroit Pushing Sales in Europe
description: BONN  Gerd Hoegner does not think American automobile companies are very alert. But he loves their cars.

title: Caldwell, Kostelanetz, Meta in Parks Series
description: Zubin Mehta, the New York Philharmonic's new music director, will be one of the conductors tfor the orchestra's annual series of concerts in the city's parks. The others will be Andre Hostelanetz and Sarah Caldwell.

title: DR. JOSEPH H. LAPIN
description: Dr. Joseph H. Lapin, a pediatrician and for many years chief of service at Bronx Hospital, died Sunday at his home, 290 Collins Avenue, in Mount Vernon, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Cosmos, Aware of Future Needs, Close to Signing Portuguese Star
description: Despite having the best wonlost record in the North American Soccer League, the Cosmos were planning for the future yesterday. They were negotiating with Seninho, a Portuguese forward, and might announce his signing today.

title: Newport Jazz
description: AFTER Sonny Rollins's Newport Jazz Festival performance at Carnegie Hall Sunday night, this writer was asked to recant all suggestions he had made, in print or in conversation, that any living tenor saxophonist is mr. ttoiiins's equal. He did so gladly and with hardly a second thought. Mr. Rollins does not always feel Ii)te giving a committed performance, and the recordings he has made during recent years have been more or less disappointing. But when he wants to play, as he very evidently did on Sunday night, nobody can touch him.

title: Ford Denies Bribe Report
description: Henry R. Nolte Jr., vice president and general counsel of the Ford Motor Company, denied yesterday an assertion published in the Monday issue of The New York Times that, according to information available to top Ford executives, part of an agreedon bribe had been passed along to an Indonesian company to give to an Indonesian official.

title: CARTER, CALLING TIES WITH SOVIET STABLE, SAYS TALKS PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  President Carter, in one of his most positive evaluations of SovietAmerican relations, said today that the underlying relationship was stable, that the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, shared his desire for better friendship and that current negotiations were proceeding in good faith.

title: May Consumer Spending Brisk
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 26 (AP)A buy-in-advance psychology and fear of inflation are causing brisk consumer spending that could fall off late in 1978, a report by the University of Michigan Survey Research Center on consumer attitudes said today. Current spending should continue in the near term, but the outlook is less favorable for late 1978, the report said.

title: Blind Golfers Show No Handicap in Tourney
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 26While Tom Sullivan was on his way to the first tee of the Guiding Eyes for the Blind tournament at the Mount Kisco Country Club today, a reporter from a radio station wanted to know What would happen.

title: Dance: Martha Graham at Met
description: THE Martha Graham Dance Company opened its first season at dek the Metropolitan Opera House last night with some of the usual Graham blockbusters and a delightful hit of nonsense aided and abetted by Liza Minelli as nest star.

title: Nuclear Demonstrators End Rally With March in Manchester, N.H.
description: SEABROOK, June 26Demonstrators against nuclear power ended their threeday, legally sanctioned protest here without incident or arrest today. in contrast to an illegal occupation 13 months ago that resulted in a confrontation with the police and the arrest of 1,414 demonstrators.

title: Taxes &
description: WASHINGTON

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: Satellite That Will Scan Oceans Is Launched at Vandenburg Base
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 26 (UPI)A new satellite designed to provide detailed information about the world's oceans was launched today from Vandenberg Air Force Base

title: Pet and IC Approve Merger Terms
description: The boards of Pet Inc. and IC Industries yesterday approved the previously announced terms for combining the two companies and agreed to drop litigation against each other.

title: Sex Education: Suburban Parents And School Aides Pursue the Debate
description: CENTEREACH, L.I.Richard Arluck began to discuss the sexeducation classes he teaches and the 50 assembled parents grow still. qioldonly, the silence was interrupted by a man in the back of the room who tried to shout down Mr'. Arluck.

title: Experimental BusSubway Route to Kennedy Planned
description: You say you're sick of getting stuck in traffic when your plane from Kennedy International Airport leaves in half an hour? There will soon be temporary relief.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SILVER SCREENINGS Today: Two heist comedies, the Italian Big Deal on Madonna Street (1960) and the British Lavender Hill Mob (1950) at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (7572132). The same showcase has a classic Comedy Dill tomorrow, bracketing Ernst Lubitsch's Heaven Can Wait (1943) and Frank Capra's It's a Wonderful Life (1946).

title: Boy, 5, Kills Infant
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 26 (AP) An 18-month-old girl was killed when her 5-year-old brother accidentally discharged a 12gauge shotgun he was showing to a young friend, the police said. Michelle Iturino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Iturino Sr., was pronounced dead on arrival at 1:40 P.M. yesterday at Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River, N.J., the police said.

title: Rosenberg Sons to Receive $195,802 From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, lune 26The Justice Department has agreed to pay $195,802.50 to the two sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were elecrocuted on conviction of espionage charges :n 1953, to cover legal costs the men have incurred in their continuing suit to obtain information about the Government's espionage investigation of theft parents a quarter of a century ago.

title: TradeApprentice Applications Given to All Those Who Waited
description: The persistence of more than 1,000 prospective electricians and plumbers, who camped out for five days in Flushing, Queens, and in Manhattan, was rewarded yesterday when all received applications for apprenticeships.

title: CAREY FORMS PANEL ON SCHOOL FINANCING
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that a task force would be formed to study ways to revise the formula used to finance education in New York State in light of the decision last week declaring unconstitutional the present property tax system of financing education.

title: Carter Aides Favor Ban on Oil Equipment for Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, June 26White House officials are pressing for a curb on the export of American oil production technology to the Soviet Union. The aim of the proposed shift in trade policy would be to give the United States new leverage over Soviet behavior.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Dow Jones industrial average skidded 10.74 points to 812.28, and the highflying casino group dived. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 29.25 million shares. On the Amex Resorts International, which did not open until noon, ran up to 961/2 only to turn. ble to 801/4 because of sell orders. Trading was halted at 3:30 p.m.[DI.]  In the commodity markets livestock futures continued to recoup some of their recent sharp losses, but nearby deliveries of cattle, hogs and pork bellies were off fractionally. [D12.]

title: World News Briefs
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 26 (Reuters) The conservative and centrist parties that make up Iceland's coalition Government suffered heavy losses in parliamentary elections yesterday, and the Prime Minister announced tonight that he Would submit his Cabinet's resignation tomorrow.

title: U.S. EMISSARY RETURNS FROM ANGOLAN MEETINGS
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 26Donald F. McHenry, a United States diplomat, returned here today from Angola where he had conferred with officials on the recent strife involving Zaire.

title: PROSELYTIZER'S DISMISSAL FROM RYE SCHOOL UPHELD
description: The dismissal of a tenured art teacher at Rye Senior High School in Westchester County because she sought to proselytize students for a religious sect was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Second Judicial Department.

title: WPIX Case Clouds Role Of F.C.C. Act
description: WASHINGTON Coming on the heels of a Congressional proposal to revise the 1934 Communications Act, the resolution of the nineyear contest for the license of WPIXTV has made ccnverts to the cause of rewriting the law.

title: Former L.Y. School Official Kills His Superintendent and Himself
description: EAST ISLIP, LI., June 26The Superintendent of Schools in this South Shore hamlet was shot and killed this morning in his office by the school district's recently resigned business manager, who then shot and killed himself, according to the Suffolk County Police.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Villard
description: Elizabeth St. John Villard, an assistant professor of drama at Vassar College, was married yesterday to David Porter Howe, a lawyer with the Admiralty and Shipping Section of the De partment of Justice in New York. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert Bremicker performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Cubs (6 in 5th) Defeat Mets (6 in 5th) by 109
description: CHICAGO, June 26It was no afternoon for the faint of heart in Wrigley Field, where ivy has grown up the walls and hitters have Mocked baseballs over the walls for 62 summers. In three and a quarter hours of roughhouse swinging. the Chicago Cubs outslugged the New York Mets by 109, broke a sixgame losing streak and sent the Mets to their third straight defeat and the 13th in their last 17 games.

title: Expert Says at Jascalevich Trial He Found No Curare in One Body
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26New Jersey's chief toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that his own experiments and confirming tests by another laboratory had convinced him that there had been no curare in the body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: Rock: First Concert At Giants Stadium
description: ACROWD of 61,128 people heard the Beach Boys, the Steve Miller Band, Pablo Cruise, and Stanky Brown at Giants Stadium, In New Jersey's Meadowlands Sports Complex, Sunday afternoon. It was the first rock concert at the stadium, but it probably will not be the last. The crowd was well behaved, the facility was run as smoothly and efficiently as one could expect, and the weather was perfect.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMF inc., Asheville, N.C., worldwide producer of leisure time and industrial products, has named Stanley Groner executive vice president-administration. Also announced was the election of Frederick A. Poss as vice president, group services, succeeding Mr. Groner, and of Gary B. Ward as vice president, corporate development, a newly created post.

title: Court Denies a Hearing to Unlicensed Options Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The Supreme Court today denied a bearing to a commoditytrading adviser who was barred from using the mails because he had been operating without a license. The Court acted in a brief order, without opinion.

title: M. V. Keldysh Dies: Mathematician Led Academy in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 26 (ReuterslMstislav Vsevolodovich Keldysh. a mathematician who headed the Soviet Academy of Sciences for 14 years, has died at the age of 67.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 26Whether he is producing and directing a television series or competing in bridge tournaments, Barry Crane of Studio City, Calif., is a very successful man.

title: South Y emen Chief Reported Slain, But ProRed Group Stays in Power
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26The President of Southern Yemen, an ally of the Soviet Union on the Arabian Peninsula, was deposed today after a day of heavy fighting and was reported to have been put to death.

title: Issue and Debate
description: When the Wimbledon tennis championships opened yesterday in England, the courts resembled an international gathering of the clans and nobody doubted that these were the best players in the world,

title: Shipping/Mail
description: KUNGSHOLM (Flagship Cruises). Lett Tilbury lune 19; due 8 A.M. at VI. 55th Street.

title: Topics
description: Anyone who has worked with Averell Harriman during his 45 years as an official and adviser at the highest levels of Government will tell you why people call him, with awe and affection, The Crocodile. Eight Presi dents have known his toughness and tenacity. Now, a feisty 86, he remains as formidable an adversary as any of the younger denizen of the policy swamps.

title: Beaths
description: ADRIANVictorOn Jun 23, 1978, beloved husband of Pearl, father of Howard and Robert.

title: Books of The Times
description: INCONGRUITY may be the tragedy of our age the painful tension between the expected and unexpected, between tradition and experiment, the sentimental and the inexorable,

title: HIGH COURT BARS RISE IN NUCLEAR LIABILITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court ruled today that Congress did not violate the constitutional rights of potential victims when it voted 21 years ago to limit the damages that a private nuclear power company would have to pay in the event of a nuclear accident at one of its plants.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, June 26, 1978

title: Rice, Fisk Homer Boston Increases Lead to 9
description: The last time the front office supported Billy Martin in his position as manager, the Yankees went out and won the next gamethe final game of last season's World Series. With Martin's job announced as secure once again, the Yankees went out last night and played the. Boston Red Sox, in a game that was nearly as significant as the final game of last season's World Series.

title: Leader of Public Employees Union Sees U.S. Aid as TaxReform Tool
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 26Federal aid to state and local governments should be used as a lever to force tax reform at those levels, Jerry Wurf, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said at the opening of the union's convention here today.

title: YOUTHS SAID TO LAG IN SCIENCE ABILITIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The scientific knowledge and abilities of the nation's 17-year-olds have steadily deteriorated, according to the National Assessment of Education Progress, which has also found that 9-year-olds and 13-year-olds showed less decline and some of them even showed some improvement.

title: Mortgage Certificates At Premium
description: When two scheduled issues of mortgagebacked certificates were postponed in the last two months, some observers on Wall Street thought the infant market had become saturated just as mortgage lenders felt their most pressingneed for new funds.

title: B.&W. Nuclear Deal
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company said yesterday that its Canadian subsidiary had received an order from the Darlington station of Ontario Hydro for 16 nuclear steam generators valued at 38 million. The subsidiary of J. Ray McDermott & Company said that the generators would be built at its works in Cambridge, Ontario, for delivery between 1982 and 1985.

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett
description: BEAUTIFICATION, BEGINNING AT SCHOOL: Students at the Dayton School in Newark planting marigolds in front of school as part of program sponsored by New Jersey Bell and the Newark Recreation and Parks Department.

title: CARTER ASSAILS BILLS ON CAPITAL GAINS TAX
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  President Carter, in a stern attack that reflected the Administration's anxiety about the outlook for tax legislation, today denounced bills that would cut capital gains taxes as offering tax windfalls for millionaires and two bits for the average American.

title: CHALLENGER'S ENTRY SALUTED BY DURYEA
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 26  Perry B. Duryea, the Republican candidate for Governor, said today he considered Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak's bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor a very serious challenge to Governor Carey.

title: The Talk of London
description: LONDON THIS leafy month of June, as Coleridge called it, is the culmination of the English year.

title: Police Will Arrest Wife Beaters In Reversal of New York Policy
description: Reversing a longstanding practice, the New York City Police Department has agreed in an out-of-court settlement to arrest wife beaters.

title: Reldan Gets 20 to 25 Years in Death Plot Against Aunt
description: HACKENSACK, June 26Robert Reldan, a convicted rapist awaiting trial on charges of murdering two Bergen County Women in October 1975, was sentenced to 20 to 25 years in prison today for plotting from his prison cell the murder of his wealthy aunt and her friend.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchanpe,(A) the American Stock Exchange end (O) over-thecounter.

title: U.S. Author Named For Best Science Fiction
description: DUBLIN, June 26 (AP)Brederick an American author, was honored at the World Science Fiction Writers Convention here as the best sciencefiction writer of 1977.

title: Fluor Data Contract
description: A subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation has been awarded an $18 million contract to provide services for a central dispatch data system at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The award was made by the Arabian American Oil Company.

title: Developing Lands Win On Parley
description: GENEVA, June 26  Unhappy because they feel that they are being ignored by the industrial powers, the developing countries today obtained the scheduling of a special meeting of all participants in the world trade negotiations here to air their grievances.

title: Carter Bids Gartner Quit Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Reversing a postion he took 10 days ago, President Carter today called. on David Gartner to resign from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, but Mr. Gartner quickly refused.

title: HIGH COURT BARS RISE IN NUCLEAR LIABILITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court ruled today that Congress did not violate the constitutional rights of potential victims when it voted 21 years ago to limit the damages that a private nuclear power company would have to pay in the event of a nuclear accident at one of its plants.

title: Billy's Ovation Worth All of It
description: Billy Martin suddenly was no longer under siege by George Steinbrenner and Al Rosen with his threat that he knows what happens to a manager whose team doesn't win. In a prepared statement, the front office had announced that Billy Martin would remain the Yankees

title: Court Rules Press Has No Right of Access to Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Warning that we must not confuse the role of the media with that of government, the Supreme Court, ruled today that the press had no constitutional right of access to jails and other government facilities beyond the access permitted to the public at large.

title: Effects of the Democratic Split: Both a Windfall and a Handicap
description: Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea, the Republican candidate for Governor of New York State, is clearly the chief beneficiary of the rare spliteven for wild and wooly New York politicsbetween a Governor and his ostensible copartner

title: Why Parents Space Babies Far Apart
description: THEY'VE gone through the 2 A.M. feedings, the colic and teething. They've climbed into the sand box with their toddlers and later sent them to play groups, nursery and elementary schools and camps, Iney've baked cakes for the class bazaar and umpired for the Little League. Then, just when the parentchild ties are beginning to loosen, they haye another baby.

title: Limits Placed On Credit Data
description: WASHINGTON June 26 (AP)  One of the largest credit reporting agencies in the country has agreed to discontinue practices that Federal officials alleged were unfair and deceptive.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Livestock futures prices continued to recoup some of their recent sharp losses yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. However, the nearby livestock deliveries were still depressed by the liquidation of early last week.

title: Business People
description: Columbia Pictures yesterday dropped, so to speak, the other shoe. Frank Price, former president of Universal Television, was named president of Columbia Pictures Productions, a new division of Columbia Pictures. His appointment was not unexpected in film and television circles since his abrupt departure from Universal and its parent company, the MCA Corporation, last month.

title: U.S. Sought Better Relations With Southern Yemen
description: WASHINGTON, June 26An American effort to lessen Southern Yemen's dependence on the Soviet bloc seemed to conapse today with the apparent overthrow of the President of Southern Yemen by political rivals viewed there as even more proSoviet.

title: Grounds for Investigative Cheer
description: The first cheer is for the House of Representatives. It may be serious about investigating the Korean bribery scandal after all. Last month, it blew an oppor tunity to retaliate against Seoul's continued refusal to make Kim Dong Jo, a key figure, available for testimony. By a fat margin, the House upheld food aid for South Korea. But now given a second chance, the House has voted  by an even fatter margin  to cut the $56 million in aid. Harsh medicine? Perhaps, but remember the stakes: There is reason to believe that Mr. Kim, as Ambassador to Washington in the Nixon years, took envelopes stuffed with $100 bills to scores of Congressional offices.

title: Upset at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 26(AP)Green Speed was upset tonight in the opening of the $185,000 Hiram Woodruff trotting series at the Meadowlands. The 4-year-old finished second, four lengths behind his stablemate, Cold Comfort, who returned $47.20, $9.20 and $5.40 for $2 across the board. The time for the mile was 1:57 25.

title: Knock At the Door: II
description: WASHINGTON  More questions were raised than answered last week when Senator Birch Bayh's Subcommittee on the Constitution held hearings on the recent Supreme Court ruling that even innocent parties  including newspapers and broadcasters  are subject to police searches for evidence of a crime.

title: Hospitals Aide Named
description: Bernard M. Weinstein, executive director of Bellevue Hospital since 1968, was named yesterday by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello of Westchester, as the new Commissioner of Hospitals, or head of the $61 million Westchester Medical Center that was opened last year as a specializedcare facility for a sevencounty region. Mr. Weinstein, whose nomination is subject to approval by the Board of Legislators, will take over the $54,800 post in about three months, Mr. DelBello said.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1978

title: Britain's Callaghan Calls Communism A BurntOut Case
description: Characterizing Soviet Communism as a burntout casean idea whose time has been and gone, Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain last night urged the West to trust the growing power of its own political ideology and to practice military and rhetorical restraint, especially in Africa.

title: Brooklyn College Instructor Is Dismissed Over Student Fracas and Later Takeover
description: The Board of Higher Education yesterday dismissed Richard Perez, an instructor at Brooklyn College who had been suspended and barred from the college since April because, the board found, he had led minority group students in a chairthrowing fracas and had participated in the takeover of a college building.

title: Transcript of President's News COnference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Misses Caulkins, Linehan Set U.S. Swim Records
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., June 26 (AP) Tracy Caulkins won her sixth event with an American record last night and Kim Linehan also set a United States mark in a women's meet at the Mission Viejo International Swim Complex.

title: Stage: Price of Genius Vignettes of Sor Juana
description: SUSAN STEVENS adjusts her performance as Sister, or Sor Juana alpInez de la Cruz to one fierce phrase written by this great Mexican poet arter her religious superiors had suggested that she stop writ ing. To do so, she replied, would make me explode like gunpowder.

title: The New York Times/Barton Silverman
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., June 26Eight of the 245 caps that went flying into the air today as the Merchant Marine Academy wound up its graduation ceremonies in traditional fashion returned for the first time in, the academy's history to the hands of women.

title: Expert Tells Trial He Found No Curare in One Body
description: HACKENSACK, June 26New Jersey's chief toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that his own experiments and confirming tests by another laboratory had convinced him that there had been no curare in the body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

title: Antique Dealer Specializes in City Artifacts
description: Evan Blum got into antiques at the age of 12 when he mastered the technique of restoring old phonographs without making them appear restored. Now the interest of the 24-year-old native Long Islander has expanded to in dude architectural antiques. Mr. Blum owns and operates Irreplaceable Artifacts, a warehouse business that caters to customers who covet the eclectic look in urban architecture.

title: The Now York Times/Marlin Franck
description: PARIS, June 26Three underground organizations claimed responsibility today for the earlymorning bomb blast at the Palace of Versailles that wrecked three of 14 groundfloor rooms containing art works celebrating the Napoleonic era. But the police, reacting with skepticism, said they had no firm clues.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Stocks Off; Casinos Are Hardest Hit
description: The highflying casino stocks hit an air pocket late yesterday and broke sharply in price as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped more than 10 points.

title: Sex Education: Suburban Parents And School Aides Pursue the Debate
description: CENTEREACH, L.I.Richard Arluck began to discuss the sexeducation classes he teaches and the 50 assembled parents grew still. Suddenly, the silence was interrupted by a man in the back of the room who tried to shout down Mr. Arluck.

title: 3 Groups Claim Versailles Bombing
description: PARIS, June 26Three underground organizations claimed responsibility today for the earlymorning bomb blast at the Palace of Versailles that wrecked three of 14 groundfloor rooms containing art works celebrating the Napoleonic era. But the police, reacting with skepticism, said they had no firm clues.

title: Cairo Astonished That Israel Bars Peace Plan Before It Is Completed
description: CAIRO, June 26Egypt today expressed astonishment at Israel's swift rejection of a peace proposal that the Egyptians had not vet completed.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree to Release 3 Suspects Pending Their Trials
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Two Soviet citizens, each being held on $2 million bail on espionage charges, were released today in the custody of Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union, and Moscow agreed to turn over an American businessman being held in a currencyviolation case there to Ambassador Malcolm Toon.

title: StrongMinded Candidate
description: ALBANY, June 26Her election as Lieutenant Governor in 1974, after a long, extraordinary uphill campaign, culminated 20 years of preparation in state government for Mary Anne Krupsak  a fact that only exacerbated her disappointment upon learning that she would be given so little to do in her new job.

title: Assets of Abrahams's Concern Found
description: Five months ago, Alan Abrahams, a 'smoothtalking Boston commodity options dealer who turned out to be a prison escaper, was arrested by Federal officials on charges of criminal contempt in selling foreign options to the American public. He was using the name James A. Carr and working through a firm he called Lloyd, Carr & Company.

title: Food Program Vendors Assailed
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman charged yesterday that vendors who served spoiled food and used collusive bidding in the past were being permitted to hid for contracts in the 1978 summer food program for needy school children in New York City.where Agriculture Department officials are thumbing their nose at Congress, not to mention the taxpayers and the needy children who are supposed to benefit from this program,

title: MISS KRUPSAK OPENS STATEWIDE CAMPAIGN
description: AMHERST, N.Y., June 26Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak formally opened her campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor today with a promise to carry her new vision of our government to the people.

title: Fairbanks: From Pipeline Boom to Bust
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  Like an outofwork actor, the economy here is between engagements. With the TransAlaska Pipeline finished and filled with oil moving to tankers at Valdez, the labor force and business community exist on short rations while waiting for a new gas pipeline.

title: A Critic's Notebook: Greek Tycoon To Auto Movies to Rock-and-Roll
description: THERE are two moments in The Greek Tycoon that deserve to be remembered long after the mom rest of the film fades into complete obscurity (which will happen, if there's any justice, about a week from next Sunday). In one of them, a fight scene between the shipping magnate Theo Tomassis and his glamorous bride. Anthony Quinn grabs one of Jacqueline Bisset's legs, forcing her to hop very unglamorously on the other one for an excruciatingly long time. In the other, Miss Bisset tells her first husband, handsome young President Cassidy  (James Franciscus), that she loves him. And I you, he gallantly replies. What say? And I you? How now!

title: Egyptian Official Hints at Renewed Pressure on Israel for Stalling
description: The Speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, Sayed Marei, said yesterday that Israel's rejection of Egypt's latest peace proposals may lead his Government to renew International pressure on Israel in the United Nations and other international forums.

title: Proposition 13: Savings Begin in California.
description: LOS ANGELES  California property owners are already beginning to feel dollar benefits from the successful revolt against high state property taxes, and a banker says it may be a shot in the arm for the real estate market.

title: Dollar Fails To 206:3 Yen; Volume High
description: TOKYO, June 26  The dollar dropped sharply again today, touching a rate of 204.50 yen in another active trading session before recovering a bit of the lost ground to close at 206.30 yen, still at a postwar low.

title: Jazz Events
description: Fsillowing is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: Tax Revolt Ripples Sway Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, June 22After a decade or more of steeply rising property taxes that have earned this state the bitter sobriquet Texachusetts and sent thousands of residents fleeing to New Hampshire with its lower taxes, an air of expectancy has replaced the former mood of helplessness among taxpayers.

title: Chiefs Would Keep Marijuana Ban
description: CAPE MAY, June 26 (UPI)The New Jersey Chiefs of Police Association adopted a resolution today at its 66th annual fourday conference opposing the decriminalization of marijuana.

title: Citing Irish Situation, Carey Refuses to Co To Callaghan Dinner
description: Governor Carey refused to attend a dinner honoring Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain last night because of what his press secretary called the situation in Northern Ireland.

title: A Bronx Girl, 14, Found Beaten In Basement, Dies at Hospital
description: A 14-year-old Bronx girl died last night, less than two hours after she had been found severely beaten in the basement of her apartment building in the borough's University Height's section, the police reported.

title: Washington journal
description: ROBERT STRAUSS, the garrulous millionaire Texan who is gradually supplanting Bert Lance as Jimmy Carter's good of buddy, took the President to dinner one night last

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Meditation from Thais, Massenet; Caprice Viennois, Kreisler; Ave Maria, Hoist; La Fiera di Venezia Overture, Salieri; Caprice No. 24, Paganini; Schlagobers Waltz, R. Strauss; La Clemenza di Tito Overture; Scherzo, Mozart; Scherzo a la Russe, Stravinsky.

title: Output of Steel Fell in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended June 24 declined by 1.2 percent to 2.749 million tons from the 2.781 million tons produced the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: French Win Plane Bid
description: PARIS, June 26 (Reuters)  Despite stiff competition from the General Dymimics Corporation, France's Marcel Dassault, a large aircraft manufacturer, won a $700 million contract to pro- vide Spain with 48 Mirage F1 fighterbombers, French officials reported today. The planes will be delivered from 198082, with the Spanish aircraft concern Construcciones Aeronatitica S.A. producing slightly more than 20 percent of them as a subcontractor.

title: Mike Douglas Show Heads for (Hollywood) Hills
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 20The Mike Douglas Show, one of the more popular television talk shows, has been broadcast from Philadelphia for the last 13 years. It has succeeded in the ratings by snagging celebrities on the Los Angeles-to-New York City promotion shuttle and by bringing them here in long limousines, It plugged the tcwn five days a week to an estimated 25 million viewers across the nation.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Seeks Federal Inquiry in Miller Death
description: The State Conference of N. A.A. C. P. Branches announced yesterday that it had asked for a Justice Department investigation into what it called the denial of _civil rights to black victims of violence in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Jersey Winds It Up With a Picnic
description: STANHOPE, N. J., June 26The New Jersey branch of the Newport Jazz Festival, which opened Friday evening with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band and continued on Saturday with the New York Jazz Repertory Company playing the music of King Oliver and Louis Armstrong, wound up its three days at Waterloo Village yesterday with the New Jersey Jazz Society's jazz picnic, a daylong event that started at noon and continued until 10 P.M.

title: Beaths
description: GLICKSTEINPhilip. Beloved brother of Morris. Loving uncle of Ira, Maddy, Robin, Lee Glickstein and Linda Karp. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, Kirschenbaum's, Coney Island Ave at Ave H, Brooklyn.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: Events Today
description: NEWPORT JAll FESTIVAL: American Song Salute, Carnegie Hall, 8; Maynard Ferguson Orchestra and Stan Getz Quintet, Avery Fisher Hall, 8.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The financial reorganization of the New York Islanders is proceeding acscording to schedule, the club's general manager told the National Hockey League's board of governors yesterday in Detroit.

title: Appellate Court With No Case Backlog Is Honored
description: Such is the state of justice in America that, when a Federal appellate court operates on schedule, some of the country's leading lawyers feel that there is cause for a celebration.

title: Warrant Issued in Moro Case
description: ROME, June 26 (AP)Italian authorities issued an arrest warrant today for Barbara Balzarani Marini, who is accused of complicity in the kidnapping and slaying of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro. She is the wife of Antonio Marini, who is in jail on charges of kidnapping and killing Mr. Moro,

title: Election Cheers Italy's Top Parties
description: ROME, June 26  Italy's dominant parties, the Christian Democrats and the Communists, held their own in regional elections in northern Italy today as local political groups posted gains at the expense of the smaller national parties.

title: Black Gains Membership at Forest Hills
description: William Cammack, a national coordinator for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has been elected to the West Side Tennis Club, an election that he said highly probably makes him the first black to be admitted to full membership at Forest Hills.

title: Betty Carter With Roach And Gordon
description: BETTY CARTER, Dexter Gordon and Max Roach made an unusually strong bill at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, and each of them was in excellent form. In the past, concerts that featured superficially similar groupings have not fared as well either artistically or at the box office, but one senses different forces at work at this year's Newport Festival. Jazz commands a substantial and increasing popular following, and the musicians seem to be doing everything they can to make sure they keep their present fans and attract new ones, now that they realize they do not have to compromise their art to do so.

title: Liability Decision Protested
description: CONCORD, N. H., June 26 (AP)The Supreme Court decision limiting the Iiability of nuclear power plants was condemned today by the Clamshell Alliance. This ruling deprives all of those Americans living near power plants of any possibility of recovering full after a serious accident, Dick Bell, an alliance spokesman, said.

title: Carter Names 2 to Air Unit
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)President Carter has appointed a Florida legislator old an Ohio corporation president to the National Commission on Air Quality, the White House announced today. Appointed were Edward E, Dodd of Toledo, Ohio, president of OwensIllinois Inc., and Torn McPherson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., chairman of the Florida House Committee on Community Affairs.

title: Beaths
description: LAIDLAWRobert, M.D. The Roo evett Hospital Board of Trustees notes with great sadness the passing of Dr. Robert Laidlaw, founder and former director of the Department of Psychiatry. Dr. Laidlaw was a great figure of strength at The Hospital over many years and continued to teach within psychiatry until the present time. The Laidlaw Library for Psychiatry is an effort on the part of The Roosevelt Hospital to remember and express thanks to a remarkable physician.

title: Beaths
description: PAYNEKenneth Walter. On June 25, 1978. Of Port Jefferson, L.I. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Kenneth W. Payne, Jr., Gail Moseley, and Mary Jo Johnson. Also survived by his sister, Ethel Payne and grandchildren Theresa Payne, Lauren Payne, Bronwyn Payne, Ellie Johnson III and Andrea Johnson. Reposing at the O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Nesconset Highway (Rte 3471, Port Jefferson Station, L.I. Visitation Tuesday 710 PM. Graveside service Wednesday, 11:15 AM at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: President Of Conrail Is Leaving
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) The board of directors pf the Consolidated Rail Corporation announced today that Richard D. Spence, as expected, was leaving as president and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

title: Suit Over F.B.I. Breakin Raises Some New Questions
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Several times in 1974, a team of agents of the Federal 1311reau of Investigation, searching for inUrination that mint Icad to the wherealiouts of radical Weather Underground fugitives, stagec warrantless entries in a small cabin in a remote, wooded section of Hurley, N.Y., near Kingston.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON. June 26The United Slates Supreme Court ruled for the first time today that a person charged with a crime has a right to challenge evidence figainst him on the ground that the prose culion obtained a search warrant by making false sworn statements before the issuing judge.

title: Jesselson to Direct Jewish Fund Drive
description: Ludwig Jesselson, an industrialist and philanthropist, has been appointed chairman of the United Jewish AppealFederalion of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign for 1979, which begins July 1,

title: It Was a Day for Miniparks Despite the Overcast
description: New York City's miniparks, those unexpected oases of trees, plants, waterfalls and bubbling fountains scattered amid the skyscrapers of Manhat7 tan, proved popular yesterday, even with overcast skies and the threat of rain.

title: Greyhound Unit Offers to Buy DCL
description: The Greyhound Computer Corporation, a subsidiary of the Greyhound Corporation, has submitted an informal proposal to acquire DCL Inc., in which shareholders would get $4.50 a snare tor the 3.6 million shares of outstanding DCL stock.

title: Women's Net Tour Obtains New Sponsor
description: WIMBLEDON, England June 26A longrange agreement for sponsorship of the women's professional tennis tour will be announced here tomorrow by officials of the Women's Tennis Association and Avon Products.

title: Neighbors Fight Sale of a Princeton House
description: PRINCETON, June 26Eight neighbors of the stateowned mansion once occupied by Ralph A, Dungan, former New Jersey Higher Education Chancellor, have mounted a drive to block the sale of the ISroom house to two leaders of a mystical, wealthy religious group, The Circle of Friends.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An East Meadow, L.I., printer was charged with second degree murder by the Nassau County police after allegedly beating his pregnant wife to death and then setting her on fire in their twostory frame house at 270 North Newbridge Road.

title: City Ballet: 2 Debuts in Robbins Works
description: SUNDAY night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet closed its series of programs devoted to the choreography of Jerome Robbins with performances of In the Night, Verdi vartations, Otter Dances and In G Major.

title: Beaths
description: COHENRAE O. Beloved wife of the late Victor, toying mother of Jerome, devoted sister of Estelle Cohen (nee Oelbauml and Ave Oct. baum and the late Jerry and Henry Oclbaum and Helen Rich. Adored grandmother of Robin and Michael. dear mother in law of Joan. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Av at 61 St, Interment new Mt. Carmel Cemetery. Friends may call at Frank E. Cantobell Tuesday and Wednesday 7:30 to 9:30 P1,1. Contri to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: $500 Million Subsidy for Amtrak Challenged by Taxpayers Union
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The National Taxpayers Union, following its success in campaigning for California's Proposition 13, a. voter initiative to reduce taxes, launched an effort today to cut out the $500 million Federal subsidy for Amtrak, calling it a Government boondoggle.

title: South Y emen Chief Reported Slain, But ProRed Group Stays in Power
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26The President of Southern Yemen, an ally of the Soviet Union on the Arabian Peninsula, was deposed today after a day of heavy fighting and was reported to have been put to death.

title: Reporter's Notebook: HowWillin4 Are CubanVolunteers?
description: HAVANAIt is difficult for a reporter who has just spent nine days in Cuba to come away with an accurate picture of what the average person thinks about the military, technical and medical missions that President Fidel Castro has dispatched to help friendly leftwing regimes and insurgents in Africa.

title: State Drafts a Plan To Rid the Hudson Of PCB Hot Spots
description: New York State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, Peter A.A. Berle, yesterday announced a $25 million plan to start a cleanup of the Hudson River of PCB contamination.

title: Notes on People
description: THE Air Force announced yesterday that Lieut. Gen. John P. Blynn, who was the senior American war prisoner in North Vietnam, planned to retire in October. General Blynn, a native of Cleve- land, was flying a B105 fighterbomber when he was shot down by a surface-toair missile over Hanoi in October 1967. He was held captive for five and a half years. He has been the Air Force's inspector general for nearly two years.

title: Death of a Benefactor Leaves Project Pending
description: Harry Ocko, a wealthy Rockland County inventor never lived to see his dream of building a home for the elderly fulfilled. He died of cancer last Saturday in his home in Monsey, N.Y., at the age of 82.

title: Elderly Act Out Celebration Of Life
description: CHICAGO

title: VOTE IN SENATE IS AIMED AT HALTING GUNTRACKING
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)The Senate voted today to cut $3.8 million from the Treasury Department budget in an effort to make sure that it cannot set up a computerized guntracking system designed to fight crime.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Enid Nemy

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR several years now, Italy has been pouring money into an effort to capture a larger share of the American wine market. The effort has paid off handsomely so far.

title: Gentile Victor by 5 Strokes In Westchester Open Golf
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 27John Gentile, the 31-year-old assistant professional at Century, earned a silver bowl, a check worth $1,600 and the Westchester County Golf Association's open championship today. He previous-

title: Hunter's Shoulder Is Worked On; Randolph Placed on Disabled List
description: Catfish Hunter, who has been plagued by a sore shoulder all season, underwent nonsurgical manipulation of his shoulder yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital and was reported feeling fine , after the 10minute procedure.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, June 27, 1971

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SNUG PORT River's Edge Is a misnomer for the restaurant (PL 83258) at midblock between 99th and 50th Streets, its brightgreen awning edging First Avenue. Formerly a delicatessen and open since last Decem- ber, this unpretentiously pleasant and friendly spot has a nice cocktail oasis by the front window. A few feet away, a young man named Richard Currier plays and sings at the piano from 6 P.M. until around midnight Tuesday through Saturday.

title: Principle's Price
description: Who can oppose human rights? Most Americans rank them with God, Mother and Country. What we will do about them is another matter. The gap between preaching and practice may leave both human rights and Jimmy Carter the losers.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Up In Europe
description: The dollar, buoyed by news of a smaller United States trade deficit in May than in recent months, was slightly higher in European foreign exchange trading yesterday. The Associ- ated Press reported. But, in later trading in New York, it declined on news

title: ExOfficials of Puerto Rican Poverty Agency Indicted
description: Three former officials of the Puerto Rican Community Development Project were indicted yesterday on charges of grand larceny, perjury and conspiracy.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, June 19, to Sunday, June 25), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: 86 SOCIAL WORKERS GIVEN SUSPENSIONS
description: Eightysix caseworkers and unit supervisors who work for New York City have been suspended, after staging a wildcat walkout Monday at the Brooklyn field office that handles reports of child abuse and neglect. Fifteen more were reported away from their jobs, and therefore facing suspension, and 50 or 60 pickets demonstrated outside.

title: Fund Raising: Few Givens
description: THE AMERICAN Cancer Society recently held A Night on the Nile in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom, which was festooned for the occasion with sheaves of wheat, 14foot palm trees and specially designed tablecloths. Peter Duchin's orchestra provided music and Thomas Hoving illumined guests with a slide show and lecture on the upcoming King Tutankhamen exhibition at the Metropolitan. It was black tie, of course, and tickets were $150 each. The evening netted over $100,000.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Corn
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)  An additional 200,000 metric tons of United States corn have been sold by private traders to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said today. That brought to 14.1 million tons the amount of grain bought by the Russians under the second year of an agreement with the United States. For the year ending Sept. 30, the Russians have purchased about 3.4 million tons of wheat and 10.7 million tons of corn, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Yanks Winin 14th On Nettles Homer
description: The Guidry Express, also known as the Yankees skinny, 160pound Ron Guidry, couldn't derail Boston's roaring 25car freight train by himself last night, but the Yankees defeated the Red Sox nonetheless, 64, on Graig Nettles tworun homer in the 141% inning.

title: Carey Announces Express Service To Kennedy by Bus and Subway
description: Starting about Sept. 24, there will, for the first time, be express subwaybus service from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport, Governor Carey officially announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Some 20 families who have been living part of each year in primitive isolation in an eightmile area of Fire Islandtheir only visitors an occasional deer, fox, or aquatic birdmay have to abandon their small clapboard houses if the Federal Government has its way. The Government. has moved in Federal Court in Brooklyn. to require the families who built their cottages as squatters 25 to 30 years ago, to move out within the next iew weeks.

title: Senate Vote Bars Fee on Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The Senate voted today to remove President Carter's authority to impose oilimport fees, despite assertions that the move would cause political problems for the President at next month's economic summit.

title: Two Rastafarians Acquitted
description: Two Rastafarian brothers were acquitted in State Supreme Court, Queens yesterday of charges of murdering another member of their sect. in June 1976. Erroll Jackson, 30 years old, and his brother, uswaid, 26, had been accused of shooting to death 20-year-old Ronald Hylton, who lived at 10466 212th Street in Queens. The jury deliberated only two hours after a month of testimony.

title: New Jersey's Chief Toxicologist Defends CurareTesting Method
description: HACKENSACK, N.J. June 27New Jersey's chief toxicologist, in his fourth day under crossexamination by the defense at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, strongly defended today his use of R.I.A., or radio immunoassay, to detect curare in bodies of the alleged victims exhumed after a decade.

title: Carter Using OldLine Democrats For Advice on Wooing Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Iune 27The Carter Administration, concerned by the political obstacles it has encountered on Capitol Hill in its first 16 months, is turning to some seasoned Democratic insiders for practical advice on the care and feeding of Congress.

title: CITY AID BILL HEADS FOR FLOOR IN SENATE
description: The bill to provide New York City with $1.5 billion in a 15year loan guarantees was expected to come before the Senate today amid indications that it would pass essentially as it was reported out of the Banking Committee two weeks ago.

title: Union of Public Employees Votes To Open Drive for Tax Changes
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 27The millionmember municipal employees union formally voted today to battle the socalled meatax approach to the Proposition 13 taxcutting movement by joining the tax revolt.

title: The U.S. vs. Israel
description: It is clear to everyone that the Uoited States is about to mount a new car Taign to pressure Israel into greater flexibility. What is not so clear is that the only way the Israelis can demonstrate flexibility in American eyes is by agreeing to the eventual establishment of an independent Palestinian state on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip which would in all likelihood be dominated by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Judge Reserves Decision on Move By Socialist VVorkers to Jail Bell
description: Arguments were heard yesterday in a move to hold Attorney General Griffin B. Bell in contempt of court and to send him to jail for disobeying a judge's order to release Government files on 18 informers who spied on the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Jockey's Family Is Suing For $10 Million in Death
description: BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP)The family of Robert Pineda, a 25-year-old jockey who was killed May 3 in a fourhorse pileup at Pimlico Race Course, filed a $10 million wrongfuldeath suit today in Federal court here.

title: 60,000 Vietnamese Are Said to Invade Areas of Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, June 28 (AP)  About 60,000 Vietnamese troops have invaded Cambodia in what could be the biggest- military operation in more than six months in the frontier war between the two Communist countries, Thai military sources said today.

title: Arlen Gives New Officer A Mandate
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, one of the nation's largest realestate companies and the operator of the Korvettes departmentstore chain, is preparing to acquire a series of nonrelated companies as well as garner a greater return from existing properties.

title: The China Connection
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The hardest things for this city to handle these days are the blurry lines between one policy and another at home and abroad. Washington wants a clear sharp line from President Carter be- tween high property taxes and adequate public services, between inflation and unemployment, the Israelis and the Arabs, the Soviets and the Chinese, but there are no clear lines, and Mr. Carter refuses to choose up sides.

title: Hamilton F. Potter,  An Ex

title: A Film by Beatty:A Remake of 1941
description: THERE is something eerily disconnected about "Heaven Can Wait." It may be because in a time of comparative peace, immortality  at least in its life-after-death form  doesn't hold the fascination for us that it does when there's a war going on, as there was in 1941 when "Here Comes Mr. Jordan" was released and became such a hit. Or perhaps we are somewhat more sophisticated today (though I doubt it) and comedies about heavenly messengers and what is, in effect, a very casual kind of transubstantiation seem essentially silly.Whatever the reason, "Heaven Can Wait," Warren Beatty's remake of "Here Comes Mr. Jordan," gives the impression of being a swinging 1978 romantic comedy struggling to free itself from the body of the 1941 film. Most of the time it remains locked in, embraced by the unyielding requirements of its elaborate, facetious plot gimmick.This, as in "Here Comes Mr. Jordan," which also was based on a play titled "Heaven Can Wait," is about a professional athlete, a star quarter-back with the Los Angles Rams, who is accidentally gathered by a heavenly messenger before his time has come. When the mistake is realized, the athlete, named Joe Pendleton (Mr. Beatty), is escorted back to earth to find a suitable body to inherit so that Joe can go on to play in the Super Bowl. That, unfortunately, is just the beginning, though it takes so much screen time to tell that the audience is always ahead of it.The surprise is that "Heaven Can Wait" is as much fun as it is when it has to waste so much energy in the service of a gimmick that we would now endure only in a pilot film for a projected television series titled "I Dream of Joey."The movie, which opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters, is a hybrid of no great style but of a good deal of charm and with a marvelous cast headed by Julie Christie, Jack Warden, Dyan Cannon, Buck Henry, James Mason and Mr. Beatty, who stars in the film, produced it, co-directed it (with Mr. Henry) and co-wrote the screenplay (with Elaine May).Only time and innate modesty, I assume, prevented him from acting as his own assistant producer.Though updated from the 40's, the May-Beatty screenplay seems to follow closely the earlier film, written by Sidney Buchman and Seton I. Miller, yet only Harry Segall, the author of the play, is given screen credit. Some of the film's best moments, however, are random inspirations of dialogue and bits of business that recall the tone of Miss May at the peak of her comic form.The film's funniest characters are not played by Mr. Beatty or Julie Christie (as the spunky English girl Joe Pendleton falls in love with). They are Joe's wife (when he is in the body of a wealthy nut named Farnsworth) and her lover, a pair of scheming, would-be murderers of the sort Miss May showed such fondness for in "A New Leaf." The characters are well written and beautifully played by Dyan Cannon and Charles Grodin.I suspect that no one but Miss May (and possibly Buck Henry) would envision a scene in which one of the murderers, expecting at any minute to be discovered, says to his accomplice when the police are about to enter the drawing room, "Pick up 'The Fountainhead' and pretend to be reading."The film's associations to time are nothing if not eclectic. Memories of "Here Comes Mr. Jordan" evoke the 1930's and early 40's. "The Fountainhead" suggests the late 40's and early 50's. The Rams and pro football are very much of today, while the very funny populist speech that Joe Pendleton delivers (in the body of Mr. Farnsworth to a board of directors' meeting) recalls Frank Capra's comedies of the mid-30's. All of which may lead you to believe  correctly  that "Heaven Can Wait" hasn't much personality of its own.Instead it has a kind of earnest cheerfulness that is sometimes most winning. Mr. Beatty and Miss Christie are performers who bring to their roles the easy sort of gravity that establishes characters of import, no matter how simply they are drawn in the script. Neither James Mason as Mr. Jordan, the fellow in charge of recently gathered souls, nor Mr. Henry, as the messenger who botched his first job, have much to do, but they are presences we recognize. In a much more colorful part, that of Joe Pendleton's trainer, Jack Warden must bridge the gap between the film's sentimental impulses and its lunatic comedy, and he succeeds with ease.All of these people, though, are upstaged by a plot that keeps butting into the movie just as it's building some comic momentum. There's nothing worse than a pushy narrative."Heaven Can Wait," which has been rated PC ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some language that, I suppose, could be called grown-up if not adult, but there is nothing else in the movie to disturb the smallest mind.
