title: Film: Peckinpah's 'Convoy,' Open-Road Machismo:Truckers and Women
description: CONVOY," which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is Sam Peckinpah's multimillion-dollar "B" picture, the sort of movie about men who drive trailer trucks, and the women who love them, which has been made before much less expensively and much more entertainingly by directors with no aspirations to be artists. "Convoy" is a bad joke that backfires on the director. He has neither the guts to play the movie straight as melodrama nor the sense of humor to turn it into a kind of "Smokey and the Bandit" comedy.The movie is a big, costly, phony exercise in myth-making, machismo, romance-of-the-open-road nonsense and incredible self-indulgence. It takes its large cast of good actors and makes a fool of each one of them, including Kris Kristofferson, who plays a trucker whose CB radio handle is Rubber Duck, a fellow so laid-back he seems horizontal even when walking upright, and Ali MacGraw, who, for reasons that remain forever obscure, has had her hair clipped like Maria's in "For Whom the Bell Tolls."Miss MacGraw is supposed to be a classy society photographer, a woman of intelligence and realized sexuality, but the effect of the haircut is to make Mr. Kristofferson's girlfriend look like an exceedingly pretty boy.This may well be one of Mr. Peckinpah's more knowing sexist gags, but because the movie is so muddled or nasty in every other way, I don't feel like trying to decipher the point. To transform a naturally beautiful woman into a figure of such androgyny seems, at best, short-sighted; at worst, it's mean-spirited.That may be to credit "Convoy" with more consistent purpose than it has. The screenplay by B.W.L. Norton, based on C.W. McCall's song about a showdown between a group of independent truckers and the law, attempts to be both funny and serious. It asks us to admire the free spirit of the truckers who own their own rigs, who love their trucks as cowboys used to love their horses, and who represent  or so we are told  a vanishing breed of Americans whose backbone made this country great.I could buy that in earlier Peckinpah movies like "The Wild Bunch," "The Ballad of Cable Hogue" and "Junior Bonner," but here the director is sending himself up but not in any healthy, good-humored way. There is a feeling of desperation about "Convoy."It's like finding Mr. Peckinpah as the star of a carnival sideshow. There is still talent evident, but the backbone has rotted away. Here's a fellow, you feel, with no pride, no scruples, who'd sell his grandmother for 5 percent of the gross.The movie has the form of one long, occasionally interrupted chase as the independent truckers, objecting to unrealistic speed limits and corrupt highway cops, flee across Arizona to New Mexico. There are roadside-diner brawls filmed in slow-motion, a couple of spectacular traffic violations and a lot of scenery so pretty it would tone up any post card.The supporting cast includes Ernest Borgnine as a vicious, bigoted cop; Burt Young, as a trucker who hauls pigs and fancies himself a ladies' man; Seymour Cassel, as an opportunistic and foolish state Governor, and Madge Sinclair, as a woman trucker who is black and who, maybe significantly, is the only trucker to have a major accident in the course of the film."Convoy," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some coarse language and mildly suggestive sex scenes.

title: In a Hot Season, Hot Seasonings
description: HOT season, hot seasonings is an epigram that lovers of fiery sauces might well consider embroidering on samplers to adorn their kitchen walls. For though devotees of fiery condiments indulge their preferences the year round, summer seems a peak period for such longings, and on this matter I speak first hand. Just let the mercury hover in the 90's for a day or two and my thoughts on eating inevitably turn toward the dishes of Szechwan or Hunan, India or the Caribbean, Mexico or Southeast Asia, or to the Tasco chili zapped specialties of Texas and Louisiana.

He educated many generations of Pediatric Interns and residents and made many contributions in his chosen specialty. We extend our heart. felt sympathies to his family In their bereavement.

title: Stay of Execution Granted

Powell Jr. today granted a stay of execution to James David Raulerson, a prisoner in Florida convicted of fatally shooting policeman in 1975. Justice Powell ordered that the death sentence not he carried out until Mr. Raulerson could file a formal appeal with the Supreme Court and it cculd act on his petition. That will not be until next fall or winter at the earliest, since the Court is winding up its current session this week and will not return until October.

A for. mer General Motors executive, John De Lorean, who had originally been negotiating with the Irish Republic to take over an empty tire cord factory at Limerick, has been attracted to Ulster by grants of up to 50 percent of initial costs. The site for the factory is Dunmurry, about six miles south of Belfast, In an area that has been relatively free from violence.

title: Pulling the Plug on New York's Water

The board had become publicly disreputable largely because its members were appointed for life terms by the Mayor and because they were charged with not doing much to earn their $25,000 yearly stipends. Limited terms would be preferable, but the accusation of indolence is hard to sustain.

title: And Who Will Bail Out Diplomacy?
description: The Great Bail Swap may have been the only way out of the awkwardness of the moment, but it does no credit to either the United States or the Soviet Union. The periodic barter in spies has been an unavoidable accommodation between their intelligence services and legal systems. But both Governments know that this dirty business needs to be insulated from all other transactions. If it is confused with normal standards justice, the precarious open traffic in Ideas and goods between the two societies will not long survive the hidden wars of espionage.

title: Books of The Times
description: LET me enthuse. I didn't think, before I read Better Times Than These; that a convenNom tional war story could do justice to Vietnam. I thought the nightmare of that unprecedented military experience  unprecedented for Americans, at any rate would demand an innovative form of fiction to convey its peculiar horror  a dream form of narrative lying somewhere beyond the black absurdity of Catch22. But Winston Groom's tragicomic first novel proves this assumption incorrect. For he has marshaled the familiar conventions of American war fiction  a cast of, characters that includes everyone from the dumb Southern farm boy to the thoughtful Jewish officer, to the Queeglike battalion commander; junglefighting setpieces that we've known since The Naked and the Dead (there are even a case of snakebite and an attack by a swarm of bees), and the fall from a sense of glory to disillusion that Philip Caputo caught so well in A Rumor of War. And Mr.. Groom has fashioned them into a mirof hell that leaves

title: Botanists Find Ancient Leaves Are Still Green
description: The most perfectly preserved specimens of living tissue from the distant past have been discovered by a team of botanists from the New York Botanical Garden and the University of North Carolina, The specimens are tree leaves that are 16 million to 36 million years old but that remain green and intact down to the membranes, organelles and other microscopic structures inside the cells.

title: Personal Health
description: THESE days Rocky Mountain spotted fever is something of a misnomer. Although it was first identified in the late 1800's in the Rocky Mountains where It pri- madly infected lumberjacks, hunters and trappers, today only 5 percent of the cases Occur there. Now it's a nationwide problem, with more than half the cases diagnosed among residents of the Southeast, and the majority of victims are children.

title: Newport Jazz
description: THE week of the NewportNew: York Jazz Festival is tradition. ally a time when big bands gather. Count Basie, Machito, Tito Puente and Maynard Ferguson havealreadv performed with the or- chestras, and Buddy Rich, Chick Corea, Lionel Hampton and Stan Kenton will all be leading big bands before the festival ends on Sunday. Bytt this weekend, two very different and very special big bands will be performing. They are led by two formidable tenor saxophonists, Sam Rivers and David Murray, and the jazz they play is new jazz. It is a music usually heard from small combos; when big bands perform it, it can be exceptionally compelling.

title: Jazz: A Tribute to Clifford Brown
description: THE Tribute to Clifford Brown presented by Jack Kleinsinger early in the season as part of his Highlights in Jazz Series seems to have struck a responsive chord in someone connected with the Newport Festival. It was repeated Monday night in its original location, New York University, with most of its original cast playing mostly the same tunes. One hopes it drew a different crowd because of its association with Newport. It was an impressive program when it was first presented, and it was equally impressive the second time around.

title: Backgammon:

Goble gained in stature in 1976, when his overall tournament record surpassed everyone else's. That year, in addition to winning major tournaments in San Francisco and Chicago, he took the World Grandmaster's Cup in Las Hadas, Mexico.

Asked by Mayor Pomeroy if he would be willing to meet with President Carter, Mr. Castro replied, Why not? But I can't suggest it.

description: CHICAGO, June 28I guess I could have been out fishing or something, but then I probably would have just stayed at home and slept, Peter Vovobylski said when asked how he felt about spending his summer mornings in school.

Helicopter, the company's largest division, before the Senate banking Committee. Its investigation last winter delayed the confirmation of G. William Miller, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (AP)The California Supreme Court agreed today to consider three challenges to Proposition 13, the amendment cutting property tax, but refused to delay implementation of the law.

description: MANILA, June 23 (Reuters)A mild learthquake was felt in metropolitan Manila arlri nearby Bataan Province today but no damage or casualties were reported. The geophysical observatory placed its epicenter at sea 96 miles southwest Of here.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the first edition of Business Day yesterday, a photograph of Laurenice Tisch was misidentified as David Gartner. A correct photograph of Mr. Gartner was published in later editions.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE reason prefinished wood paneling is used on interior walls is that it would appear to be maintenancefree. But owners of: homes with wood paneling eventually discover that this is not entirely true. Good quality factoryfinished paneling will indeed last for many years with only an occasional dusting or other cleaning, but after a time the finish tends to get so dull and cloudy looking that more than a casual cleaning is required to restore its original luster. The surface may also be marred by numerous scratches, nicks and other blemishes.

title: Cosmos Top Aztecs, 21, On a Late Goal by Hunt
description: EAST RUTHERFORD,.N.J., June 28Steve Hunt, who has been drawing lOt of abuse from the fans at Giants Stadium, said tonight he had something to prove to those fans and went out and'did it.

title: Tradition Still Reigns at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 28After weeks of rain and un. seasonable cold, the clouds gave way today to what is referred to in this idyllic town on the Thames as regatta weather. Gardeners wheeled pinkandblue hydrangeas to their planting beds in the Steward's Enclosure. putting final touches to preparations for the 139th rowing of the Henley. Royal Regatta beginning tomorrow morning.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28  W. Michael Blumenthal, the Secretary of the Treasury, today labeled as the sheerest conjecture the assertion that a bill pending in Congress to cut capitalgains taxes would lead to higher stock prices and more capital investment.

title: RULING OF INSANITY ENDS TRIAL FOR SLAYINGS OF
description: A 48yearold Brooklyn lawyer was acquitted yesterday of the murder of his wife and three children on the ground that he was insane at the time and not aware he was committing a criminal act. The lawyer, Robert Rowe of 24.43 East 64th Street in the Mill Basin section, battered his three children to death with baseball hat last Feb. 22 and then waited in the family apartment for his wife to come home from work to kill her, too.

title: Theater: Macbeth Comes. From Atlanta
description: IN Shakespeare's Macbeth, the three weird Sisters appear only four times, and two of those appearances are of the briefest kind. But in the production that a young group from Atlanta, the Theatrical Outfit and Gypsy Rainbow Dance Theater, has brought to the Black Box Theater, 89 West Third Street, through Saturday, the malevolent trio are omnipresent. They are the murderers when Banquo is killed; they are the women who cry out when Macduff's castle is assaulted; they accompany the ghost of Banquo to the feast; they are in attendance when the kingdom is restored to Duncan's son, Malcolm.

title: TV Networks to Produce 3 New Feature Programs
description: The surge of new shows devoted to talk and feature and magazine type of television format has sent network talent scouts on raiding forays to local stations and other places where names and faces that are new to the national audience have been nurtured to prestige in live, spontaneous circumstances.

title: Sound
description: ATELY I have been listening to ghostly voices issuing from a pile of ancient records inherited, so to speak, from a friend Who no longer wanted to give them house room. Among forgettable trivia. the stack yielded a few exquisite rarities by Lawrence Tibbett and other by luminaries of the Metropolitan Opera, along with vintage pop sung by a young vocalist named Frank Sinatra, just starting out with Tommy Dorsey's band. I decided to cull the best from his motley batch and transfer it to cassettes. And to make the voices of the past more alive  less ghostly, that is  I tried several novel devices to truce up the dim sound and remove those.pesky pops and clicks that sprang from the scarred platters.

title: COLISEUM REBUILDING LAGGING IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, June 27Plans to resurrect the Civic Center Coliseum, which collapsed last January only hours after the end of a basketball game attended by a crowd of several thousand, may not be proceeding as smoothly as city officials had promised.

title: Southern Yemeni Radio Mentions Casualties in President's Ouster
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, June 28 (Reuters)The Aden radio made the first official mention today of casualties in the fighting that led to the overthrow and execution of President Salem Robaye All on Monday.

title: A Model Wiretap Bill in Peril
description: After three years of effort by two Administrations, members of both parties and in both houses, Congress is nearing a milestone: a law to regulate national security wiretapping. Does the proposed law protect against. abuses of individual rights in the name of national security'? The American Civil Liberties Union, vigilant against Government becoming a Big Brother, supports it. Does the bill safeguard legitimate security investigations? Federal intelligence agencies, vigilant against making Government a weak sister, support it. The bill passed the Senate by a vote of 95 to 1. But as it approaches what should be an early floor vote in the House, the measure is in danger of sabotage.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: Cabinet work with little or no hardware showing has become the look of today. Whether it is a mirrored storage wall in a dining room or bathroom or a kitchen cabinet, sleek is best.

title: Cost of the July Blackout Is Put At $310 Million in Federal Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 28New York City's blackout last July cost New Yorkers, state and. Federal governments andpeople throughout the country an estimated total of $310 million, according to a Congressional study released today. The figure is twice the estimate made right after the blackout, which lasted 25 hours in some areas, but far less than later estimates of $1 billion.

title: FREDERICK HOLMES, 71; EXTRAINER AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 28Frederick (Bobo) Holmes, a trainer in athletics at Princeton University for 35 years, died Monday at Mercer Medical Center. He was 71 years old and had left Princeton three years ago under the mandatory retirement system.

title: Scientists Unveil Designs for Living Space in Outer Space
description: CHICAGO Perhaps permanent communities in outer space aren't such a far'0;out idea  some scientists are already trying to solve the nittygritty details of where to make the toothpaste and how to popularize rabbit bureers.

title: 14 Powers Agree to Revise Arms Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 28Four of the nuclear powers have reached agreement on revamping the Geneva Disarmament Conference, which has been the main international disarmament negotiating body for 15 years but continues to be boycotted by France and China. The new agreement was worked out i by representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. !Approved by the General Assembly assured tonight, and would enable the current General Assembly to end its five!welt disarmament session tomorrow or Friday with at least one accomplishment.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A general contractor from Clifton pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Newark yesterday to paying nearly $120,000 in kickbacks to members of the Lodi Housing Authority in exchange for work on a public housing project.

title: Gabrielle Ruth Riback Bride of Seymour Propp
description: Gabrielle Ruth Riback, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Sidney B. Riback of Philadelphia, was married in New York yesterday to Seymour Propp, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Propp of New York. The bride's father and Rabbi Leo Jung officiated at the ceremony in the bridegroom's home.

title: New Glamour for the Ritz  And a Casino, Too
description: LONDON, June 28The midst of a week crowded with Ascot, Wimedon and the Henley Regatta, e insatiable London social set a quirky and colorful hodgepodge of aristocrats, starlets, big business wheels, sports stars and high rollers flocked to the Ritz Hotel here last night for the opening of an opulent private gaming club.

title: F.H.A. Lifts Rate to 9%
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)  The Government raised the maximum interest rate on Federal Housing Administration homemortgage loans today from 9 percent to 91/2 percent.

title: The New York Times/Gary Settle
description: TOETAPPING ON WALL STREET: One of a number. of dance groups who performed at lunch hour at Wall and Broad Streets in Lower Manhattan yesterday. The event was a tuneup for a Fourth of July dance party.

title: Boy, 15, Who Killed 2 and Tried To Kill a Third Is Given 5 Years
description: A 15yearold Harlem youth who admitted killing two subway passengers and attempting to kill a subway motorman in one eightday period last March has been sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison.

title: Ruling Termed Helpful To a Case in Colorado
description: BOULDER, Colo., June 28 (UPI)The attorney for a Boulder man who filed a reverse discrimination suit against the University of Colorado said today that he thought the United States Supreme Court ruling on the Allan P. Bakke case would have a positive effect on the outcome of his suit.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS; June 28  The two favorites, Italy and the United States, have qualified for the final of the world women's team championship here tomorrow, but they did it the hard way.

title: News Summary
description: Efforts to curb nuclear arms gained. American attempts to persuade South Africa to sign a treaty banning the spread of such weapons reportedly reached an advanced stage as highlevel officials of the two Governments ended talks in Pretoria. Reports from Washington indicated that South Africa was ready to accept stricter controls to prevent its nuclear energy program from being used to develop weapons. 1page Al, Column 2.1

title: Ground Is. Broken for Apartment Complex for Aged
description: CLIFTON, June 28Construction on a 150apartment housing complex for the elderlythat sponsors call the first of its kind in North Jerseygot under way here today.

title: About New york
description: There was a sunny day in Ossining last week that brushed the Hudson blue and billowed the trees with freedom and made for society's perfect revenge. Men who have done society harm saw the Hudson and the trees reel with life. They watched the day run not and shadowy as the wails of Sing Sing, their prison now known as the State Correctional Facility at Ossining. If rehabilitation is a dead ideal and punishment Is all that's left for motive, then the day was sadistically gorgeous, a thing of righteous beauty.

title: SENATE GETS A BILL ON RELIEF TAKEOVER
description: WASHINGTON. June 28Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and two influential DernOcratic colleagues introduced a $5 billionatyear, no frills welfare bill today that would provide for a Federal takeover of local costs. It would mean an annual saving of about $310 million for New York City.

title: A SoHo Pioneer, But Disenchanted
description: IN 1978, SoHo is considered the place to live.. I live there. I moved to my loft in 1973, when SoHo did not even have a fully stocked grocery store, let alone gourmet shops and boutiques.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL, OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY 1201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 5594600; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Books of The Times
description: OMEN, say Frances and Joseph Gies, have been silent and unsung partners In Medieval history. They do not figure prominently in the pollties, wars and revolutions of unimagi.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW YOU SEE HIM Peter Samelson, known for his legerdemain act in clubs and on the college circuit, is the special guest artist through July 15 at the Magic Towne House. The converted dwelling on Third Avenue just south of 61st Street is a popular weekena snowcase tor magic fans. On the top floor audiences gather informally on Friday and Saturday, from 9:30 P.M.until around 1 A.M., to watch a rotatibg series of illusionists in all kinds of feats.The atmosphere is concentrated, centered on the star of the evening, and also informal, with guests helping themselves to an ample buffet and beverages. No liquor, but you're invited to bring your own.

title: Newport Jazz
description: THE Salute to American Song, which has become an annual feature of the Newport Jazz Festival, has often provided an opportunity for fine singers who are only peripherally a part of the jazz world to be heard at the festival  the late Teddi King, Mabel Mercer and Bobby Short, among others. And, by focusing specific songwriters, it has brought to light some delightful but littleknown songs, such as Cole Porter's Dream Dancing, sung on the Salute in 1973 by Miss King.

title: PBS to Carry 4 Met Operas Live
description: There will be four live telecasts next season, one more than last year, of Metropolitan Opera productions in the Public Broadcasting Service series Live From the Met.

title: A BILL ON WIRETAPS CRITICIZED BY A.T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON. June 28 (AP)American Telephone and Telegraph Company objected today to legislation permitting the Attorney General or Federal judges to order the telephone company to participate in national security wiretaps.

title: 20 Egyptian Military Students Die In Explosion of Old Mortar Shell
description: CAIRO, rune 28 (Reuters)  A mortar shell exploded in the Mediterranean city of Damietta today, killing more than 20 students and injuring about 20, Interior Ministry sources reported.

title: United Press International
description: UNENVIABLE POSITION: The fishing boat Bob Kat N, from Brielle, N.J., perched on a rock orr city island wnere it ran aground during high tide. It was freed with a bargemounted crane.

title: High Living On the QE2
description: THE best things in life are free, but the nexttobest things tend to be expensive.

title: Letters
description: There is a whole world out here of women who are not buffeted by every fad  every whim of the media. They are not lined up for face lifts, disco openings, asexual movements. They are married to the same man who went to the altar with them in their youth. They are alive and well.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: D'Ambrosio's Catwalk Wins 7Horse Jumpoff
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 28Catwalk, owned and ridden by Anthony D'Ambrosio Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., won the intermediate jumper class in a jumpoff against seven rivals today at the Lake Placid horse show.

title: Indians Given Permission to Use Capital Site for DeMonstrations
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Leaders of a nationwide walk to protest legislation they deem antiIndian have won permission to use the grounds at the Washington Monument for eight days of demonstrations next month.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Leave it to the Italians to come up with a platform bed whose headboard and poufs can be rearranged at will to turn a bedroom into a living room, or even to create an extra bed. Called Atollo, its the most versatile of a series of designs introduced here recently by Sleeping SystemItalia. Some of the beds are curved, some are angular. but all are totally covered with fabric. In fact, part of the upholstery turns out to be a comforter which is difficult to believe when the bed is made, because the fabric fits so snugly. The lining of the comforter is matched to the sheet that comes with the bed, for total coordination. The Atollo design offers a queen size or twin size mattress. The queen size is $1,900 for the 92by94inch fabriccovered platform, mattress, comforter and sheet, three poufs that when turned upside down become end tables, and a removable headboard that can be used as a single bed. It's at W & J Sloane on the fifth floor, in a black and white checked cottonandrayon fabric; other fabrics are available on special order. The twin size, which is on the store's fourth floor in a natural homespun blend of linen and cotton, is $1,599 including the 47by94inch platform, mattress, comforter and sheet, two large poufs and two small ones. The poufs can be lined up on the platform next to the mattress to make a double bed or placed on the mattress to create multilevel seating.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A proposed reduction in capital gains taxes was attacked by W. Michael Blumenthal, the Treasury Secretary, who said it was the sheerest conjecture that such a reduction would lead to higher prices in the stock market and greater capital investment by industry. But Representative William Steiger countercharged that the Carter Administration suffered froma deeprooted confusion over the difference between income and capital. [Page D1].

title: Youth Sitting on Track Killed
description: A 15yearold youth who had been sitting on Long Island Rail Road train track in Forest Hills, Queens, was killed last night when he failed to jump out of the way of an oncoming train, the police said. The youth was not immediately identified. The police said the train hit the youth at 11:45 P.M., about four blocks east of the Forest Hills station. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Dispute Over Hours of Police Lieutenants Appears Ended by Impasse Panel Ruling
description: A oneman impasse panel reccmmended yestarday that the daily wcrking time of police lieutenants should be eight hours and 15 minutes and that they should work 253 tours a ye4r.

title: Deaths
description: LEVINELeon H. The Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Ave, records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, Dr. Leon H. Levine. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife. Fanny J. Levine & all the members of his family.

title: Excerpts From Opinions by Supreme Court Justices in the Allan P. Bakke Case
description: For the reasons stated in the following opinion, I believe that so much of the judgment of the California court as holds petitioner's special admissions program unlawful and directs that respondent be admitted to the medical school must be affirmed. For the reasons expressed in a separate opinion, my brothers the Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens concur in this judgment.

title: President to Name ExIsrael Lobbyist As Jewish Liaison
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Carter intends to appoint a leading member of the American Jewish community to be a principal adviser on matters affecting the nation's Jews and to help sell Administration policy to them, White House sources said today.

title: GUIDANCE IS PROVIDED
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court by 5to4 vote affirmed today the constitutionality of college admission programs that give special advantage to blacks and other minorities to help remedy oast discrimination against them.

title: Events Today
description: ANNIE GIST YOUR GUN,. musical by Irving Berlin; musical director, Jay Blackton; book by Herbert and Dorothy Fields; choreography by Bert Michaels; starring Lucie Arnez and Harve Presnell; at the Jones Beach Theater, Wentagh.

title: Blacks in Congress Urge Caution For Carter on Arms Aid to Africa
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Reuters)The Congressional Black Caucus has called on President Carter to exercise caution in sending military aid to African countries.

title: U.S. and Europe Said to Patch Up AtomFuel Dispute
description: PARIS, June 28Western Europe and the Carter Administration have patched up, at least temporarily, their quarrel over tighter safeguards for American nuclear reactor fuel, which led the United States to cut off new supplies to its European allies last April, according to French officials.

title: Palm Oil Imports Rankle US. Farrriers
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Few urban Americans realize it, but the hamburgers and french fries they buy in many restaurants may well have been cooked partly in Malaysian palm oil, the juice from the berries of tropical palm trees.

title: The Great Fastball Debate
description: Perhaps the most fascinatingelement in sports is speed. The world's fastest human. The 200mileperhour lap auto racing. The big serve in tennis. Clubhead speed in golf. 0. J. Simpson running away from defensive backs. Muhammad Ali's hands. The fast break. The blur of a hockey puck. And in baseball, the fastball. Especially the fastest fastball. Nolan Ryan of the California Angels once had his fastball timed at 100.9 m.p.h. back in 1974, the fastest recorded time in baseball history. But there are those, notably Carl

title: Shipping/Mail
description: KAMATERI (NedLloyd). Jeddah July 18 and Muscat 24; sails from Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

title: MONDALE ACTS TO END RIFT OVER ISRAEL TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Vice President Mondale sought to dampen controversy that has threatened to mar his goodwill trip to Israel this weekend by saying he would visit the revered Wailing Wall in the occupied Old City, and that Mayor Teddy KoTrek of Jerusalem could accompany him if he wished.

title: 2 U.S. NEWSMEN GET SOVIET LIBEL CHARGE
description: MOSCOW, June 28Two American reporters were formally accused in a MosOw court today of having libeled Soviet state television by writing articles about an imprisoned dissident's televised confPssion that his friends and relatives believed had been fabricated.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In the forthcoming public debate on recommendations of the President's Commission on Military Compensation it will be important for Americans to recognize the flaws in the current 20year retirement system, defended in a recent OpEd article by J. D. Hittle.

title: Begelman Fined $5,000 In Theft From Columbia
description: BURBANK, Calif., June 28  A Superior Court judge fined David Begelman, a former Columbia Pictures executive, $5,000 and placed him on three years probation today for having allegedly stolen $40.000 from Columbia.

title: CITY BUDGET BACKED BY CONTROL BOARD
description: Brushing aside a warning from Special Deputy State Comptroller Sidney Schwartz, the Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved the city's 1979 budget, its labor settlement and its financial plan.

title: Environmental Agency Studies New Rules Costs
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would analyze all its new regulations, except for some minor and technical matters, to judge their effect on the economy and their costs to the public.

title: C Uruguay Once Shaken by Guerrillas, Asserts Only the Extremists Now Live in Fear
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 23Since 1972, when the military ordered that all political and security cases be tried by courts martial, more than 5,000 people in this country of 2.5 million, or about one in every 500. have been brought to trial. The reasons vary from shooting policeman to painting a slogan on a wall.

title: A Plateau for Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The United States Supreme Court's split decision in the I Allan P. Bakke case means, according to Ithe consensus on both sides, that the great majority of affirmative action programs, public and private, will continue, as will the debate and lawsuits over what constitutes a proper racial balance.

title: Flute of Pan Given By Graham Dancers
description: It is ironic, then, that the premiere given by Miss Graham yesterday afternoon is by its very nature the kind of piece that looks as if it were being viewed through a telescope. Flute of Pan, as it is called, is another Graham treatment of Greek myth but. so totally distant from its subject that it becomes a tantalizing departure in style. it has none of the closeup intensity of the usual Graham Greek pieces in which Miss Graham zeroes with ferocity into the very soul of her heroines or other protagonists.

title: Planning Study Finds That Lingering Bias Could Curb Projected Efforts to Redetielop the State's Cities
description: TRENTON, June 28A regional planning agency reported today that an ex- tensive study had found that most whites in New Jersey's cities retained a lingering prejudice against blacks, and that this could stall efforts to rebuild the state's cities.

title: 2 Hoffa Books Pose Publishing Problem
description: Two follthcOming books on the same controversial subjects  James R. Hoffa and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters covert Tole in American political and criminal lifeton's publisher, who told me he would tight to keep the October publication date. He liked the book and doubled my advance to $10,000. nave pittea their autnors and publishers in a behindthescenes contest, with possible broad implications for publishing Independence or suppression.

title: Carey Names Mediator
description: Joseph Peter Neglia, a Republican state committeeman from Brooklyn, was appointed yesterday by Governor Carey to fill a vacancy on the threemember State Mediation Board. Announcement of the selection of Mr. Neglia, the 54yearold deputy executive director of the New York City Board of Elections and former assistant state industrial commissioner was made by Msgr. James A. Healy, chairman of the state board. Monsignor Healy and Daniel R. McGram, the other members, are Democrats.

title: BELL HAILS DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Among the entire spectrum of people and groups with a stake in the Bakke decision, there were degrees of satisfaction and relief today.

title: A.T.& T.: Borrowing Big in Credit Market
description: Late in 1976, the New York Telephone Company, looking at projected growth and needs to modernize, figured that would have to raise $100 million to $200 million from outside the company in 1978. The second quarter of 1978 seemed a good time to get the giant sum of money. Early in 1977, the date was narrowed down to June. In the fall, June 20, a Tuesday, was picked. The conventional method for New York Telephone of 40year bond debentures was settled on as the best way to raise the cash.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Art Sale of the Century
description: IN the beginning, in the 19th century, there was a German Jew called Robert Hirsch. When he grew up, they made him a baron, Robert von Hirsch, in tribute to his splendid art collection. Driven out of tiermany by the Nazis, he settled and prospered in Basel, Switzerland, and there he died last November at 94 years of age, honored as a gourmet, esthete and man of the world.

title: Army Aids Cincinnati Schools
description: CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP)With the help of the Army, a military school is being developed in the Cincinnati public school system.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Traders in commodity futures turned cautious yesterday, with many of them confining operations to squaring positions before the holiday weekend. Indeed, a preholiday mood pervaded most markets, brokers said..

title: Sails Starting to Billow For Harbor Festival
description: For the four days of this year's Fourth of July celebration, Harbor Festival 78 will remind us of how once was in New York Harbor and how it could be.

title: Deaths
description: HORNSTEINIrving. Suddenly en June 27. Beloved husband of Dorothy, father of William and Enid, brother of Aaron, son of David and grandfather of Adam. Services at 1:15 P.M., June 29, Park West Chapals, 115 W. 79th St., N.Y. In lieu of flowers, a gift to the American Heart Association or your favorite medical researchentIty is suggested.

title: Accounting Report By S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that its five commissioners had given final approval to a report on the accounting. profession that says that substantial progress has been made in remedying some of problems of the profession.

title: N.B.A. Buffalo Club Seeks to Move
description: The National Basketball Association received a request yesterday from John Y. Brown, the coowner of the Buffalo Braves, to shift the franchise to San Diego. Brown's request came amid reports that he had tentatively agreed to switch ownership 01 franchises with Iry Levin, the owner of the Boston Celtics.

title: Buslness People
description: Douglas D. Danforth, who has headed Industry Products, one of the three operating companies that make up the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, yesterday was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of Westinghouse.

title: Kaiser CementMedusa Merger Terms Settled
description: In a $150 million move that would create the nation's largest cement company, the Kaiser Cement and Gypsum Corporation said yesterday that had reached definitive terms for the takeover of the Medusa Corporation.

title: PANEL REPORTEDLY CLEARS SEVERAL IN KOREAN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)The House ethics committee has tentatively voted to clear several Congressmen of misconduct in connection with money they received from Tongsun Park, Congressional sources said today.

title: Who Won?
description: Bakke won. The admissions office of a California medical school lost. But Americans determined to repair a history of discrimination gained the blessing of the Supreme Court to let race and ethnicity count in programs of affirmative action.

title: U. S. Wins First Medal In World Junior Cycling
description: CABIN JOHN, Md., June 28Kicking hard, a fourman United States junior roadcycling squad sprinted furiously across the line at the 45mile team trials race today to win an unexpected prize  America's first roadracing triPdal in the sixyear history of the world junior championship.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overtheCounter.

title: Around the Nation
description: COVINGTON, Ky., June 28 (AP)A choking cloud of dhlorine gas engulfed a crowded swimming pool when its filter system failed today, sending more than 300 peoplemost of them childrento area hospitals, the police said.

title: Wait
description: POTTERHamilton Fish. Of St. James, Long Island, N.Y. died June 27, 1978 at St. James, Long Island. Survived by wife Alma M. Potter. two sons Hamilton F., Jr., and Bronson M. and several grandchildren.

title: Harvard Admissions Plan Held a Model of Flexibility
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28Harvard University's admissions practices, which were singled out for praise today by Justice Lewis F. Powell in announcing the United States Supreme Court's decision in the Allan P. Bakke reversediscrimination case, were described by Harvard officials as a loose and subjective system without quotas or a formal, structured plan.

title: Levitt Says Port Authority Allowed Altering of Expense Vouchers
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey negated its own investigation of executive expense account cheating by allowing directors who admitted to falsifications to alter their previously submitted expense vouchers, the New York State Comptroller charged yesterday.

title: Executives Are Quitting TV to Make Movies
description: During the 60's, actors, writers and directors who had made names for themselves in television left the medium at their first invitations to make motion pictures. Their exodus being joined in this decade by televison executives.

title: Assembly in Italy BeginsVoting T oday On New President
description: ROME,. Tune 28A special assembly of more than a thousand members is scheduled to begin voting tomorrow for a new president, and it is not yet clear how many candidates there will be. A long bitter fight is expected.

title: Gunman on a Queens Street Fires One. Shot, Wounding Two Persons
description: A 13ycarold girl and a 25yearold man were shot and wounded by a single bullet yesterday evening on a street in Jamaica, Queens, by a man who was reportedly upset about an open fire hydrant. The man was later arrested.

title: Deaths
description: DeGROOTGerald A. Sot New York State Police.,Suddenly June 24, 1978 of Watertown, New York. Formerly of Hollis and Garden City, N.Y. Beloved husband of Mary E. Devoted father of Robert, Katherine, Patricia and Andrew. Son of Gertrude V. and the late John F. Brother of John F. and Robert J.. Private Services were held.

title: Individual, Sporadic Conservation Resulting From High Energy Costs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 27A new energy policy is forming in this country as states and localities, spurred by new Federal laws and grants, draw up energy conservation plans that rely on voluntary participation and economic incentives.

title: Boy, 15, Who Killed 2 and Tried To Kill a Third Is Given 5 Years
description: A 15yearold Harlem youth who admitted killing two subway passengers and attempting to kill a subway motorman in one eightday period last March has been sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison.

title: 17 Die in Motor Home Crash
description: BOULEVARD, Calif., June 28 (AP)Seven persons in a motor home were killed today when the vehicle hit a guard rail on Interstate 8, overturned and caught fire, the California Highway Patrol said. Investigators said that the victims, three adults and four children, were not immediately identified, but the vehicle carried Illinois license plates.

title: Five Found Slain at Boston Disco In Apparent Dispute Over Drugs
description: BOSTON, June 28 (AP)Five men were slain in the basement of a downtown disco last night in a gangland dispute over drugs, the police said today.

title: NNE STRIKES DOWN NEW YORK DRUG LAW
description: A Federal judge overturned a 1949 New York State law yesterday that said the presence of narcotics in an automobile was presumptive evidence that everyone riding in the automobile knowingly possessed the narcotics.

title: Q&A
description: I have had a home two blocks Q. from the ocean for about 13 years and had no problem with the paint until this last fall, A new coat of paint began to peel after about a month, taking off the old paint down to the bare wood. What could have caused this?  G.F., Bethethy, Md.

title: A Reaction of Disappointment on the Davis Campus
description: DAVIS, Calif., June 28There were not many people on campus here today. But those attending summer school or working at the University of California at Davis generally opposed the United States Supreme Court decision striking down quotas for minorities entering the medical school here.

title: GUIDANCE IS PROVIDED
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court by a 5to4 vote affirmed today the constitutionality of college admission programs that give special advantage to blacks and other minorities to help remedy past discrimination against them.

title: Injunction Dropped By Merrill Lynch
description: A request by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith for a preliminary injunction against Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company and eight former employees of White Weld & Company  since acquired by Merrill Lynch  was withdrawn yesterday.

title: Advertising
description: IT is just possible that the next youngster you meet may be either Superman, Spiderman or Wonder Woman or at least be wearing the proper secret uniform of same.

title: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes
description: Inmates at the Ossining (N.Y.) Correctional Facility relaxing In the prison yard on a sunny morning. The tall walls are never far away.

title: Rhodesian Guerrilla Leader Dies As Land Mine Blows Up a Vehicle
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 28 (AP)A land mine blew up a vehicle near the Rhodesian border today and killed a leading black Rhodesian guerrilla commander, it was confirmed by Joshua Nkomo, coleader of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance.

title: Deaths
description: ATESHOGLOUAnastasis D. on June 27, 1978 Civil Engineer, beloved husband of Maria Elsa. Devoted father of Helena and Steven. Reposing at Cooke Funeral Home, 85th St & 3rd Ave, NYC. Services at The Greek Cathedral 319 E 74 St, NYC Friday 12 noon. Visiting hours 6 to 9:30PM.

title: Ali Helping Rossman in Bid for Title
description: With some encouragement from Muhammad Ali, Mike Rossman vowed yesterday to bring the world lightheavyweight championship back to the United States, where it belongs.

title: Sports Today
description: Niels vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (TelevisionChannel 9, 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWMCA. WGLI, 7:30 P.M.)

title: REA Express: 5 More Indicted
description: A continuing Government investigation into operations of REA Express Inc. before its bankruptcy in November 1975 brought five more indictments yesterday.

title: Witco to Seek Southwest
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation plans to make a cash tender offer to purchase all of the stock of Southwest PetroChem Inc., Wichita, Kan. The offer, which has been submitted to the board of Southwest, will be conditioned on Witco's purchase of not less than 955,000 Southwest shares. These shares represent about 60 percent of Southwest's 1,591,492 outstanding shares. The companies have entered into option arrangements permitting Witco to acquire, before July 31, about 655 Sopthwest shares for $12.50 cash each.

title: Jewish Activist Stands Trial In Soviet After Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (AP)Iosif Begun. activist, looking weak after a 40day hunger strike, Stood trial toda'y on charges of having violated Soviet passport laws but the verdict was not made public, his wife said.

title: U.S. Sells 8% Bonds, A Record
description: The Federal Government yesterday sold $1.75 billion in 15year bonds that will carry an interest rate of 8% percent, the highest coupon the Treasury has ever put on a longterm bond issue in the 188 years it has been in existence. Treasury bonds have often yielded more in the secondary market, and shorterterm Government securities have also yielded more. The Treasury in 1974 sold threemonth bills at a peak rate of 9.908 percent, and it also sold sixyear 9 percent notes that year. an issue that is still outstanding. Up till. now, however, the peak rate for longterm Treasury bonds has been 8 percent, the coupon set on an issue of 25year bonds also sold in 1974 that will mature in 1999.

title: MAJORITY IN POLL OPPOSE CASINOS IN THEIR STATES
description: Legalized casino gambling of the kind now operating, in Las Vegas, Nev., and Atlantic City would not be welcomed in other states, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: World Oil Use Rises
description: LONDON, June 28 (AP)  World energy demand rose by 3.5 percent in 1977 and total oil consumption increased by slightly more than 3 percent to nearly 3 billion tons, the British Petroleum Company reported today.

title: I'm the President.
description: WASHINGTON, June 28I'm the President, Mr. Carter felt it necessary to say in his latest press conference; I make the decisions...

title: TWO GERMAN JESUITS ARE SLAIN IN RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 28Two German Jesuits were shot to death at a remote hospital station yesterday, becoMing the 14th and 15th missionaries killed in Rhodesia this month by attackers believed to be black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Remerithering a Bad Violinist
description: The city, the local school board and a lot of other people recently agreed that a playground should be built in back of P.S. 41  the Greenwich Village School at 11th Street and Sixth Avenue  in memory of its hestknown principal, Irving Kreitzberg, who died three years ago. It's one more proof that, for all its vain cosmopolitanism, New York is the most parochial of cities, with its thousands of block associations, its groups of citizens determined to do some good.

title: Brooklyn Picketing By Social Workers Gains No Support
description: Suspended Brooklyn social workers yesterday picketed the Office for Special Services for Children, at 80 Lafayette Street, but no service disruptions in support of the job action developed at the division's other borough offices.

title: GARDENING Mountain Laurel Blooms In the Densest Shade
description: The mountain laurel is spectacular this year  nature's rornpericatinn fnr the browned rhododendron leaves and nipped azalea buds the harsh winter left. The mountain laurel leaves are a handsome deep green, the tiny flower buds are quilted puffs with curious pouches near the bottom. They opeh and spread into tiny cups of white petals.

title: No More Pencils, No More Books, No More Teachers
description: When the bell sounds at 3 o'clock this afternoon at Intermediate School 44 in Manhattan and hundreds of other public schools in the city, the summer vacation will officially begin. But most of the schoolchildren will have left hours or even days earlier after having picked up their report cards.

title: Jazz: Hannibal Peterson Adds to the Musical Legacy ofJohn Coltrane
description: HANNIBAL PETERSON'S performance at the Public Theater Tuesday night was an inspiring example of how much remains to be done with the legacy of the late John Coltrane. The Coltrane style of improvising ana group organization has long since become a clich in lesser hands, but Mr. Peterson is the kind of musician who can take a series of onechord vamp figures, some simple African rhythms, an originalmelody or two, and plenty of energy and make the whole thing come alive.

title: United Press International
description: MONTE CARLO, June 28 This town seemed only half dressed up: A few redandwhite Monagasque flags and blue, white and red French tricolors were bunched together here and there to symbolize the union of Princess Caroline of Monaco, 21 years old, anti her fiance, Philippe Junot, 38, a French financial counselor who works out of his living room in Paris.

title: Dodger Presses Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28 (UPI)Tony Mendoza of El Monte, Calif., who allegedly smashed a beer bottle on the head of Reggie Smith, the Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder, Saturday night was charged today with assault and battery with a deadly weapon. Smith said he was approached in the Dodger Stadium parking lot by two men after a loss to the Cincinnati Reds. He told the police the men asked for his autograph and when he refused, one of them smashed the bottle on his head while another broke the windshield of his car.

title: Albany Legislative Session: Helping Business
description: ALBANY, June 27  The New York State Legislature spent much of its regular session this year trying to live down its reputation for social largesse, doing instead what it could to please business.

title: Disks: Piaf's First American Concert
description: IN January 1957; Edith Piaf, whose previous performances in the United States had been in intimate supper clubs such as the Versailles (aside from a brief appearance 10 years earlier in a Broadway EDITH PIAF: At Carnegie Hall, Jan. 13, 1957. Peters International PLC 2014/15, two disks. revue that starred Les Compagnons de la Chanson), made her American concert debut at Carnegie Hall. At the. time, she had not worked for a year and she had been going through some severe (even by her standards) personal crises. But the evening was a complete triumph. She had an adoring audience and won glowing reviews.

title: Yankees Bow to Brewers by 50, 72
description: CHICAGO, June 28Ken Holtzman, the mystery man of baseball, pitched four innings for the Cubs against the Mets today in his comeback after long months of having done virtually nothing while drawing $165,000 a year from the Yankees.

title: Ferguson and His Band Play the BigBand Gig
description: PERSONAL tastes being a personal matter, critics tend to give the benefit of a doubt to competently executed music that does not appeal to their particular sensibilities. At least this music critic does. But sometimes music will strike one as so boorish, heavyhanded and banal that few redeeming qualities can be discerned. The Maynard Ferguson big band's Newport Jazz Festival performance Tuesday night in Avery Fisher Hall struck this writer just that way.

title: Dance: janak Khendry in Bharat Natyam Style
description: JANAK KHENDRY approaches the Indian Classical dance form of Bharat Natyam from a somewhat specialized point of view. A North Indian, he has chosen to perform a more stylized form of dance associated with the South of India. And Mr. Khendry is a sculptor by profession. So his concert of traditional and new dances in the Bharat Natyam style on Tuesday at the Carnegie Recital Hall was an Indian Classical dance performance with a difference.

His time was 16 minutes 32.6 seconds. Remulus Della Valle of the East Coast A.C. finished second among the 232 starters, all of whom finished the race. Lauri Pedrian of the Greater New York A.A., in 40th place, was the first woman to finish, clocking 19:32.

title: About Newyork
description: There was a sunny day in Ossining last week that brushed the Hudson blue and billowed the trees with freedom and made for society's perfect revenge. Men who have done society harm saw the Hudson and the trees reel with life. They watched the day run not atm snauowy as tne wails of Sing Sing, their prison, now known as the State Correctional Facility at Ossining. If rehabilitation is dead ideal and punishment is all that's left for motive, then the day was sadistically gorgeous, a thing of righteous beauty.

description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 28; (UPI)Health authorities today reported six more cases of poliomyelitis among! fundamentalist Protestants who refuse; vaccination on religious grounds. The new cases brought the total in recent weeks to 67, most of them involving young children. The fundamentalists oppose vaccination on the ground that their fate is in the hands of God.

title: Notes on People
description: THE South African National Theater hal been notified by Golds MeIr, former Prime Minister of Israel, that she opposes the production of Golda, the William Gibson play based on her life for allwhite audiences only in South Africa. Mrs. Meir, who shares the playwright's royalties, said in Tel Aviv that she had agreed that the play could be shown in South Africa only if it could be seen in theaters open to all races. The play is to open next month in Pretoria, but Yitzhak Unna Israel's Ambassador to South Africa, and diplomats from several other countries have said that they will not attend the opening because of the exclusion of blacks. The play will be performed later in Johannesberg before a mixed audience.

description: WASHINGTON, June 29The United States Government said today that it was following the case of two American reporters in Moscow accused of libel with great concern and seriousness and cautioned the Soviet authorities to reflect very carefully on the broader implications of this issue.

title: E1 Barrio Readies A July 4th Fiesta
description: A Fourth of July celebration guaranteed to turn on Yankee Doodle himself to Hispanic rhythms and flavors will begin Sunday afternoon with dance performances, ending the holiday weekend Tuesday with heavy salsa all day.

title: Anker, Retiring Today, Calls End Of School Strife His Key Legacy
description: In a school system marked for more than a century by political, racial and religious strifeand often by a virtual state of warIrving Anker considers his greatest achievement to be the state of peace that has existed in the schools since he became Chancellor of the New York City svtPni.

title: Every Thursday Is Egg ay at Family's Lower East Side Store
description: Uptown, the movie marquees say Thank God It's Friday, but downtown, a small coterie of shoppers sings hosannas to Thursday or Egg Day on East Seventh Street.

title: 4 New Bus Routes From Wall Street To Bronx Approved
description: In a compromise package, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved four new express bus routes from the Bronx to Manhattan, one of which is to be operated by the Transit Authority.

description: DETROIT June 29The Newspaper Guild, meeting here in its 45th annual convention, unanimously adopted resolution today condemning the Soviet proceedings against Craig R. Whitney of The New York Times and Harold D. Piper of The Baltimore Sun.

description: It was separate tables for Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak last night as 1,500 Democrats gathered at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for their annual $250aplate fundraising j dinner.

title: Missionaries in Rhodesia Bury Dead Without Rancor
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, June 29Eight British missionaries and four young children, battered 1.0 death last weekend by black nationalist guerrillas, were buried here today after a funeral service that evoked powerful themes of mercy, revenge and redemption.

title: New York on the Hoof Three Ways on Sunday
description: Walks through Lower Manhattan, Greenwich Village and along Fifth Avenue, sponsored by, the Municipal Art Society, are scheduled for Sunday. All three tours start at 2 P.M. and cost $3 ($1.50 for members of the society).

description: The Federal Trade Commission issued a formal complaint yesterday challenging the proposed acqusition of Tropicana Products Inc., the citrusfruit company, by the Beatrice Foods Comnanv.

description: Maddog apprehenders and New Yorkers went out in the midday sun yesterday, turning a steaming City Hall plaza into something of a circus.

title: Folk Concert in Scarsdale.
description: A concert tomorrow night at 8 by Robb Goldstein, folk balladeer, will open this summer's series of outdoor concerts at the Greenburgh Nature Cente'r, Dromore Road, Scardala. N.Y. Ttckets are $2 ($1.50 for members of the center); listeners should.bring folding chairs or blankets. In case of rain, the concert will be held indoors in the clubhouse of the Greenburgh Town Park, Heatherdell Road, Ardsley, N.Y. Information: (914) 7233470.

title: Two Charged in Check Scheme
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said that two men, including a commodities broker for the firm of Rosenthal & Company, had been arraigned yesterday on charges of having attempted to defraud five New York banks of $4.5 million. The men had implemented just a fraction of their alleged scheme, however, and most of the money has been recovered, according to the F.B.I.

title: Business and the Law
description: DOVER, DEL. ASK any corporate lawyer on Wall Street what the most important court for business is. Chances are that, after the United States Supreme Court, the answer will be the Supreme Court of Delaware.

title: Japanese Official Reports Pledge By U.S. to Continue Aid to Taiwan
description: TOKYO, June 29 (Reuters)The Japanese Defense Minister, Shin Kanemaru, said today that American officials had told him the United States would keep its commitments to Taiwan.

title: Soviet Spy Suspect Named by Defector Is Said to Go Home
description: GENEVA, June 29A suspected Soviet intelligence agent whose cover as an official of the International Labor Organization was apparently revealed by a defecting Soviet diplomat has failed to report to work since early this month, I.L.O. sources said today.

title: Oil Price May Shift With Dollar
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 29  The dollar cost of oil can go up within a month or so despite the 1978 price freeze agreed on by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at its recent Geneva meeting, according to the Iranian Finance Minister, Mohammed Yeganeh.

title: Carters and Andrus Fish Off Virginia Coast
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 29 (AP)President Carter spent today deepsea fishing aboard a 50foot power boat piloted by a young skipper who described himself as nervous.

title: Rise Likely In Fed Rate And Prime
description: With bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve up sharply again, the expected rise in the Fed's discount rate. is likely very soon, figures releasedyesterday indicated. Based on another set of statistics, a rise in the prime rate. charged by commercial banks is also imminent.

title: EATING HABITS IN U.S. ARE LINKED TO CANCER
description: SEATTLE. June 29Increasing research into the nutritional causes of cancer indicates that the American way of eating and cooking may contribute to 40 percent of the nation's cancer deaths, researchers told the openingsession of national meeting here today.

title: ANTHONY J. DELORENZO
description: BRISTOL, Conn., June 29 (AP)  Anthony J. DeLorenzo, a former Democratic Party national committeeman from Connecticut and a former official in the United Auto Workers union, died yesterday, at New Britain General Hospital at the age of 63.

Grasso, defending herself against charges of election law violations brought in a civil suit, took the witness stand today in Superior Court and testified that neither she nor members of the campaign staff had any authority or control over a number of allegedly false advertisements.

title: Record Pirates: Industry Sings the Blues
description: A century after piracy was stamped out, it is once again a international problem. But today's pirates no longer sport colorful names like Bluebeard or Captain Kidd. Instead, they do business under such ordinary names as David Barnes, and the treasure they seek is not doubloons or pieces of eight but motion pictures, phonograph records and tapes.

title: Books: Herzog's Collected U.N. Speeches
description: BY and large, reading a collection of United Nations speeches by the chief delegate of a country to that body is an act of selfimmolation. That this is not true of Chaim Hermy's eathprino of his speeches is due to a number of reasons. Foremost, of course, is the fact that the Middle East, with Israel as one of its focuses, is high in the consciousness of politically aware people everywhere.

title: Abraham Burack, Publisher And Editor of Writer Magazirr
description: BROOKLINE, Mass. June 29 (UPI)Abraham Saul Burackowner, editor and publisher of Writer magazinedied yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: Free Plays at the Public
description: Two free plays will be presented at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater through July 16. Michael by Ed Bullins, author of The. Taking of Miss Janie, and Passion Without Reason by Neil Harris are part of the ManWoMan series at the Other Stage, 425 Lafayette Street. Performances are at 8 P.M., Tuesday through Sunday. Reservations should be made: 6776350.

title: CAREY, IN SHIFT, BACKS TRIAL IN ADULT COURT FOR SOME JUVENILES
description: ROCHESTER, June 29In an abrupt shift, Governor Carey said today that, under certain circumstances, he would support giving prosecutors the discretion to try juveniles in adult courts if the Legislature approved the money he had requested for improvements in the justice system.

title: Red Sox Rally in Ninth and Set Back Orioles, 43
description: Dennis Martinez of Baltimore stifled the big bats of the Red Sox on three hits until the ninth last night, but then Boston erupted with consecutive home runs by George Scott and Dwight Evans and turned a 31 deficit into a 43 victory. The loss was the eighth in row for Baltimore, for the Orioles Innrrnst Incinp streak in twn vparc.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: In the eyes of Boleslaw and Marie Louise d'Otrange Mastai, the American flag is not so much a patriotic sym. bol as a work of folk art. Flag making developed in this country as a purely native art form, they explain, whereas in Europe designs for national flags were usually regulated by governments. For decades, the Mastais have traveled across this country and abroad, building a collection of 2,000 banners. Ari exhibition of 110 of the Mastai's antique flags, plus 200 related items, is on view at the United States Custom House, 6 World Trade Center (through Aug. 25). No admission charge. Hours: 8:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday through Friday. Information: 2475340.

title: David Taylor Marke, an Editor And PublicRelations Man, at 67
description: David Taylor Marke. an editor and publicrelations man, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old. and lived in West New York, N.J.

title: Connecticut Back in Brokerage Business
description: HARTFORD, June 29  Connecticut Nutmeg Securities Inc. is back in busindss as a registered brokerdealer. But Merrill Lynch it is not: The unusual operation has only one employee and one customer.

title: Stock Volume Lowest. Since May 30
description: Takeovers produced big advances in selected stocks yesterday, as trading volume, for the second session in a row, sank to the lowest level in June.

title: ABC Target in Football Antitrust Suit
description: A company that is experimenting with pay television in Ohio has brought suit against the American Broadcasting Company to restrain the network from keeping Ohio State University tootball games from the cable company's own system.

title: Topics Out of Service
description: I'm aconsumerist, declares Virginia Knauer, who served as Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs to Presidents Nixon and Ford. Her declaration begins a fullpage advertisement for an insurance company, about which Mrs. ICnauer,has only flattering things to say. The company explains that it paid Mrs. Knauer to give us her consumer point of view. We fear that Mrs. Knauer may be running into trouble, much as her sister consumerist Bess Myerson did last year when she edited a drug company booklet which stated that there is no evidence that hair dyes pose a threat to health.

title: New Pianist at Caramoor
description: Garrick Ohlsson, pianist, will replace JeanPhilippe Collard, who is indisposed, as soloist in the concert at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N.Y:, tomorrow night. He will be heard in Mozart's Piano Concerto in B flat (K. 450) and in the same composer's Ch'io mi scordi di te, in which the soprano will be Jessye Norman.

title: Helen Forrest Keeps the 40's Alive
description: Helen Forrest smiled and shook her head as she looked at the flier from Reno Sweeney, the club at 126 West 13th Street, heralding a series of great women of jazz starting there this week. The first name on the list was her own. She is there tonight and tomorrow night and all next week, giving shows at 9 and 11:30 P.M., followed by oneweek engagements of Anita O'Day, Maxine Sullivan and Helen Humes.

title: Tourism Booming Along in New York
description: The Gray Line is so busy this summer that it frequently runs out of tour buses, according to Edward Blaine, its operations director. Its 100bus metropolitan fleet is often fully chartered five days in advance.

description: HAZLET, June 29Not even the arrest early this morning of a teenaged suspect has allayed the fearor the mysteryfor residents on a quiet residential street here whose homes have been bombarded with rocks and jagged pieces of driveway macadam the last three weeks.

description: A band of pyrotechnists slipped into town this week with plans to set the sky on fire.

description: PARIS, June 29The United States and a group of other predominantly Western industrial nations began a $1 billion rescue operation today for Zambia, the financially troubled coppermining country that is playing a central role in efforts to promote a peaceful settlement in nrsivillhnrinn Pilnrinzia.

title: About Real Estate Law to Change on Conversion of Buildings.
description: Within a month or so Governor Carey is expected to sign into law bills affecting two types of real estate activity that have gained momentum in recent months. One is the conversion of loft buildings into residential cooperatives in New York City. The second is the conversion of rental apartment houses into cooperatives in the suburban counties of Westchester, Rockland and Nassau.

title: On the Shore
description: AVARIED spectacle of dancing and troubadors marching bands and spinning wheels, food and planes will move around the city from the Batten to Coney Island for the five days of this elongatec Fourth of July weekend.

title: Films: 'The Cat From Outer Space':Feline Marvel
description: THE opening scenes of "The Cat From Outer Space," which opens in New York today at the Rivoli and other theaters, are a moderately amusing parody of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." Deep-focus photography, flashes of light in the night, unearthly roaring and wailing, chickens squawking, a puzzled farmer with a shotgun and a Labrador retriever that sniffs the air and insouciantly returns to the house.However, we don't have to wait until the end of the film to see the visitor from another galaxy. It won't be giving anything away to say that it turns out to be a quite ordinary-looking male cat wearing a crystal collar.In Disney movies of another era, the collar would simply have been described as magical, like Cinderella's glass slipper. Nowadays it is necessary to say that the collar focuses highly developed telepathic powers. Anyhow, it enables the cat to open doors and windows, to levitate his friends, to freeze his enemies in their tracks, control remote events and, of course, to speak English and probably the language of every other country in which the film is exhibited.Naturally, the Pentagon wants the cat, who goes by the name of Jake. So does a mysterious and unquestionably villainous figure, who knows that the collar would give him control not merely of the world, as a stooge suggests, but of the universe. All Jake wants to do, at first, is to repair his comfortable little spaceship and get back to pussycat heaven, but then he falls in love.The complications begin amusingly enough, but tend to become tiresome and predictable well before the movie is over. Even so, "The Cat From Outer Space," is likely to keep the under-14's amused, at least if supplemented by plenty of popcorn.The human players, led by Ken Berry, as a scientist who befriends Jake; Sandy Duncan as his colleague, friend and the owner of the feline femme fatale; McLean Stevenson, as a scientist who drinks beer and gambles, which are relatively serious failings in a Disney film, and Harry Morgan as a short-tempered general, all perform creditably.Jake, a 15-month-old Abyssinian making his screen debut, gets the best of it in front of the camera, however. He should hire out between films as a watch cat. No one could steal a scene from him, at any rate.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen and the British pound in late New York foreignexchange trading yesterday, according to The Associated Press. It closed mixed against other major currencies.

description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium. River Avenue and 161st Street, the BronX, P.M.

title: JERSEYMADE FILIIIS URGED BY KINGSLEY
description: NEWARK, June 29Sidney Kingsley, the Pultizer Prizewinning dramatist who heads the state's Motion Picture and Television Development Commission, urged an effort today to attract the film industry back to New Jersey.

description: The following table, provided by the New York State Department of Taxa tion and Finance, shows how the new tax tables that go into effect tomorrow will effect the taxes paid by persons at various income levels. The figures are calculated for a married taxpayer with two children.

title: LEBANESE LEADERS MEET OVER CHRISTIAN VIOLENCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29Lebanon's President, Elias Sarkis, held emergency Meetings with Cabinet ministers and security chiefs today as a result of the raids in the eastern part or the country yesterday by unidentified gunmen who killed 36 rightwing Christian militants.

title: Court Bars Antitrust Defense
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Supreme Court ruled today that businessmen who trade price information are not exempt from antitrust laws merely because they maintain they need the information in order to match competitors discounts to favored customers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article Tuesday about an exhibition of photographs by Lewis Carroll at the Rosenbach Foundation Museum in Philadelphia, the hours when the museum is open were incorrectly given. The museum is open Mondays through Fridays from 2 P.M. to 5 P.M. through July. It will be closed in August.

description: Aron Yagoda is a gentleman and a scholar and an exceptional judge of horseflesh. He is the author of Aron Picks, a sheet of selections issued irregularly and distributed free to a selected clientele of horseplayers.

description: JERUSALEM, June 29Two persons were killed and at least thirtyfive injured today when a bomb believed to have been hidden in a crate of tomatoes exploded in the central market here.

title: Untied Press International

Mr. Keldysh died last Saturday. Leading pallbearers are President Leonid I. Brezhnev and Anatoly P. Aleksandrov, in light suit, head of academy. Behind them are Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, left, and Mikhail A. Suslov, Politburo member.

title: Samuel DiFalco, Surrogate, Dies; Power in New York City Politics
description: S. Samuel DiFalco, a longtime Manhatl'an Surrogate, died Wednesday night, of a heart attack while. dining with friends at the Columbus Club, in Manhattan. He wes 71 years old.

title: More Than the Market in Common
description: In all our enterprises Europe and America must work together. Our partnership is now one of the permanent facts of history. We are interlocked economically, through our armed forces, in our cultures. Changes in America are soon reproduced in Europe. Changes in Europe feed back into America. We are wedded to democratic values and we have a joint responsibility to uphold them. So Europe and America should work together. We shall have the chance to do so next month when the leaders of seven powerful industrial democracies, six from Europe and North America, together with Japan, will meet to seek agreement on an international program of concerted action to overcome our shared problems.

title: Senate Backs a Proposal Aimed at Ending Dispute With Canada on Fishing
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate gave final approval today to a bill aimed at ending the threeweekold fishing war between the United States and Canada.

title: Dangerous Dogs in the City
description: Last year the Association for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals picked up about 100,000 stray dogs and cats on New York City streets, found old or new owners for about 10,000 of them and painlessly destroyed the rest. A private, voluntary agency, the A.S.P.C.A. runs a veterinary hospital, animal shelters and spayingananeutering clinics. But notning it aoes is more important than its work with sick, wounded, emaciated and dangerous homeless animals.

title: TESTS ON SEWER PIPE ORDERED IN SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 29 John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, announced today that immediate tests would be performed on concrete pipe used in the Southwest Sewer District in an effort to ensure that the pipe was structurally sound. Some of the pipe is already underground.

title: High Couri Strips U.S. Officials Of Full Immunity in Damage Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court today. stripped Federal executives or the, absolute immunity from damage suits that had protected them in the paSt.

title: Ailing Whata Baron Captures the Driscoll Pace at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 29  Whata Baron, the surprising 6yearold bay with the ailing legs, gained his 10th straight victory of the year tonight in the $152,000 Alfred E. Driscoll Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, June 29 (UPI) The Cleveland City Council voted today, 32 to 1, to hold on Aug. 13 the first recall election in the city's history, at which voters will decide whether to oust 31yearold Mayor Dennis Kucinich from office.

title: DR. JAMES L. KELSO, 85; DISCOVERED ANCIENT CITY
description: PITTSBURGH, June 29Dr. James Kelso, rn archeologist and professor theology, died yesterday at Mercy Hospilal. He was R5 years old.

description: THE New York City Ballet has so many Stravinsky ballets in its repertory that, on the surface, it should be no surprise to see the 1910 Firebird included within that repertory.

description: Washington warned Moscow to reflect very carefully on the broader implications of its libel charges against two American reporters and said it was viewing the case with great concern. The Carter Administration held out the possibility that the case could affect overall relations and the ability of Soviet and American newsmen to report freely from each other's country.
