title: In Suburbs, They're Painting The Towns Red (White & Blue)
description: For example, the Lions Club in Port Jefferson begins its celebrations with an Oktoberfest at Caroline Field at P.M. tonight. In Germany, this festival is, naturally enough, held in October. But perhaps the Port Jefferson Lions.

title: Construction Contracts At Record Levels in May
description: Construction activity climbed to record levels in May as $17.8 billion in new projects were signed up, marking an 11 percent increase over the same Period last year. But several industry experts, and economists warned that the upward tide, which began after the 1975 recession, was peaking, and that hard times may be ahead.

title: GERSHON EPHROS
description: Gershon Ephros, a cantor and composer, died Wednesday at the Mount. Sinai Hosrital. His age was 88 and he lived at 9815 Horace Harding Boulevard, Rego Park, Queens.

title: An Arts Marathon Comes to Westbeth
description: If you drop in this weekend at WestBeth, the housing comp cx for artists on the western edge of Greenwich Village, you may observe, depending upon the hour: a young man pursuing another with a meat hook; a poetry reading; a game of hockey played sitting down; a woru premiere or a play Dy James Purdy, the novelist; dance; rock, or improvisational comedy.

title: Carter's 17Month Rating in Poll Is Below That of 5 Predecessors
description: The American public's approval of President Carter has fallen, perhaps because of doubts about his foreign policy leadership, to 38 percent, a lower standing than any of the last five Presidents held after their first 17 months in office, according to the latest national poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Grand Union Makes Bid for Colonial
description: The Britishowned Grand Union Company said yesterday that it had offered to pay $30 a share, or nearly $114 million in cash, for Colonial Stores. operator of 370 supermarkets in tne Southeast. If consummated, the merger would create the nation's eighthlargest food chain. Grand Union now ranks as 11th while Colonial is 15th.

title: Chemist Testifies to Finding Curare in Body Tissues
description: HACKENSACK, June 29Over strenuous objections from the defense, a chemist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that there was reasonable scientific certainty that curare was in tissues from the exhumed body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims, and that there was a possibility the drug was in two other bodies.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I noted with interest the June 19 Editorial Notebook article by Hugh B. Price, Let the Punishment Fit the Criminal. Mr. Price's comments on juvenile corrections, though less extreme than much of the political rhetoric bandied about in New York these days, are misinformed.

title: Dance: Romantic Journey a la Graham
description: WHEN Martha Graham choreographed O Thou Desire Who Art About to Sing last year, wits quipped that the title was longer than the dance. The dance is no laughing matter, however. This brief duet, set to music by Meyer Kupferman, reveals much about the present concerns of the Martha Graham Dance Company.

title: Celtics and Braves Agree on Switch
description: The Boston Celtics and the Buffalo Braves agreed yesterday to exchange ownerships of the National Basketball Association franchises. John Y. Brown, the coowner of of the Braves, will take over the Celtics and Iry Levin, the majority owner of the Celtics, will acquire the Braves and move them to San Diego.

title: U.S. Officials Praise Bakke Ruling; Suits on Employment Coming Up
description: The principal Federal officials involved in enforcing the nation's civil rights laws and regulations have joined in hailing the Supreme Court's decision in the Bakke case as judicial confirmation of the correctness of their enforcement efforts and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said that he had told the President that the derisions had enhanced affirmative action. Eleanor Holmes Norton, the head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said that Bakke doesn't dismantle affirmative action and it doesn't take employers off the hook.

title: Italian Electors Delaying Choice of New President
description: ROME. June 29A special assembly of electors began voting on Italy's next President today, with representatives of the major parties deliberately supporting candidates who could not win in order to gain time fur new behindthesem;s bargaining.

title: Sanudo Leads by Stroke With 67 in Western Open
description: OAK BROOK, III., June 29  Because three rainy months last winter in California made it hard going for the solarheating business and because. Cesar Sanudo was able to convince seven sponsors that at age 34 he was not over the hill, the Mexicanborn. golf professional is back on the PGA Tour.

description: A bill to prohibit the sale of no deposit, no return bottles and cans in New York City was backed by one mayoral agency and opposed by another at an allday hearing on the bill before. the City Council's consumer affairs committee. The Mayor said he opposed the bill.

description: Seninho of Portugal, acquired by the Cosmos for $500,000 earlier this week, is the first one to say that things did not go well in his first game with the Cosmos on Wednesday night.

The mission thus represented a welcome affirmation of commonsense policy toward Africa and of Secretary of State Vance's lowkey approach to Soviet and Cuban adventurism.

Lillian Nassau the 57th Street dealer, purchased that lamp because of its rarity, she said.

Bakke case, but they will have to be a lot more careful when doing so, the Justice Department's top civil rights official said today.

But Erich Leinsdorf, at 66 years of age an untested tyro in the Japanese concert hall, has won them over.

title: Associ a led Press
description: PLEADS NOT GUILTY: Joan Little arriving at Superior Court in Raleigh, N.C., yesterday for arraignment on escape charges. Miss Little. escaped from a Beaufort County jail in 1975, gaining national attention when she was acquitted of killing the jailer, who, she said, had sexually assaulted her. Miss Little escaped last October from the Correctional Center for Women, where she was serving sentence for breaking and entering, and was recaptured in New York. She fought up to the Supreme Court against her return to North Carolina, but lost the case and was extradited.

title: Jazz: Band From Cuba Is an Extra
description: THE Newport Jazz Festival program at Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening was called Three Pianos and Two Guitars. All five were there  Mary Lou Williams. Bill Evans and McCoy Tyner on pianos, Larry Coryell and Phillip Catharine on guitars. But by the end of the evening, they had almost been forgotten in the wake of an unannounced added attraction  Irakere, an 11piece group from Cuba that had just been brought to New York by Columbia Records.

title: Newport: Sea, Spa and 52d St.
description: The Newport Jazz Festival will go outdoors for much of the final weekend of its 25th season, today through Sunday. The festival will be sailing up the Hudson River tomorrow, strolling along 52d Street, which used to be known as Swing Alley on Sunday, and stretching out in (hopefully) the sun at Saratoga Springs where continuous noon to midnight sessions will be held tomorrow and Sunday at the Saratoga performing Arts Center. There will also be the usual indoor concerts atCarnegie Hall, Avery Fisher Hall and New York University's Loeb Student Center today and tomorrow.

title: Lucie Arnaz, the Jones Beach Annie, Gets a Kick Out of Getting Her Gun
description: Lucie Arnaz said she was happy. I've thought about this show a long time and knew it would happen one day, she declared with confidence, in a deem sliehtiv raspy voice.

title: TAX RELIEF BECOMES ISSUE IN ILLINOIS RACE
description: SPRINGFIELD III., June 29 In what has evolved as a major issue in the gubernatorial campaign in Illinois, the General Assembly has sent to Gov. James R. Thompson a sweeping measure on property tax relief that has been endorsed by his opponent.

title: 3 Boys Seized After Setting Fire To 6Family Coney Island Building
description: The police arrested three boys yesterday and charged them with juvenile delinquency after they allegedly set fire to fully occupied sixfamily building in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the nolice said.

title: National Poll Indicates Less Support for Aid
description: Federal aid to New. York City, approved yesterday by the Senate, had much easier time in Congress this year than it did in 1975, but public support for it across the country appears to be weaker.

title: Stage: A Hop That Fails to jump
description: IT probably sounds unfair to say that The Coolest Cat in Town, which was first presented a while back in a Brooklyn high school, belongs there. The truth is, it does. That's not necessarily a devastatine juagment. some things that work on a total level are not designed for export. What looks good in Flatbush doesn't have the same luster on 55th Street, where the new musical opened a week ago at the City Center Little Theater.

title: A POLE AND THREE RUSSIANS WORKING AS TEAM IN SPACE
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (AP)A Pole and three Russians orbited the earth performing experiments in the same space laboratory today after linking up with precision and harmony, Tess, the Soviet press i agency, said.

title: Guilty Pleas Offered in Option Case
description: A commodities trading company and its president pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to charges that they had conducted a fraudulent effort to obtain millions of dollars in the sale of commodity options to thousands of customers throughout the country.

title: Bob Crane, Hogan's Heroes Star, Found Slain at Home in Arizona
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., June 29 (AP)Rob Crane, the star of television's Hogan's Heroes, was found beaten to death in his apartment today.

title: Ichinohe Dancers on Riverside Bill.
description: Two dance programs will be offered this weekend at the Theater of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 120th Street, as part of the Riverside Dance Festival.

title: Wimbledon Weather Leaves 29,414 Out in the Rain
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 Stacey Grindle, Linda James, Catherine Horton and other teenage classmates from the Prendergast School in. nearby Catford had looked forward to an afternoon at Wimbledon today. A chance to dress up, eat sweets and see all the people.

title: Stones Is Among 4 Suspended by A.A.U.
description: INDIANAPOLIS June 29 (AP) Dwight Stones and three other members of the United States Olympic track team have been suspended from competition for accepting prize money, the Amateur Athletic Union announced today.

title: Pirates Top Mets on Hit By Stennett
description: PITTSBURGH, June 29  For twothirds of tonight's game against the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Mets were going meekly for the cycle: weak hitting, weak pitching and weak fielding.

title: !Activist South African Doctor Banished but Undaunted
description: LENYENYE, Sauth Africa, June 25Fourteen months ago, a black physician was banished from the southernmost part of the country to this northern village and ordered to remain here at least five !years.

title: Traces of the Occult on a Farm Pose Mystery for Arkansas Town
description: BENTONVILLE, Ark., June 27Steve Ferguson was hauling rocks off old Doc Compton's farm on the outskirts of town when he spotted what looked like some kind of altar, native fieldstones piled one upon the other, peeking through the briar and bramble amid the hickory and sycamore trees.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: DORIC (Home), Left Bermuda June 29; due 8. A.M. V.r. 55th Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article Tuesday about an exhibition of photographs by Lewis Carroll at the Rosenbach Foundation Museum in Philadelphia, the hours when the museum is open were incorrectly given. The museum is open Mondays through Fridays from 2 P.M. to 5 P.M. through July. It will be closed in August.

title: Hot Line Set Up on Boarding Homes
description: TRENTON, June 2The Commissioner of Human Services, Ann Klein, announced today a tollfree telephone hot line for former mental patients or their relatives to use to report abuses at boarding homes, and she promised speedy action on complaints. The number is 8007929773.

title: Books: U.S Propaganda in World War II
description: IN this brief and incisive study of American propaganda in World War II, Allan M. Winkler, assistant professor of history at Yale, demonstrates that the United States smoke of its war aims to the world and to its citizens with a forked tongue. On the one hand, according to Professor Winkler, early leaders of the Office of War Information emphasized the democratic purposes of the conflict, which included the Four Freedoms and the Atlantic Charter. On the other hand, the author notes, the State, War and Navy Departments were willing to compromise those aims in the interests of a quick end to the struggle.

title: 56 Opponents of Nuclear Plant Arrested After Capital TieIn
description: WASHINGTON, Jung 29 (UPI)Fifty;, six opponents of the nuclear power plant in Seabrook, N.H., staged a diein today, screaming in mock horror and collapsing in a heap to simulate the possible carnage of a nuclear power accident.

title: Issue and Debate A Flurry of Legislation. as Congress Ponders Curb on Searches of News Organizations
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Supreme Court's decision of May 31 giving the law enforcement authorities the right to search the files of news organizations as well as others has precipitated a flurry of protective legislation in Congress.

title: Playing the Chinese Card
description: Ever since Henry Kissinger's secret flight to Peking in 1971, American Presidents have held in their diplomatic hands what has come to be called he Chinese card. That is the possibility of exploiting the deepseated SinoSoviet hostility by building up China as counterweight. And whenever SovietAmerican relations turn sour, Presidents are tempted to play it. It is temptation that they are wise to resist.

title: Ziff Raises Offer For Rust Craft
description: The Ziff Corporation, owner of the ZiffDavis Publishing Company, said it had increased its offer to buy Rust Craft Greeting Cards  a company with six television and six radio stations  to $30 a share, or about $79 million.

title: Studio 54, Under. City Pressure, To Refund Price of Memberships
description: Studio 54, the discotheque at 254 West 54th Street, has signed an agreement with New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs requiring it to refund the full cost of membership to anyone whb can prove he or she ever bought a membership card.

title: In the Harbor
description: NEW YORK started its municipal life at the water's edge 350 years ago and it is to the edge of the waters that New Yorkers will return starting tomorrow in celebration of the city's newest tradition (three years old), a July 4th marine spectacle known this year as Harbor Festival 1978.

title: STATE DEPT, OPPOSES SENATE MOVE ON CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The State Department said today that a Senate resolution calling for a cutoff of all United States relations with Cuba, which passed decisively yesterday, would damage important U.S. interests.

title: Vietnam Joins Comecon
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 29 Vietnam today became the 10th member of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance  a reaffirmation of its integration into the Soviet sphere of economic and political influence. The proposal to admit. Vietnam was ratitien unanimously at the Comecon annual meeting here this week. Most diplomats believe that Laos will soon become a member also, since its economy is closely tied to that of Vietnam.

title: Notes on People
description: It was a mournful day for Jorge Ortiz Patin, the Bolivian tin tycoon, as he sat sadly watching his extensive collection of primitive art being sold at auction for recordbreaking prices to help recoup the $2 million ransom paid to save his daughter's life. There were times. during the proceedings vesterday at Sotheby's in London, that Mr Ortiz seemed overwrought and about to make bids himself, only to be re strained by his wife. Occasionally, he shouted to handlers to hold some of the precious African. and Pacific art objects the right way, up. If there was any consolation at all for Mr. Ortiz, it came in the prices his treasures fetched. Merton Simpson, a New York dealer, paid the highest price in the first session of auction, $324,000 for a wooden face mask from Pentecost Island in the New Hebrides: Anonymous bidders paid $270,000 for a leopardshaped Benin bronze from West Africa, rated by Mr. Ortiz the finest of its kind, and $216,000 for a bronze froM Niger. It appeared that the auction.will. bring more than $2 million, a record in.its category. Mr. Ortiz paid the ransom last October to obtain the release of his 5yearold daughter, who was kidnapped on her way to school in Geneva.

title: Three Juilliard Pianists Among Moscow Finalists
description: Three pianists trained at the RillHard School are among the 12 finalists in the piano division of the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. They are Diana Kacso of Brazil, Andre Laplante of Canada and Gail Martin, a native of Houston who now lives in New York. Five of the finalists are from the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Air Force Pilots Die in Crash
description: SARASOTA, Fla., June 29 (AP)Two Air Force captains were killed today when their F4 Phantom jet crashed in the Gulf of Mexico after they sent a distress call saying they were in trouble and going down. The men were identified as Steven P. Church and Larry D. Showalter, both 33 years old. They were based at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa and lived in suburban Brandon.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on disarmament.

title: SENATE VOTES, 5327, TO PROVIDE LOAN GUARANTEES TO NEW YORK; EFFORTS TO CUT AID DEFEATED
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Senate voted 53 to 27 today to provide New York City with $1.5 billion in longterm Federal loan guarantees, which the city had said were essential to its long effort to stave off bankruptcy.

title: C.I.A. Expects an Increase in Soviet Military Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Soviet Union's military spending in the first years of the next decade is expected by the Central Intelligence Agency to increase by 4 to 5 percent annually, continuing the present trend.

title: Schools Seek Right Mix
description: The Supreme Court's decision in the case of Allan P. Bakke has pointed up the importance of categories of all kinds, from minorities to quarterbacks, in the admissions process at selective colleges and universities.

title: Duke Power to Sell $40 Million in Stock
description: The Duke Power Company announced in Charlotte, N.C., that it planned to sell $40 million in stock this summer to help finance its constructiny, program and buy nuclear fuel The preferred stock, with a par value of $100 a share, is scheduled for public offering on Aug. 8 and will be sold through competitive bidding to a group of underwriters for sale to the public.

title: Sharks Arrive Off Jersey
description: AREA A  We've got a great season going this year, said Ralph Storck at Captain Andy's Marina off Margate, N.J., yesterday.

title: Those MOSCOW Trials
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  By personal preference, and some might add by popular demand, this will be the last column in this space for a couple of months, but before vanishing, herewith a few observations on the Soviet Union's trial of two United States newspaper reporters in Moscow.

title: The Impact Is Discussed on U. of California Campuses
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29University of California administrators. faculty members and attorneys began meeting around the state today to discuss the impact of the ruling by the Supreme Court against the minority quota program at the medical school at Davis.

title: At the Movies
description: IT'S not likely to be remembered as a great moment in cinema, probably not even as a great moment in Firepower, but Sophia Loren was in the shot, and so a crowd collected behind the barriers on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal one evening last week in hopes of catching a glirhpse of an actress who has become a movie icon but is not yet a museum piece.

title: CAREY, IN SHIFT, BACKS TRIAL IN ADULT COURT FOR SOME JUVENILES
description: ROCHESTER, June 29In an abrupt shift, Governor Carey said today that, under certain circumstances, he would support giving prosecutors the discretion to try juveniles in adult courts if the Legislature approved the money he had requested for improvements in the justice system.

title: Publishing: A Happy Novelist
description: I DON'T care whether I ever write another play as long as live, a 39yearold New Yorkborn writer named Michael Blankfort declared in the columns of this newspaper in 1947.

title: A Former Aide to Nixon Is Now Hoping to Unseat Senator Brooke as a Democrat
description: BOSTON, June 29 Howard Phillips is a Democrat who lives in Boston and is running for the United States Senate.

title: Bill Gains to Help Airlines Meet Costs of Noise Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Senate Commerce Committee today passed, 13 to 0, a measure to help airlines with the cost of meeting Federal noise standards that become effective in 1983.The bill is thought by the industry to solve the problem of retrofitting its twoengine and threeengine aircraft that exceed planned Federal noise limits.

title: The New York Times/William E. sauro
description: SPLASH! Their timing was a little of but the crew was enthusiastic aboard the lifeboat rowed by members of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York. Here they showed winning form in a race in event to publicize the Harbor Festival 1978 celebrations to begin Saturday and end July 4.

title: Hinault Is Primed for Tour de France
description: LEIDEN, The Netherlands, June 29  Carefully prepared and protected, Bernard Hinault set off today in an attempt to become France's next international sports star., He has 25 days to do the iob.

title: ENATE VOTES, 5327, TO PROVIDE LOAN GUARANTEES TO NEW YORK; EFFORTS TO CUT AID DEFEATED
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Senate voted 53 to 27 today to provide New. York City with $1.5 billion in longterm Federal loan guarantees, which the city had said were essential to its long effort to stave off bankruptcy.

title: Kinky Friedman Singing At the Lone Star Cafe
description: Kinky Friedman, the singerguitarist from Texas, whose Jewish upbringing often provides the material for his satiric music, will appear Sunday and Monday at the Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue and 13th Street.

title: Goodyear Producing New Line of Resins
description: Following a multimilliondollar expansion, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has begun trial production of a new line of specialty vinyl plastic resins at its plant in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: J. & L. Plans to Lift Steel Prices 3%
description: PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP)  The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today that it would join other steelmakers in a 3 percent price increase for most steel mill products effective July 30.

title: ALBANY GRANTS 12% RISE IN COMPENSATION RATES
description: The New York State Insurance Depart. ment announced agreement yesterday on a 12.7 percent increaseabcut S100 mil. lionin workmen's compensation insurance rates for employers, effective tomorrow.

title: NEW CLUE TO QUASARS IS REPORTED ON COAST
description: Four astronomers at the University of California have discovered a new way of estimating the real brightness of the mysterious objects called quasars, and their finding supports the view that the universe wilt eventually collapse upon itself.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alcan Aluminum Corporation, Cleveland, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., has named John B. Haertlein president of the Alcan Sheet and Plate division, replacing William K. Hooper, who will continue on a medical leave of absence. Patrick C. Holden will succeed Mr. Haertlein as president of the Alcan Ingot and Powders division, while Howard B. Major. J r. will succeed Mr. Holden as president of the Alcan Services division.

title: Yankees Share Blame For Lost Wednesday
description: The Ainerican League office, the American Broadcasting Companies and Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers all shared in the creation of the trip to Milwaukee the Yankees now regret having made, but the Yankee players themselves have to accept their share because they had the power to avoid the staggering 24hour journey but chose not to.

title: South Africans Rescind a Ban On Black Church Weekly Paper
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 29 (Reuters)South African authorities lifted a ban on the black church weekly The Voice today, the newsnaoer's manager said.

title: 2 REPORTERS GUILTY, SOVIET PRESS SAYS
description: MOSCOW, June 29The Communist Party daily, Pravda, and 10 other Moscow papers printed an article today declaring that two American correspondents were guilty of libel. The article appeared five days before a scheduled court hearing in an unusual action brought by the Soviet authorities.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CALGARY, Alberta, June 29 (AP) The Alberta Gas Trunk Line Company, a freespender in recent stock market purchases of Husky. Oil Ltd., does not plan to buy a controlling Interest in Canada's largest producer of heavy crude oil, the Alberta Gas president, Robert Blair. said today.

title: Higher Tape Prices
description: The Wabash Tape Corporation will raise prices on computer tape an average of 6 percent, effective Aug. 1. Higher materials costs and demands for quality tape, requiring stringent manufacturing controls, necessitated the increases, according to Donald M. Luby, president of Wabash Tape. The  company, in Huntley, Ill, is a wholly owned subsidiary of Wabash Inc., Palatine, Ill.

title: Coast Guard Wins on Disqualification
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 29  The rains poured down on today's opening rounds of the 139th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta. The weather prevented any good times, but 11 of the 17 American crews rowing today advanced to tomorrow's second round.

title: Art: What's Happening At the Frick Collection
description: NOTHING ever happens at the Frick Collection, some people say. It's beautiful, but it sits there year after year at 1 East 70th Street, and it's always just the same.

title: Jazz: Flora Purim Sings
description: FLORA PURIM'S Newport Jazz Festival performance Wednesday, night at Avery Fisher Hall was touched by a special poienancv. The Brazilian vocalist is facing deportation from the United States, apparently because of a drug conviction a few years back. If the deportation goes through, and it looks as though it will, Miss Purim's husband, Airto Moreira, the percussionist, will be forced to choose between his successful American musical career and returning to Brazil with his wife.

title: News Summary
description: Washington warned Moscow to refleet very carefully on the broader implications of its libel charges against two American reporters and said it was viewing the case with great concern. The Carter Administration held out the possibility that the case could affect overall relations and the ability of Soviet and American newsmen to report freely from each other's country. [Page A1, Col. 23.]

title: Eritrean Guerrillas Offer to Negotiate End to War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29Two of the three guerrilla organizations in Ethion:a's northern province of Eritrea offered today to negotiate an end to their I 7year rebellion.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 29  Four countries were fighting here tonight for two world titles.

title: Youth, 19, Is Arrested in Slaying Of Boy, 8, on the Lower East Side
description: A 19yearold youth was arrested and charged with seconddegree murder yesterday in the bludgeoning death of an Ryearold boy in an abandoned building on the Lower East Side.

title: Argentina After World Cup: Will the Team Spirit Prevail?
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 29The euphoria in the streets after the Argentine soccer team beat the Netherlands in overtime, 3 to 1, and won the World Cup has become the subject of political oratory and socioosychological analysis.

title: Debate Over Religious Pluralism Issue in Israel Divides Rabbinical Parleys in Toronto
description: TORONTO,: June 29The status of Reform and Conservative Jews in Israel continues to be a bitter issue between Orthodox and nonOrthodox rabbis in North America, judging by the dialogue at two rabbinical conventions here this week.

title: Deaths
description: AMSELLEMNuono. The Religious Zionist of America records with deer sorrow the sudden passing in Paris France of the beloved mother Jacques Ainsellem, a devoted frienr of our cause. We convey our sincer est condolences to the bereaved fa. mily.

title: Howell to Decide on Job
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 29 (AP)  Harry Howell, former general manager of the defunct Cleveland Barons of the National Hockey League, says he will decide by next week whether to coach the Minnesota North Stars. Howell said yesterday that the North Stars general manager, Lou Nanne, had offered him the lob.

title: From Bench to Legal Aid Post
description: When he was presiding over a trial, Leon B. Polsky had a habit of paring back and forth behind his chair. Why? he was asked. To avoid going to sleep, he replied. After nearly five years as a trial judge, he has just rejoined the.

title: Attack on Cambodia Denied. by Vietnam; Fighting Reported
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 29Vietnam denied today Western rdporls that its forces had invaded eastern Cambodia, while diplomats and Intelligence sources here described the reports as inaccurate and exaggerated.

title: DESAI IS SAID TO OUST LEADING MINISTERS
description: NEW DELHI, June 29Prime Minister Morirji R. Desai has reportedly asked two of his senior Cabinet ministers to resign, and the governing Janata Party appears headed for a split.

title: Events and Openings
description: NEWPORT JAZZ FESTIVAL: Alberta Hunter and Eubie Blake, N.Y.U. Loeb Center, 2; Chick Corea Orchestra, Woody Herman Orchestra, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. 7:30; Brazilian Nights, Carnegie Hall, B; Jazz Film, N.Y.U. Loeb Center, 8; Sam Rivers Quartet and Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, midnight.

title: Restaurants
description: THE word was out that things were looking up gastronomically at the Peking Park Restaurant on the corner of Park Avenue and 40th Street. Three new chefs were reported to be at work in the kitchen, one from a popular Chinatown Cantonese restaurant and the other two, Japanese, highly trained in the cuisine of north China.

title: HOUSE REBUFFS CARTER ON LEGISLATIVE VETO
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The House put President Carter on notice today that it did not intend to yield its authority to review Government regulations despite his attack on the socalled legislative veto.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29The General Assembly decided without a vote tonight to put off action on a resolution calling for an arms embargo against Israel that was jointly sponsored by 32 countries led by Iraq.

title: BILL ON NEW YORK FUNDS IN CONGRESS IS SHELVED
description: A bill in Congress that a city and labor official warned could threaten New York City's financial package was shelved yesterday. Donald D. Kummerfeld, chairman of the State Emergency Financial Control Board, said the bill had been pulled hack and would not he filed last night after a meeting in the Capital on the city's objections.

title: City Hall Ceremony: 3 Rings and Then Some
description: Maddog apprehenders and New Yorkers went out in the midday sun yesterday, turning a steaming City Hall plaza into something of a circus. In one ring were sanitationmen, who were there for an awards ceremony.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, unimpressed with yesterday's decline in the money supply and worried about increases in the Federal Reserve discount rate and the prime rates charged by commercial banks, showed declines in prices late yesterday.

title: United Press International
description: AT WEEKLY AUDIENCE in the Vatican yesterday, Pope Paul VI, seated his gestatorial chair, conferred his blessing on a child.

title: BUSINESS Digest.
description: Further increases in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and in the prime lending rate of commercial banks appeared likely following the central bank's weekly report on the nation's money supply and business borrowing. The basic money supply fell $1.9 billion the latest reporting period, while business loans at major New York banks increased $235 million. [Page D1.]

title: Black Sisters: Doctors Without Fanfare
description: KANSAS CITY, June 29While Allen P. Bakke was in the spotlight fighting for admission to the University of California, two black sisters who had been preferentially admitted to the University of Missouri Medical School here quietly benefited from affirmative action by breezing through their studies and becoming doctors with little fanfare.

title: Big Impact Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Federal agencies will be able to continue vigorous enforcement of antidiscrimination laws in the wake of the Supreme Court's landmark decision in the Allan P. Bakke case, but they will have to be a lot more careful when doing so, the Justice Department's top civil rights official said today.

title: IngersollRand Sees Peak Results
description: The IngersollRand Company, industrial machinery manufacturer, expects to report record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half, according to William L. Wearly, chairman.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: ANYONE interested in film or women's liberation, not necessarily in that order, is warned not to miss Hail the Woman on Channel 13 tomorrow at 10 P.M. It is part of a series called Lost and Found, consisting of eight films recently rediscovered in foreign archives by Eileen Bowser, filmdepartment curator at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Miller and Reuss Clash on Authority
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Federal Reserve Board chairman momentarily lost his composure today in an exchange with the House Banking Committee chairman. They were discussing the central bank's plan to pay interest on the money commercial banks have to freeze in reserve accounts.

title: Photography: From Manchu China
description: IN 1861, three years before Julia Margaret Cameron acquired her first camera and at just about the time that Matthew B. Brady began to make his photographic record of the American Civil War, a photograpner named M. Miller opened a studio in Hong Kong, announcing that he was now prepared to take photographic pictures of all kinds. Three years later;Miller sold his stock of negatives, and as Clark Worswick writes in his essay  Photography in Imperial China, he promptly disappeared from the China scene and, apparently, from the history of photography.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Soybean and corn futures showed strength in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday until two rumors, concerning deliveries on the expiring July contracts, reached the floor.

title: For Children
description: NEW YORK AQUARIUM at Coney Island with a sea lion show held at various times through the day, open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday, and from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. on Saturday, Sunday and holidays through August. Admission, children 2 to 12 years old, 75 cents; adults, 02; infants, free; the elderly, free after 2 P.M. Monday through Friday. Parking: $2 Monday through Friday, and 53 on Saturday, Sunday and holidays. Call 2664500.

title: California Employees Boo Governor Brown
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 29 (AP) Thousands of state employees,angered by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s proposed state pay freeze, booed him today wheit be spoke at their rally on the Capitol lawn.

title: The Pop Life
description: LONDON PERIODICALY, people breeze into New York, spend a couple of days and write indepth reports about the city's club scene. Such reports provoke amused scorn from this writer, since it's clear that nobody can really know. much of great import on such short notice.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. 3 Sonatas for Harpsichord, Scarlatti ; Relicts dans l'eau, Debussy; Heroic Music, Telemann; La Forza del Dcstino Overture, Verdi; Motet, Desprez.

title: Business Records
description: DOLORES SHEELEY, 91 Valley Ave., Walden, N.Y. LI. abilities, 529,750; assets, $48,900; real property valued at 537,500.

title: Market Place
description: LAST week, when shortsellers were feverishly trying to buy Resorts International shares, who should accommodate them but the family of I.G.(Jack) Davis Jr., president of the company.

title: EMPLOYERS GET DELAY ON STATE WAGE TAX
description: Lower state withholding taxes go into effect tomorrow, but many employees in New York State will not see the effect in their paychecks until late July under a ruling by the State Tax Commissioner, James H. Tully Jr.

title: Art: The Cedars Of Arthur Weyhe
description: THE drive to wall off Manhattan from its rivers proceeds, but sluggishly. There are still chinks through which earthbound citizens can glimpse the water and, on fine days, whole stretches of Brooklyn, Queens and New Jersey.

title: Foodways Accepts
description: Foodways National Inc. shareholders have approved the acquisition of that company by the H. J. Heinz Company. Heinz had offered $50 million, or $31 a share, for the stock of the producer of sugar, frozen food and bouillon cubes.

title: Business People
description: Bernard Cornfeld, the onetime financier who is currently serving time for cheating the telephone company in California on longdistance calls, has agreed to pay $2 million to 380 former employees in Geneva whether or not he is convicted of swindling them.

title: Gambling Was a Top Issue in Legislature's Spring Session
description: TRENTON, June 29Governor Byrne and Democratic leaders exchanged bows today in describing the spring session of the New Jersey Legislature as one of the most productive in recent state history.

title: A CHEMIST TESTIFIES ON CURARE IN TISSUES
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 29Over strenuous objections from the defense, a chemist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that there was reasonable scientific certainty that curare was in tissues from the exhumed body of one of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims, and that there was a possibility the drug was in two other bodies.

title: New Books
description: Dr. Bahr's AcuDiet, by Dr. Frank R. Bahr (Morrow, $6.95). Acupuncture diets.

title: Atlantic Sees Gains on Debts
description: The president of a company that paid former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew commissions for his work on contracts in Saudi Arabia has said in Baltimore that the concern has successfully rearranged our debts.

title: Economic Scene
description: WHEN economic forecasters predict a slower pace for the Ame,rican economy in the second half of the year, they invariably cite reduced consumer spending as the No. 1 reason. Most of them foresee a less ravenous public appetite for new cars, housing and other bigticket items because of continuing inflation both in those lines and for food, fuel and other necessities. Other factors cited are eroding confidence, declining buying power and rising interest rates.

title: Second Monaco Wedding Day: Happy and Festive
description: MONTE CARLO, June 29  There was some fumbling with the rings, the bride giggled and when the couple cut their sixtiered wedding cake, two captive doves fluttered in terror in their makeshift cage between the fifth and sixth layers.

title: Pennsy Makes Bid To End Bankruptcy
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company said they had asked the Federal District Court in Philadelphia to give final approval to nlan for the comoanv to emerge from its eightyear bankruptcy. The trustees said they wouid rename the company the Penn Central Corporation.

title: All's WellWith Shakespeare in the Park
description: town. At center stage were the spires of what seemed to be the cathedral of Notre Dame of Paris. Flanking it were the domes and turrets of a Florentine cityscape and a gingerbread castle worthy of the Brothers Grimm.

title: Broadway
description: A BROADWAY MUSICAL will go into rehearsal Aug. 28 and then open, in a way, at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Oct. 10. The church is at Riverside Drive and 120th Street, and so the production will be going up, as well as off, Broadway. Alter tour weeks at tne Riverside Church, it goes out of town. Then it comes to Broadway sometime next season. This is circuitous, but more and more it is the way musicals are now being done. This is because it is expensive open in Philadelphia, say, and then bomb in Boston.

title: New Chancellor Will Insist on Top Performance
description: Frank 3. Macchiarola, who was sworn in yesterday as New York City's new School Chancellor, said he would not let inadequate funds or the shift toward black and Hispanic student population he used as excuses for poor performance by teachers and administrators.

title: Freight Traffic Up 9.2%
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on maior United States railroads for the latest week totaled an estimated 18.2 billion tonmiles, 9.2 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Heavy movements of grain and coal were major factors in the increase. Carloadings in the same week totaled 497,619 cars, 4.1 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity truck tonnage was 0.7 percent above last year.

title: Books of The Times
description: TSK; TSK, as the comic strips used to put it. In 1956, the critic Hugh Kenner observed in a study of James Joyce called Dpblin's Joyce that Sherlock Hoimes's parents it is ???,were the male and female halves of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's divided 19thcentury mind. Nearly two decades later, in 1974, the noted trivialist Samuel Rosenberg concluded in his overstimulating study Naked Is the Best Disguise that Holmes really stood for Conan Doyle's superego, whose function it was to wage war against the author's forbidden sexual fantasies. And later the same year, one Nicholas Meyer produced evidence, in the form of a hitherto undiscovered Holmes adventure called The SevenPerCent Solution, that the great detective was driven to helpless cocaineaddiction by the repressed horror of witnessing as a child the murder of one of his parents by the other.

title: David Gartner's Obligations
description: If the circumstances surrounding the appointment of David Gartner to the Commodity Futures Trading Co'mmission seem confusing, that is due mainly to the White House treatment of his case. The facts themselves are not complicated.

title: A Guide to Where The Bands Are
description: 2 P.M. N.Y.U. Loeb Student Center. Alberta Hunter and Eubie Blake in special children's program for the young of all ages. Tickets $5 ($3 for children under 12 and students with identification.)

title: General Atomic Names Agent for Arbitration
description: The heated dispute between the General Atomic Company and the United Nuclear Corporation over 27 million pounds of uranium may be headed for arbitration.

title: Hurt Pride, Misunderstandings At Heart of CareyKrupsak Split
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak accused Governor Carey of being insulting and insensitive. The Lieutenant Governer, in turn, was accused by the Governor's top aide of being emotional and angry and of using obscenities to denounce the Governor and one of his commissioners.

title: Comecon In Strained Agreement
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 29 The annual meeting of the Council on Mutual Economic Assistance, the Soviet bloc's common market, ended today with broad agreement on several basic issues but with signs of increasing strains within the group.

title: Advertising
description: YOU'VE got to hand it to those Westerners, they're great copiers.

title: Associated Press
description: TWO DIE IN JERUSALEM BLAST: Injured man, center, being led away after a bomb exploded in a market, killing two and injuring at least 35. In Beirut, Lebanon, a Palestinian group reportedly assumed responsibility.

title: Multimedia Show on L.I.
description: Films, slides and music by Tony Conrad, film maker, will be featured tonight at 8 P.M. in a free multimedia presentation at the Port Washington, L.I., Public Library, 245 Main Street, Port Washington. Information: (516) 8839400.

title: Atlantic City Is Expecting 500,000
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 29City officials said today that they expected 500,000people for the Fourth of July weekend, almost twice as many as the resort had over the Memorial Day weekend when the city's first gambling casino opened.

title: Gas Explosion Fells 35 Workers
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., June 29 (AP) A gas explosion at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant sent 35 workers to the hospital with complaints of vomiting, shortness of breath and eye and nose irritation, the authorities said. A Pacific Gas and Eleotric Company spokesman said that 68 workers at the site were welding a crane rail yesterday when pieces of hot metal hit five containers filled with ammonia hydroxide and burst into flames.

title: Schools Seek Right Mix
description: The Supreme Court's decision in the case of Allan P. Bakke has pointed up the importance of categories of all kinds, from minorities to quarterbacks, in the admissions process at selective colleges and universities.
